Neither pipeline was in operation, but both contained natural gas - which is largely composed of methane, a potent greenhouse gas that is the second biggest cause of climate change after CO2.
Sweden’s Maritime Authority issued a warning about two leaks in the Nord Stream 1 pipeline, the day after a leak on the nearby Nord Stream 2 pipeline was discovered.

site_title: ESR-Logos Reit divests 2 Jalan Kilang Barat for S$35.3m, 21.7% above valuation
summary: ESR-Logos Reit has divested its 9-storey industrial building at 2 Jalan Kilang Barat in Singapore for S$35.3 million, a 21.7% premium to its valuation of S$29 million. The sale is expected to be completed in Q4 2022 and will not impact the trust's net asset value and distribution per unit. The divestment is part of the trust's strategy to unlock value from non-core properties, allowing it to focus on growth aspirations. The sale proceeds will be used to repay borrowings and fund working capital requirements.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng
A-Reit on Aug 4 said it is acquiring the Philips Apac Center in Singapore for S$104.8 million.

Adrian Chui, chief executive officer of the Reit’s manager said: “We are pleased to expand the Reit’s footprint into Japan, our second overseas market, with the acquisition of ESR Sakura DC, a freehold asset that will ride on the strong logistics growth trends in the Greater Tokyo area.”

site_title: Amid China concerns, Biden vows to address Pacific island needs
summary: US President Joe Biden has vowed to strengthen the US partnership with Pacific island nations, addressing the "existential threat" of the climate crisis and countering China's "economic coercion" in the region. The US has pledged over $1.5 billion in aid and launched the "Partners in the Blue Pacific" initiative to coordinate with allies and partners. Leaders from 14 Pacific island states attended a 2-day summit, where they resolved to strengthen their partnership and shared a vision for the region where "democracy will flourish." The US has also agreed to provide $2.8 million for FBI training with Pacific islands.

images.alt_text: U.S. President Joe Biden attends a performance by British rocker Elton John at the White House in Washington, U.S., September 23, 2022. REUTERS/Evelyn Hockstein
U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken speaks during a working lunch at the U.S.-Pacific Island Country Summit at the State Department in Washington, DC, US, Sept 28, 2022.

site_title: Micron forecasts Q1 revenue below estimates as demand worsens
summary: Micron Technology forecasted Q1 revenue below estimates, with $4.25 billion, due to worsening demand from key markets including PCs and smartphones. The company cut its investments, including wafer fab equipment capex, to cope with the tougher market conditions. Shares fell 2.4% in extended trading. Micron's forecast follows its previous warning of a severe slowdown in the semiconductor industry, which has worsened due to global economic concerns and rising inflation.

images.alt_text: Micron said this will be the first new memory chip factory built in the United States in 20 years, and will create 2,000 Micron jobs by the end of the decade.

site_title: GIC seeks Japan property deals as yen falls and tourists return
summary: Sovereign wealth fund GIC is seeking property deals in Japan as the yen falls and tourists return, amid the country's government plan to scrap most pandemic travel restrictions on October 11. GIC is interested in hotels, resorts, and residential properties, with its recent deal to buy properties from Seibu Holdings hitting the low single-digit billions of dollars. The fund views Japan's real estate as attractive due to low financing costs and levered yields, despite the risk of yen decline against the US dollar. GIC aims to do more deals in Japan, increasing its attractiveness to the fund.

images.alt_text: Traveloka helps consumers book a range of services including airline tickets and hotels as well as spas and tourism attractions.
As part of the investment, Mayank Rawat, managing director of GIC India Direct Investment Group, will sit on Skyroot’s board.

WSP Global is raising about C$800 million in new equity - half of it coming from Singapore sovereign wealth fund GIC, the Caisse de Depot et Placement du Quebec and Canada Pension Plan Investment Board.
The deal gives GIC and Carlyle the ability to invest more than US$3 billion in Eneus Energy’s projects in the next 5 years.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday, extending falls on Wall Street. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index dropped 0.58% to 26,268.54, while the Topix index fell 0.43% to 1,860.76. The decline was attributed to higher US Treasury yields, inflation, and rising recession fears.

site_title: US: Stocks back in the red as Apple slump
summary: US stocks fell on Thursday, with the S&P 500 dropping 2.1% to its lowest close since November 2020, and the Dow Jones losing 1.5%. The decline was fueled by a downgrade of Apple by Bank of America, citing slower growth expectations, and market volatility in Britain following Prime Minister Liz Truss's tax cut policy. Investors fear a potential "contagion" in response to the policy, which contradicts central banks' efforts to counter inflation.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average has fallen 170.0 points, or 0.57 per cent, at Thursday's (Sep 29) open to 29,513.73.

site_title: Foxconn starts EV production in US with first Lordstown pickups
summary: Foxconn, a Taiwanese technology company, has started building electric vehicles (EVs) for Lordstown Motors at a former General Motors plant in Ohio. The first two Endurance pickups rolled off the line, with Lordstown expecting to deliver 50 vehicles this year. However, initial output is slow due to "part pedigree and part availability issues." Lordstown plans to raise additional capital to deliver the next 450 vehicles, with production currently slated for the first half of 2023.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Lordstown's logo is pictured on a smartphone in this illustration taken, December 4, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: South Korea August factory output shrinks more than expected, retail sales jump
summary: South Korea's factory production declined 1.8% seasonally-adjusted in August, exceeding expectations, while retail sales surged 4.3% month-over-month, the fastest gain since May 2020. The services sector saw a 1.5% rise, contrasting with the industrial output decline. The data suggests ongoing economic challenges, despite a year-over-year increase in industrial output.

site_title: Australia: Shares set for worst month in 3 on recession risks
summary: Australia's benchmark S&P/ASX 200 index is set for its worst month in three, tracking a global selloff due to recession fears, with shares down 0.5% as of 12:20 am GMT. The US Federal Reserve's hawkish stance on interest rates has investors skittish, with the central bank expected to hike rates again in October. Tech and financials were the top losers, while miners and gold stocks bucked the trend, with iron ore futures boosted by construction activity in China.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index rose as much as 2 per cent earlier in the day, before easing to finish the session 1.4 per cent higher.

site_title: Fed to kick off climate scenario analysis in 2023 with 6 large banks
summary: The US Federal Reserve announced that 6 large banks - Bank of America, Citigroup, Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase, Morgan Stanley, and Wells Fargo - will participate in a climate scenario analysis exercise in 2023. The exercise aims to gauge the level and management of climate-related risks for banks. The Fed will provide climate scenario narratives and review the findings with the firms to help them build up their ability to manage climate-related risks. The pilot exercise will not have capital or supervisory consequences and will kick off the Fed's efforts to address climate change risks in the banking sector.

site_title: HSBC to review Canary Wharf tower HQ, consider new London base
summary: HSBC to review its global headquarters in London's Canary Wharf, considering options to stay and renovate its current 45-floor tower or relocate to a new location. The review, which will include the option to reduce space occupancy, aims to lower costs and save energy. Despite calls to shift its headquarters to Asia, HSBC has committed to keeping its global headquarters in London. The review is set to begin ahead of the lease expiring in early 2027.

images.alt_text: Amanda Murphy, HSBC's Head of Commercial Banking for South and Southeast Asia, sees strong double-digit growth in the region across all segments and countries.

site_title: Can the crypto industry become as safe as banking?
summary: Singapore's cryptocurrency industry is still developing, with 62% of respondents saying "clarity around government regulation" would increase their trust. In contrast, 49% would not recommend cryptocurrency to their family and friends, citing concerns over security and scams. To build confidence, regulators must establish a robust framework, assess and accredit organizations that comply with stringent standards, and protect investors. The industry must also develop a communication framework that governs responsible advertising, allowing regulated players to share educational content and steer consumers away from danger. With Singapore's positive sentiments towards cryptocurrency and commitment to clear regulatory oversight, the city-state can become a hub for a safer and well-regulated crypto industry.

images.alt_text: As part of industry engagement, emphasis must be placed on DLT and tokenisation education, its distinction from cryptocurrencies and awareness to build trust in these technologies, gain stakeholder acceptance and drive adoption.
Powell says the Fed is still deliberating on the idea of a digital currency and doesn’t expect to decide on the issue for some time.
Seba Bank's headquarters in Zug, Switzerland
Despite the advantages of digitisation and decentralisation, the risks associated with cryptocurrency are increasingly obvious to even the most casual of observers.

site_title: Truss says UK tax cuts are the ‘right plan’ amid market rout
summary: UK Prime Minister Liz Truss defended her government's tax cuts, blaming global economic pressures for the market rout. The pound and UK government bonds fell after Chancellor Kwasi Kwarteng announced the largest package of unfunded tax cuts in half a century. Truss stated that the government did the "right thing" and that higher taxes would lead to recession. The Bank of England intervened to stabilize the gilt market, and the International Monetary Fund urged Truss to reconsider her plans. The UK is heading towards recession, with the housing market threatened.

images.alt_text: London’s Canary Wharf, home to some of the world’s biggest banks, has its origins in a budget delivered under Margaret Thatcher.

site_title: How super apps are fuelling Asia’s US$308 billion mobility share
summary: Asia's mobility share is expected to reach $308 billion by 2030, driven by super apps and digital services. This represents a larger market share than North America and Europe combined. Ride-hailing, taxi, and car-as-a-service models will account for 91% of Asia's market share, with air taxis projected to generate $140 million in revenue in Singapore by 2030. The region's growing middle class, urbanization, and smartphone adoption are driving this growth, with Asia expected to dominate the mobility market share.

images.alt_text: Bhavish Aggarwal's ANI Technologies, is behind India's top ride-hailing app (above).  He now aspires to enter the electric car market with an electric car due in the summer of 2024.
Customers queue at a Shein pop-up shop in San Francisco, June 2022.
Carpooling apps such as Singapore’s Ryde allow private car owners to offer empty seats to fellow travellers.

site_title: China to relax lower limit of first home loan interest rate in some cities
summary: China's central bank has allowed local governments to decide on the interest rate limit for commercial housing loans for first home buyers by the end of 2022. Localities can choose to maintain, lower, or scrap the floor on mortgage rates, aiming to stimulate housing market growth. This move is part of China's efforts to address the country's slowing GDP growth and increasing pressure on policymakers. The decision will be implemented in phases, with no specific timeline or interest rate targets announced.

site_title: BBC announces job losses at World Service
summary: The BBC has announced plans to merge its BBC World News television and domestic UK equivalent into a single channel, resulting in nearly 400 job losses and a shift to digital platforms. The move aims to save £28.5 million as part of a £500 million cost-cutting program. The BBC World Service, which reaches 364 million people weekly, will continue to operate, but production will move out of London, with some services relocating to new hubs. The changes are driven by changing audience habits and increased operating costs.

images.alt_text: BBC to resume English-language reporting from Russia

site_title: Maersk CEO see 'modest' pick-up in trade for holiday season
summary: Maersk CEO Soren Skou expects a "modest" pick-up in trade for the holiday season, citing lower consumer demand due to the slowing global economy and Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Ocean freight volumes are forecast to be flat or lower, with freight rates remaining above pre-pandemic levels. This is despite a decrease in rates from near record highs earlier this year, following a surge in consumer demand during the pandemic. Maersk has raised its 2022 profit guidance twice due to the prolonged high freight rates.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower on growing economic downturn worries
summary: US stock indexes opened lower on Thursday, September 29, due to growing concerns of a global economic downturn. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 170.0 points, or 0.57%, to 29,513.73, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. Worries about aggressive central bank rate hikes and potential contagion from turmoil in UK markets led to a risk-averse investor sentiment.

site_title: China certifies C919 jet to compete with Airbus and Boeing
summary: China has certified its C919 narrowbody passenger jet, allowing it to compete with Airbus and Boeing in the country's aviation market. The plane, produced by state-owned manufacturer COMAC, had been widely expected to be certified after 2 aircraft flew to Beijing in September. The certification means the C919 can be delivered to its first customer, China Eastern Airlines Corp, but its impact on the global market may be limited due to Western components and US export licensing rules. The plane has 815 orders, but China's technological self-reliance ambitions and trade tensions may influence its production and market presence.

site_title: German inflation hits double digits for first time in euro era
summary: German inflation has reached double digits for the first time in the euro era, with consumer prices jumping 10.9% from a year ago in September, exceeding economists' estimates. The surge is attributed to the end of temporary government relief measures and the worsening energy crisis. The European Central Bank is expected to raise interest rates to combat inflation, with some economists predicting a 9.7% median estimate for the eurozone. The German government has announced a plan to cap petrol prices, borrowing 150 billion euros to mitigate inflation.

images.alt_text: With year-on-year inflation running at 7.9 per cent in August, Berlin has been under pressure to provide further aid for consumers and businesses hit by a surge in energy prices.

site_title: Housing loan limits – including for HDB loans – tightened in fresh measures to cool property market
summary: The Singapore government has introduced fresh measures to cool the property market, including tightening housing loan limits, including for HDB loans. The Total Debt Servicing Ratio and Mortgage Servicing Ratio limits will be hardened, and the Loan-to-Value limit for HDB housing loans will be cut from 85% to 80%. A 15-month wait-out period will be introduced for private property owners and former private property owners to buy a non-subsidised HDB resale flat. The new measures aim to moderate demand and ensure that resale flats remain affordable for flat buyers, especially first-timers.

images.alt_text: Michelle Low
Borrowers who take up the POSB HDB home loan package and have a DBS multiplier and a POSB Save-As-You-Earn account can earn higher interest on their savings.
While Lentor Modern was the latest suburban condo to see strong take up at its launch, developers appear to be cautious in land bidding.
Developers sold a total of 437 units excluding executive condominiums (ECs), 47.6 per cent lower than the 834 units sold in July 2022.
OrangeTee & Tie's Christine Sun thinks overall condo and HDB rental prices may either continue rising or remain at current levels in the coming months.

site_title: China forex regulator warns against illegal money outflows
summary: China's foreign exchange regulator, the State Administration of Foreign Exchange (Safe), has named and shamed 10 banks, including top banks, for assisting illegal capital outflows through fake forex transactions between 2017 and 2020. The regulator vowed to strengthen supervision and crack down on such behaviors, aiming to stabilize the sliding yuan. The move is part of efforts to safeguard national economic and financial security, with Safe to closely monitor cross-border money flows and step up the fight against fraudulent trade.

images.alt_text: Chinese 100 yuan banknotes are seen in a counting machine while a clerk counts them at a branch of a commercial bank in Beijing, China, March 30, 2016. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon/File Photo
Localities will be allowed to decide on whether to maintain, lower or scrap the floor on mortgage rates for first home buyers  by the end of 2022.

State banks were told to ask their offshore branches, including those based in Hong Kong, New York and London, to review their holdings of the offshore yuan and ensure US dollar reserves are ready to be deployed

site_title: Europe: Shares tumble on recession angst, grim German inflation data
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index fell 1.7% on Thursday, September 29, as investors fretted about a global economic downturn amid concerns over soaring prices and aggressive central bank moves. Grim inflation data from Germany and weaker-than-expected profits from retailers such as H&M and Next contributed to the decline. The slump in the Stoxx 600 index marked a reversal from the previous day's gains, as relief from the Bank of England's bond buy-back plan dissipated. The downturn was widespread, with nearly all Stoxx sectors falling.

images.alt_text: London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index sank 1.2 per cent to 6,918.36 points compared with Wednesday’s close, also after the pound briefly shed 1 per cent in value.

site_title: Volkswagen battery IPO could be next, says CFO
summary: Volkswagen is considering a possible initial public offering (IPO) of its battery cell business, PowerCo, after setting aside 20 billion euros for investment. CFO Arno Antlitz said the company will first form partnerships and then consider an IPO, citing financial flexibility from the recent listing of Porsche. This move comes as Volkswagen expands its battery production and research, with plans to source cathode materials and reduce waiting times for electric vehicles amid ongoing microchip shortages.

site_title: Nord Stream underwater gas pipes are leaking in 4 places
summary: The Nord Stream underwater gas pipes are leaking in four places, with two leaks in Sweden's exclusive economic zone and two in Denmark, according to the Swedish Coast Guard. Gas has been bubbling up from the pipelines since earlier this week, and officials suspect the leaks may be deliberate sabotage. Several governments, including Finland and Poland, have pointed the finger at Russia, which is waging war in Ukraine and has curbed gas flows to Europe. The incident has prompted increased security measures on energy infrastructure across Europe.

images.alt_text: This handout photo taken on September 28, 2022 from an aircraft of the Swedish Coast Guard (Kustbevakningen) shows the release of gas emanating from a leak on the Nord Stream 1 gas pipeline, in the Swedish economic zone in the Baltic Sea. - A fourth leak has been detected in undersea gas pipelines linking Russia to Europe, the Swedish Coast Guard said on September 29, 2022, after explosions were reported earlier this week in suspected sabotage. Neither pipeline was in operation, but both contained natural gas - which is largely composed of methane, a potent greenhouse gas that is the second biggest cause of climate change after CO2.

site_title: China’s state banks told to stock up for yuan intervention: sources
summary: China's central bank has instructed major state-owned banks to stock up on US dollars to sell in offshore markets, aiming to stem the yuan's decline and put a floor under the currency. The move follows recent efforts by the People's Bank of China to defend the weakening yuan, which has lost over 11% to the US dollar this year. State banks are scrambling to procure more US dollars, and the intervention plan involves using their US dollar reserves primarily.

images.alt_text: Several Chinese city commercial banks and rural commercial lenders have cut their rates on a range of deposits this week.
The People’s Bank of China also said it will focus on stabilising employment and prices, and will seek ways to help reduce corporate financing and consumer credit costs.

site_title: US economy ends 2021 on firmer footing; weekly jobless claims fall
summary: The US economy ended 2021 on a firmer footing than initially thought, with real GDP growth revised up to 5.9% from 7.3%, and inflation-adjusted GDP 1% higher than previously reported. Consumer spending on big-ticket items and services bolstered the recovery from the pandemic. Meanwhile, weekly jobless claims fell to 193,000, with the number of Americans receiving benefits after an initial week of aid dropping 29,000 to 1.347 million. The strong labour market is helping to keep the economy afloat, despite rising interest rates and slowing demand.

images.alt_text: Jobless claims have generally been dropping as employers try to fill millions of open positions while retaining the workers they already have.

site_title: SoftBank cuts about 150 staff globally: source
summary: SoftBank Group is cutting around 150 staff globally, affecting 30% of employees in its Vision Fund unit and SoftBank Group International. The cuts primarily impact investment teams and back-office staff in departments such as finance and legal. The move comes after the Vision Fund unit recorded a record $50 billion loss in the 6 months through June, with CEO Masayoshi Son pledging to cut costs. The cuts are part of Son's efforts to reduce expenses following a series of huge losses on his tech bets.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: SoftBank Corp's logo is pictured at a news conference in Tokyo, Japan, February 4, 2021. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon/File Photo

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Australian government ordered Optus, a Singapore-based telecoms giant, to pay the cost of replacing millions of passports and driver's licenses stolen in a major data breach. Singapore moved up to seventh in the World Intellectual Property Organisation's Global Innovation Index. The Urban Redevelopment Authority and Ministry of Health launched a site for a private assisted living development in Singapore. Taiwan ended its mandatory Covid-19 quarantine for arrivals starting October 13, allowing tourists to return.

site_title: Sterling volatile as PM defends plan, euro drops with inflation data in focus
summary: The British pound fell 0.19% to $1.0866, while the euro dropped 0.2% to $0.9720, amidst concerns over the UK's tax-cutting budget and inflation data. The Bank of England's emergency bond-buying plan failed to stabilize the gilt market, and investors await German inflation figures for further guidance on the European Central Bank's rate hike path. Analysts expect the pound to remain volatile, with some warning that the BOE's intervention only addressed symptoms, not the cause of the economic woes.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: British Pound Sterling banknotes are stacked in piles at the Money Service Austria company's headquarters in Vienna, Austria, November 16, 2017. REUTERS/Leonhard Foeger/File Photo/File Photo

State banks were told to ask their offshore branches, including those based in Hong Kong, New York and London, to review their holdings of the offshore yuan and ensure US dollar reserves are ready to be deployed

site_title: The closest thing to Formula 1 for the road
summary: Boutique sports carmaker BAC has unveiled the Mono R, a road-legal, high-performance car inspired by Formula 1. Weighing just 555 kg, the Mono R boasts a 2.5-litre engine producing 346 horsepower, accelerating from 0-100 km/h in 2.5 seconds. The Mono R is limited to 40 pieces and starts at around S$300,000, with a top-of-the-line model costing S$550,000. Although not available in Singapore, the Mono R is legal to drive in many other countries, including Malaysia, where NB Auto, its Singapore dealer, is also present.

images.alt_text: Flavio Manzoni, Chief Design Officer of Ferrari, with the new Purosangue.
Built from carbon fibre to make it light yet strong, the Daytona SP3 is a modern interpretation of Ferrari’s 330 series of impossibly sensual racing cars.
A Lamborghini on display at the Motor Valley Fest in Modena, Italy in May 2022. The Italian luxury sports car manufacturer had a record year for sales in 2021.
The Flying Spur is not merely big but handsome with it, with such a rakishly angled front windscreen, fetchingly broad rear flanks and impressively taut lines all over.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 4.39 points to 1,397.50. Volume reached 2.277 billion lots worth RM1.861 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 499 to 343.

site_title: Canadian pension fund CDPQ eyes infrastructure opportunities as it looks to invest C$15b in Apac over 5 years
summary: Canadian pension fund Caisse de dépôt et placement du Québec (CDPQ) plans to invest C$15 billion in Asia-Pacific over the next 5 years, expanding its existing C$56 billion portfolio in the region. The fund's CEO, Charles Emond, attributes the interest to economic and population growth, innovation, and urbanization in the Asia-Pacific. Infrastructure, real estate, and private credit assets are expected to form a significant part of the investments, with CDPQ also considering opportunities in public and private equities. The fund's investments will shift its geographical portfolio distribution, with Asia-Pacific becoming a larger share.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Indonesia's wealth fund signs 39t rupiah toll road investment
Technology is 1 of 4 sectors the Caisse focuses on in private equity.

site_title: ISDN posts 9% fall in H1 net profit to S$11.1 million
summary: ISDN Holdings reported a 9.1% decrease in H1 net profit to S$11.1 million, down from S$12.2 million in the year-ago period. Revenue fell 12.2% to S$190.7 million, while cost of sales dropped 14.1%. The company attributed the decline to business disruptions due to Covid-19 lockdowns in China. Despite this, ISDN sees long-term demand for industrial automation in China and Southeast Asia, driven by labour wage pressure and manufacturing capabilities.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng
ISDN Holdings' president Teo Cher Koon noted in the regulatory filing that the issue price of srip dividend was below the average market price.
ISDN H2 net profit rises to S$13.3m, proposes S$0.0145 final dividend

site_title: China’s smaller banks cut deposit rates to ease margin pressure
summary: China's smaller banks have cut deposit interest rates in a bid to ease margin pressure, following larger peers in the first broad-based move since 2015. The cuts, which include 5 basis points on 3-month deposits, aim to boost profit margins and support economic growth. Despite the central bank's recent lending rate cuts, credit demand remains weak, and banks face challenges in controlling costs. Analysts expect further deposit rate cuts and predict a slowdown in China's economy, citing fragile business and consumer confidence.

site_title: UK banks, insurers told to step up help for struggling customers
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has told banks and insurers to step up their help for struggling customers amid a cost of living crisis, with interest rates rising to combat decades-high inflation. Over 9 million people have too much debt, and 30 firms are identified as needing to do more, while 40 will be investigated. The FCA also warned insurers not to cancel policies during the crisis, and urged banks to pass on interest rate increases to savers clearly.

images.alt_text: Prices in Britain rose by 5.7 per cent, speeding up from 5.1 per cent in the 12 months to August, led by an unprecedented 10.6 per cent jump in food prices as the war in Ukraine inflated the costs of animal feed, fertiliser and vegetable oil, the BRC said.

site_title: Chuan Park owners headed for mediation over en bloc sale; Senior Counsel appointed
summary: Representatives of Chuan Park owners will meet for mediation on Oct 18 to resolve disagreements over the condominium's en bloc sale. The sale, valued at S$890 million, was made to buyers related to developers Kingsford Group and MCC Singapore, with 10 minority owners objecting to the deal. A Senior Counsel has been appointed to assist the majority owners in the mediation, with the Strata Titles Board set to mediate the dispute within 60 days. If unsuccessful, the majority owners may apply to the High Court for approval.

images.alt_text: 位于罗弄泉的春景花园（Chuan Park）私人公寓外观。Chuan Park, a 446-unit condominium near Lorong Chuan MRT station.
Chuan Park FB posts: A case of putting cart before the horse?
Chuan Park owners to get S$1.16m to S$2.53m each; some unhappy with lack of timely updates
There will be an owners’ meeting on Jul 25, at which information will be shared on the preparation for the next stages and the estimated timeline for the sale completion.

site_title: French fashion giant LVMH announces bonus payment to help staff tackle inflation pressures
summary: French fashion giant LVMH announced a bonus payment to its 27,000 staff in France, ranging from 1,000-1,500 euros, to help them cope with inflationary pressures. This move follows similar bonuses from other blue-chip French companies, such as Air France and Stellantis, amid rising inflation in Europe. The bonus aims to support staff amid Russia's invasion of Ukraine, which has disrupted global energy markets and contributed to inflation.

site_title: With Xi Jinping expected to remain top leader, China’s zero-Covid policy is here to stay
summary: China's President Xi Jinping is expected to remain top leader, likely solidifying his zero-Covid policy for a significant part of 2023. Over 2,000 Chinese Communist Party members will gather in Beijing on October 16 to affirm Xi's consolidation of power and policies. Analysts say Xi's insistence on zero-Covid is a non-negotiable stance, given the policy's effectiveness and low vaccination rates among the elderly. The prolonged lockdowns and movement curbs may hinder China's economy, which could have grown 4.5-5% without Covid policies. Xi's expected third term may also lead to continued scrutiny of the tech sector and efforts to tackle corruption.

images.alt_text: A yearlong slump in the property market is denting demand for real estate.
The government will continue to test inbound travellers in order to stay alert to new variants.

site_title: Nationwide strike disrupts France’s energy sector
summary: France experienced a nationwide strike on September 29, 2022, as hard-left trade unions demanded higher pay, causing disruptions to the energy sector. The 24-hour strike by the FNME union reduced nuclear power generation by 3.3 gigawatts and hydropower output by 610 megawatts. The strike is seen as a test of union mobilization and a barometer of potential social unrest ahead of President Emmanuel Macron's pension reform plans. The strike is expected to cause disruptions to schools and transport, with the CGT union calling for increased wages and retirement benefits.

site_title: T-Rex skeleton expected to fetch up to US$25m at auction
summary: A T-Rex fossil, named Shen, is expected to sell for up to US$25 million at an auction in Hong Kong in November. Weighing 1,400 kilograms and standing 43 feet tall, Shen is 66-68 million years old and would have lived during the cretaceous period. The winning bidder will gain full ownership rights and commercial rights to lease the dinosaur, with a high chance of it being displayed in public institutions.

site_title: Porsche ignites blockbuster IPO, defying market turmoil
summary: Porsche successfully listed on the Frankfurt stock exchange, defying global market turmoil with its shares rising to over 84.70 euros (S$118.07) in morning trading. The luxury sports carmaker's valuation exceeds 76 billion euros, outperforming a weak Frankfurt market. Despite surging inflation and recession fears worldwide, Porsche's bold flotation demonstrates its brand power and confidence in the market.

images.alt_text: Porsche will mark its first day of trading when markets open on Thursday in Frankfurt.
Indicated demand for Porsche listing, due to take place on Sep 29 at the Frankfurt Stock Exchange, exceeds the full deal size, the bookrunning said.

site_title: Citroën invents cardboard car for resourceless world
summary: Citroën has unveiled a concept car called "Oli" that uses cardboard instead of steel for parts, designed for a resource-constrained world. The car's body is made of a specialized honeycomb cardboard reinforced with plastic, and it features a vertical windscreen to reduce glass usage. The Citroën "Oli" concept car weighs under 1 tonne and is designed to be recyclable, repairable, and last for at least 50 years. Developed in partnership with BASF, the car is part of a growing trend of carmakers exploring sustainable materials and designs in response to raw material shortages and climate change.

site_title: Two-Buck Chuck: Wine of the people or a cultural wedge?
summary: Fred Franzia, the founder of Bronco Wine Co., has died at 79, leaving behind a legacy of the infamous "Two-Buck Chuck" wine. The cheap Charles Shaw wine was initially seen as a bottle for those who wanted to enjoy wine without spending a lot of money, but its production and popularity have been criticized for perpetuating the notion that expensive wines are not worth the price. Franzia's message that no wine could be worth more than $10 was seen as cynical and damaging to American wine culture, alienating wine enthusiasts and promoting the idea that all wine is the same.

images.alt_text: Fred Franzia built a cult following with his Trader JoeÕs wine, but it comes at a cost to the wine business. (George Wylesol/The New York Times) Ñ FOR EDITORIAL USE ONLY WITH NYT STORY POUR CHUCK BY ERIC ASIMOV FOR SEPT. 26, 2022. ALL OTHER USE PROHIBITED. Ñ
Are wine lovers generalising from bad wines, or is riesling's appeal profound but too narrow?

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend losses into close
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.49% to 17,165.87, following a loss in early trading, as traders fret over the economic outlook amid rising interest rates to combat inflation. The Shanghai Composite Index lost 0.13% and the Shenzhen Composite Index dipped 0.05%. The losses come as investors await the release of GDP data and amid uncertainty over US-EU trade talks and tariff developments.

images.alt_text: The flags of China, right, and the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (HKSAR) fly near an electronic screen displaying the Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong, China, on Tuesday, March 15, 2022. Chinese stocks suffered another deep selloff on Tuesday as concerns about the country’s ties with Russia and persistent regulatory pressure sent shares on a downward spiral. Photographer: Paul Yeung/Bloomberg

site_title: Next warning, H&M cuts add to European retail woe as prices soar
summary: European retailers, including Next and H&M, are battling weak consumer demand as prices hit a fresh record high this month. Brands are passing costs on to consumers due to inflation, which makes clothing more expensive and reduces purchasing power. Next issued its second profit warning this year, while H&M reported a 86% slump in third-quarter earnings. Retailers are also facing a drop in demand as customers cut expenses due to rising energy and petrol bills.

images.alt_text: Prices in Britain rose by 5.7 per cent, speeding up from 5.1 per cent in the 12 months to August, led by an unprecedented 10.6 per cent jump in food prices as the war in Ukraine inflated the costs of animal feed, fertiliser and vegetable oil, the BRC said.

site_title: China’s central bank to step up efforts to support economic recovery
summary: China's central bank plans to step up efforts to support the economic recovery, citing risks to the global economy. The People's Bank of China aims to stabilize employment and prices, reduce corporate financing and consumer credit costs. Despite a recovering domestic economy, it faces triple pressures of shrinking demand, supply shocks, and weakening expectations. The bank also pledged to keep the yuan exchange rate stable and enhance currency flexibility. Premier Li Keqiang stated that China's economy has stabilized in the third quarter, and the country will continue its economic program in the fourth quarter.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Headquarters of the People's Bank of China (PBOC), the central bank, is pictured in Beijing, China September 28, 2018. REUTERS/Jason Lee/File Photo

site_title: Singapore stocks track regional declines; STI down 0.04%
summary: Singapore stocks declined 0.04% on Thursday, following regional market losses, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 3,115.08. Despite a 2% gain in the S&P 500 on Wednesday, Saxo's head of equity strategy Peter Garnry warned of more pain ahead due to potential significant misses in earnings estimates for the third quarter. The largest gainer was Keppel Corp, rising 2.5%, while Sats plummeted 20.7% after announcing its acquisition of Worldwide Flight Services.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
The inflight caterer and ground handler on Wednesday announced its 1.3 billion euro (S$1.9 billion) deal to acquire Paris-based air cargo handler Worldwide Flight Services.

site_title: Oil pares drop with Opec+ cuts weighed against growth outlook
summary: Oil prices traded near US$82 a barrel, paring an earlier decline, as Opec+ discussed cutting output at a meeting next week to stem a recent slump. Despite a potential output cut, crude futures are still on track for the first quarterly decline in over 2 years due to fears of a potential recession. The US dollar's spike and increased sanctions on Russia also weighed on the market. However, some analysts believe the market structure has firmed up, indicating tighter supplies, and backwardation continues to strengthen.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled up US$3.05, or 3.5 per cent, at US$89.32 per barrel on Wednesday.

site_title: Taiwan to end Covid quarantine for arrivals, welcome back tourists
summary: Taiwan to end mandatory Covid-19 quarantine for arrivals starting Oct 13, allowing tourists to return. Arrivals will still need to monitor health for 7 days and take rapid tests. The move marks a significant step in re-opening to the outside world, following a well-vaccinated population and controlled pandemic. Other measures include ending PCR tests and resuming visa-free entry for eligible citizens.

images.alt_text: The island joins Japan and Hong Kong, which is also weighing ending mandatory hotel quarantine requirements, in gradually emerging from isolation.

site_title: How Singapore’s monetary policy works
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) manages the exchange rate to ensure price stability, a goal of sustainable economic growth. Unlike most major economies, MAS controls the exchange rate, rather than interest rates, due to Singapore's small and open economy. By managing the exchange rate, MAS gives up control over domestic interest rates, which are influenced by foreign interest rates and investor expectations. This approach helps maintain price stability and a competitive export industry, making Singapore a favorable destination for long-term investments.

site_title: Europe: Stocks sink, London hit hardest after BOE move
summary: European stocks declined, with London's FTSE 100 index falling 1.2% to 6,918.36 points, after the Bank of England intervened in bond markets to prevent a risk to UK financial stability. The eurozone's DAX and CAC 40 indices also declined, with Frankfurt's DAX dropping 0.9% and Paris's CAC 40 shedding 1.0%. The decline follows a brief rally in volatile trade on Wednesday, following the BOE's surprise purchase of long-dated UK government bonds.

site_title: Economists split on whether MAS tightening in October will be single or ‘double-barrelled’ move
summary: Economists are divided on whether the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will take a single or "double-barrelled" move in its upcoming policy tightening in October. Some predict a more aggressive move, steepening the S$NEER slope and re-centring the policy band, while others expect a steeper slope but no change in the band's width or midpoint. The MAS is likely to coincide with flash estimates of third-quarter economic growth, rather than preceding them. The central bank aims to address inflation pressures, with core inflation reaching a multi-year high of 5.1% in August.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) manages the exchange rate to ensure price stability.
People shopping for bread and biscuits at Vivocity, Harbourfront on March 10, 2022.
BT Explains: The 3 ways that MAS might change exchange rate policy

site_title: Singapore Writers Festival 2022: 20 for 25
summary: The Singapore Writers Festival is set to return this November with a theme of "if" to mark its 25th anniversary. The festival will feature over 200 in-person programs, including appearances by literary heavyweights such as Ted Chiang, Claudia Rankine, and Shane Koyczan. The festival also highlights the works of Malay women writers, who have been overlooked in the literary scene. Other notable events include a discussion on the concept of free will in time travel, a panel on how to counter literary apathy with new media, and a special series of programs on cyberpunk from South-east Asian writers. The festival runs from November 4-20 and features a range of programs, including talks, readings, and performances.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

Photographer Aik Beng Chia takes over one of the units in Peace Centre and transforms it into a Club Hawaii-like experience to showcase his photographs. (Club Hawaii is one of the oldest nightclubs in Singapore.)
Singapore Biennale 2022 will be led by co-artistic directors (from left) June Yap, Nida Ghouse, Ala Younis and Binna Choi.

site_title: S Korean exporters show more hints of slowdown in global demand
summary: South Korean exporters are showing signs of a slowdown in global demand, with inventories at the nation's 100 biggest firms by revenue rising at the fastest pace in a decade. Inventories surged to 300 trillion won, up 52% from a year earlier, driven by tech giant Samsung Electronics and steelmaker Posco Holdings. Central banks' interest rate hikes are attributed to the slowing consumption and slowing inventories, with manufacturers expecting a 7.1% increase next month and a cooling business outlook for October, the lowest since 2020.

site_title: From Singapore to London
summary: Singaporean designer Hans Tan's "R for Repair" exhibition, which showcases innovative and quirky ways to repair or repurpose broken items, is now on display at the Victoria & Albert Museum in London. The exhibition, which originated in Singapore, features objects from Singapore and the UK, with designers from both countries giving them new life. The exhibition aims to promote sustainability and creativity in design, and Tan is thrilled to have his work acquired by a top museum. The exhibition will run until November 2.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang
Spring Table, designed and made in Singapore.

site_title: Amazon urges call centre staff to work from home to cut real estate costs
summary: Amazon is encouraging customer service employees at US call centres to work from home to cut real estate costs, as part of a plan to close multiple call centres. The shift aims to save money and provide flexibility for employees, with some employees already working remotely before the pandemic. Amazon's move is seen as a response to the industry's high turnover, and the company can now recruit employees without being tied to specific cities. This change will also help Amazon save on real estate costs.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Amazon logo is seen outside its JFK8 distribution center in Staten Island, New York, U.S. November 25, 2020.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid./File Photo

site_title: Indonesia’s digital banks may face asset quality challenges despite continued profits: UOBKH
summary: Indonesia's digital banks face asset quality challenges despite continued profits. Three digital banks - Bank Jago, Seabank, and Bank Neo Commerce - raised their loan loss reserve in August 2022, with Bank Jago predicting higher non-performing loans and Bank Neo Commerce's loan-at-risk trend increasing to 21% in H1 2022. This indicates potential "hiccups" in asset quality despite robust loan growth and profit improvements.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Singapore Fintech Association chief operating officer Reuben Lim (left) with Indonesian Fintech Association deputy secretary-general Alwin Jabarti at a business seminar in Jakarta in August 2022.
BukaTabungan has received approval from Indonesia financial services authority Otoritas Jasa Keuangan.

site_title: China warning on speculation sparks first yuan gain in 9 days
summary: China's onshore yuan advanced 0.1% for the first time in 9 sessions after the central bank issued a verbal warning against currency speculation, halting an 8-session slide. The warning stated that speculators will lose money in the long term, and the daily reference rate was set at a stronger-than-expected level for the 26th straight session. The yuan has fallen about 4% against the greenback this month and is on track for its worst annual loss since 1994, amid a surging dollar and local economic woes.

images.alt_text: Moscow Exchange said that yuan-rouble trading turnover exceeded 6.9 billion roubles in August, 61 times higher than in December 2021, before Russia sent its armed forces into Ukraine.
The offshore yuan – which is circulated outside mainland China and is more freely traded than currency in the domestic market – fell to 7.2386 against the dollar on Wednesday, according to Bloomberg.
The PBOC’s policy divergence with a hawkish US Federal Reserve has fuelled capital outflows and driven the yuan lower.

site_title: Seafood firm plans Japan’s first bond to help ocean
summary: Japan's Maruha Nichiro Corp, a seafood firm, plans to sell its first blue bond, worth 5 billion yen ($49.8 million), to fund sustainable fisheries projects, including salmon farming. This is the country's first blue bond and the company's debut bond. The bond, managed by Mizuho Securities and Mitsubishi UFJ Morgan Stanley Securities, aims to support the blue economy, a concept that promotes sustainable ocean management. The blue bond market is emerging, with only a few issuers having sold blue bonds globally, totaling about $2 billion.

site_title: Vietnam’s economic expansion tops 13% in third quarter
summary: Vietnam's economy experienced a double-digit growth of 13.67% in the third quarter, surpassing expectations. The country's inflation remains low at 3.94%, and exports rose 10.3% while imports climbed 6.4% compared to the same period last year. Following a 6.02% contraction in the same quarter last year, Vietnam's rebound is attributed to lifted restrictions and increased domestic activity. The central bank aims to keep lending costs low to support businesses, despite recent interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Vendors sell at a market after the government eased a nationwide lockdown during the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak in Ho Chi Minh, Vietnam, April 25, 2020. REUTERS/Yen Duong/File Photo

site_title: Iron ore climbs on China construction support, restocking
summary: Iron ore futures rose on Thursday, reaching a 2-week high, due to increased construction activity in China and sustained policy support for the sector. Restocking demand ahead of China's Golden Week holiday also contributed to the increase. Steel inventories in China have fallen, indicating improving domestic demand, but reduced output. China has allocated an additional 300 billion yuan for infrastructure projects to shore up the domestic economy. Despite concerns about a weakening yuan, the outlook for construction activity remains subdued due to potential strict virus controls.

site_title: BlackRock, Indonesia join US$300m funding for South-east Asian travel startup
summary: Traveloka, a South-east Asian online travel startup, has secured US$300 million in new financing from investors including BlackRock and Allianz Global Investors. The funding round is significantly larger than initially discussed and will help the company expand in the region as tourism recovers from the pandemic. Traveloka, which has over 100 million app downloads, is considering an initial public offering in the US or Indonesia. The company's valuation remains unclear, but it was previously valued at US$3 billion.

images.alt_text: "Design has allowed us to create memorable and unforgettable journeys, thereby strengthening the connection between Changi Airport and passengers." - Jayson Goh MD, Airport Operations Management, Changi Airport Group
Traveloka had been valued at US$3 billion, according to CB Insights, but Bloomberg News reported in 2020 that it was seeking funds at a lower valuation.

site_title: Hong Kong will keep reopening unless new variant emerges, says top official
summary: Hong Kong's top health official, Lo Chung-mau, has stated that the city will continue to reopen to the world unless a new and dangerous Covid-19 variant emerges. This decision prioritizes protecting mainland China from major outbreaks, with the city aiming to ease restrictions gradually. Lo emphasized the need for ongoing surveillance and testing of inbound travelers to stay alert to new variants.

images.alt_text: Goldman Sach’s David Solomon will be among those attending Hong Kong's Global Financial Leaders' Investment Summit on Nov 2.
Hong Kong ended hotel quarantine for inbound travellers on Monday, in the most substantial move yet to end its pandemic isolation.

site_title: To achieve green transformation, semiconductor firms must innovate, nurture talent: Alvin Tan
summary: Singapore's semiconductor industry must innovate and nurture talent to achieve green transformation and meet sustainability goals, said Minister of State Alvin Tan. The government will support businesses by piloting emission abatement solutions and forging links with educational institutions to develop a pipeline of talent. Additionally, the government will continue to support research and development efforts to encourage innovation, with initiatives such as the Future of Microelectronics program.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh

More aggressive climate policies are par for the course if Singapore embarks on a more definitive plan to reach net-zero emissions by 2050, economists, academics and consultants told The Business Times.

site_title: Seoul: Shares erase early gains to end marginally higher as dollar rebounds
summary: South Korean shares ended marginally higher on Thursday, erasing early gains as the US dollar rebounded against the British sterling. The benchmark Kospi rose 0.08% to 2,170.93, boosted by the South Korean president's comments on stabilizing financial markets. Foreigners snapped a 7-session selling streak, buying shares worth 218.3 billion won. The won also inched up, while the benchmark bond yield fell, ending the session with a slight 0.07% gain.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi ended down 54.57 points or 2.45 per cent at 2,169.29.

site_title: Furniture made for urban living
summary: Singapore's Design Innovation Programme (DIP) has introduced 30 local furniture brands, including KERNEL, ipse ipsa ipsum, and Hyphenate Holdings, to create commercially viable products for urban living. The programme aims to incentivize collaborations between local manufacturers and designers to design, produce, and launch space-saving, health-enhancing, and sustainable furniture pieces. Recent showcases at FIND-Design Fair Asia featured products such as the Biome Collection, Steward Smart Space Series, huggu, Spacebar, KERNEL+, and more, highlighting the importance of collaborations and holistic strengths of the Singapore furniture industry.
