site_title: Travel to Innsbruck on a sustainable gourmet trail
summary: Innsbruck, Austria, is a foodie's paradise, offering a sustainable gourmet trail that showcases the region's traditional cuisine. Local food tours, led by founder Kurt Reindl, highlight Tyrolean specialties like Tiroler Gröstl, a hearty dish made with potatoes, meat, and onions. Restaurants like Weisses Rössl and Goldener Adler serve up seasonal ingredients, while cafes like Coffeekult source high-quality, sustainably-sourced coffee beans. Visitors can also sample edible souvenirs, such as Tyrolean bacon and artisanal chocolate, made with premium local ingredients.

images.alt_text: The perfect place to reset: Scotland’s Glenapp Castle offers activities that focus on guests’ wellbeing – from yoga to foraging and forest bathing

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on US gains
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Thursday, September 29, 2022, following gains on Wall Street. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.95% to 26,422.05, while the Topix index gained 0.74%. Investors were reassured by the Bank of England's intervention, which lowered bond yields, and took heart from US market gains.

site_title: The triumphant return of Calum Scott
summary: Calum Scott, a former Britain's Got Talent finalist, is set to perform his second show in Singapore on October 28. The singer-songwriter, who has over 29 million monthly listeners on Spotify, will be promoting his second album "Bridges," which has already spawned five hit singles. Scott's music career was halted by the COVID-19 pandemic, but he has since found his footing, citing the challenge as an opportunity for growth. The concert will be part of his Asian tour, which will also include stops in Australia.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

The Singapore Writers Festival, headed by Pooja Nansi (centre), returns post-pandemic more ambitious than ever. This year's festival stretches over 3 weekends and has more than 200 in-person programmes.

site_title: Hong Kong’s WeLab takes its wealth management playbook to Indonesia
summary: WeLab, a Hong Kong-based fintech, has acquired Indonesian conglomerate Astra International's bank, Bank Jasa Jakarta, for $510 million. WeLab plans to transform the bank into a digital bank, targeting retail and micro, small, and medium enterprises in Indonesia. CEO Simon Loong believes the market is big enough for multiple players, with competition allowing for customer education and earlier adoption of digital banking. The digital bank will focus on lending and wealth management, with an initial strategy of financial inclusion and a credit-led strategy, and is expected to achieve profitability through a real risk management model.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
WeLab founder and CEO Simon Loong said the company is focused on enhancing cross-country collaboration with partners.
Fintech WeLab acquires Bank Jasa Jakarta to launch Indonesian digital bank

site_title: ITAP returns to Singapore Expo Oct 18-20, expects 18,000 attendees
summary: The Industrial Transformation Asia-Pacific (ITAP) event is set to return to Singapore Expo from October 18-20, featuring over 200 exhibitors from 20 countries. The event, themed "Industry 4.0 for Business Sustainability," will focus on digitalisation, talent, and environmental sustainability. Organisers expect over 18,000 online and physical attendees, with key speakers from global industry leaders and a digital event component. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat will deliver an opening address on October 18.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan

site_title: Airlines cancel 2,000 US flights for Thursday
summary: Hurricane Ian has caused significant disruptions to US air travel, with over 2,000 flights cancelled on Thursday, including 1,935 flights by airlines and 403 flights on Tuesday. The storm hit Florida's Gulf Coast, affecting major airports such as Tampa, Orlando, and St Petersburg. Airlines such as JetBlue and Southwest cancelled a significant portion of their flights, with some carriers offering waivers for rebooking tickets without charge. The Orlando airport is expected to resume commercial operations on Friday, while the Tampa airport will remain closed until at least Thursday.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - SAINT PETERSBURG, FLORIDA - SEPTEMBER 28: A damaged sign sits on the side of state road I-275 as Hurricane Ian approaches on September 28, 2022 in St. Petersburg, Florida. Ian is hitting the area as a Category 4 hurricane.   Gerardo Mora/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by GERARDO MORA / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Australia: Shares track global markets higher as Bank of England seeks to quell UK bond rout
summary: Australia's shares rose 1.7% on Thursday, tracking a global rebound in equity markets after the Bank of England announced an emergency bond-buying program to calm Britain's distressed bond markets. Energy stocks led the gains, driven by higher oil prices, while miners, tech, and financials also advanced. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached its highest level since September 2022, with Premier Investments being the top gainer, and Iress the top decliner.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index ended 0.5 per cent lower at 6462 points.

site_title: Toyota global vehicle output rises 44.3% in August
summary: Toyota's global vehicle production surged 44.3% in August, exceeding its target of 700,000 vehicles, with overseas production rising 65.1% and domestic production increasing 5.6% year-over-year. The company secured more semiconductor components, easing chip shortages. Despite this, production in the first 5 months of the current fiscal year is 6.7% short of the initial plan. Toyota's overseas sales reached a record for the month, driven by a rebound from last year's decline due to coronavirus outbreaks.

images.alt_text: Toyota had planned to unveil the bZ3, which uses BYD’s less bulky Blade batteries, at the Beijing auto show in April, but the event was cancelled because of the Covid-19 pandemic.

(FILES) In this file photo taken on March 9, 2012, workers assemble the front bumper of Toyota's compact hybrid vechile "AQUA" on the assembly line of the Kanto Auto Works' Iwate plant in Kanegasaki, Iwate prefecture. - The global microchip shortage dragging on the auto industry has put barely a dent in production at Toyota, the world's biggest automaker, thanks to lessons it learned after Japan's 2011 tsunami disaster. (Photo by Toshifumi KITAMURA / AFP)

site_title: Macron faces strike as French unions flex muscles
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron faces a major strike as unions, led by the CGT, push for wage hikes and the end of planned pension reform. The strike affects schools, trains, and businesses, with around one in 10 schools in Paris expected to shut and 300 in the southern Bouches-du-Rhone area closing. Macron's insistence on raising the retirement age remains unpopular, with unions arguing it would leave many unemployed people without work. The strike is a test for Macron's government, which has seen its majority in parliament undermined by his centrist party's loss in June.

images.alt_text: Bruno Le Maire, Finance Minister of France, says: “The most important and most urgent challenge for France and other European nations is to bring down the inflation pressure.”
French Prime Minister Elisabeth Borne said the new price cap increase for gas would take effect from January, while the cap increase on electricity would follow a month later.
People take part in a demonstration in support of Iranian protesters in Paris, on Sept 25, 2022.

site_title: German economy seen shrinking next year due to energy crisis
summary: Germany's economy is expected to contract by 0.4% next year due to the energy crisis, according to leading research institutes. The institutes predicted a 160 billion euros lower output this year and next compared to previous projections, mainly due to increased energy costs. The government has assembled 3 packages of aid measures worth nearly 100 billion euros to offset the impact. Despite easing energy crunch in the medium term, gas prices are expected to remain high, leading to a permanent loss of prosperity for Germany, with inflation forecast to accelerate to 8.8% next year.

images.alt_text: A street demonstration byGermany's metal workers union IG Metall in the city centre of Leipzig in eastern Germany, on Sep 10 (Saturday). They are demanding a wage increase of 8 per cent in the upcoming collective bargaining talks even as the country convulses under slashed energy supplies from Russia, which has driven up living costs.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open with rally
summary: Hong Kong stocks experienced a 1.85% rally, with the Hang Seng Index jumping 319.29 points to 17,570.17, driven by bargain-buying following heavy losses and the Bank of England's decision to intervene in bond yields. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains, adding 0.74% and 1.04% respectively. The rally came despite US tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Indonesia central bank expects pressure on rupiah to be temporary: official
summary: Indonesia's central bank expects temporary pressure on the rupiah, which hit its weakest since April 2020 due to a US dollar rally. Senior Bank Indonesia official Edi Susianto said the currency is expected to strengthen to reflect its fundamental value later in the year, without requiring capital controls. He predicted some market volatility in coming weeks as interest rates are speculated on to tame US inflation, but believes the rupiah will achieve its fundamental value once market sentiment eases.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.66 points or 0.26% to 1,405.55 at 9:15 am on Thursday, with 332 gainers outpacing 89 losers. Volume reached 242.68 million lots worth RM127.91 million.

site_title: Asia: Stocks pick up after Bank of England steps in, but pound rally wanes
summary: Asian stocks rallied on Thursday after the Bank of England stepped in to prevent a financial catastrophe by buying £65 billion in UK bonds, but the pound's rally waned as yields rose and the dollar remained strong. Despite the initial surge, markets began to lose momentum as central banks worldwide continue to hike interest rates to combat inflation, fueling recession concerns. The Bank of England's intervention provided some hope that similar support could be offered elsewhere, but analysts warn that the pound faces further pain due to the UK's fiscal situation and financial stability risks.

images.alt_text: Prices for everything from iron ore to copper has tumbled in recent months due to concerns about China’s economic growth, which is sapping demand.

site_title: AI guru is helping retool popular Japanese snacks like Pocky
summary: Japanese snack food maker Ezaki Glico has appointed Junichi Hasegawa, founder of top AI startup Preferred Networks, as its new CEO to revitalize its business and develop healthier food ingredients with the help of artificial intelligence. Hasegawa aims to find the perfect blend of taste and nutrition through massive data harvesting and machine learning, and will also link up the company's internal research with outside AI firms to accelerate the development of healthier foods. The company plans to offer personalized nutrition services and tailor its products to customers' needs, with a focus on increasing consumer awareness of its healthier offerings.

images.alt_text: The hiring momentum has shifted to a slew of burgeoning industries favoured by Beijing.
Reinventing skills and developing talent lie at the heart of the financial sector's rapid transformation.

site_title: Gold’s relief rally fizzles as dollar firms on recession risks
summary: Gold prices retreated 0.2% to $1,656.59 per ounce amid concerns of a global recession and rising interest rates. The dollar index rose 0.2%, boosting the cost of gold for overseas buyers. The US central bank is expected to maintain "moderately restrictive" interest rates, reaching 4.25-4.50% by year-end. This has led to a 20% decline in gold prices since March, when they reached a key $2,000 per ounce level.

images.alt_text: Though gold is seen as a hedge against inflation and economic uncertainties, rate hikes have dented the non-yielding bullion’s appeal and pushed the dollar to multi-year highs.

site_title: Sats’ play for cargo handler Worldwide Flight Services wipes S$1b off market cap
summary: Sats, a Singapore-based inflight caterer and ground handler, saw its shares plummet to a near 2-year low after announcing a $1.9 billion bid to acquire Paris-based air cargo handler Worldwide Flight Services (WFS). The acquisition is expected to result in an "unmatched global footprint" covering 50% of global air cargo volumes. However, analysts at UOB Kay Hian and CGS-CIMB expressed concerns over the potential impacts of a global recession and macroeconomic uncertainty on the deal, leading to a 23.5% decline in Sats' shares.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
SATS said this acquisition would result in an “unmatched global footprint” that would cover trade routes responsible for over 50 per cent of global air cargo volumes.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.85% on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index reaching 26,397.57, driven by investors' reassurance over the Bank of England's intervention on bond yields. The broader Topix index also edged up 0.29%. This follows gains on Wall Street, where investors are optimistic despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Chinese EV maker Leapmotor tumbles in Hong Kong trading debut
summary: Leapmotor, a Chinese electric vehicle maker, slumped 15% in its Hong Kong trading debut, falling to HK$41.00 after being sold at HK$48 apiece. The IPO raised about HK$6.3 billion, with half of the 16 firms that listed this year after offerings over $100 million ending their first session below water. Leapmotor's shares were moderately oversubscribed for funds, but under-subscribed for individual investors. The firm plans to use the IPO proceeds for business expansion and brand awareness promotion.

site_title: URA, MOH launch Parry Avenue site for private assisted living development
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) and Ministry of Health (MOH) have launched a site at Parry Avenue for a pilot private assisted living development. The 12,912.1 sq m site is zoned for residential use and must include at least 60% of the maximum GFA for assisted living units and communal spaces, and at least 20% for health and medical care use. The site is near dining and shopping amenities and is expected to cater to Singapore's ageing population, with around 1 in 4 citizens aged 65 and above by 2030. A tender for the site will close on March 21, 2023, with developers expected to submit concept proposals and tender prices separately.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Photo by Yen Meng Jiin. Generic pictures of properties in Singapore
Developers sold a total of 437 units excluding executive condominiums (ECs), 47.6 per cent lower than the 834 units sold in July 2022.

site_title: Optus data hack could eat into Singtel’s profit
summary: A data breach at Optus, Australia's second-largest mobile phone operator, exposed the personal information of 9.8 million customers, including 2.8 million with sensitive documents. The breach, disclosed last week, could wipe out more than a quarter of Singapore Telecommunications' annual profit. Estimated costs for Optus range from $420 million to $560 million, including replacement documents, security measures, and public relations campaigns. The Australian government plans to tighten cybersecurity legislation and Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has called for Optus to pay for replacement passports.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A woman uses her mobile phone as she walks past in front of an Optus shop in Sydney, Australia, February 8, 2018. REUTERS/Daniel Munoz//File Photo
Optus said last week that home addresses, drivers’ licences and passport numbers of up to 10 million customers were compromised in one of Australia’s biggest data breaches.

The Australian federal government has blamed Optus for the breach, flagged an overhaul of privacy rules and more fines, and suggested the company had “effectively left the window open” for hackers to steal data.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SATS, Keppel Corp, Nanofilm
summary: SATS is acquiring Paris-based air cargo handler Worldwide Flight Services for a maximum total consideration of about 1.3 billion euros (S$1.9 billion). Keppel Corporation secured a repeat contract for a newbuild floating production, storage and offloading vessel worth about US$2.8 billion. These developments may affect trading of their securities on the stock market.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

site_title: China offers loans of 300b yuan for infrastructure spending
summary: China has distributed an additional 300 billion yuan ($60 billion) in loans for infrastructure projects through three state policy banks, as part of policymakers' efforts to spur growth in the country's economy. The funds, allocated for big public works projects, aim to boost infrastructure investment by around 10% for the whole year. This move comes after China's cabinet offered stimulus measures in August, including raising the quota on policy financing tools by 300 billion yuan, to revive the country's faltering economy.

images.alt_text: A person looks towards cranes in front of the skyline of the Central Business District (CBD) in Beijing, China, October 18, 2021. REUTERS/Thomas Peter

site_title: World Bank’s Malpass sees risk of stagflation, likely recession in Europe
summary: World Bank President David Malpass warned of a high likelihood of recession in Europe, slowing China's growth, and contracted US economic output. He attributed these developments to a "perfect storm" of rising interest rates, high inflation, and slowing growth, posing grave consequences for developing countries. The report also showed a 4% decline in global median income, the first decline since 1990, and a slowdown in poverty reduction. Malpass urged countries to reduce inflation through targeted spending and increase global capital for developing countries, while also addressing climate change and debt levels.

images.alt_text: The euro area bond market has recently trailed yields in British gilts, which recorded their sharpest rise in decades in response to new finance minister Kwasi Kwarteng’s tax cuts and borrowing plans.
Liz Truss, who hasn’t appeared in public since Friday, is preparing for her first speech to the Conservative Party conference as prime minister next week.

site_title: UK car manufacturers hit by 50% surge in energy costs
summary: UK car manufacturers have seen a 50% surge in energy costs, amounting to £100 million, due to rising inflation and economic growth. This has led to 9 in 10 automakers passing on costs to customers, while many have delayed or cancelled major investments. Despite a 4th consecutive month of increased production, the UK auto industry remains 46% below pre-pandemic levels. The shift towards electric vehicles is gaining pace, with 30% of UK cars produced in August being battery electric or hybrid. Manufacturers are struggling with recruitment and facing uncertain business environments.

site_title: China Vanke’s Onewo slides in first day of Hong Kong trading
summary: China Vanke's property management unit Onewo slumped 7.6% in its Hong Kong trading debut, falling to HK$45.60, amidst a struggling Chinese real estate sector. The IPO raised about HK$5.8 billion, with cornerstone investors including UBS and Temasek Holdings. Onewo's drop suggests investors are cautious about new share sales by firms linked to Chinese developers, which have been affected by the nation's long-simmering real estate crisis.

images.alt_text: Vanke owns 62.9 per cent of Onewo and is its biggest customer, regulatory filings showed.

site_title: Amazon raises hourly wages at cost of almost US$1b a year
summary: Amazon has raised hourly wages for US employees, with the average starting wage for front-line employees in warehousing and transportation increasing to over $19/hour. The minimum wage of $15/hour for all hourly workers in the US remains unchanged. The company's $1 billion annual investment in wages represents a significant increase, with the pay raise set to take effect in the coming months. This move comes as Amazon faces employee activism and union drives at some of its facilities.

site_title: Moveon Technologies finds new uses for proven tech as it keeps moving on
summary: Moveon Technologies, a Singapore-based optoelectronics company, is focused on staying ahead of the curve by finding fresh applications for its existing know-how and developing new technologies. The company, which makes optical components for industries such as automotive and consumer electronics, is investing heavily in research and development, with about S$5.5 million spent on nanofabrication capabilities. Moveon is also exploring new markets in the medical and industrial automation industries and has invested in over 14 optics-related startups to secure a place in their supply chain.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Plastic bag alternatives made out of the roots of the cassava plant are being produced at the Green Lab, Singapore's first eco-friendly manufacturing facility.

site_title: Japan to sign MoC on LNG with Petronas, with emergency steps: source
summary: Japan will sign a memorandum of cooperation with Petronas on liquefied natural gas (LNG) on September 29, including emergency measures, to address the country's energy security risk amid the Russia-Ukraine war. The MoC will consider joint upstream investment, technical cooperation, and mutual assistance in fuel supply. Japan aims to make similar collaborations with other Asian countries, such as Singapore, to bolster its LNG supplies and mitigate the impact of soaring spot LNG prices. The agreement will also provide emergency fuel supply to whichever country faces a shortage.

images.alt_text: Petronas said profit for the April-June period totalled RM23 billion (S$7.2 billion), compared with 9.6 billion ringgit profit in the same quarter last year.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Thursday; STI up 0.9%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.9% to 3,143.48 as of 9:01 am, driven by global market rallies following the Bank of England's bond market intervention. The top traded counter was Sembcorp Marine, with Singtel and SATS also in positive territory. US stocks, including the Dow Jones Industrial Average, rallied after the Bank of England's move, while European shares gained after the UK's blue-chip index reversed losses.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Sats is acquiring Paris-based air cargo handler Worldwide Flight Services for a maximum total consideration of about 1.3 billion euros (S$1.9 billion).

site_title: Pullback in Asia’s best-performing stock has analysts saying buy
summary: PT Adaro Minerals Indonesia, Asia's best-performing stock, has slid 40% since its April peak due to concerns about China's economic growth and the Federal Reserve's rate hikes. However, analysts predict a 53% gain over the next 12 months, driven by the company's expansion into aluminium production for electric vehicles, which will boost sales into the supply chain. Analysts see the stock as undervalued, with a 12-month price target of 2,650 rupiah, and increased demand for the company's coking coal business due to the rising needs from the nickel smelting industry.

images.alt_text: The ETF, called the CSOP CGS-CIMB FTSE Asia Pacific Low Carbon Index ETF, tracks the newly-created FTSE Asia Pacific Low Carbon Select Index.
Asian currencies have tumbled this year as Fed rate hikes have bolstered the dollar.

site_title: Europe: Shares reverse losses as Bank of England intervenes to cool bond markets
summary: Europe's shares reversed losses after the Bank of England intervened to cool bond markets. The UK's blue-chip index rose 0.3% as the BoE announced it would buy long-dated government bonds to stabilize financial markets. The move came after the International Monetary Fund and Moody's pressured Britain to reverse its economic strategy, which proposed unfunded tax cuts. Euro zone borrowing costs fell, and the European Central Bank may need to hike interest rates again to combat rising inflation.

images.alt_text: The region extended on Tuesday’s losses, with London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index tumbling 1.6 per cent to 6,870.45 points.

site_title: E-commerce rollup player Una Brands raises US$30 million in Series B funds
summary: Singapore-based e-commerce aggregator Una Brands has raised US$30 million in Series B funding led by White Star Capital and Alpha JWC Ventures. The startup, which acquired over 20 e-commerce brands across 6 countries, expects to achieve group profitability by the end of this year. It plans to use the funding to acquire more e-commerce brands and invest in its in-house tech infrastructure. Una Brands' valuation has risen to US$72.2 million, and its CEO Kiren Tanna said the funding will strengthen the company's balance sheet and cash position.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Una Brands commits US$100m into South Korea; allies with KlickBrands

site_title: Robinhood partners with USD Coin issuer to bring first stablecoin
summary: Robinhood has partnered with crypto firm Circle to offer customers the ability to buy and sell the stablecoin USD Coin (USDC) on its platform, bringing the total number of assets available to 17. USDC, issued by Circle and backed by cash and US treasuries, is the second-largest stablecoin with over $50 billion in circulation. This partnership marks the first stablecoin listed on Robinhood Crypto.

images.alt_text: The move, which follows an earlier headcount reduction in April when Robinhood eliminated about 9 per cent of its staff, brings the total number of employees dismissed this year to more than 1,000.

site_title: Ryanair ready to relocate planes from UK if pound hits demand
summary: Ryanair is prepared to redeploy aircraft from the UK to more vibrant markets if the pound's collapse and economic challenges in the UK begin to impact travel demand. Despite concerns about the UK's economic situation, Ryanair sees no evidence of slowing demand and plans to expand winter capacity 8% above pre-Covid levels. The airline has flexibility to transfer planes between its 36 bases and will do so if demand dictates, according to CEO Michael O'Leary.

images.alt_text: Ryanair aircraft on the tarmac at London Stansted Airport in Stansted, UK. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

site_title: Google adds visual, local flair to search and maps to draw youth
summary: Google has introduced changes to its search and maps products to appeal to a younger generation. A new "neighbourhood vibe" feature will allow users to select a neighborhood and see popular spots nearby, using AI technology to pick out highlights and community contributions. Other features include immersive view, live view, and the ability to take a screenshot of an item and find it nearby. Additionally, users will be able to view translated text overlaid on the camera's live view. These updates aim to make Google Maps more visually engaging and user-friendly.

site_title: US rolls out red carpet to Pacific Islands amid China inroads
summary: The US has rolled out the red carpet for Pacific Island leaders amid growing Chinese influence in the region. US Secretary of State Antony Blinken welcomed leaders to a summit in Washington, promising greater aid and diplomatic engagement on issues like maritime security, pandemic recovery, and climate change. Despite friction with the Solomon Islands, Blinken called for a free and open Indo-Pacific where every nation can choose its own path, as China seeks to expand its presence across the Pacific. The US will operate around Taiwan and increase diplomatic engagement in the region, while also addressing climate change concerns.

images.alt_text: The UK, New Zealand and Japan will also be part of the Partners in the Blue Pacific pact, an informal mechanism to assist Fiji, Samoa and other small nations in the region.
Australia will establish a defence school to train Pacific island militaries, Canberra’s new Pacific minister  Pat Conroy (right) said on Tuesday.
US Vice-President Kamala Harris speaking via video-link at the Pacific Islands Forum in Suva on July 13, 2022.
A Chinese military vessel sails off Pingtan island, one of mainland China's closest point from Taiwan, in Fujian province on August 5, 2022.

site_title: White House bullish on ‘resilient’ US economy amid global tensions
summary: The White House remains bullish on the US economy, citing its resilience in the face of global challenges. Despite rising stresses from energy prices, food supply disruptions, and tensions with China, the economy remains strong, with jobs and incomes up. Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre stated that the US is in a stronger position to navigate these challenges than any other country. The economy is expected to continue recovering from the Covid pandemic slump, with President Biden's economic plan credited for the historic recovery.

site_title: Amazon’s latest devices push it deeper into wellness, cars
summary: Amazon unveiled its latest devices at its annual event, expanding into wellness, security, and the auto industry. The lineup includes a bedside device called Halo Rise, an upgraded Echo smart speaker, a new Kindle, and enhanced security technology from Amazon's Ring division. The company also announced plans to buy One Medical and expand its healthcare offerings. New devices include an updated Echo Studio, Echo Dot, and Echo Auto, as well as a new Fire TV Cube and QLED Fire TV display.

images.alt_text: CEO of Zoox, Aicha Evans said she believes the development of Zoox’s so-called robotaxis is the “beginning of a wave” for autonomous driving.

site_title: Licence to bill: Bond’s Aston Martin sells for nearly £3m
summary: An Aston Martin DB5 stunt car from the James Bond film "No Time to Die" sold for nearly £3 million at Christie's auction. The replica, one of eight specially designed for the 2021 film, features imitation machine guns behind the headlights. Proceeds from the sale, £2.92 million, will be donated to charity, along with receipts from the sale of 24 other items. This is the only DB5 stunt car put up for sale by Aston Martin and EON productions, and 35 additional lots are available online until October 5.

site_title: Nord Stream gas leaks raise climate fears, but impact hard to quantify
summary: Two Russian gas pipelines in the Baltic Sea experienced unexplained leaks, spewing greenhouse gas emissions and raising climate fears. The pipelines, which contained mostly methane, a potent greenhouse gas, released an estimated 500 metric tons of methane per hour, with potential emissions estimated to be around 200,000 tonnes over a 100-year timeframe. The impact on climate change is uncertain, but experts warn that methane has 80 times the planet-warming potency of carbon dioxide over 20 years. An investigation is underway, and EU countries are working to stop the leaks and mitigate damage.

images.alt_text: Gas leak at Nord Stream 2 as seen from the Danish F-16 interceptor on Bornholm, Denmark September 27, 2022. Danish Defence Command/Forsvaret  Ritzau Scanpix/via REUTERS    ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE WAS PROVIDED BY A THIRD PARTY. DENMARK OUT. NO COMMERCIAL OR EDITORIAL SALES IN DENMARK.

site_title: EDF to review case for keeping open UK nuclear plants set to close in 2024
summary: France's EDF to review keeping UK nuclear plants open beyond 2024 closure date. EDF will invest £1 billion (S$1.5 billion) from 2023-25 to maintain output at Hartlepool and Heysham 1 plants. The review aims to extend the plants' operation if possible, supporting UK's nuclear skills and electricity security. Britain seeks to increase low-carbon nuclear power generation to meet 25% of electricity demand by 2050 and net zero emissions target.

site_title: Hong Kong’s global investment summit to take place on Nov 2
summary: Hong Kong's Global Financial Leaders' Investment Summit will take place on November 2, featuring top banking executives, including Goldman Sachs' David Solomon, Citigroup's Jane Fraser, and Morgan Stanley's James Gorman. The event aims to signal a re-opening of the city, which has been under Covid-19 border restrictions for over two years. Despite the city lifting mandatory hotel quarantine, some restrictions remain in place for visitors, including limited access to bars and restaurants during the first three days. The summit is seen as an opportunity for Hong Kong to re-establish itself as a major financial hub.

site_title: Nanofilm unit forms joint venture to develop coating solutions for EV batteries
summary: Nanofilm, a subsidiary of Nanofilm Technologies, has formed a joint venture with two Chinese companies, Shenzhen Everwin Precision Technology and Shanghai Hongshi Enterprise Management, to develop coating solutions for electric vehicle batteries and energy storage applications in China. The joint venture, named Sichuan Apex Technologies, aims to replace electroplating with proprietary coating solutions, reducing environmental impact. The venture targets initial production in 2023 and plans to reach industrial-scale mass production in 2024.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng
Gary Ho, Nanofilms's chief executive officer noted that the group will focus its energies on its business unit-driven strategy that will fuel growth for the longer term.

site_title: The UK’s crisis of confidence was years in the making
summary: The UK is facing a financial crisis, with a self-inflicted recession looming. The new prime minister, Liz Truss, has introduced the biggest tax cuts since 1972, which lack detail on how they will be financed. This has led to a crash in the pound, soaring cost of insuring government debt, and the Bank of England intervening to prevent a gilt market crash. Investors are questioning the government's credibility, and economists warn of an emerging market-style crisis. The government needs to restore credibility and set out how it will cover the additional borrowing required for the tax cuts and energy bills.

images.alt_text: The Chancellor reiterated his view that ‘a strong UK economy has always depended on a strong financial services sector.
The IMF urged UK authorities to consider providing more targeted support to families and businesses instead of sizable tax cuts and sharply higher government spending.

site_title: US: Stocks rally after Bank of England intervention
summary: US stocks rallied on Wednesday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index gaining 2.0% and 2.1% respectively, as the Bank of England's intervention in the British bond market calmed investors. The BoE's move pressured Treasury bond yields, reversing a spike earlier in the day. The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished up 1.9% at 29,683.74, with individual stocks such as Biogen and Netflix advancing. The rally comes after a recent slump in the markets.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 63.9 points, or 0.22 per cent, at the open to 29,198.92.

site_title: CGS to assume full control of CGS-CIMB Securities by January
summary: CHINA Galaxy Securities (CGS) will assume full control of CGS-CIMB Securities by January 2023, following a split between the two parent companies. The split comes after CIMB pared its 50% stake in the joint venture to 25.01% in December last year. As a result, CGS' stakes in the companies increased to 74.99% and 75% respectively. Both parties have agreed to continue collaborating in stockbroking despite the split, with CGS group chief executive Carol Fong stating that they will work together to maintain their stockbroking operations.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng

site_title: Volkswagen sets Porsche price at top end in bold listing move
summary: Volkswagen has set the final listing price for Porsche at 82.50 euros per share, valuing the company at 75 billion euros. This marks Europe's largest initial public offering (IPO) in a decade, despite the challenging market conditions. Porsche will list its shares in Frankfurt, with 12.5% of the total share capital being publicly listed, and the German carmaker retaining 75% ownership. The IPO aims to raise funds for Volkswagen's electrification push and provide investors with a slice of the iconic sports-car brand.

images.alt_text: The electric version of the Volkswagen Golf being charged. The Volkswagen Group, Europe’s biggest automaker, is setting up 6 battery plants in the region to enable the industry’s most ambitious rollout of electric cars; the plan is to develop 50 purely battery-powered models by the end of the decade.

site_title: AI must consider human factors
summary: Artificial intelligence has revolutionized work and daily tasks, but robots are not fully autonomous, relying on human programming. Singapore aims to establish the world's largest fully automated port in Tuas within 2 decades, utilizing AI, 5G, and IoT. The port's reliance on AI raises concerns about humans being left behind in an AI future. As innovation advances, it is essential to consider human factors in AI development to ensure a balanced and equitable future.

images.alt_text: Nvidia has gained attention in recent years with its booming data center business, which sells chips used in artificial intelligence work such as natural language processing.
Fukuda and his team chose Madagascar hissing cockroaches for the experiments because they are big enough to carry the equipment and have no wings that would get in the way.

site_title: US FDA proposes new rules for packaged foods to qualify as ‘healthy’
summary: The US FDA has proposed new rules for labelling packaged foods as "healthy", aiming to help people make informed nutritional choices and lower the risk of chronic diseases. The proposed changes require products to contain a certain amount of food from at least one of the recommended dietary groups, with limits on saturated fat, sodium, and added sugars. The move comes amid concerns that over 80% of the US population is not eating enough vegetables, fruit, and dairy, and consuming unhealthy amounts of these nutrients. A logo for manufacturers to display on healthy products is also being considered.

site_title: ThaiBev names Prapakon Thongtheppairot as new CFO
summary: Thai Beverage has named Prapakon Thongtheppairot as its new CFO, effective October 1, replacing Sithichai Chaikriangkrai. Prapakon will also continue to serve as CEO of the spirit product group and CFO of international business. Sithichai will remain a director and senior executive vice-president. The company also announced the cessation of two senior vice-president roles.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng

site_title: Oil prices jump after US crude, fuel stocks drop, dollar weakens
summary: Oil prices surged for a second day, with Brent crude futures up 3.5% at $89.32 per barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures up 4.7% at $82.15 per barrel. The US dollar's weakness and larger-than-expected drawdowns in US fuel inventories contributed to the price increase. Analysts believe oil prices may be bottoming out as Chinese demand shows signs of rebounding, but volatility is expected to persist. Refining activity remains lower than last year, but still at 90.6% capacity in the US.

images.alt_text: Brent crude settled at US$86.27 a barrel, up US$2.21, or 2.6 per cent on Tuesday.

site_title: Why job redesign continues to be relevant in the post-Covid world
summary: Job redesign, the process of transforming jobs to enhance job roles and improve organizational output, remains relevant in the post-Covid world. As businesses restart and prepare for a rebound, the need for a right talent pool and workforce capability is crucial. Redesigning jobs allows automation and digital technologies to alleviate rote work, freeing up capacity for value-added tasks. Employers should rethink their hiring approach, considering candidates from other sectors or occupations with relevant transferable skillsets. Initiatives like the Career Conversion Programme (CCP) support mid-career individuals in reskilling and upskilling, enabling them to take on new or expanded job roles.

images.alt_text: Visitors at Pagoda Street and along Chinatown in Singapore.

Minister for National Development Desmond Lee speaks to Azam from Primo Guards, the security team at Great World Serviced Apartments, which ran one of the pilots in the Singapore Business Federation's Lighthouse Project.

site_title: Why Singapore and Vietnam mean business
summary: Singapore and Vietnam are strengthening their economic ties, with potential synergies in digitalization, manufacturing, and sustainability. The two countries have signed over 30 memoranda of understanding worth almost $11 billion, focusing on technology and digital infrastructure. Singapore can assist Vietnam in developing its digital infrastructure and nurturing its skilled workforce, while Vietnam can help advance Singapore's manufacturing transformation and supply chain diversification. The two countries also share ambitions to become net-zero by mid-century, with Vietnam aiming to reduce greenhouse gas emissions per GDP by 30% by 2050. A close partnership between the two nations can drive growth, prosperity, and interconnectivity in the region.

images.alt_text: (L to R): Maisie Chong, head, transaction banking, Singapore and head, trade and working capital, Asean at Standard Chartered; and Ankur Kanwar, head of cash products, Singapore & Asean and global head of structured solutions development, cash management, at Standard Chartered.

site_title: Swiber unit inks preliminary deal to sell vessel for US$30m
summary: Swiber Holdings' subsidiary Resolute Offshore has entered into a non-binding letter of intent to sell vessel Swiber Resolute to Rawabi Vallianz Offshore Services for US$30 million. The vessel, a 2009 pipe-lay and accommodation work barge, has a book value of US$122.4 million. The sale is expected to help Swiber repay debts and reduce liabilities, with net proceeds going towards partial repayment of mortgage amounts. Trading in Swiber shares has been suspended.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng
Built in 2009, the Swiber Quetzal is a pipe lay and accommodation work barge registered under the Mexico flag.

site_title: PropertyBT: Are Singapore’s office buildings a good bet? (Ep 11)
summary: Singapore's office market is experiencing strong leasing activity and investment sales, with optimism justified for good-grade office buildings in the Central Business District. However, concerns about weaker economic growth and the rise of remote working pose risks to the market. Experts warn that differentiation between winners and losers will be crucial, with factors such as location, amenities, and sustainability playing key roles in differentiating office buildings.

site_title: Ringfencing advance payments by consumers could see businesses pass on higher costs to customers
summary: Several Singaporean consumers have lost prepaid amounts after gyms and fitness studios abruptly closed down. If prepaid payments were protected by law, businesses might pass on the higher costs to customers, according to lawyers. The Consumers Association of Singapore (Case) has received 23 complaints due to sudden closures of gyms and fitness centers, involving over $16,000 in contract value. The government may consider new legislation to protect consumers, but balancing business costs and public protection is key, lawyers said. Consumers can file claims with the Small Claims Tribunals or their banks for chargebacks, but may not recover their money.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim

Corporate lawyers agreed that temporary relief measures and government financial support for businesses during the pandemic provided a reprieve from the commencement of winding up applications in 2020 and 2021.

site_title: Third swimmer Teong Tzen Wei implicated in Joseph Schooling, Amanda Lim drug use case
summary: Singaporean swimmer Teong Tzen Wei has admitted to consuming a controlled drug overseas, along with Olympic champion Joseph Schooling and Amanda Lim. The three athletes have been issued letters of warning and had their support suspended for one month. They had cooperated fully in the review process and expressed remorse for their actions, pledging not to abuse controlled drugs in the future. The incident has raised concerns about the athletes' accountability and responsibility as national representatives.

images.alt_text: Lim was issued a stern warning by CNB under the Misuse of Drugs Act while Schooling has been referred to the Ministry of Defence (Mindef) to assess and take the appropriate measures.

site_title: US pending home sales post third straight monthly decline in August
summary: US pending home sales declined for the third straight month in August, falling 2.0% to 88.4, the lowest level since April 2020. Soaring mortgage rates and high house prices are eroding affordability. Contracts have declined in 9 of the last 10 months, with a decline in the Northeast, South, and Midwest, but a rise in the West.

images.alt_text: Rising mortgage rates are increasingly weighing on the interest-rate-sensitive housing sector as the Federal Reserve (Fed) pushes on with aggressively lifting borrowing costs to curb high inflation.

site_title: Eurozone yields fall from multi-year highs tracking UK gilts
summary: Eurozone borrowing costs fell on Wednesday, tracking moves in British gilts, which recorded their sharpest rise in decades amid tax cuts and borrowing plans. The euro area bond market trailed yields in British gilts, with German 10-year government bond yields falling 10 basis points to 2.15% after hitting a nearly 11-year high. The Bank of England's intervention in the £2.1 trillion market helped restore market confidence, with yields dropping 50 basis points. European Central Bank officials may need to raise interest rates further to control inflation.

images.alt_text: The BOE says the purchases are designed to restore orderly market conditions.

site_title: Vietnam preparing rules to limit news posts on social media accounts: sources
summary: Vietnam is preparing new rules to limit which social media accounts can post news-related content, aiming to control news dissemination on platforms like Facebook and YouTube. The rules, expected to be announced by the end of the year, would establish a legal basis for controlling news and place a significant moderation burden on platform providers. Authorities have been holding confidential meetings with social media and internet firms to brief them on which types of accounts will be allowed to post news content. The move is part of Vietnam's efforts to restrict the flow of news from unauthorised sources, following the country's tight media censorship and national guidelines on social media behaviour.

images.alt_text: According to Vietnam finance ministry, tax collection would be reduced by 7.4-12.2 trillion dong.
TOPSHOT - A man stands among fallen trees following the passage of typhoon Noru in Danang on September 28, 2022. (Photo by Nhac NGUYEN / AFP)

site_title: Cineplex makes approach for Cineworld's US franchise
summary: Cineplex, a Canadian cinema chain, is in early talks with Cineworld's lenders to take over Regal Entertainment, Cineworld's US unit, in exchange for debt and stock. This potential merger comes after Cineworld filed for bankruptcy in the US, struggling with massive debt. The talks were previously abandoned in 2020 due to breaches in the merger agreement, resulting in a $894.81 million damages claim by Cineplex. The deal could help Cineworld's lenders recover some losses, while Cineplex would gain a significant US presence.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Cineplex movie theatre sign looms over Yonge street in Toronto, Ontario, Canada, March 16, 2020.  REUTERS/Chris Helgren/File Photo

site_title: China will push forward policy implementation in Q4: state media cites premier
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang stated that the country will push forward with its economic program in the fourth quarter, despite a weak economy due to strict Covid curbs and a property crisis. The government has rolled out over 50 policy measures to support the economy, which narrowly escaped a contraction in the June quarter. Analysts expect the economy to grow at 3% this year, the slowest since 1976. The World Bank has also revised its forecast to 2.8% growth for 2022.

site_title: Angela Lee ready to make MMA history in One Championship title showdown
summary: Angela Lee, 26, is set to make MMA history by facing Xiong Jing Nan for the women's strawweight world title at One Championship on October 1. If she wins, Lee will become One Championship's first female world champion in two weight classes, having previously won the atomweight title. The trilogy match between Lee and Xiong is the third installment, with Lee winning their previous two encounters. Lee is confident in her abilities and has prepared well for the fight, while Xiong acknowledges pressure but is motivated to win.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Deputy US Treasury chief says soft landing is possible
summary: Deputy US Treasury chief Wally Adeyemo expressed confidence in the US economy, stating a "path" exists to reduce price pressures while maintaining growth and a healthy labor market. He acknowledged the challenges posed by high inflation, but believes the economy can achieve a "soft landing" without a recession. Adeyemo cited a strong consumer and corporate balance sheet as a foundation for the economy's momentum, despite external factors such as the Russia-Ukraine war and Covid-19 lockdowns.

site_title: Adobe outlines Figma feature ideas, commits to keeping free tier
summary: Adobe plans to integrate its creative software technology into Figma without changing pricing or simplifying the design app, aiming to ease concerns among loyal users. The company will add photo, video, and illustration editing capabilities, as well as link projects from Adobe products like Photoshop and Premiere. Figma's pricing model will remain "freemium," with a basic tier always accessible without cost. Adobe's acquisition of Figma, valued at $20 billion, is expected to expand its web-based offerings to cater to casual designers and small businesses.

site_title: More yuan than US dollars to be traded in Moscow next year as ‘yuanisation’ expands
summary: Russia's Moscow Exchange expects yuan-rouble trading volumes to outpace US dollar-rouble trading next year as the country strengthens its economic ties with China amid Western sanctions. In August, yuan-rouble trading turnover exceeded 6.9 billion roubles, 61 times higher than in December 2021. Russian companies, including aluminium producer Rusal, are issuing debt in yuan, and the Russian central bank is now the third-biggest user of yuan for international settlements. However, increased "yuanisation" will require adjustments to currency regulation due to China's capital controls and complex system of measures to manage yuan trading.

site_title: Amazon’s Robotaxi arm Zoox coming ‘sooner than people expect’
summary: Amazon's self-driving unit Zoox expects autonomous vehicles to appear in cities "sooner than people expect," according to CEO Aicha Evans. Testing has already begun, and the company plans to launch its robotaxis on public roads with a small-to-moderate scale. Evans believes the development of Zoox's robotaxis is the "beginning of a wave" for autonomous driving, but stopped short of providing a specific timeline. The bigger challenge will be expanding infrastructure and maintaining a consistent user experience beyond initial cities.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: SATS, a Singapore-based in-flight caterer and ground handler, has agreed to acquire Paris-based air cargo handler Worldwide Flight Services (WFS) for up to 1.3 billion euros. The deal is expected to give SATS an "unmatched global footprint" covering over 50% of global air cargo volumes. This move will propel SATS into a global player in the air cargo market.

site_title: US trade gap narrows to smallest since Oct 2021
summary: The US merchandise-trade deficit narrowed to its smallest since October 2021, shrinking 3.2% to $87.3 billion in August. Exports declined 0.9% to $179.8 billion, while imports retreated 0.3% to $267.1 billion, driven by lower consumer merchandise imports. The dollar's strength, which has risen for three consecutive months, has made exports more expensive. Supply-chain logjams are easing, and interest-rate increases are expected to weigh on demand, suggesting a tailwind for economic growth in the third quarter.

images.alt_text: Soaring US inflation and supply chain snarls have challenged industry and consumers, causing a pullback in spending and investment.

site_title: Purpose at the core of business goals
summary: Two Singaporean companies, Push Pull Give and Preschool Market, have been named Champions of Good 2022 by Company of Good for their corporate giving efforts. Push Pull Give empowers disadvantaged youths through fitness education and scholarships, while Preschool Market provides business-to-business solutions to underprivileged children and families. Both companies leverage their expertise and partnerships to drive positive change, believing that their corporate purpose can attract talent and drive future growth. This recognition highlights the importance of aligning business goals with social causes to create meaningful impact.

images.alt_text: Since 2018, Certis has partnered like-minded organisations to develop inclusive programmes for the well-being of its beneficiaries, and drive employee engagement and volunteerism by organising regular outreach programmes to help the community.
Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wrong interacting with various Champions of Good 2022.

site_title: Sterling slides after BOE jumps into gilt market, US dollar marches on
summary: The British pound slid 1.5% to US$1.0583 after the Bank of England (BOE) stepped in to prop up the gilt market, buying long-dated government bonds to stabilize financial markets. The BOE's move came as the US dollar hit a 2-decade peak, with the US dollar index rising 0.5% to 114.78. The pound's decline was attributed to the BOE's intervention, which may indicate rising UK interest rates, further weakening the currency.

site_title: The Ukraine war: Biden’s dilemmas
summary: US President Joe Biden faces a dilemma in providing military and economic aid to Ukraine without deploying US troops, as Russia's military strategy under Vladimir Putin raises the risk of nuclear conflict. Putin has threatened to use nuclear weapons if Ukraine forces attempt to push back Russian troops from occupied areas, but experts argue that this would be a risky proposition, potentially triggering a Western military response and a full-blown world war. Instead, Putin may use conventional military resources to inflict death and destruction on Ukrainians, raising concerns about the long-term viability of the US aid package.

images.alt_text: Russian president Vladimir Putin, in a speech on Wednesday, inverted a war of aggression against Ukraine into one of defence of the "motherland". "This is not a bluff", he said to the West.
Speaking at the UN General Assembly in New York, Biden slammed Russian President Vladimir Putin for starting an unprovoked war that some 40 UN members are helping Ukraine fight.

site_title: Regulators that over-manage crypto risks will hurt growth: Binance regional head
summary: Binance's regional head for the Middle East and North Africa, Richard Teng, warned that over-managing crypto risks will stunt growth, as good regulations should focus on understanding risks to support innovation. Teng stated that Singapore's current approach, focusing on blockchain applications and creating friction for retail investors, is strategic but may hinder growth. Binance is still working with Singapore government agencies on blockchain applications, despite pulling out its application for a crypto permit in December 2021.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng
Japan’s easing approach to crypto and substantial potential for user growth are the key reasons for Binance’s renewed interest in the world’s third-largest economy.
Crypto lenders such as Voyager boomed during the Covid-19 pandemic, luring depositors with high interest rates and easy access to loans rarely offered by traditional banks.
Richard Teng now Binance's Mena head after short-lived stint as Singapore CEO

site_title: Keppel subsidiary bags US$2.8 billion repeat FPSO contract from Petrobras
summary: Keppel O&M, a subsidiary of Keppel Corporation, has secured a repeat contract worth US$2.8 billion from Petrobras for a newbuild floating production, storage and offloading (FPSO) vessel, the P-83. The contract, scheduled for delivery in 2027, will be built on the synergies reaped from the P-80 FPSO, with the fabrication of the topside modules replicated across Keppel O&M's facilities in Singapore, China, and Brazil. This contract adds approximately S$3.8 billion to Keppel O&M's orderbook, bringing the unit's net orderbook to S$11.8 billion.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Keppel O&M's wholly-owned subsidiaries, Keppel AmFELS, Inc and Keppel Shipyard Ltd have been awarded contracts worth around S$75 million.
The contract is not expected to have a material impact on the net tangible assets of earnings per share of Keppel Corporation for the current financial year, the company said.

site_title: BOE steps back into bond market to restore stability
summary: The Bank of England intervened in the gilt market, pledging unlimited purchases of long-dated bonds to restore stability. The move came after a potential crisis was anticipated, with collateral calls on Wednesday that could have forced investors to dump government bonds, triggering a major crash. The BOE's intervention had an immediate effect, with yields on 30-year debt falling to the biggest drop on record, and the central bank warned that continued dysfunction would threaten financial stability and even damage the economy.

images.alt_text: Just weeks in office, British Prime Minister Liz Truss has announced a neo-Reaganite "fiscal event" that has sent the British pound crashing.

site_title: UK’s Kwarteng assures bankers of the government’s commitment to fiscal discipline
summary: UK Finance Minister Kwasi Kwarteng assured bankers of the government's commitment to fiscal discipline, reiterating his view that a strong financial services sector is crucial to the UK economy. Kwarteng met with investment bank executives to discuss the upcoming Medium Term Fiscal Plan and the planned financial services deregulatory package, dubbed "Big Bang 2.0". He emphasized the government's focus on boosting growth, generating investment, and delivering higher wages across the UK, while making no mention of market turmoil or the Bank of England's surprise intervention in bond markets.

images.alt_text: The IMF urged UK authorities to consider providing more targeted support to families and businesses instead of sizable tax cuts and sharply higher government spending.

site_title: IMF and Moody’s censure UK policy, Bank of England says will act big
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) and Moody's have criticized the UK's new economic strategy, which includes deep tax cuts and deregulation, citing concerns over increased inequality and potential market turmoil. The criticism comes as investors braced for more economic upheaval, with the pound down 0.5% and UK borrowing costs hitting multi-year highs. The UK Treasury department plans to announce plans to cut debt in the medium term in November, amid pressure from lawmakers and financial sector leaders to reassess the policy.

site_title: Lions Gate focusing on spinning off studio business over Starz
summary: Lionsgate Entertainment announced plans to spin off its studio business before exploring alternative options for its cable and streaming division, Starz. The company has an extensive library of films and TV shows, including hits like "Hunger Games" and "The Expendables." Lionsgate+ will rebrand its international streaming service in 35 countries, competing with Netflix and Disney+. The company stated it remains on a path to separating its Starz and studio businesses, aiming for financial and strategic benefits. Negotiations are ongoing, with a focus on spinning the studio business.

site_title: US plans reinstating Malaysia aviation safety ranking, sources say
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) plans to reinstate Malaysia's air-safety ranking to Category 1, allowing Malaysian airlines to expand flights to the US and enter codeshare agreements with American carriers. This decision comes three years after the FAA downgraded Malaysia's rating due to unresolved safety concerns. Malaysia has addressed all 33 issues raised by the FAA in 2019 and is expected to meet with FAA officials to finalize the rating. A Category 1 rating would enable Malaysian airlines to access the lucrative US market and boost tourism.

site_title: Rolex watches on sale in UK for US visitors as pound slumps
summary: The British pound's record low against the US dollar has led to significant discounts on luxury watches in the UK, particularly for US visitors. A steel Rolex GMT-Master II can be purchased for US$9,293, a 19% discount, and a 41mm diameter Datejust model for US$7,088, a 19% discount. The discounts are expected to increase to 32% if the UK government reintroduces Value Added Tax rebates on tourist goods. Despite this, demand for Rolex watches remains high, and prices are unlikely to be widely taken advantage of due to limited supply.

site_title: Sats to buy Worldwide Flight Services for up to 1.3b euros, plans S$1.7b equity fundraising
summary: SATS has agreed to acquire Paris-based air cargo handler Worldwide Flight Services (WFS) for up to 1.3 billion euros (S$1.9 billion), aiming to become the largest global air cargo handler. The acquisition is expected to result in an "unmatched global footprint" covering 50% of global air cargo volumes and propel SATS into a global player. The deal will be funded through a S$1.7 billion equity fundraising and internal cash resources, with expected synergies of over S$100 million in medium-term Ebitda.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
SATS last week said it was in discussions to acquire air cargo handler Worldwide Flight Services.
SATS says it is constantly on the lookout for acquisition opportunities.
Losers beat gainers 413 to 194 on Monday.
SATS confirmed on Wednesday that it was in discussions regarding the potential deal, but no definitive terms have been reached.

site_title: Indonesia approves first home-grown Covid vaccine for emergency use
summary: Indonesia has approved its first domestically-produced Covid-19 vaccine, Indovac, for emergency use in people over 18. Developed by Bio Farma and the Baylor College of Medicine, the vaccine is intended to reduce the nation's dependency on imported vaccines. 80% of the vaccine is locally-sourced, and Indonesia aims to produce 20 million doses in 2022 and 100 million by 2024. The approval comes as Indonesia seeks to boost its vaccination efforts, which were hindered by high transmission rates last year.

images.alt_text: Pfizer said Paxlovid treatment courses will be available for procurement through Global Fund’s Covid-19 Response Mechanism to 132 low- and middle-income countries this year, subject to local regulatory clearances.

site_title: Alzheimer's drug study yields positive results, say makers Eisai and Biogen
summary: Eisai and Biogen's experimental Alzheimer's drug, lecanemab, slowed cognitive and functional decline in a large trial by 27% compared to a placebo, meeting its main goal. The study's results, announced on September 27, offer hope for patients and their families desperate for an effective treatment. Lecanemab targets forms of amyloid that have not yet clumped together, unlike previous failed treatments. The companies aim for FDA approval in early January and full approval and commercialization by the end of 2023.

images.alt_text:
naada - The dementia epidemic in Singapore may be bigger than we know, says the Alzheimer's Dementia Association (ADA). According to IMH, in Singapore, 1 in 10 people above the age of 60 is diagnosed with dementia. At the time of that study, this corresponded to approximately 82,000 people in 2018 living with dementia. In order to tackle this issue, ADA has been implementing various programmes to reach out to persons with dementia to provide support as well as care needs.

cred:  Alzheimer's Disease Association

site_title: US mortgage interest rates jump to 6.52%, highest since mid-2008
summary: The US average interest rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage jumped to 6.52%, the highest since mid-2008, according to data from the Mortgage Bankers Association. This increase is attributed to the Federal Reserve's efforts to curb high inflation. The rate rise weighs on the interest-rate-sensitive housing sector, with mortgage rates rising for five straight weeks. The Federal Reserve's aggressive borrowing cost hikes are expected to continue to impact the housing market.

site_title: China central bank says stabilising FX market is top priority
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), has emphasized stabilizing the foreign exchange market as its top priority. Despite the yuan's recent weakness to its lowest level since 2008, the PBOC stated that the FX market is largely operating in an orderly manner. However, the central bank warned against making heavy one-way bets on the currency and urged regulatory bodies to prevent sharp fluctuations. The PBOC also called for strengthened expectation management to prevent speculative trading.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 open higher on lower yields
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 63.9 points, or 0.22%, to 29,198.92, while the S&P 500 opened higher, 4.7 points, or 0.13%, at 3,651.94. The Nasdaq Composite, however, dropped 12.0 points, or 0.11%, to 10,817.525, due to losses in Apple after it dropped plans to boost iPhone production. Easing Treasury yields lifted rate-sensitive growth stocks, but gains were capped by the tech company's decision.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - SEPTEMBER 16: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) on September 16, 2022 in New York City. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell again on Friday as economic concerns over inflation and global corporate profits of transport companies fall.   Spencer Platt/Getty Images/AFP

site_title: Central bank’s role to maintain price stability to manage inflation: Ravi Menon
summary: MAS managing director Ravi Menon emphasizes the central bank's role in maintaining price stability to manage inflation, citing structural shifts in the labor market, supply chains, and energy security as contributing factors. Menon suggests central banks should focus on understanding supply factors and supply chains, and work with governments on labor policies to mitigate the impact of liquidity shocks. He also notes a growing alignment between the objectives of tackling climate change, enhancing energy security, and addressing inflation.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
FOMC participants are now projecting US GDP growth of just 0.2 per cent for 2022, and 1.2 per cent for 2023
“(Consumers) seem to be irrationally oblivious about the risks of cryptocurrency trading,” Menon said at a seminar on the digital asset ecosystem in Singapore.
An orderly transition to a greener economy may help keep both inflationary pressures and the disruption in labour markets manageable, MAS managing director Ravi Menon said in a speech on Wednesday.

site_title: South Korea preparing to re-activate stock market stabilisation fund
summary: South Korea's Financial Services Commission has instructed officials to prepare to re-activate a stock market stabilisation fund amid global market turmoil. The fund, which has been used in the past to buy shares of major companies, was activated previously to stabilize financial markets. The benchmark KOSPI share index has fallen 27% this year, while the won currency has lost 17% of its value against the US dollar. The move aims to help restore stability to the financial markets.

site_title: Sentek Marine & Trading to be charged for alleged offences linked to Shell Bukom heist
summary: Sentek Marine & Trading will be charged in court for alleged offences linked to the US$56 million acquisition of marine gasoil from Shell's Pulau Bukom facility between 2014 and 2018. The company faces 42 charges under the Corruption, Drug Trafficking and Other Serious Crimes Act. Sentek's ex-managing director Pai Keng Pheng has also been charged with related offences. If convicted, Sentek could face a fine of up to S$1 million or twice the value of the property. The charges are linked to the dishonest misappropriation of marine gasoil worth over US$56 million.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim

site_title: Japan’s securities watchdog recommends punishment for SMBC Nikko
summary: Japan's Securities and Exchange Surveillance Commission recommended the Financial Service Agency impose administrative punishment on SMBC Nikko Securities for insufficient compliance allowing market manipulation. The misconduct led to the indictment of former executives and a revenue impact of 10 billion yen. The watchdog also found SMBC Nikko and SMFG's banking unit shared customer information in violation of firewall rules. SMFG and Nikko Securities have vowed to regain public trust and take the recommendations seriously.

site_title: Europe: Equities slump at open
summary: Europe's stock markets slumped at open on Wednesday, with the FTSE 100 index falling 1.6% to 6,870.45 points, extending Tuesday's losses. The eurozone's DAX and CAC 40 indices also dropped, with Frankfurt's DAX falling 1.3% and Paris's CAC 40 shedding 1.4%. Investors are fretting over recession fears, heightened geopolitical concerns, and Britain's tax-slashing budget, contributing to the global selloff.

site_title: Tata Motors launches US$10,000 electric car in India
summary: Tata Motors launched its US$10,370 electric car, the Tiago EV, in India, making it the most affordable electric vehicle in the country. The operating cost is expected to be about a seventh of the gasoline version, with a driving range of 250 km for the cheapest version and 315 km for the more expensive version. This launch further solidifies Tata's lead in India's electric car market, driven by government subsidies and high tariffs that keep out imports.

site_title: Oil’s current funk may prompt Opec+ to cut output
summary: Opec+ is set to meet on October 5 to discuss output targets, amid oil's current instability due to recession, monetary tightening, and geopolitical tensions. Expectations are high that the 13-member group may cut production targets, following Russia's push for a major output cut. This move could support prices in the global oil market if fundamentals change or volatility persists. A production cut could set a floor for oil prices, potentially holding crude prices firm despite soaring prices globally.

images.alt_text: While traders mostly expected the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) and its allies would hold steady, the coalition’s leading producer had indicated it might be about to pivot.
One way Russian products such as fuel oil can make their way into Asia is flowing through the region's major distribution hubs.
Brent crude futures for November settled down US$2.09, or 2.4 per cent, to US$84.06 a barrel on Monday, plunging below levels reached on Jan 14.

site_title: Taiwan spent US$8.25b to hold back currency depreciation in H1
summary: Taiwan's central bank spent US$8.25 billion in the first half of 2022 to intervene in the foreign exchange market and prevent the devaluation of its currency, the Taiwan dollar, which has depreciated 13% against the US dollar this year. The bank cited concerns over the economy's trade dependence and the impact of large international capital movements on financial stability. Despite the depreciation, the Taiwan dollar has been relatively stable against other major currencies, and the country's managed floating exchange rate system has contributed to domestic financial stability and economic growth.

images.alt_text: A Taiwan dollar note is seen in this illustration photo May 31, 2017.     REUTERS/Thomas White/Illustration

site_title: Sats calls for trading halt pending announcement
summary: SATS requested a trading halt on Wednesday, pending an announcement, following a Bloomberg report that the company was in discussions to acquire Worldwide Flight Services for up to US$3 billion. The acquisition was first reported last week, but no definitive terms or documentation had been agreed upon. SATS ended Tuesday at S$3.87, 0.8% lower.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

site_title: Seoul: Shares, won tumble on recession fears
summary: South Korea's benchmark Kospi index plummeted 54.57 points or 2.45% to 2,169.29 on Wednesday, its lowest close in over 2 years, due to heightened global recession fears. The Korean won also dropped 1% against the dollar to a 13 1/2-year low, while the benchmark bond yield erased early gains. The decline was attributed to market concerns over the global economic downturn.

images.alt_text: epa10103834 An electronic signboard in the dealing room of Hana Bank in Seoul, South Korea, 03 August 2022, shows the benchmark Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) having risen 21.83 points, or 0.89 percent, to close at 2,461.45. Seoul shares ended higher on gains in automakers and battery makers, with investors eyeing the fallout from U.S. House of Representatives Speaker Nancy Pelosi's trip to Taiwan amid global recession worries.  EPA-EFE/YONHAP SOUTH KOREA OUT

site_title: Sembcorp walks the ‘green’ talk with sale of Indian coal power assets
summary: Sembcorp Industries, a utilities giant, has sold a 100% stake in Sembcorp Energy India, a 2.6GW coal-fired power plant in India, to Oman's Tanweer Infrastructure for S$2.1 billion. This sale marks a significant step towards Sembcorp's "brown-to-green" transformation goals, with the company aiming to increase its renewable energy portfolio to 51% of its energy capacity by 2025. The sale reduces Sembcorp's carbon emissions intensity by 0.19 tCO2e/MWh, surpassing its 2025 target of reducing emissions to 0.40. The deal is seen as a positive move for Sembcorp's stock, with analysts praising the company's decarbonisation efforts.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

In a bourse filing on Monday evening, Sembcorp said its wholly-owned subsidiary agreed to sell Sembcorp Energy India Limited to Tanweer Infrastructure.

This undated handout photograph released by Singapore's national water agency PUB on July 14, 2021 shows an aerial view of Sembcorb energy company's new floating solar power farm at Tengeh reservoir in Singapore.
