Sembcorp's exposure to the UK consists of energy generation and battery storage.

site_title: Q3 office rents near 14-year high; landlord’s market to extend into 2023: consultants
summary: Singapore's office rents in Q3 have reached a near 14-year high, surpassing the pre-pandemic peak, with Central Business District (CBD) Grade A office rents reaching S$11.06 per sq ft per month. The market is expected to continue its strength into 2023, driven by demand from businesses, technology startups, and private equity companies. Occupier caution due to global economic headwinds is expected to moderate, with consultancy JLL forecasting a 10% growth in Grade A CBD rents for 2022 and 5% for 2023.

images.alt_text:
cbd / ST20220716_202206887671 / Alphonsus Chern //

Generic photograph of the Singapore city skyline in the CBD 16 July 2022.
Savills sees robust demand for office assets despite headwinds from geopolitical uncertainties and higher interest rates.
Singapore office rents rise 2.4% in Q2, prices fall 5.1%: URA

site_title: Insurer AIA acquires healthcare firm in the Philippines
summary: AIA Group, a Hong Kong-based insurer, has agreed to acquire MediCard, a healthcare firm in the Philippines, to expand in the country's growing healthcare market. MediCard has over 920,000 members and a network of partner hospitals and clinics. The deal is subject to regulatory approvals and no financial details were disclosed. This acquisition marks AIA's entry into the Philippines' healthcare market, which is one of the fastest-growing in the region.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: AIA Group logo is pictured on a smartphone in front of an electronic display showing the same logo in this illustration taken December 4, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Vietnam suffers foods, blackouts after typhoon Noru makes landfall
summary: Typhoon Noru made landfall in Vietnam's central region, causing widespread power outages, flooding, and property damage. Over 500,000 households lost power, and more than 500 trees were toppled. Four people were injured, but no deaths were reported. The storm, considered the strongest to hit Vietnam in two decades, also threatens to delay coffee harvests, a major industry for the country. Authorities had warned of heavy rain, wind, and flash floods, and the military mobilized over 260,000 soldiers to assist with preparations.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks suffer fresh round of hefty losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 3.41% on Wednesday, September 28, with the Hang Seng Index falling to 17,250.88, led by tech firms and property developers. The decline was attributed to fresh recession fears fueled by central bank interest rate hikes to combat inflation and rising tensions between Russia and the West. This marks the latest heavy loss in Hong Kong stocks, following previous downturns.

images.alt_text: epa09478741 Electronic billboards display stock transactions on Exchange Square, the building housing the stock exchange, in Hong Kong, China, 21 September 2021. The Hang Seng Index dropped 0.5 per cent to 23,982.23 as of 1:45pm Hong Kong time on concerns over the Chinese real-estate developer Evergrande financial crisis.  EPA/JEROME FAVRE

site_title: China’s oil demand set to recover as Covid curbs ease
summary: China's oil demand is expected to recover next year as Beijing eases COVID-19 restrictions, supporting the world's second-largest economy. Chinese refiners anticipate up to 15 million tonnes worth of oil product export quotas to be released, boosting sagging exports. Oil demand contracted in 2022 for the first time in 20 years due to the zero-Covid policy, but is expected to rebound as restrictions ease.

site_title: Australian state announces world's biggest pumped hydro scheme
summary: Queensland, Australia has announced plans to build the world's largest pumped hydroelectric energy storage scheme, with a capacity of 5 gigawatts, to be completed by 2035. The project is part of a new $62 billion "energy and jobs plan" aimed at generating 80% of the state's energy from renewable sources by 2035. The plan is considered ambitious, with Queensland aiming for 60% renewable energy by 2030, surpassing other Australian states. The project will use cheap solar electricity to pump water up a mountain, storing it for night-time electricity generation.

site_title: Writing for a new era
summary: The Singapore Writers Festival returns this November after a 2-year hiatus, with a theme of "if" that explores global society and its future. The festival features over 200 programmes and live appearances by notable authors such as Ted Chiang, Claudia Rankine, and Lois Lowry, spanning 3 weekends. This marks the longest festival yet, aiming to tackle the topics writers have been grappling with since the pandemic.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close lower after Wall Street falls
summary: Tokyo stocks fell on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index losing 1.50% to close at 26,173.98, following a decline in US blue-chip shares, which hit a new low for the year. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq also edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore stocks hurt by global risk-off mood; STI down 1.6%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.6% on Wednesday, closing at 3,116.31, tracking global market decline. Regional markets also dropped, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index down 3.4%, South Korea's Kospi 2.5%, and Japan's Nikkei 225 1.5%. IG strategist Yeap Jun Rong attributed the weak performance to the global risk-off environment, while a stark warning by the IMF on UK tax plans added to market concerns. Only two companies, Emperador and Venture Corp, rose, while DFI Retail Group fell 4.4%.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
FOMC participants are now projecting US GDP growth of just 0.2 per cent for 2022, and 1.2 per cent for 2023

site_title: Regional pandemic beneficiaries tanking; analysts see worst yet to come
summary: Regional pandemic beneficiaries, including glove makers Top Glove, Medtecs International, and UG Healthcare, are experiencing declining profitability and market values amid the easing of the coronavirus pandemic. Analysts expect the worst yet to come, citing a lack of diversification and innovation by these companies during their heyday. Glovemakers have seen record-high profit and revenue figures during the pandemic, but now face lower average selling prices, stiffer competition, and higher energy and raw material costs.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
H1 revenue fell per cent to 754.3 million ringgit, compared to 2.02 billion ringgit in the corresponding 6-month period last year.

As of Thursday (Jun 2), some 121 local companies had released their results for Q1 2022. Total net profit from these companies amounted to S$7.2 billion, down 8.7 per cent from the same period a year earlier.
Among glove makers, Riverstone has most attractive margins
The Malaysian glove maker on Tuesday posted its first quarterly loss since listing amid rising cost pressures and a pullback in demand.
The softer financial performance comes as the industry weathers an adjustment period, dealing with oversupply and excess stockpiling by customers during the pandemic, the group said.

site_title: Verstappen on verge of second world title as F1 returns to Singapore
summary: Max Verstappen has a mathematical chance to secure his second consecutive Formula 1 world title at the Singapore Grand Prix, where he has never won. To clinch the championship, Verstappen must win the race and have his closest rivals, Charles Leclerc and Sergio Perez, falter. With a 116-point lead over Leclerc, Verstappen can seal the title with 5 races to spare if he extends his lead to 138 points by the end of the weekend.

site_title: Global markets risk more turmoil
summary: Global markets are experiencing turmoil due to various factors, including the UK's economic instability, the US Federal Reserve's tight monetary policy, and recession concerns in the euro area. The UK's new government is under pressure, and a sharp rate hike by the Bank of England could exacerbate the situation. The US Fed is committed to controlling inflation, and a global market downturn could be a concern for US policymakers. The European Central Bank is also facing challenges, and Chinese financial markets are experiencing weak growth. A collective G7 statement is unlikely to calm markets, but individual statements from key officials could help alleviate concerns.

images.alt_text: Asked at a Washington Post event whether he felt US investors had taken an overly optimistic view of Fed policy until a recent sharp sell-off begin, Atlanta Fed president Raphael Bostic said that was beside the point.
A global slowdown may not even bring about a weaker dollar.

site_title: Cathay in talks with Boeing, Airbus to refresh ageing cargo fleet: sources
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways, Hong Kong's main carrier and one of the world's biggest cargo airlines, is in talks with Airbus and Boeing to purchase next-generation freighter aircraft, potentially including the Airbus A350 freighters or Boeing 777-8F jets. The airline aims to renew and replace some of its ageing cargo jets, which are currently being studied for evaluation. Cathay has not yet determined the number of new freighters to order, but could buy up to 6. The move comes as the airline seeks to adapt to a weaker upcoming peak Christmas season and a potential global economic slowdown.

images.alt_text: In a sign of how isolated Hong Kong has become, in the first 8 months of this year, the city’s airport handled just 3.4 per cent of passengers that it did before Covid, and 30 per cent of flights.
Cathay operated 59 per cent of its pre-pandemic cargo capacity in August and forecast it would reach around two-thirds of 2019 levels by the end of the year.

site_title: CSOP, CGS-CIMB list ETF tracking low carbon Asia-Pacific companies on SGX
summary: CSOP Asset Management and CGS-CIMB launched the CSOP CGS-CIMB FTSE Asia Pacific Low Carbon Index ETF on the Singapore Exchange (SGX), tracking low-carbon Asia-Pacific companies. The ETF, which launched with S$150 million in assets under management, tracks the FTSE Asia Pacific Low Carbon Select Index, comprising 214 companies with the lowest carbon intensities relative to peers. The index assesses measures taken by companies to reduce carbon intensity using data from organizations like the Transition Pathways Initiative.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
OCBC Securities, Lion Global to list low carbon ETF on SGX in April

site_title: China’s offshore yuan hits record low against dollar
summary: China's offshore yuan hit a record low of 7.2386 against the US dollar on Wednesday, its weakest level since 2010. The yuan's depreciation comes amid the US Federal Reserve's hawkish tone and expectations of further interest rate hikes. Despite the People's Bank of China's efforts to shore up the currency, the onshore yuan also extended its slump to a 14-year low of 7.2297 per dollar. The yuan's depreciation may put pressure on the central bank to balance domestic stimulus and foreign exchange policies.

images.alt_text: This move follows other steps authorities have taken to put a floor under the yuan, which is down more than 11 per cent against a US dollar.
The PBOC’s policy divergence with a hawkish US Federal Reserve has fuelled capital outflows and driven the yuan lower.

site_title: Australia: Techs, banks pull shares lower on recession risks
summary: The Australian stock market ended 0.5% lower on Wednesday, with technology and financials leading losses due to recession risks. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6462 points, with financial shares falling 0.8% and technology shares dropping 1.6%. Despite August retail sales beating expectations, investors showed little response, and market participants remain cautious about the impact of rising interest rates on global growth.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index was up 0.2 per cent, as of 0014 GMT on Wednesday.

site_title: Thailand raises key rate by a quarter point to 1% as expected
summary: Thailand's central bank, the Bank of Thailand (BOT), raised its benchmark policy rate by 25 basis points to 1% for the second consecutive meeting, aiming to combat the country's fastest inflation in 14 years. The move follows India and the Philippines in tightening policy to address high inflation and weakening currencies. Despite this, Thailand remains one of the least hawkish central banks in Asia, raising concerns about capital outflows and currency volatility. The baht has declined to a 16-year low against the dollar, prompting the government to direct the finance ministry to "talk" with the central bank.

site_title: Hong Kong home prices drop 2.3% in August to lowest in 3½ years
summary: Hong Kong's private home prices dropped 2.256% in August to the lowest since February 2019, hurt by rising interest rates. The 6.5% decline in the first eight months of the year marks the first fall since 2008. Experts predict a 10% drop in home prices for the full year, with a weak global economy and rising mortgage costs contributing to the market softening. The city's financial chief remains optimistic, but analysts expect a moderate decline until better economic conditions are achieved.

images.alt_text: Evergrande has introduced Shenzhen Longgang Ancheng Investment Operation into four developments situated in the Longgang district.
China’s home prices slumped for the 12th straight month in August.

site_title: Dymon Asia PE closes third fund at US$650m as investors take a long view amid uncertainties
summary: Dymon Asia Private Equity (DAPE) has closed its third fund at a hard cap of US$650 million, exceeding its initial target of US$550 million. Despite a tepid macroeconomic outlook, investors, including public pension funds and family offices, showed strong demand for the fund. DAPE will focus on privatisations, management-led buyouts, and growth capital investments in South-east Asian companies, particularly in sectors benefiting from a growing middle class, such as healthcare and education.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Singapore O&G gets S$0.295-a-share takeover offer from vehicle linked to Dymon Asia

site_title: BTS’ managing agency loses US$10b since peak as stock slides
summary: BTS' managing agency, Hybe, has seen its market value drop by US$10 billion after its stock price slid 7.9% to 129,000 won, below its initial public offering price of 135,000 won. The decline is attributed to concerns over the group's looming military service, which could last at least a year and a half, and the potential impact on their work. The agency's reliance on BTS has also raised investor worries. The stock has been on a downward trend this year, with the group's oldest member, Jin, needing to enlist before the end of the year.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Corp
summary: A new wholly-owned subsidiary of Keppel's infrastructure arm is partnering with Mitsubishi Heavy Industries and DNV to explore the adoption of an ammonia-fired gas turbine on Jurong Island in Singapore. The study aims to assess the feasibility of an ammonia-fuelled power plant. As a result, Keppel Corporation's shares closed 0.6% lower at S$6.97 on Tuesday.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

A worker stands in front of the Floatel Triumph, a semi-submersible accommodation rig operated by Floatel International Ltd. and developed by Keppel Offshore & Marine Ltd.'s deep water technology group, during a media tour in Singapore, on Friday, March 11, 2016. Keppel Corp., parent company of Keppel Offshore & Marine, is the world's biggest builder of oil rigs. Photographer: Nicky Loh/Bloomberg

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 6.31 points or 0.45% to 1,404.56, with volume reaching 129.27 million lots worth RM67.69 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 185 to 122, marking a lower opening for Malaysian shares on Wednesday.

site_title: NEA’s direct emissions fall 20% on scale-down of Tuas Incineration Plant operations
summary: Singapore's National Environment Agency (NEA) reported a 20% drop in direct carbon emissions for its 2021 fiscal year, attributed to the scaling down of operations at the Tuas Incineration Plant. The plant ceased operations in February after the commissioning of a new plant, TuasOne, which generates 120 MW of electricity and can power 240,000 flats. NEA's Scope 1 emissions fell to 635,482 tonnes, while Scope 2 and 3 emissions remained largely unchanged.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting

At the International Solid Waste Association (ISWA) World Congress on Wednesday (Sep 21), Minister Grace Fu said the Government sees it as a priority to “get our economic policies right, to signal that there is a high environmental cost to unsustainable practices”.

This undated handout photograph released by Singapore's national water agency PUB on July 14, 2021 shows an aerial view of Sembcorb energy company's new floating solar power farm at Tengeh reservoir in Singapore. site_title: HSBC doubling down on South-east Asia, targeting double digit growth
summary: HSBC is targeting double-digit growth in South-east Asia, with strong growth seen across all segments and countries. The bank's global commercial banking division saw a 14% year-on-year revenue growth in the first half of 2022, with Asia contributing $12.2 billion of the group's pre-tax profit in 2021. HSBC is placing greater emphasis on the region as it aims for growth beyond traditional markets, targeting new business segments such as small and medium-sized enterprises, technology, and sustainable finance. The bank has launched tech funds in Singapore and South-east Asia, and is considering a launch in Australia.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: China real estate shares, bonds slump on report of CIFI default
summary: China's real estate sector slumped on Wednesday after a report that CIFI Holdings defaulted on debt, triggering a sell-off in shares and bonds of property firms, including CIFI, Sunac Real Estate, and Gemdale. The Hong Kong-listed shares of CIFI Holdings plummeted 26% to a record low, while a mainland developer index tumbled over 5%. The crisis-stricken sector remains plagued by investor pessimism, despite Beijing's efforts to aid it. The default raises concerns about the industry's ability to recover amid a bearish market and sluggish property sales.

images.alt_text: China’s home prices slumped for the 12th straight month in August.
The Beijing-based developer is struggling to repay its creditors and it is undergoing an offshore debt restructuring after defaulting some dollar bonds this year.

site_title: Thai factory output rises 14.52% in August, beats forecast
summary: Thai manufacturing production index rose 14.52% in August, exceeding forecasts of a 10.1% increase, driven by easing of Covid-19 curbs. This follows a revised 6.39% rise in July. The unexpected growth is attributed to the relaxation of restrictions, which boosted factory output.

site_title: Indonesia’s central bank guarding against excessive rupiah falls: official
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, is taking measures to guard against excessive falls in the rupiah exchange rate, following a 0.9% drop to 15,260 per dollar, its weakest since April 2020. The bank's "triple intervention" strategy includes intervening in the domestic nondeliverable forward market and conducting "operation twist" in the bond market, aiming to maintain market stability and prevent wild depreciation. The moves come amid market jitters due to hawkish US Federal Reserve statements and reports of a potential OPEC+ oil output cut.

images.alt_text: Asian currencies have tumbled this year as Fed rate hikes have bolstered the dollar.
The study highlights challenges that financial institutions face in assessing the suitability of corporate plans and projects for transition finance.

site_title: Why the British pound is getting pounded
summary: The British pound has plummeted in value following Prime Minister Liz Truss's announcement of a neo-Reaganite "fiscal event," which includes tax cuts to aid families hit by higher energy bills. This reaction is unusual for an advanced economy, where investors typically expect governments to cover deficits through fiscal measures rather than monetary policy. The Bank of England's reluctance to raise interest rates to offset inflationary pressures may be due to concerns about the impact on homeowners, who have floating-rate or soon-to-be-refinanced mortgages. This could limit the bank's ability to contain inflation, raising concerns about the long-term stability of the pound.

images.alt_text: epa10173056 British Prime Minister Liz Truss leaves Downing Street for the House of Commons to pay tributes to Queen Elizabeth II in London, Britain, 09 September 2022. Britain's Queen Elizabeth II died at her Scottish estate, Balmoral Castle, on 08 September 2022. The 96-year-old Queen was the longest-reigning monarch in British history.  EPA-EFE/TOLGA AKMEN
Britain’s Treasury department said the November announcement would detail government plans to cut debt in the medium term.
Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer Kwasi Kwarteng unveiled an anti-inflation budget at the House of Commons in London on Sep 23, 2022.

site_title: Serene Centre to go up for sale; Sultan Plaza plans to lower en bloc reserve price
summary: Serene Centre, a 4-storey mixed-use development near Bukit Timah Road, will be put up for sale via tender on Sep 29 with a reserve price of S$120 million. The property, owned by a single family, spans 32,225 sq ft and is zoned for commercial and residential use. The sale follows a similar move by the owners of Sultan Plaza, who plan to lower their reserve price.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
The site is located in the downtown District 7 and is a 5 minutes walk to Nicoll Highway and Lavender MRT stations.

site_title: Australia posts fiscal boost from exports; surplus still distant
summary: Australia reported a significantly improved budget outcome for fiscal 2022, with a deficit of A$32 billion (1.4% of GDP) in the year through June, a A$47.8 billion improvement on forecasts. The budget boost was due to surge in commodity prices following Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Treasurer Jim Chalmers dismissed prospects for the books to return to the black over the next 4 years, citing a deteriorating global economy and intensifying spending pressures.

images.alt_text: Data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics on Wednesday showed retail sales rose 0.6 per cent in August from July to a record A$34.9 billion (S$32.4 billion).

site_title: Australian retail sales keep defying gravity with August jump
summary: Australian retail sales rose 0.6% in August to a record A$34.9 billion, defying expectations and inflation, with consumers spending on household goods and eating out. This marks a 19.2% increase from August last year, driven by the food industry and household goods. The strong sales data may reassure the Reserve Bank of Australia that it can continue raising interest rates without tipping the economy into recession, despite a 2-1/2 year low in the Australian currency.

images.alt_text: The RBA is seeking submissions from industry participants ranging from financial institutions, fintech, public sector agencies and technology providers.

site_title: Yuan at 2008 low fuels speculation monetary easing to slow
summary: The yuan has fallen to its weakest level since the 2008 global financial crisis due to the PBOC's policy divergence with the US Federal Reserve, fueling capital outflows. This has sparked speculation that the PBOC will slow monetary easing to avoid further currency pressure, potentially complicating China's efforts to shore up its economy. Economists predict a slowdown in GDP growth to 3.4% this year, the slowest pace in over 4 decades.

images.alt_text: This move follows other steps authorities have taken to put a floor under the yuan, which is down more than 11 per cent against a US dollar.

site_title: UK shop price inflation speeds up again to new high: BRC
summary: UK shop price inflation accelerated to a new high of 5.7% in the 12 months to September, driven by a 10.6% jump in food prices due to the Ukraine war. This is the highest rate since 2005. Consumers expect to be moderately or severely affected by the cost-of-living crisis, leading to cautious spending. The UK's consumer price index hit a 40-year high of 10.1% in July, and the slump in the value of the pound is expected to further inflate imported goods prices.

site_title: Apple ditches iPhone production increase after demand falters: sources
summary: Apple has cancelled plans to increase iPhone 14 production by 6 million units in the second half of the year, citing weaker-than-expected demand. The company will now aim to produce 90 million handsets, matching its original forecast from this summer. Demand for higher-priced iPhone 14 Pro models is stronger than for entry-level versions, with some suppliers shifting production capacity to premium models. The news led to a decline in US stock-index futures and impacted chipmakers and Apple's suppliers.

images.alt_text: Apple made the announcement on Monday (Sep 26), less than 3 weeks after the iPhone 14’s unveiling.

site_title: Bitcoin reserve linked to fugitive Do Kwon denies moving tokens
summary: A Bitcoin reserve linked to fugitive Do Kwon denied transferring tokens after South Korean prosecutors sought to freeze assets. The reserve, Luna Foundation Guard (LFG), stated it hadn't created new wallets or moved tokens since May 2022. Prosecutors froze 3,313 Bitcoins worth about $67 million, linked to Kwon, wanted in South Korea for securities law violations amid the collapse of his Terraform Labs ecosystem. Kwon's location remains unknown, with Interpol assistance sought.

images.alt_text: South Korean officials have accused Do Kwon and 5 others of crimes including breaches of capital-markets law.

Prosecutors said Kwon is not cooperating with probes and he told investigators via an attorney he had no intention to appear before them for questioning, Yonhap said, citing people it didn’t identify.

site_title: Quality and standards adoption helped SMEs get an edge, access markets overseas: EnterpriseSG survey
summary: A survey by Enterprise Singapore found that 900 out of 1,000 small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) that adopted Singapore's quality and standards (Q&S) ecosystem reported a competitive edge and increased access to overseas business opportunities. The Q&S adoption helped companies differentiate their offerings, increase exports, and gain international business opportunities. Companies like Jurong Cold Store, which adopted the SS 668 cold chain management standards, found overseas opportunities through Q&S. EnterpriseSG plans to strengthen Singapore's Q&S ecosystem to help SMEs build trust in their products and services, focusing on digitalisation, sustainability, and resilience.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim

veocbc31 - Christie Chu, head of emerging business and commercial banking cash, global commercial banking, at OCBC

Credit: OCBC

site_title: US: Wall Street ends mixed following days of losses
summary: US stocks closed mixed on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.4% and the S&P 500 hitting a new low for the year. Despite five straight days of declines, the Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.3% to a fresh record. The Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes have fueled recession concerns, while inflation data showed a mixed picture, with orders for big-ticket goods slipping but new home sales surging. Consumer confidence jumped nearly five points in September, but economists remain skeptical about the sustained increase.

images.alt_text: People walk past the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) on Wall Street on July 12, 2022 in New York City. (Photo by ANGELA WEISS / AFP)

NEW YORK, NEW YORK - AUGUST 29: Stock trader Peter Tuchman works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange during afternoon trading on August 29, 2022 in New York City. Stocks opened lower this morning continuing the downward trend of last week after the Dow closed falling 1,008 points after Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's remarks on inflation at the central bank’s annual Jackson Hole economic symposium. site_title: Deflation looms in China amid property crisis, survey shows
summary: China faces increasing risks of deflation due to an ongoing property crisis, despite a slight increase in wages and input costs. The country's home prices slumped for the 12th straight month in August, and homeowners are citing concerns over construction and noise pollution to boycott mortgage payments. A private survey by China Beige Book International found that companies reported the weakest growth in sales prices since 2020, with the manufacturing industry also showing deteriorating indicators. The report warns of a "new era of much slower growth" for China.

images.alt_text: Analysts expect more stimulus for the property market as authorities seek to rescue the ailing industry.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks begin on a negative note
summary: Hong Kong stocks began trading on a negative note, with the Hang Seng Index falling 0.88% to 17,703.39, tracking losses in New York and Europe due to recession fears. The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also declined, with the Shanghai Index slipping 0.15% and the Shenzhen Index easing 0.28%. The decline follows a mixed session in US markets, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Chinese snap up used Rolexes, Birkins to satisfy luxury cravings amid slowdown
summary: China's luxury goods market is experiencing a surge in demand for pre-owned items, particularly handbags and watches, as consumers seek to sell or buy luxury goods amid economic slowdown. Second-hand luxury platforms like ZZER and Feiyu have seen a 40% increase in consigners and 5 million luxury pieces expected to be sold this year. The trend may impact the strategies of luxury goods makers, with consultancy Digital Luxury Group suggesting that China's interest in the resale market could "move the needle" for brands. China's second-hand luxury market is expected to grow to $30 billion by 2025.

images.alt_text: The Tambour's drum-shaped case and applied horns make it a sought-after timepiece.

A staff places watches in a display on March 18, 2015 at the booth of Swiss watchmaker Rolex during the watch industry's biggest annual trade show BaselWorld in Basel. After years of strong growth of watchmaker Baselworld opens this year on a uncertain mood, with the competition of the connected watch.  AFP PHOTO / FABRICE COFFRINI (Photo by FABRICE COFFRINI / AFP)
To mark its 190th anniversary, Longines has elected the Master collection to headline its commemorative offerings, by way of three exclusive and distinguished creations.
Oyster Perpetual Rolex Day-Date 40

site_title: Australia: Miners, energy stocks lift shares despite recession jitters
summary: Australia's shares rose 0.2% on Wednesday, driven by strong commodity prices, particularly in energy and mining sectors. The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 0.2% as oil prices jumped due to US supply curbs ahead of Hurricane Ian. Miners and energy stocks surged, with Woodside Energy and Santos advancing 3.5% and 0.9% respectively. Despite recession jitters, Australian shares continued to climb, with healthcare stocks being the top percentage losers.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index closed 0.4 per cent higher.

site_title: Celsius CEO resigns as bankrupt crypto firm works to survive
summary: Celsius Network's CEO Alex Mashinsky is stepping down amid the company's bankruptcy proceedings. The move comes after Celsius filed for bankruptcy protection in July and has been mired in controversies, including a lawsuit calling it a "Ponzi scheme." CFO Chris Ferraro has taken over as interim CEO and chief restructuring officer. The company is working to recover funds for investors, with a committee of unsecured creditors seeking to pursue claims against Mashinsky and other executives.

images.alt_text: Celsius has filed for bankruptcy in July, a high profile casualty of this year’s meltdown in digital assets.
Celsius currently owns 11 different forms of stablecoin, for a total of about US$23 million.

site_title: Toyota to start selling small electric sedan in China by year-end: sources
summary: Toyota plans to start production and sales of its small electric sedan, the bZ3, in China by year-end, as part of its collaboration with Chinese company BYD. The car uses BYD's less bulky Blade batteries, making it a more feasible option for a sedan configuration. The bZ3 will be priced around 200,000 yuan (approximately $40,023), nearly 30% below an entry-level Tesla Model 3, and will be produced at a rate of 30,000 vehicles per year in Tianjin. This marks Toyota's second electric vehicle model in its "Beyond Zero" series.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Toyota logo is displayed at the 89th Geneva International Motor Show in Geneva, Switzerland March 5, 2019. REUTERS/Pierre Albouy/File Photo

(FILES) In this file photo taken on March 9, 2012, workers assemble the front bumper of Toyota's compact hybrid vechile "AQUA" on the assembly line of the Kanto Auto Works' Iwate plant in Kanegasaki, Iwate prefecture. - The global microchip shortage dragging on the auto industry has put barely a dent in production at Toyota, the world's biggest automaker, thanks to lessons it learned after Japan's 2011 tsunami disaster. (Photo by Toshifumi KITAMURA / AFP)

site_title: Crypto billionaire Bankman-Fried eyeing bid for Celsius assets
summary: Crypto billionaire Sam Bankman-Fried is considering bidding for the assets of bankrupt lender Celsius Network, according to a person familiar with his deal-making. This comes after Bankman-Fried's FTX crypto exchange acquired Voyager Digital's assets for $1.4 billion. Celsius, which filed for bankruptcy in July, owns Bitcoin mining operations and a crypto custody business. The company's token jumped 9.9% before retreating, and Bankman-Fried's crypto companies are exploring a potential bid for some or all of Celsius's assets.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.32% at 26,485.89, and the Topix index down 0.41%. This follows mixed US market performance, with the S&P 500 notching a new low for the year. The decline is attributed to uncertainty surrounding the US-EU trade talks and tariff concerns.

site_title: Asian central banks need broader FX defence as reserves slide
summary: Asian central banks are likely to diversify their foreign exchange (FX) defenses as their reserves continue to slide, driven by Federal Reserve rate hikes bolstering the dollar. Analysts at Nomura Holdings suggest alternative methods such as mandating exporters to sell foreign-currency proceeds, restricting trade accounts, and boosting capital inflows. Several Asian countries, including India, China, Thailand, and South Korea, have already spent billions of dollars supporting their currencies, with some reserves dwindling to more than 10% of their end-2021 levels.

images.alt_text: Asian currencies foreign exchange Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg
The cryptocurrency has risen 6.5 per cent over the past seven days, a surprisingly strong run that has caught the eye of crypto bulls and bears.

site_title: Gold prices drop on firmer dollar, hawkish Fed talk
summary: Gold prices dropped 0.3% to $1,624.81 per ounce, as the US dollar surged to a 20-year high, amid Federal Reserve officials' hawkish stance on inflation. Rate hikes have reduced gold's appeal, with benchmark US 10-year Treasury yields reaching a 12-1/2-year high. Minneapolis Federal Reserve Bank president Neel Kashkari and Chicago Fed president Charles Evans reiterated the central bank's determination to combat inflation, further supporting the dollar's climb.

images.alt_text: China’s net gold imports via Hong Kong jumped nearly 40 per cent to an over 4-year high in August.

site_title: Jaguar Land Rover sets out to train workers, dealers for EV world
summary: Jaguar Land Rover plans to retrain 29,000 employees and retailers globally over the next 3 years to adapt to the shift to electric vehicles (EVs). The company aims to provide fresh skills in designing, building, and servicing EVs. This move aims to address emerging skills gaps and mitigate concerns about job losses in the auto industry due to fewer moving parts in EVs. The retraining program will focus on servicing EVs, with most technicians expected to receive training by the end of the financial year.

images.alt_text: Like other carmakers, BMW has had to contend with shortages of semiconductors and supply chain disruptions related to the pandemic that have slowed the production of EVs.
Leapmnotor will have a market capitalisation of US$6.99 billion to US$9.03 billion based on the price range flagged to investors.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip as UK adds to rate hike worries
summary: Europe's stock market declined 0.1% on Tuesday, extending a sell-off driven by recession fears and aggressive central bank policy tightening. Germany's DAX slipped 0.7% to November 2020 lows, while Italy's MIB index lost 1.2%. The UK's FTSE index fell 0.5% due to concerns over the "mini budget." Analysts warn that the Bank of England's rate hikes may impact the pound, and a global economic downturn is feared.

images.alt_text: London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index rose 0.3 per cent to 7,041.74 points.

site_title: Saudi king names crown prince as prime minister
summary: Saudi Arabia's King Salman named his son and heir Prince Mohammed bin Salman as prime minister and his younger brother Prince Khalid as defence minister in a royal decree. This reshuffle keeps other key ministers unchanged. Prince Mohammed, known as MbS, has been the de facto ruler of Saudi Arabia since 2017, implementing reforms while facing criticism for a crackdown on dissent and strained relations with the US and Western allies.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia – one of the world’s largest oil exporters – seeks to increase the role that environmental, social and governance principles play in its investments.

site_title: Pie from the sky: drone delivery lands in America
summary: Drone delivery services have begun operating in parts of the US, with flying shipments of pizzas and birthday gifts available in some areas. Although tech leaders initially predicted widespread adoption, it has not yet become the norm. Proponents argue that drone delivery is safer and more environmentally friendly than traditional delivery methods. Government regulation is catching up, with the service expected to gain traction in the future.

images.alt_text: A senior Pentagon official said the United States and India will co-develop drones as Washington seeks closer ties with Delhi as a way of countering China.

site_title: Japan’s businesses brace for long-awaited return of tourists
summary: Japan's tourism industry is set to reopen on October 11, with businesses preparing for a rebound in visitor traffic. After the pandemic, Japan's tourism sector suffered significantly, with 4,000 enterprises folding due to lockdowns. The country's affordable and attractive destination, combined with the yen at quarter-century lows against the dollar, is expected to attract overseas visitors. However, uncertainty remains, with limited reopening in June failing to attract meaningful traffic, and staffing shortages complicating the issue. Domestic travel is also picking up, with many residents taking advantage of affordable prices.

images.alt_text: That level of so-called “herd immunity” reflects partial protection imparted from both natural infection and vaccination, according to the Tokyo Foundation of Policy Research.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at open after Wall Street ends mixed; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.3% to 3,155.06 at open, tracking a mixed Wall Street performance. The S&P 500 closed 0.2% lower, while the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.3%. Banking stocks declined, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC losing 0.9%, 0.6%, and 0.3% respectively. European shares also fell, with the Stoxx 600 index down 0.1%.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

A new wholly-owned subsidiary of Keppel's infrastructure arm is tying up with Japan’s Mitsubishi Heavy Industries (MHI) and DNV to explore the adoption of an ammonia-fired gas turbine on Jurong Island in Singapore.

site_title: Meta says it removes China-based propaganda operation targeting US midterms
summary: Meta has removed a China-based propaganda operation targeting US users ahead of the midterm elections, with the network maintaining fake accounts on Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter. The operation, which posed as liberal and conservative Americans, posted political content and engaged with public figures since November 2021. This marks a shift towards more direct interference in US domestic politics, with messages aimed at Americans on divisive issues. Meta did not identify the individuals behind the operation, and US Attorney General Merrick Garland expressed concern over foreign government election interference.

images.alt_text: The company, which owns Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp, has avoided outright layoffs.

site_title: Bitcoin steady as currencies around the world tumble
summary: Bitcoin has risen 6.5% over the past seven days, outperforming other currencies as the dollar tumbles. Despite being volatile earlier, Bitcoin has become relatively calm, catching the eye of crypto bulls and bears. This strong run contrasts with the decline of rival currencies, such as the British pound, and tech-heavy stocks, like the Nasdaq. Bitcoin has lost over half its value in 2022, but its recent performance suggests it may be less volatile than traditional assets.

site_title: Crypto advertising can skirt ban via Singapore Grand Prix loophole
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) has allowed cryptocurrency platform ads to return at the Singapore Grand Prix, despite a ban on marketing services to the public. The regulator has deemed sponsored team logos and equipment as exempt from the guidelines, citing that the displays are not targeting the Singapore public. This move has sparked concerns about the difficulty of regulating international brands on the local stage, echoing parallels with tobacco advertising in motorsports.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
The new rules include clearly showing investment risks in advertisements and providing a balanced view of potential risk and returns, the SEC said in statement on Thursday (Sep 1).
Austraslian Treasurer Jim Chalmers said that his department would undertake “token mapping”, or cataloguing the types and uses of digital currency owned within the country.
“(Consumers) seem to be irrationally oblivious about the risks of cryptocurrency trading,” Menon said at a seminar on the digital asset ecosystem in Singapore.

site_title: Oil rises 2% from multi-month low on US Gulf output cuts, supply outlook
summary: Oil prices rose 2% from a nine-month low on Tuesday, settling at $86.27 a barrel, driven by supply curbs in the US Gulf of Mexico ahead of Hurricane Ian and the US dollar's easing from a 20-year high. Analysts expect Opec+ to meet on October 5 to set policy, potentially leading to supply cuts. US offshore oil production shut-in about 11% of oil production in the US Gulf of Mexico, but prices may rebound once production resumes.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures for November settled down US$2.09, or 2.4 per cent, to US$84.06 a barrel on Monday, plunging below levels reached on Jan 14.
According to Aramco's chief executive, the oil market is not in balance, and supply is getting tighter because there is little new supply to make up for natural depletion.

site_title: China lacks the right workers to boost Xi’s favoured tech jobs
summary: China's tech giants are struggling to find skilled workers as a regulatory crackdown, economic slowdown, and Covid lockdowns force them to cut thousands of jobs. Hiring momentum has shifted to emerging industries favored by Beijing, including electric vehicles, bio-pharmaceuticals, and artificial intelligence, where job postings have surged 382% over the past year. However, a skills mismatch in the highly-educated workforce is hindering the transition, with many former Internet sector employees lacking the skills to pivot into these emerging industries. This has led to a high rate of unemployment, particularly among young people, and may slow advancements in prioritized industries facing a talent shortage.

images.alt_text: Foreign trade is losing momentum as demand wanes at home and abroad.
PPI, which is strongly correlated with industrial profits, has been dragged by falling commodity prices and production disruptions, which in August were in part attributable to power shortages.

site_title: US regulators fine 16 Wall Street firms US$1.8b for discussing deals on personal devices
summary: US regulators fined 16 major Wall Street firms, including Bank of America, Citigroup, and Goldman Sachs, a combined $1.8 billion for discussing business deals on personal devices and apps from January 2018 to September 2021. The firms failed to preserve these communications, violating federal rules, and impeded investigations. The Securities and Exchange Commission and Commodity Futures Trading Commission imposed the largest collective resolution, with the institutions admitting to the facts and cooperating with the investigation. They have implemented improvements to their compliance policies and procedures.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo a sign for Bank of America is seen on 3rd Avenue in New York City, on May 11, 2018. - Bank of America announced plans to lift its minimum wage to $25 an hour and said on May 18, 2021 it is requiring US vendors to pay employees at least $15 an hour. The salary hike for employees will take place by 2025, the company said. In March 2020, the giant US bank lifted its minimum wage to $20 an hour from $17 an hour. (Photo by HECTOR RETAMAL / AFP)
Wall Street institutions faced challenges in tracking staff communications in the work-from-home pandemic era, particularly over personal devices.

site_title: House sales collapse as UK lenders withdraw mortgage offers
summary: UK lenders have withdrawn mortgage offers amid soaring interest rates, leading to a collapse in house sales. Major lenders, including Lloyds Banking Group and HSBC Holdings, have halted or temporarily stopped offering home loans. Analysts predict house prices could fall 10-15% due to interest rate increases. Some hopeful buyers have had their mortgage offers fall through, and the market is expected to remain uncertain until the Bank of England's next interest rate decision.

site_title: Malaysia’s premium visa scheme draws thousands of applications ahead of Oct 1 launch
summary: Malaysia's premium visa scheme, the Premium Visa Programme (PVIP), has drawn thousands of applications ahead of its October 1 launch. The government expects at least 1,000 individuals to be granted the visa in the first year, generating RM200 million in estimated revenue and RM1 billion in fixed savings. Applicants must pay a one-off fee of RM200,000 and meet a minimum monthly income requirement. Despite concerns over the application process, business groups are eager to support PVIP applicants, and experts believe the scheme's potential lies in attracting wealthy investors for business opportunities or studying in Malaysia.

images.alt_text: Tan Ai Leng
Iskandar boleh

site_title: Singapore 4th in digital competitiveness, leads Asia’s rankings
summary: Singapore has moved up one spot to 4th place in the IMD World Digital Competitiveness Ranking, driven by improvements in tertiary education, research and development, and regulatory frameworks. The country ranked 1st in "technology" and retained its top spot in "regulatory framework," but struggled in "future readiness." East Asian economies, including Singapore, show high cybersecurity capacity, but all regions are far from being fully prepared to combat sophisticated cyberattacks.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng
Singapore climbs back up to be the world’s 3rd most competitive economy, after slipping from first to fifth place in 2021.

site_title: Thailand set for another rate hike as baht falls
summary: Thailand is expected to raise its policy rate for the second consecutive meeting, with a 25-basis-point increase to 1% predicted by 18 of 23 economists surveyed. The baht has weakened to its lowest level since 2006, losing about 12% this year, and policymakers aim to curb inflation pressures exacerbated by currency weakness. The central bank will also release its latest economic forecasts and assess the tourism industry, which accounts for about 12% of the country's GDP.

images.alt_text: A customer hands money to a vendor at a wet market in Bangkok. Photographer: Andre Malerba/Bloomberg
Thailand’s public debt is expected to be at 60.43 per cent of GDP at the end of the fiscal year.

site_title: UK 30-year bond yield surges above 5% for first time since 2002
summary: The UK's 30-year bond yield surged above 5% for the first time in 20 years, driven by concerns over the government's fiscal stimulus and the Bank of England's interest rate hikes. Investors are demanding higher yields to hold the nation's debt, with some betting on 4 additional interest-rate hikes by May to reach 6.25%. The selloff has wiped out billions in bondholder value and raises pressure on policymakers to respond to market fears, potentially leading to further turbulence.

images.alt_text: The Bank of England in London. Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg
Policyholders led by the Federal Reserve are unwinding ultra-easy policies, unleashing an extended plunge in markets.

site_title: Intel unveils new chips and software as it chases a comeback
summary: Intel unveiled new Core desktop processors and graphics semiconductors, aiming to regain its footing in the chip industry. The company's latest processors offer a significant boost for gamers and high-performance users, while a new graphics chip for data centers challenges Nvidia's dominance. CEO Pat Gelsinger is trying to restore Intel to its former dominance, despite the company's recent losses and a slump in PC demand. Intel is also focusing on partnerships and open ecosystems, with the introduction of the Intel Developer Cloud program.

images.alt_text: Mobileye makes chips for cameras and drive-assistance features and is seen as a prized asset as the car industry races towards fully automated vehicles.

site_title: JPMorgan doubles down on UK retail bank Chase
summary: JPMorgan Chase plans to double its workforce in the UK to at least 2,000 by the end of 2024, as part of its expansion of its fledgling British retail bank Chase. Despite losses and investor skepticism, the venture has attracted 1 million customers and £10 billion in deposits since its launch last September. CEO Sanjiv Somani aims to replicate this success in other international markets, including Germany, where JPMorgan is hiring retail bankers ahead of a potential launch.

images.alt_text: Truss has made a slew of expensive promises including a plan to freeze household bills that could reach £130 billion (S$183.3 billion), as well as a package to help businesses with their energy bills that could cost £40 billion.

Bank of America chairman and CEO Brian Moynihan testifies during a US House Financial Services Committee hearing titled “Holding Megabanks Accountable: Oversight of America’s Largest Consumer Facing Banks” on Capitol Hill in Washington, Sep 21, 2022.

site_title: What sets the crazy rich Chinese apart from other family offices in Singapore
summary: About 44% of new family offices in Singapore are from Greater China, driven by first or second-generation businesspeople with significant wealth tied to family businesses. These patriarchs and matriarchs are open to ideas and diversifying into the Asean region. Unlike their European and South-east Asian counterparts, they are typically driven by economic and political reasons. This shift is significant, as it marks a notable change in the demographics of Singapore's family offices.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng
Marina Bay Sands hotel, Central Business District and Marina Bay Financial Centre from the rooftop deck of Supertree Observatory at Gardens by the Bay on Oct 11, 2021.
Single family offices in Asia Pacific tend to participate in private equity at a later stage than their European counterparts, according to Credit Suisse.

GCB land prices have continued to soar in 2022, rising 8.9 per cent between H1 21 and H1 22, to average S$1,839 per square foot (psf) according to JLL. This reflects a recovery of 25.3 per cent from the Covid trough of S$1,468 psf in H2 20.

epa07757516 Chinese 100 yuan or renminbi (RMB) notes in Beijing, China, 05 August 2019. China's Yuan fell below the key level of seven to the US Dollar for the first time in eleven years, following the last week's US President Donald Trump's threat for more tariff on Chinese goods, according to media reports on 05 August 2019.  EPA-EFE/ROMAN PILIPEY
High net worth investors from China have been setting up family offices in Singapore.

site_title: US consumer confidence rises for second straight month in September
summary: US consumer confidence rose for a second month in September to 108, the highest since April, driven by relief at lower gas prices and a robust job market. The median forecast was 104.6. Expectations improved, while spending plans for major appliances and cars rose, while those for homes fell due to rising mortgage rates. Inflation expectations dropped to the lowest level since the start of the year.

images.alt_text: Soaring US inflation and supply chain snarls have challenged industry and consumers, causing a pullback in spending and investment.

site_title: Food security crisis an opportunity for reinvention in Asia
summary: A perfect storm of growing populations, war in Ukraine, climate change, and the Covid-19 pandemic is putting significant pressure on food security in Asia. The region, home to hundreds of millions of smallholder farmers, faces a perfect storm of challenges, including food inflation, supply chain disruptions, and protectionist policies. However, these issues also present opportunities for governments and businesses to build resilient, equitable, and sustainable food systems, with policy reforms, climate-smart agriculture, and empowering smallholder farmers being key ingredients for success.

images.alt_text: The severe drought in the Horn of Africa has pushed people to the brink of starvation says the head of the UN Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO).
Thai exporters have said a price cartel would be unfeasible and would make Thailand and Vietnam uncompetitive.

site_title: Less jostling and more deliberation by VCs as startup fever cools
summary: Venture capital (VC) funding for startups has slowed due to tough macroeconomic conditions, including the Russia-Ukraine conflict, inflation, and recession risks. Investors are scrutinizing financials and valuations, leading to reduced funding for startups in later stages. Instead, VCs are focusing on seed stage and Series A levels, and are demanding better margins and longer track records. This shift is expected to force startups to be more deliberate in their product-market fit, with a focus on profitability. While the funding environment is challenging, it may also lead to clearer decision-making and more opportunities for investors and founders.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Claudia Chong
Sharanya Pillai
Agritech is among the sectors that venture capitalist Jefrey Joe is bullish on.
Sea’s e-commerce arm Shopee is axing more employees as its parent company Sea faces pressure to turn profitable.

site_title: US manufactured goods orders fall for second straight month
summary: US-manufactured goods orders fell 0.2% in August, marking the second consecutive monthly decline, due to soaring inflation and supply chain snarls. Durable goods orders dropped to $272.7 billion, with a 0.9% decline excluding defense aircraft. However, resilient demand was seen in rising orders for vehicles, computers, and electrical equipment, which posted a 1.0% increase.

site_title: Fed’s Powell says there’s ‘real need’ for better crypto regulation
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell emphasized the need for better regulation of cryptocurrencies, citing the industry's "significant structural issues." He noted that while the current lack of regulation has prevented broader financial turmoil, this may not be the case in the future. Powell reiterated that the Fed is still deliberating on the idea of a digital currency and expects a multi-year process to decide on the issue. He also highlighted the need for regulation of stablecoins to ensure sufficient reserves and combat money laundering.

images.alt_text: The Fed’s determination to raise rates to levels that hammer inflation at the cost of sliding asset prices sent a chill across global markets.

site_title: Hollywood star, tech execs invest in Italian start-up Bending Spoons
summary: Italian start-up Bending Spoons has raised 340 million euros from investors including Hollywood actor Ryan Reynolds and former Vimeo CEO Kerry Trainor. The funding, which could be used for acquisitions, follows the company's 500 million downloads and 90 million monthly active users since its launch in 2013. Bending Spoons' apps, including video editing tool Splice and AI-powered image editor Remini, have been backed by Italian banks Intesa Sanpaolo and Banco BPM, and former Google executive Eric Schmidt.

site_title: Spain court orders Shakira to stand trial for tax fraud
summary: A Spanish court has ordered Colombian singer Shakira to stand trial on charges of tax fraud, accusing her of defrauding the country's tax office of 14.5 million euros (S$20 million) on income earned between 2012 and 2014. Prosecutors seek an 8-year sentence, while Shakira's lawyers claim she has paid 17.2 million euros and has no outstanding debts. The case centers on where Shakira lived during 2012-2014, with prosecutors claiming she was not a resident of Spain despite dating a Spanish citizen.

images.alt_text: India has seized US$725 million from the local bank accounts of Xiaomi after a probe found the Chinese smartphone giant unlawfully sent money abroad in the guise of royalty payments.

site_title: SMEs going digital, workers aiming to hone skills can get help under new schemes
summary: Singapore has launched two new digitalisation programmes, Rise for Business and Rise 2.0, to support small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and workers seeking to upskill. The programmes, run by Boston Consulting Group and SkillsFuture Singapore, offer up to 90% subsidy for training and digital skills enhancement. The initiatives aim to help businesses and workers adapt to digitalisation, improving productivity and competitiveness. Education Minister Chan Chun Sing emphasized the importance of business transformation and workforce transformation, stating that those who do not transform will not be motivated to reskill.

site_title: Elon Musk and Twitter dig for evidence as trial looms
summary: Elon Musk and Twitter are preparing for a high-stakes trial next month over Musk's bid to break his $44 billion buyout deal. Musk claims Twitter misled regulators and investors about the number of spam and bot accounts, as well as its growth measures. Twitter counters that Musk is trying to back out of the deal due to changing his mind. Both sides are digging for evidence to support their claims, with Musk seeking to prove Twitter's misrepresentations and Twitter seeking material or testimony to discredit Musk's excuses. The trial is set to take place in October.

images.alt_text: The tech groups on the losing end of Friday’s ruling include NetChoice and the Computer & Communications Industry Association, which count Meta Platform’s Facebook, Twitter and Alphabet’s YouTube as members.

Musk said on Monday that the company wanted to provide Starlink satellite broadband service - already provided to Ukraine for its fight against Russia’s invasion - to Iranians, and would ask for a sanctions exception.

James Morsch, a corporate litigator who is not involved in the court battle, said the lawyers for Elon Musk (above) will want to keep him focused on answering questions, but that can be a challenge with such a smart and opinionated witness.

site_title: US Education Department sued over Biden’s student loan cancellation plan
summary: The US Department of Education is being sued by the Pacific Legal Foundation over President Joe Biden's student loan cancellation plan. The plan, which aims to forgive $10,000 in student loans for millions of debt-saddled former college students, has been estimated to cost $400 billion. The lawsuit claims the plan is "flagrantly illegal" and was created without statutory authority or notice and comment procedure. The Education Department has not responded to a request for comment, while the White House defends the plan as fiscally justified due to a projected $1.7 trillion reduction in the federal deficit.

images.alt_text: U.S. President Joe Biden attends a performance by British rocker Elton John at the White House in Washington, U.S., September 23, 2022. REUTERS/Evelyn Hockstein

site_title: Wall Street’s Whatsapp probe set to result in historic fine
summary: US regulators are set to announce a settlement with Wall Street firms for failing to monitor employees using unauthorized messaging apps. The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) and Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) are expected to extract total fines of around $2 billion, a rare escalation from regulators. This marks one of the largest-ever penalties levied against US banks for record-keeping lapses, surpassing a $15 million penalty imposed on Morgan Stanley in 2006. The investigation stems from the challenges firms faced in tracking staff communications during the work-from-home pandemic era.

site_title: Chinese banks set to revive counter-cyclical factor in yuan fixing
summary: Chinese banks are being asked by the regulator to revive a counter-cyclical factor in their daily fixing rates for the yuan, aiming to slow the currency's decline. This adjustment, introduced in 2020, was abandoned as the yuan rose sharply, but may be reintroduced to stabilize the currency, which has fallen over 11% against the US dollar. The move follows other efforts by authorities to put a floor under the yuan. The 14 banks involved will start including the counter-cyclical factor in their fixing quotes, potentially helping to stabilize the currency's value.

images.alt_text: The onshore yuan has lost about 4 per cent over the past month, trading within 1 per cent of 7.2 per dollar, a level it hasn’t reached since 2008.

site_title: What will keep business leaders awake in 2023?
summary: Business leaders face multiple concerns in 2023, including supply chain disruptions, a talent crunch, and the uncertain landscape of a potential recession. The ongoing war in Ukraine and Covid-19 disruptions will continue to affect global supply chains, while inflation and labor shortages persist. Geopolitical contestations and their impact on globalization and international trade are also major concerns, with central banks and governments working to engineer a "soft landing" while taming inflation.

images.alt_text: US consumer prices rose again in August, raising the likelihood of another historically large interest-rate hike by the Federal Reserve.

site_title: Spirit of cooperation needed as South-east Asia gears up for trio of major summits
summary: South-east Asia is set to host three major international summits in November, including the Asean Summit, G20 Summit, and Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) meeting. World leaders, policymakers, and business leaders will gather over a 10-day period to address pressing global and regional issues, such as geopolitical uncertainty, rising tensions, and economic concerns. The summits aim to demonstrate strong leadership and wisdom to tackle these challenges, with the host nations, Cambodia, Indonesia, and Thailand, under pressure to deliver tangible outcomes. Key attendees include US President Joe Biden, Chinese President Xi Jinping, and Russian President Vladimir Putin.

images.alt_text: Special force police officers take part in a simulation emergency crisis of terrorist mass shooting drill for the upcoming regional APEC Summit in November, at a department store in Bangkok, Thailand, September 19, 2022. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha
Thailand announced in late August that the national daily minimum wage would go up by an average of 5 per cent from October – the first such increase since January 2020.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks eke out small gains by close
summary: Hong Kong shares closed marginally up on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 5.17 points to 17,860.31, as bargain-buying helped stabilize the market after recent losses. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains, while recession fears continue to weigh on the market.

site_title: Phil Mickelson is withdrawing from LIV golf suit against PGA
summary: Phil Mickelson and several other top golfers, including Talor Gooch, Hudson Swafford, and Ian Poulter, have withdrawn from an antitrust lawsuit against the PGA Tour. The lawsuit, filed by 11 players, accused the PGA of being an "entrenched monopolist" and sought to end its suspension of LIV Golf players. However, LIV has now sued the PGA, prompting the withdrawal of the original plaintiffs. The move may help ease tensions between the PGA and LIV Golf, which offers higher prize purses but has faced criticism for its Saudi Arabian backing.

site_title: Oracle to pay about US$23m to resolve a second SEC bribery case
summary: Oracle has agreed to pay approximately US$23 million to settle charges from the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) for violating the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. The case involves the company's units in Turkey, the UAE, and India using slush funds to bribe foreign officials in exchange for business. This is the second time Oracle has been charged by the SEC for violating the anti-bribery law, with a previous settlement in 2012. The US$15 million civil fine and US$7.9 million in disgorgement and interest will be paid to resolve the charges.

site_title: Chou Sean Yu set to succeed WongPartnership managing partner Ng Wai King
summary: WongPartnership has appointed Chou Sean Yu, the head of litigation and dispute resolution group, as deputy managing partner. This move signals his likely succession to Ng Wai King, who is set to retire, as the firm's managing partner. Ng, 56, will continue to lead the firm as chairman and managing partner, citing the support of his partners to extend his term beyond the age of 55. Chou, 52, will concurrently continue to serve as head of the litigation and dispute resolution group.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
Yeo was appointed senior counsel of the Supreme Court in 2000 at the age of 37.
SPACs' impact on Singapore market will depend on their long-term performance

site_title: Europe suspects sabotage as mystery gas leaks hit Russian pipelines
summary: Europe suspects sabotage behind mysterious gas leaks in two Russian pipelines under the Baltic Sea, sparking concerns over energy security. Leaks were discovered in the Nord Stream 1 and Nord Stream 2 pipelines, with Poland's Prime Minister attributing the incidents to sabotage. Russia denies involvement, but European officials warn of a possible escalation of the energy war. The leaks will likely scupper Europe's remaining gas supplies via Nord Stream 1 before winter, with gas prices rising amid concerns over supply and security.

images.alt_text: European buyers will need to purchase 90 per cent more LNG on the spot market than they have secured under long-term contracts, further ratcheting up competition with Asia.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher after brutal selloff
summary: Wall Street opened higher on Tuesday after a brutal selloff, with the S&P 500 rising 31.4 points, or 0.86%, to 3686.44, and the Nasdaq Composite rising 152.4 points, or 1.41%, to 10955.288. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 159.1 points, or 0.54%, to 29419.88, following five sessions of relentless selling due to worries of a rate-hike induced economic slowdown.

site_title: Asian Development Bank vows more help for crisis-hit Sri Lanka
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has pledged further financial support to crisis-hit Sri Lanka, following an emergency loan of $200 million. ADB President Masatsugu Asakawa said Sri Lanka's economy has contracted and is suffering from high inflation, affecting living standards. The bank is working closely with the government to support the country, with a staff-level agreement with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) nearing completion for a $2.9 billion loan. Asakawa also highlighted the risks of capital outflows and volatile portfolio capital movement, but expressed confidence in Asia's resilience against financial turmoil.

site_title: Can Reits do well as interest rates surge?
summary: Reits face challenges as interest rates surge, with higher borrowing costs and decreased demand for yield products. However, Reits can hedge their liabilities through acquisitions, asset enhancement initiatives, and debt management. Historically, Reits have grown their DPU despite rising interest rates, with some Reits such as Ascendas Reit and CapitaMall Trust increasing their DPU during periods of rate hikes. Reits with strong sponsors and a ready pipeline of properties can offset DPU declines through acquisitions and debt management, making them attractive investments despite the current economic environment.

images.alt_text: Retail investors have been a key driver in the locally-listed Reit ETFs for the past year, accounting for 44 per cent of Reit ETF holdings.

site_title: Singapore stocks track Wall Street lower; STI down 0.5%
summary: Singapore shares fell for the third consecutive session, with the Straits Times Index shedding 0.5% to 3,165.50. The market tracked overnight Wall Street losses, driven by rising bond yields and a strengthening US dollar. Financial conditions and valuations remain pressured, with the Fed's pledge to tighten liquidity. The top gainer was Genting Singapore, while Keppel DC Reit was the biggest loser.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
FOMC participants are now projecting US GDP growth of just 0.2 per cent for 2022, and 1.2 per cent for 2023

site_title: US sales of new homes unexpectedly rise in a break from downturn
summary: US sales of new homes unexpectedly rose 29% in August to a 685,000 annualized pace, according to government data. This marks a break from the downturn, despite mortgage rates hitting a 14-year high and cooling home-price appreciation. The median sales price of a new home was $436,800, up 8% from last year, the smallest increase since November 2020. The inventory of new homes for sale reached 461,000, the most since March 2008.

images.alt_text: A for sale sign is displayed outside a home under construction in the Norton Commons subdivision of Louisville, Kentucky, U.S., on Monday, March 23, 2020. Photographer: Luke Sharrett/Bloomberg

site_title: Asian women in US financial sector see race and gender as career hurdles, says study
summary: A study by The Association of Asian American Investment Managers found that 60% of Asian women in the US financial sector reported their race as a career hurdle, particularly at senior levels. The "bamboo ceiling" limits the advancement of Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders, with 62% of AAPI women surveyed saying race became a bigger impediment later in their careers. Despite industry efforts to boost diversity, biases about gender and race continue to block AAPI women from executive roles, with industry leaders acknowledging a lack of significant progress in promoting Asian women to senior positions.

images.alt_text: Single family offices in Asia Pacific tend to participate in private equity at a later stage than their European counterparts, according to Credit Suisse.

site_title: Saudi wealth fund mandates banks for debut dollar green bond
summary: Saudi Arabia's sovereign wealth fund has mandated banks for its debut dollar green bond sale, aiming to increase environmental, social, and governance principles in investments. The PIF is working with banks BNP Paribas, Citigroup, Deutsche Bank, Goldman Sachs, and JPMorgan on the multi-tranche ethical sale. This move comes as Saudi Arabia seeks to diversify its economy away from oil exports and boost its reputation on environmental issues. The fund has been investing in businesses that benefit from a transition away from fossil fuels, such as renewable energy and electric vehicles.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed at 1,410.87, down 2.17 points on Tuesday, September 27. The index saw 2.283 billion lots worth RM1.923 billion in volume, with gainers outnumbering losers 427 to 392.

site_title: Singapore’s sovereign fund helps create Thailand’s latest unicorn
summary: Singapore's sovereign fund GIC led a US$265 million Series B funding round for Thai food and parcel delivery app Line Man Wongnai, valuing the company at over US$1 billion. The app competes with Grab Holdings and SCB X, and also offers business solutions for shops and restaurants. The funding will be used to expand into new services and hire more employees, marking Line Man Wongnai as Thailand's latest startup unicorn.

site_title: WTO chief warns world edging into 'global recession'
summary: WTO Director-General Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala warns the world is edging into a global recession due to multiple crises, including Russia's war in Ukraine, climate crisis, and Covid-19 pandemic aftermath. The World Bank and IMF have downgraded global growth forecasts, and trade indicators are "not looking too good." Okonjo-Iweala calls for radical policies to revive growth and restore economic stability, citing the need for central banks to take action to combat inflation and ensure food and energy security.

images.alt_text: The World Trade Organization said on Tuesday(Aug 23) that its global goods barometer was stable, pointing to stagnant global trade growth following a Covid-19 triggered slowdown.

site_title: US dollar pauses for breath as fragile pound edges up
summary: The US dollar experienced a brief pause in its recent climb, with sterling, the euro, and the Japanese yen recovering some ground from multi-year lows. Sterling rose 1% to US$1.0810, while the euro rose 0.2% to US$0.9629. The decline in the US dollar was attributed to a recovery in riskier assets and steady US treasury yields. However, medium-term fundamentals remain in favor of the US dollar, and experts predict it will continue to strengthen due to the Federal Reserve's hawkish stance and weakening global growth.

site_title: Hertz partners with BP to build out electric car charging network
summary: Hertz Global Holdings has partnered with BP to build a US-wide electric car charging network. The two companies aim to operate over 100,000 chargers by 2030, with 90% fast-charging. Hertz plans to electrify a quarter of its rental car fleet by 2024. The deal comes after Hertz agreed to buy 175,000 electric vehicles from General Motors and Tesla. The partnership is part of a growing network of 3,000 charging stations available to Hertz vehicles by the end of 2022, with BP to install chargers at 25 Hertz locations.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on October 25, 2021 people rent cars at a Hertz car rental counter in the Miami International Airport in Miami, Florida. - US rental car giant Hertz will buy up to 175,000 electric vehicles from General Motors by the end of 2027, the companies announced on September 20, 2022, as the auto industry grapples with concerns over climate change and petroleum dependency. (Photo by JOE RAEDLE / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / AFP)

site_title: Falling oil prices are about to reverse course
summary: Oil prices are expected to reverse course, reversing their recent decline. Despite warnings from Aramco's CEO Amin H Nasser that the oil market is not in balance and supply is getting tighter, oil prices fell due to traders bracing for a recession. However, some analysts, including JPMorgan and Goldman Sachs, expect oil prices to rebound to $101 and $125 respectively, citing tighter supply and increased demand for oil products in electricity generation. A shift in demand and supply dynamics is expected to drive oil prices higher, with some predicting prices could surge next year.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures for November settled down US$2.09, or 2.4 per cent, to US$84.06 a barrel on Monday, plunging below levels reached on Jan 14.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Corporates have been shelling out thousands for hospitality packages at the upcoming F1 weekend from Sep 30 to Oct 2. Demand is so high that 2 additional packages were launched and sold almost instantly. Meanwhile, Grab aims to turn profitable by the second half of 2024 in its adjusted Ebitda, while a report suggests sustainable investments could unlock Singapore's US$91b of retail capital potential. Keppel is also exploring the adoption of an ammonia-fired gas turbine on Jurong Island.

site_title: Carbon credits in compliance markets make poor strategic investments: Morningstar
summary: Morningstar Equity Research analysts found that compliance carbon markets are ineffective in raising the cost of emissions, as most cap-and-trade regimes fail to induce a price on carbon. Despite covering 17% of global greenhouse gas emissions, compliance markets have limited political appeal and often result in oversupplied credits, lowering the cost of emissions. This makes investments in carbon credits a poor strategic allocation. However, Morningstar suggests that voluntary carbon markets may yet be enticing for investors with ESG objectives, particularly if they buy credits at primary auctions to support clean energy projects.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
Mikkel Larsen, chief executive officer of Climate Impact X.
Budget 2022: Carbon tax set to rise to S$50-80 by 2030; watchers call surprise move 'bold', 'aggressive'
Sembcorp Energy India's two thermal power plants in Nellore District, Andhra Pradesh, have four 660-megawatt supercritical coal-fired units and a total installed capacity of 2.64 gigawatts.

site_title: Thai government plans 820 billion baht in new borrowing in 2023 fiscal year
summary: Thailand's government plans to borrow approximately 820 billion baht (S$31 billion) in the 2023 fiscal year to finance a budget deficit and bolster economic recovery. The borrowing is part of a debt management plan that includes existing debt of 1.74 trillion baht and debt repayment of 360 billion baht. The plan aims to stimulate the economy through infrastructure investment and mitigate the impact of global economic factors. Thailand's public debt is expected to reach 60.43% of GDP at the end of the fiscal year.
