images.alt_text: A Tuk-tuk driver waits for customers along the popular Yaowarat street in the Chinatown area of Bangkok on September 5, 2022. (Photo by MANAN VATSYAYANA / AFP)

site_title: King Charles banknotes won’t circulate until mid-2024
summary: The Bank of England announced that King Charles III's image will not be featured on UK banknotes until mid-2024, despite the royal family's guidance to minimize the environmental and financial impact of the change. Notes with Queen Elizabeth II's image will only be removed from circulation if worn or damaged, and coins featuring the late monarch will also be phased in gradually, co-circulating with coins featuring Charles. The transition to Charles' image on coins is expected to take at least several months.

images.alt_text: At Alliance Coin & Banknote in Almonte, Ontario, owner Sean Isaacs is preparing for an auction this month featuring some “significant” royal-themed items, including the 1935 Canadian $20 bill featuring then-Princess Elizabeth at the age of 8.

site_title: Singapore’s population grows 3.4% to 5.64 million, reversing 2 consecutive years of decline
summary: Singapore's population grew 3.4% to 5.64 million in June 2022, reversing two years of decline, according to the government's annual Population in Brief report. The resident population increased, driven by more people returning to Singapore after living abroad. Citizen births rebounded to 31,713 in 2021, while marriages increased by 20.6% to 23,433. The total fertility rate recovered slightly to 1.12 births per woman, but remains below the pre-Covid-19 level of 1.14 in 2019.

images.alt_text: Talent management concentrates on identifying and developing a small number of workers. Diversity management, on the other hand, promotes the inclusion of all.

site_title: Xi makes first public appearance since returning from overseas
summary: President Xi Jinping made his first public appearance since returning from a summit in Uzbekistan on September 16, reemerging in Beijing on September 27. He visited an exhibition about China's achievements over the past decade, wearing a mask. Xi's public appearance comes after a nearly 2-year absence, consistent with China's strict Covid protocols. His return to Beijing marks a significant development in the country's post-Covid recovery.

site_title: Stellantis and Uber join forces on electric vehicles market in France
summary: Stellantis, a carmaker, and Uber announced a partnership to focus on the French electric vehicles market. Free2Move will help Uber convert 50% of its fleet in France to electric models, while Stellantis aims to double its revenues to €300 billion by 2030. This move follows Uber's positive quarterly cash flow and forecasted third-quarter operating profit. The partnership aims to promote the production and sale of electric and hybrid vehicles, aligning with Stellantis' plans to drive growth in the electric market.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Stellantis is seen on a company's building in Velizy-Villacoublay near Paris, France, February 23, 2022. REUTERS/Gonzalo Fuentes/File Photo

site_title: India mulls US$2.5b aid to manufacture grid-scale batteries
summary: India's power ministry is proposing a $2.5 billion incentive plan to encourage domestic manufacturing of grid-scale batteries, aiming to reduce energy storage costs and speed up its energy transition. The plan, which could total 200 billion rupees, includes offering incentives to manufacturers for batteries produced over a certain time period. India is also in talks with countries like Australia to secure lithium supplies, and plans to promote other battery technologies to reduce reliance on China.

site_title: EU urges Italy to stick to programme as approves more funding
summary: The European Commission approved an additional 21 billion euros in post-Covid recovery funds for Italy, bringing the total to 192 billion euros. Italy has met 45 reform targets, including in public employment, procurement, and healthcare, to qualify for the funding. The new Italian government, led by Giorgia Meloni, must now stick to reform plans to ensure the funds are used effectively. Economy Commissioner Paolo Gentiloni urged the government to seize the opportunity to transform the Italian economy, while Meloni has hinted at the possibility of amending the programme to reflect the energy crisis.

site_title: Worst bond rout in decades intensifies with UK losing 27%
summary: The worst bond sell-off in decades intensifies with the UK losing 27% this year due to central banks' aggressive policies to combat high inflation. The Bloomberg Global Aggregate Total Return Index of investment-grade bonds has dropped for an eighth consecutive session, with inflation-linked debt shedding 29% in 2022. Policymakers, led by the Federal Reserve, are unwinding ultra-easy stances, fueling market turmoil. The US benchmark 10-year Treasury yield has reached a level not seen since 2010, and investors are bracing for potential currency volatility and economic crisis.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Chinese national flag flutters outside the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) building on the Financial Street in Beijing, China July 9, 2021. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Europe ready for a winter without Russian gas, BNEF says
summary: Europe is likely to have enough liquefied natural gas to offset Russian pipeline flows this winter, according to BloombergNEF. European buyers will need to purchase 90% more LNG on the spot market, further increasing competition with Asia. The region is expected to import 40 million tons of LNG this winter and 14% more next summer to rebuild inventories. This will support global gas prices and leave limited supply for Asia, with China and emerging markets seeing lower imports.

images.alt_text: The global LNG market has more than doubled in size since 2011, ushering in dozens of new entrants and the expansion of smaller players in Asia.

site_title: Inflation, conflicts weaken Myanmar’s economy, World Bank says
summary: Myanmar's economy is weakening due to high inflation and international sanctions, with a 3% expansion forecast for this year after a 18% contraction last year. Conflicts between pro-democracy groups and the military government are crimping domestic supply and demand, leading to frequent power outages and commodity shortages. The country faces a foreign currency shortage, price pressures, and logistics disruptions, which are straining household income and hindering economic recovery. The World Bank warns that policy uncertainties and the reversal of earlier reforms are inhibiting trade and investment in the country.

site_title: 15 strata units in International Plaza for sale at S$60m guide price
summary: A portfolio of 15 commercial units in International Plaza, consisting of 5 shop units and 10 office units, is up for sale via expression of interest with a guide price of S$60 million. The units offer high footfall and approved for food and beverage use. The sale highlights the limited supply of quality strata and shop office space in Singapore's central business district due to recent restrictions. Interested parties can acquire either the entire portfolio or individual strata units, providing a rare opportunity for investors to acquire prime strata commercial units with stable recurring income.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
International Plaza collective sale makes history with S$2.7b reserve price
International Plaza relaunched for sale with unchanged S$2.7b reserve price
International Plaza fails to get URA's nod for CBD Incentive Scheme
Singapore property investment sales could return to pre-Covid levels

site_title: Shenzhen government-owned firm steps in to complete 4 Evergrande projects
summary: China Evergrande Group has introduced Shenzhen Longgang Ancheng Investment Operation into four property developments in the Longgang district to complete them. The state-owned firm will assist with project construction to ensure timely delivery of homes to buyers, as instructed by authorities. This move aims to address concerns about the completion of Evergrande projects, which have been stalled due to financial difficulties. The partnership between Evergrande and Shenzhen Longgang Ancheng Investment Operation is expected to provide stability to the company's real estate projects.

site_title: ‘Waves’ musician Mr Probz files US$10m suit against Sony over royalties
summary: Mr. Probz, a Dutch musician, has filed a US$9.66 million lawsuit against Sony, alleging the company fraudulently withheld royalties. Sony deducted administration and distribution fees without permission, resulting in an underpayment of 3-6% on royalties. A 2020 court ruling ordered Sony to return control of Mr. Probz's music and allow his auditor access to documents. The lawsuit claims Sony's actions led to a significant loss of royalties, with Mr. Probz having around 5 million monthly listeners on Spotify. Sony denies the allegations and is reviewing the summons.

site_title: Seoul: Shares recover after 4 sessions on automakers' boost
summary: South Korean stocks ended slightly higher on Tuesday, snapping a 4-session losing streak, led by automakers' stocks. The Kospi index rose 2.92 points or 0.13% to 2,223.86, driven by gains from Hyundai Motor and Kia. The US dollar's gain eased, and investors bought oversold stocks, while the won jumped and the benchmark bond yield dropped. US Vice-President's assurance on addressing Seoul's concerns over electric vehicle subsidies also supported the market.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi was down 69.06 points or 3.02 per cent at 2,220.94, the lowest close since Jul 27, 2020.

site_title: Marine insurers adapt to new realities
summary: Marine insurers have reported a positive year in 2021, with global marine insurance premiums rising 6.4% to $33 billion, driven by increased global trade volumes, a stronger US dollar, and higher vessel values. However, the industry faces complex issues, including onboard fires, mis-declared cargoes, and worsening severe weather conditions, which increase the risk of large event losses. Insurers are also navigating the challenges of decarbonization and environmental, social, and governance (ESG) issues, with a growing focus on sustainability and verifiable data.

images.alt_text: The danger to whales comes more from the sheer volume of shipping now using the world’s oceans, and the speed and size of ships., rather than people trying to watch them.

site_title: Vietnam shuts airports, imposes curfews as Typhoon Noru nears
summary: Vietnam has closed airports, imposed curfews, and urged thousands to evacuate as Typhoon Noru approaches, with wind speeds expected to reach 183 km/h. Around 400,000 people were ordered to evacuate before the storm, with 270,000 military personnel on standby. The typhoon is expected to make landfall on Wednesday, causing widespread flooding and damage in the Philippines, where it killed at least eight people. The central provinces of Quang Ngai and Quang Nam are expected to be worst hit, with curfews in place in tourist cities like Danang and Hue.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - Waves generated by Typhoon Muifa along the coast in Hangzhou. China has higher exposure to physical hazards relating to climate change, including floods and tropical cyclones.

site_title: Japan’s Covid-19 herd immunity near 90% after Omicron wave: study
summary: Japan's Covid-19 herd immunity has reached approximately 90% in major population areas, according to a study by the Tokyo Foundation of Policy Research. This level of protection is attributed to both natural infection and vaccination. The high case counts in Tokyo, Osaka, and Okinawa led to most people gaining immunity through contagion. However, the protection is likely to diminish in a few months, and the 5-month interval for booster shots may be too long for vulnerable groups, prompting concerns for an upcoming eighth wave.

site_title: China regulators ask funds to stabilise markets before Communist Party Congress: sources
summary: China's securities regulators have instructed fund managers and brokers to avoid massive equity sales ahead of the Communist Party Congress, scheduled for October 16, to stabilize the market. The verbal guidance, known as "window guidance," aims to prevent big market fluctuations. The move comes as China's main stock benchmark has lost roughly 6% this month and over 20% this year, amid concerns over economic growth and geopolitical tensions. The regulators' efforts are seen as a bid to maintain market stability before the congress, where President Xi Jinping is likely to be anointed for a third term.

images.alt_text: Chinese bond funds have already seen their assets under management (AUM) jump 18 per cent during the first 7 months of the year, to 4.8 trillion yuan, the latest data shows.
The onshore yuan has lost about 4 per cent over the past month, trading within 1 per cent of 7.2 per dollar, a level it hasn’t reached since 2008.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher on commodities boost
summary: Australian shares ended 0.4% higher on Tuesday, driven by a commodity rally, despite weak sentiment due to global recession worries. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose, with miners and energy stocks leading the gains, while financials fell 0.3%. The rally was also supported by higher iron ore prices in China.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index advanced 0.5 per cent by 0016 GMT on Tuesday.

site_title: With flowers and a gun salute, Japan bids farewell to Abe
summary: Japan held a state funeral for former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, the first for an ex-premier in 55 years, with a 19-gun salute and thousands of mourners paying their respects. The ceremony, attended by 4,300 people, including US Vice-President Kamala Harris and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, was a contentious decision amidst controversy over Abe's ties to the Unification Church and his divisive policies. Despite opposition from many Japanese, Prime Minister Fumio Kishida defended the decision, saying it was a way to honour Abe's achievements and stand up for democracy.

images.alt_text: Hideyuki Teshigawara, general manager of the Japan branch of the Family Federation for World Peace and Unification (FFWPU), widely known as the Unification Church, speaks during a press conference at the FFWPU Tokyo headquarters on Sept 22, 2022.

site_title: Europe: Stocks climb at open
summary: Europe's stock markets rose at the start of trading on Tuesday, September 27, 2022, following gains in Tokyo. The FTSE 100 index in London increased 0.3% to 7,041.74 points, while the DAX index in Frankfurt rose 1.0% to 12,347.55 points and the CAC 40 in Paris advanced 0.7% to 5,807.60 points.

site_title: ‘Overinvested’ China healthcare sector set for shake up:  top venture fund
summary: China's massive healthcare sector, driven by pharmaceuticals and tech/biotech firms, is ripe for consolidation due to a decline in valuations following over-investments during the Covid-19 pandemic. A leading local venture capitalist notes that the sector's growth prospects have slowed, making it vulnerable to consolidation. Rising public and private spending has also contributed to the sector's growth, but the sharp decline in valuations presents an opportunity for firms to restructure and refocus. This shake-up could lead to more efficient operations and better returns for investors.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher, rebounding from rout
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Tuesday, rebounding from a rout, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index advancing 0.53% to 26,571.87. Investors sought bargains following fears of an economic slowdown, and the broader Topix index rose 0.47%. The gains followed sharp falls in the previous session.

site_title: Keppel ties up with Mitsubishi Heavy, DNV to explore ammonia-fuelled gas turbine
summary: Keppel New Energy, a subsidiary of Keppel Infrastructure, has partnered with Mitsubishi Heavy Industries and DNV to explore the use of ammonia-fueled gas turbines on Jurong Island in Singapore. The companies will study the feasibility of ammonia power plants and develop guidelines for the safe and sustainable use of ammonia as a clean fuel. Ammonia has a higher volumetric density than hydrogen and produces no carbon dioxide when fired, making it an efficient hydrogen carrier. The agreement follows Keppel Energy's plan to develop Singapore's first hydrogen-ready power plant.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: On bears, dragons and tigers: Diversification is the best defence
summary: Asian equities are likely to be impacted by a US bear market, following a pattern of previous cycles where Asian equities fell by an average of 24% during US declines of 20% or more. With the US Federal Reserve signaling a hawkish stance, investors should diversify their portfolios, actively manage them, and consider downside-hedging protection. The Asia-Pacific region's growth trajectories are expected to slow, with domestic-oriented economies potentially outperforming export-oriented ones, and earnings growth likely to decelerate alongside economic growth, leading to a downgrade cycle for Asian earnings.

images.alt_text: John Woods
A global slowdown may not even bring about a weaker dollar.

site_title: British banks pull mortgage deals with UK markets in turmoil
summary: British banks are withdrawing mortgage deals amid concerns the Bank of England will hike interest rates to support the pound. Virgin Money UK, Lloyds Banking Group, and Skipton Building Society have temporarily stopped making new mortgage loans, citing volatile market conditions. Specialist lender Paragon also withdrew some fixed-rate products. Experts predict mortgage rates will increase, with few fixed-rate mortgages available below 5% by next week.

images.alt_text: Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer Kwasi Kwarteng unveiled an anti-inflation budget at the House of Commons in London on Sep 23, 2022.
The UK housebuilders index fell 6 per cent to hit its lowest level since March 2013.
Housing has remained a bright spot in the economy, growing despite the recession that came with Covid-19 lockdowns.

site_title: Developer Sunac China seeks to extend payment for 4b yuan bond for the 3rd time: sources
summary: China property developer Sunac China is seeking its third extension of a 4 billion yuan (S$802 million) bond repayment, pushing back the deadline by 6 months to March 31, 2024. The move comes as the company struggles to repay creditors and undergoes offshore debt restructuring after defaulting on dollar bonds this year. The payment extension requires bondholder approval and will delay the last amortisation payment, originally due on September 30, 2023. Sunac had previously extended the principal payment by 18 months and reduced amortisation payments in June.

images.alt_text: It is the first winding-up petition known to have been filed against Sunac, a top 3 property developer by sales last year.
Cash-strapped property developer Sunac China is talking to investors about a second extension on part of an onshore bond payment due at the end of this month.

site_title: Australia to create national anti-corruption watchdog
summary: Australia's government plans to create a National Anti-Corruption Commission, with a proposed A$262 million funding over four years. The commission will investigate serious or systemic corruption by politicians and government employees, with retrospective powers and the ability to make findings or refer cases to law enforcement. The move aims to "restore trust and integrity in politics." A bill is expected to be introduced to parliament, following years of debate over the need for an independent watchdog.

images.alt_text: Star was accused of misleading the regulator and allowing a Macau-based junket operator, Suncity, to operate a prohibited money-for-chips desk.

site_title: New hospitality packages snapped up as corporates splurge on F1
summary: Demand for hospitality packages at the upcoming Singapore Airlines Singapore Grand Prix Formula 1 (F1) has been extremely high, with 2 additional packages launched and sold out almost instantly. The event's organiser, Singapore GP, reported that 3-day grandstand and combination tickets were sold out within 6 hours, and all 6 hospitality packages initially launched were fully booked. Corporates have been shelling out thousands for a spot at the event, with some packages priced at S$1,988 and S$6,300 per head. The event is expected to see a sell-out, with ticket sales already surpassing that of 2019.

images.alt_text: Hotel revenue at ParkRoyal Collection Marina  could surpass pre-Covid years due to the pent-up demand from visitors who have been eagerly anticipating the F1 's return to Singapore.
Singapore has reported some 3 million international visitor arrivals so far in 2022, against STB’s expectation of 4 to 6 million international visitors for the year announced in July.

For the upcoming Grand Prix, CGS-CIMB estimates that up to 35,000 tourists could make their way to Singapore’s shores, which could potentially fill 45 to 50 per cent of the island’s hotel room inventory.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 6.68 points or 0.47% to 1,419.72 as trading began on Tuesday, with a total volume of 169.82 million lots worth RM87.12 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 162 to 106.

site_title: China vows positive trade growth in the second half of the year
summary: China's foreign trade is expected to experience positive growth in the second half of 2022 despite slowing external demand, according to Vice Commerce Minister Wang Shouwen. Foreign trade is losing momentum due to waning demand at home and abroad, with August trade data showing weakening external demand and declining orders for Chinese trade firms. The economic growth of Europe and the US has slowed, increasing uncertainty for China's foreign trade. China's economic growth is also expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This file photo taken on June 22, 2021 shows cargo containers stacked at Yantian port in Shenzhen in China's southern Guangdong province. - China's export growth slumped in April to its lowest level in almost two years, customs data showed on May 9, 2022, as a Covid resurgence shuttered factories, sparked transport curbs and caused congestion at key ports. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

site_title: Shell sees 2024 global demand for aviation fuel return to level before pandemic
summary: Shell Aviation President Jan Toschka expects global aviation fuel demand to fully recover to pre-pandemic levels of 300 million tonnes per year in 1-2 years. US demand is back at 2019 levels, while Europe's consumption has recovered to over 80% and is on track for full recovery in the next year. However, Europe's jet fuel supplies are tightening due to EU sanctions on Russian oil products, causing increased imports from the US, China, India, and the Middle East.

site_title: Radical economic policy lands UK in crisis
summary: The UK is facing a financial crisis after Chancellor Kwasi Kwarteng's emergency budget, which included massive new spending and tax cuts, received the most negative reaction to any UK fiscal event in living memory. Markets have reacted negatively, with the pound trading below parity with the US dollar, and the Bank of England has ruled out an emergency interest rate rise. The crisis has raised concerns about the UK's economic strategy and has led to speculation about Kwarteng's future. The situation has also boosted Labour, with a new poll showing the party 17 percentage points ahead of the Conservatives.

images.alt_text: Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer Kwasi Kwarteng unveiled an anti-inflation budget at the House of Commons in London on Sep 23, 2022.

site_title: Fed hikes harming global markets, economy, ex-PBOC official says
summary: A former Chinese central bank official, Sheng Songcheng, warns that the US Federal Reserve's aggressive interest-rate hike cycle is destabilizing global financial markets and harming other economies. The Fed's decision has weakened major currencies and spurred capital outflows from developing countries, triggering deep-rooted problems in the global economic and financial system. Sheng argues that the Fed's hawkish stance is "harming others without benefiting itself" and that a more effective approach would be to accelerate shrinking the balance sheet while raising rates. This could contain inflation and reduce recession risks.

images.alt_text: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) building in Beijing. Source: Bloomberg

site_title: Sustainable investments could unlock Singapore’s US$91b of retail capital potential: report
summary: A report by Standard Chartered found that Singapore has a high potential for growth in sustainable investments, estimated at US$91 billion. Despite 37% of investors expecting to allocate more than 15% of their portfolios to sustainable investments, perceived low returns and higher risk remain the top barriers. Concerns over comparability and comprehensibility also hinder adoption. To address these concerns, Standard Chartered aims to provide professional advice and education to make sustainable investing more accessible and relevant to investors, ultimately unlocking the country's retail capital potential.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Asia’s green bond issuers look past pricing to branding and investor access
The Awwa School students, aged 15-16, were introduced to various job roles at the bank’s newly revamped flagship branch at Six Battery Road, such as that of a sales and services manager.
STACS' Benjamin Soh says the volume of green finance is on the rise, which raise demand for ESG data and monitoring services.
nature, earth, sustainability

site_title: Italy’s Meloni faces prime tests over Europe and Ukraine
summary: Giorgia Meloni, Italy's newly elected prime minister, faces key tests in maintaining Mario Draghi's European recovery program and cohesion in the G7 alliance against Russia's Ukrainian war. Meloni has toned down her nationalist rhetoric and backed Draghi's pro-EU stance, but her coalition with right-wing allies may hinder government stability. Italy's economy is doing better than expected, with strong growth and low unemployment, but large problems remain, including high public debt and stagnant productivity. Meloni must balance "Italy-first" policies with EU reforms and international commitments, with expectations of significant investment flows from the Next Generation EU program.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - Leader of Italian far-right party "Fratelli d'Italia" (Brothers of Italy), Giorgia Meloni reacts as she holds a placard reading "Thank You Italy" after she delivered an address at her party's campaign headquarters overnight on September 26, 2022 in Rome, after the country voted in a legislative election. - Far-right leader Giorgia Meloni won big in Italian elections on September 25, the first projections suggested, putting her eurosceptic populists on course to take power at the heart of Europe. (Photo by Andreas SOLARO / AFP)
Giorgia Meloni, leader of far-right Brothers of Italy party, looks likely to become the country's new prime minister after the election on Sunday.
Italy's Prime Minister Mario Draghi looks on during the debate on government crisis following his resignation the week before, at the Senate in Rome on July 20, 2022.

The first task for Giorgia Meloni, leader of the far-right Brothers of Italy, will be finding billions of euros to keep her election pledges to soften energy costs, cut taxes and block a hike in the retirement age due to kick in from January.

site_title: More roadmaps, stakeholder support needed for Asia’s transition finance: study
summary: A new study by the Asia Transition Finance Study Group (ATFSG) highlights the need for more guidelines, financing, and stakeholder support for transition finance in Asia. The study found that financial institutions face challenges in assessing corporate plans and projects for transition finance, and that governments should create decarbonisation pathways and technology roadmaps to support the transition. The report also emphasizes the need for incentives such as subsidizing corporate assessments, warranty periods, and carbon credits, and for governments to consider public financing options like concessional finance and blended finance.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Relatively newer sustainable bond markets around the globe are increasingly complementing sustained growth in more seasoned markets such as China, according to Moody's ESG Solutions.
The refreshed VIMA revised the initial model agreements and incorporated more annotations and alternative provisions.

China will remain the main contributor to Asia’s non-hydropower renewables capacity growth - thanks to its robust solar and wind equipment manufacturing industry, says Fitch Solutions. (PHOTO: REUTERS)
Governments need to step up as world falls behind on climate goals: ISWA panel
Emerging economies, in particular, requires extra help in the form of investments in order to wean national dependencies on cheap fossil fuels used domestically and exported, said researchers.

site_title: Asia: Dollar softens after rally but stocks struggle to recover
summary: The US dollar lost some strength after a record-high surge against the pound and other major currencies, but Asian stock markets struggled to recover from recent losses due to recession fears. The dollar's rally was fueled by the US Federal Reserve's hawkish tone and interest rate hikes to combat inflation. Despite a brief stability, analysts warn that volatility will remain high due to ongoing global rate hikes and unresolved geopolitical crises. The S&P 500 fell to its lowest close since December 2020, and Asia's stocks were mixed, with Tokyo, Shanghai, and Sydney rising but Hong Kong, Singapore, and other markets falling.

images.alt_text: It wouldn’t take much additional advanced economy weakness to mechanically push the world into recession. But risks aren’t solely tilted to the downside.

site_title: World Bank forecasts Thai GDP growth at 3.1% this year
summary: The World Bank forecasts Thailand's GDP growth at 3.1% for this year, higher than the June forecast of 2.9%, driven by private consumption and exports. The bank cuts 2023 growth forecast to 4.1% from 4.3%. Thailand expects 8-10 million foreign tourist arrivals this year, with the tourism-reliant economy expected to grow 3-3.5% this year. The forecast supports a tourism recovery despite a global economic slowdown next year.

images.alt_text: epa10189323 Tourists walk around the popular Chatuchak Weekend Market, also known as JJ market, in Bangkok, Thailand, 17 September 2022. The Thai economy showed signs of recovery, mainly driven by an increase in foreign tourists arrivals. Thailand’s gross domestic product (GDP) is expected to expand by three percent in 2022 after 3.2 million foreign tourists arrived in the first half of the year and a forecast of a total of eight million by the end of the year, according to the Bank of Thailand (BoT)’s governor.  EPA-EFE/NARONG SANGNAK

site_title: Crypto exchange FTX wins bankrupt firm Voyager’s assets
summary: FTX US, founded by billionaire Sam Bankman-Fried, won an auction for the assets of bankrupt crypto brokerage Voyager Digital, valued at approximately $1.4 billion. The agreement includes $111 million in additional consideration and the market value of Voyager's cryptocurrencies. Voyager's customers will be able to transfer their assets to the FTX US platform after the bankruptcy process is completed. This purchase follows earlier attempts by FTX to bail out or acquire Voyager, which filed for bankruptcy protection in July after a failed attempt by Alameda Research to provide a revolving line of credit.

site_title: World Bank cuts 2022 East Asia growth outlook, cites China slowdown
summary: The World Bank has cut its 2022 growth outlook for East Asia and the Pacific to 3.2%, citing a sharp slowdown in China due to strict zero-Covid rules. China's economy is expected to grow 2.8% this year, down from a previous forecast of 5.0%. The region's growth is expected to pick up in 2023, with China projected to grow 4.5%. The World Bank warns of the risks of aggressive interest rate hikes and policy distortions that could hinder long-term development.

images.alt_text: A participant stands near a logo of World Bank at the International Monetary Fund - World Bank Annual Meeting 2018 in Nusa Dua, Bali, Indonesia, October 12, 2018. REUTERS/Johannes P. Christo/
Thailand expects eight million to 10 million foreign tourist arrivals this year, having received five million so far.

site_title: Grab expects breakeven for adjusted Ebitda in H2 2024, digibank operations in 2026
summary: Grab, a regional tech group, aims to break even in its adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization (Ebitda) by the second half of 2024, with a 27% improvement in Ebitda and 45-55% revenue growth in 2023. The company's digital bank operations are expected to break even in 2026 across Singapore, Malaysia, and Indonesia. Grab is shifting focus from offline payments to transactions within its platform, and will not undertake mass layoffs despite cost-cutting efforts.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
GXS might be the first digital bank to launch, but its limited pool of customers mean Trust Bank has more time to try and slice a piece of the market.

site_title: Optus, Australian government clash over massive data breach
summary: The Australian government has blamed Optus, the country's second-largest telecoms firm, for a massive data breach that exposed the personal data of up to 10 million customers. The breach, which included home addresses, driver's licenses, and passport numbers, was attributed to a vulnerability in the company's cyber defenses. Optus CEO Kelly Bayer Rosmarin disputed the government's analysis, stating that the company's data was encrypted and protected by multiple layers of security. The Australian government has proposed overhauling privacy rules and increasing fines for companies that fail to protect customer data.

images.alt_text: Optus said last week that home addresses, drivers’ licences and passport numbers of up to 10 million customers were compromised in one of Australia’s biggest data breaches.
Optus, the Australian subsidiary of Singtel, says it is working with the Australian Cyber Security Centre to mitigate any risks to customers.

site_title: God save the pound?
summary: The UK's growing budget deficit and public debt are raising concerns about the pound sterling's value, with the currency hitting its lowest level ever against the dollar in response to unfunded tax cuts and spending increases. The issue is not just about the pound's value, but also about the UK's fiscal policy and its impact on the economy, inflation, and long-term growth. The UK's strong institutions and ability to pay its debts are being questioned, and the country's ability to manage its debt and inflation is becoming increasingly uncertain.

images.alt_text: When currency trading restarted in Asia on Monday, the beleaguered pound dropped to a fresh 37-year low against the dollar.

site_title: China industrial profits fell more as producer prices slowed
summary: China's industrial profits declined 2.1% in the first 8 months of 2022, following a slowdown in producer prices and production disruptions, including power shortages. The decline is attributed to falling commodity prices and a continued property slump, with mining industry profits shrinking to 88.1% year-to-date. Economists warn that the foundations of recovery remain fragile, and a spike in infections could continue to disrupt economic activity, despite recent stimulus measures.

images.alt_text: Workers work beside steel wires at a factory in Beijing, China November 22, 2017. Picture taken November 22, 2017. REUTERS/Stringer
Through August, Chinese dealers sold gold at anywhere between a premium of US$4 to US$16 an ounce to global benchmark spot prices.

site_title: Hong Kong’s Lee says Covid rulebreakers could derail reopening
summary: Hong Kong's Chief Executive John Lee warns that the city's plan to ease Covid-19 curbs could be jeopardized if people defy virus protocols. Non-compliance with compulsory testing orders has reached an 8-9% rate over the past two months, with over 1,000 individuals previously defying protocols. Authorities have also found 20,000 fake vaccine exemption certificates and cases of people uploading fake rapid antigen test results. Lee emphasizes that strict compliance is necessary to prevent a rebound in cases and maintain the success of the city's Covid-19 plan.

images.alt_text: In a sign of how isolated Hong Kong has become, in the first 8 months of this year, the city’s airport handled just 3.4 per cent of passengers that it did before Covid, and 30 per cent of flights.

site_title: Yuan plunge nears 14-year low, inviting aggressive PBOC pushback
summary: The onshore yuan has plummeted to near a 14-year low, trading within 1% of 7.2 per dollar, prompting China's central bank to consider more measures to slow depreciation and discourage capital flight. Analysts predict the yuan could weaken further to 7.30 per dollar by year-end, driven by policy divergence between China and the US. The PBOC has already taken steps to defend the currency, including imposing a risk reserve requirement and increasing the issuance of central bank bills, but may need to take more drastic measures to stem the depreciation.

images.alt_text: The People’s Bank of China said it would raise the foreign exchange risk reserves for financial institutions when purchasing FX through currency forwards to 20 per cent from the current zero, starting on Sept 28.

site_title: Singapore shares slip at Tuesday’s open as global selloff continues; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) slipped 0.3% to 3,173.92 at Tuesday's open, following a global selloff as major US indices plunged to new lows. Regional markets, however, opened higher on bargain-hunting. Key stocks fell, with Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust rising 0.8% and Sembcorp Marine sliding 1.9%. Banking stocks, including DBS, UOB, and OCBC, declined 0.5%, 0.8%, and 0.2%, respectively.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
An offer from its executive director to privatise Silkroad Nickel was declared unconditional on Monday.

site_title: Japan’s Hakuhodo to start joint venture with crypto entrepreneur
summary: Japanese advertising firm Hakuhodo DY Holdings plans to launch a joint venture with Stake Technologies, a Singapore-based Web3 infrastructure developer, this year. The move aims to help Japanese firms build Web3 businesses, following a government pledge to support the country's crypto industry. The joint venture will utilize Stake Technologies' Astar blockchain and is part of Hakuhodo's efforts to tap into demand from Japanese companies looking to enter the crypto market, with the goal of changing Japan's tax code to make it more favorable for crypto-related businesses.

site_title: Philippines to shut 175 offshore gambling firms, deport 40,000 Chinese workers
summary: The Philippines will shut down 175 offshore gambling firms and deport approximately 40,000 Chinese workers, part of a crackdown on the online gaming industry. The move was triggered by reports of crimes committed by Chinese nationals against fellow Chinese nationals. The government generated 7.2 billion pesos in 2020 and 3.9 billion last year from Pogo fees, with economists estimating larger amounts spent on taxes and workers' spending. China supports the deportation and crackdown, while the Philippines regulator did not immediately respond to a comment request.

images.alt_text: Star was accused of misleading the regulator and allowing a Macau-based junket operator, Suncity, to operate a prohibited money-for-chips desk.
The plunge in tourism has rippled through other sectors, such as suppliers of slot machines, baccarat table systems and other casino equipment.

site_title: Philippines to open door to LNG imports next year with 3 terminals
summary: The Philippines is set to begin importing liquefied natural gas (LNG) next year, with three government-approved terminals expected to start commercial operations in early 2023. The Department of Energy (DOE) has approved six LNG import terminal projects, with three others expected to come online within the next three years, including a project proposed by Shell. This marks the birth of the country's LNG industry, which aims to reduce its reliance on imported fuel and increase energy security.

images.alt_text: Tanks onboard the Karmol LNGT Powership Asia floating storage and regasification unit (FSRU), operated by Karpowership, viewed from the ship's bridge whilst docked at Cape Town port in Cape Town, South Africa, on Tuesday, April 19, 2022. Karpowership, the world’s biggest supplier of floating gas-fired power plants, is expanding its generation capacity by 50% to tap global demand even as it struggles to get projects going in potentially its biggest market. Photographer: Dwayne Senior/Bloomberg

site_title: Putin grants Edward Snowden Russian citizenship
summary: Vladimir Putin granted Russian citizenship to Edward Snowden, a US whistleblower who exposed the NSA's mass surveillance program in 2013. Snowden had requested Russian citizenship in 2020 to facilitate travel for his American wife and children, and Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov confirmed the move. Snowden retains his American citizenship, but the US Justice Department had previously charged him with multiple felonies. The decision comes amid strained relations between the US and Russia over the conflict in Ukraine.

images.alt_text: Frances Haugen last year leaked reams of internal studies showing Facebook executives knew of their site’s potential for harm, prompting a renewed US push for regulation.

site_title: Tesla's stock emerges as unlikely megacap rival to Apple
summary: Tesla's stock has emerged as a rival to Apple's in terms of market value, despite being the most expensive among the 5 largest US companies by market value. Tesla's shares are down 22% this year, while Apple has fallen 15%. Both companies have huge market values and are less tied to the business cycle, making them less vulnerable to recession fears. Their cult followings and stable revenue streams have made them attractive to retail traders, with Apple's premium valuation and dividend payments also contributing to its strong performance.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average shed 0.4 per cent to 30,076.68 on Thursday, while the broad-based S&P 500 declined 0.8 per cent to 3,757.99.
Tesla will test the production lines for the upgrade at Shanghai plant, during From Sep 19 to Nov 30.

site_title: Aston Martin stunt car, Daniel Craig costumes star at James Bond auction
summary: A charity auction featuring James Bond props and memorabilia, including an Aston Martin DB5 stunt car used in No Time to Die, will be held on September 28 and October 5. The 60-lot auction, benefiting different charities, includes costumes worn by Daniel Craig and other cast members, as well as vehicles, watches, and props from various Bond films. The stunt car, valued at £1.5-2 million, is one of eight replicas built for the movie, and several outfits worn by Craig are also up for auction.

images.alt_text: Don McLean said he wrote the lyrics while looking at the Van Gogh painting.

At Alliance Coin & Banknote in Almonte, Ontario, owner Sean Isaacs is preparing for an auction this month featuring some “significant” royal-themed items, including the 1935 Canadian $20 bill featuring then-Princess Elizabeth at the age of 8.

site_title: Gold firms on dollar pullback, rate-hike jitters cap gains
summary: Gold prices rose 0.6% to $1,631.89 per ounce, as the dollar's rally paused, but held near a 2-1/2-year low due to US Federal Reserve policy tightening expectations. China's net gold imports via Hong Kong jumped 40% to an over 4-year high in August. US gold futures rose 0.3% to $1,638.1, as investors await further rate hikes to curb inflation.

images.alt_text: Through August, Chinese dealers sold gold at anywhere between a premium of US$4 to US$16 an ounce to global benchmark spot prices.

Gold premiums in top consumer China climbed last week, helped by strong demand for bullion, while prices in India traded at a discount for the first time in 4 weeks due to an uptick in domestic rates.

site_title: Britain’s fund management assets rise in 2021, slowdown seen
summary: Britain's fund management assets reached £10 trillion in 2021, with £4.1 trillion managed within funds open to a range of investors, mostly in Ireland and Luxembourg. The 6% growth was below the 11% compound average annual increase in the last decade. The Investment Association predicts a slowdown due to rising interest rates and recession fears. Sterling fell to record lows against the dollar, prompting calls for an emergency Bank of England rate hike to restore confidence. Sustainable investing has become a "standout trend," with 28% of assets applying exclusions.

images.alt_text: Analysts expect further downside for the GBP/SGD rate in the near future.
Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer Kwasi Kwarteng unveiled an anti-inflation budget at the House of Commons in London on Sep 23, 2022.

site_title: Siemens automates design process for testing new chips with advanced packaging
summary: Siemens Digital Industries Software has launched Tessent Multi-die, a new software that automates the design process for testing chips made with advanced packaging. Advanced packaging involves stacking multiple silicon tiles, making testing more challenging. The new software will make it easier for companies to test these chips, which is crucial for the chip-making process. This move aims to boost the adoption of 2.5 and 3-dimensional packaging technology. The software is now available for general use, providing a solution for companies to overcome the challenges of testing advanced packaged chips.

site_title: Transforming talent to win the digital race
summary: Financial services companies in Asia-Pacific are transforming their talent to stay ahead in the digital race. To do this, they are upskilling internal talent online, adopting a skills-first approach, and building digital and data fluency. Additionally, they are focusing on leadership development and prioritizing human skills like creativity and problem-solving alongside technology skills. By doing so, BFSI companies are turning technological disruption into an advantage and unlocking new opportunities to stay ahead in the digital market.

images.alt_text: A customer uses a DBS Group Holdings Ltd. automated teller machine (ATM) while other banks booths stand at Changi Airport in Singapore, on Thursday, July 28, 2011. DBS Group Holdings Ltd., Southeast Asia's largest bank, posted second-quarter earnings that missed analysts' estimates as trading income fell 47 percent and loan profitability shrank. during a results briefing in Singapore, on Thursday, July 28, 2011. Photographer: Munshi Ahmed/Bloomberg
DBS, OCBC and UOB ATMs at Tang Plaza near Orchard MRT on July 30, 2020.

site_title: Silkroad Nickel’s privatisation offer turns unconditional
summary: Silkroad Nickel's privatization offer has turned unconditional, with 90.2% of shares owned or agreed to be acquired by Horowitz Capital and its concert parties. Valid acceptances from the offeror's concert parties stood at 63.2%, while 27% came from other shareholders. The offer was launched at S$0.42 per share and was extended to Oct 25, as Horowitz Capital has crossed the 90% shareholding threshold for a compulsory acquisition.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng
Generic pictures of SGX

site_title: Stocks to watch: Silkroad Nickel
summary: An offer by Silkroad Nickel's executive director to privatise the Indonesia-based nickel ore miner has been declared unconditional, with 63.2% of valid acceptances from concert parties and 27% from other shareholders. The closing date for the offer has been extended to Oct 25.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Generic pictures of SGX

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks in red at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index down 0.09% or 16.49 points at 17,838.65. Investors struggled to find positives amid an uncertain economic outlook and rising interest rates. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index edged up 0.17% and the Shenzhen Composite Index added 0.31%. The decline follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and comes as traders await GDP data and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Nasa’s Dart spacecraft hits target asteroid in first planetary defence test
summary: NASA's Dart spacecraft successfully impacted a 170-meter asteroid, Dimorphos, at a speed of 24,000 kph, marking the world's first planetary defense test. The test aimed to determine if a spacecraft can alter an asteroid's trajectory using kinetic force. Although the immediate outcome is uncertain, NASA officials hailed the success of the mission, citing its potential to save humanity from a potential doomsday meteorite collision. The asteroid's orbital path is expected to be shortened by 10 minutes, and further observations will determine the success of the mission.

images.alt_text: NASA's Double Asteroid Redirection Test (DART) spacecraft prior to impact at the Didymos binary asteroid system showed in this undated illustration handout. NASA/Johns Hopkins/Handout via REUTERS ATTENTION EDITORS -  THIS IMAGE HAS BEEN SUPPLIED BY A THIRD PARTY. IT IS DISTRIBUTED, EXACTLY AS RECEIVED BY REUTERS, AS A SERVICE TO CLIENTS. MANDATORY CREDIT.

site_title: Airlines would have to disclose fees under new US proposal
summary: US President Joe Biden unveiled plans to regulate airlines and internet service providers to increase transparency about hidden fees. A proposed rule would require airlines to disclose more information about fees, such as those for cancelling flights or seat selection. The administration also plans to strengthen competition rules in the agriculture sector and propose FCC requirements for internet service providers to offer clear breakdowns of fees and charges. The moves aim to combat rising inflation and protect consumers from "junk fees."

images.alt_text: The improvement in orders suggests demand is holding up yet remains tenuous as customers of service providers adjust to still-elevated prices and higher interest rates.

site_title: Star says has taken ‘urgent’ steps to fix Sydney casino problems
summary: Star Entertainment Group has taken "significant and urgent steps" to address shortcomings at its Sydney casino, following an inquiry's finding that it was unsuitable to run the venue. The company has increased staff monitoring, upgraded surveillance technology, and exited junkets, while also overhauling its management team. Star accepts the inquiry's findings but intends to restore itself to suitability, with a comprehensive remediation plan to be completed by the end of October. The company aims to rectify lax anti-money laundering controls and problem gambling issues, following accusations of misleading regulators and allowing prohibited money-for-chips desks.

images.alt_text: The Star complex, operated by Star Entertainment Group Ltd., in Sydney. Photographer: Brent Lewin/Bloomberg

site_title: Federal Reserve officials stare down market volatility, say inflation remains paramount focus
summary: US Federal Reserve officials downplayed market volatility, citing controlling inflation as their top priority. Atlanta Fed President Raphael Bostic stated that investors' optimism about Fed policy was beside the point, as the focus should be on reducing inflation. The Fed has raised interest rates to combat inflation, which remains above the 2% target. The recent UK tax cuts and Bank of England's efforts to control inflation have sent the pound into a tailspin, adding to global market volatility. Fed officials will continue to push interest rates to cool inflation, even if it means rising unemployment and a possible recession.

images.alt_text: Bank of England governor Andrew Bailey is under intensifying pressure to serve as a line of defence for rattled financial markets amid calls to hike interest rates aggressively, perhaps as soon as this week
FOMC participants are now projecting US GDP growth of just 0.2 per cent for 2022, and 1.2 per cent for 2023
US Federal Reserve chief Powell is now being compared to Paul Volcker, the ruthless former Fed chief who brought on 2 recessions to quell the last round of inflation.

site_title: Japan, Australia ask UK to reconsider agriculture tariff in CPTPP talks: Jiji
summary: Britain has opposed expanding tariff-free items to 100% in its entry talks to the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), instead agreeing to lift tariffs for only 90% of imported products. Japan and Australia have asked the UK to reconsider this condition. The request may delay Britain's entry to the pact by year-end, as it is set to resubmit its tariff conditions.

images.alt_text: Delivery boxes are stacked on the table as Cheesemaker Radek Bernas watches mozzarella cheese move along the production line in the dairy at Laverstoke Park Farm near Overton, Hampshire on February 6, 2019. - Buffalo mozzarella made from the milk of a herd roaming the green rolling hills of southern England is hoping to dethrone the Italian original in the UK thanks to Brexit. Some 2,000 kilometres from Campania in southern Italy is Laverstoke Park Farm in Hampshire -- owned by former Formula One motor racing champion Jody Scheckter. (Photo by ADRIAN DENNIS / AFP)

site_title: Europe: Italian shares shine after election, Stoxx 600 slips
summary: The Europe-wide Stoxx 600 index fell 0.4% on Monday, closing near December 2020 lows, amid risk aversion following central bank tightening. Italy's FTSE MIB index rose 1% after a right-wing coalition led by Georgia Meloni won the national election, potentially providing a rare chance of political stability. Meanwhile, the UK's FTSE 100 was flat, while the UK mid-caps index dropped 1.4% to near two-year lows.

images.alt_text: London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index grew 0.4 per cent to 7,044.18 points after sterling hit a record-low against the US dollar overnight.

site_title: Dutch limit Groningen gas production despite energy crisis
summary: The Dutch government has capped gas production at the Groningen field, operated by Shell and Exxon Mobil, at 2.8 billion cubic meters starting October 1, 2022, due to safety concerns and damage to buildings from drilling-induced tremors. Extraction is expected to end by 2024 at the latest. The government maintains that production can only be resumed as a last resort if gas supplies for Dutch households run out, despite pressure to increase production amid the energy crisis triggered by Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P fall again, ending at lowest level of year
summary: US stocks fell, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average finishing down 1.1% at 29,260.81, marking its lowest level of 2022. The S&P 600 and Nasdaq Composite Index declined 1.0% and 0.6%, respectively. Market turmoil amid central bank policy pivots to address inflation has boosted the dollar and raised recession fears. Despite some analysts considering the market "oversold," others predict a short-term relief rally, but its sustainability remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 53.57 points, or 0.18 per cent, at the open to 29,536.84.

site_title: Google’s India policy head Gulati resigns: sources
summary: Google's India policy head, Archana Gulati, has resigned 5 months after taking the job. The reasons for her resignation are unclear. Gulati led a team of public policy executives at Google, focusing on regulatory implications in India, a key growth market for the company. India's competition watchdog is investigating Google's business conduct in smart TVs, Android, and in-app payments, and is close to announcing decisions in at least two antitrust cases. This comes at a critical time for Google, which faces stricter tech regulations and antitrust cases in the country.

site_title: Netflix sets up first internal studio to develop video games
summary: Netflix establishes its first in-house video games studio in Helsinki, led by Marko Lastikka, to develop original games with no ads and in-app purchases. The studio aims to expand the company's gaming offerings and reduce reliance on third-party creators. With 31 mobile games currently available, Netflix plans to reach 50 games by the end of the year, including the upcoming "Stranger Things: Puzzle Games." The move follows the company's push into video games in 2021 to diversify its streaming offerings, following a decline in growth and a loss of 970,000 subscribers in the second quarter.

images.alt_text: Insider Intelligence analyst Ross Benes estimates that advertising revenues from streaming could reach US$30 billion in two years in the United States alone.
The streaming service filed a copyright infringement suit against Abigail Barlow and Emily Bear in Washington in late July.
Despite concerns about increased competition and a potential recession, Netflix remains confident in its position.

site_title: US hotel firm counts on Thai tourism rebound for Asia expansion
summary: US hotel firm Standard International plans to expand its operations in Asia, with a focus on Thailand's post-pandemic tourism recovery. Chairman Srettha Thavisin aims to open boutique hotels in Pattaya and Phuket by 2025 and community-oriented Bunkhouse properties in smaller towns like Chiang Mai. The company also plans to manage more properties in Singapore, Melbourne, Europe, and North America, reaching a total of at least 20 worldwide by 2026. Thailand expects 10 million arrivals this year, with authorities advised to promote smaller towns and offer diverse experiences to encourage longer stays and higher spending.

images.alt_text: Thailand has moved to end most pandemic-era restrictions on travel and businesses following a steady decline in new Covid cases and pickup in vaccination rate.

site_title: Letting geopolitics shape trade takes world down ‘dangerous’ path: DPM Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong warned that the world is heading down a "dangerous and fractured" path due to geopolitics-driven economic decisions. The shift from a unipolar to a multipolar world has led to a change in logic, where geopolitics is shaping trade and investments. While the world is not yet at an equilibrium, Wong expressed concerns that a new era of geopolitics could lead to accidents and miscalculations, particularly if there is no people-to-people connection and communication between nations. Singapore is navigating US-China tensions by maintaining open lines of communication and upholding its interests in a rules-based multilateral system.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Surging prices have forced central banks worldwide to tighten monetary policy, which is expected to cool inflation but risks tipping economies into recession.

PM Lee said Singapore’s success depends on getting 3 fundamentals right, despite its challenges. This includes always having a united people, a high-quality leadership team and high trust between the people and their leaders.

site_title: Oil prices slide US$2/bbl; settle at 9-month lows on dollar strength
summary: Oil prices plummeted to nine-month lows on Monday, with Brent crude futures settling at $84.06 a barrel, down $2.09 or 2.4% from the previous session. The decline was attributed to a strengthening US dollar, which pressured demand for oil priced in the US currency. The dollar index hit a two-decade high, further exacerbating the decline. The market is also awaiting details on new sanctions on Russia and concerns about an economic slowdown due to interest rate increases by central banks.

images.alt_text: A vessel docks along the Shell Petroleum refineries on Pulau Bukom in Singapore; June 2022.

Brent crude futures were up 17 cents, or 0.2 per cent, at US$86.32 a barrel at 0116 GMT on Monday, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures were up 21 cents, or 0.3 per cent, at US$78.95 a barrel.

site_title: Gas crisis lands LNG cargo market in hands of energy giants
summary: The global liquefied natural gas (LNG) market has more than doubled in size since 2011, leading to a concentration of the business in the hands of a few international energy majors and top global trading houses. This has squeezed out dozens of smaller traders, particularly in Asia, where they once accounted for 20% of LNG imports in China. The market is expected to remain dominated by these large players until 2026, when new LNG supply is expected to materialize and lower prices, potentially easing supply worries for poorer states and driving up costs for big Asian economies.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A liquefied natural gas (LNG) tanker is tugged towards a thermal power station in Futtsu, east of Tokyo, Japan November 13, 2017. REUTERS/Issei Kato/File Photo
Shell will still be able to meet its commitments to supply customers with LNG regardless of its participation in the project.
The patchwork shipments mix supplies of LNG that are left over after partial deliveries from hubs like Australia and Oman to customers in North-east Asia.

site_title: How Abe’s murder increased scrutiny of the Unification Church
summary: Former Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's assassination has heightened scrutiny of the Unification Church, also known as the Family Federation for World Peace and Unification. The church's alleged links to Abe and his family, including his mother's ruinous donations, are being investigated. Abe's alleged killer reportedly resented the church due to these ties. The incident has raised questions about the church's influence on politics and its pressure tactics on members to donate, sparking renewed criticism of the organization.

images.alt_text: Revelations of long-running links between some lawmakers of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) and the controversial Unification church have caused headache for Japan PM Fumio Kishida.
Liberal Democratic Party Secretary-General Toshimitsu Motegi said a probe found some lawmakers had accepted support for election campaigns from the church and its spin-off groups.
The share of those who did not support Kishida rose to 47 per cent from 39 per cent, the poll by the Asahi Shimbun daily showed.

Police officers and firefighters investigate at the site where a man who was protesting a state funeral for former Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe set himself on fire, near Prime Minster Fumio Kishida's official residence in Tokyo, Japan Sept 21, 2022.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's suburbs have improved, but the CBD and districts 9, 10, 11 still command price premiums for offices and homes. The country's factory output grew 0.5% in August, beating economists' estimates. Incumbent banks in Singapore should focus on improving customer engagement amid increasing competition from digital banks. The government announced the reappointment of Lucien Wong as Attorney-General for another 3-year term. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.4% on Monday, tracking regional declines.

site_title: World’s largest ocean freight carrier launches air-cargo business
summary: MSC, the world's largest container line, launches an air cargo business using 4 leased Boeing wide-body freighters. The move comes as container shippers face a downturn due to weaker demand, with prices at their lowest in over 2 years. Led by former Delta Air Lines executive Jannie Davel, the air cargo business will complement MSC's core shipping business, with flights operated by Atlas Air on behalf of MSC.

images.alt_text: Tugboats guide an MSC container ship arriving at the Port of Los Angeles in California. Photographer: Tim Rue/Bloomberg
Liner shipping has in general either yielded very thin profits or has been loss making from the early years of containerisation.

site_title: Oxley’s shareholders should vote down distribution of Aspen shares
summary: Oxley Holdings, a Singapore-based property developer, is proposing a distribution-in-specie of Aspen shares to its shareholders. The proposal, if approved, would give shareholders 0.023 Aspen shares for every 1,000 Oxley shares held. However, the value of the distribution is minimal, and shareholders who sell the Aspen shares would face significant brokerage fees, making it a costly endeavor. Aspen shares have slumped 58.3% year-to-date due to the company's dismal financial performance, including a loss before tax of RM130.2 million. Shareholders are advised to vote against the proposal to allow management to explore alternative options, such as selling the stake to a buyer.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Oxley Holdings' hotel development Novotel Singapore and Mercure Singapore on Stevens Road. The group posted a S$20.3 million loss attributable to shareholders for H2 FY2022.
For the 4 trading sessions over the span of Jul 8 to 14, the Straits Times Index lost 1.2 per cent.
Construction progress of the company's Singapore projects are on schedule, with 7 out of its remaining 8 projects expected to TOP in the next 6 months.

site_title: Canada to remove all Covid border, travel measures from Oct 1
summary: Canada will remove all COVID-19 border, travel measures, including testing and vaccination requirements, starting October 1, as the country has reached a high vaccination rate and passed the peak of the latest wave of coronavirus infections. This decision was made based on vaccination rates, new vaccine availability, and scientific modeling. The move applies to all travelers, regardless of citizenship, and also removes mask requirements on planes and trains. The government is prepared to reinstate restrictions if necessary.

site_title: Twitter to interview Elon Musk, known for combative testimony
summary: Elon Musk is set to be interviewed by Twitter's lawyers on September 26, in a closed-door session, as part of the ongoing court battle over his $44 billion deal to acquire the social media company. Musk's lawyers aim to keep him focused on answering questions, but his tendency to be combative and opinionated during depositions may pose a challenge. Twitter's attorneys will likely try to show that Musk abandoned the deal due to falling financial markets, rather than due to Twitter's alleged misrepresentations.

images.alt_text: Twitter counters that Musk’s bot concerns are a pretext to get out of a deal in which the world’s richest person allegedly developed buyer’s remorse.
Musk’s legal team argued in court on Tuesday that justice demanded delaying the 5-day trial, so he could investigate allegations that Twitter had misrepresented its data security.

Tesla CEO Elon Musk at the Offshore Northern Seas 2022 meeting in Stavanger, Norway, on Monday (Aug 29).  The billionaire is still trying to walk away from the Twitter deal; he is seeking to cancel his offer to buy out Twitter for US$4 billion. The trial begins on Oct 17.

site_title: Energy, taxes, pensions first challenges for Italy’s Meloni
summary: Italy's newly elected Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni will face pressing economic challenges, including finding billions of euros to soften energy costs, cut taxes, and block a hike in the retirement age set to kick in from January. The country's laborious institutional proceedings mean Meloni won't take office until at least a month, with outgoing Prime Minister Mario Draghi remaining in charge. Meloni's government will need to approve measures to address the energy crisis, which is expected to worsen, and the rising state pension bill, which is the second-highest in the eurozone.

images.alt_text: Giorgia Meloni, leader of the Brothers of Italy party, speaks at the party's general election night event in Rome, Italy, on Monday, Sept. 26. 2022. Giorgia Meloni is on track to lead Italys most right-wing government since World War II after exit polls projected a clear victory for her coalition in Sundays election. Photographer: Alessia Pierdomenico/Bloomberg

Giorgia Meloni has only slight government experience, and has been rocketed to the top of Italian politics in great part thanks to her boycotting Draghi’s technocratic administration over the past 18 months

site_title: As more foreigners go house-hunting in Malaysia, sellers say cash is king
summary: Malaysia's property market has seen a surge in transactions, with 188,002 properties worth RM84.4 billion transacted in the first 6 months of 2022, a 34.5% year-on-year increase in volume and 36.1% increase in value. Foreign buyers, particularly from South Korea, Hong Kong, Taiwan, and Japan, are driving the demand, attracted by the country's lower property prices and weaker ringgit. Sellers are willing to offer discounts of up to 21% for cash deals, as they can process transactions in as short as 2 months, compared to up to 6 months for bank loans.

images.alt_text: Malaysia has registered 188,002 property transactions worth RM84.4 billion in the first 6 months this year, a year-on-year increase of 34.5 per cent in volume and 36.1 per cent in value.
Propnex Malaysia group leader and resident manager Matt Tian: “Some property owners are willing to sell at a discount for if buyers are paying in full cash.”
Juwai IQI global chief economist Shan Saeed: “Global investors are shifting attention to real estate market for wealth preservation.”
Savills (Malaysia) group managing director Paul Khong : “The transitions into endemicity have spur the market sentiment and investment interest.”
Rahim and Co International Property Consultants (Real Estate Agency) CEO: “Investors worried their investment value will shrink if ringgit depreciates further.”
Hartamas Real Estate Group managing director Eric Lim: “Market sentiment has gone sideways after a few rounds of interest rate hikes and concerns on soaring inflation.”

site_title: China’s August net gold imports via Hong Kong hit over 4-year high
summary: China's net gold imports via Hong Kong surged 40% to a 4-year high of 68.227 tonnes in August, exceeding July's 48.773 tonnes. This marks the highest level since June 2018. Strong demand, fueled by significant premiums of $4 to $16 per ounce, is believed to be the primary driver. The rebound in demand may be linked to the lifting of lockdowns in major Chinese cities.

images.alt_text: Gold premiums in top consumer China climbed last week, helped by strong demand for bullion, while prices in India traded at a discount for the first time in 4 weeks due to an uptick in domestic rates.
Benchmark prices in Shanghai have climbed to a premium of more than US$43 an ounce over their London equivalent, the highest since 2019, according to data from the World Gold Council.

site_title: Singapore stocks track regional declines; STI down 1.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.4% to close at 3,181.97, tracking regional declines. Losers beat gainers 413 to 194, with major market indices in Asia also declining. The US yield curve inverts, reflecting increased recession risks, which may impact economically sensitive sectors. Only two counters, Sats and Emperador, remained in the black, while Yangzijiang Shipbuilding fell 10.5% after heavy trading.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
As at 3.35pm on Friday, the counter had climbed S$0.17 or 15.5 per cent to reach an intra-day high of S$1.27 after 118.7 million of its shares changed hands.

site_title: Volkswagen builds battery supply chain with joint venture cathode plant
summary: Volkswagen is setting up a joint venture with Umicore to invest 3 billion euros in a cathode plant in Brussels, aiming to supply battery cell factories with cathode materials. The venture, starting operation in 2025, will power about 2.2 million fully-electric cars by the end of the decade. The move is part of Volkswagen's plan to develop 50 purely battery-powered models by the end of the decade, with six battery plants in the region.

site_title: Indonesia posts 107.4 trillion rupiah Jan-Aug budget surplus, expects higher energy bills
summary: Indonesia reported a budget surplus of 107.4 trillion rupiah (S$10.2 billion) from January to August, equivalent to 0.58% of GDP. Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati attributed the increase to high commodity prices and economic recovery from the pandemic. However, the government still expects to pay large energy subsidies in the third and fourth quarters, with projected costs of up to 649 trillion rupiah (US$42.91 billion).

site_title: UK air-taxi startup’s prototype takes maiden flight
summary: UK-based Vertical Aerospace successfully completed the maiden flight of its prototype electric air taxi, the VX4, in a tethered hover test. The test marked the first for a UK manufacturer in over 20 years and demonstrates the company's commitment to meeting safety requirements. Vertical Aerospace aims to secure certification by 2025 and has received over 1,400 pre-orders, including from American Airlines Group and Virgin Atlantic Airways. The VX4 can carry a pilot and 4 passengers, with a range of up to 160 km and a cruise speed of 240 km/h.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower on rate-hike, recession fears
summary: US stocks opened lower on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 53.57 points, or 0.18%, to 29,536.84. Investors are concerned that the Federal Reserve's rate hikes may lead to a recession. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also fell, with the S&P 500 down 10.51 points, or 0.28%, and the Nasdaq down 34.54 points, or 0.32%. The decline was attributed to recession fears, with investors worried about the impact of the Fed's actions on the economy.

site_title: Samsung to lure 175 million existing India customers with cashback card
summary: Samsung Electronics launched a new credit card with Axis Bank, offering 10% cashback on all Samsung product purchases throughout the year, targeting its 175 million existing Indian customers. This move aims to boost sales, following a decline in market share to 19% in the Indian smartphone market. The company hopes financial support will help consumers make smartphone purchase decisions, as it competes with Chinese rivals such as Xiaomi, Oppo, and Vivo.

site_title: TikTok may be fined £27m for failing to protect children’s privacy
summary: Britain's data protection agency, the Information Commissioner's Office, has sent a warning notice to TikTok, intending to impose a £27m fine for failing to protect children's privacy in the UK. The regulator claims TikTok handled youngsters' information without parental permission, processed sensitive details without grounds, and failed to explain data practices in a way children could understand. The findings are provisional, but the document constitutes a formal notification of the intended fine, marking the first major case under new British rules protecting minors online.

images.alt_text: TikTok and the Biden administration have drafted a preliminary agreement to resolve national security concerns but are still deciding on a potential agreement.
The move comes as TikTok and other social media platforms are working to clamp down on political misinformation ahead of the US midterm elections in November.
Customers queue at a Shein pop-up shop in San Francisco, June 2022.

site_title: Walmart makes its first move into the metaverse
summary: Walmart is making its first foray into the metaverse with the launch of two immersive experiences, Walmart Land and Universe of Play, on Roblox Corp's virtual platform. The virtual worlds will feature elements of gaming, social media, and e-commerce, targeting younger shoppers and aiming to build brand equity. The experiences will offer virtual stores, games, and interactive content, with the goal of enticing users to move beyond avatars and shop at Walmart's stores and website.

images.alt_text: Most of these sales came through its US e-commerce business, which grew 12 per cent during the quarter, and helped the retailer post better-than-expected sales and lift its full-year profit forecast.
The service rivals Amazon’s Prime, which also offers free shipping as well as video and music streaming services and has around 200 million subscribers.
A US federal judge ordered Walmart, Walgreens and CVS on Wednesday to pay US$650.6 million to two Ohio counties plagued by the US opioid crisis.

site_title: Washington should tone down its hawkish stance over Taiwan
summary: The US Senate Foreign Relations Committee has passed the Taiwan Policy Act, providing $6.5 billion in military aid and elevating the US representative to Taipei to ambassador status. China has warned that this would violate the "one China" policy and "shake the foundations" of the Sino-American relationship. President Biden has pledged to send troops to Taiwan if China invades, marking a shift in US policy towards greater support for Taiwan. This move has raised tensions between the US and China, potentially leading to a military confrontation.

site_title: TikTok inching towards US security deal to avoid sale: report
summary: TikTok and the Biden administration have drafted a preliminary agreement to address national security concerns without requiring ByteDance to sell the app. The plan involves changes to data security and governance, which would resolve concerns raised by US lawmakers. This comes after a 2-year-old order from a US national security panel to divest TikTok due to fears of US user data being passed on to China's communist government. A final decision is still pending, but the agreement could potentially avoid a sale of the popular social media app.

site_title: To really understand the ocean, we need to go back in time
summary: A growing body of research is using historical ecology to better understand the state of the world's oceans, revealing a stark contrast between past and present conditions. In the 1500s, Europeans reported abundant sea life, including cod, turtles, and whales, while today, overfishing, climate change, and pollution have led to a decline in ocean health. This "shifting baselines syndrome" can obscure our view of past plenitude, hindering conservation efforts. Historians' accounts, including old photographs, logbooks, and diaries, are providing surprising insights into the past, highlighting the need to look backward to truly comprehend our losses and move forward.

images.alt_text:
strait16 - Singapore's Minister for Foreign Affairs, Dr Vivian Balakrishnan,




Credit: United Nations Ocean Conference
Humpback Whales in Australia were found to be passing their songs to others in French Polynesia, which in turn gave songs to whales in Ecuador.

site_title: EasyJet shifts focus to cut own emissions rather than off-setting
summary: EasyJet plans to reduce emissions by 78% by 2050 through investments in efficient aircraft, sustainable aviation fuel, and operational efficiencies. The airline will end its carbon-offsetting scheme, instead focusing on zero-emission technology. EasyJet has contracted sustainable aviation fuel for the next 5 years and is investing in technology to optimize aircraft descent.
