site_title: Taller towers – but fewer homes – coming up in NY
summary: A new wave of high-rise towers is being constructed in Manhattan's Upper East and Upper West sides, but with fewer units than previously allowed by zoning laws. Developers are citing high construction costs and market demand for luxury condos, but urban planners argue that these projects squander limited sites in high-density neighborhoods. Some of these towers could have supported thousands of apartments, but instead, they feature few units, including some with prices exceeding $65 million. Critics say the city should take steps to encourage developers to build more affordable housing, such as reviving a tax subsidy program or lifting the density cap on residential buildings.

images.alt_text: New York property firm buys Long Island offices in a bet on suburbs

site_title: S-Reit ETFs continue to see inflows, doubling AUM in 2 years
summary: The combined assets under management (AUM) of Singapore-listed Reit ETFs (S-Reit ETFs) has doubled in 2 years, reaching over S$900 million. Retail investors account for 44% of Reit ETF holdings, with net inflows exceeding S$930 million in mid-September 2022. Despite generating average total returns of -6.8% in the first 8 months of 2022, the 5 Reit ETFs recorded net inflows of S$163 million. The Lion-Phillip S-Reit ETF is the best performer, with a dividend yield of 5.04%, and the CSOP iEdge S-Reit Leaders ETF follows with a dividend yield of 4.97%.

images.alt_text: Last week, Ascendas Reit proposed to acquire a cold storage logistics facility in Singapore for S$191.9 million.

site_title: Roger Federer: Enfant terrible to saintly global icon
summary: Roger Federer, a tennis legend, has retired after a career spanning over two decades, leaving behind 20 Grand Slam titles, including 8 Wimbledons, 103 titles, and over $130 million in prize money. The 41-year-old Swiss player, known for his rare grace and precision, bowed out with a loss in a doubles match at the Laver Cup. Federer's journey was marked by a transformation from a hot-headed young player to a universally respected role model, with a net worth estimated at $450 million.

images.alt_text: The 20-time Grand Slam champion, 41, and Nadal, playing for Team Europe, went down 6-4, 6-7 (2/7), 9-11 against Team World’s Frances Tiafoe and Jack Sock.

site_title: Credit Suisse seeks to ease jitters after turnaround speculation
summary: Credit Suisse's new CEO and Chairman issued a memo to staff, attempting to ease concerns about the bank's turnaround plans. They reiterated the October 27 deadline for unveiling a strategic plan, without providing new information on the company's future. The memo emphasized the bank's focus on clients and restoring financial performance. Despite this, shares hit a record low on concerns over strategy and capital position. The executives stopped short of commenting on potential outcomes, saying it would be premature to do so before the planned announcement.

images.alt_text: The bank is now electing which businesses to cut, exit or keep as part of its second restructuring in less than a year., and its top management is seeking to shore up confidence and return it to profitability after a string of losses and missteps.

site_title: US: Dow at lowest level since Nov 2020 as stocks rout worsens
summary: US stocks plummeted on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 1.6% to its lowest level since November 2020, as markets bet on a rising risk of recession due to interest rate hikes. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also dropped over 1.5% each, with investors seeking to raise cash amid growing uncertainty and volatility. The Federal Reserve's third consecutive interest rate increase has sparked concerns about central banks' ability to restore price stability, fueling fears of a global recession.

images.alt_text: The S&P 500 opened lower by 30.85 points, or 0.82 per cent, at 3,727.14.

site_title: Gold flirts with bear market after rate hikes batter bullion
summary: Gold prices slipped nearly 20% below its all-time high in March, closing at US$1,643.94 an ounce, amid a broad selloff triggered by interest rate hikes and a strong dollar. Central banks worldwide raised interest rates to curb inflation, leading to outflows from gold exchange-traded funds and a bearish sentiment among money managers, who boosted their net-short position in Comex futures and options by 22,834 contracts.

images.alt_text: The US dollar was on track for its highest close against a basket of other currencies since May 2002.
Gold prices have fallen nearly 20 per cent since scaling above the key US$2,000 per ounce mark in March.

site_title: US: Wall St heads toward June lows on growth worries
summary: US stock indexes fell, heading toward June lows, as investors worried about an economic downturn and hit corporate earnings due to the Federal Reserve's aggressive monetary policy. The Dow Jones dropped 121.03 points, or 0.40%, at 29,955.65, while the S&P 500 fell 30.85 points, or 0.82%, at 3,727.14. The Nasdaq Composite dropped 114.11 points, or 1.03%, to 10,952.69.

site_title: Owner of Manchester City offers US$190m for Brazilian soccer club Bahia
summary: City Football Group (CFG) has offered $190 million to acquire 90% of Brazilian soccer club Esporte Clube Bahia. The bid, part of a funding surge in Brazilian soccer, requires approval from the club's members. CFG, majority-owned by Abu Dhabi's Sheikh Mansour bin Zayed Al Nahyan, would become the 13th club purchased by the company if the offer is accepted. The bid exceeds the 650 million reais cited by the club president earlier this year and includes an option to buy an additional 5% of the club.

site_title: TPG shutters SPAC after failing to find deal
summary: TPG Pace Beneficial Finance Corp, a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC) backed by private equity firm TPG, will wind down operations and return money to investors after failing to find a suitable target to merge with within the 2-year deadline. The company had raised $350 million in an IPO in 2020 and had previously struck a deal with EVBox Group but terminated it due to unsatisfactory issues. This marks the second SPAC sponsored by TPG to shut down, following TPG Pace Beneficial II, amid market volatility and cooling investor appetite for SPACs.

images.alt_text: Bridgetown Holdings, the US-listed blank-cheque company backed by billionaires Peter Thiel and Richard Li (top), is considering a potential merger with digital telecom services provider Circles.Life.

site_title: Federer hails 'amazing journey' as he bows out with defeat
summary: Roger Federer, a 20-time Grand Slam champion, bowed out of tennis with a defeat in a doubles match at the Laver Cup, saying it was an "amazing journey." Federer, 41, partnered Rafael Nadal in the loss to Frances Tiafoe and Jack Sock. In his final match, Federer expressed gratitude to his wife, parents, and fellow legends in attendance, describing the experience as a "celebration."

images.alt_text: (From left) Rafael Nadal and Roger Federer during a practice session of team Europe, ahead of the Laver Cup;  Federer bowing out for his last competitive match with Nadal alongside him is a dream scenario.

site_title: Sri Lanka aims to have US$2.9b IMF loan finalised in December: sources
summary: Sri Lanka aims to finalize a $2.9 billion IMF loan by mid-December, with talks with private and official creditors expected to start after IMF board approval. The country is struggling with its worst economic crisis in over 70 years, and aims to reach agreements with all creditors by the second quarter of 2023. Sri Lanka has already reached a preliminary deal with the IMF and is encouraging bilateral creditor coordination to obtain financing assurances from official creditors such as China, Japan, and India.

site_title: Apple to sponsor the Super Bowl halftime show
summary: Apple will sponsor the Super Bowl halftime show, replacing Pepsi in a deal reportedly worth $50 million. The NFL has been shopping around for the sponsorship, which is part of a larger agreement with Apple over Sunday football games. The league has been seeking $2.5 billion for NFL Sunday Ticket rights, but talks have been dragging due to pricing disputes. Apple's sponsorship deal is separate from its agreement to provide music streaming services to the NFL. The terms of the Super Bowl halftime show deal were not disclosed.

images.alt_text: The app developer group, known as ACT, says it’s not beholden to Apple (above), but confirmed that it derives more than half its funding from the company. The former employees say the actual percentage is much higher.

site_title: It’s Tour de France fever as elite cyclists set to race on Marina Bay street circuit
summary: The Tour de France Prudential Singapore Criterium, set for October 29-30, will be the first Tour de France event in South-east Asia. Thirty-two top riders from 8 professional cycling teams, including Jonas Vingegaard and Mark Cavendish, will compete in a specially designed street circuit in the Marina Bay area. The event aims to promote cycling as a healthy lifestyle, aligning with Prudential Singapore's focus on long-term wellness and prevention. The insurer is also using the event to engage customers and promote its Pulse app, which helps users manage their health and prevent chronic diseases.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
woman, jogging, running
Running through the streets of Kyoto.

site_title: The Fed appears more optimistic than some investors. Here’s why.
summary: The US Federal Reserve appears more optimistic about its ability to reduce inflation gently, despite warnings of economic pain to come. Policymakers have set the policy rate at its highest level since 2008, with forecasts predicting further increases. However, traders and analysts disagree, expecting a more dire outcome and a potential recession. Market prices reflect what many analysts expect - the Fed will have to cut interest rates by the end of next year to support an ailing economy. The market's optimism is at odds with Goldman Sachs' forecasts, which align with the Fed's, and analysts predict inflation will remain too far from the Fed's target of 2% to warrant interest rate cuts.

images.alt_text: REDWOOD SHORES, CA - JUNE 19: The Oracle logo is displayed in front of the Oracle headquarters on June 19, 2014 in Redwood Shores, California. Oracle will report fourth quarter earnings today after the closing bell.   Justin Sullivan/Getty Images/AFP== FOR NEWSPAPERS, INTERNET, TELCOS & TELEVISION USE ONLY ==
The daily Sora rate shot up by about 0.3 percentage points on Friday following the US Federal Reserve’s decision to raise interest rates by 0.75 per cent on Wednesday.
On a weighted-average basis, the dollar is the highest it has been in 20 years.

Speaking at the Atlantic Festival, US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said there is likely “some inflationary pressure” caused by the shortage of workers in the labour market, which has driven wages up.

site_title: Barclays sued by investors over multibillion securities blunder
summary: Barclays has been sued by investors over a multibillion-dollar securities blunder. The bank issued about $36 billion of investment products after registering to sell up to $20.8 billion, leading to a $591 million repurchase and taking a significant hit. The lawsuit alleges that Barclays made false and misleading statements, failed to disclose important information, and had inadequate internal controls. The investors claim that stopping the over-issuance wasn't "rocket science," according to Barclays' chairman Nigel Higgins.

images.alt_text: Barclays said in Monday's (Jul 25) statement that the securities in question consist of about US$14.8 billion of structured notes and around US$2.8 billion of exchange-traded notes.

site_title: FedEx needs to deliver on cost-cut plan as investor patience wanes: analysts
summary: FedEx's new CEO, Raj Subramaniam, needs to deliver on his plan to slash up to $2.7 billion in expenses for fiscal 2023 to regain investor confidence. Analysts expressed skepticism about the execution of the plan, citing recent missteps and a volume slowdown in the industry. Despite this, some analysts believe FedEx has room to cut costs and pricing power is holding up for now, with Wells Fargo analyst Allison Poliniak-Cusic stating that a period of execution will be key to luring investors back to the story.

site_title: Thanksgiving turkeys never cost so much as bird flu ravages US flocks
summary: US turkey prices are at record highs due to a resurgence of bird flu, affecting egg and turkey operations nationwide. Prices for turkey hens are 30% higher than last year and 80% above pre-pandemic costs, while inventories of whole turkeys are at their lowest since 2006. The outbreak, which has killed over 45 million birds, is expected to worsen as wild birds migrate back to the US, leading to concerns about persistently higher prices and potential shortages during the holiday season.

images.alt_text: US finds highly pathogenic bird flu in wild duck, first case since 2016

site_title: Britain to open £40b support scheme for power firms on Oct 17
summary: Britain's finance ministry will open a £40 billion support scheme for power firms on October 17, providing a short-term last resort to protect energy suppliers from volatile prices and ensure liquidity in UK energy markets. The Energy Markets Financing Scheme (EMFS) will offer a 100% guarantee to commercial banks covering additional lending extended to firms deemed financially stable and contributing to market liquidity. The move aims to prevent energy firms from collapsing due to record-high wholesale power and gas prices following Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: Oil plunges to 8-month low on strong dollar, recession fears
summary: Oil prices plummeted to an eight-month low, with Brent futures falling 4.8% to $86.15 a barrel and US WTI crude dropping 5.7% to $78.74 a barrel, due to a strong US dollar and fears of a global recession. The US Federal Reserve's interest rate hike and other central bank actions raised concerns about economic slowdowns. The strong dollar reduces demand for oil, making it more expensive for buyers using other currencies, and has pressured oil prices, with US gasoline and diesel futures also falling over 5%.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled up 63 cents, or 0.7 per cent on Thursday, at US$90.46 after rising by more than US$2 earlier in the session.

site_title: Burberry CFO to step down in second major shakeup in a year
summary: Burberry CFO Julie Brown is stepping down in April after over 5 years, following former CEO Marco Gobbetti's departure earlier this year. The company is struggling to regain pre-pandemic sales levels, hindered by lockdowns in China and a reversal in fortunes in the Americas. New CEO Jonathan Akeroyd will lead the brand, aiming to build on existing growth foundations. A successor to Brown will be identified, facing challenges of weak demand and rising costs.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Shoppers walk past a store of fashion company Burberry, amid the spread of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19), in Zurich, Switzerland December 11, 2021. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo

site_title: Credit Suisse shares hit record low on capital, strategy doubts
summary: Credit Suisse shares plummeted to a record low after the bank denied reports it was considering exiting the US market, amid doubts over its strategy revamp. The bank is electing which businesses to cut, exit, or keep as part of its second restructuring in less than a year, and is sounding out investors for a possible capital raise. Analysts at Deutsche Bank estimate a capital gap of at least 4 billion Swiss francs, while Citigroup indicates skepticism about a broad exit from the US market, citing potential near-term charges and long-term capital release risks.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse is also considering cutting around 5,000 jobs, about one position in 10, as part of the cost reduction drive.
The Swiss lender is in the middle of a broader strategic review after a string of losses under former chief executive officer Thomas Gottstein.
UK real estate is in a moment of flux as a decade-long bull market fuelled by rock bottom interest rates shudders into reverse amid recession fears.

site_title: Twitch creator chief exits with controversy over streamer pay swirling
summary: Twitch creator chief Constance Knight has resigned amid controversy over the platform's changes to streamer pay. The company, owned by Amazon, announced that top streamers will receive 70% of revenue up to $100,000, then drop to a 50/50 split. The move was seen as a cost-cutting measure, with Twitch president Dan Clancy citing the need to boost profitability. The changes have sparked concerns among creators that the platform is falling out of touch with its content creators, who are essential to its success, with 2.5 million concurrent viewers tuning in daily.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This file photo taken on September 21, 2018, shows the logo of the VOD and streaming video games company Twitch at the Tokyo Game Show. - Twitch on September 21, 2022, announced a ban on sites that stream unlicensed roulette, dice, or slots games as the platform is hit with concerns about getting users hooked on gambling. (Photo by Martin BUREAU / AFP)
Twitch struggles with hackers and hate raid bots

site_title: Europe: Shares routed as recession worries heighten
summary: Europe's largest economy, Germany, saw its main index hit its lowest since November 2020, down 2%. European energy and material stocks plummeted 6% on Friday, pushing the Stoxx 600 index to near 2-year lows. The pan-European index dropped 2.3% and weekly losses reached 4.4%. UK stocks fell 2% and the pound dropped 3% after British finance minister Kwasi Kwarteng announced tax cuts to boost growth. The economic downturn and hawkish central bank moves have fueled recession worries.

images.alt_text: London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index dipped 0.1 per cent to 7,154.20 points ahead of a UK budget aimed at tackling sky-high inflation.

site_title: Ford breaks ground on US$5.6b complex for electric vehicles and batteries
summary: Ford has broken ground on a US$5.6 billion electric vehicle manufacturing complex, BlueOval City, in western Tennessee. The 6-square-mile site will include a battery factory and the first all-new assembly plant since 1969, employing 6,000 workers by 2025. The complex is part of Ford's US$50 billion EV investment through 2026, aiming to produce 2 million EVs annually by 2026 and have over half of its sales be battery-powered by 2030.

site_title: Preventing sudden cardiac death
summary: Sudden cardiac death (SCD) occurs when the heart stops pumping effectively due to a life-threatening heart rhythm. According to data from the US National Registry of Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation, 24% of SCD patients had ventricular fibrillation (VF) or ventricular tachycardia (VT), while 39% had pulseless electrical activity (PEA) or asystole. Warning symptoms preceding SCD include chest pain and shortness of breath, with 51% of patients experiencing symptoms within 4 weeks of the event. Risk factors for SCD include smoking, sedentary lifestyle, and underlying heart disease. Taking precautionary measures, such as consulting a doctor before vigorous exercise and quitting smoking, can help reduce the likelihood of SCD.

images.alt_text: Listen to your heart: Separating myth from fact

site_title: Singapore receives 15 recommendations on creation of a sustainable air hub
summary: Singapore receives 15 recommendations from the International Advisory Panel on Sustainable Air Hub, focusing on creating a long-term secured Sustainable Aviation Fuel supply ecosystem and demand signals for greener alternatives. The recommendations are divided into three key areas: airport, airline, and air traffic management. The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore will study and incorporate the recommendations into the Sustainable Air Hub Blueprint.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Infrastructure upgrades help cut airport's energy usage, costs and improve sustainability
S$500m in aviation support for Singapore Changi Airport
Singapore to conduct sustainable aviation fuel pilot at Changi Airport in Q3

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend losses ahead of weekend
summary: Hong Kong stocks dropped 1.18% on Friday, Sept 23, amid recession concerns and interest rate hikes. The Hang Seng Index fell to 17,933.27, while the Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.66%. Global markets were impacted by central banks' efforts to combat inflation. The losses capped a tough week for Hong Kong shares, which were already experiencing a downturn due to recession fears.

site_title: Vietnam plans cuts in fuel taxes as inflation rises
summary: Vietnam's finance ministry proposes cutting special consumption tax and value-added tax on fuels to keep inflation under 4% this year. The proposed cuts could reduce tax collection by 7.4-12.2 trillion dong. The move follows the central bank's decision to raise policy rates and previous tax cuts on fuels. If implemented, the tax cuts could lower the average consumer price index by 0.1-0.15% over 6 months. The decision aims to mitigate inflationary pressure amid rising food and energy prices globally.

site_title: Hot stock: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding surges over 15% in afternoon trade, responds to SGX query
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding surged 15.5% to S$1.27 on Friday, with 118.7 million shares changing hands, prompting a query from the Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) over "unusual price movements". The company attributed the trading activity to media reports on its entry into a technical assistance and licence agreement with France-based Gaztransport & Technigaz (GTT). The stock closed 12.7% higher at S$1.24, with analysts citing the weakening Chinese yuan and global shipbuilders' strong performance as contributing factors.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
The index stock was the top traded counter by volume at Friday’s opening bell, with more than 22.1 million shares changing.
Ren Letian, executive chairman and CEO of Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, said: “As one of the leading shipyards in China, we are determined to be a major part of providing greener solutions."
Yangzijiang Shipbuilding has clinched a total of US$990m new orders this year.

site_title: New UK finance minister slashes taxes - and hopes growth will pay for it
summary: UK Finance Minister Kwasi Kwarteng unveiled historic tax cuts and increased borrowing to boost economic growth, but the move sent financial markets into turmoil, with sterling and government bonds plummeting. The cuts include scrapping the top income tax rate and cancelling corporate tax rises, but critics warn it could exacerbate inflation and debt. The move is seen as a gamble, with investors expecting higher interest rates and a potential policy tug-of-war reminiscent of the 1970s.

images.alt_text: Kwasi Kwarteng's first budget represents a significant gamble as UK faces the most difficult economic landscape in years.

site_title: Award-winning British author Hilary Mantel dies at 70
summary: Award-winning British author Hilary Mantel has died at 70. Mantel, known for her Wolf Hall trilogy, which won two Booker Prizes, passed away peacefully surrounded by family and friends. The trilogy, which includes Bring Up the Bodies and The Mirror & the Light, sold over 5 million copies worldwide and charted the fortunes of Thomas Cromwell, King Henry VIII's most powerful adviser. Mantel was praised for her biting wit, stylistic daring, and historical insight, leaving behind a remarkable body of work.

site_title: Some US firms wait to issue bonds in a bet rates will come down
summary: US companies with top credit ratings are opting for shorter-term debt solutions, such as bank term loans and bridge loans, to fund their operations, rather than issuing bonds. This is a bet that rising interest rates will lead to recessionary headwinds and lower Treasury yields. By drawing down on bridge loans or issuing bonds with maturities of 5 years or less, these companies are hoping to avoid higher funding costs. This trend is slowing new bond issuance despite investor demand, as companies wait for a more favorable funding environment.

images.alt_text: The hopes of a dovish shift that drove a rebound through June and July have evaporated since Fed Chair Jerome Powell committed to higher rates for as long as it takes to tame inflation.

site_title: Gloom descends on UK property market amid higher interest rates, recession fears
summary: The UK property market is facing a downturn amid higher interest rates and recession fears. Commercial property values are expected to fall 10-20% between 2021 and 2023, with some segments like warehouses experiencing rental growth. The Bank of England may raise interest rates further, causing inflation to spike. Despite this, long-term property investments have proven to be a hedge against inflation, with UK property outperforming the consumer price index over the past 40 years.

images.alt_text: Of the cuts, Chancellor Kwasi Kwarteng said: “The steps we’ve taken today mean 200,000 more people will be taken out of paying stamp duty altogether."
A person walks with a dog in front of a row of residential housing in south London, Britain, August 6, 2021. REUTERS/Henry Nicholls
UK real estate is in a moment of flux as a decade-long bull market fuelled by rock bottom interest rates shudders into reverse amid recession fears.

site_title: Green bonds attract higher subscription rates, better secondary pricing than conventional ones: CBI
summary: Market demand and pricing for green bonds in the first half of 2022 remained stronger than their conventional counterparts, despite a drop in issuance volumes. Euro-denominated green bonds were 3.1 times oversubscribed, while US dollar-denominated green bonds were 3.8 times oversubscribed. Green bonds also commanded higher prices on the secondary market than conventional bonds, with an average spread compression of 18.2 basis points. However, the relatively low incidence of a "green premium" in the first half of the year reflects investors' cautiousness due to uncertain geopolitical and macroeconomic conditions.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
Asia’s green bond issuers look past pricing to branding and investor access

site_title: SLA to help Turf City tenants relocate, reiterates lease will end on Dec 31, 2023
summary: The Singapore Land Authority (SLA) has confirmed that the lease on Turf City will end on December 31, 2023, despite two 18-month extensions granted earlier. The SLA will assist tenants, including childcare providers, food and beverage establishments, and motor vehicle-related businesses, with relocation plans. Government agencies will help affected tenants with their transition, and SLA will engage stakeholders to share plans for the site's future development. Tenants have varying reactions, with some hoping for further lease extensions and others expressing disappointment over the final deadline.

site_title: Hong Kong lowers buyer stress test requirement for mortgages
summary: Hong Kong's de facto central bank, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, has lowered the mortgage stress test requirement for property buyers to 200 basis points from 300, effective immediately. This change aims to support the market amid rising interest rates and a softening market. The decision is seen as prudent for effective risk management of banks' property lending business, allowing homebuyers to borrow more despite the interest rate hike.

images.alt_text:
ST20190615-201926348522-Lim Yaohui/Elizabeth Law/

Housing apartments and Kowloon Bay Mass Transit Railway (MTR) station in Hong Kong on June 23, 2019. 

A series of protests have erupted over the past few weeks in Hong Kong as tens of thousands of protesters clashed with the police to oppose a proposed extradition bill that would send lawbreakers to face trial in mainland China. Hong Kongers see it as China's steady erosion of civil rights in the territory.

(ST PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI)

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Food inflation in Singapore rose 6.4% in August, exceeding the 6.1% in July, driven by higher prices for food services and non-cooked food. Core inflation in Singapore reached 5.1% in August, its highest in three months. Singapore overtook Hong Kong to become Asia's top financial centre and the third globally. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.1% due to inflation concerns. DBS and UOB reviewed fixed-rate home loans after the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike, while DBS also allows accredited investors to trade cryptocurrencies via its mobile app.

site_title: Malaysia inflation rate surges to 4.7% in August, driven by rising food prices
summary: Malaysia's inflation rate surged to 4.7% in August, driven primarily by rising food prices. The consumer price index (CPI) rose 0.2% month-over-month, with food and non-alcoholic beverages increasing 7.2%. Core inflation, excluding volatile items, rose 3.8%. Despite higher inflation, about 30 controlled-price items with government subsidies helped ease consumer burden. Economists predict moderation in inflation in the next few months due to improving economy and income levels.

images.alt_text: Higher food prices continue to fuel Malaysia's inflation with the country's consumer price index climbed 4.4 per cent in July this year, the highest since May 2021.

site_title: Hong Kong says will scrap Covid hotel quarantine from Sep 26
summary: Hong Kong will scrap its Covid-19 hotel quarantine policy for all international arrivals starting September 26, more than 2.5 years after its implementation. Arrivals will be allowed to return home or choose accommodation, but must self-monitor for 3 days after entry. They can attend work or school but not bars or restaurants during the period. The policy change aims to boost the city's competitiveness as a global financial center, ending a policy that has weighed on its economy and fueled an exodus of residents since early 2020.

images.alt_text: Travellers need to stump up HK$102,000 (S$18,511) for a return business-class flight to Los Angeles early next month, more than double the usual fare.

site_title: MPA teams up with industry to build future maritime talent
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) has partnered with industry players, including Pacific Carriers Limited and the American Bureau of Shipping, to establish the Alliance for Future Maritime Talent. The alliance aims to equip the maritime workforce with new skills as the industry transforms, putting Singapore in a favorable position in the face of global competition for maritime talent. A tripartite advisory panel will support the alliance in engaging stakeholders and gathering industry feedback, identifying emerging and future skills for the maritime industry.

images.alt_text: MPA chief executive Quah Ley Hoon will step down on Sep 5.

site_title: US business activity gauge still contracting
summary: US business activity contracted for a third-straight month in September, but at a more moderate pace, according to the S&P Global flash composite purchasing managers output index. The index rose to a three-month high of 49.3, indicating a slight improvement. Demand remains tenuous as customers adjust to elevated prices and higher interest rates. Input-cost inflation is cooling, but remains elevated, and business activity continues to paint a picture of an economy struggling in a stagflationary environment.

images.alt_text:
NEW YORK, NEW YORK - JULY 28: A man moves merchandise from a truck in Manhattan on July 28, 2022 in New York City. The Commerce Department said on Thursday that the nation's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) fell 0.2 percent in the second quarter. With two GDP declines in a row, many economists fear that the United States could be entering a recession.   Spencer Platt/Getty Images

Among industry groups, US factory production for machinery, aerospace equipment, and computers and electronic products increased.

site_title: Kwarteng slammed for driving a wedge between UK's rich and poor
summary: Chancellor Kwasi Kwarteng's economic plan, featuring a tax giveaway and changes to welfare payments, has been criticized for being "socially divisive." Only 12% of the gains will benefit the poorest half of households, with those earning £20,000 expected to gain £157 per year, while those earning £200,000 will see a £5,220 increase. The plan has sparked concerns about widening the gap between the rich and poor in the UK.

images.alt_text: Sterling fell as low as US$1.1151 – its weakest since early 1985 – after the Bank of England on Thursday hiked borrowing costs by 50 basis points.

site_title: China has 3.57 trillion yuan bailout ammunition for property mess
summary: China has sufficient bailout funds to address its property crisis, with total bailout funds potentially reaching 3.57 trillion yuan (S$720.6 billion). This exceeds the estimated 700 billion yuan to 800 billion yuan funding gap for stalled projects. Authorities have implemented measures such as cutting interest rates and offering special loans to ensure property projects are completed. Despite these efforts, mortgage boycotts and homeowners' demands for better construction and services continue to grow, posing a challenge to the government's efforts to stabilize the economy and social stability.

site_title: Stamford Land confirms sale of Sydney hotel for A$210.5m
summary: Stamford Land has confirmed the sale of its 10-storey hotel, Sir Stamford at Circular Quay, in Sydney's central business district to JDH Capital for A$210.5 million. The sale price is A$120.5 million higher than the latest property valuation, and the company expects to receive a 76% increase in net cash compared to redevelopment. The sale will be used for future acquisitions and investments, and to mitigate rising interest rates. The redevelopment, valued at over A$380 million, is expected to take 3 years and will convert the property into residential units.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
Sydney's Sir Stamford at Circular Quay, one of Stamford Land's hotels.

site_title: Hong Kong airfares skyrocket as hotel quarantine ends
summary: Hong Kong's end to hotel quarantine on September 26 is expected to lead to a surge in airfares, with business-class flights to Los Angeles costing HK$102,000 (S$18,511), more than double the usual fare. Airlines, including Cathay Pacific, have been preparing for the move, with Cathay planning to add over 200 flights in October. However, foreign carriers face challenges in restarting services due to airport restrictions and staff shortages, with some airlines planning to resume flights only in late 2022 or early 2023.

images.alt_text: ANA carried 330,796 passengers internationally in July, up from 197,571 in April.

site_title: Japan to support Sri Lanka's debt restructuring negotiations
summary: Japan will support Sri Lanka's debt restructuring negotiations, with the country backing the South Asian nation as it seeks to restructure around $30 billion of foreign debt. Japan, one of Sri Lanka's main creditors, will work with other creditor countries, including China and India, to find a way out of the crippling economic crisis. The IMF's $2.9 billion bailout package depends on reaching an agreement with creditors. Japan will only resume talks on large infrastructure projects once Sri Lanka's economy recovers.

images.alt_text: Food inflation climbed 84.6 per cent in August, while non-food inflation was up 57.1 per cent, Sri Lanka's Department of Census and Statistics said in a statement.

site_title: Britain to scrap banker bonus cap to 'deregulate' the City
summary: Britain plans to scrap its banker bonus cap, allowing banks to offer unlimited bonuses to top executives. The move is part of an "ambitious deregulatory" package, which aims to boost the City of London's competitiveness as a global financial centre. The cap, introduced in 2014, limits bonuses to twice a banker's basic salary with shareholder approval. The decision comes amid a cost of living crisis and a need to bolster the UK's financial sector, but is expected to trigger anger among consumer groups and critics who argue it will increase inequality.

images.alt_text: After 8 years of dealing with the rules, British banks have found ways to align pay with that of other regions.

site_title: Eurozone likely entering recession as price rises hit demand
summary: The eurozone is likely entering a recession as price rises hit demand, according to a survey by S&P Global. The Composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) fell to 48.2 in September from 48.9 in August, indicating a deepening downturn in business activity. High energy costs and a cost of living crisis led to consumers reducing spending, particularly in the manufacturing and services sectors. This marks the third month below the 50 mark separating growth from contraction, suggesting a recession is imminent.

images.alt_text: The latest inflation data for the eurozone is due to be published next week and will provide a crucial input for ECB upcoming decisions.

site_title: UK slashes property tax, with biggest cuts for first-time buyers
summary: The UK government has announced significant tax cuts to stimulate the housing market, with the stamp duty threshold for first-time buyers increasing to £425,000 from £300,000. The maximum home value eligible for relief will also rise to £625,000. Chancellor Kwasi Kwarteng stated that these changes will benefit 200,000 more people, reducing the tax burden. The measures are permanent and effective immediately, aiming to increase housing supply and make homeownership more affordable.

images.alt_text: Inflation is close to a 40-year high, driving up the cost of goods and services of all kinds.

site_title: UK’s biggest tax cuts since 1972 prompt crash in pound
summary: The UK's largest tax cuts since 1972, including the scrapping of the 45% top income tax rate and a 1% cut in the basic rate, prompted a significant decline in the pound, falling to a 37-year low of US$1.1151. The package, worth £161 billion over five years, has raised concerns about Britain's debt burden and inflationary threat. The Bank of England has since raised borrowing costs by 50 basis points, with traders predicting a further rate hike to 3.25% in November. The move has been criticized by economists and opposition parties, who warn it will worsen the economy and finances of families struggling with rising inflation and energy bills.

images.alt_text: The BOE on Thursday hiked rates by half a point to take the benchmark to 2.25 per cent.

site_title: Hungary and Russia hold talks on gas, nuclear plant
summary: Hungary's Foreign Minister Peter Szijjarto met Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov in New York, discussing gas shipments and the construction of the Paks nuclear plant. Hungary relies heavily on Russian energy, with Szijjarto stating that without it, the Hungarian economy would not operate. The two nations also agreed on the next steps for the nuclear plant project, with Hungary aiming to expand the plant with two new Russian-made reactors. The talks came as EU sanctions on Russia remain in place, with Hungary criticizing the measures for failing to weaken Moscow.

site_title: DBS, UOB review fixed-rate home loans as latter ceases offering
summary: UOB and DBS are reviewing interest rates on their fixed-rate home loans following the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike. UOB has temporarily ceased offering its 2-year and 3-year fixed-rate packages, while DBS is reviewing rates but will still offer fixed-rate loans. OCBC continues to offer a 2-year fixed rate at 2.98%. All three lenders will still offer floating-rate home loans pegged to the Singapore Overnight Rate Average (Sora). The review is aimed at ensuring competitive pricing and meeting homeowners' unique needs.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
The Fed's move to raise interest rates has had wide-ranging effects on different asset classes.
MORTGAGE rates have continued to climb in Singapore as lenders here take their cue from the US Federal Reserve.

site_title: Europe: Stocks fall at open
summary: European stocks fell at the open, with London's FTSE 100 index dipping 0.1% to 7,154.20 points ahead of a UK budget aimed at tackling inflation. The eurozone's DAX and CAC 40 indices also fell 0.3% each. This follows a week of interest rate hikes by central banks to cool inflation, with European indices closing down nearly 2% on Thursday.

site_title: Japan PM says to ease Covid border control requirements next month
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida announced plans to ease COVID-19 border control requirements starting October 11, aligning with the US, and resume visa-free travel and individual travel. The move aims to boost Japan's tourism sector, which has been hindered by strict border measures since the pandemic's onset. The changes will include scrapping a daily cap on arrivals and revising hotel regulations, allowing for refusal of guests who don't adhere to infection controls.

site_title: Singapore stocks stumble on inflation woes; STI falls 1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.1% to close at 3,227.10 on Friday, down 1.3% for the week, due to higher-than-expected inflation figures for August. Core inflation accelerated, driven by price increases in services and food, suggesting that domestic drivers for inflation are becoming more prominent. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding was the biggest gainer, while Jardine Matheson Holdings fell 2.7%. The decline was part of a broader market trend, with most Asian markets ending lower due to interest rate hikes amid high inflation.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
As at 3.35pm on Friday, the counter had climbed S$0.17 or 15.5 per cent to reach an intra-day high of S$1.27 after 118.7 million of its shares changed hands.
People shopping for bread and biscuits at Vivocity, Harbourfront on March 10, 2022.

site_title: Pakistan PM says ‘all hell’ to break loose without debt deal
summary: Pakistan Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif urged the international community to provide debt relief as the country struggles with catastrophic floods that have displaced millions and caused $30 billion in damage. With debt obligations looming in the next two months, Sharif warned that "all hell will break loose" without assistance. He has signed an agreement with the IMF and will begin talks with China for debt relief, but faces a "yawning gap" between what Pakistan needs and what is available.

images.alt_text: A family evacuating following rains and floods during the monsoon season in Sohbatpur in Pakistan on Aug 29. The floods are expected to have an economic impact of at least US$10 billion, worsening the economic fortunes of a country already beset by political turmoil and raging inflation.

site_title: South Korea central bank enlists its pension fund to defend weak won
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, has enlisted its pension fund, the National Pension Service, in a $10 billion currency swap deal to defend the weakening won. The deal will last through the end of the year, allowing the fund to access the bank's foreign exchange reserves and reducing demand for US dollars. The move aims to stabilize the currency market and curb further capital outflows, which have led to a 16% decline in the won against the US dollar this year.

site_title: Crypto lender Celsius shareholders set up representation committee
summary: Celsius Network's shareholders have filed a motion to establish a representation committee to ensure their interests are protected in the company's bankruptcy proceedings. The move comes after Celsius filed for bankruptcy in July, following the collapse of other digital assets such as Voyager Digital Holdings and Three Arrows Capital. The committee aims to safeguard the rights of Series B preferred shareholders, who "urgently require their own fiduciary." The filing was made on September 22, amid the ongoing bankruptcy proceedings.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 14.18 points to 1,424.98. A total of 1.844 billion lots worth RM1.574 billion changed hands, with losers outnumbering gainers 540 to 278.

site_title: Golden Equator to launch Web3 fund with Snoop Dogg’s son
summary: Golden Equator Group has partnered with Cordell Broadus, son of Snoop Dogg, to launch the Welcome To The Block (WTTB) Web3 fund, aiming to raise $40-50 million for early-stage blockchain and Web3 investments by the end of 2022. The fund will focus on centralised finance, decentralised finance, and Web3 infrastructure, targeting scalable businesses with strong founding teams and high growth potential.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

Ethereum used to be secured by a network of high-powered computers that competed against one another to solve cryptographic puzzles, burning vast amounts of energy in the process. Now, it will be secured by a process known as “staking”, which involves investors agreeing to deposit their crypto coins in a shared pool in exchange for a chance to earn financial rewards.
Developers have spent years working on a more energy-efficient version of the ethereum blockchain.
Demand in the NFT market has slumped in recent months, with resale value performing poorly alongside wider industry turmoil that has wiped around US$2 trillion from the crypto sector's total value.
OpenSea is the top NFT marketplace by trading volume, having done more than US$31 billion in sales all-time.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit over 2-month low after Fed hike; banks drag
summary: Australia's shares closed at a 2-month low, falling 1.9% to 6,574.7 points, as banking stocks declined following the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hike and hawkish stance on policy tightening. The S&P/ASX 200 index declined 2.4% for the week. Energy stocks also fell, weighed down by weak oil prices, while technology stocks dropped 4.4% tracking US peers.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index slumped as much as 1.4 per cent to 6,602.6 by 0040 GMT on Friday, to hit its lowest level since July, with all but one subindex trading in the red.

site_title: Swiss bank UBP returns to Chinese markets
summary: Swiss private bank Union Bancaire Privée (UBP) has returned to Chinese markets, re-entering the world's second-largest economy after withdrawing last year. UBP has over $150 billion in assets and has bought China A-shares, avoiding companies with geopolitical exposure. Chief Investment Officer Norman Villamin sees "hope" for stimulus measures ahead of the Communist Party Congress in October, which could ease Covid restrictions. UBP believes China is poised to recover, but growth opportunities are limited due to deep-seated problems such as the real estate debt crisis.

images.alt_text: Risk-on but be selective

site_title: Seoul: Won posts seventh weekly loss on slowdown concerns; stocks fall
summary: The South Korean won dropped to its weakest level since 2009, losing 1.5% against the US dollar, as investors worried about the US Federal Reserve's aggressive approach to tame inflation triggering a recession. The benchmark KOSPI index fell 1.81% to 2,290.00, marking its sharpest weekly decline since mid-June. The won lost 15.6% against the US dollar this year, while the KOSPI dropped 23.09% so far this year.

site_title: Malaysia’s ex-DPM acquitted of graft charges
summary: Malaysia's former Deputy Prime Minister Ahmad Zahid Hamidi was acquitted of 40 bribery charges by a high court, citing insufficient evidence. The charges involved alleged bribes of around $11 million to win government contracts over a foreign visa system. This acquittal comes after former Prime Minister Najib Razak received a 12-year jail term for corruption and abuse of power in a separate scandal. The verdict marks a significant development in Malaysia's ongoing efforts to address corruption and bring high-ranking officials to justice.

images.alt_text: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak is escorted by the prison officers during a break of his second trial related to the 1Malaysia Development Berhad scandal at the Kuala Lumpur Court Complex in Kuala Lumpur on Aug 25.

site_title: The second coming of the Appletini
summary: A resurgence of the 1990s martini trend is underway, with bartenders reimagining classic cocktails and offering unique twists. From the purple Grand Martiny's at Martiny's in Manhattan to the apple martinis at Milady's in SoHo, creative bartenders are pushing the boundaries of the traditional martini. The trend is driven by nostalgia, improved palates, and the need for a stiff drink in hard times. With a focus on high-quality spirits and a drier touch, modern martinis are being crafted with skill and attention to detail, reviving the classic cocktail in a new and exciting way.

site_title: BT Market Focus: Recession fears remerge (Ep 13)
summary: Recession fears are reemerging in global markets, according to a recent podcast by The Business Times. The episode discusses the drivers and movements in Singapore and the region. Key factors include the wrap-up of SGX's weekly market analysis, insights from The Business Times' newsdesk, and notable company-specific news. The podcast aims to provide general information and is not intended to be relied upon for investment advice. Recession fears are dominating markets due to various economic indicators and market movements.

images.alt_text: How are markets reacting to looming interest rate hikes?
How might possible central bank announcements affect markets?

site_title: Singapore-Tokyo economy airfares cross S$2,000 mark as Japan lifts restrictions on tourists
summary: Japan has lifted restrictions on tourists, resuming border reopenings, with return economy tickets from Singapore to Tokyo's Haneda Airport now over S$2,000. Flights to other popular spots like Sapporo are also selling for above S$2,100. Strong demand from "revenge travel" is driving up prices, with a 100% increase in flight ticket searches on Expedia. The country's reopening is expected to boost tourism, with Tokyo ranking 9th on Expedia's top 10 searched cities list.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

Japan intervened in the foreign exchange market on Thursday to buy yen for the first time since 1998, in an attempt to shore up the battered currency after the Bank of Japan (BOJ) stuck with ultra-low interest rates.

site_title: Daimler Truck begins producing Mercedes-Benz branded trucks in China
summary: Daimler Truck has begun producing Mercedes-Benz branded trucks in China, marking a significant move into the country's massive market. The joint venture with Foton Motor in Beijing will initially produce around 50,000 Actros trucks per year. China is the world's largest market for heavy trucks, with 1.5 million units sold in 2021, and Daimler aims to tap into this market with its Mercedes-Benz brand. This move comes after the company previously only sold imported Mercedes-Benz trucks at a higher price.

site_title: A global recession isn’t inevitable
summary: A global recession isn't inevitable, according to recent analysis. While the US, Canada, and most of Europe are expected to fall into recession within the next year, the global economy can narrowly avoid a contraction. Since the 1980s, there have been 9 advanced economy recession clusters, with only 5 coinciding with global GDP falls. The upcoming US recession is expected to be smaller than previous ones, making a global contraction avoidable.

images.alt_text: On Sep 16 it took more than seven yuan to buy a dollar for the first time since July 2020.
Surging prices have forced central banks worldwide to tighten monetary policy, which is expected to cool inflation but risks tipping economies into recession.

site_title: Singapore overtakes Hong Kong in world financial centres ranking
summary: Singapore has overtaken Hong Kong to become the world's third-largest financial centre, according to a report by the Global Financial Centres Index. New York and London remain in the top two spots. The city-state's high-profile events and business-friendly environment have contributed to its rise, while Hong Kong struggles to revive its role due to strict Covid restrictions and an exodus of talent.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong is the most expensive office market in the world.

site_title: Japanese airline ANA will increase international flights as borders reopens for travel
summary: ANA to increase international flights as Japan abolishes Covid border controls next month. The airline carried 330,796 international passengers in July, up from 197,571 in April, and plans to add more flights to serve 36 cities. Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida announced the easing of border controls, allowing tourists to enter without visas, and ANA expects strong demand for trips to Honolulu and Singapore. The airline also plans to increase North America flights to about 90% of pre-pandemic levels from October 30.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Ground crew members work next to an All Nippon Airways (ANA) aircraft at the Tokyo International Airport, commonly known as Haneda Airport, in Tokyo, Japan October 27, 2020. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon/File Photo  GLOBAL BUSINESS WEEK AHEAD

site_title: Apple will sponsor Super Bowl halftime show starting in February 2023
summary: Apple has signed a multi-year deal to sponsor the Super Bowl Halftime Show starting in February 2023. The deal, worth undisclosed financial terms, will feature Apple Music as the primary sponsor of the halftime show. This marks a significant promotional platform for Apple, which has been associated with music since 2001. The Super Bowl Halftime Show is one of the most-watched television events in the US, with over 120 million viewers tuning in for the 2022 halftime show.

site_title: China’s Sinopec launches carbon capture, investment unit
summary: Sinopec Group has launched a unit to engage in carbon capture and storage, with a registered capital of 2.5 billion yuan. The new firm, Sinopec Carbon Industry Technology, aims to capture and store 3 million tonnes of CO2 annually and utilise 2 million tonnes by 2025. This move is part of Sinopec's national goal to reach peak carbon emissions by 2030 and carbon neutrality by 2060, with a multi-billion dollar investment in low-carbon sectors.

images.alt_text: The project, which started construction just over a year ago, involves capturing carbon dioxide produced from Sinopec’s Qilu refinery in Shandong province during a hydrogen-making process, and then injecting it into 73 oil wells in the nearby Shengli oilfield. The company has estimated that 10.68 million tonnes of carbon dioxide will be injected into the oilfield over the next 15 years, boosting crude oil production by nearly 3 million tonnes.

site_title: Malaysia rules out capital controls, currency peg as ringgit trades near 24-yr low
summary: Malaysia's central bank rules out capital controls and pegging the ringgit to the US dollar amid a 24-year low. The ringgit has dropped nearly 9% this year, following a strengthening US dollar. Governor Nor Shamsiah Mohd Yunus stated that policy priority is sustaining economic growth with price stability and strengthening domestic fundamentals through structural reforms, providing a more enduring support for the ringgit.

images.alt_text: No more election play? Analysts said the excitement of the upcoming general election will be less pronounced due to political uncertainties and depleting government coffers.

site_title: Thailand to lift Covid emergency as virus declared not dangerous
summary: Thailand has lifted most pandemic-era restrictions on travel and businesses due to a steady decline in new Covid cases and an increase in vaccination rates. The country downgraded Covid-19 from a "dangerous" communicable disease to one requiring surveillance, ending a nationwide state of emergency declared in March 2020. The move is expected to boost tourism, a key sector in sustaining economic recovery, with foreign visitor arrivals reaching 5.26 million between January and September this year, up from 427,869 in 2021. Travellers will no longer require proof of vaccination to enter the country starting next month.

site_title: Vietnam’s central bank sees 2022 GDP growth of 6.7% to 8.5%, inflation below 4%
summary: Vietnam's central bank expects the country's GDP to grow 6.7% to 8.5% in 2022, while keeping inflation below 4%. The bank will maintain "flexible monetary policy" to support economic growth while controlling inflation. Vietnam has rebounded from the pandemic with strong manufacturing and exports, but faces upward pressure on inflation. The country's official GDP growth target is 6.0 to 6.5%.

images.alt_text: The State Bank of Vietnam's rare monetary policy tightening comes as it tries to control inflation.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars wallow at over two-year lows as risk aversion reigns
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars hit a two-year low due to risk aversion, driven by the US Federal Reserve's aggressive interest rate hikes and concerns over global growth and geopolitical tensions, particularly from Russia's war in Ukraine. The Aussie dollar fell to US$0.6574, its lowest since May 2020, and was headed for a weekly loss of 1%. The decline was attributed to investors seeking safe-haven assets, with the US dollar gaining strength.

images.alt_text: A man uses his mobile phone next to the Reserve Bank of Australia building in central Sydney March 2, 2010. Australia's central bank increased its key cash rate by 25 basis points to 4.0 percent on Tuesday, the fourth hike in five meetings as it gradually normalizes policy to reflect a recovering economy. REUTERS/Daniel Munoz (AUSTRALIA - Tags: BUSINESS)
Australia’s central bank is in the midst of its sharpest policy tightening cycle in a generation.

site_title: An energy crisis and geopolitics are creating a new-look Gulf
summary: The Gulf region is undergoing a transformation, driven by an energy crisis and geopolitics, making it richer, more powerful, and more volatile. The 2022 FIFA World Cup in Qatar, expected to draw 1 million fans, is set to coincide with a $3.5 trillion energy boom, fueled by Vladimir Putin's war in Ukraine. This boom is also linked to Western sanctions and climate change, leading to a re-engineering of global energy flows and remaking of geopolitical alliances in the Middle East. The region's stability is uncertain, with ongoing conflicts and a security vacuum.

images.alt_text: Dubai, as part of its long-term efforts to diversify its economy away from oil, wants jobs in the metaverse.
Brent crude futures rose 60 cents, or 0.7 per cent, to US$91.95 a barrel by 0330 GMT on Monday after settling up 0.5 per cent on Friday.

site_title: The unspeakable joy of a permanent downgrade
summary: Travel writer Vijay Verghese recounts his journey from Hong Kong to New Delhi, navigating India's complexities, including temperamental airport water dispensers, bank upgrades, and autorickshaws. After experiencing a downgrade on his credit card, he continues his trip, visiting cemeteries, local banks, and enjoying Indian cuisine. Despite power outages and bureaucratic hurdles, Verghese finds the beauty in India's "unfathomable things" and timelessness. His journey highlights the country's quirks and resilience, leaving him with a newfound appreciation for the land and its people.

images.alt_text: Venice, a repository of centuries-old culture and bustling commerce

site_title: Epidemic preparedness: No template
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has taught the world a valuable lesson in epidemic preparedness, despite a lack of initial action. The failure to freeze international travel early on exacerbated the outbreak. However, the pandemic has accelerated vaccine development, approval, and production processes, which can be leveraged for future epidemics. As the World Health Organisation suggests the pandemic's end is near, it's crucial to assess global preparedness for potential future outbreaks.

images.alt_text: “We are not there yet. But the end is in sight,” WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus told reporters at a virtual press conference.

site_title: In the dollar we trust
summary: The US dollar has reached its highest level in 20 years, with a 28% gain against the yen, 20% against the pound, and 19% against the euro since May last year. Despite inflation and slowing growth, the dollar's strength can be attributed to the relative resilience of the US economy and the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes. The US economy remains strong compared to its major trading partners, which are experiencing energy crises and economic slowdowns. The widening interest rate differential between the US and other countries also makes dollar assets more attractive to global investors, making the dollar a safe haven.

images.alt_text: US Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell speaking during a news conference following a meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) on Sep 21, 2022 in Washington, DC.

site_title: Chipmaker Qualcomm says automotive future business expands to US$30b
summary: Qualcomm's automotive business is expected to reach $30 billion by 2025, with a potential market size of $100 billion by 2030. The company's Snapdragon Digital Chassis product, used by car makers and suppliers, provides assisted and autonomous driving technology, in-car infotainment, and cloud connectivity. This growth is driven by the increasing use of chips in electric vehicles and autonomous features in cars, making the automotive market a key area for chipmakers.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Qualcomm sign is pictured at Mobile World Congress (MWC) in Shanghai, China June 28, 2019. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo
IdeaForge is working with financial advisers on the potential listing, which could happen in the first quarter of 2023.

site_title: Malaysia to table amended anti-tobacco Bill after resistance
summary: Malaysia's government plans to table an amended anti-tobacco Bill in October, which aims to ban smoking and vaping for those born in 2007 and restrict their access to tobacco products after age 18. The Bill, dubbed a 'generational endgame,' has been amended following resistance from lawmakers, who criticized its features as infringing on personal freedom. Health Minister Khairy Jamaluddin clarified that enforcement powers will be restricted to distribution, manufacturing, and supply, and individuals will not be frisked or have their personal belongings confiscated if they contravene the law.

site_title: LG Energy inks cobalt, lithium supply deals with 3 Canadian miners
summary: LG Energy Solution has signed agreements with 3 Canadian mining firms - Electra, Avalon, and Snowlake - to secure mid- to long-term supply contracts for cobalt and lithium. The deals, part of LG's expansion efforts in North America, aim to meet the US Inflation Reduction Act's requirement for critical minerals used in EV batteries to come from the US or an American free-trade partner. The agreements include 7,000 tonnes of cobalt sulfate, 55,000 tonnes of lithium hydroxide for 5 years, and 200,000 tonnes for 10 years.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index up 0.21 points or 0.01% to 1,439.37. Volume was 171.86 million lots worth RM86.17 million, with 176 gainers outnumbering 129 losers.

site_title: Philippines signals more rate hikes, FX moves to defend peso
summary: The Philippines central bank has signaled more interest-rate hikes, with Governor Felipe Medalla indicating the need for bigger policy rate increases due to the strong US dollar. The bank has raised borrowing costs by 225 basis points this year and may intervene more actively in the foreign exchange market to support the peso. Medalla also expects inflation to return within the 2-4% goal range next year, possibly closer to 3%. The peso rose 0.3% in trading on Friday after the central bank's intervention.

images.alt_text: Felipe Medalla Photographer: Geric Cruz/Bloomberg
The majority of economists in a Bloomberg survey expect Bank Indonesia to raise its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points to a two-year high of 4 per cent.
The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) now expects the current account balance this year to register a deficit of US$20.6 billion, or 5.0 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP).

site_title: Indonesia power firm PLN starts construction US$850m hydro plant
summary: Indonesia's state utility company PLN has begun construction on a US$850 million 4x260 megawatt hydropower plant in West Java, aiming to increase the country's renewable power contribution to 23% by 2025. The project is part of PLN's 2021-2030 power development plan, which targets an additional 10.4 gigawatt of hydropower capacity. The plant is expected to be operational in 2027 and will help lower PLN's carbon emissions as it phases out coal power plants. This move is part of Indonesia's efforts to reduce its reliance on coal and increase its use of hydropower.

site_title: Accredited investors can now trade crypto on DBS mobile app
summary: DBS has expanded its cryptocurrency trading services to accredited investors on its mobile banking app, DBS digibank. Eligible clients can trade Bitcoin, Bitcoin Cash, Ethereum, and XRP with a minimum investment of US$500. The move is seen as a positive development for the industry, with some experts calling it a step towards mainstream acceptance of cryptocurrencies. The bank's move is expected to broaden access to its DBS Digital Exchange to 100,000 more clients in Singapore, with the service launching in late September or early October.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng
The quantity of the world’s largest token, Bitcoin, bought on the members-only exchange was 4 times higher than April, according to a statement from South-east Asia’s largest lender.
DBS not opening crypto services to retail market anytime soon: CEO

site_title: Asia to lead next decade’s global growth in renewable energy: Fitch Solutions
summary: Asia is expected to lead the world's growth in renewable energy over the next decade, driven by a surge in solar energy, with 2 terawatts of new capacity anticipated. China will remain the main contributor to Asia's non-hydropower renewables growth, thanks to its robust solar and wind equipment manufacturing industry. The region is expected to account for 66% of its power capacity growth from non-hydropower renewables, with solar expected to add 1.2 terawatts and wind adding 0.8 terawatts.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah
A Chinese alkaline electrolysis system costs about US$343 per kilowatt, compared with US$1,200 per kilowatt in the West, BloombergNEF said in a report.
Emerging economies, in particular, requires extra help in the form of investments in order to wean national dependencies on cheap fossil fuels used domestically and exported, said researchers.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks kick off with more losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks dropped 0.51% on Friday, September 23, extending the week's sell-off amid recession fears and rising interest rates. The Hang Seng Index fell to 18,055.59, while Shanghai and Shenzhen composite indices also declined. Global market sell-off was fueled by central banks' efforts to control inflation.

site_title: Gold flat as firm dollar, US rate hike dent appeal
summary: Gold prices remain flat at $1,671.60 per ounce, nearly 20% lower since reaching $2,000 in March, due to a strong US dollar and expectations of further interest rate hikes by the US Federal Reserve. The dollar index is close to a 20-year peak, and rising rates are reducing gold's appeal as a non-yielding asset. Many central banks, including the US Federal Reserve, have raised interest rates to combat inflation, which has led to a decline in gold prices.

images.alt_text: Benchmark prices in Shanghai have climbed to a premium of more than US$43 an ounce over their London equivalent, the highest since 2019, according to data from the World Gold Council.
Even though gold is seen as a hedge against inflation, rate hikes to tame inflation tend to raise the opportunity cost of holding zero-yield bullion.

site_title: It’s never too late to ‘fly’ on a trapeze
summary: Director Tom Moore, 79, has pursued his childhood dream of flying on the trapeze, despite being too small for sports in his youth. After a chance encounter with a trapeze teacher in 1996, Moore began learning the sport and made a documentary about the Flying Gaonas. He now practices trapeze about once a month, citing the physical demands as a challenge but also a source of joy and self-discovery. Moore credits the sport with giving him a sense of purpose and attitude, and he shows no intention of giving it up, saying, "If you keep doing it, then your body gets used to it."

images.alt_text: On the bike leg of the Roth Ironman race in Germany, 1997. The event covers a 3.8km swim, 180km cycling, and then a 42km run.

site_title: Asia: Markets suffer further losses as central banks turn screws
summary: Asian markets plummeted on Friday, following a global sell-off fueled by recession fears and central banks' interest rate hikes to combat decades-high inflation. The Federal Reserve's 75 basis point rate hike and similar moves by other countries indicate a dark outlook for equities. The yield on a 10-year US Treasury surged to 3.7%, while the S&P 500 hit its weakest level since June. The dollar strengthened, and oil markets remained subdued due to recession concerns, with prices falling a third from pre-Ukraine conflict highs.

images.alt_text: The Fed's move to raise interest rates has had wide-ranging effects on different asset classes.

Japan intervened in the foreign exchange market on Thursday to buy yen for the first time since 1998, in an attempt to shore up the battered currency after the Bank of Japan (BOJ) stuck with ultra-low interest rates.
Australia’s central bank is in the midst of its sharpest policy tightening cycle in a generation.

site_title: Singapore core inflation climbs to 5.1% in August; prices to stay elevated in coming months
summary: Singapore's core inflation rose to 5.1% in August, exceeding economists' expectations, and is expected to remain elevated in the coming months. Headline inflation, which includes accommodation and private transport costs, jumped to 7.5% in August. Food inflation edged up 6.4% in August, driven by steeper price increases for food services and non-cooked food. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) maintained their full-year forecast ranges of 3-4% for core inflation and 5-6% for headline inflation, but some private-sector economists predict revised forecasts.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Dark clouds above Singapore's central business district. With growth slowing and inflation rising, tougher times may lie ahead.
Private-sector economists are now expecting full-year gross domestic product (GDP) to grow 3.5 per cent, slightly worse than the 3.8 per cent projection they made in June.

site_title: Facebook whistleblower launches nonprofit to take on big tech
summary: Facebook whistleblower Frances Haugen launched a nonprofit organization called Beyond the Screen to combat harm caused by social media. The first project will document big tech's failures in its "legal and ethical obligations" and develop solutions to address these issues. Haugen aims to create social media that "brings out the best in us."

images.alt_text: A trial in Texas federal court ended with jurors deciding that “live” features at Facebook and Instagram used technology patented by Voxer, a company co-founded by Tom Katis, legal documents showed.

The tech groups on the losing end of Friday’s ruling include NetChoice and the Computer & Communications Industry Association, which count Meta Platform’s Facebook, Twitter and Alphabet’s YouTube as members.
The company, which owns Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp, has avoided outright layoffs.

site_title: HappyFresh exits Malaysia and Thailand after strategic review
summary: HappyFresh, a Jakarta-based grocery delivery startup, has ceased operations in Malaysia and Thailand after a strategic review. The company will focus on its main Indonesian market after securing fresh funding and restructuring its business with venture debt funds Genesis, Innoven, and Mars. This decision comes after struggling to raise capital and a sharp downturn in the online grocery sector this year. HappyFresh will stop its grocery business effective immediately, replacing 3 former directors on its board as part of the restructuring effort.

site_title: Singapore shares start lower on Friday; STI down 0.6%
summary: Singapore shares started the day lower, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.6% to 3,243.93, following a decline on Wall Street amid growing recession fears. The tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index fell 1.4% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average shed 0.4%. European shares also slipped, with the pan-European Stoxx 600 index hitting its lowest since February 2021. Key Singaporean stocks, including LifeBrandz, Marco Polo Marine, and Genting Singapore, also declined.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Simon Garing, CEO of Cromwell European Reit's manager. The manager said changes to Dutch tax regime will not affect the real estate investment trust’s distributable income.

site_title: Yvon Chouinard is the founder of Patagonia – and also my ‘dirtbag’ friend
summary: Yvon Chouinard, founder of Patagonia, has given away his US$3 billion company to a trust and nonprofit group to fight climate change and protect wild places. The company's profits, valued at US$100 million annually, will now be used for this purpose. Chouinard, 83, has been a vocal advocate for environmental causes and has risked his life on numerous adventures. He has been a close friend of Tom Brokaw, who met Chouinard through a mutual friend and has shared his passion for the environment. This move is seen as a significant step in reducing the environmental impact of business.

images.alt_text: “Each year, the money we make after reinvesting in the business will be distributed as a dividend to help fight the crisis,” Chouinard said.

site_title: US charges Boeing with misleading investors on 737 MAX safety, fined US$200m
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) fined Boeing $200 million for misleading investors about the safety of the 737 MAX airplane following two deadly crashes. Boeing agreed to settle charges of negligently violating US securities laws. Former CEO Dennis Muilenburg also agreed to pay $1 million to settle the same charges.

site_title: Citigroup sets India as high priority market amid China risks
summary: Citigroup is targeting India as a high-priority market to expand globally due to growing risks in China and other regions. India presents "very clear" opportunities for the bank, with expected initial public offerings and inbound deals in renewable energy and infrastructure. The nation has seen a record $82 billion in merger and acquisition deals in the second quarter, defying global market declines. This move comes as Citigroup lags behind main rivals in setting up a fully-owned investment bank in China.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians cross a busy intersection outside the Citibank branch in the BBD Bagh area in Kolkata, West Bengal, India, on Thursday, 31st October 2012.  Photo: Sanjit Das/Bloomberg

site_title: Australia sees ‘long road’ to repairing China ties
summary: Australia's Foreign Minister Penny Wong warned that repairing ties with China will be a "long road" requiring multiple steps. The two nations have strained relations since 2020 over issues like Chinese influence operations and the COVID-19 pandemic. Wong met with Chinese State Councillor Wang Yi in New York, describing the talks as "constructive" but cautioning against quick normalisation. Trade blockages and consular cases, including the detention of Australian journalist Cheng Lei, were key issues raised during the meeting. A possible first leaders' meeting since 2017 could happen at the G20 in Bali in November.

images.alt_text: Expectations that Australia will avoid 2 straight quarters of contraction are reflected in a bond market where the yield curve has steepened.
Even after a meeting last week where Chinese authorities pleaded with major producers to stabilise prices, lithium carbonate surged to a fresh record, rising to 500,500 yuan (S$100,291) a ton.

site_title: EU set to pave way for 565b euro overhaul of electricity grid
summary: The European Union plans to invest 565 billion euros by 2030 to overhaul its electricity grid, aiming to reduce dependence on Russian fossil fuels and increase renewable energy. The "Digitalising the Energy System" action plan includes measures such as promoting data sharing on electricity use, installing solar panels, and increasing heat pumps and zero-emission vehicles. The plan aims to boost flexibility in energy markets and create a more resilient energy network.

images.alt_text: Europe is entering a critical phase with energy shortages set to increase the strains on the fragile unity that the 27 EU members have managed to maintain since the February invasion.

site_title: Startup model contracts refreshed to include ESG agreements, ESOP terms
summary: The Venture Capital Investment Model Agreements (VIMA) has been updated to include environmental, social and governance (ESG) agreements and employee share option plan (ESOP) terms. The refreshed model contracts, developed by the Singapore Academy of Law and Singapore Venture and Private Capital Association, aim to provide a standardized framework for early-stage startups. The update includes new documents such as a model company constitution and primer for ESOPs, and has been developed in collaboration with 32 industry stakeholders over two years. The VIMA 2.0 documents are intended to alleviate the time and resource burden on startups and promote transparency in the venture capital industry.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
legal, attorney, jurist
Agritech is among the sectors that venture capitalist Jefrey Joe is bullish on.
There were 27 biotech venture investments worth US$530.1 million in South-east Asia this year, as at Aug 25, according to Preqin.

site_title: Faraday Future says ‘misinformation campaign’ hurt fundraising efforts
summary: Faraday Future, an electric vehicle startup, claims a "misinformation campaign" has impacted its fundraising efforts, amid threats of physical violence and death threats against its executives. The company's law firm investigation found allegations against executive chair Susan Swenson to be without merit. Despite facing cooling capital market conditions, Faraday Future is still in talks for significant funding, with a financing facility seeking up to $600 million. The company's production of its luxury electric car, FF 91, is delayed to the fourth quarter of 2022 due to high costs and supply-chain disruptions.

images.alt_text: Faraday Future unveiled its first production vehicle, the FF91, at the CES 2017 in Las Vegas. The vehicle is undergoing testing at the company's California plant.

site_title: Mosul sculptor ‘recreates what was demolished’ on murals depicting Iraq history
