summary: Iraqi sculptor Khaled Al-Abadi has created clay-based murals in Mosul to "recreate what was demolished" during the country's turbulent years of war. The murals depict the country's long history, from the Assyrian period to the Islamic State occupation. Al-Abadi aims to remind future generations of the country's rich cultural heritage, which has suffered significantly during conflicts. The murals are displayed in a courtyard in old Mosul, a part of the city that was heavily damaged during the war.

images.alt_text: The sculptor Khaled al-Abadi works inside his workshop on his sculptures which depict scenes from the history of the city of Mosul, in Mosul, Iraq, September 15, 2022. REUTERS/Khalid al-Mousily
The sculptor Khaled al-Abadi works inside his workshop on his sculptures which depict scenes from the history of the city of Mosul, in Mosul, Iraq, September 15, 2022. REUTERS/Khalid al-Mousily
The sculptor Khaled al-Abadi looks at sculptures he completed which depict scenes from the history of the city of Mosul, in Mosul, Iraq, September 15, 2022. REUTERS/Khalid al-Mousily

site_title: Stocks to watch: Cromwell E-Reit, OxPay Financial, iWOW Technology
summary: Key developments in Singapore's stock market on September 23, 2022, include: Cromwell E-Reit's manager clarifying that changes to Dutch tax regime won't affect distributable income, OxPay Financial's shares rising after paying former executives, and iWOW Technology potentially acquiring a private telecommunication solutions provider. Trading halts were also requested for mm2 Asia and USP Group.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

site_title: Economists raise RBA cash rate outlook to 3.1% by year’s end
summary: Economists predict the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) will raise its cash rate to 3.1% by year's end, a 75 basis point increase from 2.85%, amid a tight labor market and elevated savings levels. This is the sharpest policy tightening cycle in a generation, with economists forecasting a peak of 3.35% in the first quarter. The RBA is expected to keep the cash rate above 3% due to sticky annual inflation above 3% and a moderation in economic growth.

images.alt_text: Outside the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) building in Sydney. Photographer: David Gray/Bloomberg

site_title: Australia: Shares hit over two-month low on Federal Reserve’s stance; banks, tech stocks weigh
summary: Australian shares plummeted to a two-month low, with the S&P/ASX 200 index falling 1.4% to 6,602.6, its lowest level since July. The decline was attributed to the US Federal Reserve's hawkish stance on monetary policy to combat inflation, which led to a global sell-off in riskier assets. Investors exited the market after a one-day holiday, with all but one subindex trading in the red, as concerns of a recession grew.

images.alt_text: The benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index climbed about 0.2 per cent to end at 11,524.21.

site_title: Oil edges higher on Russian supply concerns in volatile trade
summary: Oil prices rose 0.7% on Thursday, with Brent crude futures reaching $90.46, after concerns about Russian supply amid the ongoing war in Ukraine. The market was also influenced by rebounding Chinese demand and interest rate hikes from the Bank of England and other central banks. Russia's conscription efforts have raised concerns about potential supply disruptions, while the European Union considers implementing an oil price cap and tighter sanctions on Russia.

images.alt_text: Walkouts caused the gradual shut down of Exxon’s Port Jerome-Gravenchon oil refinery and Notre Dame de Gravenchon (NDG) petrochemical site in France on Sep 20 before spreading to Fos-Sur-Mer 24 hours later.
Brent futures fell 54 cents, or 0.6 per cent, to US$90.08 a barrel by 2.15 pm EDT (1815 GMT) on Wednesday, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude fell 71 cents, or 0.9 per cent, to US$83.23.

site_title: Credit Suisse sounds out investors about capital hike: sources
summary: Credit Suisse is sounding out investors for a potential capital hike as part of its radical overhaul of its investment bank. The bank is considering drastic scenarios, including exiting the US market, and has already gathered nearly $17.4 billion in capital since 2015. Share prices fell 5.5% after the news, and investors are making tough demands for participating in a capital increase. The bank is also planning to cut around 5,000 jobs as part of a cost reduction drive. No decisions have been made, but quarterly results are due on October 27.

site_title: With an eye on China, US to develop drones with India
summary: The US and India plan to co-develop drones to counter China's growing influence in the region. The US will support India's defense modernization goals by co-producing and co-developing capabilities, including drones launched from airplanes and anti-drone defense systems. India will build the drones and export them to other countries in its region at affordable price points. This move aims to diversify India's weaponry and develop its own defense industry, as well as strengthen US-India ties. The partnership is seen as a response to China's military expansion in the Indo-Pacific region.

images.alt_text: IdeaForge is working with financial advisers on the potential listing, which could happen in the first quarter of 2023.

site_title: Federer, Nadal team up for doubles on Friday at Laver Cup
summary: Roger Federer will team up with Rafael Nadal in a doubles match at the Laver Cup on Friday, marking his last competitive match with his long-time rival. The 41-year-old Federer, who announced his retirement, will play alongside Nadal in a match against American duo Jack Sock and Frances Tiafoe. This will be a dream scenario for Federer, who will be playing his last match with Nadal, a fellow record 22-time Grand Slam champion. The match is part of the 3-day Laver Cup event in London.

images.alt_text: “I’ve worked hard to return to full competitive form. But I also know my body’s capacities and limits, and its message to me lately has been clear. I am 41 years old.” Federer said.

site_title: China may find it hard to cool lithium’s rally this time around
summary: China struggles to control rising lithium prices, which have surged to a record 500,500 yuan (S$100,291) a ton, despite a meeting with major producers to stabilize prices. The supply-demand mismatch and weakening yuan contribute to the rally, squeezing Chinese lithium refiners' margins. China's manufacturing is picking up, with electric vehicle output doubling from last year, further straining lithium supply. The government has urged producers to keep prices in line with production costs and will boost exploration, stabilize imports, and promote recycling.

images.alt_text: With all net growth in car sales last year coming from EVs, demand for the raw materials in batteries has ramped up suddenly.

site_title: Poorer nations face rising debt servicing costs in 2024: report
summary: Poorer nations face rising debt servicing costs in 2024, with the Vulnerable Group of Twenty (V20) expecting debt service payments to rise to $69 billion by 2024, the highest level in the current decade. This increase is attributed to the Covid-19 pandemic, Russia's war in Ukraine, and the climate crisis, making it challenging for these countries to invest in climate-proofing and shoring up their economies. The report urges governments to step up debt relief measures and upgrade the International Monetary Fund's Debt Sustainability Analysis to account for climate risks.

images.alt_text: Europe has insisted the rise in coal use is only a temporary measure that will have no long-term impact on the EU target to cut emissions by 55 per cent from 1990 to 2030.
Governments need to step up as world falls behind on climate goals: ISWA panel
Foreign direct investment could bring funding and talent development to areas in South-east Asia and nudge countries away from cheaper but dirtier fossil fuels for energy.

site_title: New Zealand’s inflation data gap leaves RBNZ alone among peers
summary: New Zealand will remain the only OECD member without a monthly inflation report, defying calls from its central bank for more timely data. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand wants a monthly Consumer Price Index (CPI) to assess price pressures, but Statistics New Zealand has no plans to introduce a monthly report, citing resource constraints. The gap, currently 3 months, will be in place until the next monetary policy review on October 5.

images.alt_text: The government’s measure of food prices climbed 8.3 per cent in the year to August, the biggest increase in 13 years.

site_title: UK consumer mood sinks to new depths despite energy bills help
summary: UK consumer confidence has reached its lowest level since records began in the mid-1970s, falling to -49 in September, according to GfK. This is worse than forecasted and has occurred despite the government's announcement of support for households, including capping energy bills. The reading has preceded recession on 4 out of 5 occasions since the survey started in 1974, with consumers buckling under the pressure of the cost-of-living crisis. The outcome will be a major test for Prime Minister Liz Truss's new government.

images.alt_text: A woman wearing a face mask shops in Cambridge Market Square, amid the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak, in Cambridge, Britain, January 14, 2022. REUTERS/Andrew Couldridge/File Photo

site_title: World’s biggest EV battery maker considers third plant in Europe
summary: China's Contemporary Amperex Technology (CATL), the world's biggest EV battery maker, is considering a third factory in Europe, according to its president. The company has already announced plans to build a second European EV battery plant in Hungary, investing 7.3 billion euros, with a planned output of 100 gigawatt hours. Internal discussions are underway, but no clear decision has been made. The move aims to further strengthen CATL's lead over rivals, including LG Energy Solution, the world's second-biggest cell producer.

images.alt_text: CNPC aims to build over 1,000 charging stations by 2025 in China, having built 203 so far, the company said.
The person with knowledge of the company's planning told Reuters CATL had not changed its plan to start local battery production for North America from 2026.

site_title: Nasdaq increases scrutiny of small-cap IPOs after big swings: sources
summary: The Nasdaq is increasing scrutiny of small-cap IPOs following a series of wild market debuts, mainly by issuers based in China and Hong Kong. The exchange is reviewing companies more closely, and some have put their IPO plans on hold. Recent examples include AMTD Digital's 32,000% surge and subsequent 97% drop, and Addentax Group's massive share move. The US Securities and Exchange Commission is also looking into the causes of unusual moves. This increased scrutiny adds uncertainty to ongoing IPOs, including those by Hongli Group, Lichen China, and US-based Alopexx.

images.alt_text: Nasdaq Digital Assets will offer custody services for cryptocurrencies, including bitcoin and Ethereum.

site_title: US can fight inflation without sinking job market: Yellen
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen stated that it's possible to combat record-high inflation while maintaining a healthy labor market. She acknowledged "some inflationary pressure" from the labor market shortage, which has driven wages up. Yellen expressed hope that the Federal Reserve can successfully reduce inflation while preserving the labor market. This contradicts the Fed's recent 75 basis point interest rate hike, which Chair Jerome Powell warned could be painful for the US economy.

images.alt_text: US Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell speaking during a news conference following a meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) on Sep 21, 2022 in Washington, DC.
The Fed's move to raise interest rates has had wide-ranging effects on different asset classes.
Jobless claims have generally been dropping as employers try to fill millions of open positions while retaining the workers they already have.

site_title: Japan to restore visa-free travel from Oct 11
summary: Japan will abolish most COVID-19 border controls starting October 11, allowing individual visitors to enter without visas and ending the daily arrival cap. This move aims to revive the tourism industry, which suffered during the pandemic. The country's deadliest wave of the pandemic has receded, and the yen's slump to its lowest levels in nearly a quarter century is expected to make Japan an attractive destination for visitors. The decision comes as the government seeks to boost the economy and recover lost business.

images.alt_text: Currently, the wearing of masks is not compulsory in Japan but is strongly recommended indoors and on public transport.

site_title: China's Xiamen Airlines orders 40 A320neo aircraft
summary: Xiamen Airlines, a Chinese carrier, has ordered 40 A320neo aircraft from Airbus, marking the airline's switch to the European manufacturer for its fleet growth. Xiamen Airlines previously exclusively operated Boeing aircraft. This order makes the airline the newest Airbus customer.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Airbus A320neo (New Engine Option) takes off during its first flight event in Colomiers near Toulouse, southwestern France, September 25, 2014. REUTERS/Regis Duvignau/File Photo

site_title: Volkswagen has gas supplies for winter but could see shortages next year
summary: Volkswagen expects to maintain production for 5-6 months due to Germany's gas reserves, but rising energy prices and supply chain instability pose a risk. If Nord Stream 1 pipeline resumes, natural gas shortages are unlikely. Volkswagen plans to reduce its natural gas intake by over 20% to meet government minimums. The carmaker also warns of potential shortages in energy-intensive areas like glass and chemicals, which could impact global production.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Volkswagen is displayed at the carmaker's factory in Puebla, Mexico August 31, 2022. REUTERS/Imelda Medina/File Photo

site_title: Chinese gold fetches huge premium as demand improves
summary: Chinese gold prices have reached a premium of over $43 an ounce over international prices, the highest since 2019, according to the World Gold Council. Demand in China has outstripped supply, driven by government policy limiting imports to accredited banks. This premium shows the gap between Chinese and international gold markets, with China's gold market remaining relatively firm despite pressure on international prices. The divergence is attributed to China's unique import system, which restricts gold imports to accredited banks with set quantities.

site_title: US: Wall Street mixed at open after Fed-driven sell-off
summary: US stocks opened mixed on September 22, 2022, after the Federal Reserve's fight against inflation impacted economic growth assessments. The Dow Jones rose 20.7 points, or 0.07%, to 30,204.52, while the S&P 500 fell 7.6 points, or 0.20%, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 52.8 points, or 0.47%. The mixed performance reflects investors' concerns over inflation and economic growth.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - SEPTEMBER 16: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) on September 16, 2022 in New York City. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell again on Friday as economic concerns over inflation and global corporate profits of transport companies fall.   Spencer Platt/Getty Images/AFP

site_title: US: Stocks fall again on Thursday on recession fears
summary: US stocks declined on Thursday, with the Dow Jones shedding 0.4% to 30,076.68 and the S&P 500 falling 0.8% to 3,757.99, amid growing recession fears and interest rate hikes by central banks. The Bank of England raised interest rates for the second consecutive month, warning of a recession. Other European and Asian central banks also increased rates. The decline follows a week of losses, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records earlier in the week.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average has risen 20.7 points, or 0.07 per cent, at the open to 30,204.52.

site_title: Europe: Shares slide to over 1-1/2 year lows on slowdown fears
summary: European shares fell 1.8% on Thursday, reaching a 1.5-year low due to recession fears amid the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hike and signal of more hikes to combat inflation. Rate-sensitive tech and real estate stocks, which fell over 4% each, led the decline. The Stoxx 600 index has hit its lowest since February 2021, highlighting concerns over the European economy.

site_title: Thirteen years later, ‘Avatar’ to return with a focus on family
summary: James Cameron's 'Avatar: The Way of Water' is set to be released in December, 13 years after the first film. The sequel focuses on the theme of protecting family, with Jake Sully (Sam Worthington) and Neytiri (Zoe Saldana) working to shield their family from harm. The movie will expand the world of Pandora, but is not a rehash of the same story. The original 'Avatar' remains the top-grossing film of all time with over $2.8 billion in global ticket sales, and four 'Avatar' movies are planned through 2028.

site_title: Bitcoin tests almost 2-year lows; Ether extends post-merge slide
summary: Bitcoin and Ether cryptocurrencies have plummeted, with Bitcoin fluctuating around $19,000 for a third day and Ether shedding 3% as it continues to underperform since a recent network upgrade. The decline is attributed to the Federal Reserve's efforts to combat inflation by tightening financial conditions, leading to a bond curve inversion and a sharp increase in US dollar gauge. This backdrop is expected to worsen the crypto market, which has already seen a $2 trillion plunge from its 2021 record high.

images.alt_text: The Fed’s determination to raise rates to levels that hammer inflation at the cost of sliding asset prices sent a chill across global markets.
A drop of more than 7 per cent in Bitcoin – something that can happen in a few seconds in digital assets – would send it back to 2020 prices.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Macquarie initiates GoTo at ‘Outperform’ with over 20% upside
summary: Macquarie analysts Ari Jahja and Akshay Sugandi have initiated coverage on GoTo Group, Indonesia's largest tech firm, with a "Outperform" rating and a target price of 324 Indonesian rupiah. The analysts believe growth execution, cost cuts, and fundraising progress will drive the stock's re-rating, with an upside of over 20%. They expect solid revenue growth, robust growth for the financial services arm, and margin improvement, but note certain risks, including lower-than-expected growth and macro slowdown.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
GoTo will likely only turn profitable in 2029, with net income projected at 18.25 trillion by 2032, UOBKH said.
Indonesian tech entrepreneur Pandu Sjahrir, 43, has over 60 companies in his portfolio and over US$1 billion in investments.

site_title: Polaroid ventures into music with speakers, radio-style streaming
summary: Polaroid has entered the music industry with four Bluetooth speakers and an internet radio streaming service, Polaroid Radio. The speakers, priced between $59.99 and $289.99, come in various sizes and colors, including portable P1, pill-shaped P2, boom box-like P3, and large P4. Polaroid Radio offers five curated stations with no ads, and users can save their favorite songs to the Polaroid Music App or Apple Music account. The company aims to expand its presence in the music industry while maintaining its roots in photography, with plans to launch a continuous-focus camera in 2023.

images.alt_text: Spotify"s decision to offer audiobooks on a pay-per-download basis is a departure from the monthly subscription model it uses for music and podcasts.

site_title: Central bank rate hikes are far from over
summary: Central banks worldwide continue to raise interest rates to combat inflation, with aggressive moves from Indonesia and Vietnam. The US Federal Reserve increased its benchmark rate by 75 basis points, while Sweden's Riksbank and Switzerland's SNB also raised rates. However, some countries, such as Turkey and Brazil, cut rates, and others, like Japan, maintained ultra-low rates. Economists warn that higher rates could lead to economic growth slowing, and some predict a recession. The Fed forecasts further rate hikes before year-end, while the Bank of England and Bank of Japan maintain their cautious approach.

images.alt_text: The State Bank of Vietnam's rare monetary policy tightening comes as it tries to control inflation.
Taiwan's central bank has raised the benchmark discount rate by 12.5 basis points (bps) to 1.625 per cent.
The rate decision comes after the government raised fuel prices by about 30 per cent earlier this month,.

site_title: UK to reverse payroll tax increase from Nov 6
summary: UK Finance Minister Kwasi Kwarteng announced the reversal of a 1.25 percentage point increase in payroll tax, set to take effect on November 6, as part of new Prime Minister Liz Truss' pro-growth agenda. The government will also cancel plans to separate out the National Insurance increase and scrap dividend tax rate increases from April 2023. Kwarteng stated that "taxing our way to prosperity has never worked" and aims to grow the economy to raise living standards.

site_title: World champion Carlsen refuses to clarify cheating claims
summary: Chess world champion Magnus Carlsen refused to clarify cheating claims against Hans Niemann, citing inability to speak on the matter. Carlsen withdrew from the Sinquefield Cup in St Louis and surrendered a game against Niemann earlier this month. This is the second time Carlsen has pulled out from a tournament featuring Niemann, who lags 200 ELO points behind him. Carlsen's silence on the allegations has fueled speculation about the legitimacy of Niemann's chess skills.

site_title: US jobless claims rise slightly, still near lowest since May
summary: US jobless claims rose slightly, increasing by 5,000 to 213,000 in the week ended Sep 17, after a downward revision in the prior week. This marks the first increase in jobless claims since June. Despite the slight rise, continuing claims remained historically low at 1.38 million. The Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes are expected to weaken hiring, leading to a predicted rise in unemployment to 4.4% by the end of next year.

images.alt_text: US retail sales have increased 0.3 per cent last month, the Commerce Department said on Thursday (Sep 15).

site_title: David Bowie honoured with stone on London’s Music Walk of Fame
summary: David Bowie was honored with a paving stone on the London Music Walk of Fame, joining other notable musicians like The Who and Amy Winehouse. The stone, featuring a music record with the word "icon," was unveiled at a ceremony where Bowie's hits were played. It marks the first honor since March 2020, following a pause due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The event was facilitated by the release of the documentary "Moonage Daydream" about Bowie's life and career.

site_title: Eurozone consumer sentiment hits record low on energy woes
summary: Eurozone consumer confidence has reached a record low of -28.8 in September, down from analyst estimates of -25.5. The decline is attributed to households bracing for a winter energy crunch and soaring inflation. Economists predict a recession in the region, with Russia's throttling of gas supplies exacerbating the issue. Governments are rushing to devise support measures, but their firepower is being stretched by efforts to rescue struggling companies.

site_title: World Bank head hits back at Al Gore, saying he’s no climate denier
summary: World Bank president David Malpass acknowledged that the burning of oil, natural gas, and coal contributes to global warming, contrary to his previous comments. Malpass stated that people need to find cleaner ways to make energy, amid mounting calls for his resignation. He denied being a "climate denier" and claimed the World Bank is a leader in financing climate-friendly green projects, citing $31.7 billion in climate efforts in 2022. The move comes as environmental activists and the Biden administration renewed criticism of the World Bank's support for fossil-fuel projects.

site_title: iWOW inks deal for potential S$18m acquisition of telco-solutions provider
summary: iWOW Technology, a Catalist-listed company, has signed a non-binding term sheet for the potential acquisition of a Singapore-based telecommunication solutions provider for up to S$18 million. The target company has a proven track record of serving telcos and enterprise clients with mission-critical infrastructure. The proposed acquisition aims to enhance iWOW's capabilities, credibility, and customer base, while contributing to its growth and financial position.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
Raymond Bo, CEO of  iWOW Technology

site_title: OxPay says S$77,000 in wrongful dismissal claims not declared as amounts ‘not material’
summary: OxPay Financial, a Singapore payment services company, was queried by the Singapore Exchange Regulation for not disclosing wrongful dismissal claims of S$77,501.52 against its former CEO and CFO. The company argued that the claim amount constituted 1.4% of its total equity and 0.3% of its total assets, and that it had sufficient cash to meet the payment. As a result, the company deemed the information "not material" and did not disclose the claims on SGXNet.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
OxPay Financial has been ordered by the Employment Claims Tribunal to pay its former chief executive and chief financial officer following their wrongful dismissal claims.

site_title: Accenture forecasts revenue below estimates on IT spending cut, higher US dollar
summary: Accenture forecasts Q1 revenue below expectations due to IT spending cuts and a stronger US dollar, with a 6% hit to fiscal 2023 results. The company reported $18.40 billion in new bookings for the fourth quarter, but expects an 8.5% negative foreign-exchange impact. Analysts say digital transformation projects will cushion the impact, and the company forecasts earnings per share of $11.09-$11.41. Accenture also authorized an additional $3 billion in share repurchases.

site_title: Proposed changes to Dutch tax regime will not affect distributable income: Cromwell European Reit manager
summary: Cromwell European Reit's manager has clarified that proposed changes to the Dutch tax regime will not affect the Reit's distributable income. The Reit and its subsidiaries are not considered fiscal investment institution entities and are already subject to corporate income tax in the Netherlands. The clarification comes after the Dutch government announced plans to subject Dutch fiscal investment institutions to corporate income tax starting January 1, 2024. The Reit's manager stated that the changes will not impact the Reit's distributable income.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
The manager said the Reit and its subsidiaries are not considered fiscal investment institution entities, and are already subject to corporate income tax in the Netherlands.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Optus, an Australian subsidiary of Singtel, reported a potential cyberattack that may have compromised customer information. The company is working with the Australian Cyber Security Centre to mitigate any risks. Meanwhile, the Federal Reserve increased interest rates by 75 basis points, signaling a continued battle against inflation. The Bank of Japan kept ultra-low interest rates to support economic growth, bucking a global trend of monetary tightening.

site_title: Yen strengthens after Japan intervenes to support currency for first time since 1998
summary: The Japanese yen strengthened against the US dollar after the government intervened in the foreign exchange market for the first time since 1998. The yen rose to a fresh 24-year peak of 145.9 yen before hitting a low of 140.31 yen. The US dollar was down 1.17% at 142.42 yen. The intervention was seen as a bid to shore up the battered currency, which has been weakened by aggressive interest rate hikes by other central banks, including the US Federal Reserve.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Japanese yen and U.S. dollar banknotes are seen with a currency exchange rate graph in this illustration picture taken June 16, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: One home to suit many
summary: Architects are designing innovative multi-generational houses to meet the growing demand for shared living spaces. A business consultant and his family are living together in a shared home, with his son and daughter-in-law also opting to live with them. This trend is driven by the desire for family bonding and financial benefits, as seen in the case of Andrew Ng, who believes in continuing the family tradition of living with parents. Architects are now exploring creative solutions to accommodate various family needs and requirements.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang
For story on multigenerational living - why families do it, and how architects create homes to suit that lifestyle

site_title: UK fiscal stimulus will be ‘difficult’ for BOE, Haskel says
summary: The UK government's planned fiscal stimulus has raised "difficult" issues for the Bank of England (BOE) as it attempts to cut inflation, which reached near its highest in 40 years. BOE member Jonathan Haskel noted the economy's tight labour market and compromised supply chains due to China's difficulties, making it challenging to absorb a big fiscal expansion. The BOE has raised interest rates by half a point to 2.25% to combat inflation, while the government plans to announce measures to stimulate growth, sparking trade-offs and potential recession risks.

images.alt_text: A cast of an infantry soldier, left, stands on a war memorial dedicated to the London troops who died in first and second World Wars, opposite the Bank of England in London, U.K., on Tuesday, Feb. 4, 2014. Between 2007 and 2011, policy makers in London lagged behind their American counterparts in cutting rates and adopting emergency policy measures in response to the financial crisis. Photographer: Simon Dawson/Bloomberg

site_title: Tesla recalls nearly 1.1 million US vehicles to update window reversing software
summary: Tesla is recalling nearly 1.1 million US vehicles due to a software issue with the window automatic reversal system, which may not react correctly after detecting an obstruction, increasing the risk of injury. The recall affects 2017-2022 Model 3, Model Y, and 2021-2022 Model S and Model X vehicles. Tesla will update the software remotely and reported no warranty claims, crashes, injuries, or deaths related to the issue. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) cited the recall as a failure to comply with federal motor vehicle safety standards.

site_title: Exxon Mobil shuts Fos-Sur-Mer refinery in France due to strike
summary: Exxon Mobil is shutting down its 235,000 barrel per day Fos-Sur-Mer refinery in France due to ongoing strike action. The strike, called by French unions CGT and Force Ouvriere, began on Sep 20 and spread to Exxon's Port Jerome-Gravenchon oil refinery and Notre Dame de Gravenchon petrochemical site on the same day. The shutdown will affect customers, contractors, suppliers, and employees, and Exxon Mobil's international reputation in France. The company is gradually shutting down the refinery and petrochemical plant.

site_title: Governments need to step up as world falls behind on climate goals: ISWA panel
summary: Governments are urged to step up efforts to address climate change as the world falls behind on sustainability targets. Senior Minister Amy Khor notes that the chance of global temperatures rising beyond the 1.5 degree Celsius limit by 2050 is "very, very high." A panel discussion at the ISWA World Congress highlights the need for effective policies and drivers to align companies and individuals with sustainability goals, particularly through pricing carbon and other economic activities. Governments are advised to create a structure that allows companies to benefit from cost savings and find revenue opportunities.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim

This undated handout photograph released by Singapore's national water agency PUB on July 14, 2021 shows an aerial view of Sembcorb energy company's new floating solar power farm at Tengeh reservoir in Singapore. (Photo by Handout / SINGAPORE'S NATIONAL WATER AGENCY - PUB / AFP) / RESTRICTED TO EDITORIAL USE - MANDATORY CREDIT "AFP PHOTO /SINGAPORE'S NATIONAL WATER AGENCY - PUB / HANDOUT " - NO MARKETING - NO ADVERTISING CAMPAIGNS - DISTRIBUTED AS A SERVICE TO CLIENTS

site_title: Desaru getaway at One&Only resort
summary: One&Only Desaru Coast, a luxury resort in Malaysia, has gained popularity among Singaporeans, accounting for 40% of guests since the Causeway reopened. The resort, designed by Kerry Hill, features 45 villas on 128 acres of real estate, including a 50-meter infinity pool, private beach, and tranquil spa. Guests can enjoy fine dining at Ember Beach Club, which offers Michelin-starred chef Julien Royer's signature bouillabaisse. The resort's exclusivity and natural surroundings make it an attractive alternative to destinations like Phuket or Koh Samui, with rates averaging S$1000 per night for an ocean-facing villa.

images.alt_text: Hazuki's Gucci-inspired interiors.

site_title: Manchester United set financial goals for year after quarterly loss narrows
summary: Manchester United has set financial goals for the year, forecasting total revenue between £580 million and £600 million and adjusted core profit between £100 million and £110 million. The club's annual revenue rose 18% to £583 million in the year to June, driven by increased ticket sales. Despite missing the Champions League, net debt grew 23% to £514.9 million. The club's new CEO, Richard Arnold, stated that everyone is aligned on a clear strategy to deliver sustained success on the pitch and a sustainable economic model.

site_title: Vietnam central bank raises policy rates by 100 bps
summary: The State Bank of Vietnam raised its policy rates by 100 basis points to 5.0% and the discount rate to 3.5% to combat inflation, which is above the 4% target. This move follows the US Federal Reserve's rate hike and comes amid a weakening Vietnamese dong, which has fallen for 9 consecutive sessions. The decision aims to control inflation and maintain economic stability, with the central bank's governor stating that controlling inflation is the biggest economic challenge at present.

images.alt_text: Thai exporters have said a price cartel would be unfeasible and would make Thailand and Vietnam uncompetitive.

site_title: Bank of England raises rates to 2.25% despite likely recession
summary: The Bank of England raised its key interest rate to 2.25% from 1.75%, despite the UK entering recession, with an estimated 0.1% economic shrinkage in the third quarter. This move aims to combat inflation, now forecasted to peak at 11% in October, below the previous peak of 13.3%. The decision follows the US Federal Reserve's rate hike and aims to balance inflation pressures and recession concerns.

images.alt_text: Economists polled by Reuters last week expect the Bank of England to increase interest rates to to 2.25 per cent from 1.75 per cent.

site_title: Renault ahead of schedule on EV partnerships: CEO
summary: Renault, the French carmaker, is ahead of schedule in developing electric vehicle (EV) partnerships, aiming to control 80% of its EV value chain by 2030, according to CEO Luca de Meo. The company is co-investing, co-developing, and co-creating with partners in batteries, electric motors, and power electronics. This strategy mirrors Apple's business model, which relies on partnerships. Renault's EV value chain percentage has increased from 10% to 30% in three years and will hit 80% before the decade's end. A detailed blueprint for the new EV entity is expected to be unveiled this autumn.

site_title: CNPC in swappable battery joint venture with SAIC, CATL
summary: CNPC, China's top oil and gas producer, has joined SAIC Motor and CATL in a joint venture to supply swappable batteries for electric vehicles. The venture, Shanghai Jieneng Smart Power New Energy Technology, has a 37.5% stake held by SAIC Motor, while CNPC and CATL each hold 12.5%. The company aims to build over 1,000 charging stations in China by 2025, with a focus on leasing power batteries and researching swappable battery technology. This move is part of China's goal to be carbon neutral by 2060 and expand investment in low-carbon businesses.

site_title: Singapore stocks take Fed rate hike in stride; STI ends with slight gains
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) bucked the trend, closing almost flat with slight gains of 0.04% after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates by 75 basis points. The index rose 1.28 points to 3,263.07, with losses outnumbering gains 257 to 230. Analysts expect a Fed-induced recession, with terminal policy rates potentially reaching 5%.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
As at 9.01 am, the Straits Times Index shed 11.27 points or 0.4 per cent to 3,250.52.

site_title: Singapore’s judicial management regime under review
summary: Singapore is reviewing its judicial management regime to prevent it from being used as a precursor to winding up. Minister Edwin Tong announced the review, citing the jurisdiction's potential as a restructuring hub, particularly for crypto platforms with growing presence in Asia. Officials will conduct a root-and-branch study to assess applicant suitability, tailor judicial manager expertise, and address specialized industry needs. The goal is to ensure judicial management is used effectively for rehabilitation rather than liquidation.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng

Corporate lawyers agreed that temporary relief measures and government financial support for businesses during the pandemic provided a reprieve from the commencement of winding up applications in 2020 and 2021.
As cryptocurrencies take a beating, Singapore is tranforming from crypto hub to crypto restructuring hub.
Pride may hurt Singapore's aim to be restructuring hub

site_title: WhatsApp Pay India head quits, joins Amazon: source
summary: WhatsApp's India payment head, Manesh Mahatme, has quit to join Amazon India as director of product in the e-commerce division. Mahatme's exit comes at a critical time for WhatsApp, which is seeking to ramp up its payments service in a highly competitive market. During his stint at WhatsApp Pay, the company won regulatory approval to expand its payments offering to 100 million users in India. WhatsApp's payments service faces stiff competition from rivals such as Google Pay, Paytm, and PhonePe, and the company will continue to innovate and drive momentum, according to a statement.

site_title: Land betterment charge rates raised on average by 12.9% for non-landed residential use; 10.2% for landed residential use
summary: Singapore's Land Betterment Charge (LBC) rates have been increased by 12.9% for non-landed residential use, 10.2% for landed residential use, 5.4% for commercial use, and 2.3% for industrial use, reflecting the robust performance of the local property market. The rate hikes, announced by the Singapore Land Authority, are the sharpest since 2018 and are based on the chief valuer's assessment of land values. The increases are expected to impact developers' margins and may lead to reassessments of potential bids for collective sale sites.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
Kalpana Rashiwala
piximage

site_title: UK tech firms eye Singapore as gateway for regional expansion
summary: Twenty-four British technology companies are exploring growth opportunities in Singapore under the UK-Singapore Digital Economy Agreement (DEA), which aims to break down trade barriers in areas like lawtech, data flows, and cybersecurity. The UK's lawtech sector is valued at £11.4 billion, and the agreement is the world's first to contain specific commitments on lawtech. The companies will meet government agencies and corporates in Singapore to find partnerships and opportunities, with the goal of increasing trade between the two nations, which is currently worth over £17 billion per year.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
The international rules-based order -- based on which global organisations such as the United Nations operate -- is in need of repair, but remains essential and salvageable.

site_title: Pfizer to supply up to 6 million Covid pill courses for lower income countries
summary: Pfizer has agreed to supply up to 6 million courses of its Covid-19 antiviral treatment, Paxlovid, to 132 low- and middle-income countries through the Global Fund's Covid-19 Response Mechanism, subject to local regulatory clearances. This move aims to address disparities in Covid response worldwide and provide equitable access to oral Covid treatments, which have been severely restricted in poorer countries.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Pfizer logo is seen at the entrance to Pfizer UK headquarters in Tadworth, Britain, December 2, 2020.  REUTERS/Peter Nicholls/File Photo

site_title: South Korea president caught on hot mic insulting US Congress
summary: South Korean President Yoon Suk-yeol was caught on a hot mic insulting US Congress, calling American lawmakers "idiots" after a brief meeting with President Joe Biden. The comments were made in New York while Yoon and Biden were discussing issues including US electric vehicle subsidies. Yoon's remarks were deemed unofficial and unverified, but sparked criticism from opposition lawmakers and raised concerns about the president's diplomatic achievements. The incident comes amid pressure for Yoon to remedy provisions in the Inflation Reduction Act, which could disadvantage South Korean brands like Hyundai and Kia.

images.alt_text: epa10197983 South Korean President Yoon Suk-yeol speaks during a digital vision forum at New York University in New York, New York, USA, 21 September 2022.  EPA-EFE/YONHAP SOUTH KOREA OUT

South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol (left) and Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida pose for a photo prior to their talks as they meet on the sidelines of the UN General Assembly, in New York, Sept 21, 2022.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 8.02 points to 1,439.16. A total of 2.167 billion lots worth RM1.679 billion were traded, with losers outnumbering gainers 447 to 372.

site_title: UK’s first CO2 storage round attracts bids from 19 companies
summary: The UK's first carbon dioxide storage licensing round attracted bids from 19 companies, as the country aims to use carbon capture and storage (CCS) technology to store 20-30 million tonnes of CO2 by 2030. The North Sea Transition Authority (NSTA) noted that strong competition is expected, requiring high-quality bids to secure licenses. This move is part of Britain's efforts to reduce its carbon footprint and meet its climate change targets.

site_title: Mercedes EQB review: Lucky 7 for this electric Mercedes
summary: The Mercedes EQB is a 7-seat electric car with few rivals, including combustion cars. It features a unique design with batteries under the floor, providing a stable ride and 1,620 liters of cargo space. The EQB 250 starts at S$305,888, while the twin-motor EQB 350 costs S$352,888. The EQB 350 accelerates quickly and quietly, making it a standout electric vehicle with its 7-seat capability and impressive performance.

images.alt_text:
jumercedes22 - 

credit, source: Mercedes-Benz Singapore

jumercedes22 - 

credit, source: Mercedes-Benz Singapore

site_title: German finance minister cuts lonely figure backing debt brake
summary: German Finance Minister Christian Lindner reaffirmed his plan to return to the nation's constitutionally enshrined debt brake despite criticism. Lindner considers a further suspension of borrowing limits a "last resort" for unforeseen, catastrophic events. The decision comes as Germany faces mounting costs to support households and businesses struggling with energy bills. A recent plan to prop up Uniper, a nationalized Russian gas importer, will cost the government 29 billion euros. Lindner remains committed to his plan, despite feeling "a little lonelier" in his stance.

images.alt_text: German Finance Minister Christian Lindner speaks during the German Employers' Day of the Confederation of German Employers' Associations (BDA) in Berlin, Germany September 13, 2022.  REUTERS/Michele Tantussi

site_title: Analysts cautious as shadow of recession looms over markets
summary: US Federal Reserve raises interest rates by 75 basis points, sparking market volatility. Asian stock markets declined, with Singapore's Straits Times Index and Hong Kong's Hang Seng index falling 0.04% and 1.6% respectively. Analysts express concerns over the Fed's hawkish stance, which may lead to a recession. Despite this, some investors are seeking value plays in South-east Asia, particularly Indonesia and Vietnam. Fixed income yields are expected to rise, but shorter-term bond yields are seen as relatively attractive. The US dollar strengthens against many currencies, while gold prices are expected to underperform due to rising interest rates.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
US Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell speaking during a news conference following a meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) on Sep 21, 2022 in Washington, DC.
US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell announced that it will raise interest rates by three-quarters of a percentage point, Sept 21, 2022.

site_title: GIC buys into Sani/Ikos, valuing resorts group at 2.3b euros
summary: Singapore sovereign wealth fund GIC has acquired a majority stake in Mediterranean luxury beach resort Sani/Ikos Group, valuing the company at 2.3 billion euros. The deal, expected to close in the fourth quarter of 2022, will help the resort group deliver on its 5-year investment plan and create jobs in the Mediterranean. GIC's investment is seen as a testament to its confidence in the Greek and wider European tourism sector over the long term, with CEOs Andreas Andreadis and Mathieu Guillemin set to continue managing the company.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end at 11-year low
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted to an 11-year low on Thursday, closing at 18,147.95 after a 1.61% drop. The decline was driven by a third consecutive 75-basis-point interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve and warnings of further increases. Global markets were also affected, with the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index experiencing similar declines. The sharp drop reflects the ongoing impact of monetary policy changes on the region's stock market.

site_title: Japan intervenes in FX market to stem yen falls after BOJ keeps super-low rates
summary: Japan intervened in the foreign exchange market for the first time since 1998, buying yen to stem its decline, which has fallen nearly 20% this year. The move came after the Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained ultra-low interest rates, bucking a global trend of monetary tightening. Analysts doubt the intervention's effectiveness, citing the yen's prolonged slide and aggressive US interest rate hikes. The US dollar surged over 2% to 141.15 yen, while the BOJ's dovish policy stance is expected to continue.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Japan kept unchanged its -0.1 per cent target for short-term interest rates, and 0 per cent for the 10-year government bond yield by a unanimous vote.

site_title: UK watchdog clarifies post-Brexit conditions for share trading licences
summary: The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) in the UK has clarified the conditions for share trading licenses post-Brexit, stating it will not change the legal perimeter but will clarify where the border lies. This move aims to keep London's capital market competitive. The FCA's plans follow the UK's withdrawal from the EU, allowing for approaches tailored to the UK market. The clarification is part of the government's efforts to "unshackle" the City of London and boost its global competitiveness.

images.alt_text: Under the latest planned legislation, the Companies House register will receive “significant new powers” to challenge and decline dubious information and make it easier to report suspicious activity to law enforcement.

site_title: China Vanke unit set to raise HK$5.75b in Hong Kong IPO: sources
summary: China Vanke's property services arm Onewo is set to raise HK$5.75 billion in its Hong Kong IPO after pricing shares at HK$49.35 each. The shares represent 10% of Onewo's capital and are among the largest Hong Kong IPOs in 2022, which saw a 90% decline in deal value due to Sino-US tensions and a tightening regulatory environment. Onewo is a unit of China's second-largest developer by sales, Vanke, which has weathered the property sector crisis better than most rivals.

site_title: Indonesia resumes penalising exporters that break repatriation rules
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, has reinstated rules to penalize natural resource exporters that break repatriation rules, including not receiving earnings through domestic banks. The move aims to strengthen the rupiah currency and increase onshore US dollar supply. The country has recorded its highest monthly exports on record in August, with exports expected to reach a historic high this year due to strong commodity prices. The bank's governor, Perry Warjiyo, believes the rupiah should strengthen due to the strong exports performance.

site_title: HappyFresh wins funding, revamps board as business resumes
summary: HappyFresh, a South-east Asian online grocery delivery service, has secured funding to resume operations in Indonesia after a strategic review. The startup will focus on Indonesia while considering options for its businesses in Thailand and Malaysia. As part of a reshuffle, new representatives will join the board, led by Jason Kardachi from US firm Kroll. HappyFresh had struggled to raise capital amid a downturn in the online grocery sector, but will now work with venture debt funds Genesis, Innoven, and Mars to restructure its business.

images.alt_text: Founded as one of the first Instacart-style grocery delivery services in South-east Asia, HappyFresh has raised at least US$97 million in equity funding in addition to debt financing.
Battling in grocery war, HappyFresh sees the light in 'dark stores'

site_title: New kind of workshop shows the writing on the wall
summary: Komoco Motors has opened its 800 sqm EV Service Centre, the first Hyundai dealership to do so, showcasing the industry's optimism and anxiety about the future of electric vehicles. The workshop, designed to minimize waste and emissions, requires specialized technicians who can interpret complex data from battery packs. Komoco and Hyundai have signed a Memorandum of Understanding with the Institute of Technical Education to train 10 students annually, providing scholarships and potential full-time employment. The centre's overcapacity suggests a projected explosion in EV demand, signaling the writing on the wall for the traditional car industry.

images.alt_text: Car dealers trim EV prices ahead of new COE rule

site_title: Credit Suisse considers plan to resurrect ‘bad bank,’ FT reports
summary: Credit Suisse is considering a plan to resurrect a "bad bank" to hold high-risk assets as part of its strategic review, following a string of losses under former CEO Thomas Gottstein. The investment bank could be divided into three parts: advisory business, "bad bank," and the rest of the business. The bank is also exploring deals to sell the entire business or specific portfolios to investors such as Apollo Global Management and BNP Paribas. Credit Suisse will update on its strategy review when it announces third-quarter earnings.

site_title: Thai finance minister meets central bank, urges close watch on weak baht
summary: Thailand's Finance Minister Arkhom Termpittayapaisith urged the central bank to closely monitor the baht currency after it hit its weakest level in nearly 16 years. The baht has lost 10.6% this year, but its weakness is benefiting exports. The central bank is expected to raise interest rates on September 28 to curb inflation. The government will continue to help with energy prices and living costs, and the economy is still expected to grow 3% to 3.5% in 2022.

site_title: Analysts divided on whether SMG investors should accept privatisation offer
summary: Analysts are divided on whether investors should accept Singapore Medical Group's (SMG) S$0.37 per share offer to take the company private. UOB Kay Hian recommends rejecting the offer due to a lower valuation multiple compared to peer Singapore O&G, while Lim & Tan Securities views the deal as "reasonable but not compelling." The offer price falls short of the analysts' target prices, with UOB Kay Hian aiming for S$0.45 and Lim & Tan Securities at S$0.43 per share.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Singapore Medical Group has its heart set on regional growth
Singapore Medical Group net profit up 78.8% to S$15.6m in FY21

site_title: HSBC, StanChart raise prime rate for first time since 2018
summary: HSBC and Standard Chartered raised their prime rate in Hong Kong for the first time in 4 years, increasing borrowing costs for property owners and businesses. The rate hike follows the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's 75 basis point increase in its base rate, in line with the US Federal Reserve's aggressive tightening to combat inflation. The move is expected to further pressure Hong Kong's unaffordable property market, with Goldman Sachs estimating prices may slump by 20% over the next 4 years.

images.alt_text: Nearly 97 per cent of mortgages in Hong Kong are tied to Hibor, the city’s benchmark interbank rate, according to July data for new loans by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority.
The Federal Reserve's hawkish rate hikes, aimed at curbing soaring inflation, come at an especially difficult time for Hong Kong, dampening sentiment when the economy is already struggling.

site_title: SIPF 2022: Enigmatic and entrancing
summary: The 8th edition of the Singapore International Photography Festival features an eclectic and thought-provoking lineup of works, showcasing the diverse talents of local and international photographers. Key installations include "Peace Agency," a site-specific installation by three artists that explores the concept of waiting, and "Hawaii Nights," a Club Hawaii-themed experience by Aik Beng Chia. Other notable works include romantic photographs by Masato Seto, surreal images by Seok-Woo Song, and a Virtual Reality experience designed by Elise Morin, all co-curated by Gwen Lee, John Tung, and He Yining, running until October 30.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Singapore Biennale 2022 will be led by co-artistic directors (from left) June Yap, Nida Ghouse, Ala Younis and Binna Choi.
Distrik Seni is a new museum-like marketplace for quality art, with works by hot artists such as Mulyana, Hahan and Jompet Kuswidananto.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower after central bank decisions
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on September 22, 2022, following the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hike and the Bank of Japan's decision to maintain its easing policy. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 0.58% or 159.30 points to 27,153.83, while the Topix index lost 0.24% or 4.68 points to 1,916.12.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians reflected on an electronic stock board outside a securities firm in Tokyo, Japan, on Friday, June 9, 2017. Photographer: Noriko Hayashi

site_title: HSBC fund arm toughens thermal-coal policy to curb climate change
summary: HSBC has accelerated its plan to stop financing the expansion of thermal coal, a cheap energy source responsible for climate-damaging emissions, from its actively managed funds with immediate effect. This marks a significant step in the banking sector's efforts to curb climate change, following HSBC's broader commitment made last year. The move comes after Standard Chartered announced it would end direct coal financing for clients by 2032, highlighting the growing pressure on financial institutions to address environmental concerns.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong’s biggest lender HSBC is boosting its prime rate by 12.5 basis points to 5.125 per cent and warns of more increases to come.
Asia’s green bond issuers look past pricing to branding and investor access
Demonstrators take part in a protest against the greenwashing of nuclear energy and gas through the taxonomy of the EU in front of the Euro sign in Frankfurt, Germany, January 11, 2022.

“Decarbonisation cannot be achieved in silos – the global banking and business community, and world leaders have a part to play in balancing the climate agenda, social equity and economic development. Collectively, we must exercise leadership by working towards a balanced, sustainable and just transition,” said Piyush Gupta, chief executive, DBS: “The decarbonisation targets will act as the ‘north star’ for our financing activities guiding us to net zero by 2050 through measurable change.”

site_title: Food inflation sends American Diner Index soaring 13%
summary: The American Diner Index, tracking food costs at US diners, has surged 13% in a year, driven by a 11.4% increase in food costs, the highest since 1979. Key ingredients like lettuce, bread, turkey, and ham have seen significant price hikes, with lettuce rising 33% and a half-gallon of ice cream costing $5.64. Restaurant owners face challenges in balancing price increases without losing customers, with some owners reporting a decline in sales.

images.alt_text: While fewer consumers mentioned supply shortages and gas prices are falling, other measures of inflation are still accelerating and widespread, such as costs for food and shelter.

site_title: Opel Mokka-e review: A clean shot of Mokka
summary: The Opel Mokka-e is the first electric SUV in Singapore to sport a German badge, qualifying for the cheaper Category A Certificate Of Entitlement (COE) and making it relatively affordable at S$159,500. The Mokka-e features a striking design, with a glossy black strip and black interior, and is easy to drive with a responsive and instant kick from the electric motor. It has a range of 324km, 0-100km/h in 10.1 seconds, and can be fully charged in 30 minutes with a 50 kW DC charger.

images.alt_text: General Motors plans to return to Europe with battery-powered models starting with the Cadillac brand and is considering selling the hulking Hummer electric vehicle, according to people familiar with the matter.

site_title: Philippine central bank hikes rates again, raises inflation forecast
summary: The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) raised its benchmark interest rates by half a percentage point, bringing the total increase to 225 basis points this year. The overnight reverse repurchase facility rate was set at 4.25%, as predicted by most economists. The central bank also raised interest rates on the overnight deposit and lending facilities to 3.75% and 4.75%, respectively. The decision was made amid a forecasted increase in inflation for this year and next, as well as a record low peso. This is the fifth rate hike this year.

site_title: Hot stock: SATS hits 2.5-month low following news of potential acquisition
summary: SATS shares dropped to a 2.5-month low on September 22, 2022, after announcing talks to acquire Worldwide Flight Services. The Singapore-listed company's shares fell 5.1% to S$3.87 as the news was released. Analysts from Citi believe the deal could be "strategically correct" due to limited overlap in geographies, allowing SATS to scale up globally. The potential acquisition would create the world's third-largest ground handler, with increased revenue and cost synergies.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Vivienne Tay
SATS says it is constantly on the lookout for acquisition opportunities.
On Friday, mainboard-listed SATS posted a net loss of S$22.5 million for the quarter ended June due to lower government grants and increased costs

Sats chief executive Kerry Mok said the group has started to pass on some of the higher costs to  customers . "We all know ticket prices have gone up a fair bit, so those are things that’s a clear pass through."

site_title: Global rail market still growing, buoyed by green hopes: World Rail Market study
summary: The global rail market is expected to experience an average annual growth rate of 3% through 2027, reaching a global market volume of 211 billion euros by 2027. The highest growth rates are expected in smaller markets such as Africa and the Middle East, while mature markets like the Asia-Pacific will also see significant growth. The World Rail Market Study, conducted by Roland Berger, attributes the growth to increasing hopes for a greener and more sustainable rail industry.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan
President Xi Jinping has called for an "all out" effort to increase infrastructure spending this year in the hope of fuelling economic growth and meeting a GDP growth target of around 5.5%.
China will act decisively in ramping up support for the economy and roll out more policy steps but will refrain from issuing excessive money.

site_title: Hong Kong mortgage costs spiking with 97% on floating rates
summary: Nearly 97% of Hong Kong mortgages are tied to Hibor, the city's benchmark interbank rate, according to July data. This is likely one of the highest rates in the world, surpassing 17% in the UK and over 70% in Japan. The high rate is due to the city's pegged exchange rate to the US dollar, leading to five rate hikes this year. The 3-month Hibor has reached its highest level since 2008, making Hong Kong's property market vulnerable to tightening monetary policies.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong banks are expected to increase their best lending rate as soon as Thursday, the first increase since 2018.

site_title: Taiwan central bank raises benchmark rate, cuts growth outlook
summary: Taiwan's central bank raised its benchmark discount rate by 12.5 basis points to 1.625% for the third time this year, citing continued concerns about inflation. The decision was in line with expectations, following the US Federal Reserve's third straight 75 bp rate hike. The central bank cut its 2022 economic growth forecast to 3.51% from 3.75% and predicted 2.9% growth for 2023, as inflation eases and the economy loses momentum due to weakening consumer demand in major markets.

images.alt_text: Higher interest rates may also help bolster Taiwan’s dollar, which has slumped this year on the back of a stronger US currency, weaker export demand and rising geopolitical tensions.

site_title: Indonesia central bank raises rates by 50 bps to head off inflation risks
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, raised interest rates by 50 basis points to 4.25% to combat inflation risks, following a 30% fuel price hike by the government. The decision aims to control inflation, which is expected to peak at 6% and 4.6% by year-end. The move was seen as a surprise by 3 out of 30 economists polled, with most expecting a 25 basis point increase. The rate hike is intended to support the rupiah currency and maintain economic stability.

images.alt_text: Indonesia booked its highest monthly exports on record in August.
The majority of economists in a Bloomberg survey expect Bank Indonesia to raise its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points to a two-year high of 4 per cent.

site_title: Hazuki brings well-priced Japanese dining to Orchard Road
summary: Hazuki, a new kappo eatery at Takashimaya shopping mall, offers premium Japanese dining at well-priced options, with lunch starting at S$180 and dinner options at S$280 and S$380. Chef Kenta Yamauchi brings his expertise from Ki-sho and Tsubaki, with a focus on classic cooking. The menu features dishes such as kegani crab, sashimi platter, and abalone slices, all made with high-quality ingredients. With its Gucci-inspired interiors and convenient location, Hazuki is a great option for those looking for a high-end dining experience without breaking the bank.

site_title: Aviation chiefs warn of prolonged ticket price pain
summary: Aviation industry leaders warn of prolonged ticket price pain due to higher fuel prices and crippling losses from the Covid pandemic. International Air Transport Association (Iata) director general Willie Walsh and Qatar Airways CEO Akbar Al Baker predict more price increases in coming months, with ticket pressures extending into 2023. Airlines have posted losses of $180 billion in 2020 and 2021, and expect another $9.7 billion in losses this year. A reopening of China's frontiers is seen as crucial for the industry's recovery.

images.alt_text: The airport reached 56 per cent of its 2019 passenger numbers in August and the government expects flights will reach 80 per cent of pre-pandemic levels by the end of the year.
The SAF will be supplied by Neste, produced from used cooking oil and waste animal fats, then blended with refined jet fuel at Exxon Mobil’s facilities in the city-state.
Strikes and staff shortages in the past few months have forced airlines to cancel thousands of flights, dashing their hopes of a summer rebound after widespread Covid-19 lockdowns.

site_title: Blockchain could bring a revolution in public financial management
summary: A digital technology-based approach using blockchain could revolutionize public financial management, reducing costs and increasing the impact of public spending. By integrating financial and non-financial reporting, reconciling and consolidating information, and producing near real-time spend and performance reporting, governments can improve control over public funds and achieve accountable outcomes. Research by Prysm Group and EY found potential administrative savings and value added from better allocation of spending, offering an opportunity for governments to use money more effectively and create high-quality, well-funded government services.

images.alt_text: As part of industry engagement, emphasis must be placed on DLT and tokenisation education, its distinction from cryptocurrencies and awareness to build trust in these technologies, gain stakeholder acceptance and drive adoption.
Despite the advantages of digitisation and decentralisation, the risks associated with cryptocurrency are increasingly obvious to even the most casual of observers.

site_title: Toyota to produce 800,000 vehicles in October, weighed by chips shortage
summary: Toyota plans to produce 800,000 vehicles worldwide in October, about 100,000 short of its average monthly production plan due to semiconductor shortages. The company now expects to produce 850,000 vehicles per month on average from October to December, down from its initial target of 900,000 vehicles per month from September to November.

site_title: China’s largest policy bank to boost infrastructure loans to local governments
summary: China's China Development Bank (CDB) will increase infrastructure loans to local governments, prioritizing major economic provinces. The lender has spent 360 billion yuan (S$72.2 billion) on over 800 projects, including a railway in Guangzhou and a water project in Guangxi. The move comes after China's cabinet announced plans to support the economy, including raising policy financing tools by 300 billion yuan. The CDB will focus on projects that can start construction quickly in the third quarter, aiming to boost infrastructure development.

images.alt_text: The central bank last week refrained from cutting its key interest rates as it defended a depreciating yuan.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slump at open on rate hike concerns
summary: Europe's stocks plummeted at the open on Thursday, September 22, 2022, following the Federal Reserve's announcement of a third consecutive interest rate hike to combat inflation. The FTSE 100 index fell 1.0% to 7,166.81 points, while the DAX and CAC 40 indices also declined by 1.9% and 1.7% respectively. The Bank of England was set to announce a second rate rise.

site_title: Vietnam says not in deal with Thailand to jointly raise rice prices
summary: Vietnam's Agriculture Minister Le Minh Hoan stated the country is not involved in a deal with Thailand to jointly raise rice prices, contradicting a Thai official's previous claim. The two countries began talks in May to increase their leverage in the global market and boost farmers' incomes, but Thai exporters have deemed a price cartel unfeasible and potentially detrimental to their competitiveness. Vietnam's rice exports are expected to rise to 6.3-6.5 million tonnes this year due to strong demand.

images.alt_text: Monsoon rains, which were delayed in parts of India’s northern and eastern rice producing regions, have improved over the last couple of weeks, boosting crop prospects in the world’s largest rice supplier, traders said.

site_title: Tambour marks Louis Vuitton’s 20 years of watchmaking
summary: Louis Vuitton celebrates 20 years of watchmaking with the release of the Tambour Twenty, a limited-edition chronograph timepiece paying homage to the original 2002 model. The watch features a unique drum-shaped case and applied horns, along with a brown sun-brushed dial and 12-lettered name "Louis Vuitton" engraved on the stainless steel case sides. Powered by a high-frequency La Fabrique du Temps LV 277 calibre, the Tambour Twenty is available in a mini version of the iconic Louis Vuitton trunk and priced at US$17,800.

images.alt_text: Big Bang Tourbillon Automatic Purple Sapphire

site_title: As America raises rates, the rest of the world bears the pain
summary: The US Federal Reserve's interest rate hike has worsened the global economic situation, with the Fed's benchmark rate now at 3-3.25%, up 3 percentage points since the start of the year. The rate rise is expected to lead to higher inflation and unemployment worldwide, with the dollar's value increasing by 16% since the start of the year. Other economies are struggling to cope with the tighter financial conditions, with countries like Sweden, the UK, and South Korea raising their interest rates in response.

images.alt_text: Tokyo, Hong Kong, Seoul, Taipei and Manila were each down at least 1 per cent. Shanghai, Singapore and Jakarta were also in the red on Thursday.

site_title: New Zealand: Shares firm as consumer confidence grows, Aussie markets shut
summary: New Zealand shares rose 0.2% to 11,524.21, driven by gains in healthcare and growth stocks, as consumer confidence increased to 87.6 in the third quarter. The country's benchmark index was capped by risk-off sentiment following a 75 basis point US Federal Reserve rate hike. Key gainers included Pushpay Holdings (2.7%), Fisher & Paykel Healthcare (1.5%), and Fonterra (1.8%), which reported its best day in a week.

images.alt_text: Markets in Australia were closed for a holiday. The S&P/NZX 50 index climbed about 0.1 per cent to 11,509 by 2335 GMT on Thursday, also helped by improving consumer sentiment.

site_title: Rupee tipped to fall further after reaching record low, RBI key: analysts
summary: The Indian rupee reached a record low of 80.2850 per US dollar, down from 79.9750 in the previous session. The US Federal Reserve hinted at more aggressive rate hikes to tame inflation, leading analysts to predict the rupee will fall further. The Fed raised rates by 75 basis points, with rates expected to stay elevated until 2024.

images.alt_text: DPM Lawrence Wong met India's Power and New and Renewable Energy Minister R K Singh (above) on Tuesday, as well as Health Minister Mansukh Mandaviya.
India government had previously agreed to cover between 30 per cent and 50 per cent of the cost of setting up new display and chip plants.

site_title: Hong Kong finance chief says no sharp risk to property prices
summary: Hong Kong's finance chief, Paul Chan, says there is no sharp risk to the city's real estate market, despite rising interest rates and a drop in home prices by 6% in the first 8 months of the year. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority raised its base rate by 75 basis points, its highest since 2008. Chan notes that the property market's performance depends on various factors, including employment and repayment capabilities. Despite this, he does not see a need to adjust property control measures, which include stamp duties on non-Hong Kong citizens and second homebuyers.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong is the most expensive office market in the world.

site_title: ‘Very high chance’ Hong Kong will end year in recession: finance secretary
summary: Hong Kong is expected to end the year in recession due to a "very high chance" of negative GDP growth, according to Finance Secretary Paul Chan. The city's economy is struggling amid strict Covid-19 controls and the Federal Reserve's hawkish rate hikes aimed at curbing inflation. Interest rates have been raised at a pace not seen in three decades, further dampening sentiment. The city's economy is heavily influenced by the US dollar, as its currency is pegged to it.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong banks are expected to increase their best lending rate as soon as Thursday, the first increase since 2018.

site_title: Singtel’s Optus says customer information potentially compromised in cyberattack
summary: Optus, the Australian subsidiary of Singtel, reported a potential cyberattack that may have compromised customer information, including names, dates of birth, phone numbers, and email addresses. The company is working with the Australian Cyber Security Centre to mitigate risks and has notified relevant authorities. Payment details and account passwords remain unaffected. Optus CEO Kelly Bayer Rosmarin expressed regret and urged customers to be vigilant, offering personal notifications and expert monitoring services to those with heightened risk.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Unnamed sources suggested that Optus could be worth between A$8 billion and A$12 billion.
Singtel looks to streamline its operations to stay relevant and maximise shareholder returns.
The interest rate discounts for the revolving credit facility are linked to Optus’ reduction of its absolute greenhouse gas emissions by 25 per cent by 2025.

site_title: Biden’s trade war against himself
summary: US President Joe Biden's administration is waging a "trade war against himself" by prioritizing protectionism despite its domestic and foreign policy objectives. The administration's tariffs on Canadian lumber, stricter "Buy American" measures, and lack of interest in joining the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) harm US allies and contradict its own goals. This protectionism also raises costs and prices, particularly in the solar panel industry, where domestic production is not competitive. The Biden administration should instead subsidize solar panel and semiconductor production, relax immigration restrictions, and join the CPTPP to achieve better results for the US economy and the world.

images.alt_text: Semiconductors have become nearly ubiquitous, but it shouldn't be left to government planners to decide which factories to build now in order to produce the types of high-end chips that will be needed a few years out.
Efforts to reduce prices at the pump in America have been misguided.

site_title: Taiwan may scrap quarantine for arrivals about mid-October
summary: Taiwan is considering scrapping its 3-day quarantine requirement for arrivals around mid-October, joining Japan and Hong Kong in easing border restrictions. The move aims to boost the economy, which is facing headwinds from slowing global demand and high inflation. The government will monitor the situation for another week before announcing the new rules, which would be effective around October 13. The quarantine requirement will be replaced with rapid-antigen testing at the airport, and the weekly arrivals cap will increase to 150,000.

site_title: Seoul: Shares, currency, treasury bonds tumble on Fed outlook
summary: South Korean shares, currency, and treasury bonds plummeted on September 22 after the US Federal Reserve delivered a 75 basis point rate hike, signaling aggressive increases ahead. The benchmark KOSPI fell 14.90 points, or 0.63%, to 2,332.31, marking its lowest close since July 15. Fed chair Jerome Powell vowed to continue battling inflation, with borrowing costs expected to rise this year.
