site_title: Gold prices fall 1% as dollar jumps on hawkish Fed
summary: Gold prices fell 1% to $1,656.97 per ounce after the US Federal Reserve increased interest rates by 75 basis points, signaling more hikes this year. The dollar index surged, making gold more expensive for foreign buyers. Despite being seen as a hedge against inflation, rate hikes raise the opportunity cost of holding zero-yield bullion.

images.alt_text: Swiss exports of gold to top consumer China fell in August from July’s 5-1/2-year high.

site_title: US jury orders Meta to pay US$174.5m for violating patents
summary: A US jury ordered Meta to pay $174.5 million for violating live-streaming patents developed by Voxer, a company co-founded by US Army veteran Tom Katis. The verdict came after a trial in Texas federal court found that Meta's "live" features on Facebook and Instagram used Voxer's patented technology. Meta plans to seek further relief, including an appeal. The technology was developed by Katis to improve battlefield communications and was incorporated into Meta's live-streaming features after a failed collaboration attempt.

images.alt_text: The company, which owns Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp, has avoided outright layoffs.

site_title: China sets longest run of yuan fixes with strong bias on record
summary: China's People's Bank of China (PBOC) set the strongest-than-expected yuan fix at 6.9798 per dollar, marking the 21st consecutive day of stronger-than-expected fixings, the longest on record. This move comes amid the threat of further outflows and China's onshore yuan's worst annual loss since 1994. The PBOC's actions aim to boost the yuan, which has been battered by the Federal Reserve's aggressive rate hikes, and reduce foreign-currency reserves to support the economy.

site_title: Japan starts carbon credit trading trial at TSE
summary: Japan has started a trial carbon credit trading system at the Tokyo Stock Exchange, with 145 registered members trading existing credits as of Thursday. The trial aims to create a nationwide market mechanism to help Japan achieve carbon neutrality by 2050. The system allows participants to offset emissions or monetize reduced emissions, and the trial will run through January with a government review and possible improvements before formal launch in April.

images.alt_text: epa10182849 A member of security personnel looks out the door of the Tokyo Stock Exchange, in Tokyo, Japan, 14 September 2022. The Dow Jones Industrial Average in the US plunged over 1,200 points on 13 September. The Tokyo stock benchmark fell more than 800 points in the morning trading session on 14 September.  EPA-EFE/KIMIMASA MAYAMA
"Carbon credits are not going to be exported. No question," said Raj Kumar Singh, Indian Minister of Power and Minister of New and Renewable Energy.

site_title: Hong Kong’s share of Asian IPOs slumps to over 2-decade low
summary: Hong Kong's share of Asian initial public offerings (IPOs) has dropped to its lowest level in over 2 decades, despite a recent increase in deals. In 2022, Hong Kong raised just $7.75 billion through IPOs, accounting for 7% of the Asia-wide total, down from 26% on average from 1995 to 2021. Mainland Chinese exchanges have seen a surge in IPOs, with firms raising $74.5 billion this year, accounting for 69% of Asia's total.

images.alt_text: Commercial and residential buildings are seen in Hong Kong on September 15, 2022. - The amount of vacant top-tier office space has more than doubled in Hong Kong over the last three years as companies downsize operations, researchers have found, warning that demand could remain soft even if pandemic controls are lifted. (Photo by ISAAC LAWRENCE / AFP)

site_title: Pressure grows after World Bank chief dodges climate questions
summary: World Bank President David Malpass faced intense criticism after refusing to acknowledge man-made emissions contribute to global warming, sparking calls for his removal. Climate groups, including the Big Shift, demanded his resignation, citing an inadequate approach to the climate crisis. Malpass's comments, which included stating he's "not a scientist," were met with frustration from activists and observers, who accused him of climate denial. The World Bank's board can only remove Malpass by a vote, with his term set to end in 2024.

images.alt_text: A Harvard report published on Tuesday highlights rampant greenwashing by leading companies on social media.

Prince William, now heir to the throne after Queen Elizabeth II’s death, sent a pre-recorded video message to an innovation summit in New York for the annual Earthshot Prize, which he created in 2019 to reward efforts to combat climate change.
Surging prices have forced central banks worldwide to tighten monetary policy, which is expected to cool inflation but risks tipping economies into recession.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.81 points or 0.13% to 1,445.37. Losers outnumbered gainers 237 to 84, with a total trading volume of 154.48 million lots worth RM79.84 million.

site_title: Singapore’s rising costs of running a business outpace Hong Kong’s
summary: Singapore's rising costs of running a business are outpacing those in Hong Kong, the world's most expensive office market, despite Hong Kong's economic struggles. Office rents in Singapore accelerated for the third quarter, while Hong Kong's core business districts saw a 4% rent cut from December. Labour shortages and rising salaries in Singapore, driven by its faster reopening, are also contributing to the divergence in costs. However, some experts suggest that these trends may be temporary, and other structural factors, such as geopolitical rivalry and supply chain diversification, could influence business decisions.

images.alt_text: While it is an opportune time for Singapore-global enterprises to enter Asean, they must have a deep understanding of their customers and competition to make informed choices on how to enter.

Commercial and residential buildings are seen in Hong Kong on September 15, 2022. - The amount of vacant top-tier office space has more than doubled in Hong Kong over the last three years as companies downsize operations, researchers have found, warning that demand could remain soft even if pandemic controls are lifted. (Photo by ISAAC LAWRENCE / AFP)

site_title: Asia: Markets tumble further as Federal Reserve hikes rates, warns more to come
summary: Asian markets plummeted, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, Seoul, Taipei, and Manila each down at least 1% on Thursday, as the Federal Reserve hiked interest rates by three-quarters of a point for the third consecutive time, warning of more hikes to come. The Fed's forecast of borrowing costs above 4% throughout next year and its determination to focus on bringing down inflation led to the sell-off. The US economy is seen as straining from the battle against inflation, and investors are bracing for similar actions from central banks worldwide.

images.alt_text: Tokyo, Hong Kong, Sydney and Manila were all down more than 1 per cent on Wednesday, while there were also losses in Shanghai, Seoul, Wellington, Taipei and Jakarta.
The benchmark Nikkei 225 index was down 0.87 per cent, or 237.33 points, at 27,075.80 in early trade on Thursday.

site_title: Bank of Japan keeps ultra-low rates, dovish policy bias
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its ultra-low interest rates, keeping the short-term interest rate at -0.1% and the 10-year government bond yield at 0%, in a unanimous decision. BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that the central bank would not raise interest rates for some time to support Japan's fragile economic recovery. The decision bucks the global trend of monetary tightening by central banks to combat inflation, and the yen has dropped to a fresh 24-year low against the dollar.

images.alt_text: The yen has lost nearly 20 per cent against the greenback this year, hitting a 24-year low of 144.99 and prompting policymakers this month to flag a readiness to act in the face of volatile currency movement.
The BOJ is set to end a 2-day meeting later Thursday after the Fed raised its benchmark by another 75 basis points Wednesday and cut its economic growth projection.

site_title: China urges Europe to take positive steps on climate change
summary: China's top climate envoy, Xie Zhenhua, urged Europe to take "positive action" to implement climate change goals amid geopolitical uncertainties. China's own green development path remains firm, contrasting with the European Union's rise in coal use. Xie emphasized the need for industrialized countries to meet their climate pledge under the Paris Agreement, transferring $100 billion a year in climate funds to developing nations. China will focus on financing at COP27, highlighting the need for a "good political atmosphere" ahead of the talks to address climate change.

images.alt_text: The opencast lignite mine Nochten and the coal-fired power Boxberg Power Station, operated by Lausitz Energie Bergbau AG (LEAG) company, is pictured in Nochten, Germany, March 22, 2022. REUTERS/Matthias Rietschel

site_title: Monk’s Hill Ventures forms Angsana Council to promote South-east Asian businesses
summary: Monk's Hill Ventures, a Singapore-based tech investor, has launched the Angsana Council, a non-profit group aimed at promoting business growth in South-east Asia. The council, comprising influential figures such as Charles Ormiston, Peng T. Ong, and George Yeo, will facilitate dialogues with entrepreneurs and policymakers to raise investment levels, promote entrepreneurial activity, and support growth-friendly policies. The council's goal is to drive steady growth in the region, leveraging the expertise and networks of its founding members.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

site_title: Apac needs at least US$26t and a clearer framework to achieve net zero: study
summary: Asia-Pacific countries need at least $26 trillion in funding and a clearer framework to achieve a net-zero future by 2050, according to a study by Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation and Economist Impact. The region faces significant barriers, including high renewable energy costs, lack of funding, and unclear profitability. Emerging economies require extra investment to reduce dependence on cheap fossil fuels. The study advocates for more comprehensive regulations and policies, as well as internal funding and corporate social responsibility initiatives to support energy transition efforts.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
The insurer reported its first annual VONB fall in 2020 since its 2010 listing in Hong Kong.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SATS, DC Reit, First Reit, Daiwa
summary: SATS is in discussions to acquire Worldwide Flight Services, with no definitive terms agreed upon. Digital Core Reit (DC Reit) has entered an agreement to purchase interest stakes in data centers in Dallas, Texas, and Frankfurt, Germany, pending unitholder approval. First Reit expanded its portfolio with 2 new nursing homes in Japan, while Daiwa House Logistics Trust is set to acquire logistics facilities and land in Japan, lifting its distribution per unit by 1.3%.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

site_title: Crypto shake-out engulfs the C-suite as CEOs start stepping down
summary: Crypto industry leaders are stepping down as CEOs amid a shakeout triggered by a slump that shaved off $2 trillion from cryptocurrencies' market value. Kraken's Jesse Powell is leaving to focus on products and advocacy, while Genesis's Michael Moro and Bitcoin evangelist Michael Saylor have also relinquished top positions. Insiders are taking over at these companies, and the shakeout is driven by regulators' efforts to tame the industry and pre-empt potential risks. Industry experts expect further changes as the biggest overhang not just for crypto, but all global markets, tightens monetary policy.

images.alt_text: The Fed’s determination to raise rates to levels that hammer inflation at the cost of sliding asset prices sent a chill across global markets.
Nasdaq Digital Assets will offer custody services for cryptocurrencies, including bitcoin and Ethereum.
Crypto lenders such as Voyager boomed during the Covid-19 pandemic, luring depositors with high interest rates and easy access to loans rarely offered by traditional banks.
Bitcoin may not work well as a hedge for equity risk.
Coinbase said in a statement that it made the shifts “to account for changes in global crypto trading volumes and asset prices”.

site_title: ICP eyes Nagoya, Sapporo hotel stakes in 6.5b yen deal
summary: ICP Group has proposed a 6.5 billion yen (S$64 million) deal to acquire a 5% stake in two hotel properties in Sapporo and Nagoya, Japan. The hotels, operated under the 2ND by hotel androoms brand, will be managed by Travelodge Hotels (Asia) upon completion. The acquisition is expected to be funded by internal resources and bank borrowings, with a total cost of 334.4 million yen. The deal is part of ICP's expansion efforts in Japan, complementing its existing Travelodge hotels.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Travelodge Phuket Town opened earlier this year. ICP said this will be followed by the opening of Travelodge Chiang Mai in the fourth quarter of 2022.

site_title: Digital Core Reit eyes Germany, US acquisitions to up portfolio value by as much as 43% to US$2b
summary: Digital Core Reit, a pure-play data centre Reit, proposes to acquire core data centres in the US, aiming to boost its portfolio value by up to 43% to US$2 billion. This would represent a 43% increase from its IPO portfolio valued at US$1.4 billion. The acquisitions, the company's first since its IPO in December 2021, demonstrate its external growth strategy, according to CEO John Stewart.

site_title: Amazon drives renewable energy push with 71 new projects
summary: Amazon has announced plans to add 71 new renewable energy projects, increasing its total capacity to 379 and aiming for 100% renewable energy by 2025. The new projects include large-scale plants, rooftop solar, and its first solar farm in Poland, generating 50,000 gigawatt hours of clean energy equivalent to powering 4.6 million US homes annually.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower on Thursday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index falling 1.97% to 18,080.93, following a big interest rate hike by the US Federal Reserve and warnings of more rate hikes to come. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined, with the Shanghai Composite Index falling 0.59% and the Shenzhen Composite Index falling 0.73%. The declines were attributed to concerns over the impact of US interest rate hikes on global markets.

site_title: Hong Kong central bank raises interest rate after Federal Reserve hike
summary: Hong Kong's central bank raised its base rate by 75 basis points to 3.5% in response to the US Federal Reserve's 75 basis point rate hike, maintaining a lock-step monetary policy approach. This move aims to contain inflation, following the Fed's signal to continue raising borrowing costs. The decision follows the US central bank's third consecutive rate increase, underscoring its commitment to controlling inflation.

site_title: Singapore gaining traction among global funds, with 639 VCCs as at end-Aug
summary: Singapore's asset management industry has seen significant growth over the past two years, with the country now attracting global funds from North America, Europe, and other regions. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) reported that the country's asset under management reached S$4.7 trillion in 2020, up 17% from the previous year. The Variable Capital Company (VCC) structure has gained traction, with 639 live VCCs in Singapore as of end-August 2022, offering fund managers greater operational flexibility and cost savings. The MAS plans to enhance the VCC framework to make it more accessible to participants and asset owners.

HK boutique investment firm's founder, Ronald Chan pictured on August 26, 2022.

site_title: BOJ curve-control policy bolstered as US yields fall after Fed
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is set to maintain its yield curve-control policy after the US Federal Reserve raised its benchmark by 75 basis points and cut its economic growth projection, causing longer-maturity Treasury yields to fall. The BOJ spent over 1 trillion yen on bond purchases on Wednesday, aiming to cap 10-year yields and contain super-long yields. Despite the Fed's actions, the BOJ's stance remains unchanged, with its chief market economist stating that the central bank will continue its unlimited fixed-rate bond buying operations.

images.alt_text: This photo taken on September 17, 2022 shows people shopping at a clothing store in the Motomachi shopping street in Yokohama, Kanagawa prefecture, south of Tokyo. - Inflation in Japan hit 2.8 percent in August, the highest level since 2014, government data showed on September 20, 2022 as soaring energy prices bite. site_title: Investors pour money into China ETFs as markets drop: report
summary: China's equity exchange-traded funds (ETFs) saw a net inflow of 33 billion yuan ($6.6 billion) over the past month, as investors sought bargains in a bearish market. More than 70% of the 598 stock ETFs saw net inflows, with blue-chip ETFs such as ChinaAMC China 50 ETF and Haitai-PB CSI 300 ETF drawing significant inflows. This trend reflects shifting investor preferences amid a gloomy economic outlook and rising geopolitical tensions, which have led to a decline in Chinese stocks, with the bluechip CSI300 Index hitting a 4-month low.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on US falls with eyes on Bank of Japan
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower, extending falls on Wall Street, after the US Federal Reserve announced a widely expected rate hike. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index dropped 0.87% to 27,075.80, while the Topix index fell 0.78% to 1,905.86. The focus shifts to the Bank of Japan's upcoming meeting, which may impact the Japanese economy.

site_title: Federal Reserve goes big again with latest rate hike of 75 bps; Powell vows to ‘keep at it’
summary: The US Federal Reserve raised interest rates by 3/4 percentage point, marking its third consecutive hike, to a range of 3.00-3.25% and projecting a 4.25-4.50% rate by year-end. Fed Chair Jerome Powell vowed to continue battling inflation, which has been running above the 2% target, and signaled at least one more 75-basis-point increase. The move is expected to slow the economy, with year-end growth projected at 0.2%, and the unemployment rate rising to 3.8% by year-end.

images.alt_text: The broad-based S&P 500 dropped 1.7 per cent to 3,789.93, while the tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index declined 1.8 per cent to 11,220.19..
Brent futures fell 54 cents, or 0.6 per cent, to US$90.08 a barrel by 2.15 pm EDT (1815 GMT) on Wednesday, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude fell 71 cents, or 0.9 per cent, to US$83.23.
A drop of more than 7 per cent in Bitcoin – something that can happen in a few seconds in digital assets – would send it back to 2020 prices.
The US dollar index, which measures the greenback’s value against other major currencies, was up more than 0.5 per cent higher to 110.87 - its highest level since 2002.

site_title: South Korea, Japan hold first bilateral talks since 2019, seek stronger ties
summary: South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol and Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida held their first bilateral talks since 2019, aiming to strengthen ties between the two countries. The meeting, held in New York during the UN General Assembly, came amid historical disputes stemming from Japan's 1910-45 colonization of the Korean peninsula. The leaders agreed to improve relations, with Yoon seeking to address past issues while facing common threats from North Korea's nuclear and missile programs.

images.alt_text: Japan Prime Minister Fumio Kishida on Tuesday offered to meet North Korea’s leader Kim Jong Un.

site_title: Oil prices fall after Federal Reserve raises interest rates
summary: Oil prices fell on Wednesday after the US Federal Reserve raised interest rates by three-quarters of a percentage point to quell inflation. This move led to a decline in risk assets, including stocks and oil, while the dollar rallied. Oil prices dropped 0.6% for Brent futures to $90.08 a barrel and 0.9% for US West Texas Intermediate crude to $83.23. This is the lowest close for both benchmarks since September 8.

images.alt_text: West Texas Intermediate surged toward US$87 a barrel, adding as much as 3.2 per cent.

site_title: Daiwa House Logistics Trust proposes S$47.7m maiden acquisition in Japan
summary: Daiwa House Logistics Trust (DHLT) proposes a S$47.7 million acquisition of 2 logistics facilities and a freehold land in Japan, representing an 11.8% discount to the properties' average appraised value. The acquisition is expected to broaden DHLT's earnings base, diversify its portfolio, and mitigate potential concentration risk. The deal will also enhance the quality of the existing portfolio, with the target properties being 100% occupied by high-quality tenants, including listed companies.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
A weaker yen against the Singapore dollar led net property income and gross revenue to fall short of the real estate investment trust’s pro-rated forecasts from the prospectus.
The Reit's financials for the quarter were in line with the pro-rated forecasts disclosed in its initial public offering prospectus, the manager said on Thursday.
Daiwa House Logistics Trust's N-E Japan properties sustain 'minor physical damage' from quake
Daiwa House Logistics Trust portfolio valuation up 14.1% from purchase consideration

site_title: Biotech startup ImmunoScape raises US$14m to further cancer therapy discoveries
summary: Biotech startup ImmunoScape has secured US$14 million in funding from Anzu Partners, Amgen Ventures, and EDBI. The Singapore-headquartered company's proprietary "Deep Immunomics" platform enables the discovery and characterization of rare T-cells specific to certain cancers. The funding will aid in expediting development efforts for ImmunoScape's T-cell receptor (TCR) therapeutics, which aim to modify immune cells to target cancer cells. This investment highlights ImmunoScape's potential to develop innovative medicines, according to Amgen's vice-president of research.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
ClavystBio is led by CEO Dr Christopher Laing, who was previously vice dean of innovation and entrepreneurship at the Duke-NUS Medical School.

site_title: Meet Japan’s cyborg cockroach, coming to disaster area near you
summary: Japanese researchers have developed a cyborg cockroach that can carry solar cells and electronics on its back, controlled remotely. The cockroach, a Madagascar hissing cockroach, was chosen for its size and lack of wings, allowing it to carry equipment without hindrance. The breakthrough, led by Kenjiro Fukuda at the Thin-Film Device Laboratory at Riken, could potentially aid in locating survivors trapped under rubble after an earthquake. The flexible solar cell film is 4 microns thick and can be fitted on the cockroach's abdomen, enabling remote control and powering the device.

images.alt_text: Called ZEM, for zero emission mobility, the 2-seater houses a Cleantron lithium-ion battery pack, and most of its parts are 3D-printed from recycled plastics.

site_title: Haulio wants to be go-to digital platform for container haulage
summary: Singapore-based digital trucking platform Haulio has raised US$7 million in a Series A round led by Temasek's Heliconia Capital to enhance service quality, acquire talent, and expand deeper into the region. Founded in 2018, Haulio has grown significantly, transacting over 1.8 million twenty-foot equivalent units annually. The company plans to expand into Thailand and other South-east Asian markets, aiming to be the go-to digital platform for container haulage. With strategic investors, Haulio aims to achieve its vision of transforming the traditional logistics industry through digitalization and sustainability.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Haulio raises US$7m in Series A round led by Temasek's Heliconia
Funding Societies partners Haulio to provide ready credit to hauliers
Digital tools helping SMEs to handle supply-chain chaos
Logistics tech firm Haulio seals undisclosed pre-Series A round, eyes regional expansion

site_title: Singapore shares open Thursday lower after Wall Street slump; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore shares declined 0.4% on Thursday, following overnight losses on Wall Street, after the US Federal Reserve announced its third consecutive interest rate hike. The Straits Times Index dropped 11.27 points to 3,250.52, with local banks UOB, DBS, and OCBC also falling. The decline follows European shares' earlier gains, which were driven by a rebound in the Stoxx 600 index after Russia's partial military mobilization announcement.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Singapore bourse was a stark outlier on Wednesday as it bucked the regional trend and finished higher

site_title: A great copper squeeze is coming for the global economy
summary: A copper shortage is looming, with inventories near historical lows and prices expected to double by 2025, according to Goldman Sachs. The global recession and under-investment in copper mines will exacerbate the shortage, which could lead to a 10 million-ton deficit by 2035. The energy transition and net-zero goals will drive demand, but supply growth will peak by 2024, leaving a massive shortage. Recycling and scrap supply will help fill the gap, but it may not be enough to meet the projected demand.

images.alt_text: Copper reversed after data showed the US consumer price index gained 0.1 per cent last month while economists polled by Reuters had forecast it would dip 0.1 per cent.

Workers at a production line of copper foils used for lithium batteries in Tongling, Anhui province, China. The premium for cash copper over three-month futures on the London Metal Exchange rose by as much as 91 per cent on Thursday.

site_title: Bitcoin, Ether drop as Fed warning of rate-hike pain hits crypto
summary: Cryptocurrencies, including Bitcoin and Ether, plummeted as the Federal Reserve raised interest rates to combat inflation, sending global markets into a chill. Bitcoin fell 4% and Ether shed 7.2%, with the crypto market already reeling from a $2 trillion decline since 2021. Experts warn of further failures and blood in the streets, with a few wealthy champions emerging at the expense of many others.

images.alt_text: Nasdaq Digital Assets will offer custody services for cryptocurrencies, including bitcoin and Ethereum.
Digital assets' valuation hit a peak last November and has faced headwinds since.

site_title: Bank of England set for second hefty rate rise in a row
summary: The Bank of England is expected to raise interest rates by at least half a percentage point to 2.25% from 1.75%, aiming to tame inflation at a 40-year high. This move comes amid a tumbling currency and a free-spending government, following the US Federal Reserve's 0.75% rate hike. Economists predict higher rates could prompt more policy tightening, despite a reduced risk of recession. The decision is also influenced by new Prime Minister Liz Truss's caps on energy tariffs and potential cuts to taxes.

images.alt_text: US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell announced that it will raise interest rates by three-quarters of a percentage point, Sept 21, 2022.
Surging prices have forced central banks worldwide to tighten monetary policy, which is expected to cool inflation but risks tipping economies into recession.

site_title: Sports car maker Lotus’s tech arm valued at US$4.5b in fundraising
summary: Lotus Technology, the tech arm of sports car brand Lotus, has completed a fundraising valued at nearly US$4.5 billion. The company plans to use the proceeds for product innovation and developing global distribution networks. This valuation surpasses the initial target of US$5 billion to US$6 billion set in 2021. Lotus Technology is also set to start production of its first electric SUV by the end of this year, marking a significant milestone for the company.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Lotus sign is seen at the car plant headquarters in Hethel, Britain June 23, 2021. Picture taken June 23, 2021.    REUTERS/Dylan Martinez/File Photo

site_title: Amid frenzied buying at new home launches, developers may be signalling a peak
summary: Developers in Singapore are signaling a potential peak in the private home market with cautious land bids despite strong demand for suburban condos. Recent launches saw 75-84% of homes sold, and developers are instead bidding less aggressively for land, which may remove a key marketing point for real estate agents. This cautious approach may indicate that developers believe prices are peaking, and they're avoiding potential losses due to rising interest rates and construction costs.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
Lentor Modern is the largest private non-landed residential launch in 2022, said Huttons Asia.

Trendale Tower was put up for sale in August at a guide price of S$178 million, which works out to S$2,386 per plot ratio after factoring in the seven per cent bonus gross floor area (GFA) for balconies.

krtender13 - Land parcel along Lentor Central. URA tender for this site closes on September 13, 2022.



Source: URA

site_title: Europe: Shares recover from geopolitical shock before Federal Reserve’s rate hike
summary: European shares rose 0.9% on Wednesday before the US Federal Reserve's third interest rate hike, driven by gains in defence stocks and oil prices following Russia's announcement of a partial military mobilization. Despite concerns over the conflict, markets focused on the Fed's decision, with some expecting a full percentage point rate increase. The Stoxx 600 index bounced back after hitting its lowest level since early July.

images.alt_text: London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index shed 0.2 per cent to 7,179.26 points.

site_title: Meta gains on report social-media giant to cut costs at least 10%
summary: Meta Platforms is cutting costs by at least 10% through employee attrition and reorganizing departments, avoiding outright layoffs. The company has already slowed hiring and reprioritized key projects. Meta reported a 32% growth in full-time employees over the previous year, but is now reducing costs. The cost-cutting measures come after the company trimmed an estimated $95 billion in annual expenses and delayed handing out jobs to summer interns. Meta's stock initially rose 1% on the news but later pared the gains.

images.alt_text: As digital advertising enters a period of transformation, the challengers to the duopoly of google and Meta look well-placed to increase their gains.

Representatives from major technology companies including Twitter, Facebook, YouTube, Twitter and Tik Tok testify in a hearing, held by members of the Senate Homeland Security and Government Affairs Committee to examine social media's impact on homeland security, at the US Capitol in Washington, Sept 14, 2022.
Project Cambria, which will be the successor to Meta Quest 2, will be the centrepiece of the company’s metaverse strategy.

site_title: Britain to overhaul public company registry in dirty money crackdown: source
summary: The UK government plans to overhaul its public company registry, giving it "significant new powers" to challenge and decline dubious information and report suspicious activity to law enforcement. The move aims to crack down on "dirty money" and tackle problems such as international money laundering networks and fraudsters. The Economic Crime and Corporate Transparency Bill, set to be introduced to parliament, will provide the registry with increased powers and resources to improve transparency and tackle corruption through shell firms. The reforms follow calls from anti-corruption groups and lawmakers to improve the registry's ability to tackle dirty money.

images.alt_text: London's fintech boom opens the door for dirty money

site_title: ‘Buckle up’ as inflation fight threatens growth, IMF chief warns
summary: IMF managing director Kristalina Georgieva warns of a recession-like experience for millions of people due to tightening monetary policy to combat inflation, despite efforts to cool inflation. Higher interest rates will slow growth, forcing central banks to balance inflation control with economic stability. Georgieva also expects a food-shock window to be approved to aid countries affected by the Ukraine war, which has disrupted grain shipments.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A participant stands near a logo of IMF at the International Monetary Fund - World Bank Annual Meeting 2018 in Nusa Dua, Bali, Indonesia, October 12, 2018. REUTERS/Johannes P. Christo/File Photo
The IMF in July revised down global growth to 3.2 per cent in 2022 and 2.9 per cent in 2023. It will release a new outlook next month.

site_title: UK’s top manufacturing body slashes forecasts for 2023
summary: The UK's manufacturing association, Make UK, has slashed its forecast for manufacturing growth in 2023 to 0.6%, down from 1.7% in June, citing uncertainty around demand and energy prices. Soaring energy costs, caused by Russia's invasion of Ukraine, have eroded consumer demand and increased operating costs. The weak pound has also hindered exports, with many UK manufacturers being less well-positioned to take advantage of relative devaluations in sterling. This downgrade is a blow to the UK's recovery from the pandemic and poses a risk to businesses.

images.alt_text: Kwasi Kwarteng's first budget represents a significant gamble as UK faces the most difficult economic landscape in years.
Wholesale prices for electricity will be capped at about £211 pounds (S$338) per megawatt hour (MWh) and for gas at £75 pounds per MWh.
The retailer said on Wednesday (Sep 21) that it plans to boost hourly wages to at least £10.20 from £10, its second pay rise this year, while providing one-time £250 M&S vouchers to 4,500 workers.

site_title: Indonesia, Philippines set to hike rates further to quell inflation
summary: Indonesia and the Philippines are set to hike interest rates further to combat inflation, with Bank Indonesia expected to raise its benchmark rate by 25 basis points to 4% and the Philippines' Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) likely to hike its policy rate to 4.25%. The moves aim to ease price and currency pressures amid inflation concerns, with economists predicting inflation to accelerate further in the coming months. The decisions are also seen as part of the global tightening on interest rates to quell inflationary pressures.

images.alt_text: The Bank Indonesia (BI) headquarters in Jakarta.  Lawmakers have been considering revisions to BI’s role since 2020, including at one stage a plan to give government ministers a say in determining monetary policy. The move spooked financial markets, which feared this could undermine the autonomy of the central bank.
The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) now expects the current account balance this year to register a deficit of US$20.6 billion, or 5.0 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP).

site_title: Taiwan set for modest rate hike as growth slows
summary: Taiwan's central bank is expected to raise its benchmark interest rate by 12.5 basis points to 1.625% on Thursday, its third hike this year, as it battles inflation without hurting its slowing economy. The decision comes as the US Federal Reserve hikes interest rates by 75 basis points to tame rampant inflation. Economists expect Taiwan's GDP to slow to 3.2% for this year and raise interest rates again in the fourth quarter to 1.75%. The move aims to bolster Taiwan's dollar, which has slumped due to a stronger US currency and rising geopolitical tensions.

images.alt_text: The island’s export orders, a bellwether of global technology demand, unexpectedly fell in July.

site_title: Nvidia CEO sees ‘large space’ for China sales despite US restrictions
summary: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang expressed optimism about the Chinese market despite US restrictions on exports of its A100 and H100 chips. The restrictions, which apply to chips with specific performance and connectivity thresholds, leave "a large space" for Nvidia in the Chinese market. The company expects that most customers won't be affected by the rules, and it will seek licenses for Chinese customers who need its top chips. The restrictions could impact up to $400 million in sales for Nvidia in its current fiscal quarter.

images.alt_text: Danny Shapiro said Drive Thor would be able to replace numerous chips and cables in the car and bring down the overall system cost, although he did not give specific numbers on savings.
Nvidia has gained attention in recent years with its booming data center business, which sells chips used in artificial intelligence work such as natural language processing.

site_title: US bank CEOs back Federal Reserve hikes during congressional grilling on economy, China ties
summary: US bank CEOs, including Jamie Dimon and Brian Moynihan, testified before Congress, endorsing Federal Reserve rate hikes to tame soaring inflation. They acknowledged potential pain for consumers and a chance of a mild US recession, citing uncertainty over global energy and food supplies. The CEOs also discussed their institutions' operations in Russia and China, with some lawmakers pressing them on ties to Russia and potential responses to a Chinese invasion of Taiwan.

images.alt_text: Brent futures fell 54 cents, or 0.6 per cent, to US$90.08 a barrel by 2.15 pm EDT (1815 GMT) on Wednesday, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude fell 71 cents, or 0.9 per cent, to US$83.23.
US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell announced that it will raise interest rates by three-quarters of a percentage point, Sept 21, 2022.

site_title: Deutsche Bank’s new London headquarters to sell for a discount
summary: Deutsche Bank has signed a 25-year lease for a 568,500 sq ft London property, paying £38 million annually. The building, valued at £809 million, is being sold at a 9% discount by Landsec to an investment vehicle managed by Lendlease for £809 million. The sale is part of the UK's commercial real estate market's response to rising interest rates and inflation.

site_title: New definitions of floor area could eat into developers’ saleable area - and margins - for condo projects
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) is introducing new floor area definitions that will reduce saleable area for condominium projects by around 5% as of June 1, 2023. This change will include strata areas, such as private aircon ledges and curtain wall systems, as gross floor area (GFA). The reduction in saleable area will lead to lower profit margins for developers, potentially making it less viable to invest in property development. Developers may respond by adjusting land prices or increasing selling prices, but this could be challenging in competitive markets, and reduced profit margins could be too low to justify the risks of development.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

generic / ST20210126_202104438482 / Alphonsus Chern //

Generic photograph of the Saint Andrew's Cathedral and the City Hall area with the Padang, Singapore. 26 January 2021.

site_title: India’s Reliance Retail in talks for rights of beauty retailer Sephora: report
summary: Reliance Retail, a unit of Indian conglomerate Reliance Industries, is in talks to acquire the rights to operate beauty retailer Sephora in India. Sephora's operations would transfer from Arvind Fashions if an agreement is reached. The deal would see Sephora's 25 stores in 13 Indian cities, carrying brands such as cosmetics, fragrances, and skincare, fall under Reliance Retail's management. No comment was immediately available from the parties involved.

site_title: Thailand plans to cut borrowing to US$60b next fiscal year
summary: Thailand plans to borrow 2.23 trillion baht (S$85 billion) in the next fiscal year, a 3% decrease from its target this year, as the country rolls back Covid-related spending. The debt-raising will include 793.6 billion baht of fresh borrowing and 1.44 trillion baht for refinancing existing debt. The move is seen as a response to rising global yields and the central bank's rate hikes.

images.alt_text: The excise tax rebate of 5 baht per litre on retail diesel prices will be extended for two months to Nov 20.
Thailand has promoted high-tech sectors and supported electric vehicles to maintain its status as a regional auto production base..

site_title: India expects at least US$25b investment under semiconductor incentive scheme
summary: India expects at least $25 billion in investments under its semiconductor incentive scheme, according to Junior IT Minister Rajeev Chandrasekhar. The government has raised fiscal support to cover 50% of project costs for new semiconductor facilities and display manufacturing. Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government aims to attract big-ticket investments under a $10 billion incentive plan to make India a key player in the global supply chain. Several global players, including Vedanta and Foxconn, have already announced investments in India's chip sector.

site_title: Navigating the high seas of Singapore’s talent and supply chain
summary: Singapore's logistics and supply chain industry has undergone significant transformation in recent years, driven by the e-commerce boom, rising domestic and cross-border express shipments, and global trade disruptions. The talent market has also become increasingly competitive, with 6 in 10 employers in Singapore reporting difficulty in hiring, especially in operations and logistics roles. To address this, companies must invest in upskilling employees with digital skills, empower frontline colleagues, and create a purpose-driven work environment that fosters motivation and value. By doing so, businesses can attract and retain top talent, drive productivity and customer satisfaction, and ultimately thrive in the post-pandemic workplace.

images.alt_text: Deep transformation can navigate us to a just and regenerative future, in which our social and environmental systems are capable of adapting to and addressing challenges of the future with flexibility and resilience.

site_title: Warner Music names YouTube business head Kyncl as CEO
summary: Warner Music Group has named Robert Kyncl as its new CEO, effective January 1, 2023. Kyncl, who previously led YouTube's business, will succeed outgoing CEO Steve Cooper. The move aims to diversify revenue streams as the music industry seeks growth beyond streaming, amid inflation and declining shares. Kyncl spent 12 years at YouTube and was vice-president of content at Netflix before joining Warner Music.

site_title: First Reit to buy 2 Japan nursing homes for 2.6 billion yen
summary: First Reit has agreed to buy two nursing homes in Japan for 2.6 billion yen (S$26.3 million), fully funded by debt, as part of its expansion in the key growth market. The nursing homes, Loyal Residence Ayase and Medical Rehabilitation Home Bon Séjour Komaki, have a combined net property yield of 5.2%. The acquisitions are expected to be distribution per unit (DPU) accretive and will contribute to about one-quarter of First Reit's assets under management.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Japan's ageing population is driving  demand for quality care homes, said Yong Yean Chau, the chief executive officer of PLife Reit's manager.
Japan’s aged care market remains stable, said the CEO of PLife Reit's manager.

site_title: How Singapore-global enterprises can seize opportunities in South-east Asia
summary: Singapore-global enterprises (SGEs) can capitalize on growth opportunities in South-east Asia by understanding their customers and competition. Asean's prospects are driven by the rise of the middle class, digital adoption, and manufacturing diversification. SGEs must choose the right playing field across five dimensions: markets, customer segments, products, distribution channels, and the industry value chain. To create competitive advantages, SGEs can scale, differentiate, or adopt a hybrid approach. Government assistance schemes, such as the Market Readiness Grant and Enterprise Development Grant, can also support their entry into new markets.

images.alt_text: Grab riders and taxi drivers in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam. Consumer digital services will be one of the major growth drivers for Asean in the post-Covid future.

site_title: Investors keen on regional biotech, but are cautious about deal terms
summary: South-east Asian biotech companies continue to draw investors, with 27 venture investments worth US$530.1 million as of August 25, despite macroeconomic headwinds. Investors are seeking more protection against risks, resulting in tighter deal terms, including lower valuations and more protective clauses. Despite this, some investors remain optimistic about the sector, citing segments of interest such as mRNA technology and breakthrough innovations. Companies are adapting to the cautious market by focusing on their value proposition and longer-term outlooks.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Tessa named a new chief executive on Aug 22, Thomas Willemsen, who most recently led Japan’s Takeda Pharmaceutical Company in Asia-Pacific as a senior vice-president
ClavystBio is led by CEO Dr Christopher Laing, who was previously vice dean of innovation and entrepreneurship at the Duke-NUS Medical School.

site_title: Asian insurance giant bets on China ESG assets as tech flounders
summary: Asian insurance giant AIA Group is shifting its investment focus from technology to Chinese equities and ESG assets. The company, which had invested heavily in Big Tech, is now overweight Chinese equities and favors solar, wind, and electric-vehicle assets. AIA's chief investment officer, Mark Konyn, cited a significant shift in the energy mix and growing interest in green and sustainability-linked bonds. The move comes as traditional energy sector stocks have rebounded and tech stocks have underperformed in the ESG space this year.

images.alt_text: The insurer reported its first annual VONB fall in 2020 since its 2010 listing in Hong Kong.

site_title: SATS in talks to buy Worldwide Flight Services; no definitive terms reached
summary: SATS is in talks to acquire air cargo handler Worldwide Flight Services, with no definitive terms agreed upon. The potential acquisition, which could reach US$3 billion, is contingent on financing from private equity owner Cerberus Capital Management. SATS has expressed a strategic priority to expand its network and capabilities, but notes that there is no certainty a transaction will materialise. The acquisition would mark a significant move for SATS, which operates in over 160 airports worldwide.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
On Friday, mainboard-listed SATS posted a net loss of S$22.5 million for the quarter ended June due to lower government grants and increased costs

site_title: Europe burns cash to help businesses in deepening energy crisis
summary: European Union governments are burning cash to support businesses in the deepening energy crisis, with Germany being more reliant on Russian gas. In response to Russia's partial military mobilization, Britain will halve energy bills for businesses, while European governments have earmarked €500 billion in the past year to shield citizens and companies from soaring gas and power prices.

images.alt_text: Uniper, the biggest German buyer of Russian gas, is at the epicentre of the crisis sparked by Russia’s moves to cut energy supplies in retaliation for war-related sanctions.

site_title: Cristiano Ronaldo wants to play till Euro 2024
summary: Cristiano Ronaldo, 37, expressed his desire to continue playing until Euro 2024, stating he feels "very motivated" and has "great ambition." Ronaldo, Portugal's all-time top goalscorer with 117 goals in 189 appearances, aims to be part of the World Cup and Euros. Despite speculation about his future, Ronaldo has chosen to stay at Manchester United, scoring in their last Europa League match. With Euro 2024 in sight, Ronaldo seems determined to continue his career.

site_title: Bitcoin hovers near three-month low ahead of Fed rate decision
summary: Bitcoin prices hovered near a three-month low ahead of the Federal Reserve's rate decision, with the largest token rising less than 2% to $19,306. A 7% drop in Bitcoin would send it back to 2020 prices, potentially sparking significant losses. Investors await the Fed's policy decision, which could impact liquidity and volatility in riskier assets. A 100 basis point hike is expected, but a one-percentage-point increase could lead to further pressure on cryptocurrencies.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher as investors gear up for another big rate hike
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday ahead of a widely expected rate hike from the Federal Reserve, with investors awaiting cues on policy tightening. The Dow Jones rose 113.2 points, or 0.37%, to 31,819.39, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained ground. The rate hike is expected to tame surging price pressures, but investors remain cautious about the impact on the economy.

site_title: Biden accuses Russia of 'irresponsible' nuclear threats, violating UN charter
summary: US President Joe Biden criticized Russian President Vladimir Putin at the UN General Assembly in New York, accusing Russia of violating the UN charter by invading Ukraine. Biden stated that Russia's actions are "irresponsible" and threatening, particularly the use of nuclear weapons. The US is among 40 UN members helping Ukraine fight the war. Biden's comments come as the conflict has been ongoing since Russia's unprovoked invasion in February.

images.alt_text: The United Nations flag flies in front of the Secretariat Building at the UN headquarters in New York City. The high-level meeting of the 193-member UN General Assembly starts on Sep 20.

site_title: US: Stocks tumble after latest big Federal Reserve rate hike
summary: US stocks plummeted 1.7% on Wednesday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index declining 1.7% and 1.8% respectively. The Federal Reserve raised interest rates by 0.75 percentage point for the third consecutive time to combat inflation, with the policy rate now at 3.0-3.25%. Markets were caught off guard by the Fed's hawkish outlook, leading to a sharp sell-off. The Dow Jones Industrial Average also fell 1.7%.

images.alt_text: A Wall Street sign in New York on May 25, 2018. MUST CREDIT: Bloomberg photo by Michael Nagle.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 113.2 points, or 0.37 per cent, at the open to 30819.39.

site_title: US existing home sales fall less than expected in August
summary: US existing home sales fell 0.4% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.80 million units in August, the lowest sales level since November 2015. Despite the decline, sales rose in the Northeast and West, while falling in the Midwest. Affordability deteriorated further due to surging mortgage rates and high house prices. Home resales decreased 19.9% on a year-on-year basis, and confidence among single-family homebuilders eroded for the ninth straight month.

images.alt_text: Rising mortgage rates are increasingly weighing on the interest-rate-sensitive housing sector as the Federal Reserve pushes on with aggressively lifting borrowing costs in order to tame high inflation.

site_title: Climate-focused investor TRIREC hits US$66 million for fund’s first close
summary: TRIREC, a Singapore-based investment firm, has raised US$66 million for the first close of its decarbonisation fund, TRIREC Venture I. The fund, which focuses on companies tackling climate change, secured capital commitments within 4 months and has raised its cap from US$75 million to US$100 million. Founded in 2015, TRIREC has backed 18 businesses to date and manages over US$120 million across 2 pools of capital. The firm expects to hold a final close by the first half of 2023.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Two men fish at a pond filled with plastic waste at a village in Lhokseumawe, Aceh on September 29, 2021. (Photo by Azwar Ipank / AFP)

site_title: US bank CEOs set for congressional grilling by Democrats and Republicans
summary: US bank CEOs, including JPMorgan's Jamie Dimon, Wells Fargo's Charles Scharf, and Citigroup's Jane Fraser, will testify before the House of Representatives Financial Services Committee on September 21, facing questioning from both Democratic and Republican lawmakers on issues such as consumer protections, fossil fuel lending, and firearms. The CEOs will tout their financial strength and efforts to boost lending in poorer communities and diversity within their ranks. The hearing is seen as a risk for CEOs, who will be defending their banks amidst the November elections and lawmakers' efforts to boost their profiles.

site_title: Nearly 1 million people face starvation in hunger hotspots, warn UN agencies
summary: Nearly 1 million people in Afghanistan, Ethiopia, South Sudan, Somalia, and Yemen are at risk of starvation due to severe drought and conflict, according to the UN Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO). The global food crisis worsens, driven by economic instability linked to the Covid-19 pandemic and Russia-Ukraine war. Without a scaled-up humanitarian response, the situation is expected to worsen, with poverty and acute food insecurity rising further. The FAO warns of risks of civil unrest driven by socio-economic grievances.

images.alt_text: An image of 'Brave Commander,' the first ship to sail from Ukraine to the horn of Africa carrying grain supplies, is shown on screen as UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres speaks at the 77th General Debate at the UN headquarters in New York, Sept 20, 2022.

site_title: China Evergrande mulls asset transfer to property unit for debt payment
summary: Evergrande Group, a Chinese developer with approximately $300 billion in debt, is considering transferring assets to its property unit to settle debt payments. The company has sold $18.16 billion worth of properties since January and has 706 pre-sold but undelivered construction projects. This move comes after the company's chief executive and finance head stepped down in July due to loans secured by the property unit being diverted to the parent group. Evergrande is in talks to muster funds to repay loans, with deposits held by the property unit being used as collateral.

site_title: Zero-Covid policy has cost Hong Kong its aviation hub status: Iata
summary: Hong Kong has lost its position as a global aviation hub due to China's zero-Covid policy, according to Iata Director General Willie Walsh. The policy has "devastated" Cathay Pacific and hindered the industry's recovery. The city's position as a transit hub for international flights to China has been lost, and it will struggle to regain it if Beijing continues its restrictions next year. The Iata is closely watching for any indications that China will ease its restrictions, and continued restrictions will impact the industry's overall recovery strength.

site_title: New city-fringe condo prices climbing closer to those in central region
summary: The median price per square foot (psf) gap between new, non-landed homes in Singapore's Core Central Region (CCR) and Rest of Central Region (RCR) narrowed to 14.9% in August, down from 25.07% in April. The median price paid for a new non-landed home in the RCR exceeded that in the CCR, with buyers paying S$2.47 million for a new non-landed home in the RCR, 10.8% more than in the CCR. This narrowing price gap has led to increased sales of CCR homes, with 66.7% more sales in the second quarter of 2022 compared to the first quarter.

images.alt_text: Developers sold a total of 437 units excluding executive condominiums (ECs), 47.6 per cent lower than the 834 units sold in July 2022.

ST20211117_202146255160 Kua Chee Siong/ pixgeneric/ Generic pix of private housing in Holland Road with the backdrop of D'Leedon condominium towering over properties in the central part of Singapore on 17 Nov 2021.
Condominiums, apartments and hotels as viewed from Moulmein Road on May 4, 2021.

site_title: A cornered Putin is more dangerous than ever
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin doubled down on his nuclear threat and accused the West of seeking to "destroy" his country in a speech, effectively conceding that the war in Ukraine has not gone as he wished. He called up 300,000 reservists and suggested that Ukrainians are mere pawns of the "military machine of the collective West". Putin's speech marked a shift in his rhetoric, labeling the war as a "defensive war" against the West's attempt to dismember Russia. The move raises concerns about the potential for nuclear confrontation, with Putin warning that any attack on Russian soil could provoke a nuclear riposte.

images.alt_text: PDirect flights to cities in nearby ex-Soviet countries of Armenia, Georgia, Azerbaijan and Kazakhstan were all sold out for Wednesday.
Russian President Vladimir Putin speaks to China's President Xi Jinping during the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation (SCO) leaders' summit in Samarkand on Sept 16, 2022.
Vladimir Putin blamed what he called “the green agenda” for the energy crisis, and insisted that Russia would fulfil its energy obligations.

A new  image released by Buckingham Palace on September 18, 2022, shows Britain's Queen Elizabeth II smiling, photographed at Windsor Castle in May 2022. Huge crowds built in central London from early morning on September 19, 2022, to secure a spot to watch the state funeral of Queen Elizabeth II at Westminster Abbey.

site_title: Prince William cites queen’s love for environment in climate plea
summary: Prince William, now heir to the throne, sent a pre-recorded video message to the annual Earthshot Prize in New York, calling for the "fastest change the world has ever known" in transitioning to sustainable energy sources. He cited his late grandmother Queen Elizabeth II's passion for the environment as a key motivator for his climate plea. The Earthshot Prize, created by Prince William in 2019, rewards efforts to combat climate change, and the event was held two days after Queen Elizabeth II's funeral.

site_title: Milan Fashion Week opens with a spring in its step
summary: Milan Fashion Week opened on September 21, 2022, with a strong lineup of 70 catwalk shows and 110 presentations from top Italian fashion brands, including Gucci, Prada, Versace, and Dolce & Gabbana. The event comes after a two-year hiatus due to the COVID-19 pandemic and Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The return of a full live program is seen as a positive sign for the fashion industry, with Chinese buyers also returning to boost business.

site_title: US dollar hits 2-decade high as Putin rattles markets before Fed rate hike
summary: The US dollar reached a 2-decade high of 110.87 against other major currencies, driven by Russian President Vladimir Putin's mobilization of 300,000 troops for the Ukraine conflict and expectations of an aggressive US Federal Reserve rate hike. European currencies, particularly the euro and sterling, fell due to concerns about the economic outlook. The Fed is expected to lift interest rates by 3-quarters of a percentage point, further testing the world economy's resilience. The US dollar index has surged 16% this year, its biggest annual gain since 1981.

site_title: China calls for ‘ceasefire through dialogue’ following Putin’s address on Ukraine
summary: China has called for a "ceasefire through dialogue" following Russian President Vladimir Putin's announcement of partial military mobilization in Ukraine, urging all parties to respect territorial integrity and abide by the UN Charter. Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Wang Wenbin emphasized the need for a peaceful resolution, while reaffirming China's support for the sovereignty of all countries. This stance aligns with China's previous announcements and its "no-limits" relationship with Russia, which aims to counter Western influence.

images.alt_text: Russian President Vladimir Putin speaks to China's President Xi Jinping during the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation (SCO) leaders' summit in Samarkand on Sept 16, 2022.

site_title: US mortgage interest rates reach 6.25%, highest level since October 2008
summary: US mortgage interest rates reached 6.25%, the highest level since October 2008, according to Mortgage Bankers Association data. The Federal Reserve is aggressively lifting borrowing costs to tame high inflation, weighing on the interest-rate-sensitive housing sector. The central bank is set to raise interest rates by 3-quarters of a percentage point for a third straight time. Rising mortgage rates are expected to further impact the housing market, which is already sensitive to interest rate changes.

site_title: Living under one roof
summary: Architects are seeing a growing demand for multi-generational family homes, where multiple generations live under one roof. This trend is driven by high property prices, small apartment sizes, and the need to care for ageing parents. Design solutions are being developed to ensure space and privacy for each generation, resulting in unique homes that stand out from the rest. From detached bungalows to corner terraces, architects are creating innovative designs to accommodate the changing family dynamics.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 13.92 points to 1,447.18. A total of 2.343 billion lots worth RM1.658 billion were traded. Losers outnumbered gainers 529 to 296, indicating a bearish trend in the market.

site_title: TikTok to verify political accounts in US, ban campaign fundraising
summary: TikTok will verify US government, politician, and party accounts, requiring them to submit a verification request. Verified accounts will receive a blue check mark, and unverified accounts will be prohibited from accessing advertising features. The platform will also ban campaign fundraising videos and money-making features, including digital payments and gifting, to prevent politicians from soliciting donations. The move aims to clamp down on political misinformation ahead of the US midterm elections in November.

site_title: M&S launches £15m package to help employees in cost of living crisis
summary: Marks & Spencer plans to spend £15 million to support employees struggling with the UK's cost of living crisis. The retailer will boost hourly wages to at least £10.20 and provide one-time £250 vouchers to 4,500 workers. Additionally, it will offer free meals, sanitary products, and financial planning workshops. This move comes as rival companies, including J Sainsbury and John Lewis Partnership, have also announced measures to support employees. The measures aim to help staff cope with rising prices for food, energy, and other essentials.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Minister for Sustainability and the Environment, Grace Fu, emphasized the government's priority to align economic policies with environmental costs. The government aims to signal a high environmental cost for unsustainable practices through policies like the Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) framework, which shifts the responsibility of waste management from consumers to producers.

site_title: Sri Lanka’s national consumer price index soars 70.2% year on year in Aug
summary: Sri Lanka's National Consumer Price Index (NCPI) surged 70.2% year on year in August, surpassing a 66.7% rise in July. Food inflation reached 84.6%, while non-food inflation was up 57.1%. This marks a significant increase in inflation, which is attributed to various economic factors affecting the country.

images.alt_text: Sri Lankan rupees are seen in a bowl at a vegetable vendor's shop amid the rampant food inflation, amid Sri Lanka's economic crisis, in Colombo, Sri Lanka, July 29 , 2022. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon

site_title: Britain halves electricity and gas prices for businesses
summary: Britain has announced a plan to cap the wholesale cost of electricity and gas for businesses at less than half the market rate, starting from October 1, 2023. The cap for electricity will be set at £211 per megawatt hour and for gas at £75 per megawatt hour. The measure aims to relieve pressure on businesses and protect jobs, with the support package set to last until March 31, 2023. The government also announced support for households in Northern Ireland on the same level as the rest of the UK.

images.alt_text: Suppliers will get rebates for those discounts, which would apply to contracts already signed earlier this year.

site_title: Don McLean’s ‘Vincent’ lyrics expected to fetch US$1m at auction
summary: Don McLean's original handwritten lyrics to his song "Vincent," a tribute to painter Vincent van Gogh, are expected to fetch US$1 million at auction in November. The lyrics were written on green paper and scrawled in pencil, and were inspired by Van Gogh's famous painting "The Starry Night." McLean, now 76, is selling the lyrics as part of a collection of personal items, including 25 guitars, jewelry, and vintage watches, with proceeds going to the Don McLean Foundation.

site_title: Local business leaders celebrated at Singapore Business Awards, Events & Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: Wee Ee Cheong, a 38-year-old Malaysian squash player, made history by becoming the first Southeast Asian player to win a Grand Slam title in squash. Cheong defeated England's Tom O'Connor in the men's singles final at the 2023 British Open Grand Slam tournament. The victory marked a significant milestone in Cheong's career and made him the first Malaysian player to win a Grand Slam title. Cheong's win was met with widespread celebration in Malaysia, with many hailing him as a national hero and a symbol of Asian squash excellence. He won the match 3-1.

site_title: Putin's military call up sparks rush to buy flights out
summary: Russia's partial military mobilization, announced by President Putin, has led to a surge in flight bookings out of the country. Direct flights to nearby countries, such as Armenia, Georgia, Azerbaijan, and Kazakhstan, were sold out on Wednesday. Turkish Airlines reported all flights to Istanbul fully booked until Saturday. Google data showed a significant increase in searches for "tickets" and "plane" after Putin's televised address. The move has sparked concerns among Russians, leading to an exodus of tens of thousands to neighboring countries.

images.alt_text: Passenger planes owned by Russia's airlines, including Aeroflot and Rossiya, are parked at Sheremetyevo International Airport in Moscow, Russia March 1, 2022. REUTERS/Marina Lystseva NO RESALES. NO ARCHIVES.

site_title: China has enough coal reserves to last another 50 years
summary: China has sufficient coal reserves to last approximately 50 years, according to the Ministry of Natural Resources. The country's coal reserves stood at around 208 billion tons in 2021, with an increase of 28% from the previous year. Additionally, China's oil reserves are enough to last at least 18 years at current production rates, while natural gas reserves are sufficient for the next 3 decades. The country's reliance on imports for oil and gas remains significant, with investment in exploration rising 13% to 80 billion yuan in 2021.

site_title: In small Chinese cities, unsold housing stock hits highest level since 2019
summary: China's unsold housing stock in small cities reached its highest level since 2019 as of August, according to a report from China Real Estate Information Corp. Unsold new homes in tier-3 and tier-4 cities increased by 5% year-over-year. It now takes developers about 20 months to sell a new home nationwide, with over 50 months in some small cities. This fragile demand in the country's downtrodden property market has led to a rally in shares of Chinese property developers.

images.alt_text: August is traditionally a strong month for the Swedish housing market, and on seasonally adjusted terms, prices overall fell by 1.2 per cent.

site_title: Australia: Commodity stocks drag shares to 2-month low ahead of Fed decision
summary: Australian shares fell 1.6% to a 2-month low on Wednesday, led by commodity and financial stocks, ahead of the US Federal Reserve's expected 75-basis-point rate hike. Miners, including Rio Tinto, BHP Group, and Fortescue Metals, slumped 2.8% due to concerns over a global recession and China's zero-Covid policy. Gold stocks and financials also fell, with the S&P/ASX 200 index closing at 6,700.2.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index fell about 1 per cent by 0050 GMT on Wednesday, with all the subindexes in the red.

site_title: Singapore stocks finish lower as Fed rate hike looms; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.2% to 3,261.79, losing 5.15 points, amid regional losses ahead of the Federal Reserve's rate hike. The decline follows Wall Street losses, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index down 1.8% and Japan's Nikkei 225 falling 1.4%. Top Glove's share price slid 7% after posting its first quarterly loss since 2001, while Parkway Life Real Estate Investment Trust declined 2% after announcing a nursing home acquisition in Japan.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
On the Singapore bourse, the Straits Times Index slipped 0.1 per cent or 3.14 points to 3,263.80 as at 9.03 am.

site_title: China’s Internet giants out to conquer the world
summary: Chinese Internet giants have achieved success through a combination of factors, including the country's rapid modernization, a homogeneous market, and government support. E-commerce firms like Alibaba and JD.com have expanded globally, with Shein, a fast-fashion retailer, dominating the US market. Social media platforms like TikTok and ByteDance have gained popularity worldwide. However, the Chinese domestic market is slowing due to Beijing's zero-Covid policy and frosty relations with the US. Despite these challenges, Chinese Internet firms are expanding globally, and their strategies include copying and innovating, as well as investing in customer satisfaction.

images.alt_text: From biotech to electric vehicles, shares of China’s key manufacturers have seen heavy selling recently as US initiatives to secure domestic supply chains and solidify its industrial superiority raised uncertainties for Chinese firms.
China suspended game approvals last August before resuming them in April.
As digital advertising enters a period of transformation, the challengers to the duopoly of google and Meta look well-placed to increase their gains.

site_title: UK housing stocks rise on potential cut in stamp duty
summary: UK homebuilders' stocks surged 3.2% on Wednesday after a media report suggested the British government would cut stamp duty in a mini-budget this Friday, aiming to boost economic growth. The move comes as the UK housing sector faces pressure from rising costs and mortgage rates. The potential cut, first reported by The Times, could be a repeat of a policy used by previous finance minister Rishi Sunak, which helped drive economic growth during the pandemic.

site_title: Putin, Xi and the limits of friendship
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin's war in Ukraine has dealt a significant strategic setback to China, particularly its most important international partner, Russia. The conflict has weakened Russia, destabilized Eurasia, and strengthened the Western alliance, contradicting China's shared hostility to American global leadership. A protracted conflict in Ukraine would be a major embarrassment for China, while a Russian defeat would make Beijing's friendship with Russia look like an asset. Xi Jinping may regret his words of "friendship with no limits" between Russia and China, as the situation now favors the West.

images.alt_text: Russian President Vladimir Putin speaks to China's President Xi Jinping during the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation (SCO) leaders' summit in Samarkand on September 16, 2022. (Photo by Sergei BOBYLYOV / SPUTNIK / AFP)
Vladimir Putin acknowledged India’s concerns, echoing language he used a day earlier in a meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping.

site_title: China’s Nio takes on BMW, Mercedes in home market with flexible battery plan
summary: Chinese electric-car startup Nio plans to expand its European market by rolling out a battery leasing and swapping network, aiming to cut costs for users. The company plans to build 1,000 battery swapping stations outside China by 2025, mostly in Europe, to service its expanded range of electric vehicles. Nio's battery swap stations promise to send drivers out with a new, fully-charged battery in just a few minutes, faster than current charging alternatives. This strategy has set Nio apart from rivals in China's EV market, but shifts costs and risk to the company.

site_title: Japan weighs plan for ban on hotel guests without masks: media
summary: Japan is considering allowing hotels to refuse entry to guests who do not wear masks during an outbreak, as the government prepares to ease Covid-19 border controls. A bill will be submitted to Parliament next month, revising the law governing hotels and inns to give them more power to enforce infection measures. This move comes as Japan is set to waive visa requirements for certain tourists and remove daily arrival limits.

site_title: Automakers tackle patent hurdle in quest for in-car tech
summary: Over a dozen automakers, including Toyota and Nissan, have signed up with Avanci, an independent licencing marketplace, to access patents for wireless technology from 51 tech companies. The platform charges a flat fee of $20 per car, distributed among patent holders, and covers 2G, 3G, and 4G technology. The move aims to simplify access to wireless technology and avoid costly legal battles, with 80-85% of cars with 2G technology or higher licensed through the platform.

images.alt_text: A view of cars on the road during rush hour traffic jam, while California's government authorities are expected to put into effect a plan to prohibit the sale of new gasoline-powered cars by 2035, according to local media, in San Francisco, California, U.S. August 24, 2022. REUTERS/Carlos Barria
Germany’s Mercedes-Benz was among the best performers with a 16 per cent jump from a year ago.
The meeting will discuss the roles of the auto industry in a decarbonised society.

site_title: China’s rulers seem resigned to a slowing economy
summary: China's economy is expected to grow by less than 3% in 2022, significantly below the official target of 5.5%, due to a deep property slump and zero-Covid policy. The country's currency is also weakening, and its GDP could be over $2 trillion below forecast in 2023. Unlike in the past, China's unconventional tools to stimulate spending are not working, and the lack of borrowers is blunting monetary policy. The government's reluctance to implement large-scale stimulus efforts, led by President Xi Jinping's zero-Covid regime, is also a factor.

images.alt_text: Unemployment among people in China aged 16 to 24 stands at almost 19 per cent, after hitting a record 20 per cent in July, according to government data.
A yearlong slump in the property market is denting demand for real estate.

site_title: British monarchy’s fashion mantle passes to younger generation
summary: Queen Elizabeth II's death marks a shift in the British monarchy's relationship with fashion, with younger members, particularly Catherine, Princess of Wales, taking on a greater public role. The late queen's fashion formula, characterized by elegant coats and classic accessories, will be replaced by more relatable and restrained styles. Catherine, 40, is expected to hold the public's attention with her understated yet smart style, which has sparked buying frenzies in the past. However, her potential increase in glamour may conflict with King Charles' sustainability messaging, which emphasizes purchasing quality items that will last.

images.alt_text: epa10170605 (FILE) -  Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge (L) looks on laughingly as her mother-in-law, Britain's Queen Elizabeth II gestures while they watch part of a children's sports event during a visit to Vernon Park in Nottingham, east Midlands, Britain, 13 June 2012 (reissued 08 September 2022). According to a statement issued by Buckingham Palace on 08 September 2022, Britain's Queen Elizabeth II has died at her Scottish estate, Balmoral Castle, on 08 September 2022. The 96-year-old Queen was the longest-reigning monarch in British history.  EPA-EFE/PHIL NOBLE UK AND IRELAND OUT SHUTTERSTOCK OUT  EDITORIAL USE ONLY
Queen Elizabeth represents a figure of significant continuity during a seven-decade period when the world has been transformed.

site_title: SGX launches SGX CurrencyNode FX trading venue
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX Group) has launched SGX CurrencyNode, a foreign exchange electronic communication network offering market participants anonymous access to over-the-counter (OTC) FX liquidity. The launch completes SGX's OTC FX infrastructure, enhancing price discovery, efficiency, and liquidity for Asian currencies. SGX CurrencyNode currently streams liquidity for FX spot, precious metals, and non-deliverable forwards, with plans to launch FX swaps and NDF spreads later. The move is seen as a response to global regulatory developments affecting the FX industry, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) supporting the development of a best-in-class FX marketplace.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Full year revenue for SGX reached S$1.099 billion, a 4 per cent increase as compared with last year’s S$1.056 billion.
SGX chairman Kwa Chong Seng (left) and CEO Loh Boon Chye .

site_title: I.D.E.As to leverage long-term growth trends
summary: DBS's Chief Investment Office has introduced the I.D.E.A acronym to identify growth equities in the digital world. The four categories are innovators, disruptors, enablers, and adapters, which have successfully adapted to trends such as content streaming, e-commerce, cloud computing, and digital payments. These companies have stood out and reshaped their industries, making them potential winners in the new digital landscape. The approach is part of DBS's barbell strategy, combining income-generating assets with secular growth equities.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan

site_title: Singapore airport working with airlines to avoid travel chaos as demand returns
summary: Changi Airport in Singapore has successfully managed to avoid travel chaos by coordinating with airlines and suppliers to increase capacity without compromising service levels. The airport reached 56% of its 2019 passenger numbers in August and is forecast to reach 80% of pre-pandemic levels by the end of the year. By retaining 25,000 of its pre-pandemic workforce and recruiting additional staff, the airport has been able to ramp up capacity more easily than its rivals. This has enabled the airport to capitalize on Singapore's hub status as travel demand returns.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines planes at Changi Airport Terminal 3 on July 9, 2022.

site_title: KFC threatens legal action over Mbappe’s sponsorship stance
