summary: The Singapore Business Federation's (SBF) third run of its SME transformation programme, the MAP initiative, will focus on sustainability, responding to growing global demand for green materials, products, and processes. The programme aims to benefit over 500 participants from 300 companies and integrate the principles of long-termism, values, strengths, and risks from Singapore sovereign wealth fund GIC. The initiative will provide tools to measure energy consumption and carbon footprint, and solutions to reduce traditional energy sources.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
SGX and MAS launched ESGenome, a disclosure portal for corporates to report their ESG data, on Monday (Sep 12).

site_title: Singapore-based fintech platform #dltledgers raises S$8.5m in Series B
summary: Singapore-based fintech platform #dltledgers raised S$8.5 million in its Series B funding round led by the Tata group's family office and Centrum. The company plans to use the funds for business expansion in North America and scaling its engineering and growth teams. The funding round is expected to close by the end of October, with a potential extension to S$15 million. #dltledgers aims to leverage the funds to further its blockchain-based multi-enterprise supply-chain business network.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

site_title: Marco Polo Marine to build new vessel supporting offshore wind-farm demands
summary: Marco Polo Marine plans to build and operate a new Commissioning Service Operation Vessel (CSOV) valued at $60 million, set to be deployed in Q1 2024. The vessel, designed with Seatech Solutions International, will support the growing demand in Asia's offshore wind-farm industry, addressing a CSOV shortage and rising charter rates. The CSOV will be equipped with green technology, including hybrid energy storage systems, to reduce carbon emissions by 15-20%. The global offshore wind market is expected to grow 49% from 2021 to 2026, driven by Asia-Pacific's leading wind power development.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Marco Polo’s new vessel is based on a design co-developed by the group and Seatech Solutions International (S).

site_title: Singapore stocks close 0.3% higher after last-hour dip-buying on Wall Street
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.3% higher on Tuesday, September 20, 2022, following a last-hour dip-buying on Wall Street that reversed earlier declines. Asian markets, including Hong Kong, mainland China, South Korea, and Japan, also ended in the black. Interest rate bets have ramped up ahead of the US Federal Reserve's Federal Open Market Committee meeting, with a 75 basis-point hike expected and an 18% chance of a 100-bp increase.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
The Petronas Twin Towers, a landmark in Kuala Lumpur. In the Malaysian bourse on Tuesday (Sep 20), xxxx.

site_title: JPMorgan names Hong Wai Mei senior country officer for Singapore
summary: JPMorgan Chase has appointed Hong Wai Mei as senior country officer for Singapore, effective October 1. Mei, who has over 25 years of experience in the banking industry, will oversee client engagement, governance, and coordination. This promotion comes as the bank has internally promoted leaders in the region, including Tammi Yong, who was named head of investment banking for Malaysia. Mei will continue in her existing roles as head of corporate banking for Singapore and Asean.

site_title: Beware the rise of the black box algorithm
summary: A recent article warns that the rise of black box algorithms in artificial intelligence can lead to mundane yet significant problems, such as faulty Satnav directions that cause accidents, rather than catastrophic societal disasters. This oversight can distract from the real risks posed by AI, including the potential for personal tragedies and policy failures. The author argues that a more nuanced approach to AI research and ethics is needed to address these everyday dangers.

images.alt_text: Banks are now using AI to help them manage a broad spectrum of risks, streamlining everything from know-your-client (KYC) checks to identifying fraudulent behaviour among millions of transactions a day.
Has AI advanced beyond intelligence to becoming sentient? Perhaps the more important issue is how suggestible humans can be to AI already.

site_title: China, North America dominate global wealth growth in 2021, but inequality widening
summary: China and North America dominated global wealth growth in 2021, with China adding a quarter and North America bringing in over half of the global growth. Aggregate global wealth totalled $463.6 trillion, with wealth per adult rising 8.4% to $87,489. However, inequality widened, with the top 1% holding 45.6% of wealth, up from 43.9% in 2019. China's middle and upper-middle-class segments grew significantly, while median wealth in China lagged behind, and inequality widened in China and India.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng
They’ve increasingly shunned stocks and bonds to focus on their own companies or assets deemed safer such as gold and cash.
Credit Suisse Group is shifting resources to win business from a broader range of rich clients, as the lender focuses more heavily on wealth management amid cuts to its troubled investment bank.

site_title: Aramco CEO says Europe's energy crisis plans only short-term solution
summary: Saudi Aramco CEO Amin Nasser says Europe's energy crisis plans, including capping energy bills and taxing companies, are only short-term solutions that don't address the root causes of the problem. He attributes the crisis to underinvestment in the hydrocarbons sector, despite alternatives to fossil fuels not being readily available. Nasser warns that global investments in hydrocarbons are "too little, too late, too short term" and that demand will rebound further, eliminating available spare oil production capacity.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Amin H. Nasser, President & Chief Executive Officer Saudi Aramco, speaks during the CERAWeek energy conference in Houston, Texas, U.S. March 8, 2022.  REUTERS/Daniel Kramer/File Photo

Capital spending jumped an annual 64 per cent in April to June, as Saudi Arabia embarks on a building spree including malls and parks as well as grandiose plans for a new city built from scratch and a luxury tourism development on the Red Sea.

site_title: Tom Cruise, Sandra Bullock say Paramount is cheating them out of millions
summary: Tom Cruise and Sandra Bullock claim Paramount Pictures is cheating them out of millions of dollars due to a deal with cable channel Epix. The deal allegedly denies the stars and producers a share of digital sales and licensing to third parties, resulting in significant losses. Paramount has delivered its best box-office results in a decade, with Top Gun: Maverick being the highest-grossing film of the year so far. The dispute highlights the complex nature of movie profits and the potential for discrepancies between studios and their partners.

site_title: China EV maker Leapmotor launches up to US$1b Hong Kong IPO
summary: Leapmotor, a Chinese electric vehicle maker, is launching a Hong Kong IPO to raise up to $1.03 billion, with a market capitalization of $6.99 billion to $9.03 billion. The company plans to use the funds for research and development and expanding production capacity. This is the largest IPO in Hong Kong in 2022, following China Vanke's $733 million IPO. Despite positive investor interest, bankers remain cautious due to ongoing China-US tensions, the Russia-Ukraine war, and high inflation. The IPO is set to start trading on September 29.

site_title: Can Britain's King Charles fill his treasured mother's shoes?
summary: King Charles III, 73, succeeds his mother Queen Elizabeth II at a time when public support for the monarchy has reached its lowest level, with opinion polls showing 62% approval. Despite this, Charles has received a groundswell of goodwill, with a YouGov survey finding 63% think he would be a good king. He faces challenges in dealing with his feuding sons, William and Harry, and delivering on his aim to slim down the monarchy. Historians and experts warn that if support for the monarchy drops below 50%, it could lead to an elected head of state.

images.alt_text: King Charles III follows the coffin as it arrives at the Committal Service for Britain's Queen Elizabeth II in St George's Chapel inside Windsor Castle on September 19, 2022. (Photo by Jon Super / POOL / AFP)

The coffin of Queen Elizabeth II with the Imperial State Crown, along with the orb and sceptre, symbols of her authority, was borne on a gun carriage that made its way to Westminster Abbey for the state funeral on Monday (Sep 19). The cortège then made its way to St George's Chapel in Windsor for interment before a smaller congregation.

site_title: National mourning ends in Britain after queen's funeral
summary: National mourning in Britain has ended after Queen Elizabeth II's state funeral. Following the funeral, around a quarter of a million people viewed the queen's coffin in the days leading up to the service, and an epic clean-up operation was underway. Flags were returned to full mast, and the royal family remains in mourning for another week. New Prime Minister Liz Truss attended the funeral, and her appointment occurred just two days before the queen's death.

images.alt_text: Charles, 73, takes the throne at a time when opinion polls show that support in Britain for the monarchy has slipped to its lowest level, and that - despite a jump since he became king - he is much less personally popular than his mother.

site_title: Indonesia’s parliament submits draft law on wider role for central bank
summary: Indonesia's parliament has proposed a draft law to widen the central bank's mandate, including economic growth, and formalize bond purchases in the primary market. The bill aims to expand Bank Indonesia's objectives to support sustainable economic growth and remove a 23-year-old rule barring top policymakers from joining political parties. The move aims to maintain the central bank's autonomy and independence, as proposed by President Joko Widodo. The bill's next step is for the government to discuss it with lawmakers, with parliamentarians hoping it can pass into law later this year.

images.alt_text: A student helps farmers to harvest patchouli plants at a patchouli oil refinery in Lhoong, Aceh province on Sep 10, 2022. Indonesia's exports rose 30.15 per cent on a yearly basis in August to US$27.91 billion.
Students rallying against Jakarta's 30 per cent fuel price hike in Surabaya on Sep 8.
“Please don’t think we will be aggressive like the Fed,” central bank governor Perry Warjiyo said.

site_title: Vietnam’s capital needs US$887m investment for fully electric bus fleet
summary: Hanoi, Vietnam's capital, needs approximately $887 million in investment to replace its 1,100-bus fleet with electric vehicles by 2050. The city aims to convert around 1/5 of its fleet to electric by 2025. Electric buses currently run 250-300km per charge, compared to 260-400km for combustion engine buses. The move aligns with Vietnam's goal to become carbon-neutral by 2050. The Hanoi Transport Corporation plans to introduce electric buses to ensure long-distance coverage and mitigate range anxiety.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with much-needed gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed up 1.16% on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index reaching 18,781.42, as Asian markets rebounded from recent sell-offs. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains. Despite the rally, traders remain cautious ahead of an expected Federal Reserve interest rate hike later this week.

site_title: Demand for Porsche listing exceeds deal size: bookrunner
summary: Demand for Porsche's initial public offering (IPO) exceeds the full deal size, according to a bookrunner. The IPO, set to take place on September 29 at the Frankfurt Stock Exchange, has generated indicated demand multiple times the full deal size. Cornerstone investors have already secured 40% of the shares, including Qatar Investment Authority and Norway's sovereign wealth fund. Total proceeds from the sale will be 18.1-19.5 billion euros, which could help Volkswagen fund its electrification drive.

site_title: Making industrial policy “in”
summary: US President Joe Biden signed the CHIPS and Science Act of 2022, a $280 billion bill aimed at bolstering the American chip manufacturing industry. The legislation marks a shift in US economic policy towards a coordinated national approach, driven by the need to compete with China in high-tech sectors. The bill provides $52 billion in subsidies and tax credits for chip manufacturers and $200 billion for new manufacturing initiatives in AI, robotics, and quantum mechanics. The move reflects a bipartisan consensus on the need for industrial policy, with 17 Republicans supporting the bill.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden speaks at the groundbreaking of the new Intel semiconductor manufacturing facility near New Albany, Ohio, on Sept 9, 2022. Last month, Biden signed into law the Chips and Science Act, which authorised about US$52 billion in government subsidies for US semiconductor production and research.

The United States is leading an unprecedented effort to supercharge domestic semiconductor research and production, both to alleviate Covid-19 supply chain issues and shift away from reliance on Chinese technology.
If we see some decline in world trade in the years ahead, it won’t be the first time that’s happened. Rising international interdependence is not an inescapable trend.

Semiconductors have become nearly ubiquitous, but it shouldn't be left to government planners to decide which factories to build now in order to produce the types of high-end chips that will be needed a few years out.

site_title: Covid-hit Shanghai unveils 1.8 trillion yuan in projects in infrastructure push
summary: Shanghai has unveiled 1.8 trillion yuan in infrastructure projects to boost its economy, which has been hurt by COVID-19 lockdowns and a protracted property downturn. The city's infrastructure investment fell 27.4% in the first 8 months of the year, but recent months have seen a pick-up in investment, with contracts signed for 597 big projects. The projects include transport hubs, urban railways, and offshore wind power demonstration projects, aiming to bolster the slowing economy. This move echoes national policymakers' calls to revive sluggish economic growth.

site_title: UK's new PM vows billions in Ukraine aid, admits US trade talks off
summary: UK Prime Minister Liz Truss vowed billions in aid to Ukraine, exceeding the £2.3 billion already planned, as she kicked off her UN General Assembly debut. She also conceded that a post-Brexit UK-US trade deal is unlikely for years. Truss's hard line on Brexit has drawn criticism from US President Joe Biden and European leaders, who are seeking western support for Ukraine. Despite this, Truss promised to rally western backing, saying her government will continue to support Ukraine's security.

images.alt_text: New British Prime Minister Liz Truss will be at the UN General Assembly in New York, her first outing on the world stage since becoming the UK's leader.

site_title: Marcos embarks on US charm offensive in shift from Duterte
summary: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr has embarked on a charm offensive in the US, seeking to strengthen ties with the country after his predecessor Rodrigo Duterte's shift towards China. Marcos stated that he cannot envision the Philippines without the US as a partner and expressed confidence in the country's economic growth, despite external challenges. He also met with US-based companies to attract investment and addressed concerns about high power costs. Marcos's remarks mark a significant shift in the Philippines' foreign policy, and he is facing a $354 million fine in the US for contempt of court.

images.alt_text: The first offering under Marcos Jr took place against the backdrop of rising borrowing costs and as governments spend to fund recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: SpaceX wants to bring satellite Internet to Iran: Musk
summary: SpaceX plans to offer satellite internet to Iran, with owner Elon Musk stating the company will apply for an exemption from US sanctions. Musk announced Starlink's availability on every continent, including Antarctica, with plans to launch up to 42,000 satellites. This move aims to boost connectivity in the country.

images.alt_text: SpaceX's chief operations officer Gwynne Shotwell on Monday said the company probably won’t need to launch 40,000 satellites into orbit.

site_title: Truss team takes gamble with emergency budget
summary: UK Chancellor Kwasi Kwarteng delivers an emergency budget as part of Prime Minister Liz Truss's pledge to revitalize growth, despite a stagnant economy and high inflation. The budget includes tax cuts, a £150 billion energy price cap, and potential abolition of measures like the sugar tax. However, the government's plan to pay for £30 billion in tax cuts is unclear, and economists question the feasibility of the tax cuts in curbing inflation. The budget represents a significant gamble for the UK, with uncertain outcomes for growth and the ruling Conservatives' election prospects.

images.alt_text: Britain’s response to the cost of living crisis has differed from its European peers, notably in PM Truss’ rejection of a windfall tax on energy companies’ profits.
After 8 years of dealing with the rules, British banks have found ways to align pay with that of other regions.
New British Prime Minister Liz Truss will be at the UN General Assembly in New York, her first outing on the world stage since becoming the UK's leader.

site_title: Thai acting PM asks finance ministry to monitor weak baht
summary: Thai Acting PM Prawit Wongsuwan has asked the finance ministry to closely monitor the country's weak baht currency, which has been trading at its weakest level in over 15 years against the US dollar. The cabinet approved an investment budget of 276 billion Thai baht for state-owned enterprises in the 2023 fiscal year. Despite concerns over the currency's volatility, industrial sentiment improved in August, reaching an 11-month high. The finance minister expects the Thai economy to grow 3-4% this year, driven by tourism, exports, and public investment.

site_title: Malaysia’s exports up 48.2% in Aug, exceeding economists’ forecast
summary: Malaysia's exports surged 48.2% in August, exceeding economists' forecast of 34.4%, driven by double-digit growth in electrical and electronic products, petroleum products, and machinery. The country's trade surplus rose to RM16.9 billion, 19.9% lower than the previous year. Imports also increased 67.6% year-on-year, higher than the economists' forecast. The trade performance is the 13th consecutive month of double-digit growth, with exports reaching RM1 trillion for the first 8 months of the year.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's industrial production in July was expected to rise 15.2 per cent, according to 13 economists surveyed in a Reuters poll.

site_title: Covid curbs leave Hong Kong musicians on their 'last dollar'
summary: Hong Kong musicians are struggling to survive due to the city's prolonged COVID-19 restrictions, which have banned live performances in venues serving food and drink for over 650 days. Despite the lifting of restrictions in other cities, Hong Kong remains a "touring dead zone" for international acts, and many venues have closed. The ban has led to job losses in the thousands, with musicians forced to pawn instruments or switch to the gig economy, resulting in a significant decline in income. The mental toll is also high, with 11% of musicians reporting suicidal thoughts and 13% selling their instruments.

images.alt_text: The service would ease the quarantine logjam that has crimped returns to China and mitigate a major roadblock for Hong Kong’s economic recovery by making family or business visits easier.

Hong Kong's incoming Health Secretary Lo Chung-mau told local media outlet Commercial Radio that the city's Covid-19's death toll required that it maintain tough rules, but declined to give a timeline on plans to open up Hong Kong's border with mainland China.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Yanlord Land, OxPay Financial
summary: Yanlord Land Group's indirect subsidiary won a residential site tender at Lentor Central in Singapore for S$481 million, with plans to build a 470-unit development. OxPay Financial was ordered to pay S$77,501.52 to two former employees following wrongful dismissal claims. Shares in Yanlord ended flat, while OxPay's shares rose 3.7%.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

site_title: Gan Kim Yong to attend G20 ministerial meetings in Bali
summary: Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong will attend the G20 ministerial meetings in Bali from Sep 21 to 23, discussing trade and investment in global economic recovery, future-proofing the World Trade Organization, and building resilient global value chains through digital trade. This is his second overseas trip in less than a week, following the Asean Economic Ministers' Meeting in Cambodia. Gan will meet with international counterparts to reaffirm ties and explore collaboration opportunities.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Singapore ‘glad’ progress made on US-led Indo-Pacific economic pact: Gan Kim Yong

DPM Wong will attend the Third Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors Meeting as well
as associated events in Bali.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close higher ahead of Fed decision
summary: Tokyo shares rose 0.44% on September 20, 2022, ahead of the US Federal Reserve's expected rate hike. The Nikkei 225 index climbed 120.77 points to 27,688.42, while the Topix index rose 8.71 points to 1,947.27. The move is seen as a response to investors' anticipation of the Fed's decision, which is expected to impact global markets.

site_title: Norway wealth fund sets net-zero target for portfolio firms
summary: Norway's $1.2 trillion sovereign wealth fund has set a net-zero emissions target for its portfolio companies by 2050, with the aim of reducing emissions from scope 1, 2, and 3 sources. The fund will push companies to set credible interim targets and plans, starting with those with the largest emissions. By 2025, the fund aims to have a comprehensive system in place for measuring climate risks and opportunities, with the goal of all portfolio companies having set net-zero targets by 2040.

images.alt_text: Norway central bank to buy currency for wealth fund for first time since 2013

site_title: Australia: Shares bounce back with all eyes on Fed meeting
summary: Australian shares bounced back with a 1.3% gain to 6,806.4 points, their best day in nearly two weeks, ahead of the US Federal Reserve meeting. The market is pricing in a 75-basis-point rate hike but is concerned about the impact on the economy. The Reserve Bank of Australia's minutes revealed a case for slowing rate hikes, boosting sentiment. Energy and mining indexes rose, while iron ore miners rallied despite a decline in prices due to easing lockdowns in China and government efforts to stimulate the property sector.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index closed down 0.3 per cent at 6,719.9 at the close of trade.

site_title: Wide talent networks, continuous learning are key in future of work: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore's Education Minister Chan Chun Sing emphasized the importance of a wide talent network and continuous learning in the future of work. To remain competitive, companies must refresh their workforce at scale and speed, with 20-30% of employees learning something new each year. Institutions should work with industries to provide just-in-time training, and individuals must have a culture of lifelong learning, adapting to changing skills and technologies. This approach will enable Singapore to outrun competition and create opportunities for Singaporeans.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
A digital native generation fuels consumption of products and services in Asia today. Growing up with the Internet, they are familiar with digital lifestyles and more receptive to new technologies.

Companies such as Accenture, Walmart and Bank of America are increasingly using VR for both onboarding and training. Last year, Accenture purchased 60,000 Oculus VR headsets to use for onboarding, and joiners now spend their first day at the company in its One Accenture Park campus, part of its “Nth floor” corporate metaverse, which the company has developed with Microsoft.

A future-fit office is one that incorporates quality spaces, sustainability and technology to elevate the workplace. Today, these elements come together to create a compelling offer for current and future employees, who will prioritise companies that align to their needs and values.

site_title: Europe: Shares flat with all eyes on central bank moves
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 index ended down 0.09% despite a brief 0.2% gain in the last hour, after trading lower for most of the session. Investors await central bank meetings, including a potential large interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve. European shares took heart from a brief US market move higher, and reduced expectations of a 100 basis points Fed hike may have aided sentiment. Most banks meeting this week are expected to hike interest rates.

images.alt_text: The Frankfurt DAX was 0.6 per cent lower at 12,671.70 points in morning trades.

site_title: UK businessman Mike Ashley to step down as Frasers’ director
summary: UK businessman Mike Ashley will step down as a director at sportswear and fashion retail group Frasers on October 19. Ashley, 57, will leave the board and provide the company with £100 million of additional funding. He had handed over the CEO role to his daughter's partner, Michael, months prior. Ashley expressed confidence in the company's leadership and strategy, stating he feels "very confident passing the baton" to Michael and his team.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Soccer Football -  FA Cup Fourth Round Replay - Oxford United v Newcastle United  - Kassam Stadium, Oxford, Britain - February 4, 2020  Newcastle United owner Mike Ashley before the match     REUTERS/David Klein/File Photo

site_title: Russia to flood Asia with fuels as Europe ramps up sanctions
summary: Russia is expected to increase fuel shipments to Asia and the Middle East as the European Union tightens sanctions in response to the Ukraine invasion. Asia-Pacific countries, including India and China, have already increased imports of Russian crude and products, with a combined daily total of 2.7 million barrels. To evade sanctions, Russian sellers are employing tactics like re-exports and ship-to-ship transfers. Emerging nations, such as Indonesia and Sri Lanka, may also be targeted as Russia seeks alternative markets. This could lead to lower prices and increased volumes stored at sea.

images.alt_text: Oil tanks inside Fujairah port in Fujairah, United Arab Emirates.  Abu Dhabi National Oil Co, which pumps almost all the UAE’s oil, wants to be able to produce 5 million barrels a day by 2025 – sooner than a previously disclosed aim of 2030, said sources.
Brent crude futures rose 60 cents, or 0.7 per cent, to US$91.95 a barrel by 0330 GMT on Monday after settling up 0.5 per cent on Friday.
Europe is entering a critical phase with energy shortages set to increase the strains on the fragile unity that the 27 EU members have managed to maintain since the February invasion.

site_title: China’s Fosun further cuts stakes in listed firms amid debt concerns
summary: China's Fosun International has further cut its stakes in listed firms, including New China Life Insurance and Shanghai Yuyuan Tourist Mart Group, amid concerns over its financial health. The conglomerate raised approximately 696 million yuan (S$139.7 million) through share reductions. Fosun has reduced its stakes in several companies this year, including Tsingtao Brewery and Fosun Tourism. The company has denied reports that Chinese regulators have told banks to check their financial exposure to Fosun, which has been a subject of market speculation.

images.alt_text: Fosun said in a statement media reports saying Chinese regulators have told the country’s biggest banks to start a round of checks on their financial exposure to the company were “sheer nonsense”.

site_title: Seoul: Shares rebound on battery makers boost
summary: South Korean shares rebounded on Tuesday, with the benchmark Kospi ending 12.19 points or 0.52% higher at 2,367.85. The gains were led by electric-vehicle battery makers LG Energy Solution, Samsung SDI, and SK Innovation, which rose 1.26%, 4.28%, and 1.42%, respectively. The rebound follows a 4-session losing streak that saw the Kospi hit a 2-month low. The won strengthened, while the benchmark bond yield rose ahead of a US central bank meeting.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi ended down 27.12 points or 1.14 per cent at 2,355.66, extending losses to a fourth session.

site_title: Iron ore, steel futures fall on China demand worries
summary: China's iron ore and steel futures fell on Tuesday, September 20, amid concerns over the country's persistent zero-Covid policy and ailing property sector, which kept demand subdued. Iron ore prices dropped 3.1% to 696 yuan (S$139.7) a tonne, while steel futures fell 1.5% and hot-rolled coil shed 2%. The US Federal Reserve's expected interest rate hike also contributed to the market volatility. Despite Beijing's easing of border restrictions, demand remains subdued due to regional lockdowns and a weakened housing market.

images.alt_text: A mechanical scoop unloads the iron ore aboard a bulk carrier cargo ship docked at an iron ore transfer and storage center operated by the Shanghai International Port Group in Shanghai, China, on Tuesday, Jan. 26, 2010. Iron ore for immediate delivery into China surged to $131.20 a metric ton on Jan. 8, the highest in at least 13 months, according to data compiled by The Steel Index, a venture of Steel Business Briefing Ltd. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg
Rio said last week it had established a strategic partnership with the new Chinese state-owned agency created to centralise iron ore purchases.

site_title: Manning the defences: Investment themes for the rest of 2022
summary: The global economy is experiencing a paradigm shift due to rising interest rates, inflation, and geopolitical tensions, leading to a slowdown in economic growth. The market is oscillating between concerns about inflation and growth, making it challenging to choose between fixed income and equities. To navigate this uncertainty, investors should adopt a tactical, active management approach, focusing on fundamentally strong companies with pricing power, such as those in life sciences and energy. Macro hedge funds are also expected to continue generating decent alpha from economic and policy divergence.

images.alt_text: The IMF in July revised down global growth to 3.2 per cent in 2022 and 2.9 per cent in 2023. It will release a new outlook next month.

site_title: Europe: Stocks advance at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets opened higher on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index gaining 0.8% to 7,295.40 points after a holiday closure for Queen Elizabeth II's state funeral. The eurozone's Frankfurt DAX and Paris CAC 40 also rose, with the DAX adding 0.5% and the CAC 40 rising 0.6%. Despite earlier Asian gains, looming interest rate hikes remain a focus.

site_title: US: Wall Street ends choppy session higher with focus firmly on Federal Reserve
summary: US stocks ended a choppy session higher on Monday, driven by investor focus on the Federal Reserve's policy meeting and potential interest rate hikes. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 197.26 points, or 0.64%, to 31,019.68, while the S&P 500 gained 26.56 points, or 0.69%, to 3,899.89. Despite a 18.2% decline in the S&P 500 this year, traders are positioning themselves for a rising interest rate environment, with the terminal rate for US fed funds now at 4.46%.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 99.56 points, or 0.32 per cent, at the open to 30,722.86.

site_title: 5 common investing mistakes
summary: Warren Buffett emphasizes the importance of avoiding common investing mistakes to outperform professionals. Key errors include: trusting tipsters over research, lacking a clear investment strategy, overtrading, holding onto losing shares, and failing to reinvest dividends. Buffett advises being a "know-nothing" investor who realizes its limitations and trusting but verifying information. By avoiding these mistakes, investors can potentially outperform professionals and achieve long-term success.

images.alt_text: Tracy Britt Cool, who spent a decade working with renowned investor Warren Buffet, in Omaha, Nebraska in April 2022. Cool is now parlaying her nearly unparallelled access to the mind and methods of Buffet to build her own investment firm, Kanbrick.

site_title: Japan’s inflation hits 31-year high, creating headaches for BOJ
summary: Japan's inflation has reached a 31-year high, with consumer prices excluding fresh food rising 2.8% in August from a year ago, the fastest pace in over three decades. Rising energy and processed food costs, as well as higher electricity prices, contributed to the acceleration. Despite the faster pace of inflation, the Bank of Japan is unlikely to change its policy, with Governor Haruhiko Kuroda committed to keeping interest rates low until solid wage gains make inflation more sustainable.

images.alt_text: Banknotes of Japanese yen are seen in this illustration picture taken June 15, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration

An employee handles sheets of Japanese 10,000 yen banknotes at the National Printing Bureau Tokyo plant in Tokyo, Japan, on Monday, May 20, 2019. Japan’s unexpected growth spurt on the gross domestic product (GDP) in the first quarter masked weakness in the economy just as policy makers prepare to hike the sales tax in October. Photographer: Akio Kon/Bloomberg

site_title: Vessel shortage makes soaring shipping costs a new energy threat
summary: A vessel shortage is driving up shipping costs for energy, with LNG ships being kept busy and delayed in returning to service. As the conflict in Ukraine continues, energy majors are refusing to release vessels, and companies are booking them for winter earlier than usual. This has led to a surge in global freight rates, with LNG freight rates reaching elevated levels for this time of year and threatening to surpass last year's winter peak. The shortage threatens to impact Asian economies and further burden buyers with expensive petrochemical feedstock shipments.

images.alt_text: Oil tanks inside Fujairah port in Fujairah, United Arab Emirates.  Abu Dhabi National Oil Co, which pumps almost all the UAE’s oil, wants to be able to produce 5 million barrels a day by 2025 – sooner than a previously disclosed aim of 2030, said sources.

site_title: AmEx to hire 1,500 tech staff by year-end even as recession looms
summary: American Express plans to hire 1,500 tech staff by the end of the year, despite fears of an economic slowdown. The company has already brought in 3,600 tech employees this year, bolstering its revenue forecast boosted by surging travel and entertainment spending. This move contrasts with other US financial companies, such as Goldman Sachs and financial technology firms, which have cut jobs due to recession concerns. AmEx's decision suggests that moderate inflation benefits credit card companies.

images.alt_text: The company added US$410 million in provisions for credit losses, mirroring similar build-ups at major US banks, and said it expects to set aside more funds.

site_title: CFOs are primed to steer the ESG agenda
summary: CFOs are increasingly expected to drive ESG initiatives as the role of the chief financial officer expands to encompass strategic and long-term organizational success. A recent report by Anaplan and Deloitte found that 81% of non-CFO leaders globally believe CFOs should select resources and technology to execute ESG strategies. However, ESG ranks lower on CFOs' list of priorities, with Singapore CFOs being the most primed to lead ESG initiatives, considering themselves most effective in addressing ESG initiatives. CFOs are now expected to bring together organization-wide data, layer it with external considerations, and use digital planning to execute a future-ready ESG strategy.

images.alt_text: Businesses need to be responsive to their stakeholders in the ESG space to remain relevant, competitive and sustainable.

Beh Siew Kim, the former chief executive and executive director of the managers of Ascott Residence Trust, assumed the role of chief financial and sustainability officer, lodging, at CapitaLand Investment.

site_title: Oil edges up as supply woes outweigh demand and rate hike worries
summary: Oil prices edged higher on Monday as supply concerns outweighed demand worries, despite forecasts of weaker growth and forecasts of zero demand growth in the fourth quarter. Brent crude rose 65 cents to $92 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate rose 62 cents to $85.73 a barrel. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) fell short of its production target by 3.583 million barrels per day in August, citing inability to increase production. Central banks are expected to raise borrowing costs to tame high inflation, but some traders are waiting for the US Federal Reserve's meeting this week.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures rose 60 cents, or 0.7 per cent, to US$91.95 a barrel by 0330 GMT on Monday after settling up 0.5 per cent on Friday.

Oil tanks inside Fujairah port in Fujairah, United Arab Emirates.  Abu Dhabi National Oil Co, which pumps almost all the UAE’s oil, wants to be able to produce 5 million barrels a day by 2025 – sooner than a previously disclosed aim of 2030, said sources.

site_title: Digital gold or fool’s gold: Crypto as a hedge for equity risk
summary: A study by CFA Society Singapore found that Bitcoin does not serve as a reliable hedge against equity risk, contrary to claims by crypto enthusiasts. Correlation data showed that during major market crashes, the correlation between Bitcoin and the S&P 500 increased, rather than decreasing, indicating that Bitcoin actually increased in value during such downturns. In contrast, gold exhibited a negative correlation with the S&P 500 in 4 out of 5 crashes, making it a more effective hedge against equity risk.

images.alt_text: Digital assets' valuation hit a peak last November and has faced headwinds since.

site_title: Coinbase hikes some crypto trading fees in boon to biggest clients
summary: Coinbase, the largest US crypto exchange, has increased some trading fees for customers with lower monthly volumes, while lowering fees for high-volume users. The fee hikes, effective September 20, are attributed to changes in global crypto trading volumes and asset prices. Some customers with $15 million to $250 million in monthly volume may pay up to 2 basis points higher fees, while others may see slight reductions or unchanged fees. The changes aim to better reflect the exchange's changing market conditions.

site_title: Ether's outlook darkens in charts capturing hangover after the Merge
summary: Ethereum's native token, Ether, has slid 10% since the Merge upgrade, with a 63% decline this year. The network's energy use reduction has fizzled out, and technical patterns hint at more downside risk. Ether is now below its second standard deviation of a regression channel, suggesting a potential retreat to $1,250, and potentially lower. Options data from Deribit show a trading range for Ether around $1,000 and $2,000, with some analysts suggesting the maximum pain point is around $1,600.

site_title: Data analytics no longer just a sideshow at banks: OCBC’s MacDonald
summary: OCBC Bank's Group Data Office Head Donald MacDonald has spent 29 years working in data analytics, growing his team from 5 to 130 employees. MacDonald, who was appointed in June 2022, emphasizes the importance of adapting to changing trends and technologies in the banking industry. He notes that banks must now compete with non-traditional players like Amazon and Netflix, requiring real-time data and decisioning capabilities. MacDonald's team focuses on upskilling staff and evolving platforms to deliver personalized customer experiences.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Kevin Lam, head of TMRW and group digital banking at UOB, believes that having an open mind and being ready for new ideas is key in the ever-changing banking industry.
Jessie Li, Standard Chartered Singapore's head of consumer, private and business banking (CPBB), sees herself as a universal travel adapter.
Helge Muenkel, chief sustainability officer at DBS, says transition finance will be key to cutting emissions and saving the planet.

site_title: Bright spots in EU bank bonds as rates rise
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) raised interest rates by 75 basis points to 1.25% to combat inflation, which is expected to remain elevated in the eurozone. This increase in interest rates benefits European banks by boosting net interest margins and improving net interest income. Additional Tier 1 (AT1) bonds, which have risen in yield, offer an attractive entry point for investors, as banks are well-capitalized to withstand any impact on their solvency. Subordinated bank bonds also present opportunities, with some issuers such as Societe Generale and Commerzbank offering attractive yields.

images.alt_text: The cost of borrowing cash against German government bonds in repo markets has only climbed 57 basis points since the ECB’s decision to raise rates by 75 basis points last week.

site_title: Australia: Shares gain more than 1% on commodity, financial boost
summary: Australian shares rose 1.2% to 6,796.8 on Tuesday, driven by gains in financial and commodity stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose despite expectations of a likely US Federal Reserve rate hike. Resources-rich bourses were led higher by miners, with the mining index rising 2.2%. The financial sector climbed 1.4%, with the "big four" banks rising 1.4-2.1%. Fortescue Metals announced plans to eliminate fossil fuels and achieve "real zero terrestrial emissions" by the end of the decade.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index gained about 1.2 per cent to 6,796.8 by 0045 GMT on Tuesday.

site_title: China's Aug coal imports from Russia, Indonesia soar as heatwave spurs power use
summary: China's coal imports from Russia and Indonesia surged in August, reaching a 5-year high, as the country sought to meet increased power demand due to a heatwave. Russian coal imports jumped 57% year-over-year to 8.54 million tonnes, while Indonesian coal imports rose 35% to 15.82 million tonnes. This is the highest level of imports since comparable statistics began in 2017. The surge in imports is expected to continue in October as utilities replenish stocks ahead of the heating season.

site_title: Venture capital excitement cools, but bright spots remain in South-east Asia
summary: Venture capital excitement has cooled globally, with a moderation in fundraising pace in 2022, according to Angela Lai, a senior research analyst at Preqin. However, experts at the SuperReturn Asia conference noted that opportunities remain in South-east Asia, particularly in sectors like agritech, which venture capitalist Jefrey Joe is bullish on. Despite cautious investors, the region still offers potential for growth and investment.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Secondary PE investments have evolved over the past decade to become much more active, said TR Capital founder Paul Robine.

site_title: Top Glove posts first quarterly loss since listing, raises glove prices amid challenges
summary: Top Glove Corporation, a leading glove manufacturer, reported its first quarterly net loss since listing in 2001, with a net loss of RM52.6 million (S$16.3 million) for the fourth fiscal quarter ended August. Revenue declined 52.3% year-over-year to RM990.1 million, due to oversupply and excess stockpiling by customers during the pandemic. The company has deferred expansion plans to align with glove demand and supply, and has raised prices by 5% to address mounting cost pressures and declining demand. Despite this, Top Glove's executives expect the company to return to profitability once ASPs stabilize.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Uma Devi
The maker of one out of every 4 gloves in the world said in September 2020 it expected "fresh highs" after profit surged 1,500%.
Top Glove cited factors such as rising production costs and higher natural gas and electricity tarriffs that have compressed its margins.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks edge up at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.73% at open on Tuesday, following a positive lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index reached 18,700.68, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained 0.39% and 0.58% respectively. The gains come ahead of the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision later this week, leaving traders nervous.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng Index rose 0.73 per cent, or 134.71 points, to 18,700.68.

site_title: UK regulator issues warning on crypto’s FTX to consumers
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has issued a warning to consumers about Sam Bankman-Fried's crypto exchange FTX, stating it is not authorised to offer financial services in the country. Investors in the UK are unlikely to get their money back if things go wrong, as they won't be protected by the country's ombudsman service and compensation scheme. FTX claims an incorrect phone number was listed by the FCA, and a spokesperson says a scammer may be impersonating the firm. The FCA will issue updates if further information becomes available.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Representations of cryptocurrencies are seen in this illustration, August 10, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Crypto exchange FTX is in talks to acquire a stake in crypto lender BlockFi, the Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter.
The company plans to add options trading, although no specific timeline was provided.

site_title: Startup backed by billionaire family offers robots for US farms
summary: A Brazilian startup, Solinftec, backed by billionaire family Trajano, is partnering with Farmers Business Network to offer robots that spray fertiliser and pesticides to US farmers. The robots, powered by solar panels, can apply chemicals only where needed, reducing product use by up to 70%. The technology, already used in Brazil, aims to commercialize localized application of agrochemicals with robotics technology, and both companies will work with US farmers to develop new methods. The partnership is expected to reach over 124 million acres in the next few years.

site_title: Pratt & Whitney, EDB to establish technology accelerator in Singapore
summary: Pratt & Whitney (P&W) is collaborating with the Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB) to establish a technology accelerator in Seletar Aerospace Park. The facility aims to accelerate technology insertion projects worth S$31 million, focusing on automation and digitalization, across P&W's 4 Singapore-based MRO facilities over the next 5 years. The accelerator will create 16 new positions and apply developed technologies globally. The facility is expected to be ready in Q4 2022, solidifying Singapore's position as a leading aerospace hub for innovation.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

site_title: Apple plans fix for shaking iPhone 14 Pro camera by next week
summary: Apple is set to release a software update next week to fix a camera bug on the iPhone 14 Pro and Pro Max, causing the rear camera to physically shake when used with some third-party apps. The issue is attributed to the optical image stabilisation hardware malfunctioning. The update is the second fix for the iPhone 14, following an iOS 16.0.1 update on launch day. The camera bug can also cause rattling noises and affects the camera's ability to prevent blurry pictures.

site_title: Struggling EV startup Mullen bids for bankrupt Electric Last Mile
summary: Mullen Automotive has emerged as the leading bidder for Electric Last Mile Solutions' assets, including a former Hummer SUV factory in Indiana. Mullen agreed to a stalking horse bid of around $100 million. Competing bids are due by October 3, and an auction will be held on October 7. This move comes after Mullen acquired a majority stake in rival Bollinger Motors. The acquisition aims to help Mullen bring electric vehicles to market, including a compact SUV and sports car.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The filing for bankruptcy by Electric Last Mile Solutions Inc makes the company the first of the electric vehicle startups that merged with special-purpose acquisition companies (SPACs) to go out of business amid the recent market slump.
Electric Last Mile Solutions warned Friday it may run out of cash in June, at least one month sooner than previously projected, unless it can raise additional capital.

site_title: Kuroda's BOJ set to become world's last negative rate holdout
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is set to maintain its negative interest rate policy, making it the world's last holdout, as central banks worldwide are expected to raise borrowing costs. BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda is unmoved despite rapid yen weakening, which may lead to further currency fluctuations. The BOJ's dovish stance comes with increasing costs, including a global bond selloff, and may limit its options to respond to the yen's slide.

site_title: Shell plans Adidas, Starbucks stores at Philippine gas stations
summary: Pilipinas Shell plans to expand its retail offerings at gas stations in the Philippines by 2025, with 550 of its 1,300 to 1,400 stations to feature convenience stores, restaurants, and shops like Jollibee, McDonald's, Starbucks, and Adidas. The move aims to boost revenues beyond fuel, with non-fuel retail earnings expected to grow at least 15% annually, accounting for a quarter of sales. This transformation aims to shift the focus from motorists to passengers, creating a "mobility destination" experience.

images.alt_text: Wael Sawan’s appointment as Shell's new CEO is effective from Jan 1, 2023.

Shell wants to divest from the US$20 billion Masela gas project, so a consortium of state-owned energy firm Pertamina, the Indonesia Investment Authority (INA) sovereign wealth fund and other companies may take over its share.

site_title: Jokowi's popularity drops over fuel price hikes in Indonesia
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo's popularity has dropped 10 percentage points to 62.6% following the fuel price hike, according to an opinion poll. The increase, which triggered protests, was defended as the "last option" to cut energy subsidy bills. The move has intensified public dissatisfaction and opposition to calls for an extension of his presidency, which is set to end in May. Widodo's lowest rating since May signals growing discontent over soaring living costs.

site_title: Hong Kong works to cut hotel quarantine as China shows support
summary: Hong Kong is working to relax COVID-19 mitigation measures, including hotel quarantine, as the number of daily infections falls to around 6,000. Chief Executive John Lee announced plans to replace hotel quarantine with 7 days of home health monitoring, with support from mainland China. The moves aim to make travel more accessible for residents and international visitors ahead of high-profile events in October, with leaders hoping to avoid rolling back previous travel reforms.

site_title: India's Digit Insurance IPO kept on hold by markets regulator
summary: India's Digit Insurance IPO has been put on hold by the Securities and Exchange Board (SEBI). The company, backed by Canadian billionaire Prem Watsa's Fairfax Group, aimed to raise $440 million through an initial public offering. Digit plans to raise 12.5 billion Indian rupees ($220 million) through a fresh issue of shares and sell existing shares worth 109.4 million. The SEBI did not provide a reason for the action, leaving the IPO in 'abeyance'.

site_title: To keep the recovery going, let’s step on the gas for hiring flexibility
summary: Singapore's recovery from the pandemic continues, with businesses facing a shortage of skilled workers, particularly in manufacturing and food processing. The government has announced a new list of occupations for foreign workers from non-traditional source countries, set to be implemented in September 2023. However, this comes too late for many firms, who are struggling to fill skilled roles due to source restrictions and rising minimum qualifying salaries. Industry players are calling for an earlier implementation and expansion of the list to address the shortage and support the development of a local talent pipeline.

images.alt_text: எஸ். வெங்கடேஷ்வரன்
Non-resident employment rose across all work pass types, with the bulk coming from work permit and other work passes, according to the Manpower Ministry's latest Labour Market Report.

“Hiring activity in Singapore is expected to remain brisk as employers continue to scale up their hiring to fill their backlog of vacancies,” said Linda Teo, country manager of ManpowerGroup Singapore.
Tan Ru-Ding, managing director of FlexMech, said the precision enginering sector has made significant strides in work conditions and offers lucrative career prospects now.

site_title: Singapore shares climb at Tuesday's open after Wall Street rebound; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.3% or 9.5 points to 3,265.81 at Tuesday's open, following a rebound in US stocks after a week of decline. Banking stocks, including DBS, UOB, and OCBC, led the gains. Other active index counters, such as Singapore Airlines and the Singapore Exchange, also increased. The rebound in US stocks was attributed to a technical rebound and bargain-hunting, with the Dow Jones industrial average advancing 0.6% and the Nasdaq rising 0.8%.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: Asia: Markets see rare rally but caution rules as Fed hike nears
summary: Asia's markets saw a rare rally on Tuesday, driven by Wall Street's late rally ahead of the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike this week. Investors are bracing for potential recession fears despite economic woes in Russia, China, and other countries. The Fed is expected to raise interest rates by 75 basis points, with some speculating it could reach above 4% to combat inflation. Despite the cautious mood, Asian markets were up, with Hong Kong leading the way, while the dollar remained elevated ahead of the expected rate hike.

site_title: EY’s split shows what a big business auditing has become, but maybe it shouldn’t be
summary: EY, a Big Four auditor, is splitting its auditing and consulting divisions, citing concerns over conflicts of interest. The move highlights the lucrative nature of auditing, sparking debate about whether it should be a public good. Audits primarily serve corporations, rather than the public, leading some to question the industry's purpose. The decision may be a step towards separating business interests from auditing, but a more radical solution may be needed to address the underlying issues.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah
V
EY’s official announcement on Friday (Sep 9) has confirmed what the market had been speculating for months: that it would separate into 2 distinct, multidisciplinary organisations.

site_title: Kia Corp to produce electric vehicles in the US from 2024: reports
summary: Kia Corp is expected to start producing electric vehicles in the US from 2024, according to reports citing an auto industry source. This move comes after the Inflation Reduction Act, signed by US President Joe Biden, excludes Hyundai Motor and Kia Corp from federal tax credits due to their lack of North American EV production. The decision affects Kia's short-term EV ambitions, but the company is still committed to expanding its electric vehicle offerings.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, extending US Wall Street rallies, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.81% and the Topix index advancing 0.63%. The move comes ahead of the US Federal Reserve's expected rate hike later this week.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Nikkei 225 index was up 0.81 per cent, or 222.85 points, at 27,790.50 in early trade on Tuesday.

site_title: Environmental groups ask P&G investors to vote against CEO as board chair
summary: Environmental groups, including the Natural Resources Defense Council, are urging Procter & Gamble investors to vote against re-electing CEO Jon Moeller as board chair due to the company's use of virgin wood pulp in its paper products and sourcing of palm oil from tropical rainforests. They also oppose two other directors, Angela Braly and Patricia Woertz, citing insufficient efforts to mitigate deforestation. The groups want to replace Moeller with an independent chair and push for more sustainable practices, citing regulatory changes that make it easier for activist investors to nominate their own directors.

site_title: Gold prices steady with investor focus on Fed meet
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $1,676.80 per ounce, as investors maintained a cautious stance ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy meeting, where interest rates are expected to be hiked by 75 basis points. This move is likely to increase the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion, weighing on gold prices. Despite a dip in the dollar index, a stronger US dollar makes bullion more expensive for other currency holders, limiting gold's upside potential.

images.alt_text: Gold prices weakened on Monday, hovered towards a 29-month low hit on Friday, as the US dollar and Treasury yields firmed on expectations of a hefty Fed rate hike.

site_title: Hotel operators gear up for F1, with many almost at full capacity for the race
summary: Singapore's Marina Bay area is gearing up for the return of the Singapore Grand Prix, with many hotels almost at full capacity for the 3-day event. Occupancy rates at popular hotels like Marina Bay Sands, Parkroyal Collection Marina Bay, and The Fullerton Hotel are already at peak levels, with daily rates significantly higher than usual. Tourism players expect a boost in revenue, with some hotels predicting it could even surpass pre-pandemic levels. However, some businesses, such as Sentosa 4D Adventureland, are concerned that the influx of F1 fans may deter regular tourists and expect a drop in footfall and spending.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh

For the upcoming Grand Prix, CGS-CIMB estimates that up to 35,000 tourists could make their way to Singapore’s shores, which could potentially fill 45 to 50 per cent of the island’s hotel room inventory.
SIA first signed as the title sponsor in 2014 for 4 years, and subsequently extended it in 2018 and 2020 for 2 years respectively.

site_title: Chinese banks keep lending rates unchanged after PBOC pauses
summary: Chinese banks maintained their main lending rates unchanged, with the 1-year loan prime rate at 3.65% and the 5-year rate at 4.3%, after the People's Bank of China (PBOC) paused its monetary easing. This decision comes despite economists expecting a rate cut to counter growth headwinds. The PBOC defended a weakening yuan and maintained the current rates, which were last adjusted in August. A rate cut is still expected in the coming months to address economic challenges.

site_title: Reserve Bank of Australia says hikes could slow at some point
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has reaffirmed its intention to raise interest rates to combat inflation, but sees a case for slowing the pace of hikes as rates approach normal levels. The central bank lifted its cash rate by 50 basis points to 2.35% in September, and markets expect another half-point hike in October. RBA Governor Philip Lowe has flagged the possibility of a slowdown in hikes at some point, but emphasized the importance of keeping inflation expectations anchored in a tight labor market.

images.alt_text: RBA lifted its cash rate by 50 basis points to 2.35 per cent at the Sept 6 meeting, the fifth hike in as many months for a total increase of 225 basis points.

site_title: French TV stocks slide after merger to challenge Netflix collapses
summary: French TV stocks, M6 and TF1, dropped 3.3% and 3% respectively after a merger deal to challenge US streaming services like Netflix was abandoned due to French antitrust requirements. The collapse comes as global video platforms increase their dominance, and a tie-up was seen as a way to stay competitive. Investors doubt a new suitor can be found in time, and fears about a recession in the eurozone have hit media stocks hard.

site_title: OxPay ordered to pay ex-CEO, ex-CFO for wrongful dismissal
summary: OxPay Financial, a payment services company, has been ordered by the Employment Claims Tribunal to pay its former CEO and CFO, Anthony Koh and Madeline Sam, S$77,501.52 each, following wrongful dismissal claims. The payments are for the 6-month notice period and costs incurred. OxPay had terminated the executives early, despite their notice periods, and has rejected the ECT's decision to appeal. The company has decided not to pursue further legal action and will focus on growing its businesses.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Brokers' take: KGI initiates 'outperform' on OxPay Financial on digital payment trend

site_title: Grand Theft Auto VI leak a shock to video game studio Rockstar
summary: A hacker leaked authentic, pre-release footage of Grand Theft Auto VI, a highly anticipated game from Rockstar Games, a subsidiary of Take-Two Interactive Software Inc. The leaked videos provide an early and unpolished look at the game's development, despite the final version being refined. Rockstar confirmed the hack, blaming a "network intrusion," and Take-Two shares dropped 3.3% on Monday. The leak includes plans for a playable female protagonist and a fictional Miami setting, and the hacker has hinted at negotiating a deal and publishing more internal information.

images.alt_text: Splatoon 3 is part of a strong stable of games Nintendo has lined up for the holiday period.
Technologies such as virtual reality headsets and blockchain are expected to push the boundaries of the metaverse beyond gaming.

site_title: Brokers' take: UOBKH cuts ComfortDelGro target after STI exclusion but still sees upside
summary: UOB Kay Hian (UOBKH) has lowered its price target for ComfortDelGro to S$1.63 from S$1.73 due to the exclusion from the Straits Times Index (STI). Despite this, the research house maintains a "buy" call on the transport operator, citing a gradual recovery in rail ridership and taxi passenger demand in the medium term. UOBKH believes ComfortDelGro's fundamentals remain intact, and the group remains poised for a recovery.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

site_title: Marriott coaxing workers back to office with US$600m building
summary: Marriott International has cut the ribbon on its new US$600 million high-rise headquarters near Washington, D.C., aiming to entice workers to return after over two years of remote work. The 21-story building features collaboration spaces, a child care center, and high-end amenities, with about 3,500 workers accommodated. CEO Anthony Capuano believes workers will want to return due to the need for interaction and collaboration, with most workstations shared and employees encouraged to be at the office several days a week.

site_title: Morgan Stanley’s South-east Asia M&A chief to head Raine’s South-east Asia coverage: sources
summary: US investment bank Raine Group has appointed Jonathan Pflug, Morgan Stanley's head of South-east Asia M&A, to lead its coverage in the region. Pflug, a managing director at Morgan Stanley, will join Raine early next year and launch its Singapore office to expand into the market. Raine currently has offices in Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Mumbai, specializing in media, sports, and technology deals, and has advised business moguls such as SoftBank Group CEO Masayoshi Son. The move aims to further Raine's presence in South-east Asia.

site_title: Kaisa offshore creditors offer US$2b to take over stalled projects: sources
summary: Kaisa Group, a Chinese developer, is offering US$2 billion to acquire its stalled housing projects to facilitate completion. The takeover offer, made by an offshore bondholder group, aims to provide financing and split profits with Kaisa. This move comes as authorities scramble to contain a mortgage boycott by homebuyers against stalled projects. Kaisa is restructuring its US$12 billion offshore debt and struggling to repay onshore debt, highlighting the challenges facing the Chinese property sector.

site_title: Chinese scientists develop mask that detects Covid, flu exposure
summary: Chinese scientists have developed a mask that detects Covid-19 and flu exposure, with a sensor built into the mask sending notifications to a device within 10 minutes of detecting pathogens in the air. The device was tested in an indoor setting and responded to liquid produced by a sneeze, sending alerts to wireless devices. The researchers plan to improve detection times and sensitivity, and the device is best used in enclosed spaces with high infection risk. This technology could help vulnerable populations despite declining mask use worldwide.

images.alt_text: Residents line up for another round of testing on Day 09 of city wide lockdown in Shanghai, China, on Saturday, 09 April 2022

site_title: Ford to spend US$1b more than expected on supplier costs
summary: Ford expects to spend $1 billion more on supplier costs due to inflation during the third quarter, affecting 40,000 to 45,000 vehicles in inventory lacking certain parts. The company plans to deliver these vehicles in the fourth quarter, sticking to its earnings forecast. Ford shares fell nearly 5% after the announcement, while General Motors' shares dropped 1.5% after Ford's warning. The shortage of computer chips, a critical component, has been a challenge for the auto industry since 2021.

site_title: Final farewell to Queen Elizabeth after day of solemn pageantry
summary: Queen Elizabeth II's state funeral was held on September 19, 2022, at Westminster Abbey, attended by thousands of people and world leaders. The coffin was borne on a gun carriage to St George's Chapel in Windsor Castle for interment. The ceremony featured a 2,000-strong congregation, including US President Joe Biden, and was marked by a 2-minute silence and a rendition of "God Save the King." The queen, who reigned for 70 years, was laid to rest alongside her husband Prince Philip. The funeral was a fitting end to her life, with Justin Welby praising her "abundant life and loving service."

images.alt_text: The coffin of Britain's Queen Elizabeth being borne on a gun carriage through London, from Westminster Hall, where it has lain in state for the last 4 days, to Westminster Abbey for the funeral service.

Police officers patrolling outside Westminster Abbey in London on Monday (Sep 19), ahead of the State Funeral Service for Britain's Queen Elizabeth II.  The country's longest-serving monarch died at aged 96 after 70 years on the throne.
Having waited longer than any other heir to become king, Charles carved out a role for himself speaking out on issues from climate change to architecture and alternative medicine.

site_title: Swiss farmers cook up world's biggest rosti
summary: Swiss farmers have set a new record for the world's largest rosti, a traditional Swiss potato fritter, at a size of 13.7 sq m in Bern. The record beats the previous one set in 1994 and was achieved as part of the Swiss farmer's union's 125th anniversary celebrations. The pan was shaped like a cross and served to a large crowd, symbolizing unity and overcoming the cultural divide between Switzerland's German and French-speaking regions.

site_title: UAE accelerates plan to increase its oil production capacity
summary: The United Arab Emirates (UAE) is accelerating its plan to increase its oil production capacity to 5 million barrels per day by 2025, ahead of its previously disclosed goal of 2030. State-owned Abu Dhabi National Oil Co (Adnoc) aims to reach this target by raising long-term production levels by 10% or more with international partners. The move is seen as a response to high oil prices and the UAE's efforts to cash in on its crude reserves before the world transitions to cleaner energy.

images.alt_text: Oil tanks inside Fujairah port in Fujairah, United Arab Emirates. High oil prices and increased production have been a boon for the UAE’s economy this year, along with a continued recovery from the pandemic’s impact.
Oil tanks and pipes at Saudi Aramco's Ras Tanura oil refinery and oil terminal. With their outsize production and reserves, such state-owned oil giants hold the key to the world's energy transition.
Emirati exports to Indonesia are mostly petroleum gases and non-crude oils, iron and non-alloy steel, according to the Observatory of Economic Complexity.

site_title: Gold prices will fluctuate but unlikely to dip below US$1,500: traders
summary: Gold prices fell on Monday due to a stronger US dollar, driven by investors' anticipation of potential interest rate hikes by the Fed and other central banks to combat inflation. Traders predict that gold prices will continue to fluctuate but are unlikely to drop below $1,500 per ounce.

images.alt_text: Gold is known as a safe investment amid inflation woes, but high interest rates increase the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion.
"We will continue to diversify our product offerings because it’s all a part of democratizing investing," said Bursa Malaysia CEO Muhamad Umar Swift

site_title: US approves new American Airlines, JetBlue flights to Havana
summary: The US has approved new flights to Havana, with American Airlines adding 13 weekly departures from Miami and a weekly JetBlue departure from Fort Lauderdale, Florida, by mid-December. This expansion builds on the lifting of restrictions in June, which allowed US airline flights to smaller Cuban airports. The move aims to enhance service and access between the US and Cuba, reversing a two-year suspension under the Trump administration. The decision is seen as a support for the Cuban people and in line with US foreign policy interests.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower on worries over big rate hikes
summary: US stocks opened lower on Monday, extending declines for a third straight session, amid worries that a big interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve could tip the US economy into recession. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 99.56 points, or 0.32%, to 30,722.86, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. The declines follow recent rate hike concerns and signal a cautious market ahead of the Fed's next decision.

images.alt_text: A trader works on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., September 13, 2022. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly

site_title: Google faces pressure in India to help curb illegal lending apps: sources
summary: Google faces pressure from the Indian government and the Reserve Bank of India to introduce stricter checks on illegal digital lending applications in the country. The central bank has asked Google to curb the proliferation of apps that charge excessive interest rates and engage in unauthorised recovery practices. Google has already removed over 2,000 personal loan apps from the Play Store for violating its policies. The company is also introducing new advertising policies to verify advertisers, with the goal of weeding out illegal lending apps.

site_title: US dollar firm as Fed headlines big week for central banks
summary: The US dollar index rose 0.4% to 110.06, nearing a 20-year high of 110.79, ahead of a Federal Reserve meeting expected to deliver another rate hike to combat high inflation. Markets remained cautious, with world stocks on edge, despite the dollar's firm tone. The rate hike is part of the Fed's aggressive monetary policy to contain inflation, which has been uncomfortably high.

site_title: US home builder sentiment falls for ninth straight month: NAHB
summary: US homebuilder sentiment has fallen for the ninth straight month, with the National Association of Home Builders (NAHB)/Wells Fargo Housing Market index dropping to 46. Soaring mortgage rates and high building material prices have made new housing less affordable for first-time buyers. The Federal Reserve's monetary policy tightening has had a significant impact on the housing market, while demand remains strong in the labor and consumer spending markets. The NAHB noted that buyer traffic is weak and 24% of builders have reduced home prices.

site_title: Huawei aims to have its Cloud services in 170 countries by year’s-end
summary: Huawei aims to provide cloud services to over 170 countries by the end of 2022, with rotating chairman Ken Hu stating "there's no question that the cloud is the way of the future." The company plans to launch new cloud regions in Indonesia and Ireland, and has already deployed services in 29 regions and 75 availability zones across more than 170 countries. Despite facing US trade restrictions, Huawei sees growth opportunities in the Asia-Pacific region, where it aims to contribute to the digital economy and sustainable development efforts.

images.alt_text: “With survival the main principle, marginal businesses will be shrunken and closed, and the chill will be felt by everyone,” Huawei's founder Ren Zhengfei wrote in an email to staff on Monday, the financial news outlet Yicai reported.
The FCC has been auctioning spectrum in recent years to help address the rising demand for wireless connectivity as the number of internet-connected devices rises sharply.

site_title: ECB to buy fewer bonds from polluting companies
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has announced plans to tilt its purchases of corporate bonds towards companies with lower carbon emissions, using a climate score to guide its decisions. Starting next month, the ECB will consider a company's past emissions, emission reduction goals, and climate disclosures when choosing which bonds to buy. However, the bank will not sell or exclude issuers with low climate scores and will not disclose the assigned scores. The move aims to reduce the euro system's exposure to climate-related financial risk and support the green transition of the economy.

images.alt_text: The cost of borrowing cash against German government bonds in repo markets has only climbed 57 basis points since the ECB’s decision to raise rates by 75 basis points last week.
Repo market pricing is still choppy as markets adjust to the ECB’s changes, but already the reaction looks different to that seen following the previous 50 basis-point hike in July.

site_title: Singapore stock market starts trading week with 0.4% loss
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.4% to close at 3,256.31 on Monday, following last week's rout. The decline was attributed to investor concerns over the US Federal Reserve's potential 75 basis point rate hike this week, with other Asian markets also experiencing losses. The Bank of England is expected to follow with a 0.5% rate hike on Tuesday.

images.alt_text: Singapore stocks end flat amid concerns over more rate hikes

site_title: WeLab and Astra complete acquisition of Indonesian bank for US$510m
summary: WeLab and Astra International have completed the acquisition of Indonesian commercial bank Bank Jasa Jakarta for US$510 million. The digital banking company, with plans to transform BJJ into a digital bank, will serve the 77% of Indonesia's underbanked population. WeLab and Astra each hold 49.56% of BJJ, following the completion of the transaction. This deal is part of a growing trend in fintech investments in Indonesia, with other companies such as Sea and Funding Societies also expanding their presence in the country.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Shopee's parent company Sea is taking cost-cutting measures amid uncertain macroeconomic conditions. The e-commerce platform is set to lay off more employees. Oxley Garden has relaunched for sale at S$200 million, unchanged from its earlier price. Weak market sentiment is driving shareholders to privatize Singapore-listed companies, with 10 deals announced this year. Singapore's debt market saw a 8% growth in 2021, reaching S$523 billion. The Singapore stock market started trading the week with a 0.4% loss, amid concerns of another US rate hike.

site_title: China plans easier border entry rules for some foreign tourists
summary: China has introduced draft rules allowing travel groups organized by tour agencies to choose their port of entry and exit "flexibly" in border areas. This move aims to make it easier for foreign tourists to visit Chinese tourism sites along the border. The rules, part of a gradual relaxation of border restrictions, come after China has allowed specific groups of foreign nationals to enter the country, such as those holding certain work visas. China shares a border with over 10 countries and has seen imported cases of Covid-19 linked to overland crossings.

site_title: Bursa Malaysia to launch new platform for ‘debt asset class’: CEO
summary: Bursa Malaysia, the operator of the Malaysian stock exchange, plans to launch a new platform for raising funds via rated debt, targeting large SMEs and smaller listed companies. The platform aims to "democratize investing" and provide a B2B funding option. CEO Muhamad Umar Swift emphasized the platform's unique features, such as being rated and non-fungible compared to traditional corporate bonds. The platform is expected to be launched in 2024, as part of Bursa's goal to expand its product offerings and become a multi-faceted exchange.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
Muhamad Umar Swift, chief executive officer, Bursa Malaysia

Bursa Malaysia chairman Wahid Omar said a diversified economic structure with less dependence on commodities as well as pragmatic and responsive policies have helped Malaysia to mitigate recession risks.

site_title: Ralph Lauren sees faster growth on pricing, new customers
summary: Ralph Lauren is targeting mid-to-high single-digit sales growth over the next three years, exceeding Wall Street's estimates, as the fashion brand aims to pick up new customers and raise prices. CEO Patrice Louvet plans to achieve this through pricing increases, reduced promotions, and expanding its online presence, particularly among younger customers. The company also expects to boost its operating margin to at least 15% by 2025 and open several hundred new stores globally, mainly in China, South Korea, and Japan.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians pass the Ralph Lauren store in downtown Chicago, IL on Monday October 30, 2017. Photographer: Christopher Dilts/Bloomberg *** Local Caption ***

site_title: Singaporeans most worried about finances in SEA amid rising costs: UOB study
summary: Singaporeans are the most finance-conscious in the South-east Asian region, with 66% meaningfully concerned about finances, surpassing the regional average of 55%. The main worries include rising household expenses, long-term financial commitments, decline in savings, and inflation.
