Experts attribute this to Singapore's high income, compact economy, and external uncertainties. Despite concerns, economists remain optimistic about retail consumption and corporate spending, citing factors such as the strong Singapore dollar and growing economy.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun

RHB was largely optimistic on giant consumer names in the region, including Singapore’s Sheng Siong, Kimly and Food Empire; Indonesia’s Mitra Adiperkasa (MAPI) and Indofood CBP; Malaysia’s Nestle, QL Resources, Farm Fresh and Power Root; and Thailand’s Central Retail Corporation (CRC).
South-east Asia's favourable climate and fertile soil make it a major crop grower. The region is home to key producers of  palm oil, rice and dried beans.
Thailand announced in late August that the national daily minimum wage would go up by an average of 5 per cent from October – the first such increase since January 2020.

site_title: Tesla completes production capacity expansion at Shanghai plant: Shanghai government
summary: Tesla has completed the production capacity expansion at its Shanghai plant, according to the Shanghai government. The project, valued at up to 1.2 billion yuan, aims to increase production to 22,000 units per week. The plant will test the upgraded production lines from September 19 to November 30. The expansion is expected to employ 4,000 more people at the site, with the project originally planned to be finished in April.

site_title: Bluebird’s gene therapy for brain disease receives accelerated approval
summary: Bluebird Bio's gene therapy, eli-cel, has received accelerated approval from US regulators for treating cerebral adrenoleukodystrophy, a rare genetic condition affecting young boys. The one-time treatment, Skysona, costs $3 million and will be sold under this name. The approval allows Bluebird to introduce the treatment, but it must provide long-term data to prove its benefit. Bluebird's shares rose 6.8% in premarket trading following the announcement.

images.alt_text: The FDA warned of a potential risk of blood cancer with the treatment but noted studies had no such cases.

site_title: Singapore court rejects appeal to gain control of US$1.5b sustainable development fund
summary: A Singaporean court has rejected an appeal to gain control of a $1.5 billion sustainable development fund, dealing a blow to a 3-decade-long lawsuit. The fund, held by PNG Sustainable Development Program, was meant to promote sustainable development in Papua New Guinea. The plaintiffs, representing 150,000 people affected by environmental damage, alleged PNG owed a fiduciary duty and sought to have the fund paid over entirely to them. The court ruled that the plaintiffs failed to make their case and that PNG did not owe them a legal duty, upholding an earlier decision to strike out the claims.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah
Asia’s green bond issuers look past pricing to branding and investor access

site_title: Chinese crypto tycoon-backed Bitdeer buys Asia’s ‘Fort Knox’
summary: Chinese crypto billionaire Wu Jihan's Bitdeer Technologies spent $28.4 million acquiring Le Freeport, a maximum-security vault in Singapore, dubbed Asia's Fort Knox. The vault, which stores fine art, precious gems, and gold and silver bars, was sold by shareholders led by Swiss art dealer Yves Bouvier after years of failed attempts to sell. Wu's acquisition marks his expansion into the physical asset space and follows his relinquishment of control of Beijing-based company Bitmain Technologies.

site_title: Yanlord unit’s consortium wins Lentor Central residential site tender for S$481m
summary: Yanlord Land Group's indirect subsidiary, UED Alpha, has won a tender for a residential site at Lentor Central in Singapore with a bid price of S$481 million. The site, covering 144,714 square feet, will be developed into a 470-unit residential project. The winning consortium, which includes Forsea Residence and Soilbuild Group Holdings, plans to build the development within the new Lentor Hills estate, with a maximum permissible gross floor area of about 434,140 sq ft.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: Apple flexes muscle as quiet power behind app developer group
summary: Apple's tech giant exerts significant influence over the App Association (ACT), a group representing thousands of app developers worldwide. Despite ACT claiming to be independent, the organization derives over half of its funding from Apple, with former employees suggesting the actual percentage is much higher. ACT's policy positions closely align with Apple's, even when at odds with app developers, fueling criticism that the group is "beholden" to the company. ACT opposes proposed antitrust legislation aimed at loosening Apple's grip on the App Store, echoing Apple's stance.

images.alt_text: The iPhone 14 lineup reserves the best features for the high-end Pro models costing at least US$1,000.
The A17 will be used in the premium entry in the iPhone lineup slated for release in 2023.
At its biggest product launch of the year, Apple introduced the iPhone 14, fresh AirPods Pro earbuds and new Apple Watch models.

site_title: Westminster Abbey: A millennium entwined with royalty
summary: Queen Elizabeth II's funeral took place at Westminster Abbey, a site paramount for the British royal family for nearly a millennium. The abbey has hosted 38 coronation ceremonies and royal weddings, including Queen Elizabeth's own wedding in 1947 and her sister Princess Margaret's wedding in 1943. Notable burials include 30 kings and queens, as well as famous figures such as Charles Dickens and Stephen Hawking. The abbey, a "royal peculiar," is exempt from ecclesiastical jurisdiction and can seat around 2,200 people, with the royal family sitting closest to the coffin.

images.alt_text: The queen’s death on Sep 8 aged 96, after a record-breaking 70 years on the throne, has sparked an outpouring of emotion.
Mourners file past the coffin of Queen Elizabeth lying in state at Westminster Hall in London, Britain Sept 14, 2022.
Queen Elizabeth represents a figure of significant continuity during a seven-decade period when the world has been transformed.

site_title: Park Hotel CQ paying out dividend to settle preferential claims
summary: Park Hotel CQ, a unit in liquidation owing S$6.3 million to creditors, is paying out an interim dividend of 100% to its preferential claimants starting September 12. This move settles preferential claims amid the liquidation process, which was approved by the High Court in November last year.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

In July 2021, PHMPL was ordered by the High Court to be wound up. It is the sole parent of the former operators of the Grand Park Orchard and Park Hotel Clarke Quay hotels, which were unable to pay their debts.
On Nov 19, 2021, the High Court ruled that PHCQ could be wound up after it was unable to pay its debts amounting to some S$6.3 million.

site_title: Sun Life Singapore, Community Chest work together to advocate philanthropic giving
summary: Sun Life Singapore has signed an MOU with Community Chest to support charities and philanthropic giving in the community. The agreement includes a 5-year donation of S$500,000 to local non-profits and aims to promote philanthropic giving among high-net-worth individuals. The partnership will also guide content-driven conversations to build a knowledge base for clients and partners. The collaboration is part of Sun Life's new CSR strategy and will work to elevate awareness of philanthropic giving in Singapore.

site_title:
Delistings : Adapt to market’s needs and raise the
governance bar
summary: The Singapore Exchange has taken steps to address the trend of delistings in the market, including allowing dual-class capital structures and SPACs. In recent years, several companies have been delisted due to low valuations, poor liquidity, and high costs of remaining listed. This trend is not unique to Singapore, with 47 US companies delisting in 2021 and 26 firms worth US$121b delisting since the start of 2022. Regulators should adapt to the market's needs and raise the governance bar to prevent the "hollowing out" of the market, which can lead to a vicious cycle of decreased research coverage, lower liquidity, and increased delistings.

images.alt_text: Moya Asia said the privatisation offer would provide an opportunity for shareholders to realise their investments amidst low trading liquidity, allow for greater management flexibility and save costs of maintaining listing.
Intercontinental Hotel Singapore, a portfolio property within Frasers Hospitality Trust.

site_title: Build more exec condos and expand the pool of eligible buyers
summary: Singapore's executive condominium (EC) market is experiencing growth, with a top bid of S$336 million for a Bukit Batok West Avenue 5 site. The government can increase the supply of EC sites to meet rising household formation and demand for condominiums. Expanding the pool of eligible buyers, particularly singles under 35, and increasing the income ceiling could also help more people enter private homeownership. This could alleviate pressure on the Housing and Development Board (HDB) to build more flats, and provide more affordable housing options for citizens.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee

krtender13 - Land parcel along Lentor Central. URA tender for this site closes on September 13, 2022.



Source: URA
Artist's impression of Sky Eden@Bedok. Close to 75 per cent of its residential units were sold on the first day of the project's launch.

site_title: Leaders and monarchs gather for final farewell to Queen Elizabeth
summary: Leaders and monarchs from around the world gathered in London to bid farewell to Queen Elizabeth II at a state funeral, marking the end of her 70-year reign. The 96-year-old monarch died on September 8 at her Scottish summer home, Balmoral Castle. US President Joe Biden paid tribute to the queen, praising her service to her country. The funeral procession will include dignitaries, world leaders, and members of the royal family, culminating in a service at Westminster Abbey and a private burial at Windsor Castle. The queen's coffin will be lowered into the royal vault after a 2.4 km procession through central London.

images.alt_text: The coffin of Britain's Queen Elizabeth is carried on the day of her state funeral and burial, in London, Britain, September 19, 2022.  REUTERS/Hannah McKay/Pool

A new  image released by Buckingham Palace on September 18, 2022, shows Britain's Queen Elizabeth II smiling, photographed at Windsor Castle in May 2022. Huge crowds built in central London from early morning on September 19, 2022, to secure a spot to watch the state funeral of Queen Elizabeth II at Westminster Abbey.

Police officers patrolling outside Westminster Abbey in London on Monday (Sep 19), ahead of the State Funeral Service for Britain's Queen Elizabeth II.  The country's longest-serving monarch died at aged 96 after 70 years on the throne.
The queen’s death on Sep 8 aged 96, after a record-breaking 70 years on the throne, has sparked an outpouring of emotion.

site_title: The quality that sustained Queen Elizabeth is hobbling Putin
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin's war in Ukraine is hindered by his regime's lack of legitimacy, a quality sustained by Queen Elizabeth II's pre-modern, pre-democratic legitimacy. Unlike Putin, Elizabeth II retained a divine anointing and ancient oath, giving her power a mystical quality that grounds authority. Putin, lacking this, relies on personal power and repression, but his system is a polyglot imperium with no deep legitimating structures. His regime's weakness is exposed in the face of crisis, where he cannot mobilize the Russian people or justify power through democratic means, unlike his predecessors.

images.alt_text: A handout image released by Buckingham Palace on September 18, 2022, shows Britain's Queen Elizabeth II smiling, photographed at Windsor Castle in May 2022. - Huge crowds built in central London from early morning on on September 19, 2022, to secure a spot to watch the state funeral of Queen Elizabeth II at Westminster Abbey. site_title: Woman King rules North American box office
summary: The Woman King, starring Viola Davis as a fierce African warrior general, topped the North American box office with an estimated $19 million, more than tripling the ticket sales of the next-highest film, Barbarian. The film, based on a true historical episode, received a favorable critical reception, exceeding analysts' expectations. It follows the story of an all-female army protecting the 18th-century kingdom of Dahomey.

images.alt_text: In third place, down 1 spot from last weekend, was Sony action thriller Bullet Train, at US$3.3 million. Brad Pitt stars as a paid killer on a high-speed Japanese train.
US actor Brad Pitt at the premiere of the movie Bullet Train at the Regency Village Theater in Los Angeles on Aug 1.
Moroccan fashion designer Artsi Ifrach and his creation A Dialogue Between Cultures at the Africa Fashion exhibition.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Monday, down 15.79 points to 1,451.52. The index saw 2.185 billion lots traded worth RM1.763 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 706 to 217. This marks a decline in market sentiment, but global stocks continued to edge towards fresh records despite US-EU trade uncertainty and tariff concerns.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end at 2-month low ahead of US Fed meet
summary: South Korea's benchmark Kospi index fell 1.14% to 2,355.66, its lowest close in over 2 months, ahead of the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting. Investors are cautious, expecting another 75 basis point rate hike, which may lead to downgraded growth outlook and fading hopes for rate cuts next year. The won weakened, and bond yields rose, with the 10-year yield climbing 4 basis points to 3.812%. Only 143 shares advanced, with Samsung Electronics rising 0.36% and SK Hynix falling 1.32%.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi index closed down 19.05 points or 0.79 per cent at 2,382.78, extending losses to a third session and posting a fifth weekly loss of 0.06 per cent.

site_title: Europe: Stocks open lower ahead of Fed rate call
summary: European stocks opened lower on September 19, 2022, ahead of a US Federal Reserve interest rate decision, with investors fearing another rate hike that could spark a recession. The Frankfurt DAX fell 0.6% and the Paris CAC 40 shed 1.2%. The London FTSE 100 was closed for the funeral of Queen Elizabeth II.

site_title: More can be done by listed issuers to engage shareholders
summary: Listed companies can enhance their corporate image by engaging shareholders more actively. Straits Trading's initiatives, such as its Shareholders' Club, demonstrate a positive approach. In contrast, many CEOs view their responsibilities as fulfilled by paying dividends, rather than actively involving shareholders. The article suggests that companies like Straits Trading can set an example by sharing their strategies and insights with shareholders, particularly in situations where the share price is trading below book value.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start week with loss
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the week with a loss, falling 1.04% to 18,565.97, as investors prepare for the Federal Reserve's meeting where another interest rate hike is expected. This sell-off is in line with a broader Asia-wide decline. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also fell, with the Shanghai Composite Index dropping 0.35% and the Shenzhen Composite Index losing 0.76%. The decline is attributed to concerns over interest rate hikes and their impact on the global economy.

site_title: When diversity isn’t the right kind of diversity
summary: Liz Truss, the new Conservative prime minister of Britain, announced her Cabinet, marking a historic first with a diverse lineup, featuring no white men in key positions. Notable appointments include Suella Braverman, home secretary, and Kwasi Kwarteng, chancellor of the Exchequer, both of whom are from diverse ethnic backgrounds, reflecting a shift towards greater representation in British politics. This move is seen as a significant step towards promoting diversity and inclusion in the government.

images.alt_text: “The conversation around women and leadership was really dominated by bias and discrimination,” gender researcher Leah Sheppard says. “We thought that there was a place to talk about women’s agency: Are women actually intending to pursue these positions as much as men?”

site_title: Sri Lanka to present debt restructuring, IMF bailout plans to creditors
summary: Sri Lanka will present its debt restructuring and International Monetary Fund (IMF) bailout plans to international creditors on September 23. The country's economic crisis, caused by years of mismanagement and the Covid-19 pandemic, has led to a default on sovereign debt and a need for a multi-billion dollar bailout. Sri Lanka's new president, Ranil Wickremesinghe, has reached a preliminary deal with the IMF for a $2.9 billion loan over 4 years, but faces challenges in accepting the deal from the impoverished population and finding common ground with creditors from China, India, and Japan.

images.alt_text: The economic meltdown, the most dire in its independent history, spiralled into political chaos that led to a formation of a new government.

site_title: Making sense of the crypto crisis: Boon or bane for financial system?
summary: A small allocation of Bitcoin (0.5-1%) to portfolios may improve risk-adjusted returns, but benefits diminish with higher allocations. Digital assets' valuation peaked in November 2021, reaching a $3 trillion market capitalization, but has faced significant headwinds this year, resulting in the largest ever value destruction. The crisis highlights the need to reassess the impact of digital assets on the financial system, particularly given their potential to revolutionize the global financial system. The outcome of this crisis remains uncertain, and its effects on the financial system are still to be fully understood.

images.alt_text: Ethereum used to be secured by a network of high-powered computers that competed against one another to solve cryptographic puzzles, burning vast amounts of energy in the process. Now, it will be secured by a process known as “staking”, which involves investors agreeing to deposit their crypto coins in a shared pool in exchange for a chance to earn financial rewards.
Investors are bracing for volatility from the jumbo interest-rate hike expected this week from the Federal Reserve to fight price pressures.

site_title: SoftBank-backed Oyo seeks to resurrect IPO as growth resumes
summary: Oyo Hotels, backed by SoftBank, is targeting an initial public offering (IPO) in early 2023 after cost cuts and a recovery in travel helped reduce losses. The company filed fresh financial documents, showing narrower losses and a rebound in sales for the year through March 2022 and the following 3 months. Oyo had previously shelved its IPO plans in 2021 due to the pandemic, but is now internally working towards a January IPO.

site_title: Retire well in a high-inflation, high-interest rate environment
summary: In a high-inflation, high-interest rate environment, structuring retirement savings into "buckets" and investing according to when funds are needed can help mitigate risks. Experts recommend dividing retirement savings into income-generating assets for essential expenses and investment-grade assets for discretionary spending. A case study illustrates how allocating assets into buckets can mitigate risks such as longevity, inflation, healthcare, investment, and overspending risks. By structuring retirement plans effectively, individuals can ensure a reliable stream of income and mitigate the impact of market volatility.

images.alt_text: DBS, UOB and OCBC ATMs at the Singapore Institute of Management (SIM) on March 12, 2020.##########banks##########CHONG JUN LIANG

site_title: China to accelerate projects, boost consumption to spur recovery
summary: China's state planner announced plans to accelerate fund injections to expedite project construction and boost domestic consumption, amid a slowing economy. The economy showed surprising resilience in August with faster-than-expected growth in factory output and retail sales, but a deepening property crisis remains a concern. China's cabinet has rolled out measures since late May to bolster the Covid-ravaged economy, and policymakers are under pressure to address the economic slowdown.

images.alt_text: A worker welds at the top of skyscraper Xiamen International Centre under construction in Xiamen, Fujian province, China December 23, 2017. Picture taken December 23, 2017. REUTERS/Stringer

site_title: Bitcoin sinks close to lowest level since 2020 on pre-Fed nerves
summary: Bitcoin dropped 6.7% to $18,500, nearing its lowest level since 2020, ahead of a Federal Reserve interest-rate hike. Global markets are bracing for monetary tightening, with US equity futures in the red and a dollar gauge rising. Cryptocurrencies like Ether, XRP, and Polkadot also experienced significant losses. Investors are concerned about the impact of inflation on the market, with some predicting that macroeconomic factors will outweigh other considerations.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Representations of cryptocurrency Bitcoin are seen in this illustration, August 10, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Biden: US would defend Taiwan from ‘unprecedented attack’
summary: US President Joe Biden has reaffirmed that the US would defend Taiwan from an "unprecedented attack" if it were to occur, despite maintaining the "One China" policy and avoiding formal recognition of the government in Taipei. This pledge comes as tensions between the US and China over Taiwan continue to escalate, with China lodging "stern representations" with the US following Biden's remarks. The US official stated that US policy hasn't changed, but the statement may add uncertainty to Washington's long-standing policy of "strategic ambiguity" toward Taiwan.

images.alt_text: Taiwan Premier Su Tseng-chang (C) told reporters Taiwan had repeatedly issued warnings and asked China “not to encroach on our doorstep”.
Chinese military helicopters fly past Pingtan island, one of mainland China's closest point from Taiwan, in Fujian province on August 4, 2022, ahead of massive military drills off Taiwan.

Taiwan is determined to defend itself and invaders will incur a “heavy price”, President Tsai Ing-wen said on Tuesday(Aug  23) on the anniversary of a confrontation six decade ago in which Taiwanese forces beat back Chinese attackers.

site_title: Total outstanding debt arranged locally grows by 8%: MAS
summary: Singapore's debt market saw steady growth in 2021, with total outstanding debt arranged by financial institutions rising 8% to S$523 billion, and new debt issuance increasing 4% to S$232 billion. Singapore-denominated issuance volume reached a 9-year high at S$30 billion, with corporate issuers accounting for 58.9% of the market. Non-Singapore dollar long-term debt remained the majority, valued at around S$297 billion. Experts expect a "flight to stability" in the market amid a volatile environment, with low interest rates and a focus on financing for a low-carbon future driving growth.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Yong Hui Ting
Unemployment among people in China aged 16 to 24 stands at almost 19 per cent, after hitting a record 20 per cent in July, according to government data.
India and Indonesia recorded net foreign bond inflows in August, their first addition in at least 6 months, while global funds poured into Thai debt for the first time since May.

site_title: Oxley Garden tries for en bloc again at unchanged S$200m price
summary: Oxley Garden, a 58,207 sq ft freehold plot in prime District 9, has been relaunched for collective sale with a minimum price of S$200 million, unchanged from the previous attempt. Over 80% of the site's owners have consented to the sale at this price, and the tender is set to close on Nov 1, 2022. The site, comprising 6 blocks of walk-up apartments, has a gross plot ratio of 1.4645 and can accommodate a total GFA of up to 93,770 sq ft.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

Trendale Tower was put up for sale in August at a guide price of S$178 million, which works out to S$2,386 per plot ratio after factoring in the seven per cent bonus gross floor area (GFA) for balconies.

This isn’t the first time Horizon Towers has been put up for sale. It launched for sale in July 2018 at a reserve price of S$1.1 billion, just a day before the Jul 6 cooling measures kicked in that year. It then went on to relaunch for sale in early 2019 at the same price but was unsuccessful.
Sitting on a 74,739 square feet site, the freehold boutique development comprises 64 units spread across a 5-storey and a 10-storey tower.
Freehold Oxley Garden apartments up for en bloc sale, asking at least S$200m

site_title: Australia property CEOs give diverging outlooks as rates rise
summary: Australia's real estate CEOs offer diverging outlooks on the industry amid rising interest rates, which drove down home prices by the most since 1983 in August. CEOs from Lendlease and Dexus express uncertainty, with Lombardo seeing positive tailwinds from returning immigration and Steinberg citing elevated uncertainty. The Reserve Bank of Australia's head of domestic markets notes considerable uncertainty about the impact of rising rates on the housing market, while household buffers remain a key point of discussion, with borrowers having the capacity to cope with higher repayments.

images.alt_text: The average home in Australia’s major cities took 31 days to sell in August, while sellers may also factor in a contract settlement time of about 6 weeks.

site_title: China central bank cuts 14-day reverse repo rate, steps up cash injections
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), cut the 14-day reverse repo rate and increased cash injections to maintain liquidity levels at the end of the quarter. The PBOC injected 2 billion yuan through 7-day reverse repos and 10 billion yuan through 14-day reverse repos, citing a need to counteract higher demand. The move aims to stabilize liquidity levels and support the economy.

images.alt_text: A man wearing a mask walks past the headquarters of the People's Bank of China, the central bank, in Beijing, China, as the country is hit by an outbreak of the new coronavirus, February 3, 2020. REUTERS/Jason Lee

site_title: Biden says Covid pandemic in US ‘is over’
summary: US President Joe Biden stated in an interview that the COVID-19 pandemic in the US is over, despite ongoing efforts to combat the virus. This declaration comes after the lifting of most Covid restrictions and a rebound in travel to pre-pandemic levels. Biden's comments differ from recent requests by his administration for billions of dollars in funding to maintain testing and vaccine programs, sparking a potential fall wave of the virus.

images.alt_text: A yearlong slump in the property market is denting demand for real estate.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower ahead of central bank meetings
summary: Australian shares closed 0.3% lower at 6,719.9, driven by weak sentiment ahead of central bank meetings, including a potential 75-basis point rate hike by the US Federal Reserve. Tech stocks declined 1.3%, while energy stocks fell 1.1%, despite rising oil prices. The Reserve Bank of Australia may hike rates to contain inflation, putting pressure on the Aussie market.

images.alt_text: A man stands in front of an electronic board displaying stock information inside the Australian Securities Exchange, operated by ASX Ltd., in Sydney, Australia, on Monday, Sept. 9, 2013. The Australian dollar's strongest weekly advance since December 2011 is a reminder to Prime Minister-Elect Tony Abbott that his plans to revive a slowing economy will be hostage to currency markets. Photographer: Brendon Thorne/Bloomberg

site_title: Typhoon batters Japan with record rain, killing 1: NHK
summary: Typhoon Nanmadol, Japan's 14th storm of the season, made landfall near Kagoshima city on Sunday and continued to batter western Japan on Monday, killing at least one person and injuring 82. The storm brought record rainfall and ferocious winds, disrupting transport and forcing manufacturers to suspend operations. Over 340,000 households lost electricity, and 800 flights were cancelled. The storm is expected to continue northeast until Tuesday before crossing overland and moving into the Pacific. Prime Minister Fumio Kishida delayed his departure to New York to monitor the storm's impact.

images.alt_text: Rescue workers including Japanese Self-Defence Force soldiers conduct search and rescue operation at a landslide site caused by Typhoon Nanmadol in Mimata town, Miyazaki Prefecture on Japan's southernmost main island of Kyushu September 19, 2022, in this photo taken by Kyodo. Mandatory credit Kyodo via REUTERS ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE WAS PROVIDED BY A THIRD PARTY. MANDATORY CREDIT. JAPAN OUT. NO COMMERCIAL OR EDITORIAL SALES IN JAPAN

site_title: Taiwan August export orders likely contract as demand eases
summary: Taiwan's export orders are expected to contract for a second straight month in August, with a median forecast of a 2% decline from a year earlier. This follows a 1.9% drop in July, attributed to weakening demand for technology and economic troubles in China. The contraction is a sign of cooling global demand, affecting the island's manufacturers, including Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co, which are key to the global supply chain for technology giants like Apple. The data is set to be released on Tuesday.

site_title: China’s mortgage boycott quietly regroups as construction idles
summary: China's mortgage boycott, sparked by stalled construction on properties, has quietly regrouped with at least 100 cities threatening to halt mortgage payments. Homebuyers, frustrated by lack of progress, plan to stop paying mortgages if construction doesn't resume, despite authorities offering loan payment holidays and pledges to expedite construction. The boycott has expanded to 342 projects, with 2.3 trillion yuan (S$46 billion) worth of loans at stake. Beijing has set up a bailout fund, but experts say it may take time for the funds to make a difference.

images.alt_text: The shift would signal a sea change from decades of Chinese consumers putting their money into real estate as the surest way to grow their wealth.

FILE PHOTO: Cars travel down a road between blocks of 45-year-old residential flats (L) and the latest luxury homes (R) near the construction site for a high-speed railway, in West Kowloon, Hong Kong, China July 2, 2015. Hong Kong's new home sales jumped to a record high in the first half of the year, driven in part by the return of Chinese investors seeking to park money in million-dollar mansions, underscoring the challenges the government faces in curbing property prices.   REUTERS/Bobby Yip/File Photo
The Hang Seng Mainland Properties Index in Hong Kong jumped more than 5 per cent in morning trading, while China’s CSI Real Estate Index rose more than 4 per cent.

site_title: South Korea banks told to report FX positions each hour, Daily reports
summary: South Korean authorities are boosting market oversight after the won dropped to 1,399.95, its weakest level since March 2009. As part of the efforts, banks are required to report foreign-exchange-related positions every hour, up from a previous three times a day. The move aims to strengthen monitoring of the currency market amid the weakened currency. The government's actions follow the won's significant drop, prompting increased scrutiny of market activities.

site_title: The US$300bn Google-Meta advertising duopoly is under attack
summary: The US$300 billion Google-Meta advertising duopoly is facing significant challenges as digital advertising enters a period of transformation. The pair's dominance is threatened by powerful new rivals, including TikTok, Amazon, Microsoft, and Apple. Despite Meta's first-ever year-on-year decline in revenues and Snap's workforce layoffs, digital ad sales are expected to increase. The shift to targeted ads, changes in app-tracking transparency, and the rise of audio and video streaming will favor new challengers, with Amazon potentially overtaking Meta in total advertising revenue within five years.

images.alt_text: Netflix, as with other household tech names, redefined the industry years ago when it launched its online streaming service in 2007. Can it maintain its dominance in the space it helped create?
Google’s contracts form the basis of the DOJ’s landmark antitrust lawsuit, which alleges the company has sought to maintain its online search monopoly in violation of antitrust laws.

site_title: SoftBank-backed Oyo seeks to resurrect IPO after growth resumes
summary: SoftBank-backed hotel startup Oyo is reviving plans for an initial public offering (IPO) after cost cuts and a recovery in travel helped it reduce losses. The company filed fresh financial documents and is now targeting an IPO in early 2023, with a potential valuation of $9 billion. Oyo has narrowed its losses and seen a rebound in sales, focusing on four main regions: India, Malaysia, Indonesia, and Europe. The IPO comes after a series of setbacks, including a failed IPO attempt in 2021 and the pandemic's impact on growth.

images.alt_text: Akshay Bhushan, Partner and Regional Head of Lightspeed Venture Partners
India's Oyo Hotel startup eyes US$9b IPO valuation
IPO mania gets reality check in India after a series of flops

site_title: Gold’s allure to dim in India as inflation, patchy rains bite
summary: Gold consumption in India may decline this year due to inflationary pressures and erratic monsoon rains, which could reduce farmers' incomes and their ability to buy gold. The country's biggest buyer of gold, the farm sector, is vulnerable to the impact of the monsoon, and an increase in import tax in July also reduced appetite for gold. As a result, India's gold demand is expected to be lower than the 800 tons consumed last year, according to a principal consultant at London-based Metals Focus.

images.alt_text: RBI governor Shaktikanta Das has assured the markets several times that the current account gap will be sustainable and the central bank can finance it comfortably.

site_title: Asian farmers plant to boost palm oil output, seedling shortage slows pace
summary: Asian farmers are replanting palm oil trees to boost production amid rising prices, but nurseries are struggling to keep up with demand for seedlings, potentially slowing growth and keeping prices high. The shortage could delay the industry's recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic and exacerbate global inflation. Industry officials estimate that Malaysia and Indonesia, which produce over 90% of the world's cheapest edible oil, are facing significant challenges in ramping up seedling production, with demand surging 30% in the first half of 2022.

images.alt_text: India and Indonesia recorded net foreign bond inflows in August, their first addition in at least 6 months, while global funds poured into Thai debt for the first time since May.
Travel restrictions enacted in 2020 to fight the Covid-19 pandemic left the Malaysian palm oil industry short of 120,000 foreign workers needed to maintain trees and harvest fruit bunches.

site_title: Australian energy giant dumps major fracking project
summary: Australian energy giant Origin Energy is selling its stake in the Beetaloo Basin fracking project to Tamboran Resources for US$60 million. The move comes amid criticism from environmental and Indigenous groups. Origin Energy expects to take a post-tax loss of up to A$90 million from the deal. CEO Frank Calabria frames the decision as part of the company's transition to renewable energy, but notes that gas will remain a core part of the business.

images.alt_text: The Strive US Energy ETF aims to encourage more oil drilling.

The push to shore up coal power – which still makes up most of China’s energy supply – has alarmed analysts who warn that it will make an eventual transition to a renewables-dominated energy mix more difficult.

Human activity since the Industrial Revolution, largely powered by coal, oil and gas, has led to just under 1.2 deg C of warming and brought with it ever fiercer droughts, floods and storms supercharged by rising seas.

site_title: Oil prices climb on weak dollar, supply concerns
summary: Oil prices rose 0.7% to $91.95 a barrel on Monday, driven by a weaker dollar and supply concerns ahead of the European Union's December embargo on Russian oil. US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 0.5% to $85.50 a barrel. Despite fears of a global recession, the market was supported by a weaker US dollar and easing Covid-19 restrictions in China, which could provide some optimism. Supply disruptions remain a risk, but Kuwait Petroleum Corporation's CEO said customers still demand the same volumes.

images.alt_text: Human activity since the Industrial Revolution, largely powered by coal, oil and gas, has led to just under 1.2 deg C of warming and brought with it ever fiercer droughts, floods and storms supercharged by rising seas.
An anti-fracking protest in Brisbane, Australia, Sept 14, 2022. Origin Energy said on Monday it would sell its stake in a major fracking project that has come under criticism.
The Global Registry of Fossil Fuels contains data for fields in 89 countries, covering 75 per cent of global production, the non-governmental organisations which developed it said.

site_title: Euro-area recession now looks almost inevitable to economists
summary: Economists predict an 80% chance of a euro-area recession in the next 12 months due to a winter energy squeeze and record-high inflation rates. The probability of 2 straight quarters of contraction has increased from 60% in a previous survey. Germany, the bloc's largest economy, is expected to shrink as early as this quarter, while households and companies are bracing for energy rationing and supply bottlenecks. Inflation is expected to peak at 9.6% in the final 3 months of the year, almost 5 times the ECB goal.

images.alt_text: German businesses contributed more than two-fifths of the money pouring into the world’s second-largest economy from Europe.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower on Monday
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.35% on Monday, extending last week's losses, amid expectations of another interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 18,695.35, while the Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.12% and the Shenzhen Composite Index dipped 0.17%. The decline follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks, which were boosted by positive GDP data.

site_title: Asia: Markets extend losses as traders brace for Federal Reserve rate hike
summary: Asian markets declined on Monday, extending losses from last week's rout, amid expectations of a potential Federal Reserve interest rate hike. The Fed is expected to announce another significant rate increase, fueling concerns of a global recession. Markets in Hong Kong, Shanghai, and other Asian cities fell, with the yen experiencing downward pressure against the dollar. Oil prices rose following news of a lifted lockdown in China, but gains were capped by recession fears.

images.alt_text: Major markets in Tokyo, Shanghai, Hong Kong and Sydney opened lower, in line with overall market sentiment ahead of a decision from the United States Federal Reserve next week.

site_title: Stagflation-free Asian markets are leaving taper tantrums behind
summary: Emerging Asian markets, including India, Indonesia, and Thailand, are experiencing a resurgence in foreign investment as they continue to outperform traditional havens like the yen and euro. Despite global economic turmoil, countries in the region have maintained fiscal prudence and managed inflation, leading to a decrease in capital outflows. Asian economies have also built up significant foreign-exchange reserves, providing a cushion against market volatility. This has led to a shift in investor sentiment, with global funds pouring into Asian debt, and some analysts predicting that emerging Asia could gain competitiveness in the coming years.

images.alt_text: Central bankers across emerging Asia have relied on reserves to protect their currencies against a resurgent dollar as aggressive Federal Reserve policy tightening spurred flows back to the US.

site_title: Strong earthquake hits south-eastern Taiwan, 146 injured
summary: A 6.8 magnitude earthquake struck south-eastern Taiwan on Sunday, causing 146 injuries and one death. The quake, with a depth of 10 km, also damaged a convenience store, derail train carriages, and trapped hundreds on mountain roads. The US Pacific Tsunami Warning Center issued a warning but later lifted it. Aftershocks continued to jolt the island, but there was no significant impact on operations at major semiconductor factories.

images.alt_text: The epicentre was at Luding, the China Earthquake Networks Centre said, a town in the mountains about 226 km southwest of Chengdu.
Early on Wednesday, China Earthquake Networks Centre recorded a magnitude 3 aftershock at the epicentre, at a depth of 12 km.
Indonesia is one of the most disaster-prone nations on Earth.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars near 2-1/2 year lows amid risk flight
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars are near 2-1/2 year lows amid rising interest rates and risk aversion. The Australian dollar fell to a 2-1/2 year trough of US$0.6670, while the New Zealand dollar sank 1.9% to US$0.5940. Central banks, including the US Federal Reserve, are expected to hike interest rates, increasing pressure on the Reserve Bank of Australia and Reserve Bank of New Zealand to follow suit. Experts predict further rate hikes, with some forecasting a peak rate of 3.85% for the Australian dollar and 4.50% for the New Zealand dollar.

images.alt_text: Expectations that Australia will avoid 2 straight quarters of contraction are reflected in a bond market where the yield curve has steepened.

RBA Assistant Governor Jonathan Kearns said the 225 basis points of rate hikes already delivered could lower Australian property prices by at least 15 per cent over a two-year period, while also cutting borrowers’ maximum loan size by around 20 per cent.

site_title: Chinese banks likely to push lending rate cuts to later in year
summary: Chinese banks are expected to maintain benchmark lending rates unchanged this week, with only one economist forecasting a 10 basis-point drop. The People's Bank of China has paused monetary easing and defended the yuan, while many economists anticipate rate cuts later in the year to stimulate the economy. A reduction in 5-year LPRs is also expected to boost mortgage demand, which has fallen off a cliff this year.

images.alt_text: In recent months, the People’s Bank of China has been cutting rates and issuing bonds to encourage banks to lend more. That seemed to have worked in August when credit growth rebounded from a record low in July.
The People’s Bank of China offered 400 billion yuan via its medium-term lending facility, matching the median forecast in a Bloomberg survey.
Authorities including the PBOC have been stepping up efforts to support a lacklustre economy hurt by the Covid-Zero policy and a worsening housing crisis.

site_title: Shopee set for another round of layoffs
summary: Shopee, an e-commerce platform, is set to undergo another round of layoffs as its parent company Sea struggles to turn profitable amid volatile market conditions. The company has informed Singapore-based staff that further cuts will be made across various teams, including human resources, marketing, and product and engineering. Shopee's parent company, Sea, has taken massive cost-cutting steps, including rescinding dozens of job offers, shutting local operations in international markets, and cutting hundreds of staff in Shanghai. CEO Forrest Li has forgoed his salary until the group reaches self-sufficiency.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Sea's e-commerce arm, Shopee was one of the bright spots in its results, reporting an improved adjusted Ebitda loss per order for Q2 2022.

site_title: Privatisation offers continue, but shareholders increasingly discerning
summary: Singapore-listed companies continue to see offers to go private as shareholders become increasingly discerning due to weak market sentiment and depressed stock valuations. Ten such deals were announced this year, with offerors hiking prices or extending deadlines to secure approvals. Shareholders are scrutinizing details and deal structures, pushing back on opportunistic offers. Experts say this trend is a positive sign, as investors are now paying closer attention to intrinsic value and future prospects, leading to better deal terms and potentially more successful privatizations.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
SMG CEO Beng Teck Liang believes that privatisation will provide greater flexibility to execute long-term investments.

Asian Corporate Advisors, acting on behalf of THC Venture, said on Friday that the offer was declared unconditional in all respects, as the offeror and its concert parties now hold more than 90 per cent of the voting rights attributable to all the shares in issue.
The update comes after 4 directors of TTJ recommended that shareholders reject the offer.
The offer price is lower than Zico Capital’s estimated value range of between S$0.37 and S$0.46.
Acra will be proposing amendments to the compulsory acquisition framework.
Intercontinental Hotel Singapore is one of the 12 properties in FHT's initial IPO portfolio.
The superior bedroom in Capri by Fraser China Square. Only 74.88 per cent of shareholder votes were cast in favour of the take-private resolution; 75 per cent is required.
Intercontinental Hotel Singapore, a portfolio property within FHT

site_title: Lululemon billionaire helps China’s Anta in consumer sales push
summary: Chip Wilson, 67, a Canadian billionaire and former Lululemon founder, is helping China's Anta Sports Products expand sales through direct-to-consumer channels. As a minority partner in the $5 billion Amer Sports Group acquisition in 2018, Wilson aims to take Amer's brands globally. He believes the company can capitalize on its winter-focused portfolio by expanding into spring and summer products, as well as women's product lines. Wilson's efforts are part of his efforts to utilize his knowledge and expertise outside of Lululemon, which he left the board in 2015.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A shopper walks out of the Lululemon Athletica store in New York, December 16, 2013.  REUTERS/Shannon Stapleton  (UNITED STATES - Tags: BUSINESS FASHION TEXTILE)/File Photo

site_title: Fossil fuel registry launched to help spot ‘stranded assets’
summary: The Global Registry of Fossil Fuels, launched by Carbon Tracker and Global Energy Monitor, contains data on over 50,000 oil and gas fields in 89 countries, covering 75% of global production. The registry provides publicly accessible data on reserves, production, and emissions, helping investors and activists identify 'stranded assets' at risk of becoming uneconomic in the low-energy transition. The database estimates that producing and burning the world's reserves would yield over 3.5 trillion tons of greenhouse gas emissions, exceeding the remaining carbon budget for a 1.5°C climate target.

images.alt_text: “The Taxonomy was supposed to help guide consumers and enable them to compare green investments,” Monique Goyens, director-general of the European Consumer Organisation (BEUC), said.
The production growth of palm oil stalled in recent years but farmers are now looking to replant or expand plantations amid rising prices.

Human activity since the Industrial Revolution, largely powered by coal, oil and gas, has led to just under 1.2 deg C of warming and brought with it ever fiercer droughts, floods and storms supercharged by rising seas.

site_title: Three key trades to watch before the Fed rate hike
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to hike interest rates for the third time, with most economists predicting a 75 basis point increase. Investors are bracing for a potential economic downturn, with the yield curve inverting, stocks experiencing losses, and the dollar strengthening. A survey found that 44% of respondents expect to sell stocks, 61% expect the dollar to gain, and 70% expect 10-year Treasury yields to rise. The Fed's aggressive rate-hike campaign is seen as a risk of triggering a recession, with many experts warning of a hard-landing scenario.

images.alt_text: The selling on US stock markets is likely to continue if the Federal Reserve follows through on the feared 1-percentage point rate hike at its next meeting next week.

site_title: Singapore dollar may become rare global winner as MAS tightens
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is expected to tighten its exchange-rate policy again next month, potentially boosting the Singapore dollar against the US dollar. Goldman Sachs, Citigroup, and MUFG Bank are bullish on the currency, predicting a gain of over 1% against the dollar. The MAS's policy tightening is aimed at controlling core inflation, which hit a 14-year high in July. However, there is still uncertainty, and the MAS may decide to keep its policy unchanged, which could put downward pressure on the currency.

images.alt_text: Singapore’s Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong expresses hope that the agreement will open up the space for fintech companies from Singapore and India to experiment and pilot innovative products and services to serve both markets.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's share prices opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 13.84 points or 0.94% to 1,453.47. The market saw 349 losers and 102 gainers, with a total volume of 253.77 million lots worth RM180.25 million.

site_title: Gold prices gain as dollar dips with Fed meet in focus
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,677.89 per ounce, supported by a weaker dollar and concerns about aggressive interest rate hikes by major central banks, including the US Federal Reserve, to combat inflation. The dollar index fell 0.2%, making bullion less expensive for overseas buyers.

images.alt_text: Gold is highly sensitive to rising US interest rates and higher yields, which increase the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion while boosting the dollar.

site_title: China Vanke unit Onewo to raise US$783m in HK’s largest IPO of 2022
summary: China Vanke's property services arm, Onewo, has launched Hong Kong's largest IPO of 2022, aiming to raise up to $783.5 million. Onewo's shares are priced between $8.46 and $52.70, valuing the company at $7 billion to $7.8 billion. The IPO is a test of investor appetite for China's cash-squeezed real estate market, which has faced numerous crises. Onewo's parent, China Vanke, is the second-largest property developer in China and has weathered the crisis better than its rivals. The IPO's success will influence other property services companies looking to raise capital.

images.alt_text: A Vanke sign is seen above workers working at the construction site of a residential building in Dalian, Liaoning province, China September 16, 2019. REUTERS/Stringer  ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE WAS PROVIDED BY A THIRD PARTY. CHINA OUT.

site_title: SGX RegCo gets tough on companies dragging feet on board renewal, executive pay disclosure
summary: Singapore's SGX RegCo is cracking down on companies that fail to disclose executive pay and limit the tenure of independent directors. The regulator plans to require companies to report director and CEO remuneration and cap independent director terms at 9 years. A review found that only 18% of companies disclosed CEO pay and 35% disclosed director remuneration. The move aims to improve transparency and address the principal-agent problem, where directors may compromise their independence for personal gain. Regulators must also ensure corporate boards are accountable and competent, and that boards cannot offload responsibilities to auditors or experts.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul
The S$12.6 million civil penalty imposed on Noble seems minuscule compared to the billions of dollars in market value that evaporated
Companies finding ways to keep long-tenured IDs on their boards even as 9-year rule comes into effect
More can be done to elicit detailed director remuneration disclosures
SGX RegCo will review market feedback before making a decision, including whether the hard tenure limit will be set at 9 years or some other number.

site_title: Australia: Mining, gold stocks support shares ahead of Federal Reserve meet
summary: Australia's shares held steady at 6743.4 points, supported by mining and gold stocks ahead of the US Federal Reserve's rate hike meeting. Mining sector majors Rio Tinto, Fortescue Metals, and BHP Group rose 0.4-0.5%, while gold stocks jumped 1%. The financial sub-index was steady, with two "Big Four" banks rising 0.3%. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index edged up 0.1%.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index closed 1.4 per cent lower at 6,747 points.

site_title: Biden says ‘remains to be seen’ if he’ll seek second term
summary: US President Joe Biden said he has not made a firm decision on whether to seek a second term in 2024, despite previously stating he would run again. In an interview, Biden stated that reelection is his intention but emphasized that it's "too early" to confirm his decision. The 80-year-old president cited his respect for fate and the unpredictability of politics. His stance leaves room for speculation about his future plans.

images.alt_text: Biden will also consider recommendations from agencies to create a federal framework to oversee non-bank payment providers.

Russian President Vladimir Putin speaks to China's President Xi Jinping during the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation (SCO) leaders' summit in Samarkand on Sept 16, 2022. US President Biden said he told Xi that violating sanctions imposed by a coalition of countries would be a “gigantic mistake.”

site_title: Stocks to watch: Straits Trading, Metis Energy, LHN, Medinex, Shanghai Turbo
summary: Key developments in Singapore's stock market include Straits Trading's A$63.5 million purchase of a 20% stake in ILP No 1 Trust, Metis Energy's A$12 million acquisition of a solar farm project, LHN Group's S$30 million purchase of a Pasir Panjang property, and Medinex's correction on its non-executive chairman's interest in an acquisition deal. Shanghai Turbo Enterprises aims to meet current liabilities through careful cash management. These moves may impact trading of the respective companies' securities.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

site_title: Australian home buyers could benefit from higher rates: RBA
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia's Assistant Governor Jonathan Kearns suggests that rising interest rates may benefit Australian home buyers by lowering property prices, resulting in lower mortgage payments. A 225 basis point rate hike could lower prices by 15% over two years, cutting borrowers' maximum loan size by 20%. While mortgage payments may be higher for two years, declines in housing prices and mortgage sizes could ultimately lead to lower mortgage payments for new borrowers.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index closed 1.4 per cent lower at 6,747 points.
RBA Governor Philip Lowe reiterated the size and timing of future rate hikes will be guided by  incoming data and the Board’s assessment of the outlook for inflation and the Australian labour market.

site_title: Gaza farmer unearths Byzantine-era mosaic
summary: A Palestinian farmer, Salman al-Nabahin, discovered a Byzantine-era mosaic floor in his olive orchard in Gaza, 6 months ago. The mosaic, featuring colorful birds and animals, was unearthed when his son accidentally hit it with an axe while digging. The Palestinian Ministry of Tourism and Antiquities confirmed the discovery, stating it includes several mosaic panels depicting social life during the Byzantine era. The discovery is significant, given Gaza's rich history as a trading spot for ancient civilizations, and international experts are collaborating with local researchers to excavate and preserve the site.

images.alt_text: Pottery vessels, dating back to the 13th century BCE during the rule of Egypt's Pharaoh Rameses II, disovered untouched in a funerary cave at the central Palmachim park area on the Mediterranean coast.

site_title: Singapore shares edge down at open on global recession fears; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.1% or 2.2 points to 3,266.09, tracking global market losses due to recession fears and rate hike worries. Gainers outnumbered losers 75 to 47, with Sembcorp Marine holding steady and Wilmar International gaining 0.3%. Banking stocks were mixed, with DBS and OCBC down 0.1% and 0.3%, respectively. The decline follows European shares' 1.6% drop on Friday, with the US Federal Reserve and Bank of England expected to raise borrowing costs this week.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
A unit of Straits Trading will spend A$63.5 million (S$60 million) to buy over a 20 per cent stake in the Australia-established ILP No 1 Trust from Canoga Industrial Investment Trust.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Certain collectibles may beat inflation (Ep 127)
summary: Wealth expert Howie Lim discusses collectibles and their potential to beat inflation. According to Credit Suisse's chief investment officer, Nannette Hechler-Fayd’herbe, certain collectibles can appreciate in value over time, offering returns greater than inflation. The key categories include art, rare books, and sports memorabilia, which tend to be less affected by inflation. However, the value of collectibles can be unpredictable, and investors should consider their passion and investment goals before investing.

images.alt_text: Howie Lim
Is art investing the best way to hedge against inflation given its stable returns and immunity to current market conditions? Correspondent Howie Lim finds out.
How the mass affluent can get bespoke financial advice which won't cost an arm and a leg.
Are cars worth investing in?

site_title: JPMorgan reduces credit to China’s Tsingshan and metal clients globally
summary: JPMorgan Chase has reduced lending to China's Tsingshan Holding Group, a top nickel producer, and cut credit to other metal clients globally following a review of risk. The move comes after a crisis on the London Metal Exchange in March when nickel prices more than doubled, forcing the exchange to halt trading and cancel billions of dollars in deals. Tsingshan has approached other brokers to increase credit lines, while JPMorgan's actions are sending a chill through the metals sector, with other banks and brokers also tightening their lending.

images.alt_text: JPMorgan entered the British market with a digital-only retail offering last year and executives have signalled their aim is to expand this to other countries.
JPMORGAN Chase president and COO Daniel Pinto expressed caution about job cuts at a conference on Tuesday.

site_title: Marina Bay Sands raises over S$4 million to benefit the community
summary: Marina Bay Sands has raised over S$4 million for the local community through various fundraising activities, including the Sands for Singapore Charity Festival. The event featured performances by local artists, a vertical marathon, and a 4km walk, with all proceeds going to over 100 social service agencies and 200 programmes through Community Chest. MBS employees contributed over 2,000 volunteer hours and donated blood to boost Singapore's blood bank supplies. The fundraising efforts, which began in August 2022, aim to empower children with special needs, youth-at-risk, adults with disabilities, and seniors in need.

images.alt_text: Resorts World Sentosa Singapore

site_title: EU confronts opponent within who’s been boosted by Putin’s oil
summary: The European Union has imposed unprecedented penalties on Hungary, triggering a process that may withhold 7.5 billion euros unless the country takes steps to curb fraud and corruption. The move comes amid energy shortages and Russia's invasion of Ukraine, which has put Hungary's pro-Putin stance in a new light. The EU has long struggled to address Hungary's democratic backsliding under Prime Minister Viktor Orban, who has rewritten the constitution and extended government influence over institutions. The EU's concerns include irregularities in public procurement, conflicts of interest, and the independence of the judiciary, with a final decision due within a month.

images.alt_text: Companies could save as much as 290 billion euros annually in cyber incidents versus compliance costs of about 29 billion euros, the EU executive said.
Other steps laid out by von der Leyen include rationing energy, temporary state aid and decoupling the prices of gas and electricity.

site_title: Market players welcome move to tighten standards on sustainability-linked bonds
summary: Market players welcome the Climate Bond Initiative's plan to expand its certification scheme to sustainability-linked bonds, which will tighten market standards. However, the adoption of the certification remains uncertain. Sustainability-linked bonds allow issuers to use proceeds for general corporate purposes, subject to mechanisms that can affect the bonds' coupons based on sustainability key performance indicators. The certification will provide a Paris-aligned option for issuers, but its added value is still unclear.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
STACS' Benjamin Soh says the volume of green finance is on the rise, which raise demand for ESG data and monitoring services.

As compared with Compared with International Capital Market Association’s Green Bond Principles (GBP), Morningstar thinks the CGBP is more stringent for issuers in the following aspects: the scope of green projects, the clearly defined green projects, a required special account or a dedicated ledger for the fund management for issuers, as well as a detailed disclosure in reporting.

site_title: Cost of Covid Zero is straining municipal finances across China
summary: China's zero-Covid policy is straining municipal finances, with 31 of 31 provincial regions logging deficits in the first 7 months of the year. Local governments are facing financial constraints due to declining land sales, tax revenues, and Covid testing, leading to reduced spending and employee bonuses. The situation is expected to worsen as the Communist Party steps up Covid-fighting efforts, potentially impacting the economy and bond investors. Experts warn that the slowdown in the economy, combined with the stop-start approach to Covid, will suppress domestic spending and external demand.

images.alt_text: In recent months, the People’s Bank of China has been cutting rates and issuing bonds to encourage banks to lend more. That seemed to have worked in August when credit growth rebounded from a record low in July.
Chengdu residents still need to have at least 1 Covid test each week.

site_title: Xi’s heir is likely among China’s rising ‘Luckiest Generation’
summary: China's 'Luckiest Generation,' born in the 1970s, is poised to ascend to leadership ranks during a period of economic growth and potential US overtake. This generation, born after Mao's era but before Xi's, has enjoyed unprecedented economic success, building careers in finance, commodities, and industries. With over 100 already holding senior positions, they're expected to comprise 10% of the next Central Committee, potentially clearing a path to the powerful Politburo.

images.alt_text: Socks - A Christmas Album by JD McPherson

In recent months, the People’s Bank of China has been cutting rates and issuing bonds to encourage banks to lend more. That seemed to have worked in August when credit growth rebounded from a record low in July.

The push to shore up coal power – which still makes up most of China’s energy supply – has alarmed analysts who warn that it will make an eventual transition to a renewables-dominated energy mix more difficult.

site_title: VW puts Porsche at 70-75b euros for market launch
summary: Volkswagen has announced the planned initial public offering (IPO) of its luxury brand Porsche, with an indicative price range of 70-75 billion euros. If successful, it would be one of the largest European IPOs in recent years. The IPO is set to take place on the Frankfurt stock market on September 29, with a proposed share price of 76.50-82.50 euros per share. Volkswagen aims to raise funds to finance its investments in electric and autonomous cars, following the sale of some Porsche shares.

site_title: Money market funds gain popularity with investment platforms, as interest rates rise
summary: Money market funds have gained popularity with investment platforms as interest rates rise, with brokerages like moomoo and ADDX offering alternative investments to cash. Higher yields have made these funds attractive, allowing platforms to compete with banks for customer deposits. Since their introduction, money market funds have seen significant growth, with some funds delivering yields higher than stock market indices. This trend is expected to continue as customers seek higher returns on their savings amid market volatility and recession concerns.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
DBS, UOB and OCBC ATMs at the Singapore Institute of Management (SIM) on March 12, 2020.##########banks##########CHONG JUN LIANG

site_title: Why do we choose the jobs we do? Maybe it’s in our genes
summary: A recent study found that genes related to intelligence, rather than physical strength or emotional intelligence, play a larger role in life attainments such as education, job success, and income. Researchers analyzed the genetic data of over 200,000 individuals and found 39 genetic markers linked to cognitive, emotional, and physical job requirements. The study suggests that genes influencing cognitive demands are associated with positive health outcomes, while physical demands are linked to lower social attainment. The findings imply that genetics may partially shape job choices and have implications for occupational health and well-being.

images.alt_text: Office workers at the Raffles Place,  2 August 2022.

Deep transformation can navigate us to a just and regenerative future, in which our social and environmental systems are capable of adapting to and addressing challenges of the future with flexibility and resilience.
MAS projects that the financial sector will grow by an average 4 per cent to 5 per cent per annum during 2021 to 2025.
Non-resident employment rose across all work pass types, with the bulk coming from work permit and other work passes, according to the Manpower Ministry's latest Labour Market Report.

site_title: Gold seen losing tug of war with greenback
summary: Gold prices are expected to lose ground to the US dollar as investors react to the Federal Reserve's outlook and inflation concerns. The yellow metal, which had reached near-all-time highs in March, began a sixth consecutive month of decline in September 2022. The Fed's outlook and potential rate hikes are contributing to the dollar's strength, making it harder for gold to gain traction.

site_title: Frugal is the new cool for young Chinese as economy falters
summary: China's young population is adopting frugal lifestyles due to economic uncertainty, with over 19% of 16-24-year-olds unemployed. Consumer spending, accounting for half of China's GDP, is declining. Young people are cutting back on non-essential expenses, such as dining out and shopping, and opting to save instead. Social media influencers are promoting low-cost lifestyles, and some have gained large followings for sharing money-saving tips. The trend poses a threat to China's economy, which narrowly avoided contraction in the second quarter. Policymakers are struggling to boost consumption, with a focus on infrastructure instead.

images.alt_text: In recent months, the People’s Bank of China has been cutting rates and issuing bonds to encourage banks to lend more. That seemed to have worked in August when credit growth rebounded from a record low in July.

The push to shore up coal power – which still makes up most of China’s energy supply – has alarmed analysts who warn that it will make an eventual transition to a renewables-dominated energy mix more difficult.

site_title: ‘Extremely rare’ Rameses II-era burial cave found in Israel
summary: Archaeologists in Israel announced the discovery of an "extremely rare" Rameses II-era burial cave, filled with dozens of pottery vessels and bronze artefacts. The cave, uncovered on a beach, dates back to the 13th century BCE and features burial offerings, including bowls, chalices, and cooking pots. At least one relatively intact skeleton was found, along with arrowheads and spearheads. The discovery, described as "once-in-a-lifetime," provides insight into Late Bronze Age funerary customs and highlights the region's trading activity.

images.alt_text: A handout picture provided by the Israel Antiquities Authority on Septembre 18, 2022, shows finds including pottery vessels, dating back to the thirteenth century BCE during the rule of Egypt's Pharaoh Rameses II, disovered untouched in a funerary cave at the central Palmachim park area on the Mediterranean coast. - The cave was uncovered on a beach earlier in the week, when a mechanical digger working at the Palmahim national park hit its roof, with archaeologists using a ladder to descend into the spacious, man-made square cave. Some 40 visitors, most of them Iraqis, were allowed to walk around the more than 2,000-year-old archaeological site in the golden hour of twilight.

site_title: Biden warns Xi of investor fallout if China backs Russia’s war
summary: US President Joe Biden warned Chinese President Xi Jinping that violating sanctions against Russia over its invasion of Ukraine would be a "gigantic mistake" and harm the investment climate, according to an excerpt of an upcoming CBS interview. Biden made the warning in a phone call shortly after Xi met with Russian President Vladimir Putin at the Beijing Winter Olympics in February. However, there is currently no indication that China has actively supported Russia with weapons sales.

images.alt_text: The United Nations flag flies in front of the Secretariat Building at the UN headquarters in New York City. The high-level meeting of the 193-member UN General Assembly starts on Sep 20.
Vladimir Putin acknowledged India’s concerns, echoing language he used a day earlier in a meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping.

From biotech to electric vehicles, shares of China’s key manufacturers have seen heavy selling recently as US initiatives to secure domestic supply chains and solidify its industrial superiority raised uncertainties for Chinese firms.

site_title: GuocoLand sells 84% of Lentor Modern at S$1,856 to S$2,538 psf
summary: GuocoLand sold 508 units (84% of 605 units) of its Lentor Modern project at prices ranging from $1.07m to $3.33m, with all 1-bedroom and 2-bedroom units sold. The project, located in the Lentor Hills estate, is the best-selling project in 2022, according to Huttons Asia. The sales demonstrate a keen interest in the new private residential enclave and a shift towards higher prices, with buyers accepting $2,000 psf or higher as the norm.

Developers sold a total of 437 units excluding executive condominiums (ECs), 47.6 per cent lower than the 834 units sold in July 2022.
118 of the 158 units at Frasers Property's Sky Eden@Bedok were sold at launch at an average price of S$2,100 per square foot.

Artist's impression of Sky Eden@Bedok. Close to 75 per cent of its residential units were sold on the first day of the project's launch.

site_title: BT Mark to Market: What’s next for Frasers Hospitality Trust? (Ep 23)
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust (FHT) failed to privatize, prompting concerns about its future strategy. The proposed privatization aimed to address poor performance, but minority investors voted against the deal due to flaws in the trust's overall strategy. A broad reconstitution of FHT's portfolio may be necessary to improve performance. The failed privatization is not a surprise, as unitholders expect a tourism recovery. The outcome highlights the challenges faced by FHT and the need for a revised strategy to address its performance issues.

images.alt_text: Frasers Property regards hospitality as a core business and is facilitating the privatisation of Frasers Hospitality Trust
The superior bedroom in Capri by Fraser China Square. Only 74.88 per cent of shareholder votes were cast in favour of the take-private resolution; 75 per cent is required.
Intercontinental Hotel Singapore is one of the 12 properties in FHT's initial IPO portfolio.
Intercontinental Hotel Singapore, a portfolio property within FHT
In Singapore, RevPAR for the 9 months climbed 32.4 per cent to S$159 from S$120.

site_title: Under Badenoch’s watch, UK to spread mantra of free trade and free markets
summary: Kemi Badenoch, the UK's new Secretary of State for International Trade, has emphasized her commitment to faster economic growth and free trade, mirroring Prime Minister Liz Truss' stance. Despite challenges, including the Northern Ireland customs border and accelerating inflation, Badenoch aims to unleash "Global Britain's full potential" through free trade agreements, such as the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP). The UK's trade data has fallen short of forecasts, with a deficit of £29 billion last year, but joining the CPTPP could secure lower tariffs for exports and boost services exports.

images.alt_text: New British Prime Minister Liz Truss will be at the UN General Assembly in New York, her first outing on the world stage since becoming the UK's leader.
Suppliers will get rebates for those discounts, which would apply to contracts already signed earlier this year.
After 8 years of dealing with the rules, British banks have found ways to align pay with that of other regions.

site_title: Waste-to-energy emerges as new form of investment into industry projects
summary: Waste-to-energy (WTE) technologies are emerging as a viable investment opportunity, allowing for the production of new energy from waste. According to Johnny Stuen, a WTE expert, this process can be a more environmentally friendly alternative to landfills, with one tonne of residual waste incinerated releasing 1 tonne of carbon dioxide compared to 2.5 tonnes in a landfill. To achieve net zero emissions by 2050, Stuen emphasizes the need for continued development of carbon capture and storage technologies, as well as increased awareness and financing for WTE projects.

images.alt_text: In the absence of collection, plastics are finding their way into our waterways and oceans and, increasingly, into the global food chain.

site_title: New energy and the triple bottom line
summary: Dr. Michael Langen, a partner and managing director of HTP Engineers, highlights the benefits of waste-to-energy (WTE) technologies, which can be adapted to various locations worldwide. WTE strategies reduce waste disposal and save primary resources by substituting coal, crude oil, or natural gas. These technologies can be used for district heating, electricity production, or feeding to the local gas grid. The recycling industry is transforming from a volume-based to a quality-based approach, with a focus on recycled content and recyclability. New players, including companies from the petrochemical industry and retailers, are entering the market, and financing is becoming more accessible.

images.alt_text: Waste-to-energy is a much better alternative as the final sink than a landfill, says KANFA/Technip Energies' Johnny Stuen.

site_title: Fossil fuel reserves contain 3.5 trillion tonnes of CO2: database
summary: The world's remaining fossil fuel reserves contain 3.5 trillion tonnes of CO2, seven times the carbon budget to cap global heating at 1.5°C. The Global Registry of Fossil Fuels, a first-of-its-kind inventory, reveals that some countries hold reserves containing enough carbon to exceed the entire world's carbon budget. If burned, these reserves would unleash massive greenhouse gas emissions, exacerbating climate change. The registry aims to provide transparency and accountability, helping policymakers and investors make informed decisions to phase out fossil fuels and meet the 1.5°C temperature goal.
