The push to shore up coal power – which still makes up most of China’s energy supply – has alarmed analysts who warn that it will make an eventual transition to a renewables-dominated energy mix more difficult.

site_title: Circular fashion now in style
summary: A new sustainable clothing movement, known as circular fashion, is gaining momentum in Europe and beyond. Circular fashion is designed to be used and circulated responsibly, with the intention of being reused for as long as possible. The concept originated in Sweden and has been driven by companies such as Siptex, which operates the world's first large-scale textile sorting facility. The industry faces a bottleneck in scaling recycling operations due to purity standards for feedstock, but experts believe that increased investment in recycling and changes in consumer behavior can help address this issue.

images.alt_text: One area of technological improvement Siepelmeyer is particularly excited about is improved sorting techniques and plants.

site_title: Police say wanted crypto developer Do Kwon is currently not in Singapore
summary: Singapore Police Force stated that wanted crypto developer Do Kwon is not currently in the city-state, contrary to earlier claims by South Korean prosecutors who said he was residing there. Arrest warrants had been issued for 6 people, including Do Kwon, by South Korean prosecutors last week. The Singapore police will assist the South Korean police within the scope of their domestic legislation and international obligations.

site_title: Asia’s green bond issuers look past pricing to branding and investor access
summary: Asia's green bond issuers are shifting their focus beyond lower pricing to gaining access to the market. According to DBS' head of fixed income Clifford Lee, issuers with ESG-destructive practices will face a pricing disadvantage and limited market access. This change reflects the growing importance of branding and investor access, rather than just lower yields. As a result, green bond issuers must prioritize their ESG credentials to attract investors and secure market access.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
The new, more flexible product is likely to catch on, as issuers look for ways to cope with increasingly volatile markets in which key ESG parameters such as energy prices become harder to predict.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Capesize market has shown improvement, with rates rising to around $12,599, driven by increased demand and a surge of cargoes hitting the market. The Transatlantic C8 index rose +223 week-on-week, while the Transpacific C10 closed the week down -3327. The Panamax market was also bullish, with healthy demand from Southeast Asia and the US Gulf. Ultramax and Supramax markets saw mixed fortunes, with stronger rates in Asia but pressure easing in the Atlantic. Handysize markets saw gains across both basins, with East Coast South America and the US Gulf seeing increased activity. VLCC rates turned around, recovering lost ground and heading upwards. Suezmax rates climbed, with Aframax markets starting to show signs of recovery.

images.alt_text: Following successive weeks of a dire market for players, some impressive gains were made in the Panamax market as the grain markets in both EC South America and NoPac came alive.

site_title: Circular economy, green financing the way forward
summary: A circular economy, supported by green financing, is gaining importance in addressing global warming and resource scarcity. Hani Tohme, senior partner at Roland Berger, emphasizes the need to rethink the current status quo to achieve economic and ecological savings. Key to circularity are redesigning products, changing ownership and material flow, and creating links between manufacturers, sellers, and recyclers. Green financing, defined as financial instruments for green projects, can help industries adopt sustainable practices and reduce environmental impact. Tohme believes that sustainable financing can lower the bar for responsible decisions and raise the bar for polluting activities.

images.alt_text: Green financing shows a clear shift, where financial institutions clearly favour circular and climate-friendly approaches when supporting industrial investment.

site_title: Common approaches needed to cut waste generation
summary: A collaborative approach is needed to reduce waste generation, involving infrastructure, policy, and behavioral insights. PhD research fellow Henrik Siepelmeyer emphasizes the importance of setting common approaches among industry players, considering recyclability, and incorporating human behavior in waste infrastructure planning. Improved sorting techniques and plants, as well as the use of artificial intelligence, big data, and the Internet of Things (IoT), can increase recycling efficiency and transparency, leading to more effective waste management. A global perspective is also crucial in developing solutions that go beyond Western countries.

images.alt_text: Dr Langen says waste-to-energy (WTE) strategies save primary resources by substituting coal, crude oil or natural gas.

site_title: Chubu Electric joins all-Japan Toshiba buyout consortium
summary: Chubu Electric Power Co has joined a consortium led by Japan Industrial Partners to conduct due diligence for a potential buyout of Toshiba Corp. Toshiba, exploring going private and other options, has selected multiple bidders, including Bain Capital and Brookfield Asset Management, to proceed to a second bidding round. Orix Corp and Central Japan Railway Co also participated in the consortium. Toshiba has declined to comment on potential candidates for the buyout.

site_title: Do Kwon, no longer in Singapore, says he’s not ‘on the run’
summary: Do Kwon, founder of collapsed Luna and TerraUSD tokens, claims he is not "on the run" despite Singapore police stating he is no longer in the country. Prosecutors in South Korea say Kwon is not cooperating with probes and had plans to flee before the collapse of the Luna token in May. Kwon tweeted he is in "full cooperation" with government agencies and has nothing to hide, but prosecutors refute his claims, saying he is "obviously on the run" and seeking to revoke his passport.

images.alt_text: A request has been passed to South Korea’s Foreign Ministry to revoke Do Kwon's passport, the prosecutor’s office said on Thursday.
Do Kwon found himself at the centre of one of crypto’s biggest blowups when TerraUSD crumbled from its dollar peg and brought down the ecosystem he had built.

site_title: Dollar edges down but posts gains for week; yuan slips past key level
summary: The US dollar mostly held a slight gain following improved consumer sentiment data in September, with the dollar index down 0.1% on Friday but up 0.6% for the week. The dollar index is expected to remain stable as investors anticipate the US Federal Reserve to remain aggressive with interest rate hikes this week. The offshore yuan broke the 7 per dollar threshold for the first time in over 2 years, while the yuan's onshore unit also crossed the key level.

images.alt_text: US dollar, measured against a basket of currencies, is headed for a near 1 per cent rise this week,

site_title: US-China tech rivalry adds to headaches for investors
summary: US-China tech rivalry is adding to market uncertainty, with shares of Chinese key manufacturers declining 7% this month due to US initiatives to secure domestic supply chains. Rising tensions over Beijing's stance on Russia and Taiwan may accelerate economic decoupling, and investors are bracing for further market volatility. Chinese President Xi Jinping's meeting with Vladimir Putin has sparked concerns about potential US sanctions, while US President Joe Biden is set to sign an executive order intensifying national security reviews on foreign investments.

images.alt_text: The better-than-expected figures show China's economy is gaining some steam, after narrowly escaping a contraction in the June quarter and lifting recovery prospects slightly for the rest of the year.
Among industry groups, US factory production for machinery, aerospace equipment, and computers and electronic products increased.

site_title: MAS and Indian regulator to collaborate on fintech innovations
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and India's International Financial Services Centres Authority (IFSCA) signed a co-operation agreement to facilitate regulatory collaboration and partnership in fintech. The agreement aims to promote fintech innovation and experimentation through regulatory sandbox collaboration and information sharing. Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong witnessed the signing, expressing hope that the agreement will spur innovation and create new jobs and investments. The partnership will enable fintech companies from both countries to experiment and pilot innovative products and services in both markets.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
MAS projects that the financial sector will grow by an average 4 per cent to 5 per cent per annum during 2021 to 2025.

site_title: ‘Don’t Waste Our Future’ theme of this year’s ISWA World Congress
summary: The International Solid Waste Association (ISWA) World Congress 2022, themed "Don't Waste Our Future," will take place in Singapore from Sep 21-23. The 3-day event aims to promote economic growth, increase efficiency, and sustainably manage waste and resources, while tackling climate change. Key themes include sustainability, circular economy, robotics, and blockchain. The congress will feature 35 booths, a Singapore Pavilion, and technical site visits, with 1,000 foreign and local delegates attending. ISWA plans to release white papers on waste-to-energy technologies and sustainable collection and transport technologies, and will discuss financing waste management and sustainable living.

images.alt_text: James Law, chair of the ISWA's Working Group on Landfill, says we must commit to promoting sustainable living in all nations.

site_title: China needs more than fiscal and monetary support to get its economy buzzing again
summary: China's economy continues to struggle despite fiscal and monetary support measures. The country's central bank has cut rates and issued bonds to encourage lending, but credit growth rebounded only in August, with other data showing a "slight loss of momentum." The ongoing COVID-19 restrictions, known as zero-Covid, remain a major obstacle to economic growth, with sudden lockdowns affecting consumer spending and business operations. Economists predict China's growth outlook remains dim, with some forecasting a 3% full-year growth rate, down from 3.5% previously, and warning that lifting zero-Covid policies is crucial to stimulating the economy.

images.alt_text: Europe is becoming a more appealing listing venue for Chinese firms than the US.
The People’s Bank of China offered 400 billion yuan via its medium-term lending facility, matching the median forecast in a Bloomberg survey.
Authorities including the PBOC have been stepping up efforts to support a lacklustre economy hurt by the Covid-Zero policy and a worsening housing crisis.

site_title: Sustainable living key to tackling climate change
summary: James Law, chair of the ISWA's Working Group on Landfill, emphasizes the importance of sustainable living in tackling climate change. He attributes extreme climate changes, such as heatwaves and wildfires, to human activities like burning fossil fuels and deforestation. Law suggests that countries must promote sustainable living through education, outreach programs, and policy changes. He recommends actions like implementing carbon taxes, emissions taxes, and shutting down industries generating high levels of greenhouse gas emissions. The ISWA's Working Group on Landfill aims to promote sustainable waste management and sound landfill operations worldwide.

site_title: Logistics S-Reits to ride on e-commerce growth
summary: Singapore's logistics S-Reits are expected to benefit from e-commerce growth, with 11 trusts recording 10-year annualised total returns of 16.4% in 2022, outpacing the broader market. Despite underperforming in the year-to-date, these trusts have shown stronger rebounds, averaging 4% total returns in the 3Q-to-date. This growth is driven by accelerated digital transformation, shifts in consumer trends, and a focus on supply-chain resilience, positioning logistics S-Reits for continued success.

images.alt_text: Four out of the 5 stocks in the STI reserve list were in the S-Reits and Property  Trusts sector, including Suntec Reit

site_title: Crypto speculation falls out of favour with game studios
summary: Crypto assets, such as non-fungible tokens (NFTs), have failed to deliver on their promises in the gaming industry. Studios like Mojang and Sky Mavis, which initially invested heavily in NFTs, have since scaled back their efforts due to criticism from players and employees. The focus on speculative investments and financial rewards has led to a breach of trust and a perception that these games are less concerned with quality and fun than with hype and profit. As a result, many game developers and publishers are reevaluating their involvement in the crypto space.

images.alt_text: Animoca Brands is the publisher of popular Web3 game The Sandbox and has a portfolio of over 340 investments.
Some games, like the popular Axie Infinity, were said to have lifted lives amid the pandemic by helping rural communities put food on the table.
The additional funding was finalised after the TerraUSD stablecoin collapse in May, and that event didn't lead to a change in valuation or terms, Yat Siu, co-founder of Animoca, said in an email.

site_title: China doubles down on coal as energy crunch bites
summary: China has stepped up coal production amid an energy crunch, despite President Xi Jinping's vow to reduce coal use by 2026 as part of climate promises. The country's reliance on coal, which accounts for most of its energy supply, alarms analysts, making a transition to renewables more difficult. China's carbon emissions have fallen for four consecutive quarters, but authorities are relying on coal to boost the economy. The push to shore up coal power raises concerns about the country's ability to meet its climate targets and reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

images.alt_text: Oil prices could also be supported in the fourth quarter if Opec+ members cut production, which will be discussed at the group’s October meeting.
Russia and China would soon sign agreements on the delivery of “50 billion cubic metres of gas” per year via the future Force 2 pipeline in Siberia.

site_title: As Hong Kong’s office leasing activity stutters, a renewed call to lift quarantine restrictions
summary: Hong Kong's office leasing activity has hit a new low, with vacant top-tier office space more than doubling in the last three years due to companies downsizing operations. Industry analysts suggest lifting Covid-19 quarantine restrictions could boost demand, but a report by CBRE projects gradual and moderate future demand growth. The city's Grade A office market is experiencing its longest down cycle, with a record-high vacancy rate of 11.3% and a glut of new supply entering the market over the next five years. Removing quarantine restrictions could deliver a quick boost to the industry.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong has said it will further extend the rental or fee concessions for government properties and short-term tenancies and waivers to ease the operating pressure of businesses as the pandemic continues to affect economic activities.
Travellers entering Hong Kong have to spend 3 days in a designated hotel followed by 4 days of restrictions from bars and restaurants.
Between 2019 and this year, most sectors cut down on office space with the exceptions being the legal, real estate and healthcare industries as well as government departments.

site_title: Hong Kong set for fiscal deficit that’s double estimate: financial secretary
summary: Hong Kong is forecast to report a fiscal deficit of over HK$100 billion (S$17.9 billion) for the 2022-23 year, nearly double the initial estimate of HK$56.3 billion. The sluggish economy, due to weaker exports and lower private consumption, has led to reduced revenue, while the pandemic has boosted government spending. Financial Secretary Paul Chan has announced further concessions to ease operating pressure on businesses, but expects the epidemic to be better controlled and cross-border travel restored for economic growth to improve.

images.alt_text: Travellers entering Hong Kong have to spend 3 days in a designated hotel followed by 4 days of restrictions from bars and restaurants.

site_title: Critical new technologies hold key to emerging energy trends
summary: New energy technologies, such as waste-to-energy, sorting plants, and biogas production, are emerging as key solutions to address waste management and reduce greenhouse gas emissions. These technologies can convert waste into valuable resources, such as energy, fuels, and feedstocks, and can also help to reduce the amount of waste sent to landfills. According to Michael Harrison, a partner at Ashurst LLP, the use of these technologies can create a virtuous loop, where waste is converted into energy or feedstock that can be reused, reducing emissions and promoting a circular economy.

images.alt_text: Waste-to-energy is a much better alternative as the final sink than a landfill, says KANFA/Technip Energies' Johnny Stuen.

site_title: BofA small-business card spending on travel highest since Covid
summary: Bank of America's report found that small-business spending on travel has nearly reached pre-pandemic levels, with travel transactions per client at 90% of 2019 levels. Spending on travel-related activities was up 31% in August from the previous year, and up 43% for firms with annual revenue above $1 million. This follows a surge in corporate travel bookings, with US employers booking fall trips at nearly 6 times last year's rate. The report also showed strong payroll spending, rising 11% in the year through August.

site_title: 'Crowns of the forest': Indonesian helps orchids bloom again
summary: A 56-year-old Indonesian farmer, Musimin, has been a self-taught conservationist dedicated to cultivating rare, indigenous orchids at the foot of Indonesia's most active volcano. He has been salvaging and cultivating these exotic blooms for years, comparing them to gemstones. With no formal background in botany, Musimin has become a one-man mission to save these unique plants, found on the outskirts of Yogyakarta on Java island.

images.alt_text: Forests are a powerful ally in the struggle against climate change.

site_title: China’s Chengdu lifts city lockdown from Monday
summary: China's Chengdu city lifted its city lockdown from Monday, September 19, after a two-week lockdown to contain a Covid-19 outbreak. Residents must still undergo weekly Covid tests and show negative results within 72 hours to enter public venues. The move comes ahead of a Communist Party leadership summit where President Xi Jinping is expected to secure a third term. The brief lockdown was the biggest in Chengdu since Shanghai's 2-month lockdown earlier this year, and it follows other cities in China that have also imposed restrictions.

images.alt_text: Chengdu residents in locked-down areas need to remain at home and get PCR tests daily.

site_title: Longest running show on Broadway, ‘Phantom of the Opera’ to close
summary: The Phantom of the Opera, the longest-running show on Broadway, will close on February 18, 2023, after 35 years due to a sharp drop in ticket sales despite its legacy and numerous awards. The show, which celebrates its 35th anniversary in January, was losing $1 million a month and had already cast its first Black American actress to portray the lead role of Christine. The musical, based on Gaston Leroux's classic novel, will end with its final Broadway performance on February 18.

site_title: Hong Kong may announce end of hotel quarantine this week
summary: Hong Kong may announce the end of hotel quarantine for inbound travellers as early as this week, allowing arrivals to undergo self-monitoring for 7 days instead. The move, part of a broader plan to ease Covid restrictions, could come ahead of a proposed banker summit and the Rugby Sevens tournament later this year. The city has maintained strict measures, including mandatory mask-wearing and health codes, despite other countries relaxing their borders. The announcement is expected to affect airline and hotel industries, with an implementation date yet to be determined.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong has been liaising with mainland Chinese authorities regarding border reopening.

Hong Kong has some of the strictest Covid measures in the world, requiring people to wear masks at almost all times and sending travellers into hotel quarantine for days after arrival to ensure they aren’t incubating the virus.

site_title: Credit Suisse finances collateralised loan obligations in wager on UK real estate
summary: Credit Suisse is financing up to $1.3 billion in collateralized loan obligations (CLOs) for UK real estate, with Aeon Investments bundling loans and issuing bonds secured against them. This is the largest such deal in Europe, as UK property faces a recession amid rising interest rates. Aeon plans to fund mid-market projects across England and Wales, including offices, warehouses, and retail properties. The deal provides flexibility and control for managers, who can make capital injections and trade in and out of loans in response to market conditions.

images.alt_text: Inflation is close to a 40-year high, driving up the cost of goods and services of all kinds.
London was among the strongest regions for sales, with prices in the capital jumping 8.8 per cent from a year ago, the most in 6 years.

site_title: Shanghai Turbo Enterprises claims it is able to meet current obligations
summary: Shanghai Turbo Enterprises claims it can meet current obligations by implementing a debt repayment plan and special payment terms with suppliers. The company, which has a current deficit of 5.5 million yuan, expects to strengthen its cash flow position through increased revenue and customer collections. It also has 2 shareholder personal guaranteed loans totaling 9.5 million yuan, which will enhance its ability to continue as a going concern. The company's shares were trading flat at S$0.081 after the announcement.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Generic shots of SGX

site_title: Circular economy key in battle against global warming
summary: Circular economy key in battle against global warming, says Christof Delatter of OVAM. Recycling and composting are insufficient to improve resource efficiency, and financial institutions are shifting towards circular and climate-friendly approaches in industrial investments. A study by OECD found that consumption of resources causes over 65% of greenhouse-gas emissions in Flanders, Belgium. To combat global warming, a more circular economy is necessary, and Flanders is a leading region in setting out ambitious policies and targets on household waste management.

images.alt_text: Circular fashion is apparel that is designed, sourced and produced with the intention of being used and circulated responsibly and effectively in society for as long as possible.

site_title: Modi urges peace in Ukraine, joining Xi in questioning Putin
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi urged Russian President Vladimir Putin for peace in Ukraine, echoing concerns expressed by Chinese President Xi Jinping. In their first face-to-face meeting since Russia's invasion, Modi called for a path of peace in the coming days. Putin acknowledged India's concerns, echoing language used in a meeting with Xi. The meeting comes as the conflict in Ukraine continues to affect the global economy.

images.alt_text: The met on the sidelines of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) in the Uzbek city of Samarkand.

site_title: Saudi oil driller hires Goldman, HSBC, SNB Capital for IPO
summary: Saudi Arabia-based oilfield-services firm Arabian Drilling has hired Goldman Sachs, HSBC, and SNB Capital to manage its initial public offering (IPO) in Riyadh. The firm will sell 26.7 million shares, or 30% of its stake, to raise funds for scaling up operations and expanding into the Gulf Cooperation Council region. Arabian Drilling operates 45 rigs and has an order backlog of $2.2 billion, with CEO Ghassan Mirdad citing "unprecedented growth" due to high oil prices and demand for energy. The IPO is expected to value the company at over $1.4 billion.

images.alt_text: Oil prices could also be supported in the fourth quarter if Opec+ members cut production, which will be discussed at the group’s October meeting.

site_title: ESOPs can help you ride a wave, but what happens when you’re underwater?
summary: In Asia, the startup ecosystem is experiencing a downturn due to geo-political tensions, rising interest rates, and commodity prices. However, the pandemic has pushed startups to adapt and innovate, leading to the use of employee stock ownership plans (ESOPs) as an alternative compensation tool. ESOPs help companies realize the principle of "skin in the game" among employees, fostering a sense of ownership and drive. As valuations come down, companies must carefully consider the impact of ESOPs on employee confidence and other stakeholders. To manage cash outflows, companies may opt to convert bonuses into deferred equity awards or allocate equity with short vesting periods, reducing employee take-home pay in the short term but providing future benefits.

images.alt_text: For an employee, a company going from US$1 billion to US$10 billion then back to US$4 billion is not the same as a company growing from US$1 billion to US$4 billion organically. While the final valuation may be the same, the steps that follow a down round are far more brutal for employees, who may find themselves facing massive personal tax liabilities, debts or more.
Following the sale of Hmlet to co-living company Habyt, Hmlet’s employee share option programme will be terminated and any options granted will be cancelled.
(From left) Qapita co-founders Vamsee Mohan, Ravi Ravulaparthi and Lakshman Gupta.
A novel approach to startup recruiting: lower the stock price

site_title: Work sucks when you’re the only one left
summary: Millions of workers worldwide are struggling with overwork, burnout, and stress due to staffing shortages and increased workload. Despite the Great Resignation, many employees remain at their jobs, feeling pressured to do more with less. Experts say that the pandemic has brought attention to longstanding issues, but the root cause of the problem remains the extractive, capitalistic system that prioritizes profits over workers' well-being. Workers are being asked to take on more responsibilities, but the quality of their work is often suffering. The situation is further complicated by customers' high expectations and frustration with staff shortages, leading to abusive treatment of workers.

images.alt_text: On-the-job stress rose from 38 per cent of those polled in 2019 to 43 per cent the following year as Covid-19 upended the world of work, Gallup found. Women in the United States and Canada faced the most pressure.
R

Mid-sized accounting firm Foo Kon Tan’s managing director Kon Yin Tong told BT that attrition rate has more than doubled from the previous year, even as talent pools shrank, with Nanyang Technological University (NTU) taking in fewer accountancy students.

O’Connor is capitalising on a watershed moment in the workplace, where the future of when and how work happens is up for grabs. Workers and managers alike know from the past 2 years of working from home that many jobs don’t really require 40 weekly hours to complete.

site_title: Political storm returns for Liz Truss after days of UK mourning
summary: British Prime Minister Liz Truss returns to politics after a week of mourning following Queen Elizabeth II's death, facing pressure over the UK's deepening economic crisis. Truss, who unveiled a massive energy price intervention in her first week in office, will attend the UN General Assembly in New York and deliver a mini-Budget in the House of Commons. Her government's plans, including tax cuts and trade union crackdowns, have sparked concerns about her ability to govern, while her foreign policy stance on Brexit and Ukraine is expected to be scrutinized.

images.alt_text: Liz Truss gestures outside the Conservative Party headquarters, after being announced as Britain's next Prime Minister, in London on Sep 5, 2022.
Warnings of recession have weighed heavily on the pound, countering the boost from 6 back-to-back rate hikes by the Bank of England.
The United Nations flag flies in front of the Secretariat Building at the UN headquarters in New York City. The high-level meeting of the 193-member UN General Assembly starts on Sep 20.

site_title: Ong Sek Chong & Sons adds to Lian Beng stake
summary: Lian Beng Group's largest shareholder, Ong Sek Chong & Sons, acquired 7,291,000 shares of Lian Beng Group between Sep 12 and Sep 14, increasing its stake to 58.02%. This deal, valued at S$3,899,230, followed a previous acquisition of 49,300 shares on Sep 8. The deal reflects the growing confidence in the construction group's prospects, with Lian Beng Group reporting a 53.2% increase in group revenue to S$788.3 million in FY 2022.

images.alt_text: Overall, institutions were net buyers of Singapore stocks for the 5 sessions ended Sep 8, with S$137 million of net inflows.

site_title: Ether falls to lowest in seven weeks; offshoot token plunges
summary: Ether, the native currency of the Ethereum blockchain, dropped to a seven-week low of US$1,407 on September 16, falling 6.5% from its previous day's close, amid a broader sell-off in riskier assets. The transition to a more energy-efficient method of handling transactions, known as the Merge, had initially captured investor attention, but traders now view it as a "sell-the-news" event. The offshoot token, EthereumPOW, also plummeted, trading at about US$10.59 on September 16.

images.alt_text: Ethereum used to be secured by a network of high-powered computers that competed against one another to solve cryptographic puzzles, burning vast amounts of energy in the process. Now, it will be secured by a process known as “staking”, which involves investors agreeing to deposit their crypto coins in a shared pool in exchange for a chance to earn financial rewards.
The overhaul has changed how transactions on the Ethereum blockchain occur and how ether tokens are created.
Ether mining has evolved into a multi-billion dollar industry over the last several years.
A physical imitation of the Ethereum cryptocurrency. A change in how Ethereum is minted could, by some estimates, reduce power usage on the network by as much as 99.5 per cent.
The hotly-anticipated Merge, expected around Sep 15, will transition Ethereum to a more energy efficient network.

site_title: UOB sets sights on being No. 1 in cross-border trade needs in Asean
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) is aiming to become the No. 1 bank for cross-border trade in South-east Asia, with a target of S$7 billion in revenue for its wholesale banking segment by 2025. The bank is investing S$500 million to build regional platforms for cash management, supply chain management, and payments, focusing on 8 sectors driving 70% of Greater China and Asean FDI and trade flows. UOB's head of group wholesale and global markets, Frederick Chin, is confident the bank's trusted status and physical presence will help it compete in the digital age, despite potential partnerships with digital financial platforms.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

UOB's brand refresh event concluded with a fashion show, featuring staff walking down the runway with the bank’s new branch ambassador uniforms.

site_title: 5 business lessons I learned in my first 90 years
summary: The article "5 Business Lessons I Learned in My First 90 Years" by John Bittleston shares five key business lessons learned from his life experiences. The lessons include the importance of creativity, courage, effective negotiation, reading people, and recognizing purpose. Bittleston credits his ability to associate unrelated events and relationships, which he developed at age 8, with his creative talent. He also emphasizes the need for courage to take risks and stand on principles, even if it means facing challenges. Additionally, Bittleston stresses the value of seduction in negotiation, recognizing that people can be persuaded to your point of view. Finally, he highlights the significance of purpose in business, which should involve other people and be driven by passion, rather than just profit.

images.alt_text: Across the span of societies, from the wealthy to those near or at starvation point, consumers are both better and worse informed than they have ever been before.  The internet and the mobile phone have precipitated the greatest change in the distribution of information that humanity has ever seen.

People widely have a poor view of planning, especially in times of emergency. This may be partly because they see the process of planning as something you do for a posh wedding, where everything must be tickety-boo and there is no room for mishap.  The point is: How much worse would they have been without planning?

Why do humans blame their work for their misery? Why do many find themselves lacking in confidence, bereft of enthusiasm, tempted to opt out? The answer to this is another question. What do you think is the purpose of your life and the lives of those who work with you?

site_title: US vows continued deployment of strategic assets after North Korea nuclear law
summary: The US has vowed to continue deploying strategic assets to deter and respond to North Korea's new law allowing preemptive nuclear strikes. The US and South Korea denounced the law as "escalatory and destabilizing," reaffirming their commitment to defend South Korea. Any North Korean nuclear attack would be met with an "overwhelming and decisive response." The countries also committed to strengthening their deterrence posture, employing all elements of their national power to maintain the alliance's defense capabilities.

images.alt_text: North Korea has passed a law officially declaring itself a nuclear weapons state, a status that leader Kim Jong Un said is “irreversible".

site_title: Lagging repo rates risk undermining ECB’s latest tightening push
summary: The European Central Bank's (ECB) efforts to tighten financial conditions may be hindered by a shortage of high-quality assets in the euro area, leading to higher short-term borrowing costs. Since the ECB's rate hike, the cost of borrowing cash against German government bonds has increased by 57 basis points, indicating a limited supply of securities. This imbalance, caused by years of central bank bond-buying, has inflated the amount of excess money in the system, reducing the stock of government bonds available for trading. This could undermine the ECB's tightening push.

images.alt_text: The cost of borrowing cash against German government bonds in repo markets has only climbed 57 basis points since the ECB’s decision to raise rates by 75 basis points last week.
The ECB currently sees inflation at 2.3 per cent in 2024.

site_title: S Korean cinematic rise years in the making, says Squid Game star
summary: South Korean actor Lee Jung-jae credits years of effort to connect with global audiences for the success of his Emmy-winning show "Squid Game." The series, which has become the most-watched Netflix show, follows a group of misfits competing in twisted games. Lee's win marks a milestone for South Korean cinema, following the success of "Parasite," which won Best Picture at the Oscars in 2020. Lee's upcoming directorial debut, "Hunt," a Cold-War era spy thriller, is set to be released globally, reflecting the adaptation of South Korean film-making to global audiences.

images.alt_text: The Korean drama earned 14 nominations, competing against the eventual best drama winner HBO’s Succession.
Squid Game, the Netflix show – in which misfits and criminals compete for cash in barbaric and deadly versions of schoolyard games – is aiming to triumph at TV’s top prize gala.

site_title: UN summit returns in person to world of divisions
summary: The UN General Assembly is set to convene in person after two years of virtual meetings, amidst a world plagued by crises, including the war in Ukraine, climate change, and poverty. The summit will bring together over 150 world leaders, with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky leading the fight against Russian invaders, despite being granted an exception to speak in person. The event aims to build momentum on global action on climate change, with a focus on food security and addressing the global food crisis, and will take place amid concerns about rising tensions between the West and Russia.

images.alt_text: “Heatwaves in Europe. Colossal floods in Pakistan...There is nothing natural about the new scale of these disasters,” UN secretary-general António Guterres said in a video message.

site_title: Cancel culture – when to know enough’s enough
summary: Stuart Kirk, former global head of responsible investing at HSBC Asset Management, resigned after being "canceled" for speaking out against the overstated climate risk to investing. Kirk claimed that climate change risks were overhyped and that people could adapt to a changing climate, sparking a backlash from climate change advocates. While Kirk's views were factually sound, his delivery was seen as combative and dismissive of climate change concerns. The incident highlights the risks of cancel culture, where differing opinions can lead to personal and professional ruin, stifling open and honest debate.

images.alt_text: Protests in June 2022 against the Supreme Court's ruling in the Dobbs v Jackson Women's Health Organization in Atlanta, Georgia. Research at the Yale School of Management into companies’ responses to the overturning of Roe v Wade showed that these were rarely driven by the personal politics of a given boss. Instead, industry, geography, the workforce and a firm’s customer base largely determined company positions.
Kirk was suspended by HSBC in May after he said central bank policymakers and other global authorities had exaggerated the financial risks of climate change at an industry conference.

site_title: Ukraine to dominate as world leaders gather at United Nations in New York
summary: World leaders will gather at the United Nations in New York for a high-level meeting of the 193-member UN General Assembly, starting on September 20. The meeting is expected to focus on the ongoing Russia-Ukraine conflict, a global food crisis, and other global challenges. Despite efforts to address these issues, UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres warns that geopolitical divides are "paralysing the global response" and minimal progress is expected towards ending the conflict. Western countries and Russia are expected to compete for diplomatic influence, while the US is co-hosting a food security summit and a Covid-19 global action plan meeting.

images.alt_text: Vladimir Putin acknowledged India’s concerns, echoing language he used a day earlier in a meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping.
The UN summit will also mark a fresh occasion to build momentum on global action on climate change, amid mounting signs that the planet is descending into dangerous levels of warming.

site_title: World leaders head to UK for queen’s funeral as public pays tribute
summary: World leaders and hundreds of thousands of people gathered in London for the funeral of Queen Elizabeth II, who died on September 8 at 96. The queen's coffin was brought to the UK Parliament complex to lie in state, sparking an outpouring of emotion. The funeral, attended by over 2,000 guests, including US President Joe Biden, will be followed by a private burial at Windsor Castle. The event marks the end of a record-breaking 70-year reign, and King Charles III, the queen's successor, will meet with Commonwealth leaders to discuss the future of the monarchy.

site_title: Mainland China reports first imported monkeypox case
summary: Mainland China reported its first imported monkeypox case, with a person entering Chongqing city from abroad showing symptoms such as a skin rash during their quarantine for Covid. The individual was in low-risk transmission due to quarantine, and all close contacts were under medical observation. This marks the first known monkeypox infection in China, which has reported over 60,000 confirmed cases globally.

site_title: Putin tells Europe: if you want gas then open Nord Stream 2
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin blamed Europe's energy crisis on the "green agenda" and said that if the EU wants more gas, it should lift sanctions preventing the opening of the Nord Stream 2 pipeline. The pipeline, which has the capacity to supply 55 billion cubic meters of gas per year, was built last year but Germany halted its completion days before Russia invaded Ukraine. Putin urged Europe to lift sanctions to avoid further energy shortages and price surges.

images.alt_text: Russia and China would soon sign agreements on the delivery of “50 billion cubic metres of gas” per year via the future Force 2 pipeline in Siberia.

site_title: History shows no example of hiking US rates too fast, Summers says
summary: Former Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers argues that the Federal Reserve should not hold back from aggressive monetary tightening to combat inflation, citing historical examples of delayed policy adjustments that led to substantial costs. Summers suggests that the Fed should aim for a terminal rate of 4.5% to contain inflation, potentially higher than the current forecast of 3.25%. He notes that even Fed Chair Paul Volcker, who successfully fought inflation in the 1980s, had a "false start" and that the market is waking up to the underlying inflation problem.

images.alt_text: While fewer consumers mentioned supply shortages and gas prices are falling, other measures of inflation are still accelerating and widespread, such as costs for food and shelter.

site_title: Shopify offers workers greater say in compensation structure to attract talent
summary: Shopify has introduced a new compensation system, Flex Comp, allowing staff to choose between cash and equity awards, aiming to attract and retain workers amid a challenging environment. 91% of eligible employees have enrolled, with share vesting beginning immediately after removing 1-year cliffs on equity. The company, which had previously planned to cut 10% of its workforce, now says it has no additional workforce reductions planned. This move is seen as an effort to boost morale and flexibility for employees amidst high inflation and lower demand.

images.alt_text: Shopify reported a surprise loss for the second quarter, sending its US-listed shares down about 8 per cent at US$29.12 in premarket trading.
The move will eliminate about 1,000 jobs out of 10,000 or so total employees at Shopify.

site_title: UK plans to cut business energy rates in half in bailout package
summary: The UK government is developing a plan to halve energy rates for businesses, aiming to put them in line with household prices. The £40 billion support package, led by Prime Minister Liz Truss, would fix the wholesale price of business energy contracts at roughly 50% less than what households pay. The discount, lasting 6 months, would apply to contracts signed earlier this year and would be rebated to suppliers. The move aims to stem the economic damage from soaring energy costs, affecting small businesses with bills rising by up to 10 times.

images.alt_text: UK retail sales volumes dropped by 1.6 per cent in monthly terms in August, the Office for National Statistics (ONS) said - the biggest fall since December 2021.
Britain’s response to the cost of living crisis has differed from its European peers, notably in PM Truss’ rejection of a windfall tax on energy companies’ profits.

site_title: Can ‘the Merge’ save crypto?
summary: Ethereum successfully upgraded its software architecture from "proof of work" to "proof of stake", known as "the Merge", which is being hailed as a watershed moment in the history of crypto. The new blockchain is expected to be environmentally friendly, consuming 99.95% less energy than the old one, and could lead to increased value of Ether. However, critics argue that the Merge won't solve crypto's problems overnight and may introduce new issues, such as increased centralization and potential regulatory scrutiny. The Merge's impact on the crypto movement remains uncertain, and more than just a successful upgrade is needed to turn its fortunes around.

images.alt_text: FILE -- Part of a setup for mining Ethereum cryptocurrency in La Plata, Argentina, June 28, 2022. Ethereum, the most popular crypto platform, appears to have successfully upgraded its software architecture from a type of blockchain known as “proof of work,” which it has run since its inception in 2015, to a type of blockchain known as “proof of stake.” (Sarah Pabst/The New York Times)

“There was a widespread view among traders that the Merge was a ‘sell-the-news’ event despite the upgrade’s long-term positive impacts,” Christine Kim, a research associate at Galaxy Digital, wrote on Twitter.
The overhaul has changed how transactions on the Ethereum blockchain occur and how ether tokens are created.
A physical imitation of the Ethereum cryptocurrency. A change in how Ethereum is minted could, by some estimates, reduce power usage on the network by as much as 99.5 per cent.
The hotly-anticipated Merge, expected around Sep 15, will transition Ethereum to a more energy efficient network.

site_title: As US IPO market languishes, listings head east to booming China
summary: The US IPO market is experiencing a slump, with listings shifting east to China as investors seek more stable markets. Chinese IPOs have raised $104 billion this year, accounting for 68% of global volume, while US IPOs represent 14% of global volume. This is the lowest ever for the US, traditionally the busiest listings market. The trend is driven by Chinese companies' continued success despite rising interest rates and recession concerns, with 6 of the 10 largest global listings this year coming from Chinese companies.

images.alt_text: While fewer consumers mentioned supply shortages and gas prices are falling, other measures of inflation are still accelerating and widespread, such as costs for food and shelter.

site_title: Stellantis and Renault halt Spanish assembly lines as chip shortage persists
summary: Stellantis and Renault, two major car manufacturers, are halting production at their Spanish plants due to the ongoing global chip shortage. Renault's two factories in Castile and Leon will temporarily shut down, with one factory stopping production entirely and the other cancelling shifts. Stellantis' plant in Vigo will also halt production for 15 days, citing the ongoing supply shortage. This is the latest in a series of production halts by both companies in recent months, highlighting the ongoing impact of the pandemic and booming demand on the automotive sector.

images.alt_text: Dacia has only one electric model, Dacia Spring, which accounts for 12 per cent of its order intakes.
Stellantis will recognise a non-cash impairment of around 297 million euros (S$420.8 million) for its first half-year results, the company said.

site_title: US appeals court rules against big tech’s ability to regulate online speech
summary: A US appeals court has upheld a Texas law that prohibits large social media companies from banning or censoring users based on "viewpoint". The 5th US Circuit Court of Appeals ruling sets up a potential case for the US Supreme Court, which conservatives have sought to combat "Big Tech" from suppressing their views. The law, passed by the Republican-led legislature, forbids social media companies from censoring users based on viewpoint, allowing users or the Texas attorney general to sue to enforce it.

images.alt_text: Etno, Europe’s lobby for telecoms operators, said in a report in May that more than half of the global network traffic is attributable to 6 firms, including Google.
Alphabet’s Google, Apple, Amazon.com and Meta Platforms and their trade groups have poured almost US$95 million into lobbying since 2021 to derail the American Innovation and Choice Online Act.

site_title: Credit Suisse considers rebranding investment bank First Boston: sources
summary: Credit Suisse is considering reviving the First Boston brand name for its investment bank division, which was retired in 2005, as part of efforts to boost the unit's fortunes. The move could be a precursor to a potential spin-off or separation of the investment banking business. Credit Suisse is undergoing a comprehensive strategy review, with new CEO Ulrich Koerner set to present a new strategic direction next month. The bank's shares have fallen nearly 60% in the past 18 months amid scandals and losses.

images.alt_text: The shift in strategy by CS Trust’s legal team represents an attempt to draw a line in the sand and to limit the potential fallout from damaging testimony from trust staff earlier in the trial following a court loss to Ivanishvili earlier this year.

site_title: Europe: Shares slide as recession fears grip global markets
summary: Europe's shares slid 1.6% on Friday, September 16, amid recession fears and interest rate hike bets. The Stoxx 600 fell 2.9% for its worst week in three months, with industrials, healthcare, and financials leading the decline. The World Bank warned of a possible global recession, while the International Monetary Fund expected a slowdown in the third quarter. The US Federal Reserve is set to deliver its third 75-basis-point hike, further exacerbating concerns.

images.alt_text: London’s FTSE 100 index slid 0.5 per cent to 7,244.94 points, hit also by tumbling UK retail sales.

site_title: Global equity funds see fourth weekly outflow on rate hike expectations
summary: Global equity funds saw their fourth consecutive weekly outflow, totaling US$13.11 billion, amid expectations of continued interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve and risk of a global recession. This follows a previous week's outflow of US$23.02 billion. The outflows were driven by concerns over inflation and the impact of interest rate increases on the economy. In contrast, Asia equity funds received US$740 million in inflows, while consumer staples funds attracted US$1.38 billion.

images.alt_text: A trader works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., September 6, 2022.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Singapore, Cambodia agree to deepen clean energy cooperation
summary: Singapore and Cambodia have agreed to deepen their clean energy cooperation, with Cambodia welcoming investment in renewable energy and technologies from Singapore. The two countries aim to advance solutions for clean energy through a shared interest. A virtual meeting between Cambodian Minister for Mines and Energy Suy Sem and Singapore's Manpower Minister Tan See Leng led to the joint statement. The agreement seeks to promote energy transition and power trade in the region.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting

This undated handout photograph released by Singapore's national water agency PUB on July 14, 2021 shows an aerial view of Sembcorb energy company's new floating solar power farm at Tengeh reservoir in Singapore.
