site_title: Asia: Stocks edge higher, with all eyes on Federal Reserve rate path
summary: Asian stocks edged higher on Thursday, rebounding from steep losses the previous week due to higher-than-expected US inflation data. Investors remain cautious about the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes, with a 75 basis-point rise expected next week. Asian currencies, particularly the Australian dollar and yen, remain at risk due to the strong US dollar. The Fed's decision is seen as a key driver of market sentiment, with some analysts predicting a full percentage-point rise.

images.alt_text: Tokyo, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Seoul, Taipei and Sydney all opened lower at the start of trading on Wednesday, reversing gains made in recent days

site_title: Patagonia founder gives away firm to help fight climate crisis
summary: Yvon Chouinard, billionaire founder of Patagonia, is giving away the company to a trust that will use its profits to fight the climate crisis. Chouinard transferred his family's ownership to a trust and a non-profit organization, transferring the company's voting stock to the Patagonia Purpose Trust and non-voting stock to the Holdfast Collective. The trust will be overseen by family members and will distribute annual profits to fight the climate crisis, with no financial benefit to Chouinard or his family, who will face a tax bill from the donation.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise at the open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.44% at the open on September 15, 2022, following Wall Street gains. The Hang Seng Index increased to 18,929.22, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.3%. The gains came after a rout earlier in the week due to US inflation data.

site_title: Brokers’ take: UOBKH downgrades SGX, slashes price target on lack of near-term catalysts
summary: UOB Kay Hian has downgraded its call on Singapore Exchange (SGX) to "hold" from "buy" and lowered its price target to S$10.04 due to the lack of near-term catalysts. Analyst Llelleythan Tan believes homecoming dual listings, such as Sea's, will have a "muted impact" on SGX's earnings and target price. Tan still likes SGX for its resilient business model, but recommends waiting for better entry points. The revised price target implies a lower price-to-earnings multiple, reflecting reduced expectations for the bourse.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

site_title: Most European investments in China are from a few firms, study says
summary: European investments in China are increasingly concentrated among a few large corporations, mostly German firms. The top 10 European companies invested nearly 80% of total European investments in China between 2018 and 2021. German businesses, including Volkswagen, BMW, and BASF, accounted for over two-fifths of these investments. This concentration of corporate risks may lead policymakers to reconsider measures to reduce economic dependence on China, amid growing political scrutiny.

images.alt_text: It’s not just China’s strict Covid Zero policy of lockdowns and mass testing that’s buffeting the economy. A housing market collapse, drought, and weak demand both at home and overseas have all undercut growth.

site_title: UOBKH sees Indonesian retailers as relatively shielded from fuel hikes
summary: UOB Kay Hian (UOBKH) believes Indonesian retailers will continue to perform well despite a 30% fuel price hike, citing data from Bank Indonesia's Retail Sales Index (RSI) that shows a recovery in purchasing power after previous hikes. The brokerage selected top picks in the sector, including Mitra Adiperkasa, Matahari Department Store, and Erajaya Swasembada, due to lower cost structures. Analyst Stevanus Juanda is also optimistic on pharmaceutical group Kalbe Farma and food and beverage company Mayora Indah.

site_title: Australia’s central bank review panel considers board shake-up
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia's central bank review panel considers a potential overhaul of its interest rate-setting board, which could lead to more monetary policy experts and fewer business representatives. The review aims to evaluate Australia's monetary policy arrangements, including the board's composition and communication practices. The panel also explores lessons from past enquiries, such as the Federal Reserve and European Central Bank, to strengthen monetary policy decisions. The review is expected to deliver a final report in March, with Governor Philip Lowe's term set to expire shortly after.

site_title: China property shares rally on hopes of more relaxation measures
summary: Chinese property shares rallied over 5% in Hong Kong and 4% in China's CSI Real Estate Index on hopes of more relaxation measures to boost the sector. The southern Chinese city of Guangzhou will allow bigger reductions in home prices, with up to 20% cuts from 6% previously. This is the largest cut by any top-tier city in the country, sparking optimism among investors.

summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.2% to 3,264.73, tracking US gains despite concerns over inflation. Advancers outnumbered decliners 73 to 25, with top-traded stocks including Ley Choon, Addvalue Tech, and Sembcorp Marine. Local banks OCBC and UOB were mixed, while DBS declined. The benchmark Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.1%, while European shares declined 0.9% on Wednesday.

site_title: Temasek’s CLA Real Estate sets up life sciences investment company
summary: CLA Real Estate Holdings, a subsidiary of Temasek, has established ClavystBio, a life sciences investment company, to invest in emerging companies and develop an innovation district in Singapore. Led by CEO Dr. Christopher Laing, the company has made $220 million in investment commitments to 6 early-stage companies and 3 venture partners. ClavystBio aims to support cell and gene therapy, biomarkers, and digital health startups, with plans to create an innovation district and collaborate with academics, investors, and startups to drive intellectual property translation and ecosystem-building.

site_title: Scholz says Putin still doesn’t see invading Ukraine as ‘mistake’
summary: German Chancellor Olaf Scholz stated that Russian President Vladimir Putin still believes the invasion of Ukraine was justified, contrary to Scholz's hopes for a shift in Putin's stance. During a 90-minute phone call, Scholz urged Putin to seek a diplomatic solution with a ceasefire, withdrawal of forces, and respect for Ukraine's sovereignty. While Putin's positions did not change, Scholz emphasized the importance of continued communication with the Russian leader to explore a peaceful resolution.

site_title: Australia: Shares climb on energy boost, unemployment rate in focus
summary: Australia's shares rose 0.33% on Thursday, driven by energy stocks following strong commodity prices, despite a sharp sell-off in the previous session. The S&P/ASX 200 index is awaiting the release of the unemployment rate, which is expected to remain at 3.4% in August. Energy sector majors, such as Woodside Energy and Santos, climbed 3% and 1.7%, respectively.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index ended 2.6 per cent lower at 6,828.6 points, snapping 4 sessions of gains.

site_title: California sues Amazon for allegedly thwarting lower prices
summary: California's Attorney General Rob Bonta filed a lawsuit against Amazon, alleging the company uses its market influence to prevent merchants from offering lower prices on other websites, in violation of state antitrust law. Amazon requires merchants to not list items at lower prices on other websites, hurting sellers and consumers. If the court rules in favor of California, Amazon could be ordered to stop its price-floor practice and pay unspecified damages.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Thursday, rising 9.70 points or 0.66% to 1,478.14. The index saw 124.81 million lots traded worth RM56.36 million, with 183 gains outweighing 76 losses.

site_title: New Zealand economy rebounds in Q2 as tourists return
summary: New Zealand's economy rebounded in Q2, growing 1.7% in the June quarter, beating forecasts and recovering from a 0.2% drop in the first quarter. The surge in tourism and lifting of COVID-19 restrictions contributed to the growth, but annual growth slowed to 0.4% due to soaring cost pressures and interest rate hikes. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand has already raised interest rates to 3.0% and expects further hikes to contain inflation, which reached a 3-decade peak of 7.3% in the June quarter.

images.alt_text: From midnight tonight, travellers to New Zealand will no longer need to be vaccinated or forced to submit rapid antigen test results after they arrive.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Tokyo shares opened higher on Thursday, adding 0.25% to 27,887.81 on the Nikkei 225 index, following gains on Wall Street. The move reversed sharp losses from the previous day, driven by US inflation concerns. The broader Topix index rose 0.11%.

site_title: Disney CEO Chapek considering merging company’s Hulu and Disney+ services
summary: Disney CEO Bob Chapek is considering merging Hulu and Disney+ services in the US, creating a single online option for viewing the company's movies and TV shows. The move aims to eliminate friction consumers feel when switching between the apps. A merger would require Disney to buy out Comcast's 33% stake in Hulu, with plans to acquire it by 2024. The combined service would offer general entertainment and adult content, while maintaining separate services for sports (ESPN+) and other international content.

site_title: Dutch students devise carbon-eating electric vehicle
summary: Dutch students from the Eindhoven University of Technology have developed a carbon-eating electric vehicle called ZEM, which captures more carbon than it emits. The 2-seater car houses a Cleantron lithium-ion battery pack and most of its parts are 3D-printed from recycled plastics. ZEM's filters can capture up to 2 kilograms of CO2 over 20,000 miles of driving, aiming to minimize carbon dioxide emissions throughout its full lifespan. The vehicle is part of the team's goal to create a more sustainable future.

site_title: Gold dips on stronger dollar, Fed concerns
summary: Gold prices fell 0.1% to $1,693.81 per ounce due to a stronger US dollar and expectations of higher interest rates from the Federal Reserve. A firmer dollar makes gold more expensive for foreign buyers, while rising interest rates increase the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion. Spot silver also declined, with platinum and palladium experiencing minor losses. The US Federal Reserve's hawkish stance is expected to continue, impacting the metals market.

images.alt_text: Gold bars sit stacked in this arranged photograph at Solar Capital Gold Zrt. in Budapest, Hungary, on Thursday, March 10, 2016. Gold advanced to the highest level in a year after the European Central Bank indicated it wouldnÕt cut interest rates further, boosting the euro and making dollar-denominated bullion less expensive for investors. Even though gold is seen as a hedge against inflation, higher interest rates increase the opportunity cost of holding the bullion while boosts the dollar, in which the precious metal is priced.

site_title: TikTok search results rife with misinformation: report
summary: A report by NewsGuard found that 19.5% of search results from top 20 news topics on TikTok contained false or misleading claims, including conspiracy theories and medical misinformation. Researchers compared TikTok and Google results for various news topics, including school shootings, abortion, and Covid-19. TikTok responded, stating its Community Guidelines prohibit harmful misinformation and that it partners with credible voices and independent fact-checkers to assess content accuracy.

site_title: Japan posts record trade deficit in August
summary: Japan posted a record trade deficit of 2.8173 trillion yen ($27.7 billion) in August, driven by a 49.9% surge in imports due to high fuel costs and a weakened yen. The trade deficit marked the 13th consecutive month of year-on-year shortfalls, exposing Japan's economy's vulnerability to external price pressures. Despite a growing economy, analysts say the recovery remains fragile due to risks from a global slowdown and tightening monetary policy.

images.alt_text: Unlike its peers, the BOJ has maintained its ultra-low interest rates to support the economy.

Japanese Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki told reporters that recent yen moves have been “rapid and 1-sided”, adding that yen-buying currency intervention was among the government’s options should such moves continue.

site_title: UK consumer confidence drop feeds concern about house prices
summary: UK consumer confidence dropped to 98.8 in August, the first time since the 2020 pandemic lockdown, due to inflation nearing a 40-year high and concerns about house prices. Homeowners are more pessimistic about their property values, job security, and personal finances. The survey reflects a tightening squeeze on living standards, with mortgage costs rising to the highest since 2016 and investors anticipating a further rate hike. Consumers are more downbeat about the future value of their own homes, with a price correction in the property market expected.

images.alt_text: Prices for vehicle fuels and lubricants dropped by 6.8 per cent in August, their largest monthly fall since April 2020.

site_title: Straits Trading to pay special dividend early, ratify shareholder approval at a later date
summary: Straits Trading has decided to proceed with its proposed special dividend early, despite not formally garnering shareholder approval at an extraordinary general meeting. The decision was made after receiving an irrevocable undertaking from a shareholder with sufficient voting rights, allowing the company to ratify shareholder approval at a later date, no later than the next annual general meeting. The special dividend is intended to reward shareholders for their continued support and allow them to participate further in the company's growth.

site_title: Google cuts funding, jobs at its new idea incubator
summary: Google is cutting funding and jobs at Area 120, its in-house incubator for new projects, to focus on artificial intelligence and control spending amid a potential economic recession. Half of the teams at Area 120 have been affected, with workers needing to find new roles within a certain period or lose their jobs. The company will continue to incubate new projects, shifting focus to AI-driven initiatives. This move follows Alphabet's plan to prioritize financial discipline and focus on critical engineering and technical roles.

summary: Tesla's plan to expand its factory grounds in Germany has been put on hold after the mayor of Gruenheide, where the factory is located, removed the item from the agenda of the local municipal council. The expansion, which would have added 100 hectares to the existing 300 hectares of land, was submitted in May but requires further clarification. The mayor cited a need for more information before addressing the issue this year. Tesla did not immediately respond to the news.

site_title: Amazon opens the email marketing floodgates to try to boost sales
summary: Amazon is launching an email marketing initiative, allowing brands and merchants to send marketing emails to shoppers, as part of its efforts to boost sales and maintain its edge in the e-commerce market. The new "Tailored Audiences" tool will enable sellers to monitor results and connect with customers through a new feature on Alexa. The move marks a shift for Amazon, which initially resisted direct merchant-customer communication, amid slowing online sales and antitrust investigations.

site_title: How the tide turned on data centres in Europe
summary: European countries' enthusiasm for data centres, or "bit barns," has turned sour due to the massive energy and water consumption required to power and cool the server farms. Grassroots campaigns and local opposition have halted projects by Amazon, Google, and Meta in France, Luxembourg, and the Netherlands. Ireland has implemented strict limits on new developments until 2028, while the data industry argues it's unfairly targeted and is working to source green energy. The industry's carbon footprint remains unclear, with critics questioning its sustainability and critics of data centres pointing to the energy-intensive nature of emerging technologies like the metaverse.

images.alt_text: Equinix South Asia managing director Leong Yee May welcomed the increased capacity as larger data centres can benefit from economies of scale when employing advanced cooling techniques.

Demand for data centres - the buildings that house computer systems and servers that store and process the world's data - has skyrocketed due to the widespread adoption of digital communication tools and e-commerce.

site_title: Arm launches new chip design for cloud and data centre
summary: Arm, a British chip technology firm, launched its next-generation data centre chip technology called Neoverse V2 to meet the growing demand for data processing from 5G and internet-connected devices. The new design increases power efficiency, and companies such as Ampere, Amazon, Fujitsu, and Alibaba already develop processor chips based on Arm technology for their data centres. This move aims to challenge Intel and Advanced Micro Devices' dominance in the data centre processor market.

site_title: Tesla sued for ‘deceiving’ consumers about self-driving cars
summary: Tesla is sued by a California man alleging the company "deceived" consumers about its self-driving cars. The plaintiff claims Tesla's CEO, Elon Musk, made false promises about a fully self-driving car, despite the technology not being available. Musk previously stated that solving full self-driving technology is crucial for Tesla's success, and the company has charged customers extra for its driver-assistance system, Full Self-Driving. The lawsuit follows a California Department of Motor Vehicles administrative complaint accusing Tesla of false advertising.

site_title: EU’s green rulebook loses a bit more credibility as NGOs quit
summary: A group of non-governmental organizations (NGOs) has quit the EU Platform on Sustainable Finance due to accusations that the European Commission has politicized the process and ignored scientific recommendations. The NGOs, including the European Consumer Organisation, accused the EU bodies of acting against evidence and prioritizing politics over science. This move further erodes the credibility of the EU's green taxonomy, a framework intended to guide environmentally friendly investments.

site_title: South Korea, US will step up efforts to resolve electric-vehicle spat
summary: South Korea and the US are stepping up efforts to resolve a dispute over electric-vehicle (EV) subsidies, with talks set to begin on Friday. The US's "Inflation Reduction Act" rules out tax breaks for EVs assembled abroad, affecting South Korean automakers Hyundai and Kia, as well as battery makers LG Energy Solution. South Korea's Trade Minister Ahn Duk-geun hopes for a breakthrough in discussions, playing down any possible linkage with other areas of cooperation, such as chip-making alliances and the US-led Indo-Pacific Economic Framework for Prosperity.

(Photo by Ben STANSALL / AFP)##########kelgrid8##########

site_title: Chuan Park en bloc sale dissenters file objection with Strata Titles Board
summary: Dissenting owners of Chuan Park condo have filed objections with the Strata Titles Board, alleging that the Collective Sale Committee and ERA Realty failed to disclose a higher development baseline, resulting in a "deep discount" for buyers. The baseline, set by the Urban Redevelopment Authority, should be 2.4, but the actual plot ratio used in the valuation is 2.1, allowing buyers to build an additional 11,671 sq m of built-up area. The dissenters claim this material fact was not disclosed to owners and was used in marketing the site to potential buyers.

images.alt_text: Chuan Park FB posts: A case of putting cart before the horse?
Chuan Park owners to get S$1.16m to S$2.53m each; some unhappy with lack of timely updates
There will be an owners’ meeting on Jul 25, at which information will be shared on the preparation for the next stages and the estimated timeline for the sale completion.
Based on the EOI offer price of S$860 million, owners of residential units could stand to receive sales proceeds of between S$1.11 million to S$2.44 million.

site_title: Malaysia car sales on pace to exceed 2022 forecast, despite rising inflation and higher costs
summary: Malaysia's car sales are on pace to exceed 2022 forecasts, with 380,595 vehicles sold in the first 7 months of 2022, according to the Malaysian Automotive Association. The country's tax exemptions, which amount to RM4.7 billion, have contributed to the surge in car sales. However, rising inflation, higher costs, and soaring interest rates may impact demand in the coming year, with some analysts predicting potential dropouts and inventory buildups among car manufacturers.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians walk past a Charles & Keith store in downtown Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Sunday, March 17, 2013. Malaysia is scheduled to release inflation data for February on March 20. Photographer: Sanjit Das/Bloomberg

site_title: Oil rises 1% on supply concerns, expectations for fuel switching
summary: Oil prices rose 1% on Wednesday, with Brent crude futures settling at $94.10 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude ending at $88.48 a barrel. This increase was driven by concerns over gas-to-oil switching due to high prices this winter, as well as weak supply growth and a decrease in global inventories. Despite gloomy demand expectations, analysts believe prices will remain in a range between $70 and $100 per barrel.

images.alt_text: US October crude futures closed down 47 cents on Tuesday, or 0.5 per cent, at US$87.31, after touching a high of US$89.31 and low of US$85.06.

site_title: China braces for a slowdown that could be even worse than 2020
summary: China's economy is facing a slowdown, with growth projections cut to 3.5% for the year, the second-weakest annual reading in over 40 years. The country's strict Covid Zero policy, housing market collapse, drought, and weak demand are major factors. Banks no longer expect 3% growth, with some predicting even slower growth. The government's cash crunch faced by developers will extend into 2023, and weak confidence in the real estate market will hold back any meaningful recovery. The Communist Party's leadership congress in October may not ease the policy, putting the economy in for a difficult period.

images.alt_text: The party conclave will offer clues on who is in line for top posts and identify who succeeds Li Keqiang, who steps down in March after two terms as premier, a position tasked with managing the world’s No 2 economy.
The Cyberspace Administration of China said it wanted to raise the fines for some violations, from up to 100,000 yuan (S$20,191.2) previously to 1 million yuan.

site_title: World’s biggest Ether mining firm to shut down after the ‘Merge’
summary: Ethermine, the largest Ethereum mining services provider by computing power, will shut down its servers for miners after the 'Merge' upgrade, marking the end of proof-of-work mining. The historic upgrade will shift the Ethereum network to proof-of-stake, rendering graphic cards obsolete. Ethermine will trigger an automatic payout to its miners for unpaid balances and will also launch an Ethereum staking pool. Approximately one million people with over $10 billion worth of mining equipment will have to unplug their GPUs after the Merge takes place.

images.alt_text: A worker inspects mining machines at a computation center. Photographer: Christinne Muschi/Bloomberg

site_title: France caps power prices increase at 15% next year to shield consumers
summary: France has capped power price increases at 15% next year to shield consumers from soaring energy costs. The caps, set by Prime Minister Elisabeth Borne, will take effect in January for gas and a month later for electricity. This move aims to protect households from a 200-25 euro monthly price hike. The measures are part of France's efforts to tackle the energy crisis, with the government spending billions on measures to dampen inflation.

site_title: Europe: Shares extend declines driven by policy tightening fears
summary: European shares declined 0.9% on Wednesday, weighed down by concerns over policy tightening and inflation, despite a rally in oil stocks. Higher-than-expected US inflation data strengthened the case for a third 75-basis-point interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve. The Stoxx 600 index has fallen 14% this year, outperforming the S&P 500's 17% decline and the Nasdaq's 25% drop.

images.alt_text: London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index dropped 0.7 per cent to 7,332.01 points, as investors also digested news that UK inflation slowed in August but held near a 40-year peak.

site_title: BT Podcast: Are S-REITs a good hedge against inflation?
summary: Singapore real estate investment trusts (S-REITs) can still do well despite a rough first half of 2022, as rising interest rates create a favorable environment. Analyst Vijay Natarajan of RHB Singapore notes that S-REITs can serve as a hedge against inflation, and their outlook moving forward is positive, despite growing competition from other Asian REIT markets.

images.alt_text: SGX CEO Loh Boon Chye (centre), flanked by members of Reitas' exco and management, at an event celebrating 20 years of S-Reits.

site_title: Tapping into payments insights for retail revival
summary: Shoppers in Singapore expect personalized retail experiences and flexible payment options, with 67% of consumers expecting retailers to maintain pandemic-era approaches. As the Great Singapore Sale returns, brands must adapt to growing demand for both online and offline shopping, as well as contactless payments. Over half of Singaporean consumers are returning to brick-and-mortar stores despite online shopping, emphasizing the need for operational agility and smooth retail experiences.

images.alt_text: Shoppers using the escalators at NEX shopping mall on 15 Feb 2022.##########pic##########KUA CHEE SIONG

Even though the current strata retail market is nowhere near the sales performances recorded in 2012 and 2013, there are promising signs that interest in strata-titled retail space could rekindle in the next 12 to 18 months. While the lingering threat of Covid-19 remains, Singapore has resolutely reopened at a time when revenge travel and shopping is gaining momentum.
Meanwhile, food and beverage (F&B) services saw sales swell by 41.9 per cent from the previous year, extending the 59.1 per cent growth registered in June.

site_title: US producer prices fall for a second month as fuel costs retreat
summary: US producer prices fell 0.1% in August, marking a second consecutive decline, as fuel costs retreated. Despite this, the core PPI rose 0.4% and 7.3% year-over-year, indicating persistent inflation in the production pipeline. The Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates by another 75 basis points next week amid mounting concerns about US inflation.

site_title: Asset managers are facing hundreds of ESG fund downgrades
summary: Asset managers in Europe are facing hundreds of ESG fund downgrades due to the EU's strict sustainability requirements. Only a small fraction of funds registered as Article 9, the EU's strictest ESG category, meet the required level of sustainable investments. Many fund managers are reclassifying their funds to a less strict ESG designation, Article 8, to comply with the rules. This has resulted in clients being left with a less clean ESG product than expected. Regulators are struggling to interpret the rules, and some fund managers are trying to find a way to meet the EU's 80% sustainable asset threshold without actually investing in sustainable assets.

images.alt_text: european union eu flag Photographer: Yuriko Nakao/Bloomberg
A key trend amid record dealmaking is the accelerating shift to ESG investing.

site_title: Empowering CSOs from the boardroom
summary: Businesses must embed ESG and sustainability practices to create value for both the environment and the bottom line. Companies that adopt a coherent ESG strategy and demonstrate tangible success may benefit from lower cost of capital. Chief sustainability officers (CSOs) play a crucial role in driving ESG efforts, and board support is essential for their success. Boards must ensure CSOs are strategically positioned, governance is in place, and ESG reporting is robust to meet the growing demand for genuine ESG leaders.

images.alt_text: SGX and MAS launched ESGenome, a disclosure portal for corporates to report their ESG data, on Monday (Sep 12).

A worker watering plants outside Singapore's ArtScience Museum on a sweltering day in July. The National Climate Change Secretariat (NCCS) says the public can give their views on the 2050 timeline and the possibility of an updated 2030 target via government feedback portal Reach. The public consultation exercise opened on Monday and closes on Sept 26.

site_title: Private equity investments in SE Asia surge as ESG investing goes mainstream
summary: Private equity investments in Southeast Asia reached a record $25 billion in 2021, a 143% increase from 2020. Internet and tech investments made up the largest share of deal value and volume. Early-stage company investments increased fivefold, while growth company investments rose 143%. Exit values rebounded to $8 billion, with Singapore contributing most of the increase. This surge follows a sharp decline in 2020 amid COVID-19 lockdowns.

images.alt_text: A key attraction for new private equity entrants is the standout returns Tokyo’s office market has delivered so far this year.

site_title: Twilio to cut staff by 11% to rein in costs, lift margins
summary: Twilio plans to cut 11% of its staff, approximately 870 employees, to reduce costs and boost margins amid declining demand for cloud services. The restructuring is expected to incur charges of $70-90 million. The San Francisco-based cloud communications platform aims to complete the restructuring by the end of the fourth quarter. Following the announcement, Twilio's shares rose nearly 3% in morning trade.

site_title: Credit Suisse-tycoon clash has wealth industry holding its breath
summary: A US$800 million lawsuit filed by Georgian billionaire Bidzina Ivanishvili against Credit Suisse Trust (Singapore) is set to become a test case for the global wealth management industry, potentially forcing a rethink on how and when trust operators flag unusual transactions or shady practices. Ivanishvili's lawsuit claims the trustee failed to intervene when it became aware of suspicious activities by a private banker in 2006. The case may lead to a reevaluation of the limits of responsibility within trust deeds, with some arguing that trustees must intervene in cases of wrongdoing, despite not being bound to do so under their contracts.

images.alt_text: One of the key questions for the Singapore judge to evaluate is whether Credit Suisse or any of its units bear responsibility for Lescaudron’s behaviour. The Zurich-based bank has repeatedly argued that the Frenchman was a lone wolf who hid his crimes from his colleagues and supervisors around the world.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher after rout on rate hike worries
summary: Wall Street opened higher on September 14, 2022, after a sharp selloff in the previous session due to concerns over the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 36.05 points, or 0.12%, to 31,141.02, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained. The rally came despite red-hot inflation data fueling worries about the Fed's future rate hikes.

site_title: End of the Covid-19 pandemic is in sight: WHO chief
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus said the world is in a better position to end the Covid-19 pandemic, with deaths from the virus at their lowest since March 2020. The virus has killed nearly 6.5 million people and infected 606 million, but vaccination efforts and therapies have helped to stem the severity of disease. Tedros urged nations to strengthen their policies, vaccinate 100% of high-risk groups, and maintain adequate medical equipment and healthcare workers to prevent future waves of infections.

site_title: As ‘the Merge’ draws near, Ethereum takes one big step towards going green
summary: Ethereum is set to undergo a significant change, dubbed "the Merge," which aims to reduce power usage on the network by up to 99.5%. The change, expected to occur on Thursday, will transition the cryptocurrency from "proof of work" to "proof of stake," a more energy-efficient model. This shift could have far-reaching consequences, including a reduction in mining activity and a potential increase in Ethereum's market capitalization, potentially rivaling that of Bitcoin. Analysts predict that the successful Merge could lead to a wave of investment and further innovation in the cryptocurrency sector.

images.alt_text: The hotly-anticipated Merge, expected around Sep 15, will transition Ethereum to a more energy efficient network.
The hotly-anticipated Merge, expected around Sep 15, will transition Ethereum to a more energy efficient network.

site_title: Xi visits Uzbekistan ahead of meeting with Putin
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping visited Uzbekistan ahead of a meeting with Russian leader Vladimir Putin at the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) summit in Samarkand, Uzbekistan. Xi arrived on Wednesday evening and was met by officials, including Uzbek President Shavkat Mirziyoyev. The SCO summit brings together leaders from China, Russia, India, Pakistan, Kazakhstan, and other Central Asian countries to discuss regional and international issues. Xi's visit comes amid China's growing economic presence in the region, particularly through its Belt and Road Initiative.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: China's President Xi Jinping gives a speech following a swearing-in ceremony to inaugurate the city's new leader and government in Hong Kong, China, July 1, 2022, Selim Chtayti/Pool via REUTERS/File Photo
Chinese President Xi Jinping is welcomed by Kazakh President Kassym-Jomart Tokayev upon his arrival in Nur-Sultan, Kazakhstan on Sep 14, 2022.

The party conclave will offer clues on who is in line for top posts and identify who succeeds Li Keqiang, who steps down in March after two terms as premier, a position tasked with managing the world’s No 2 economy.

site_title: 3-year-old Singaporean girl dies from Covid-19 infection
summary: A 3-year-old Singaporean girl died from a Covid-19 infection, with a history of multiple medical conditions. She tested positive for the virus on August 9 and was admitted to hospital on August 13. The cause of death was anoxic brain injury due to cardiac arrest and Covid-19. This is the third child under 12 to die from Covid-19 in Singapore, with a total of 1,604 deaths since the pandemic began in 2020.

images.alt_text: A vial of the Moderna coronavirus disease (Covid-19) booster vaccine targeting BA.4 and BA.5 Omicron sub variants. Official recommendations for this booster vaccine will be issued by the Expert Committee on Covid-19 Vaccination and the Ministry of Health in due time, HSA said.

site_title: Low Keng Huat sinks into red with H1 loss on slower project sales, disposal loss
summary: Low Keng Huat, a Singapore-listed property firm, reported a net loss of S$24.1 million for the half year to July, down from a S$25.1 million net profit in the year-ago period. Revenue declined 44% to S$49.8 million, mainly due to slower property sales for the development segment. The company's hotel and investment segments both reported higher turnover, but the development segment registered a significant loss of S$372,000.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Stocks to watch: Singtel, First Reit, Keppel Corp, Sembmarine, Low Keng Huat, Wing Tai
Low Keng Huat sinks deeper into red in H2 with S$4.3m loss

site_title: SCA honours leaders in corporate governance , Events & Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: Global economies face heightened uncertainty and macroeconomic challenges, prompting the need for effective risk management. The ongoing Russia-Ukraine conflict and rising inflation have increased market volatility, while supply chain disruptions and trade tensions add to the uncertainty. To mitigate these risks, investors and businesses must diversify, invest in resilience-building strategies, and maintain a flexible approach to navigating complex market conditions. Central banks are also expected to take proactive measures to stabilize financial markets and maintain economic growth. Proactive risk management is crucial for navigating the current macroeconomic landscape.

site_title: Keppel O&M entity gets interim injunction to forbid payment on US$126.6m letter of credit
summary: Keppel Offshore and Marine (Keppel O&M) entity received an interim injunction from a Singapore court to prevent payment on a US$126.6 million standby letter of credit due to a dispute over rig contract terms. The entity had provided the letter of credit to a customer after a government authority deemed certain contractual formulas invalid. Keppel considers the decision premature and has filed legal proceedings to challenge it. The company believes no material impact on its financial performance will occur.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
The Keppel O&M entity has also filed legal proceedings in the local court to challenge the decision of the relevant authority.

site_title: FHT’s failed privatisation not a complete surprise as unitholders bet on tourism recovery
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust (FHT) failed to garner the required 75% of votes for its proposed privatization, missing by 0.12%. The offer, which valued the Reit at a 7% premium to net asset value, was seen as opportunistic given the hospitality sector's resurgence amid the easing of Covid-19 curbs and border re-openings. Minority unitholders may have felt that the Reit had not yet lived up to its promise, with its portfolio consisting of just 15 properties as of Sep 30, 2021. FHT may consider strategic divestments or the acquisition of another hospitality Reit to rejuvenate its portfolio.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
The superior bedroom in Capri by Fraser China Square. Only 74.88 per cent of shareholder votes were cast in favour of the take-private resolution; 75 per cent is required.
FHT dropped to a low of S$0.535 right when the market opened on Tuesday, down 24.1 per cent or S$0.17. The last time the counter closed near this level was Apr 1, 2022.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 19.40 points to 1,468.44. A total of 2.631 billion lots worth RM1.633 billion changed hands, with losers outnumbering gainers 595 to 256.

site_title: SoftBank considers launching third Vision Fund
summary: SoftBank is considering launching a third Vision Fund, potentially using its own capital, after the second fund reported a $50 billion loss in the first half of the year. The new fund's size has not been finalized, but it may launch early next year. SoftBank's plans are subject to change, and the company has already scaled back investment activity and sold shares in Alibaba. The move comes after the tech conglomerate's first two Vision Funds were impacted by a global tech rout and underperforming investments.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: CEO of the SoftBank Group Masayoshi Son speaks at a new conference in London, Britain July 18, 2016. REUTERS/Neil Hall/File Photo

site_title: UK monarchy criticised over staff redundancy notices
summary: The UK monarchy has faced criticism for issuing redundancy notices to up to 100 employees at King Charles III's former official residence, Clarence House. The decision was made following Charles' accession to the throne, which led to the cessation of operations at the residence. The Public and Commercial Services Union (PCS) described the move as "callous" and "heartless," particularly during a period of mourning for the late Queen Elizabeth II. Redundancy payments will be offered to affected employees, with none expected to be affected for at least 3 months.

site_title: UOB says physical presence will help it compete in digital age
summary: UOB plans to focus on transforming its physical engagement to compete in the digital age, leveraging the combination of data, technology, and human expertise to serve customers more holistically. The bank will also prioritize onboarding customers from its newly acquired Citi portfolio, with a regional brand campaign launched to enhance its presence. According to Jacquelyn Tan, head of group personal financial services, the bank's physical presence will provide a competitive edge in the region.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun

“One bullet is sufficient, you don’t need to fire many,” said UOB deputy chairman and chief executive Wee Ee Cheong about acquiring Citi consumer business in 4 Asean countries. “In life, all you need is to make 1 or 2 meaningful decisions to put you through.”
Kevin Lam, head of TMRW and group digital banking at UOB, believes that having an open mind and being ready for new ideas is key in the ever-changing banking industry.
From left: Kavita Bedi, UOB’s country head of business banking Singapore; Lawrence Loh, head of group business banking; and Rosalind Lee, head of enterprise banking, at the launch of the UOB SME app.

site_title: Green Stock Exchange focused on ESG seeks path to Wall Street
summary: Green Exchange PBC, seeking regulatory approval, plans to launch the Green Impact Exchange (GIX) in 2023, a new stock exchange exclusively for environmentally focused companies. GIX will require public companies to demonstrate and adhere to ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) efforts, with delisting and penalties for non-compliance. The exchange, founded by former NYSE executives, aims to cater to the growing demand for sustainable investments, with investors increasingly looking to preserve natural resources amid mounting pressure. GIX will enforce green-listing standards and allow investors to trade equities with ESG commitments.

site_title: Billionaire Adani’s unit eyes acquisitions to push food business
summary: Billionaire Gautam Adani's company, Adani Wilmar, is planning to acquire local and overseas brands to boost its food operations. The company has earmarked 5 billion rupees (S$88.4 million) from its initial public offering for purchases and expects to conclude a couple of acquisitions by March. This move comes as Adani Group and Reliance Industries, controlled by Mukesh Ambani, try to capture India's food production industry valued at US$400 billion. Adani Wilmar has already acquired several brands, including the Kohinoor cooking brand, and is witnessing 50% growth in e-commerce distribution via Amazon and Flipkart.

images.alt_text: Adani Group, controlled by Asia’s richest person Gautam Adani, acquired a 29.2 per cent stake in news media firm, New Delhi Television or NDTV, and offered to buy another 26 per cent from the open market, as the conglomerate seeks to expand its footprint in India’s media sector.

site_title: A China blockade of Taiwan will hurt everyone
summary: A cold economic war between the US and China, sparked by China's potential blockade of Taiwan, would be disruptive and costly for the global economy. The blockade of Taiwan, which separates the island from mainland China, would disrupt global shipping routes, increasing costs for consumers and companies. The US and its allies would likely impose sanctions on China, forcing governments and multinationals to take sides, and potentially leading to a global economic downturn.

images.alt_text: U.S. Dollar and Chinese Yuan banknotes are seen in this illustration picture taken June 14, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration

site_title: Yen recovers lost ground on BOJ rate check, hints on intervention
summary: The Japanese yen recovers over 1% against the US dollar on September 14 after the Bank of Japan conducted a rate check, reportedly in preparation for currency intervention. The move follows a sharp decline in the yen, which had fallen to a 24-year low of 144.99 yen per dollar last week. Japanese Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki stated that yen-buying intervention is an option if market moves continue, but experts caution that intervention may be challenging due to large interest rate differentials between the US and Japan.

site_title: Slowing growth exacerbates debt strains, corporate bankruptcies loom, warns IIF
summary: The Institute of International Finance (IIF) warns of a significant rise in corporate bankruptcies due to slowing economic growth, rising inflation, and increasing global debt levels. The global debt-to-GDP ratio has reached 350%, with emerging markets experiencing a 3.5 percentage point increase, amid a sharp slowdown in economic growth. Despite a decline in overall world debt, the IIF forecasts a further 2 percentage point rise by year-end, driven by increased borrowing by governments to shore up economies. Higher interest rates and borrowing costs are expected to continue, posing a challenge for central banks to engineer a soft landing.

images.alt_text: Michael Schumacher is in Formula One's thoughts as the seven times world champion approaches his 50th birthday, five years on from the near-fatal skiing accident that has left the Ferrari great fighting brain injuries behind a wall of secrecy.

site_title: China poised to shake up economic leadership as reformers bow out
summary: China is set to undergo its largest overhaul of economic leadership in a decade as reform-minded policymakers step down amid worsening growth prospects. President Xi Jinping is poised to secure a third leadership term, potentially breaking with precedent. Li Keqiang, the current premier, is stepping down after two terms, and his successor will inherit challenges including an exit from the zero-Covid policy and a property crisis. Analysts expect a more state-directed economic model, which could limit the ability of the new team to make major changes.

images.alt_text: The economy was affected by unexpected factors in the second quarter, Li said, reiterating a pledge to stabilise employment and prices.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Non-resident employment rose across all work pass types in Q2, with most coming from work permits and other work passes. Retrenchments fell to a record low in Q2, while job vacancies decreased slightly. Condo and HDB rents rose for the 20th and 26th straight month, respectively. Singapore tourist arrivals grew for the 7th month in August, setting a record. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1% due to US inflation fears.

site_title: Lebanese depositors stage heists to recover money from banks
summary: Lebanese depositors, frustrated with their savings being devalued and trapped in banks for nearly three years, staged a heist at a Blom Bank branch in Beirut, with a woman identified as Sally Hafez reportedly walking out with thousands of dollars to fund her sister's hospital treatment. This incident is part of a growing trend of depositors taking matters into their own hands to recover their money, highlighting the desperation and frustration among Lebanese citizens.

images.alt_text: Lebanon’s banking sector is now widely despised and avoided, and money transfer agencies are filling the gap, also offering currency exchange, credit card and tax payment services and even setting up wedding gift registries.

site_title: China lockdowns weigh on global oil demand: IEA
summary: China's repeated Covid lockdowns and a slowdown in developed economies are weighing on global oil demand, according to the International Energy Agency. Global oil demand is now expected to grow by 2 million barrels per day this year, slightly down from the previous forecast, and is projected to reach 99.7 million barrels per day in 2022 before returning to pre-Covid levels next year if China reopens. The IEA attributes the slowdown to a deteriorating economic environment and recurring Covid lockdowns in China, with a switch from gas to oil for power generation also contributing to the decline.

images.alt_text: Yang Mei Hu oil products tanker owned by COSCO Shipping gets moored at the crude oil terminal Kozmino on the shore of Nakhodka Bay near the port city of Nakhodka, Russia June 13, 2022. REUTERS/Tatiana Meel

site_title: China looks to increase penalties under its cybersecurity law
summary: China's Cyberspace Administration has proposed amendments to its cybersecurity law, including increasing fines for some violations from up to 100,000 yuan to 1 million yuan. The proposed changes aim to improve coordination with other laws and impose stiffer penalties on operators of critical information infrastructure that fail to undergo security reviews. The proposed amendments are open to public feedback until September 29.

site_title: Thai court to rule on premier’s term-limit case in 2 weeks
summary: Thailand's Constitutional Court will rule on September 30 whether Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-Ocha should step down due to an eight-year term limit challenge. The court has gathered evidence and will consider the case after suspending Prayuth's powers in August. Prayuth's legal team argued his premiership didn't start on August 24, 2014, the day he was appointed prime minister of a military government, challenging the eight-year term limit. The ruling will come just over a month after the court suspended Prayuth's powers.

images.alt_text: Protesters gather next to a picture of Thailand's Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha outside the Government House, as the Constitutional Court suspended Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha from official duties on Wednesday, after deciding to hear a petition to review his legally mandated eight-year term limit, in Bangkok, Aug 24, 2022.

site_title: Japan’s 10-year bond yield hits BOJ’s upper limit after US CPI shock
summary: Japan's 10-year government bond yield reached the Bank of Japan's (BOJ) upper limit on September 14, after a surprise rise in US consumer prices and expectations of aggressive Federal Reserve rate hikes to combat inflation. The BOJ has maintained ultra-low interest rates to support the economy, unlike its peers. The US Federal Reserve's next rate hike is expected to be a 75-basis-point increase, fueled by accelerating underlying inflation and rising costs for rents and healthcare. This move has shocked investors, who had been witnessing strong economic data.

site_title: Singapore stocks pull back on US inflation fears; STI down 1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1% to close at 3,258.02 on September 14, amid US inflation figures for August, which exceeded expectations. The STI was also impacted by key Asian markets, including Japan's Nikkei 225 and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index, which tumbled 2.8% and 2.5% respectively. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also finished lower, with DBS losing 0.9%, OCBC slipping 0.4%, and UOB dropping 1%.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
Authorities in Asia are squaring off with traders who bet that regional currencies will continue to slide as more aggressive Federal Reserve tightening boosts the dollar.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed 2.5% lower on Wednesday, following negative investor sentiment due to higher-than-expected US inflation numbers for August. The Hang Seng Index dropped 479.76 points to 18,847.10, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.8% and the Shenzhen Composite Index lost 1.1%. The decline was attributed to investor concerns over inflation and global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Google loses challenge against EU antitrust decision, wins 5% fine cut
summary: Google lost its challenge against the EU's 2.42 billion euro fine, which was reduced to 4.125 billion euros due to a disagreement on one point. The EU's General Court ruled that Google abused its dominance by imposing restrictions on Android manufacturers and mobile network operators to consolidate its search engine. Google criticized the decision as out of step with the economic reality of mobile software platforms. The ruling is a boost for EU antitrust chief Margrethe Vestager, who has cracked down on Big Tech with hefty fines.

images.alt_text: Google’s adtech has recently drawn scrutiny from antitrust regulators following complaints from publishers.

site_title: Seven companies bid for new casino licences in Macau
summary: Seven companies, including Sands China, Wynn Macau, and Galaxy Entertainment, have bid for new casino licences in Macau, with contracts set to start at the beginning of 2023. The Macau government has imposed formal table caps and minimum income requirements for new operators, aiming to increase oversight and control over the industry. The bidding committee will review proposals and negotiate terms by the end of November or early December, with six winners expected to be announced. The move follows a broader overhaul of Macau's gambling legislation.

site_title: Beyond a third term, Xi needs to tackle economic slowdown
summary: China's President Xi Jinping is expected to secure an unprecedented third 5-year term as party leader at the upcoming 20th Party Congress on October 16. However, the country's economic slowdown, fueled by the zero-Covid policy, poses a significant challenge for Xi's vision for the future. Investment banks have slashed forecasts for China's 2022 GDP growth to below 3%, and the economic recovery remains fragile due to persistent Covid-control restrictions. Xi's regulatory crackdown on technology giants has also led to rising unemployment, particularly among Chinese youths.

site_title: Indonesia government, key Parliament body set 2023 GDP growth target at 5.3%
summary: The Indonesian government and the key Parliament body have agreed to set a 2023 GDP growth target of 5.3% and a spending of 3,061.2 trillion rupiah (S$288.3 billion). This is similar to President Joko Widodo's proposal. The agreement will be discussed further in a wider Parliamentary vote, which is expected to take place later in September or October. The total spending figure is not expected to change from the agreed amount.

images.alt_text: epa06952124 General view of Parliament during Indonesian President Joko Widodo annual address at the Parliament building in Jakarta, Indonesia, 16 August 2018. Indonesia will celebrate its Independence Day on 17 August, which will mark the day in 1945 when the Indonesian National Revolution began resisting against the Netherlands and pro-Dutch civilians.  EPA-EFE/BAGUS INDAHONO

site_title: Crypto adoption levels off amid bear market, emerging markets lead Chainalysis’ adoption index
summary: Crypto adoption levels off globally amid a bear market, with 50% of top 20 countries, including top 3, being lower-middle income countries. According to Chainalysis, global adoption reached its all-time high in Q2 2022, but has since fluctuated. Vietnam leads the annual index, followed by the Philippines and Ukraine. Long-term holders have continued to hold through the bear market, with losses not yet locked in. Lower-middle and upper-middle income countries rely on cryptocurrency for remittances, savings, and financial needs, and tend to favor Bitcoin and stablecoins.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng
Nearly half of crypto owners first bought digital assets in 2021: survey

site_title: Hong Kong exchange considers lowering threshold for hard-tech listings
summary: Hong Kong's stock exchange, HKEX, is considering lowering the threshold for hard-tech listings, making it easier for companies in sectors such as chips and artificial intelligence to list shares in the city. The exchange is studying how to create a new listing chapter to cater to the funding needs of early-stage advanced technology companies. New draft rules are expected to be published within the next few weeks, which will reduce revenue and profit requirements for these companies. This move aims to attract more funding for large-scale tech companies in Hong Kong.

site_title: Trends in fashion, travel and more in BTLuxe
summary: The latest issue of BTLuxe magazine features fashionistas with a difference, including influencers Willabelle Ong, Glenn Goh, and Peggy Jeffs, who share their personal style and daring fashion choices. The magazine also covers travel trends, design, and the best Fall fashion looks to invest in, as well as hot watches and jewelry. Additionally, several luxury watch brands celebrate significant anniversaries, including Vacheron Constantin's 270th anniversary and Patek Philippe's Chinese New Year collection.

site_title: Jokowi could run for vice-president in Indonesia’s 2024 election
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo may run for vice-president in the 2024 presidential election, potentially extending his time in government. A senior official from his party suggests this is possible, as there's no constitutional rule preventing the president from running as vice-president. Jokowi's nomination would depend on party chairwoman Megawati Soekarnoputri, who has been speculated to support her daughter's potential presidential run. Some argue that allowing Jokowi to run for a third term would benefit the government's ambitious infrastructure agenda, but critics warn it could lead to a return to authoritarian rule.

site_title: Xi lands in Kazakhstan in first trip abroad since pandemic
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping landed in Kazakhstan on September 14, 2022, his first trip abroad since the pandemic, for a 3-day visit to Central Asia. He is scheduled to attend the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation (SCO) summit in Uzbekistan, where he will meet with Russian leader Vladimir Putin. During his visit, Xi expressed China's willingness to deepen cooperation with Kazakhstan in law enforcement, security, and defence, as well as combatting drug trafficking and transnational organized crime. The visit comes amid concerns over China's human rights record, particularly in its treatment of Uyghur Muslims in Xinjiang.

images.alt_text: Russian President Vladimir Putin attends a meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping in Beijing on February 4, 2022. Xi’s meeting with Putin on Thursday will send a very clear signal that China continues to tilt toward the side of Russia.

site_title: Europe: Stocks dip at open on inflation woes
summary: European stocks dipped at the open on Wednesday, extending a global selloff due to higher-than-expected US inflation data. The FTSE 100 index in London fell 0.7% to 7,332.01 points, while the eurozone's DAX and CAC 40 indices also declined. Investors fear prolonged Federal Reserve interest rate hikes amid slowing but still high inflation in the UK and Europe, with US inflation data showing an annual increase of 8.3% in August.

site_title: Financial services provider Fazz raises US$100m in Series C round
summary: Fazz, a financial services provider based in Indonesia, has raised US$100 million in a Series C round. The funding, comprising US$75 million in equity financing and US$25 million in debt, will be used to build teams and financial products. Existing investors, including Tiger Global and B Capital, joined new investors EDBI and Intervest in the round. The funds will also support Fazz's expansion plans, with a focus on hiring across Singapore, Indonesia, Malaysia, Vietnam, and Taiwan, to reach a workforce of 1,400.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
South-east Asia's young startup alumni are changing the face of investments

site_title: Biden to promote shift to EVs in visit to Detroit auto show
summary: US President Joe Biden is set to promote the shift to electric vehicles (EVs) at the Detroit auto show, highlighting billions of dollars in new investments in battery plants. The US Congress and Biden have pledged tens of billions of dollars in loans, tax credits, and grants to speed the transition away from internal combustion vehicles. Automakers, including General Motors, Stellantis, and Ford, are showcasing new EVs, with the goal of having 50% of new US vehicle sales be electric by 2030.

site_title: China’s top brokerage CICC shares slump on 27b yuan rights issue plan
summary: China International Capital (CICC) shares plummeted over 9% on September 14 after the top brokerage announced a plan to raise up to 27 billion yuan via a rights issue. The move is expected to dilute existing shareholders' stakes, with 3 new shares to be issued for every 10 existing ones. The capital raise will support business development and boost capital. This comes amid increasing competition in China's second-largest market, with CITIC Securities raising 28 billion yuan in a similar rights issue earlier this year.

site_title: Lawyer who fled Singapore after S$33m of client's money went missing struck off
summary: A Singaporean lawyer, Jeffrey Ong Su Aun, has been struck off the rolls after the Court of 3 Judges ruled he acted dishonestly in handling $33 million of his client's funds. Ong, 45, had allowed funds to be paid out without authorization, misrepresented about releasing the funds, and forged a cheque. His criminal case is still pending, with 76 charges including breach of trust, forgery, and cheating. Ong agreed with the Law Society of Singapore's submissions that he should be struck off.

images.alt_text: The notice was issued on May 9 by existing shareholder Lin Tah Hwa and executive director Kenneth Low

site_title: EU plans ‘comprehensive reform’ of electricity market
summary: The European Union has proposed a comprehensive reform of the electricity market to tackle soaring gas and electricity prices, triggered by Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The plan includes a cap on electricity producers' profits, which would raise 140 billion euros, and rationing energy. The EU also aims to decouple gas and electricity prices, create a new bank to invest in hydrogen, and secure critical raw materials. The measures are part of a broader effort to reduce dependence on Russian fossil fuels and increase reliance on renewable energies.

images.alt_text: Czech Industry Minister Jozef Sikela said EU countries’ energy ministers will hold an emergency summit, giving countries an opportunity to sign off on the EU proposals.

site_title: Helping American cities switch to electric heating won’t be a walk in the park
summary: US cities are struggling to switch to electric heating due to various challenges, including high upfront costs, limited space, and lack of trained workers. The Biden administration's tax rebates and the European Union's efforts to electrify buildings are expected to speed up the transition. Cities like New York and Ithaca have implemented laws requiring buildings to switch to electric heating, while others are taking measures to reduce gas use. The shift to electric heating could reduce emissions by 25 billion cubic meters, equivalent to about a sixth of the gas the European Union imports from Russia.

images.alt_text: Goldman’s preference for US exposure comes during what is turning out to be a particularly tough year for business in Europe amid a gas crisis, soaring inflation and tightening central-bank policy.
Other steps laid out by von der Leyen include rationing energy, temporary state aid and decoupling the prices of gas and electricity.
The European Commission will attempt to overlay that patchwork of national measures with a more coherent bloc-wide response, applying across all 27 EU member states.

site_title: Seoul: Shares, won tumble on US inflation shock
summary: South Korean shares and currency plummeted on September 14 after US inflation data exceeded expectations, fueling concerns of aggressive monetary tightening. The Kospi index fell 1.56% to 2,411.42, while the won dropped 1.24% to 1,390.9 per dollar. Technology giant Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix fell, while LG Energy Solution gained. Foreigners sold shares worth 163 billion won, and US interest rates are expected to rise further.

images.alt_text: The Kospi ended up 65.26 points or 2.74 per cent at 2,449.54.

site_title: Singapore approves Moderna’s booster vaccine that targets original Covid-19 virus, Omicron variant
summary: Singapore has granted interim approval for Moderna's Spikevax bivalent Covid-19 vaccine, which targets both the original Sars-CoV-2 strain and the Omicron BA.1 variant. The vaccine is recommended as a booster for people aged 18 and above who have already received their primary series vaccination. The Health Sciences Authority (HSA) cited that the benefits outweigh the risks for use of the vaccine as a booster to protect against Covid-19 as the virus continues to evolve. Official recommendations will be issued by the Expert Committee on Covid-19 Vaccination and the Ministry of Health in due time.

site_title: Virgin Australia says high staff illness rates hampering capacity, lifting fares
summary: Virgin Australia faces challenges due to high staff illness rates, resulting in reduced domestic capacity and flight delays. The airline's CEO, Jayne Hrdlicka, attributed the issues to "people capacity, not aircraft capacity." This has led to higher ticket prices, with average discount economy fares rising 56% between April and August. Despite this, Virgin sees strong bookings for December and January, and is taking steps to improve its cancellation rate. The airline aims to return to normal by Christmas time.

images.alt_text: Rex, best known for flying small propeller-driven aircraft between regional towns, is fast building out a new jet division plying busy domestic routes including Sydney-Melbourne.

site_title: Brokers’ take: DBS calls MPACT’s valuations attractive, reinstates coverage with ‘buy’
summary: DBS Group Research has reinstated coverage on Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust (MPACT) with a "buy" call and target price of S$2.30, citing its retail assets VivoCity and Festival Walk as beneficiaries of further recovery in Hong Kong and China. The trust's yield above 5% and attractive yield spread make it an "opportunity not to be missed," with a potential upside of 20.4% on its last trading price.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

Analyst Xavier Lee noted that both MPACT’s retail malls — Vivocity and Festival Walk — had maintained close to 100 per cent occupancy rates every year, even during the pandemic, as well as register positive rental reversions for most years.

site_title: Australia: Shares record worst day in 3 months amid global rout
summary: Australia's shares plummeted 2.6% on Wednesday, their worst session in three months, amid global market routs fueled by US inflation data and expectations of aggressive interest rate hikes. The S&P/ASX 200 index ended at 6,828.6 points. Financials and miners, including BHP Group and Rio Tinto, fell significantly due to weak iron ore prices. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to raise interest rates aggressively to combat inflation.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index fell up to 2.8 per cent by 0016 GMT, posting its biggest drop since June 14, after four sessions of consecutive gains.

site_title: Rio Tinto, China Baowu to develop Australian iron ore project for US$2b
summary: Rio Tinto has partnered with China Baowu Steel Group to develop an iron ore project in Western Australia for US$2 billion, aiming to boost production from the Pilbara region. The deal comes amid strained relations between Australia and China, with Beijing's efforts to centralize iron ore purchases raising concerns for mining giants like Rio. This partnership is seen as a strategic move to prop up Rio's production and mitigate potential risks from China's dwindling investment in Australia.

images.alt_text: Mining company Rio Tinto's offer doesn't “fairly reflect the fundamental and long-term strategic value of the company’s majority ownership of the Oyu Tolgoi project”, said Turquoise Hill on Monday (Aug 15).

site_title: India’s August wholesale inflation eases as commodity prices fall
summary: India's wholesale price index rose 12.41% in August, lower than the forecasted 13% and the previous month's 13.93%. A decline in global commodity prices eased pressure on companies with rising input costs. However, prices for food items such as cereals and vegetables increased. This slower-than-expected inflation rate may reduce the likelihood of further interest rate hikes this month, but double-digit price gains for the 17th consecutive month suggest ongoing upward pressure on inflation.

site_title: South Korea seeks arrest of Terraform Labs founder Do Kwon
summary: South Korea has issued an arrest warrant for Do Kwon, founder of Terraform Labs, on allegations of violating the nation's capital markets law. The warrant was issued for Kwon and five others, all currently in Singapore, in connection with the collapse of TerraUSD, a stablecoin that brought down the Terra ecosystem in May. The collapse triggered a global crypto rout and losses of over $60 billion. Kwon's followers referred to themselves as "Lunatics" and he has said he plans to cooperate when the time comes.

images.alt_text: Do Kwon, co-founder and chief executive officer of Terraform Labs, in the company's office in Seoul, South Korea, on Thursday, April 14, 2022. Kwon is counting on the oldest cryptocurrency as a backstop for his stablecoin, which some critics liken to a ginormous Ponzi scheme. Photographer: Woohae Cho/Bloomberg
Do Kwon said he plans to cooperate when the time comes.
South Korea last year mandated that cryptocurrency platforms must receive Information Security Management System certification.

site_title: Condo, HDB rents rise again in August; volumes remain lower on-year
summary: Condo and HDB rental prices in Singapore rose in August, with condo prices increasing 3.2% and HDB prices 2.4% from the previous month. Volumes, however, remained lower than last year, with condo volumes up 0.4% and HDB volumes up 3.8%. Experts predict rental prices may continue to rise or remain stable in the coming months due to the tight housing situation, with luxury segments expected to benefit from foreign talent and demand for large private homes.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Rental volumes also rose month on month for condos and HDB flats, but were lower year on year and when compared to the average 5-year volumes for July.
Year on year, overall condo rents increased by 21.1 per cent and overall HDB rents grew 17.9 per cent.
OrangeTee & Tie's Christine Sun is expecting more private rental tenants to opt for either smaller units or those located away from the city centre.
HDB rents hit new high in March; condo rents up 2.9%

site_title: Malaysia unlikely to enter recession despite global headwinds: Bursa Malaysia chairman
summary: Malaysia's recession risks are mitigated by its diversified economy, with less dependence on commodities and pragmatic policies. Despite global headwinds, including interest rate hikes and supply chain disruptions, Malaysia's GDP growth was driven by services and manufacturing sectors in 2022. The country's stable financial system, well-functioning debt and equity capital markets, and diverse trading partners also contribute to its economic resilience. Experts expect Malaysia to remain a growth destination in Asia, with opportunities for investors and businesses to take advantage of the region's unique regulatory environment.

images.alt_text: Malaysia is on track to surpass its GDP growth forecast despite 2022 being a challenging year with the strengthening of the US Dollar and slowing down of the global economy.

site_title: When Queen E died, someone had to tell the bees
summary: A tradition of "telling the bees" about major life events, particularly deaths, has been followed by beekeepers for centuries, with potentially grave consequences if not done. The practice involves informing bees of the death of a family member, usually by knocking on the hive and covering it with a black cloth during a mourning period. Although the belief in bad luck has diminished, beekeepers continue to follow the tradition as a mark of respect. Queen Elizabeth II's death prompted some beekeepers to inform her bees, with one beekeeper at Buckingham Palace reportedly telling them in hushed tones.

images.alt_text: Endangered pangolins get fresh chance in South Africa clinic
Life after death: The art of taxidermy
Life after death

site_title: Apple plans to use latest chip tech by Taiwan’s TSMC in iPhones, Macs: Nikkei
summary: Apple plans to use the A17 mobile processor, currently under development, in iPhones and Macs starting next year, according to Nikkei Asia. The A17 will be mass-produced using TSMC's N3E chipmaking technology, expected to be available in the second half of 2023. The chip will be used in the premium entry in the iPhone lineup slated for release in 2023, replacing the current A15 processor. Apple declined to comment, while TSMC did not immediately respond to a request for a comment.

site_title: Hong Kong to stop moving travellers with Covid to quarantine camp
summary: Hong Kong will stop transferring Covid-positive travellers to quarantine camps, allowing them to stay in designated quarantine hotels instead, starting November 1. The move aims to boost the city's reputation after nearly 2 years of isolation. The decision comes as Hong Kong prepares for high-profile events, including a global bankers summit and an international rugby tournament. The change is expected to alleviate concerns among potential visitors who were deterred by the risk of being sent to quarantine facilities, including the infamous Penny's Bay camp.

images.alt_text: New arrivals currently must quarantine in a hotel for 3 days, then monitor themselves for another 4 days to ensure they didn’t have a silent infection.

site_title: Zara owner Inditex’s first-half profit jumps defying inflation surge
summary: Inditex, the owner of Zara, reported a 25% increase in first-half sales to 14.8 billion euros, surpassing estimates. Earnings before interest and taxes rose to 2.43 billion euros, driven by selective price increases above inflation. The gross margin hit a 7-year high, and the company expects it to remain stable. Inditex's cost and supply chain structure, with proximity markets and dollar-denominated revenue, contributed to its success in defying inflation.

images.alt_text: Ortega’s family office Pontegadea said it is now looking for highly profitable assets with medium- and long-term leases with solid tenants and these warehouses tick all the boxes.
The world’s biggest fashion retailer said its net profit increased by 80 per cent in the first 3 months of its financial year to Apr 31, compared to the same period last year.
Although it was open earlier this month, the 3-storey building in downtown Shanghai was on Friday (Jun 24) boarded up with its H&M signage gone.

site_title: Spicing up heritage cuisine with artisanal rempah
summary: Batu Lesung Spice Company, a Singapore-based artisanal manufacturer, saw its sales spike during the 2020 "circuit breaker" as people cooked at home. Founder Jeremy Nguee's vision was to create high-quality, preservative-free spice pastes, which were initially sold online and at farmers' markets. The brand's products retail from S$10 for a 150g pack and cater to a niche market of home cooks seeking "higher-quality" rempah. With collaborations with Shake Shack and gourmet food distributors, Batu Lesung has doubled its sales annually since 2016, with plans to expand globally and work with F&B brands to create exclusive recipes.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Nicholas Lee set up Jill’s Sausages to produce and sell gourmet cooked and smoked sausages, hams and deli meats targeting the Asian market.
Melvados will be opening its 9th and 10th stores here in November. It is targeting to have 15 stores in Singapore in the next 2 years.

site_title: Allow singles to apply for BTO flats from age 28 instead of 35: Workers’ Party MP
summary: Singapore's Workers' Party MP Louis Chua proposed allowing singles to apply for Build-To-Order (BTO) flats from age 28 instead of 35, citing the financial burden on singles who wish to own a home. Currently, singles can apply for 2-room flexi flats at age 35. Chua argued that the current rule deprives singles of home ownership and sends a message that single status is undesirable. The proposal would also involve tiered Central Provident Fund housing grants for singles on a lower scale.

images.alt_text:
krtender13 - Land parcel along Lentor Central. URA tender for this site closes on September 13, 2022.



Source: URA
Resale prices, however, continued to rise for the 25th straight month.
Overall resale flats transacted in August were lower at 2,323 – representing a 1.7 per cent decrease from July 2022, and 15.5 per cent down from the previous year.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares fall sharply on US inflation as yen plunges
summary: Tokyo stocks fell sharply on Wednesday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index closing down 2.78% or 796.01 points, to 28,818.62. The decline was attributed to investor concerns over high US inflation and the yen's continued depreciation, prompting Japanese officials to voice concern.

site_title: UK inflation falls unexpectedly as fuel prices drop
summary: UK consumer price inflation fell unexpectedly to 9.9% in August, below economists' expectations of a 10.2% rise. The annual rate dropped from 10.1% in July, with prices for vehicle fuels and lubricants dropping 6.8% in August, the largest monthly fall since April 2020. Input prices for materials and energy fell 1.2% in August, driven by falling crude oil prices, providing some relief to households and the Bank of England. The Bank is expected to raise interest rates further next week.

images.alt_text: Basic pay growth in UK private sector was 6 per cent in the 3 months through July, triple the 2 per cent for those on the government payroll.
Industrial production and construction both shrank for a second month, disappointing expectations for growth.

site_title: EU to propose crisis measures to curb energy price spike
summary: The European Commission plans to propose crisis measures to curb energy price spikes, which have fueled record inflation and forced industries to shut production. The proposed measures include skimming off windfall profits from energy companies and imposing cuts in electricity usage across the 27 EU member states. This aims to shield citizens and businesses from surging energy costs ahead of winter, following national measures that have already cost hundreds of billions of euros. The EU seeks to provide a more coherent bloc-wide response to the energy crisis.

images.alt_text: Czech Industry Minister Jozef Sikela said EU countries’ energy ministers will hold an emergency summit, giving countries an opportunity to sign off on the EU proposals.

site_title: Fosun denies reports China regulators asked banks to report exposure to it
summary: Fosun International has denied reports that Chinese regulators asked the country's biggest banks to report their financial exposure to the company, calling the claims "sheer nonsense."
