According to Bloomberg, regulators including the China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission had requested banks check their exposure to Fosun's debt and assess potential liquidity risks. The company's shares plummeted 7.55% on Wednesday, reaching a 10-year low.

images.alt_text: Multiple regulators including China’s banking watchdog and the local commission that oversees state investments in Beijing recently told institutions under their oversight to closely examine their Fosun exposure.

site_title: Following in their fathers’ footsteps, they bring precision engineering into the future
summary: A younger generation of business leaders in Singapore's precision engineering industry is transforming the sector by adopting greater automation and digitalization. Companies like Flexmech Engineering and Chong Fong Engineering, led by second and third-generation leaders, are shifting from manual labor to design engineering, product development, and automation. The next decade will be crucial as older leaders pass the baton to the younger generation, who aim to use technology to shorten the gap in skills and knowledge. The industry is also working to attract younger graduates and talent to fill the talent shortage, with companies offering work-study programs and internships.

images.alt_text: எஸ். வெங்கடேஷ்வரன்
Tan Ru-Ding, managing director of FlexMech, said the precision enginering sector has made significant strides in work conditions and offers lucrative career prospects now.

site_title: Crypto nurses post-CPI losses as clock ticks to Ethereum upgrade
summary: Cryptocurrency markets experienced sharp losses due to expectations of restrictive US monetary policy, with Bitcoin near $20,000 and Ether at $1,600. The Ethereum upgrade, known as the Merge, is set to take place late this week and may overshadow current macroeconomic factors. However, the upgrade's potential for smooth execution is high, with major Ethereum-based services ready for the change. Despite this, experts warn of risks, including the possibility of Bitcoin dropping below $18,000 before reaching a bottom in October.

images.alt_text: The hotly-anticipated Merge, expected around Sep 15, will transition Ethereum to a more energy efficient network.
The hotly-anticipated Merge, expected around Sep 15, will transition Ethereum to a more energy efficient network.
Developers have spent years working on a more energy-efficient version of the ethereum blockchain.

site_title: BOJ boosts bond buying again as yields approach its policy limit
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) increased scheduled bond purchases by 50 billion yen to 550 billion yen, as its benchmark 10-year yield approached the 0.25% policy limit. This move comes amid a global Treasuries sell-off and a weakening yen. The decision aims to stabilize the market and maintain low interest rates, despite rising inflation concerns. The BOJ's governor, Haruhiko Kuroda, has emphasized his commitment to keeping rates low, despite global peers hiking interest rates to combat inflation.

site_title: Asia pushback grows as Fed fears ripple across the region
summary: Asian authorities push back against a surging dollar, citing excessive volatility in markets as a major concern. Japan and South Korea have ramped up rhetoric, while China's central bank set the daily reference rate on the yuan at the strongest bias on record. Despite efforts to intervene, regional currencies continue to decline, with the won sliding 1.6% and the baht plummeting 1.3%. Experts say the decline is largely driven by the Federal Reserve's aggressive tightening, with limited results from central bank interventions.

images.alt_text: The yuan is also under pressure as Covid-led lockdowns in major cities and turmoil in the nation’s property sector weigh on the economy.

site_title: Tencent Music plans Hong Kong debut as soon as next week: sources
summary: Tencent Music Entertainment Group plans to list its shares in Hong Kong as early as next week, according to sources. The Shenzhen-based company, which already trades in New York, aims to pursue a secondary listing in Hong Kong. This move comes amid escalating Sino-US tensions and rising delisting risks, with Tencent Music seeking alternative listing options. The listing will be by introduction, meaning no new shares will be sold, and shares have tumbled 31% this year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks lose ground at the open
summary: Hong Kong stocks dropped 2% at the open, following global market losses, after US inflation data exceeded expectations. The Hang Seng Index fell to 18,933.30, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined. The losses were attributed to concerns over global economic uncertainty and the impact of US inflation on markets.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares slump on US inflation, Wall Street falls
summary: Tokyo stocks plummeted 2.63% on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index dropping 753.85 points to 28,860.78. The decline follows US inflation data showing stubbornly high levels, triggering Wall Street selloffs. The broader Topix index also fell 2.06%. Investors shunned risk, leading to the market downturn.

site_title: Asia:  Stocks slump at open, tracking US losses after inflation report
summary: Asian markets opened lower on Wednesday, tracking US losses after higher-than-expected US inflation data. The annual increase in US CPI slowed slightly to 8.3% in August, but prices continued to rise month-on-month, fueling fears of prolonged interest rate hikes. This news shook equity markets, with the Dow plummeting nearly 1,300 points and the S&P 500 falling 4.3%. The US Federal Reserve's campaign to cool the economy may become more aggressive, raising concerns about a potential US recession.

images.alt_text: A man holding an umbrella is silhouetted as he walks in front of an electric monitor displaying the Japanese yen exchange rate against the U.S. dollar and Nikkei share average in Tokyo, Japan July 14, 2022  REUTERS/Issei Kato

site_title: US to discuss new chips bill with Taiwan next month
summary: The US will discuss its new chips bill with Taiwan next month, with the goal of boosting the American semiconductor industry. The Chips and Science Act, signed into law last month, authorizes $52 billion in government subsidies and an investment tax credit worth $24 billion for chip plants. US officials will use the US-Taiwan Technology Trade and Investment Collaboration framework to elevate economic engagements and address chip shortages. Taiwan has invested in US chip production, and the US seeks Taiwan's industry support to connect talent and ecosystems.

images.alt_text: The United States is leading an unprecedented effort to supercharge domestic semiconductor research and production, both to alleviate Covid-19 supply chain issues and shift away from reliance on Chinese technology.
Micron said this will be the first new memory chip factory built in the United States in 20 years, and will create 2,000 Micron jobs by the end of the decade.

US officials are considering options for a possible package of sanctions against China to deter Xi from attempting to invade Taiwan, said a US official and an official from a country in close coordination with Washington.

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB raises target on Parkway Life Reit by S$0.01 after Japan acquisition
summary: CGS-CIMB raised its target price on Parkway Life Reit by S$0.01 to S$5.06 after the Reit's acquisition of 3 nursing homes in Hokkaido, Japan. The acquisition expands Parkway Life Reit's Japan portfolio to S$725.3 million, making up 32% of its total assets under management. Analyst Lock Mun Yee expects the deal to be accretive to the Reit's distribution per unit and improve its income resiliency, with a raised FY22 to FY24 DPU estimate of 0.3 and 0.5%. The "hold" rating is maintained due to an estimated total return of less than 10% in the near term.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
First Reit’s Indonesia hospital operator, PT Siloam International Hospitals Tbk reported stable quarter-on-quarter performance for Q1 2022 despite the impact of the Omicron variant.

The Reit’s Singapore properties, comprising Mount Elizabeth Hospital, Gleneagles Hospital and Parkway East Hospital, are its key assets, contributing approximately 60.6 per cent of of the its net property income in the half year recorded.

site_title: Moya Holdings Asia seeks delisting through voluntary cash offer at S$0.092 per share
summary: Moya Holdings Asia, an Indonesian water treatment operator, plans to take the company private through a voluntary cash offer from Tamaris Infrastructure, a majority shareholder, at S$0.092 per share. The offer represents a 41.5% premium over the last traded price and aims to provide shareholders with an opportunity to realise their investments, allow for greater management flexibility, and save costs on maintaining its listed status. The company must attain approval from at least 75% of issued shares and have its delisting resolution approved by shareholders at its extraordinary general meeting.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

site_title: China sets yuan fix at strongest bias on record to lift currency
summary: China's central bank set the yuan's reference rate at 6.9116 per dollar, its strongest bias on record, to support the currency amid economic pressure from Covid-led lockdowns and property sector turmoil. The move follows a reduction in foreign-currency reserve requirements for banks and comes as the US Federal Reserve's hawkish inflation data fuels dollar strength. The yuan's offshore unit weakened to 7, its lowest since 2020, and traders await potential central bank liquidity measures. China's economy is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: Bearish investors for years have been warning that China’s banks have lent out far too much money, particularly to finance a real estate frenzy.
FILE PHOTO: A China yuan note is seen in this illustration photo May 31, 2017.     REUTERS/Thomas White/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Singapore tourist arrivals grow for 7th straight month in August to 728,744
summary: Singapore reported a 7th consecutive month of growth in international visitor arrivals, with 728,744 arrivals in August, exceeding July's figure. This marks a record from the beginning of the Covid-19 pandemic. The total international visitor arrivals for 2022 now stand at 3 million, lower than the expected 4-6 million forecasted by the Singapore Tourism Board. Experts attribute the slowdown to seasonality factors, with visitor arrivals typically peaking in June or July.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Some 726,601 tourists arrived in Singapore in July, up from the 543,733 recorded in June, though the new figure remains far below the 1.8 million recorded in July 2019 before the pandemic.

For the upcoming Grand Prix, CGS-CIMB estimates that up to 35,000 tourists could make their way to Singapore’s shores, which could potentially fill 45 to 50 per cent of the island’s hotel room inventory.

site_title: Tycoon Richard Li’s insurer FWD refiles for Hong Kong IPO
summary: FWD Group Holdings, backed by billionaire Richard Li, has refiled an application for a Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO) as it considers a listing next year amid market volatility. The insurer aims to raise about $1 billion in an IPO, with Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs, and others serving as joint sponsors. FWD's first half 2022 revenue rose 24.6% to $405 million, despite an adjusted loss of $333 million. The company initially sought a US IPO but switched to Hong Kong due to US regulators' concerns over the Chinese government's influence.

site_title: Gold dips amid firm dollar, concerns over aggressive US rate hikes
summary: Gold prices fell 0.2% to $1,698.14 per ounce amid a firm US dollar and expectations of aggressive interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. Higher interest rates increase the opportunity cost of holding gold, boosting the dollar and prices. The dollar index ticked 0.1% higher after a 0.4% drop in US gold futures. The Fed is likely to raise interest rates faster than expected, with a 100 basis-point hike possible at the September meet, fueling concerns over inflation.

images.alt_text: The dollar index hovered close to its lowest level since Aug 26, making the greenback-priced gold less expensive for overseas buyers.

site_title: Japan government repeats readiness to act as yen nears 24-year low
summary: Japan's government reiterated its readiness to take "necessary action" against rapid yen falls, following a 24-year low against the US dollar. The yen's weakness is hurting households and retailers by inflating prices of imported fuel and food. Japan's top currency diplomat, Masato Kanda, expressed concern over currency market moves and warned that the government would respond appropriately without ruling out any options. The dollar climbed to a near 24-year peak against the yen after hotter-than-expected US inflation prompted bets for more aggressive monetary tightening by the Fed.

images.alt_text: The dollar rose as high as 144.965 yen in the Asian session, taking it close to last Wednesday’s high of 144.99, a level not seen since August 1998, before last trading little changed at 144.56.

site_title: Japan’s July core machinery orders rise 5.3% m-o-m
summary: Japan's core machinery orders rose 5.3% in July from the previous month, beating economists' expectations of a 0.8% decline. This represents a 12.8% gain compared to the same period last year, indicating stronger capital spending in the coming six to nine months.

site_title: Australia’s Rex eyes nationwide air network as Qantas struggles
summary: Australian airline Rex is expanding its jet division to compete with Qantas, adding Boeing 737s for nationwide intercity routes. With 5% market share, Rex is more reliable than Qantas, which is experiencing post-pandemic flight cancellations and delays. Rex plans to reach 30 Boeing 737s, potentially opening routes to Australia's western seaboard, Tasmania, and new destinations. The airline aims to double its market share to 10% or more as it grows its fleet, driven by its reliability and partnerships with Delta Air Lines.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Regional Express airlines SAAB 340 plane is sprayed with water as its sets off for its first flight from Canberra during a ceremony August 6, 2002. REUTERS/The Canberra Times/Graham Tidy MDB/JD

site_title: US considers China sanctions to deter Taiwan action, Taiwan presses EU
summary: The US is considering a sanctions package against China to deter its potential invasion of Taiwan, amid growing military tensions in the Taiwan Strait. The European Union is also under pressure from Taiwan to impose sanctions, with Taiwanese officials calling for Europe to prepare for potential consequences. China claims Taiwan as its own territory and has vowed to bring it under Beijing's control, with President Xi Jinping set to secure a third leadership term. The US and EU are weighing the feasibility of imposing sanctions on China, which would require coordination among all 27 EU member countries.

images.alt_text: Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen (C) posing for a photograph with US congresswoman Stephanie Murphy (6-L) and the US delegation during their meeting at the presidential office in Taipei, Taiwan, 08 September 2022.

File photo of Vladimir Putin and President Xi Jinping meeting at the Eastern Economic Forum in Vladivostok, Russia 2018; the 2 leaders are deepening ties  with trade soaring by nearly a third between Russia and China in the first 7 months of 2022.

Russian President Vladimir Putin attends a meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping in Beijing on February 4, 2022. Xi’s meeting with Putin on Thursday will send a very clear signal that China continues to tilt toward the side of Russia.
German Economy and Climate Minister Robert Habeck said Germany must open up to new trading partners and regions as many sectors were heavily dependent on selling to China.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall most in three months as US inflation data spurs selloff
summary: Australian shares plummeted 2.8% in their largest drop in three months, following a hotter-than-expected US inflation rate that led to speculation of further interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell, with miners, energy, and financial stocks taking the biggest hits. The US inflation data, which rose in August, has prompted investors to sell, and the Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to raise interest rates in the coming months.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.7 per cent to 7,009.7, its highest closing level since Aug 26

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 12.24 points lower, or 0.82%, at 1,475.60. The market saw a significant decline in volume, with 210.01 million lots traded worth RM106.57 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 496 to 32, indicating a bearish trend in the market.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Ascendas Reit, Parkway Life Reit, Keppel, GYP, Centurion, Moya
summary: Ascendas Reit's manager proposed acquiring a cold storage logistics facility for S$191.9 million. Parkway Life Reit acquired 3 nursing homes in Hokkaido for S$26.1 million, increasing its leverage ratio. Keppel Corp's 75%-owned offshore unit applied for a court injunction to prohibit payment on a US$126.6 million standby letter of credit. GYP Properties' offeror raised its offer price to S$0.20 per share, and Centurion Corp plans to expand its dormitories in Malaysia. Moya Holdings Asia received a voluntary cash offer to take the company private.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
In the wider Singapore market, gainers edged out losers 257 to 244, with 1.24 billion shares worth S$926.9 million traded.

site_title: Singapore shares open in the red after US data disappoints; STI down 1.2%
summary: Singapore shares declined 1.2% at open on Sep 14, following US inflation data that triggered Wall Street selloffs. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell to 3,250.17, with losers outnumbering gainers 159 to 19. Top-traded counters included Sembcorp Marine, Moya Holdings Asia, and Singtel, which fell 1.8%, 36.9%, and 2.2% respectively. The decline was attributed to the US Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hike following disappointing inflation data.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Generic shots of SGX

site_title: Crowds gather as queen’s coffin to go on display in London
summary: Crowds gathered in London to pay their final respects to Queen Elizabeth II, who died on September 8, 2022. The coffin was borne on a horse-drawn gun carriage from Buckingham Palace to Westminster Hall, where it will remain for four days before the funeral. Hundreds of thousands of people are expected to attend, with strict security measures in place. The public will be let in from 5 pm, with mourners warned of long queues and airport-style security. The funeral will take place on Monday, with a procession and vigil at Westminster Hall, and will be attended by all of the queen's siblings.

images.alt_text: A hearse carrying the coffin of Queen Elizabeth II passes throngs of people on its way into Buckingham Palace in London, England on Tuesday, Sept. 13, 2022. Crowds of Londoners lined the streets as the Queen’s coffin arrived at Buckingham Palace on Tuesday night, standing by to catch a glimpse of the royal hearse as it was driven from the Royal Air Force base in the city’s west to the queen’s official residence. (Andrew Testa/The New York Times)

site_title: US dollar pushes towards fresh 24-year peak versus yen after CPI shock
summary: The US dollar surged to a 24-year high against the yen, reaching 144.965 yen, after hotter-than-expected inflation data boosted bets for aggressive monetary tightening by the Federal Reserve next week. The dollar rose 1.26% in overnight trading, with 10-year Treasury yields reaching a three-month high. Markets now price a 37% chance of a full percentage-point rate hike on September 21, up from 63% previously. This has led analysts to predict a 100 basis-point rate hike as the most likely outcome.

images.alt_text: The yen has been hammered against the US dollar as investors focus on the widening divergence between the US Federal Reserve’s aggressive interest rate hikes and the Bank of Japan’s pledge to maintain ultra-low rates.
The currency has fallen more than 19 per cent this year.

site_title: China rolls out property policies across nation to fix slump
summary: China has rolled out various property easing measures across the nation to combat a property slump, with at least 70 local governments issuing policies since President Xi Jinping's call for efforts to defuse the crisis. Measures include lowering down payment ratios, allowing parents to fund children's home purchases, and providing subsidies and credit support. Despite these efforts, the US$2.4 trillion new-home market shows little sign of recovery, and consumer confidence remains dampened by mortgage boycotts and falling home prices. Local governments are expected to continue optimising property policies based on their own situation.

images.alt_text: At a meeting on Sep 8, Premier Li called for efforts to solve the “key problem of insufficient demand” in the economy and boost consumption as a main growth driver.

site_title: Swift financial-messaging system pilots blockchain project
summary: Swift, a global financial messaging system, is piloting a blockchain project with fintech company Symbiont to automate corporate action workflow. The collaboration aims to drive efficiencies in communicating significant corporate events, such as dividend payments and mergers, among 11,000 companies in over 200 countries. Swift will use Symbiont's technology platform to create a network effect, leveraging its global network of institutions. The pilot project, set to begin in September, has the potential to reduce errors and inconsistencies in corporate action data, and could be extended to the wider Swift community if successful.

images.alt_text: A man using a mobile phone passes the logo of global secure financial messaging services cooperative SWIFT at the SIBOS banking and financial conference in Toronto, Ontario, Canada October 19, 2017. REUTERS/Chris Helgren/File Photo

site_title: Lights out early for Eiffel Tower as Paris saves energy
summary: Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo announced measures to reduce energy consumption this winter, including turning off the Eiffel Tower's lights an hour earlier, lowering pool water temperature, and delaying public building heating. The goal is to meet President Emmanuel Macron's 10% energy reduction target in response to Russia's gas supply cuts. These measures aim to save 4% of energy consumption and reduce the city's energy bill by 35 million euros. The measures will be implemented starting September 23.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A night view shows the Eiffel tower, reflected in a car's roof, in Paris, France, April 30, 2016. REUTERS/Christian Hartmann/File Photo

site_title: US must be ‘at the table’ in semiconductor field: Blinken
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken emphasized the importance of the US being at the table in the global semiconductor industry to alleviate economic and security concerns. The US is leading an unprecedented effort to supercharge domestic semiconductor research and production, with the Chips and Science Act providing around $52 billion to promote domestic production. Blinken stressed the need for the US to "carry the debate" in tech diplomacy, highlighting the significance of semiconductor technology for multiple global sectors, including the auto industry and smartphones.

images.alt_text: Micron said this will be the first new memory chip factory built in the United States in 20 years, and will create 2,000 Micron jobs by the end of the decade.
A joint venture of Taiwan’s Hon Hai, known also as Foxconn, and metals company Vedanta will set up a factory in Gujarat, the home state of Prime Minister Narendra Modi.

Reuters was first to report in July that the Biden administration was actively discussing banning exports of chipmaking tools to Chinese factories that make advanced semiconductors at the 14 nanometre node and smaller.

site_title: Porsche IPO draws commitment from Norwegian wealth fund: sources
summary: Volkswagen's Porsche unit is set to go public with a potential valuation of $98 billion to $98 billion, backed by anchor investors including the Norwegian sovereign wealth fund, Norges Bank Investment Management. Other investors, such as T Rowe Price Group and Qatar Investment Authority, have expressed interest in the IPO. Porsche will sell preferred shares without voting rights, while the billionaire Porsche and Piech clan will buy common stock for a blocking minority stake. The listing is seen as a key funding source for Porsche's electrification plans.

images.alt_text: Porsche is worth between 44.5 billion euros (S$63.09 billion) and 56.9 billion euros, analysts  said in a note which is lower than the 60 billion euros-to-85 billion euros ballpark being talked about in the media.
Volkswagen’s management and supervisory boards will meet later on Monday to discuss whether the long-anticipated listing of Porsche should go ahead in late September or early October.
The powerful billionaire Porsche and Piech clan, which controls VW through voting stock, would receive a special dividend to fund buying a blocking minority stake in Porsche.

site_title: Germany raises 760m euros from sale of full stake in Lufthansa
summary: Germany sold its full stake in Lufthansa for 760 million euros, generating 1.07 billion euros in proceeds for the Economic Stabilisation Fund. The sale, which included a 6.2% holding announced earlier, marks the end of the government's participation in the airline. Lufthansa repaid its 9 billion-euro bailout in November ahead of schedule, allowing the government to sell its stake at a significant profit. The sale will allow private investors, including billionaire Klaus-Michael Kuehne, to acquire more shares in the airline.

images.alt_text: Lufthansa's passenger pilots will strike on Wednesday and Thursday, and cargo pilots from Wednesday through Friday, said the union, which groups more than 5,000 pilots.
Lufthansa said it had cancelled about 800 flights at its main bases in Frankfurt and Munich on Friday, affecting 130,000 passengers.

site_title: JPMorgan, Bank of America cautious on job cuts as Goldman layoffs loom
summary: JPMorgan Chase and Bank of America expressed caution about job cuts amid a potential recession, contrasting with Goldman Sachs' plans to cut hundreds of jobs. JPMorgan president Daniel Pinto stated that cutting bankers during a downturn can hinder growth, while Bank of America CEO Brian Moynihan is satisfied with current staffing levels. Goldman Sachs' job cuts, which may start as early as this month, follow a 15% increase in its workforce to 47,000 at the end of the second quarter.

images.alt_text: Bank of America CEO  Brian Moynihan said the bank is satisfied with its staffing levels amid concern about job cuts across the banking industry.
Sentiment is “super bearish,” with the energy crisis further weighing on risk appetite, survey participants said

site_title: France halves flight schedules on air traffic control strike
summary: France's civil aviation authority has instructed airlines to halve flight schedules on September 16 due to a planned strike by air-traffic controllers, causing significant disruptions and flight cancellations. The strike, called by the SNCTA union, will bring back the staffing crisis that forced thousands of flight cancellations this summer. Alternative flight paths are being offered by Eurocontrol, but passengers are advised to postpone their trips. The move has led to a 5.6% decline in Air France-KLM shares.

site_title: Oil dips nearly 1%, reversing gains after bearish US economic data
summary: Oil prices reversed earlier gains, dipping nearly 1% on Tuesday, as US consumer prices unexpectedly rose in August, supporting a potential interest rate hike by the US Federal Reserve. US October crude futures fell 47 cents, or 0.5%, to $87.31, while Brent crude for November delivery lost 83 cents, or 0.9%, to $93.17 a barrel. The stronger dollar and renewed Covid-19 curbs in China also weighed on prices.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled up US$1.16, or 1.3 per cent, at US$94.00 a barrel on Monday.

site_title: Twitter ex-security chief in Congress as shareholders back Musk buyout
summary: Former Twitter security chief Peiter Zatko testified before the US Senate Judiciary Committee, claiming the platform ignored his security concerns, putting user data and national security at risk. Zatko's testimony comes as Elon Musk's $44 billion takeover deal was approved by Twitter shareholders, despite Musk trying to exit the deal. Zatko alleges that Twitter's leadership was misled by its own board and failed to protect user data, prioritizing profits over security. The testimony puts pressure on Twitter as it heads to court next month to force Musk to complete the buyout.

images.alt_text: Twitter counters that Musk’s bot concerns are a pretext to get out of a deal in which the world’s richest person allegedly developed buyer’s remorse.

It’s Musk’s third bid to withdraw his offer because of what he says are violations of the buyout agreement. He previously raised concerns about the number of “bot” accounts on the platform, and now has said that Twitter should have told him before it spent US$7.75 million in a separation agreement with Peiter Zatko, the company’s former security chief.

site_title: China approves 73 games including ones belonging to NetEase and a Tencent subsidiary
summary: China's gaming regulator approved 73 online games, including titles from NetEase and a Tencent subsidiary, after a 14-month suspension. NetEase received its first video game licence in 14 months for a sports game, and Nanjing Wangdian Technology, a Tencent subsidiary, received a licence for an educational game. However, Tencent, the world's biggest game developer, was not approved for any commercial games. The approval comes after regulators resumed game approvals in April.

site_title: Traders start to consider even bigger Fed rate hikes after hot CPI
summary: Traders are betting the Federal Reserve will raise its benchmark interest rate by at least 3-quarters of a percentage point next week, with some speculating it could be even bigger. The overnight index swap contract suggests a minimum 75-basis-point tightening is seen as a lock for the meeting, and some analysts now expect a 100-basis-point move. The US consumer price index increased 0.1% from July, above forecasts, and core CPI rose 0.6% from July. This has led to concerns that the Fed may need to push policy rates higher to combat inflation, potentially reaching around 4.3% by early 2023.

images.alt_text: The hotly-anticipated Merge, expected around Sep 15, will transition Ethereum to a more energy efficient network.

site_title: Starbucks projects profit growth from tech, stores, workers spending
summary: Starbucks projects 15-20% profit growth per share over the next three years, driven by investments in technology and store renovations. The company aims to return $20 billion to investors through share buybacks and dividends. To address barista burnout, Starbucks is introducing "load balancing" technology that sends orders to stores with capacity. The company also plans to expand to 45,000 stores by 2025, including 9,000 in China. Amid unionization efforts, Starbucks has agreed to lift pay to $17 an hour for non-unionized US locations, but faces challenges in offering increased benefits to unionized workers.

images.alt_text: Laxman Narasimhan will take over Howard Schultz (pictured) as Starbucks CEO on April 1, 2023.

site_title: Ascendas Reit to buy cold storage logistics facility in Singapore for S$191.9m
summary: Ascendas Reit has proposed to acquire a 5-storey cold storage logistics facility in Singapore for S$191.9 million. The facility, built around 7 years ago, offers storage space and ancillary office space, and is fully occupied by 5 well-established tenants. The acquisition is expected to result in a distribution per unit accretion of 0.56% or an improvement of 0.086 Singapore cent on a pro forma basis, with a net property income yield of around 7% for pre-transaction costs. The transaction is expected to be completed in Q4 2022 through internal resources and existing debt facilities.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Ascendas Reit has proposed to acquire Philips APAC Centre at 622 Lorong 1 Toa Payoh.
Fitch Ratings says Reits with exposure to prime retail malls, such as Starhill Global Reit, will take longer to reach pre-pandemic earnings than its suburban peers.
A-Reit on Aug 4 said it is acquiring the Philips Apac Center in Singapore for S$104.8 million.
Ascendas Reit will be acquiring the Philips APAC Center in Singapore from Philips Electronics.

site_title: Europe: Shares slide as US inflation hots up
summary: European shares slid 1.6% on Tuesday as hotter-than-expected US inflation data fueled bets for a third 75 basis points interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve, leading to losses in tech and real estate stocks. The Stoxx 600 index snapped a three-session winning streak, while Germany's DAX dropped 1.6%. Higher interest rates are expected to impact growth for tech companies, with tech stocks losing nearly 30% this year.

images.alt_text: London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index dipped 0.1 per cent to 7,464.30 points.

site_title: Crypto traders flee Indian exchanges for Binance to escape taxes
summary: Binance's downloads in India surged to 429,000 in August, nearly tripling that of runner-up CoinDCX, as traders flee Indian exchanges to escape the 1% tax on crypto transactions. The tax, which also bars trading losses from being offset against income, has led to a 90% decline in daily volumes at key India-based platforms. Foreign exchanges like Binance and FTX are not deducting the levy, prompting investors to switch to the latter. Binance's CEO Changpeng Zhao has been encouraging WazirX customers to defect to Binance, further fueling the platform's growth.

images.alt_text: The move is intended to enhance liquidity and capital efficiency for users, the company said in a statement.

site_title: Climate impacts heading to ‘uncharted territories of destruction’: UN chief
summary: UN Secretary-General António Guterres warns that climate change impacts are heading into "uncharted territories of destruction" due to rising greenhouse gas concentrations and inaction from world leaders. The UN's "United in Science" report states that the world is "going in the wrong direction" on climate change, with extreme weather events becoming more frequent and intense. Global carbon dioxide emissions have surged beyond pre-pandemic levels, and the Earth is inching closer to climate tipping points, with temperatures expected to reach 2.8°C by the end of the century if no aggressive action is taken.

site_title: Paramount considers merging Showtime with its Paramount+ service
summary: Paramount Global is considering merging its Showtime streaming service with Paramount+, offering a combined online TV option to consumers. The company already sells the services as a bundle and allows subscribers to access Showtime within Paramount+. The move aims to maximize the value of content investments and follows a significant growth in streaming customers, with over 43 million Paramount+ subscribers and 64 million total streaming customers at the end of June.

images.alt_text: A bilboard announcing the launch of Paramount's streaming service is pictured on Sunset Strip in West Hollywood, California on March 2, 2021. (Photo by VALERIE MACON / AFP) (Photo by VALERIE MACON/AFP via Getty Images)

site_title: Biggest jump in US rents since 1991 keeps overall inflation high
summary: US rental inflation accelerated in August with a 0.7% monthly increase, marking the largest jump since 1991. This brought shelter inflation to 6.3% over the last 12 months, the highest since 1986. Analysts expect rents to continue rising as more leases expire, but inflation is expected to moderate by the end of 2023. The increase was driven by shelter costs, which comprise about a third of the consumer price index and are a key driver of inflation. Overall inflation remains elevated, with forecasts suggesting a possible big Fed hike.

images.alt_text: The acceleration in inflation points to a stubbornly high cost of living for Americans, despite some relief at the gas pump.

site_title: Navigating an uncertain global outlook with open source
summary: Organisations worldwide are bracing for an economic downturn, but embracing open source can aid in navigating uncertainty. Open source software and digital content are freely available, promoting operational efficiencies and providing access to world-class expertise. This enables businesses to quickly build products and implement new initiatives with minimal downtime, and can also aid financial and social inclusion initiatives. By leveraging open source, industries can accelerate innovation, lower barriers to adoption, and create solutions that are consistent, secure, and scalable. This can help fortify resilience and enable businesses to withstand adversity and build back better.

images.alt_text: If passed into law it would affect how companies like Microsoft and Oracle sell their products to the federal government.

site_title: White House is pushing unions and rail companies to avoid strike
summary: The US rail system is at risk of a shutdown due to a potential strike by 125,000 railroad workers, who are prepared to walk off the job if companies don't reach agreements with all labor groups by the end of the week. The White House is engaged in last-ditch efforts to avert a strike, which could disrupt the US economy just weeks before the midterm elections and harm Democrats' chances of keeping their congressional majorities. Freight-rail operators and unions face a Friday deadline to agree to a new contract.

site_title: Strong take-up at recent launches could whet developers’ appetite for suburban sites
summary: Suburban condominium projects in Singapore, such as Sky Eden@Bedok and Lentor Modern, have seen strong sales despite elevated land and construction costs, with sales figures exceeding 75% of available units. The projects' proximity to MRT stations and schools, limited unsold supply, and high demand from HDB upgraders and owner-occupiers are contributing factors. Developers expect the strong sales performance to drive up average pricing and encourage further investment in the market, with several upcoming projects in the pipeline.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

The 2 developments will also be looking to “test the market” with an indicative pricing of S$2,000 per square foot (psf) onwards. If and when achieved, this would also set a new benchmark for projects in the Outside Central Region, said DBS.
Analysts say that higher land costs, along with the increased cost of construction and materials, are contributing to cost pressures.
AMO Residence is the first notable launch in the Outside Central Region (OCR) this year, as well as the first major project in Ang Mo Kio in over eight years.
Artist's impression of Sky Eden@Bedok. Close to 75 per cent of its residential units were sold on the first day of the project's launch.

site_title: Britons back new King Charles, so long as he keeps quiet
summary: A YouGov poll found that 63% of Britons believe King Charles will be a good king, a 24-point increase since March, while 15% think he will do a bad job. Many mourners for Queen Elizabeth believe Charles must adapt and remain quiet about his views, unlike his outspoken nature on issues like climate change. The poll also showed a record low proportion of people supporting the monarchy, with 62% of respondents backing the institution, largely unchanged since Charles became sovereign.

images.alt_text: A grab from a handout video made available by the UK Parliamentary Recording Unit shows Britain's King Charles III (at centre left) and Camilla the Queen Consort and speaker of the House of Commons Lindsay Hoyle (right) singing the national anthem following his address to the Houses of Parliament at Westminster Hall in London.

site_title: US poverty rate rises for second year while incomes are little changed
summary: The US poverty rate rose to 11.6% in 2021, a second consecutive year, while household income remained little changed, decreasing to $70,784. This marks a reversal of the previous year's decline, which had brought the poverty rate to its lowest in 6 decades. The poverty rate has been roughly cut in half over the past 60 years.

images.alt_text: The acceleration in inflation points to a stubbornly high cost of living for Americans, despite some relief at the gas pump.

site_title: Germany drawing up new China trade policy, vows ‘no more naivety’
summary: Germany is drawing up a new trade policy with China, aiming to reduce dependence on Chinese raw materials, batteries, and semiconductors. Economy Minister Robert Habeck vowed "no more naivety" in trade dealings with Beijing, citing concerns over protectionism and human rights violations. The new policy includes closer examination of Chinese investments in Europe and may include measures such as reducing or scrapping investment and export guarantees for China. The move is a tougher line than the centre-left government's predecessor, with Habeck stating that Germany must open up to new trading partners and regions to mitigate dependence on China.

site_title: Ferrari eyes billion-euro payoff with new Purosangue SUV
summary: Ferrari has unveiled its first 4-door car, the Purosangue, with a price tag of 390,000 euros (S$552,800) in Italy, estimated to be S$1.8 million in Singapore. The SUV-like vehicle offers 4 full-size seats, a 725 horsepower engine, and a unique patented wheelarch design. Ferrari aims to cater to drivers who want to share the thrills of a Ferrari car with their family and friends. The brand expects high demand for the Purosangue, with the chief marketing and commercial officer stating that the response has been "amazing" and comparable to that of limited edition Ferrari cars.

images.alt_text: “We have more and more stepping into Lamborghini. Because they trust the brand, they see how beautiful the cars are, how (high) performing they are,” CEO Stephan Winkelmann said.
Built from carbon fibre to make it light yet strong, the Daytona SP3 is a modern interpretation of Ferrari’s 330 series of impossibly sensual racing cars.

site_title: UK pay gap is set to fuel more strikes among government workers
summary: The UK public sector pay gap is expected to fuel more strikes among government workers, as private sector workers receive 6% pay growth, triple that of government employees, who received 2% growth. This widening gap is likely to intensify calls for strikes amid the rising cost of living. Industrial action has already been seen in services, and school teachers and hospital staff are threatening to take action to persuade the government to increase its pay offer. The Bank of England is set to raise interest rates to combat a wage-price spiral.

site_title: UBS CFO sees increased client caution as global economy slows
summary: UBS CFO Sarah Youngwood stated that the bank is seeing increased client caution due to the slowing global economy, rising inflation, and energy prices. This has led to fewer transactions and recurring revenues. The US and Switzerland are performing better, while the Asia-Pacific region is still deleveraging. Europe and the UK are in a cautious situation. UBS plans to increase its dividend by 10% and expects to exceed its US$5 billion share repurchase goal. The bank is conservatively positioned with a strong balance sheet and aims to be capital generative.

site_title: Making sense of the Metaverse
summary: The metaverse, a virtual realm, is evolving beyond gaming, with technologies like virtual reality headsets and blockchain expected to push its boundaries. The concept has existed in various forms for decades, with platforms like Second Life and Fortnite. Experts envision a digital economy flourishing in the metaverse, where users can create, buy, and sell goods, with interoperable digital platforms allowing seamless transitions between them. Businesses must prepare for this evolution to avoid being left behind in the digital economy, as the metaverse is poised to become a major force in the online world.

images.alt_text: Companies such as Accenture, Walmart and Bank of America are increasingly using VR for both onboarding and training. Last year, Accenture purchased 60,000 Oculus VR headsets to use for onboarding, and joiners now spend their first day at the company in its One Accenture Park campus, part of its “Nth floor” corporate metaverse, which the company has developed with Microsoft.

site_title: EU plans Sep 30 summit to greenlight emergency energy plans
summary: The European Union is set to hold an emergency summit on September 30 to approve new energy measures aimed at reducing soaring gas and power prices. The measures, proposed by the European Commission, include a cap on non-gas fuel generators' revenues and a requirement for fossil fuel firms to share excess profits. EU energy ministers will discuss and potentially approve the proposals, which are seen as a way to cushion individuals and businesses from record-high energy costs and inflation. The summit follows a week of negotiations between EU countries on the best way to tackle the energy crisis.

site_title: Asean region critical to tackling food security, but countries must deal with multiple risks
summary: South-east Asia, a major crop grower due to its favourable climate and fertile soil, faces challenges in food security due to rising inflation and climate change. The region, home to key producers of palm oil, rice, and dried beans, is vulnerable to yield stagnation, urbanization, and inadequate infrastructure. Despite opportunities for agri-tech and sustainable investing, climate risks and government intervention can impact production. Countries like Indonesia, Malaysia, and Vietnam are major producers of commodities, but face challenges such as a lack of rainfall, high temperatures, and floods.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
The Middle East Eye news site cites a shipping agent as saying that a Turkish buyer has been found for the maize on board the Sierra Leone-flagged vessel Razoni.
The nation missed its sugar production target after weather and high fertiliser costs cut harvests.

Monsoon rains, which were delayed in parts of India’s northern and eastern rice producing regions, have improved over the last couple of weeks, boosting crop prospects in the world’s largest rice supplier, traders said.
Despite higher prices, capital expenditure in oil and gas continues to decline
Thailand announced in late August that the national daily minimum wage would go up by an average of 5 per cent from October – the first such increase since January 2020.
The Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) food price index has been falling steadily since hitting an all-time high in March following Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
Britain’s supermarkets have said they are doing all they can to avoid passing on prices to shoppers but are also facing their own surging bills as energy and fuel costs rise.

site_title: Keppel O&M entity applies for court injunction to prohibit payment on US$126.6m letter of credit
summary: A Keppel O&M entity has applied for a Singapore court injunction to block a US$126.6 million payment on a standby letter of credit. The entity, which is 75% owned by Keppel O&M, had issued the letter of credit to a customer in 2019 for a rig contract. However, a government authority later deemed the contract's contractual formulas invalid, prompting the customer to seek payment. Keppel considers the decision premature and has filed legal proceedings to challenge it, with no impact on its financial performance.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Kingsdale Development owns 80 per cent of the Spring City Golf & Lake Resort in Kunming, China.

site_title: Shipping new products, attracting foreign traders among Singapore’s routes to Trade 2030 goals
summary: Singapore aims to grow its exports to at least S$1 trillion and double offshore trade to US$2 trillion by 2030, according to its Trade 2030 plan. To achieve this, the country is focusing on nurturing homegrown global traders and attracting foreign traders, even if their goods don't pass through the port. Companies like Agrocorp International, Apeiron Bioenergy, and Mlion Corporation are developing new products and services, such as plant-based cheese and biofuels, to stay ahead in the global market. Enterprise Singapore is supporting these companies through programs like Scale-up SG and the Enterprise Leadership for Transformation Programme.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim

port / ST20220512_202233333961 / Alphonsus Chern //

Generic photograph of the Tanjong Pagar container terminal. 12 May 2022.

Total merchandise trade is now expected to grow 15-16 per cent, rather than the 8-10 per cent projected just 3 months ago, Enterprise Singapore (Enterprise SG) said on Thursday (Aug 11). The updated outlook for non-oil domestic exports is 5-6 per cent, instead of 3-5 per cent.
Singapore Economy 2030 vision aims to create export value of at least S$1 trillion

site_title: US: Stocks end with steep declines after hot inflation data
summary: US stocks plummeted on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 3.9% to 31,104.97, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes dropping 4.3% and 5.2% respectively. Disappointing US inflation data, showing a 0.1% rise in July and a 6.3% increase in "core" CPI, led to the losses, with economists predicting a third consecutive three-quarter point hike by the Federal Reserve. The worst trading day in weeks was sparked by investors' concerns over the extent of price increases, with Twitter's shares rising 0.8% despite a whistleblower's allegations against the company.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 374.84 points, or 1.16  per cent, at the open to 32,006.50.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close slightly lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed slightly lower on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index dropping 0.2% to 19,326.86. Gains from earlier in the day were erased in the final hour of trading. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.1% and 0.3% respectively. The modest losses were attributed to a decline in investor sentiment, with some attributing it to tariff uncertainty.

site_title: China Aviation Oil appoints new CEO, CFO
summary: China Aviation Oil has appointed Lin Yi as its new CEO, succeeding Wang Yanjun, who is stepping down after a four-year tenure. Lin, 52, previously served as general manager at China National Aviation Fuel South China Bluesky Corp and as an advisor to the Guangdong branch from 2010 to 2018. The leadership change is part of the company's senior management succession planning.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

site_title: Auto parts supplier Aptiv to acquire 85% of Intercable unit in EV tech push
summary: Aptiv, an auto parts supplier, agreed to acquire an 85% stake in Intercable Automotive Solutions for 595 million euros, gaining access to electric vehicle technology. The deal will allow Aptiv to manufacture high-voltage busbars for EVs, a crucial component in electric vehicles. The acquisition is expected to close before the end of the year and add to Aptiv's earnings next year. The move is part of the growing trend of auto parts suppliers investing in electric and battery technology to cater to the EV market, valued at over $5 trillion over the next decade.

site_title: Evergrande vows to resume projects to allay boycott concerns
summary: Evergrande Group has pledged to resume its remaining stalled projects by the end of the month, aiming to allay concerns that prompted some homebuyers to refuse to pay mortgages for unfinished apartments. The company has already resumed building on 668 of its 706 projects and will restart construction on 38 developments by September 30. The move aims to ease pressure on the Chinese property sector and prevent a potential threat to social stability ahead of a Communist Party congress.

images.alt_text: Sunac, which was once the country’s fourth-largest builder by sales, has fallen to ninth, according to China Real Estate Information data.

site_title: Copper prices down after strong US inflation data
summary: US inflation unexpectedly rose 0.1% in August, causing copper prices to drop 1.4% to $7,847 a tonne on the London Metal Exchange. Investors feared more interest rate hikes, dampening metals demand. The dollar strengthened, weighing on commodities priced in the US currency. Other metals, such as aluminium, zinc, and nickel, also fell, while tin dropped 1.2%. The data reversed earlier buying activity in metals, with copper prices now at their lowest since August 25.

images.alt_text: BHP Group, the world’s biggest miner, is among suppliers that are diverting shipments away from Maike for now.

site_title: iPhone maker Foxconn strikes pact for chip plant in Western India
summary: Taiwan's Hon Hai, known as Foxconn, has partnered with Vedanta to set up a chip-making facility in Gujarat, India, with a total investment of $27.1 billion. The joint venture aims to tap into rising demand for semiconductors, with plans to build a factory and employ around 100,000 people. The project is part of India's US$10 billion incentive plan to lure display and semiconductor fabricators to set up base in the country, which is also the world's No. 2 smartphone maker. Construction is expected to begin within the next two years.

site_title: US: Wall St slumps at open after hot inflation data
summary: US stocks plummeted at the open on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones falling 1.16% to 32,006.50, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite opening lower by 1.78% and 2.92% respectively. This follows the release of hot inflation data, which reinforced expectations of a third consecutive 75-basis-point rate hike from the Federal Reserve next week.

site_title: Bank capital rules for cryptoassets due by year end
summary: The global Basel Committee of banking regulators has proposed punitive capital charges on 'unbacked' cryptoassets like bitcoin, with a focus on designing a robust regulatory framework for banks' exposures to cryptoassets. The committee aims to finalize the framework by the end of the year. The proposal also includes more lenient treatment for stablecoins, while urging member countries to implement the final leg of Basel III, a suite of tougher capital requirements, as soon as possible.

site_title: State land tenders for  private housing, EC plots draw fewer-than-expected bids
summary: State land tenders for private housing and EC plots in Singapore drew fewer-than-expected bids, with only 4 bids for the EC plot in Bukit Batok and 3 bids for the Lentor Central private housing site. The top bid for the EC plot was S$626 psf ppr, 5.4% lower than the winning bid for the adjacent plot. Rising interest rates, inflation, and construction costs may be deterring developers, with prices near the top-end of the price envelope for new EC projects. The government's supply build-up in the Lentor area may also be contributing to the low participation rate.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
URA tender pulls in 8 bids for Jalan Tembusu plot, and 4 for Lentor plot
krtender2 - Aerial view of Pine Grove (Parcel A).
Latest GLS tenders see firm land prices, keener interest from developers

site_title: Boeing deliveries rose in August as it resumed 787 handovers
summary: Boeing delivered 35 airplanes in August, including 27 737 MAX jets, 2 787s, and 5 freighters, bringing the total MAX deliveries to 240 and overall deliveries to 277 through August. This marks a rebound from a five-month low in July deliveries. Boeing resumed 787 handovers after a 15-month delay and has about 120 787s awaiting delivery. The company reported 30 new gross orders for airplanes in August, including 13 737 MAX planes.

images.alt_text: The deals comprise the leasing of 21 Airbus A320neos (above),  4 Airbus A321neos and 5 Boeing B777-200LRs.

site_title: Fed to stick to aggressive rate hikes as inflation stays hot
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to deliver a third straight 75-basis point interest rate hike, possibly a full percentage point increase, to combat high inflation. Consumer prices rose 0.1% in August, exceeding expectations, and core prices increased 0.6% from July. The Fed aims to keep raising rates until inflation drops, with policymakers downplaying the importance of individual data points. Market pricing now reflects a one-in-five chance of a full percentage point increase, putting the policy target in the 3-3.25% range.

images.alt_text: The acceleration in inflation points to a stubbornly high cost of living for Americans, despite some relief at the gas pump.

site_title: Xi returns to world stage with Putin to counter US dominance
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping is set to meet with Russian President Vladimir Putin, marking a significant shift in China's stance towards the US-led world order. The meeting, which will take place on the sidelines of a Chinese-founded security forum in Uzbekistan, aims to counter US dominance and promote a multipolar world. Xi's vision for a world where China can expand its interests without fearing US pressure will be further reinforced, as he prepares to secure a third term as leader of the world's second-largest economy. The meeting is seen as a key moment for Xi to re-emerge on the global stage ahead of the Group of 20 summit in November.

images.alt_text: File photo of Vladimir Putin and President Xi Jinping meeting at the Eastern Economic Forum in Vladivostok, Russia 2018; the 2 leaders are deepening ties  with trade soaring by nearly a third between Russia and China in the first 7 months of 2022.

site_title: Offer price for GYP Properties sweetened again to final S$0.20 per share
summary: Rumah & Co has raised its offer price for GYP Properties to a final S$0.20 per share, a 6.4% increase from the previous price of S$0.188. This marks a 37.9% premium to GYP's volume-weighted average price for 1 month up to Jul 8. The offer, which was initially set at S$0.168 per share, will close on Oct 7 at 5:30pm.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

site_title: SMG chairman, CEO, exec director seek to privatise company at S$0.37 per share
summary: Singapore Medical Group (SMG) has launched a privatization offer by investment vehicle TLW Success at S$0.37 per share in cash or 1 new share. The offer, led by CEO Beng Teck Liang, chairman Tony Tan Choon Keat, and executive director Wong Seng Weng, aims to provide greater flexibility for long-term investments and enhance shareholder value. The offer is conditional on TLW holding over 90% of SMG shares and will make SMG a wholly-owned subsidiary.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

Memories Group is the tourism spin-off of Yoma Strategic. The group and Memories (2022), an associate of Yoma's executive chairman Serge Pun, is offering to take Memories private. at S$0.047 per share.

site_title: Inditex founder Amancio Ortega to buy US warehouses for US$905m
summary: Spanish billionaire Amancio Ortega's family office Pontegadea is acquiring US warehouses worth $905 million from companies such as Amazon and FedEx. This deal follows previous purchases in Wisconsin and Pennsylvania, with the new warehouses having long-term leases to blue-chip companies. Pontegadea is seeking highly profitable assets with medium- and long-term leases, and these warehouses meet the criteria. Ortega's investment firm has also recently acquired a skyscraper in New York and a Canadian landmark building, and he is one of the world's 30 wealthiest entrepreneurs.

site_title: US inflation tops forecasts, cementing odds of big Fed hike
summary: US inflation rose 0.1% in August, exceeding forecasts, and increased 8.3% from last year, with core CPI up 6.3%. The acceleration in inflation suggests a stubbornly high cost of living for Americans, prompting the Federal Reserve to consider a third 75-basis-point interest-rate hike to achieve price stability. The Fed has indicated it will act "forthrightly" and some policymakers support a historically large rate hike, with traders now betting on a 75-basis-point move.

images.alt_text: A strong majority of economists polled, 44 of 72, predicted the central bank would hike its fed funds rate by 75 basis points next week after two such moves in June and July, compared to only 20 per cent who said so just a month ago.

site_title: From beer to tomatoes, Europe’s energy crisis is spilling over
summary: Europe's energy crisis is affecting various sectors beyond utilities and energy-intensive industries, including food and drink supplies. The crisis, triggered by Russia's gas cuts, has led to a surge in liquid carbon dioxide prices, causing breweries like Delirium Tremens to consider halting production. Other affected businesses include German tomato grower Wittenberg Gemuese GmbH, which relies on ammonia and CO2 for heating and greenhouses, and Swedish bakery Pagen, which warned about risks to food supply from surging energy costs. The European Union is proposing measures to cut power use and funnel energy profits to struggling consumers.

images.alt_text: The EU is seeking to curb power consumption and provide liquidity to energy markets as it seeks to prevent the crisis from engulfing the broader economy.

site_title: Future-proofing Asia’s digital native firms
summary: Asia's digital-native companies, born and bred in the cloud, have long been successful due to their agility and ability to innovate quickly. However, they are now at an impasse, struggling to maintain growth in a rapidly changing business environment. To overcome this, digital natives must prioritize understanding consumers' profiles and offering differentiated customer experiences, while also innovating sustainably and practically. This can be achieved by leveraging fit-for-purpose solutions such as software development toolkits and APIs, and investing in communications technology to facilitate borderless interactions with employees, customers, and end-users.

images.alt_text: startup, start-up, people

site_title: Germany will trigger a hydrogen industry boom: Chancellor Scholz
summary: German Chancellor Olaf Scholz announced plans to trigger a hydrogen industry boom, aiming to diversify energy sources and meet climate goals. He promised to establish the necessary infrastructure to import all hydrogen gas by the end of 2023. This move follows discussions with Canada to build liquefied natural gas terminals off the Canadian Atlantic coast. Hydrogen is a zero-carbon fuel suitable for powering large industrial machines, heavy vehicles, and heating.

site_title: US dollar weakens ahead of key US inflation data
summary: The US dollar weakened 0.4% to 107.76 against a basket of currencies ahead of key US inflation data, which could show signs of softening. The euro rose 0.6% to $1.0180, while the yen strengthened against the dollar. US inflation figures are expected to show a 0.3% month-on-month rise in the core consumer price index, down from a 0.7% rise in July. Market expectations suggest the Federal Reserve may hike interest rates by 75 basis points, but may slow the pace if inflation softens.

site_title: Saudi oil output hit 11 million barrels a day last month
summary: Saudi Arabia reported its highest monthly oil production level of 11 million barrels a day in August, surpassing the 12 million barrels a day peak in April 2020. This increase is part of Opec's efforts to stabilize global markets and respond to US and other consumer demands to curb rising fuel costs. The move fulfills Saudi Arabia's pledge to stabilize the market, with output levels rarely exceeding 11 million barrels in the country's history.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled up US$1.16, or 1.3 per cent, at US$94.00 a barrel on Monday.

site_title: Ask not when top talent will leave; rather, welcome those who stay
summary: Singapore's new pass for top talent aims to attract global experts, not just for short-term stays, but also if they choose to stay and contribute. The Overseas Networks and Expertise (One) Pass is valid for 5 years with the possibility of renewal, allowing holders to work for multiple companies. The government has clarified that imposing annual caps or maximum stay limits does not make sense, as it could hinder competition. The One Pass is a permanent visa, paving the way towards citizenship, and the government will carefully vet and monitor holders to prevent abuse.

images.alt_text: Singapore needs to make these foreign talent moves now to strengthen its position as a global hub for talent, said Manpower Minister Tan See Leng.

Safeguards will be put in place for the Overseas Networks and Expertise pass, said Minister of Manpower Tan See Leng in a ministerial statement where he also addressed the target nature of the government's recent work pass enhancements.

site_title: The 8 dangerous things people say about the stock market
summary: Investors often make mistakes in times of market stress, fueled by biases and misconceptions. The S&P 500, which hit an all-time high earlier this year, is now almost 16% below its peak. Common investment mistakes include waiting for the economy to improve before investing, selling stocks during a bear market, holding onto losing stocks, and buying or selling based on the Federal Reserve's actions. The best approach is to buy shares because you want to own a piece of the business, not because its price has fallen. Averaging down or making decisions based on emotions can also lead to poor investment decisions.

images.alt_text: Nurture your human capital along with financial assets
History suggests a continuation of the current slump would be an exceedingly rare event.

site_title: Russia tells Armenia and Azerbaijan to stop hostilities after negotiating ceasefire
summary: Russia has called on Armenia and Azerbaijan to cease hostilities and observe a ceasefire agreement, expressing "extreme concern" over renewed fighting between the two countries. A ceasefire was brokered by Russia at 0600 GMT on September 13, but it broke down within 15 minutes. Armenia's Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan reported 49 Armenian soldiers dead, while Azerbaijan blamed Armenia for the escalation. Russia urged both sides to resolve the dispute through diplomatic means, but did not specify who it held responsible for the latest escalation.

images.alt_text: Ukrainian artillerymen load a BM-21 Grad multiple rocket launcher near Izyum, south of Kharkiv, on June 11, 2022. Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky on Sunday confirmed Ukrainian troops had recaptured the strategic city of Izyum.

site_title: Google faces 25 billion euros damages claims in UK, Dutch courts over adtech practices
summary: Google faces 25 billion euros in damages claims in UK and Dutch courts over its adtech practices, which have drawn scrutiny from antitrust regulators. Publishers are seeking compensation for lost revenue from the sale of advertising space on their websites. The claims come after a French competition watchdog imposed a 220-million-euro fine on Google last year. The lawsuits, filed by law firm Geradin Partners, aim to recover compensation for EU and UK publishers affected by Google's actions.

site_title: Centurion unit to expand Malaysian worker dorm capacity amid recent regulation
summary: Centurion Corp's unit, Westlite Accommodation Malaysia, plans to expand its worker dorm capacity after reconfiguring its Malaysian properties to comply with the International Labour Organization's Act 446 regulation, which requires employers to provide migrant workers with basic amenities. The company aims to cater to growing demand from multinational companies and SMEs. Following the reconfiguration, Westlite reduced its bed count to 25,099 beds, and has since undertaken asset enhancement works to add 688 beds. CEO Kong Chee Min expects a growth in demand for high-quality worker dormitories.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Centurion on Thursday (Aug 11) posted earnings of S$32.9 million for the first half, a 277 per cent jump from S$8.7 million in the year-ago period.

site_title: China tells banks to report exposure to conglomerate Fosun
summary: China's banking regulators have instructed the nation's biggest banks and state-owned firms to examine their financial exposure to Fosun, a large non-state conglomerate. The move follows recent concerns about Fosun's financial strength, which has seen its shares and US dollar bonds decline amid a record wave of defaults by Chinese borrowers. Fosun entities have disclosed plans to pare stakes in publicly listed units and has taken steps to dispose of assets for debt repayment, including an early redemption of a 2 billion yuan bond.

site_title: Philippines’ biggest toll road operator plans IPO to raise US$500m: sources
summary: Metro Pacific Tollways, the Philippines' largest toll road operator, plans an initial public offering (IPO) to raise US$500 million, valuing the company at over US$2 billion. The IPO, expected to be listed in late 2023 or 2024, will be used to fund expansion in the Philippines and South-east Asia. The company, majority-owned by Hong Kong's First Pacific, currently operates toll roads in the Philippines and has investments in Indonesia and Vietnam. Proceeds from the IPO will also be used to repay debt.

site_title: India could grow at 7% annually this decade: chief economic adviser
summary: India's chief economic adviser, V. Anantha Nageshwaran, predicts the country's economy will grow at 7% annually this decade, driven by rising investment spending and the digital economy. The government expects the economy to expand at over 7% in the current fiscal year, following a 13.5% growth in the April-to-June quarter. However, economists warn that growth momentum may lose steam in the coming quarters due to higher interest rates.

site_title: BofA survey shows investors fleeing equities en masse on fear of recession
summary: Investors are fleeing equities en masse amid concerns of a recession, with a record 52% of respondents saying they are underweight to stocks and 62% overweight to cash, according to a Bank of America survey. A historically high 42% of global investors are underweight European equities, and 92% expect profits to decline in the next year. Despite bleak sentiment, strategists expect global stocks to rise to 4,300 points by year-end, but remain bearish, citing persistently high inflation and hawkish central banks.

images.alt_text: The Indonesia Stock Exchange (IDX) in Jakarta; the composition of South-east Asia’s equity benchmarks – low tech weighting and relatively high ratio of bank shares – is favourable in a rising global interest-rate environment.

site_title: Germany plans US$68b loan guarantees for energy firms
summary: Germany's government is set to approve a plan to provide €67 billion (US$94.9 billion) in loan guarantees to struggling energy firms amid Russia's supply cuts, helping companies cope with higher prices. The plan, overseen by state development bank KfW, aims to support utilities amid fears of bankruptcies. This move comes as Europe's largest economy faces an energy crunch, with concerns mounting that Germany could face a wave of bankruptcies. The plan is separate from a financial aid package announced in April, and is part of the government's efforts to address liquidity problems in the industry.

images.alt_text: A street demonstration byGermany's metal workers union IG Metall in the city centre of Leipzig in eastern Germany, on Sep 10 (Saturday). They are demanding a wage increase of 8 per cent in the upcoming collective bargaining talks even as the country convulses under slashed energy supplies from Russia, which has driven up living costs.

site_title: Porsche is worth much less than what’s being touted, HSBC says
summary: HSBC analysts have downgraded Porsche's valuation, estimating it to be between 44.5 billion euros (S$63.09 billion) and 56.9 billion euros, lower than the 60 billion euros-to-85 billion euros range being discussed in the media. The analysts warn that pricing power may wane as supply recovers and demand may be impacted by a recessionary environment. This assessment is in contrast to the previously touted valuations, highlighting the need for a more realistic assessment of Porsche's worth ahead of its upcoming share sale.

site_title: ERP rates at 5 locations to increase by S$1 from Sept 19
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) announced that Electronic Road Pricing (ERP) rates at 5 locations will increase by S$1 starting September 19. The rate hikes are in response to building traffic congestion on various expressways. The affected locations include the Ayer-Rajah Expressway, Central Expressway, and Pan-Island Expressway. Motorists will face increased ERP rates during specific time periods, including 8:30am-9am, 5:30pm-6pm, and 7:30pm-8pm. The LTA aims to manage congestion and alleviate traffic pressure on expressways.

images.alt_text: How large a part will electric vehicles play in solving our climate woes?

site_title: Parkway Life Reit to acquire 3 Hokkaido nursing homes for 2.6 billion yen
summary: Parkway Life Reit has agreed to acquire 3 nursing homes in Hokkaido, Japan for 2.56 billion yen, expanding its healthcare portfolio. The properties, operated by Blue Care, will be funded by Japanese yen debts and are expected to generate a 6.5% net property yield. The acquisition brings the Reit's Japan portfolio to 55 properties, valued at S$725.33 million, and is expected to be completed by Q3 this year.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
hands, old, old age

site_title: Creditors lose some rights as ESG bond market allows legal tweak
summary: Creditors lose some rights in a new, more flexible version of sustainability-linked bonds (SLBs), which allow issuers to adjust environmental, social, or governance targets without bondholder permission. This variation, known as flexible SLBs, is expected to gain traction as issuers seek to cope with volatile markets. However, investors may be unaware of the new clauses and may scrutinize them more closely, prompting issuers to provide greater clarity. Experts emphasize the need for third-party involvement to confirm the alignment of new key-performance indicators with materiality assessments.

site_title: Europe: Stocks steady at open, before US inflation
summary: European stocks steadied at the open on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 dipping 0.1% to 7,464.30 points, while Frankfurt's DAX rose 0.1% and Paris' CAC 40 gained 0.2%. The focus is on US inflation numbers due Tuesday, which will influence the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes.

site_title: Vietnam slashes power usage at its largest solar farm
summary: Vietnam's state-owned utility EVN has cut the utilisation rate of its largest solar farm, Trung Nam - Thuan Nam, by 40% to 278 megawatts from 450 megawatts due to the lack of a pricing mechanism. The move may hinder the country's drive to increase renewable energy use, despite its goal to become carbon-neutral by 2050.

site_title: Whale watching gets serious
summary: A recent incident in New Zealand's South Island resulted in 5 fatalities when a whale surfaced under a small tourist boat, capsizing it. The danger to whales primarily comes from increased shipping traffic and the speed, size, and noise of ships, rather than people watching whales. The World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF) reports that shipping has increased by 300% in the past 20 years, posing a significant threat to marine life. To address this, companies like Mediterranean Shipping Company (MSC) are taking measures, such as rerouting vessels to avoid areas with high whale activity, in an effort to reduce collisions and mitigate the impact of underwater noise pollution.

images.alt_text: strait31 - Pic for Strait Talk 31 Aug 22. Ulsteins Thor project would use nuclear energy to fuel a fleet of electric powered expedition cruise ships.

site_title: Wanted: Corporate leaders and men on the board of a women’s charity
summary: A Singaporean charity, SG Her Empowerment (SHE), founded by veteran lawyer Stefanie Yuen Thio, aims to tackle online harms faced by women and girls. Despite its focus on women's issues, Yuen Thio believes the charity should have more men and corporate leaders on its board to leverage their expertise and training programs. The charity seeks to tap into companies' leadership and internship opportunities to further its mission, emphasizing the importance of diverse perspectives and partnerships.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
The workplace should be the driving force of gender equality

site_title: Ports in eastern China at standstill as typhoon Muifa closes in
summary: Typhoon Muifa is making landfall in eastern China's Zhejiang province, causing widespread disruptions. Shanghai's ports will suspend operations, and schools in Ningbo, Zhoushan, and Taizhou have been ordered to close. Approximately 13,000 people have been evacuated from islands near Zhoushan, and nearly 7,400 commercial vessels are seeking shelter in ports. The typhoon, China's 12th cyclone of the year, is expected to bring torrential rains and waves of up to 5 meters, affecting a population of 42.26 million in the affected cities.

site_title: UK police remind officers of right to protest amid anti-royal demos
summary: UK police have reminded officers of the public's right to protest amid anti-monarchy demonstrations following Queen Elizabeth II's death. Metropolitan Police deputy assistant commissioner Stuart Cundy stated that protesters have a right to express their views, citing a positive interaction with most protesters. However, a female protester was escorted away from the UK parliament after holding a "not my king" placard, and another protester has been charged with a crime for holding an "abolish monarchy" sign. Civil rights groups have criticized the police handling of protests.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said on Tuesday that he had yet to turn his attention to whether an Australian should be on the A$5 note.

site_title: Thailand offers oil users more relief to tame inflation risk
summary: Thailand extends a 5 baht per liter excise tax rebate on retail diesel prices for two months to Nov 20 to shield consumers from higher oil prices amid forecasted sticky inflation. The move, costing the administration 20 billion baht, aims to freeze diesel prices and prevent a rise in the cost of living. Headline inflation is expected to stay above the Bank of Thailand's target range of 1-3% next year due to high energy and food prices.

site_title: Japan Airlines’ international capacity outstrips demand: official
summary: Japan Airlines operates at 65% of its international capacity, with demand limited to 40% of pre-pandemic levels due to COVID-19 curbs. In contrast, domestic flights are at 100% of pre-pandemic capacity, with demand at 80% of pre-pandemic levels. Japan's international travel demand has been hindered by visa requirements and daily caps on inbound travelers.
