The government plans to waive tourist visa requirements from some countries and lift daily arrival caps by October, which could boost international travel demand.

images.alt_text: The removal of the 50,000 people-per-day cap alone will not return Japan’s border to its pre-Covid openness, as non-resident foreigners are also currently required to obtain visas for short-term stays, and may enter for tourism only as part of approved package tours.

site_title: US-UK ties: Will the ‘special relationship’ outlast the Queen’s death?
summary: The death of Queen Elizabeth II has sparked a reevaluation of the "special relationship" between the US and UK, a bond forged during World War I, World War II, and the Cold War. The relationship, coined by Winston Churchill, symbolized cooperation between two sovereign nations. However, some Americans have expressed skepticism about the relationship, viewing the monarchy as a symbol of colonialism and racism. Despite this, the US-UK alliance may become more central to US foreign policy amid evolving geostrategic and ideological rivalries with China and Russia.

images.alt_text: A grab from a handout video made available by the UK Parliamentary Recording Unit shows Britain's King Charles III (at centre left) and Camilla the Queen Consort and speaker of the House of Commons Lindsay Hoyle (right) singing the national anthem following his address to the Houses of Parliament at Westminster Hall in London.
Britain's King Charles handshakes with the Commonwealth Secretary-General Baroness Patricia Scotland at Buckingham Palace, following the death of Britain's Queen Elizabeth, in London, Sept 11, 2022.

site_title: Thai consumer confidence at 7-month high in August
summary: Thai consumer confidence reached a 7-month high in August, rising to 43.7, driven by improved economic activity following eased pandemic curbs and the return of night entertainment. The steady rise suggests a clear recovery in Thailand's economy, with growth expected at 3.0-3.5% this year. Consumer spending is expected to increase significantly, driven by wage increases and increased exports, particularly in the tourism sector, which is forecast to reach 12 million foreign arrivals this year.

images.alt_text: Thailand has promoted high-tech sectors and supported electric vehicles to maintain its status as a regional auto production base..

site_title: Seoul: Shares post biggest surge in 1 1/2 years as heavyweights shine
summary: South Korea's Kospi index surged 2.74% to 2,449.54 points, its largest gain since February 2021, driven by heavyweights such as Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix. The won strengthened and benchmark bond yields rose, following Wall Street's rally during domestic holidays. Foreigners were net buyers of shares worth 396.8 billion won, and US inflation data due later will influence the Federal Reserve's monetary policy path.

images.alt_text: The Kospi ended up 7.82 points or 0.33 per cent at 2,384.28, rebounding from the previous session’s close at the lowest since Jul 19.

site_title: China’s C919 narrowbody jet set for Sep 19 certification
summary: China's C919 narrowbody jet is set to receive certification on September 19, aligning with the model's name. Produced by state-owned planemaker COMAC, the aircraft is China's rival to the Boeing 737 MAX and Airbus A320 family. The certification comes after two planes had landed in Beijing, and China Eastern Airlines, the first customer, expects to receive one of the jets this year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Tuesday, extending Wall Street rallies, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.25% to 28,614.63. A wait-and-see mood ahead of US inflation data release contributed to the gains. The broader Topix index also increased 0.32%.

site_title: Singapore stocks lifted on US bear market rally; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.5% to close at 3,290.08 points on Tuesday, tracking gains on Wall Street as US equities extended a bear market bounce for the fourth day. The wider market saw gainers outpace losers 257 to 244, with 1.24 billion shares worth S$926.9 million traded. The rally follows a 5-day run, amid uncertainty ahead of US CPI data release.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
As at 9.02 am, the Straits Times Index (STI) gained 0.2 per cent or 5.58 points to 3,280.30.

site_title: Soft landing for India means fast, if not fastest, growth
summary: India's central bank, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), is expected to slow down interest-rate hikes, shifting towards a "soft landing" approach to balance inflation and growth. Following weaker-than-expected GDP growth data, the RBI is likely to dial down the pace of rate hikes to quarter-point adjustments. This move aims to preserve growth while tackling price gains, as India's economy is poised to lose its spot as the world's fastest-growing major economy to Saudi Arabia this year.

images.alt_text: Food prices, which comprise about half of the inflation basket, accelerated 7.62 per cent in August while fuel and electricity prices went up 10.78 per cent from a year ago.
There are no signs of stress among home buyers and collections on loan dues remain robust says Keki Mistry, chief executive of HDFC.

site_title: Netflix’s megahit Squid Game makes history at Emmy Awards
summary: Netflix's Korean drama "Squid Game" made history at the Emmy Awards, winning top honors as the first foreign-language drama to take home the top prize. Creator Hwang Dong-hyuk won for outstanding directing, while Lee Jung-jae took home the Emmy for best actor in a drama series. The show's success follows other South Korean productions, such as "Parasite" and "Minari," which also explored themes of inequality and social issues, sparking international interest and investment in foreign-language content.

images.alt_text: Lee Yoo Mi, the winner of the Outstanding Guest Actress in a Drama Series award for Squid Game in Los Angeles, California, Sept 4, 2022.
Squid Game, the Netflix show – in which misfits and criminals compete for cash in barbaric and deadly versions of schoolyard games – is aiming to triumph at TV’s top prize gala.

site_title: US inflation likely eased in August - but not enough
summary: US inflation is expected to have eased in August, with the consumer price index (CPI) likely to have fallen and the annual inflation pace improving to 8.0%, according to a MarketWatch forecast. Despite this relief, high prices for food and housing continue to strain family budgets, and policymakers remain concerned about inflation's impact on the economy. The Federal Reserve views inflation as the biggest risk to the US economy and has taken aggressive measures to cool demand, increasing the benchmark lending rate four times this year.

images.alt_text: Goldman’s preference for US exposure comes during what is turning out to be a particularly tough year for business in Europe amid a gas crisis, soaring inflation and tightening central-bank policy.

site_title: Positioned for every growth opportunity
summary: SGX Group, the Singapore Exchange, has delivered its highest revenue of S$1.1 billion in FY2022, driven by broad-based growth in derivatives volume across equities, currencies, and commodities. The company has sharpened its service offerings to deliver multiple avenues of growth for customers, including the acquisition of MaxxTrader and BidFX, and the expansion of its international presence. SGX achieved a long-term Aa2 rating from Moody's, affirming its position as a key central counterparty clearing-house and robust business model. The company remains committed to investing in opportunities to drive long-term growth and total shareholder return.

images.alt_text: SGX and MAS launched ESGenome, a disclosure portal for corporates to report their ESG data, on Monday (Sep 12).

site_title: Classic cars are gaining traction among the rich. Should you invest in them too?
summary: Classic cars are gaining popularity as an investment among the wealthy, with the global market expected to reach $35.5 billion by 2023. Live auctions, particularly those featuring pre-war and 1960s cars, tend to attract big spenders, while online auctions cater to younger collectors. However, owning a classic car comes with high maintenance costs, and investors must consider taxes, duties, and restrictions. While some collectors view classic cars as a labor of love, others seek a return on investment, making it a niche asset class with deep pockets required.

images.alt_text: Almost every car on display at Classic Remise in Germany is for sale.

site_title: Depleting forex reserves spell risks for emerging Asian currencies
summary: EMerging Asian central banks' foreign-exchange reserves have sharply depleted, with a closely-watched measure of reserves cover dropping to about 7 months, the lowest since the 2008 global financial crisis. This erosion of developing nation firepower may limit their ability to intervene in currency markets, with analysts expecting less supportive FX policies from central banks. The decline in reserves cover poses risks to emerging Asian currencies, particularly against the resurgent US dollar.

images.alt_text: Moody's expects Indonesia's metals, mining and steel company earnings to rise over 260 per cent this year from 2019 levels.
Chinese equities are seen making up lost ground as the extreme pessimism towards its economy recedes and authorities take further steps to revive stuttering growth.

site_title: Embrace risk: Playing safe with fixed deposits can hurt in the long run
summary: Investors in Singapore should consider taking on more risk to achieve long-term financial growth, despite the current high interest rates on fixed deposits and savings bonds. Playing it safe with capital-protected instruments like SSBs and fixed deposits can hurt in the long run due to inflation and potential erosion of purchasing power. Investing in equities, property, or other growth-oriented instruments can offer potential capital appreciation, but requires a long-term perspective and manageable risk. With Singapore's stable economy and growth prospects, embracing some risk can be a wise move for those who can afford it, especially for those nearing retirement or with a long investment horizon.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
Singapore Savings Bonds
Interest rates of savings accounts at the trio of local banks have risen in August.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit over 2-week high as banks shine; all eyes on US inflation data
summary: Australian shares hit a 2-week high, rising 0.7% to 7,009.7, driven by banks and miners. Investors await US inflation data to gauge the Federal Reserve's policy tightening stance. Financials reached a 2-week peak, with the "Big Four" banks gaining between 0.6 and 1.7%. Miners also rose, led by Rio Tinto's 0.7% gain.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index had climbed 0.7 per cent by 0014 GMT on Monday, adding 4 per cent in the past four sessions.

site_title: Hong Kong hasn’t decided on hotel quarantine cut, John Lee says
summary: Hong Kong Chief Executive John Lee has stated that the city has not decided whether to cut hotel quarantine requirements for new arrivals before a series of high-profile events in October and November. The events include a fintech summit, a global bankers' summit, and an international rugby tournament. Lee emphasized that the decision will be made based on the pandemic situation closer to the event dates to protect public health and high-risk groups.

images.alt_text: Under the new arrangements, locally based air crew can return home after obtaining a negative result of the nucleic acid test conducted at the airport.

site_title: DBS sets sector-specific decarbonisation targets; O&G to cut emissions by 28%
summary: DBS has set sector-specific decarbonisation targets, with oil and gas (O&G) aiming to reduce absolute emissions by 28% by 2030. The bank aims to achieve net zero by 2050 through measurable change. DBS has set decarbonisation targets for seven sectors, including power, automotive, aviation, shipping, steel, and real estate, with intensity targets guiding the other six sectors. The targets will guide DBS' financing activities and aim to reduce environmental impact.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng
Yong Hui Ting
STACS' Benjamin Soh says the volume of green finance is on the rise, which raise demand for ESG data and monitoring services.

site_title: Look beyond short-term biases and commit to a ‘foundation’ portfolio
summary: A diversified portfolio, known as a "foundation" portfolio, is essential for long-term financial stability, despite the current challenging market conditions. Historically, only 4 out of 150 years have seen both US equities and bonds lose value, and a 60:40 equity-bond portfolio has lost value only 9 times. Investors should avoid making two costly mistakes: selling all investments and going into cash, or ignoring diversification and taking a narrow investment exposure. Instead, remaining committed to a diversified portfolio, with a possible adjustment to cash allocation based on risk tolerance, is recommended.

images.alt_text: They’ve increasingly shunned stocks and bonds to focus on their own companies or assets deemed safer such as gold and cash.

site_title: Nintendo surges after record debut of new Switch game
summary: Nintendo's new game Splatoon 3 sold 3.45 million units in Japan over its opening weekend, surpassing Animal Crossing: New Horizons' 1.88 million units. This marked the biggest Switch debut to date. Shares surged 6% in Tokyo, the largest intraday jump since December 2020. Analysts believe strong software sales and upcoming holiday releases will extend the Switch's lifespan, despite hardware sales slumping 22% in Q1.

images.alt_text: The company behind Super Mario is forecasting the second annual sales decline for its hybrid home/portable Switch device, which is in its sixth year on the market.

site_title: Australia open to replacing queen’s image on banknotes with local figures
summary: Australia's government is open to replacing Queen Elizabeth II's image on the A$5 note with local figures. Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has not yet considered the possibility, but Federal Assistant Minister Andrew Leigh mentioned that the decision to include the queen's image was based on her personality, not her status as monarch. Leigh left the door open for a conversation about replacing the monarch with an Australian figure, such as indigenous land rights activist Edward Mabo.

images.alt_text: From left: Britain's Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex, his wife Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, Britain's Prince William, Prince of Wales and his wife Catherine, Princess of Wales, look at floral tributes laid by members of the public on the Long walk at Windsor Castle on Sep 10 (Saturday)  before meeting well-wishers.  Commentators said it was a show of unity that suggested that the death of the monarch could lead to a rapprochement.

The queen's death has drawn tears, sadness and warm tributes, not just from her own close family and many in Britain, but also from around the globe – reflecting her presence on the world stage for 7 decades.

site_title: Indonesia has lost more tropical forest to mining than anywhere
summary: Indonesia has lost more than half of its tropical forest to mining over the last two decades, accounting for 80% of global tropical deforestation due to industrial mining. A study found that 1,901 square km of forest were cut down to make way for mining, an area three times the size of Jakarta. The main driver was the expansion of coal mines on Borneo, with iron ore and gold mining also contributing to forest loss in Brazil and Ghana. The study warns that the energy transition could pose new risks to forests in areas where mining is concentrated.

images.alt_text: Earlier this month, indonesia hiked subsidised fuel prices by 30 per cent.

site_title: Singapore spent S$72.3 billion on Covid-19 in FY2020 and FY2021, less than budgeted
summary: Singapore's government spent S$72.3 billion on Covid-19 measures in FY2020 and FY2021, falling short of the S$100 billion budgeted. Breakdowns include S$13.4 billion for public health, S$50.6 billion for job protection, and S$8.3 billion for direct household support. The government has started reviewing pandemic-related procurement and expenditure controls, and audits are underway to prevent erroneous payments. Hospitalizations have declined in the latest Omicron wave, but the government is still assessing its healthcare capacity.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Foreign workers queueing to collect their lunch at a dormitory in 2020.
Nightlife businesses, including KTV bars, said they intend to follow government rules and keep masks optional.
Singapore agencies must subject key Covid-19 expenditures to checks: watchdog

site_title: Book review: Insights into the future of money
summary: Economist Eswar S. Prasad's book, "The Future of Money: How the Digital Revolution Is Transforming Currencies and Finance," explores the shift from traditional paper notes to digital currencies. The book examines the potential of digital currencies, blockchain technology, and fintech innovations, highlighting both benefits and drawbacks. Prasad debunks myths about cryptocurrencies, discusses the role of central bank digital currencies, and provides insights for investors on how to navigate the emerging financial landscape. The book aims to help economists, bankers, and investors understand the implications of digital currencies on the financial sector.

images.alt_text: Institutions are seriously looking into crypto assets, says Aureole Foong, Whampoa senior partner

site_title: Indonesia to review minimum wage rules after protests over fuel price hike
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo raised subsidized fuel prices by 30% to rein in an energy subsidy budget, sparking nationwide protests by workers and students. The protests led to a review of minimum wage and labor rules, with authorities meeting with trade unions to discuss demands for changes to the Job Creation law and the minimum wage formula. The fuel price hike is expected to accelerate inflation, which has already reached its highest since 2015, and workers are calling for a reversal of the price increase and other labor reforms.

images.alt_text: Indonesia will move ahead with plans to impose similar bans on exports of other raw commodities, regardless of the WTO decision in the dispute, the president told an economists’ forum in Jakarta.
Earlier this month, indonesia hiked subsidised fuel prices by 30 per cent.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rally ahead of key US inflation data
summary: Asian stocks rose ahead of US inflation data, which is expected to show slightly slowing inflation in the US. Stocks in Japan, Australia, Singapore, and Taiwan rose at the open, with Hong Kong, South Korea, and Shanghai also gaining after reopening. Analysts expect US inflation to slow to 8% but believe the Federal Reserve will continue to tighten monetary policy. Other key data releases this week include US retail sales and industrial production, and China home and retail sales.

images.alt_text: In Tokyo, stocks opened higher on Monday, driven by positive market sentiment off the back of last week’s gains and a weaker yen.

site_title: Sembcorp likely to be hit by UK’s energy price cap, analyst says
summary: Sembcorp Industries, a Singapore-based energy company, may face significant financial impact from the UK's energy price cap of £2,500 per year. The company has 1.3GW of energy assets in the UK, including battery storage, and a 100% stake in a long-term energy contract. Analysts Terence Chua and Kelvin Tan have differing opinions on the impact, with Chua predicting a double whammy and Tan estimating minimal impact. The UK government has agreed to guarantee financing for the difference between the new tariff and the previous system.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
“I will deliver on the energy crisis, dealing with people’s energy bills, but also dealing with the long-term issues we have on energy supply,” Britain's incoming Prime Minister Liz Truss said.

UK Business Secretary Kwasi Kwarteng is working to extend so-called contracts for difference to generators to replace more lucrative subsidies in an attempt to cap profits and avoid imposing a windfall tax.
In a bourse filing on Monday evening, Sembcorp said its wholly-owned subsidiary agreed to sell Sembcorp Energy India Limited to Tanweer Infrastructure.
The unit, Sembcorp Energy India Limited (SEIL) is one of the largest independent power producers in India, operating two coal-fired plants.

site_title: Hedge fund’s decade-long wait for China yuan crash nears payday
summary: US hedge fund manager Kevin Smith is betting that China's yuan will collapse, potentially cutting its value in half, as the country's housing market falters and the economy sputters under COVID lockdowns. China's yuan has dropped over 8% against the US dollar this year, the largest annual decline since 1994. Smith's fund has gained 38% this year, thanks to its bearish bets against the yuan and other assets. Despite warnings of a financial crisis, some economists believe China's strong savings and controlled banking system will mitigate the impact of the yuan's decline.

images.alt_text: Growing geo-strategic and geo-economic risks between the US and China could ignite costly trade wars that could, under the worst case scenario, lead to a military confrontation.

The central government rolled out a “three guarantees” policy in 2020, which requires local governments to guarantee people’s basic livelihood, the payment of wages, and the functioning of the local government.
FILE PHOTO: A China yuan note is seen in this illustration photo May 31, 2017.     REUTERS/Thomas White/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Indonesia set to pass new data privacy law after spate of leaks
summary: Indonesia is set to pass a new data privacy law after a spate of high-profile data breaches, including a recent leak of 105 million Indonesians. The law, which is expected to be passed by parliament this week, would impose penalties of up to 5 years in jail and a maximum fine of $470,037 for leaking or misusing private information. The law requires consent from individuals for personal data collection and erasure of records once the purpose is met, with relevant parties having 2 years to comply. The law's passage is seen as crucial for improving Indonesia's cybersecurity, particularly as its digital economy is expected to grow to $146 billion by 2025.

images.alt_text: Forests are a powerful ally in the struggle against climate change.
Students rallying against Jakarta's 30 per cent fuel price hike in Surabaya on Sep 8.

site_title: Local business sentiment moderates further for Q4: SCCB
summary: Singapore's local business sentiment moderated further in Q4 2022, with the Business Optimism Index falling to +4.98 percentage points. Weakening external demand, escalating geopolitical tensions, and slower global growth contributed to the decline. Despite this, five out of six indicators remained expansionary, with visible improvements seen in transportation and construction sectors. The outlook for the services sector moderated further, with inventory levels remaining in the negative zone, and the wholesale sector deteriorating significantly.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

Local business sentiment has moderated slightly for the second consecutive quarter in the third quarter of 2022, amid a global economic slowdown and geopolitical uncertainties, said the Singapore Commercial Credit Bureau on Tuesday (Jun 14).
Singapore business sentiment moderates slightly in Q2 on global uncertainty: SCCB
Slight improvement in Singapore business sentiment for Q1 2022 despite Covid uncertainties: SCCB

site_title: Gold edges higher on softer dollar ahead of US inflation data
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $1,725.70 per ounce, near a 2-week high, due to a subdued dollar ahead of US inflation data. Investors await cues on the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike path, with a Reuters poll predicting a 75-basis-point rate hike next week. The dollar index hovered near its lowest level since August 26, making gold less expensive for overseas buyers. US consumer price data is expected to show headline inflation rose 8.1% year-over-year in August.

images.alt_text: Physical gold demand in some Asian hubs remained firm last week as lower prices lured buyers, although an uptick in domestic rates restrained purchases in India.

site_title: Singapore shares rise on Monday’s open; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.2% on Tuesday, reaching 3,280.30, following a positive start to the week for US and European markets. Frasers Hospitality Trust's units fell 20% after a failed privatisation offer, while Yangzijiang Financial Holdings and local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB gained. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 indices also rose, while European shares hit a two-week high.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Frasers Centrepoint Trust will acquire an additional 10 per cent interest in Waterway Point, its manager said on Monday.

site_title: Hot stock: FHT slides 24.8% after missing votes needed for proposed privatisation
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust (FHT) plummeted 24.8% to a 5-month low on Tuesday after narrowly missing the required 75% vote for proposed privatisation, which was priced at S$0.70 per stapled security. Despite the setback, FHT's stapled securities are now cheaper than most peers on a price-to-book ratio basis, with analysts like Quiddity Advisors' Travis Lundy expressing a "mildly bullish" stance on the counter.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.03 points or 0.07% to 1,496.93. Volume reached 279.36 million lots worth RM82.10 million, with 187 gainers outnumbering 115 losers.

site_title: Bank of America expands wealth management group in push to win rich clients
summary: Bank of America has formed a new wealth management group, led by April Schneider, comprising 3,500 employees. The organization brings together banking, lending, and wealth management services to compete with rivals for affluent clients. This move follows Bank of America's 7% revenue jump in its wealth and investment management group, and comes as the bank expands its offerings to wealthy individuals. The new group will deliver the best experience for Bank of America's Private Bank and Merrill clients.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Bank of America logo is seen in New York City, New York, U.S. January 10, 2017. REUTERS/Stephanie Keith/File Photo

site_title: Fewer condo deals in Aug as rising interest rates, Hungry Ghost bite: SRX, 99.co
summary: Singapore's resale condominium market saw a decline in sales for the fourth consecutive month, with 1,135 units resold in August, a 14.5% drop from July 2022. Despite this, resale prices continued to rise for the 25th straight month, advancing 1.2% month-over-month and 10.5% year-over-year. The slowdown in resale deals is attributed to rising interest rates and demand for new condo launches, with some buyers delaying purchases during the Hungry Ghost month.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
More than half of resale volumes were from the outside central region, followed by 24.6 per cent from the rest of central region and 16.3 per cent from the core central region.

site_title: Honda to ramp up sales of electric motorcycles to meet carbon target
summary: Honda plans to launch over 10 electric motorcycle models globally by 2025, aiming to achieve carbon neutrality for motorcycles by 2040. The company aims to sell 1 million electric motorcycles annually by 2025 and 3.5 million by 2030, with plans to equip them with all-solid-state batteries. Honda will also continue producing internal combustion engines, reducing emissions and introducing models compatible with carbon-neutral fuels. The move may pose challenges for developing economies where motorcycles are popular, with heavier vehicles and higher prices.

images.alt_text: BYD plans to invest about 30 billion baht (S$1.2 billion) in production of electric vehicles.
The meeting will discuss the roles of the auto industry in a decarbonised society.

site_title: Television’s A-listers ooze glamour on Emmys red carpet
summary: Television's A-listers shone on the 74th Primetime Emmy Awards red carpet in Los Angeles, marking the first full-fledged gala since the start of the coronavirus pandemic. Notable fashion moments included Elle Fanning's strapless black dress with a pink ruffled neckline, Hannah Waddingham's baby pink Dolce & Gabbana corset dress, and Quinta Brunson's strapless brown Dolce & Gabbana gown with a bronze skirt. Other notable attendees included Lizzo, who won for "Lizzo's Watch Out For The Big Grrrls," and Sandra Oh, who slayed in a sequined purple suit. The event celebrated the best of the small screen, with winners and nominees from popular shows like "Euphoria," "Ted Lasso," and "Killing Eve."

images.alt_text: Saturday Night Live veteran Kenan Thompson, himself a past Emmy winner, will make his debut as host.
Lee Yoo Mi, the winner of the Outstanding Guest Actress in a Drama Series award for Squid Game in Los Angeles, California, Sept 4, 2022.
Squid Game, the Netflix show – in which misfits and criminals compete for cash in barbaric and deadly versions of schoolyard games – is aiming to triumph at TV’s top prize gala.

site_title: Australia gauges suggest households, firms weathering rate rises
summary: Australia's consumer sentiment rose 3.9% to 84.4, while business confidence strengthened, suggesting the economy is weathering the sharpest policy tightening in a generation. The Reserve Bank of Australia's cash rate hike to 2.35% has been effective in cooling consumer prices, with inflation expected to peak at 8% before decelerating. Despite this, economists warn consumer spending will soften in the months ahead due to higher mortgage payments. The nation's economy is forecast to slow to less than 2% growth in 2023.

images.alt_text: Tuesday’s survey from National Australia Bank showed its index of business conditions rose 1 point to +20 in August, well above its long-run average.

site_title: China’s Premier Li pledges consumer support as holiday spending plunges
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang pledged to boost consumption and create demand to drive economic growth, following a 22.8% decline in tourism revenue over the Mid-Autumn Festival and a 16.7% drop in trips. The government aims to stabilize growth, employment, and prices, while the economy is expected to weaken to 3.5% this year, below the official target of 5.5%. Li emphasized the need for urgent action to address the "key problem of insufficient demand" in the economy.

images.alt_text: The central government rolled out a “three guarantees” policy in 2020, which requires local governments to guarantee people’s basic livelihood, the payment of wages, and the functioning of the local government.

site_title: Memories Group proposes to delist at S$0.047 per share
summary: Memories Group, a tourism spin-off of Yoma Strategic, proposes to take the Catalist-listed company private at S$0.047 per share. The offer includes the option to pay in cash or shares in Memories (2022) at the same price. New offer shares will not be listed on any securities exchange. The move is led by Memories Group and its associate, Memories (2022), an associate of Yoma Strategic's executive chairman Serge Pun.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Yoma Strategic returns to profitability to hit US$216,000 net profit for H2
Yoma Strategic, Memories Group issue business updates in wake of Myanmar coup

site_title: Australian business activity remains robust in August: survey
summary: Australian business activity remained robust in August, with the National Australia Bank's index of business conditions rising 1 point to +20, above its long-run average. This marks the second consecutive month of improvement, despite rising interest rates and high inflation. The index of confidence also firmed 2 points to +10, exceeding its long-run average. Strong sales persisted, indicating that cost pressures are showing signs of easing.

images.alt_text: China’s Covid Zero strategy, which effectively bars Chinese from travelling outside of the country, is also dragging on Australia’s tourism and education sectors.
The Australian dollar was off 0.2 per cent at US$0.6832 on Monday, after surging 1.4 per cent to as high as US$0.6877 in the previous session as speculators took profit on short positions.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise at the open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose slightly on Tuesday, September 13, 2022, tracking gains in worldwide markets and recovering from a public holiday. The Hang Seng Index increased 42.39 points to 19,404.64, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 9.06 points to 3,271.12. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a 0.4% gain in the STI. The slight gains are attributed to traders brushing off new Trump threats and focusing on US-EU trade talks and fresh records in the US stock market.

site_title: JPMorgan to boost payments business with Renovite purchase
summary: JPMorgan Chase has agreed to purchase US firm Renovite Technologies for an undisclosed amount, expanding its payments processing business and gaining a broader and more efficient platform to offer clients global payment methods. The acquisition, which includes 140 employees, will help JPMorgan compete with fintech disrupters such as Stripe and Adyen. The deal is part of JPMorgan's $12 billion technology investment in 2022, as the bank seeks to bolster its digital offerings and enhance its payments capabilities.

images.alt_text: JPMorgan entered the British market with a digital-only retail offering last year and executives have signalled their aim is to expand this to other countries.

site_title: Australia state regulator says Star unfit to hold casino licence
summary: Australia's New South Wales gambling regulator has found Star Entertainment Group unfit to hold a casino licence due to alleged breaches of anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism law. The regulator launched an inquiry after media reports accused the casino operator of compliance shortcomings. The Chief Commissioner described the report as "shocking" and stated that it reveals an extensive compliance breakdown in key areas of Star's business. The decision is a significant blow to Echo Entertainment Group, which operates the Star casino in Sydney.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians walk past The Star casino, operated by Echo Entertainment Group Ltd., in Sydney, Australia, on Friday, March 16, 2012. Crown Ltd. last month doubled its stake in rival Echo Entertainment, owner of the only casino in Sydney, and sought regulatory approval to buy more. Photographer: Ian Waldie/Bloomberg

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.14% at 28,582.71, following gains on Wall Street. Investors expect further interest rate hikes to tame inflation, driving the market upwards. The broader Topix index also rose 0.15%. The gains come as traders brush off new US threats, with stocks rallying ahead of US-EU trade talks and a potential boost from the eSIM platform Airalo's $220 million funding round.

images.alt_text: epa10017619 A woman walks past a stock market indicator board in Tokyo, Japan, 17 June 2022. Tokyo stocks ended the week sharply lower, crossing the 26,000 line for the first time in over a month. The Nikkei Stock Average ended down 468.20 points, or 1.77 percent, to close at 25,963.00.  EPA-EFE/Franck Robichon

site_title: Bank of America CEO says bank is satisfied with current headcount
summary: Bank of America CEO Brian Moynihan stated the bank is satisfied with its current staffing levels amid concerns about job cuts in the banking industry. Goldman Sachs, however, plans to cut jobs as early as this month. Moynihan expressed confidence that if needed, the bank won't fill all vacant positions, but is currently in good shape.

site_title: Nasa’s moon mission pushed back, again
summary: NASA has pushed back its Artemis 1 moon mission to September 27, as engineers struggle to fuel the Space Launch System rocket and secure a waiver to avoid retesting emergency batteries. The mission aims to test the SLS and Orion capsule, preparing for future human missions. A 70-minute launch window is available on September 27, with the Orion capsule set to splashdown in the ocean on November 5. The delay may push the timeline back several weeks if a waiver is not secured.

images.alt_text: The Artemis I unmanned lunar rocket sits on the launch pad at the Kennedy Space Center on September 2, 2022. - NASA will make a second attempt to launch its powerful new Moon rocket on September 3, after scrubbing a test flight earlier in the week. The highly anticipated uncrewed mission will bring the US a step closer to returning astronauts to the Moon five decades after humans last walked on the lunar surface. (Photo by CHANDAN KHANNA / AFP)
A major deity in ancient Greece, Artemis was a daughter of Zeus, the chief god of the Olympians, and the twin sister of Apollo, god of the sun and oracles.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on energy boost; US inflation data in focus
summary: Australian shares rose 0.7% on Monday, adding 4% in the past four sessions, driven by gains in energy and mining stocks on strong commodity prices. Energy stocks led the gains, with oil and gas majors Woodside Energy and Santos rising 1.4% and 2.2% respectively. US inflation data due later in the day will influence the Federal Reserve's next rate hike. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index inched 0.04% higher.

site_title: HSBC CFO says bank may ‘materially’ raise staff pay in 2023
summary: HSBC's CFO, Ewen Stevenson, stated that the bank may "materially" raise staff pay in 2023 due to rising inflation, which is expected to force significant cost increases. Stevenson noted that HSBC is about $500 million short of its cost target next year, with a 6-7% rise in underlying costs. The bank aims to limit cost growth to 2%, but Stevenson believes it will need to take a "brutal" approach to cost control internally to achieve this target.

site_title: Leaving out AMK Hub makes Mercatus’ retail portfolio a more digestible acquisition target
summary: Mercatus Co-operative, owned by NTUC Enterprise, has withdrawn AMK Hub from its potential sale package, making the remaining assets more digestible for buyers. The 4 retail assets, valued at S$4.13 billion, include Jurong Point, AMK Hub, and a half-stake in Nex in Serangoon Central. Overseas pension funds, private equity investors, and Reits have shown interest, but face challenges in acquiring the assets due to high capital costs and market volatility. Mercatus may retain AMK Hub to ensure the success of co-operatives and social enterprises catering to the community.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

krmercatus16 - AMK Hub



Source: Mercatus Co-operative Limited

krmercatus16 - Nex



Source: Mercatus Co-operative Limited
Mercatus owns about 720,000 sq ft of space at Jurong Point.
NEX shopping mall in Serangoon

Mercatus owns and runs the AMK Hub, Jurong Point and Swing By @ Thomson Plaza, and co-owns NEX. The company also has strata-titled assets within retail malls and at sites in various locations across Singapore, and One Marina Boulevard, a 31-storey office building.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Frasers Centrepoint Trust, Frasers Hospitality Trust, Memories Group
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust acquired a 10% interest in Waterway Point for S$132.3 million, raising its effective interest to 50%. Frasers Hospitality Trust's privatisation failed to garner mandatory approvals, scuttling the plan. Memories Group is seeking voluntary delisting for S$0.047 per share. The Singapore stock market rallied for a 5th consecutive day ahead of GDP data.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: Sales of royal memorabilia soar for quick-thinking online sellers
summary: Sales of royal memorabilia have surged following Queen Elizabeth II's death, with online sellers like Laura Sheldon on Etsy.com experiencing a significant increase in orders for handmade tokens, T-shirts, mugs, and other keepsakes. Other sellers on Amazon and eBay are also capitalizing on the trend, offering a range of royal-themed items. Experts attribute the demand to people seeking to commemorate the queen's legacy and pay their respects.

images.alt_text: A grab from a handout video made available by the UK Parliamentary Recording Unit shows Britain's King Charles III (at centre left) and Camilla the Queen Consort and speaker of the House of Commons Lindsay Hoyle (right) singing the national anthem following his address to the Houses of Parliament at Westminster Hall in London.

From left: Britain's Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex, his wife Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, Britain's Prince William, Prince of Wales and his wife Catherine, Princess of Wales, look at floral tributes laid by members of the public on the Long walk at Windsor Castle on Sep 10 (Saturday)  before meeting well-wishers.  Commentators said it was a show of unity that suggested that the death of the monarch could lead to a rapprochement.

The death of Queen Elizabeth has provoked tears, sadness and warm tributes, not just from the queen’s own close family and many in Britain, but also from around the globe – reflecting her presence on the world stage for the last 70 years.

site_title: Micron breaks ground on US$15b US chip plant, says more to come soon
summary: Micron Technology broke ground on a $15 billion US chip factory in Boise, Idaho, marking the first new memory chip factory built in the US in 20 years. The factory, expected to be operational in 2025, will create 2,000 Micron jobs by the end of the decade. The company's CEO announced plans for another high-volume manufacturing site, which will increase US production to 40% of Micron's global DRAM production. The move comes after the Chips and Science Act provided $52 billion in support for domestic semiconductor manufacturing.

images.alt_text: The fund was created to encourage US production of strategically important semiconductors and spur research and development into the next generation of chip technologies.

site_title: Federal Reserve set for another 75-basis-point rate hike; early pivot unlikely: poll
summary: The Federal Reserve is expected to hike its fed funds rate by 75 basis points at its upcoming meeting, according to a Reuters poll of economists. This would bring the policy rate to the 3.00 to 3.25 per cent target range, the highest since early 2008. The majority of economists (44 of 72) predicted the rate hike, while 20% predicted a 50-basis-point hike. The poll also found that the probability of a US recession over the coming year remains at 45%, and the chance of one occurring over the next two years has risen to 55%.

images.alt_text: Also troubling to Fed officials is that outside of petrol, price growth in the economy is rampant and widespread.
Goldman’s preference for US exposure comes during what is turning out to be a particularly tough year for business in Europe amid a gas crisis, soaring inflation and tightening central-bank policy.

site_title: Paddington tributes to queen prove too much to ‘bear’
summary: Thousands of tributes to Queen Elizabeth II outside Buckingham Palace include a large number of Paddington Bear tributes, following a viral video of the queen drinking tea with the character during her Platinum Jubilee. The Royal Parks have asked visitors not to bring more soft toys or marmalade sandwiches, citing the negative impact on wildlife. The tributes, which include drawings and messages from children, have become a poignant way for the public to pay their respects to the late monarch.

images.alt_text: From left: Britain's Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex, his wife Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, Britain's Prince William, Prince of Wales and his wife Catherine, Princess of Wales, look at floral tributes laid by members of the public on the Long walk at Windsor Castle on Sep 10 (Saturday)  before meeting well-wishers.  Commentators said it was a show of unity that suggested that the death of the monarch could lead to a rapprochement.

A grab from a handout video made available by the UK Parliamentary Recording Unit shows Britain's King Charles III (at centre left) and Camilla the Queen Consort and speaker of the House of Commons Lindsay Hoyle (right) singing the national anthem following his address to the Houses of Parliament at Westminster Hall in London.
LulaandGray's wooden Queen Elizabeth tokens being sold by Laura Sheldon on Etsy.com. These handmade tokens cost 3.90 pounds (S$6.35). Sheldon has had about 220 orders since last Friday (Sep 9).
The queen’s coffin was made at least 32 years ago of English oak, which is lined with lead, a royal tradition to help preserve the corpse for longer after its burial in a crypt.

site_title: Biden promotes US biotech, cancer fight in new ‘Moonshot’
summary: US President Joe Biden launched the Cancer Moonshot initiative, aiming to slash cancer death rates by half over the next 25 years. The program, inspired by JFK's 1962 "Moonshot" speech, seeks to coordinate and fund cancer treatment, search for cures, and prevent the disease through better public health. Biden emphasized the importance of unity and collaboration in the effort, drawing parallels with his father-in-law's vision for the US. The initiative includes a new agency and "cancer cabinet" to drive breakthroughs and partnerships with top researchers and industries.

images.alt_text: Reuters was first to report in July that the Biden administration was actively discussing banning exports of chipmaking tools to Chinese factories that make advanced semiconductors at the 14 nanometre node and smaller.

site_title: Indonesia’s large unbanked population offers opportunities for Singapore fintech players
summary: Indonesia's large unbanked population, estimated at 90 million people, presents a significant opportunity for Singapore's fintech players to serve the country's financial needs. The government and financial institutions are prioritizing digital solutions to address the gap, and the country's fintech sector has seen significant growth over the past two years. Singaporean fintech companies can capitalize on this growth, with Reuben Lim, chief operating officer of the Singapore Fintech Association, noting that Indonesia is a "top country for Singapore-based fintech players" due to its size and connectivity.

images.alt_text: Growth of the Islamic financing industry in South-east Asia is mainly led by Malaysia and Indonesia, amid supportive regulatory environment and strong government support.
Fintech is driving a convergence of public and private markets, altering the investment landscape.

site_title: Europe: Bank rally pushes shares to two-week high
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 index rose 1.8% on Monday, its first weekly gain in a month, as investors bet on easing energy prices and higher interest rate hikes for banks. The Stoxx 600 index reached a two-week high, driven by hopes that inflation may peak sooner than thought. Banks, which benefit from higher interest rates, rose 3.4%, while retail stocks gained 4.5%. The rally was also boosted by Ukrainian forces' advances against Russian troops and a potential easing of the energy crisis.

images.alt_text: The German share price index DAX graph is pictured at the stock exchange in Frankfurt, Germany, August 29, 2022.    REUTERS/Staff

site_title: SpaceX says likely won’t need 42,000 satellites for Starlink internet
summary: SpaceX's chief operations officer Gwynne Shotwell stated the company likely won't need to launch 40,000 satellites into orbit for its Starlink internet service, down from the initially requested 42,000. This reduction is attributed to newer satellites with larger antennae and better capacity. Shotwell emphasized that more satellites will be deployed as demand for the service increases, but a smaller number is sufficient for providing good service globally, addressing concerns about low earth orbit congestion and its impact on ground-based astronomy.

images.alt_text: Nasa initially awarded each company 6 crew missions but ordered 3 more from SpaceX in early 2022 amid Boeing’s technical woes.

site_title: Intel cuts expectations for Mobileye, aiming for US$30b IPO
summary: Intel has scaled back expectations for Mobileye's initial public offering (IPO), now valuing the self-driving technology business at up to $30 billion, down from an original target of over $50 billion. The IPO, which could delay until next year, aims to capitalize on Mobileye's growth, which has consistently outpaced Intel's parent company. A successful IPO could help Intel CEO Pat Gelsinger's turnaround plan, which includes rebuilding manufacturing prowess and restoring technological leadership.

images.alt_text: The investment is an expansion of an agreement signed by Intel and Brookfield in February to explore finance options to help fund new Intel manufacturing sites.
US chipmaker Intel Corp said on Monday (Jul 25) it will produce chips for Taiwan's MediaTek.

site_title: Oil prices settle higher amid supply concerns heading into winter
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday, with Brent crude futures settling up 1.3% at $94.00 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude up 1.1% at $87.78 a barrel. The increase comes amid supply concerns heading into winter, despite weaker demand expectations.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures dropped 78 cents, or 0.9 per cent, to US$86.01 a barrel by 0040 GMT, after settling 4.1 per cent higher on Friday.
The EU is seeking to curb power consumption and provide liquidity to energy markets as it seeks to prevent the crisis from engulfing the broader economy.

site_title: Google considers making some Pixel phones in India, says report
summary: Google is considering moving some production of Pixel phones to India due to disruptions in China caused by Covid-19 lockdowns and rising tensions between the US and China. Alphabet has solicited bids from manufacturers in India to make 500,000 to 1 million smartphones, equivalent to 10-20% of the estimated annual production. The company is also considering Vietnam as another manufacturing base, and would still require importing components from China. This move follows Apple's decision to make iPhone 14 in India, amid escalating global supply chain tensions.

images.alt_text: The launch event will take place at 10.00 am ET (2.00 pm GMT) in the Williamsburg neighbourhood of New York.
Google debuts new Pixel, latest try in smartphone fight

site_title: Jeff Bezos’ Blue Origin rocket suffers failure seconds into uncrewed launch
summary: Blue Origin's suborbital New Shepard rocket suffered a failure seconds into an uncrewed launch in West Texas, prompting an emergency abort. The rocket veered off course, and the capsule carrying payloads separated and landed safely under parachutes. No people were onboard, but a similar version of the vehicle is used for commercial flights. Details of the anomaly have not been disclosed, marking the first major failure for Jeff Bezos' company since transitioning to routine commercial flights.

site_title: Shipowners rush for tankers to move Russian oil this winter
summary: Russian oil owners are rapidly acquiring ice-class tankers to meet the EU's impending ban on seaborne imports of refined petroleum products. About $1 billion was spent on secondhand ice-class tankers in May-August, a 5-fold increase from the previous year. This move aims to overcome the threat of a shipping bottleneck this winter, as European ports, particularly those in the Baltic Sea, are a major hub for Russia's petroleum exports. The shortage of ice-class tankers could lead to increased rates for hauling refined fuels and potentially create a new trade involving ship-to-ship transfers.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled up US$1.16, or 1.3 per cent, at US$94.00 a barrel on Monday.

site_title: Crypto exchange Huobi to delist privacy tokens like Zcash, Monero
summary: HUOBI, a Chinese cryptocurrency exchange, will delist several privacy-focused tokens, including Zcash and Monero, due to rising regulatory concerns. The exchange cited compliance policies and user asset protection in its decision. The delisted tokens include Dash, Decred, Firo, and Verge, effective September 19. The move comes after the US Treasury Department's Office of Foreign Assets Control accused Tornado Cash of laundering over $7 billion in tokens since 2019. Huobi recently secured a license to operate a crypto exchange in the British Virgin Islands.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: SGX and the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) launched ESGenome, a sustainability reporting portal for corporates to report their ESG data. The portal aims to streamline disclosure and improve data quality. Meanwhile, Singapore-listed companies showed resilience in Q2 results, and the Straits Times Index rose 0.4% on Monday, driven by gains in the US and Europe. District 13's freehold condominium Euro-Asia Park will be put up for collective sale via public tender with a guide price of S$500 million.

images.alt_text: The President said "Her Majesty was a symbol of unity, greatly loved and trusted by people from across the Commonwealth. She pledged her life to service and will be remembered for her grace, warmth, and wit.”
Three-room and 5-room units saw month-on-month price increases of 0.5 per cent each, while 4-room and executive prices rose by a respective 0.8 per cent and 0.7 per cent.
Tan Ru-Ding, managing director of Flexmech Engineering, said the precision enginering industry has made significant strides in work conditions and offers lucrative career prospects now.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust to acquire additional 10% interest in Waterway Point
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) has entered into agreements to acquire an additional 10% interest in Waterway Point, a 4-storey suburban mall in Punggol, for S$132.3 million. The transaction will raise FCT's effective interest in Waterway Point from 40% to 50%. The mall has a 98.4% committed occupancy rate and offers diverse shopping, dining, and entertainment experiences. The acquisition is expected to enhance FCT's retail portfolio and provide investors with a higher stake in the mall.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Frasers Centrepoint Trust owns Central Plaza, a 20-storey office building that is directly connected to Tiong Bahru Plaza.

site_title: The edge in the global advanced manufacturing race
summary: Singapore aims to grow its manufacturing sector by 50% by 2030, driven by its innovative economy ranking as the world's second most innovative in the 2021 Bloomberg Innovation Index. Manufacturing accounts for over one-fifth of the country's GDP, and sustainable manufacturing is expected to unlock new growth opportunities. The government's plan is seen as a key strategy to future-proof local businesses and make Singapore more competitive in the global advanced manufacturing race.

images.alt_text: From left: PwC Singapore's Fang Eu-Lin, OCBC's Benjamin Henry Towell, Speco's Benjamin Chua, Green Collective's Mayur Singh, and Lenovo's Nigel Lee.

site_title: Apple rallies most since May on strong iPhone pre-order data
summary: Apple's stock surged 3.9% on its strongest one-day gain since May, driven by strong pre-order data for the iPhone 14 Pro Max, the best-selling model. The iPhone 14 series' pricing is seen as positive for future sales. Analysts from JPMorgan to Barclays attribute the demand to strong sales of the latest mobile phone series, which was unveiled last week. The stock closed above its 200-day moving average for the first time since August, marking a significant milestone.

site_title: Modern slavery on the rise as crises fuel poverty, says UN report
summary: The UN's International Labour Organization (ILO) reported that modern slavery has increased by 9.3 million to around 50 million people, with over half forced to work against their will or into marriage. The rise is attributed to crises such as COVID-19, armed conflicts, and climate change, which have led to extreme poverty and migration. The ILO calls for improved recruitment practices and labor inspections, as well as trade measures to prevent forced labor. China is singled out for concerns over human rights violations, including the detention of Uyghurs and other Muslims in Xinjiang.

images.alt_text: UN High Commissioner for Human Rights Michelle Bachelet met Chinese top diplomats on Monday as she began a six-day trip to the country that will include the remote Xinjiang region.

site_title: European gas slumps as bloc prepares details for intervention
summary: European natural gas prices fell 9.3% to their lowest in a month as the European Union outlined details of its intervention into the energy crisis, including targets to reduce electricity demand. The EU aims to curb power consumption and provide liquidity to energy markets to prevent the crisis from affecting the broader economy. Benchmark gas futures are expected to halve from current levels by the first quarter of 2023, according to Goldman Sachs. The EU's proposal includes caps on excessive revenues of companies producing power from non-gas sources, but Norway is skeptical about introducing a price cap on all gas imports.

images.alt_text: A street demonstration byGermany's metal workers union IG Metall in the city centre of Leipzig in eastern Germany, on Sep 10 (Saturday). They are demanding a wage increase of 8 per cent in the upcoming collective bargaining talks even as the country convulses under slashed energy supplies from Russia, which has driven up living costs.

site_title: Oracle reports sales that meet estimates, touts Cerner deal
summary: Oracle's fiscal first-quarter sales jumped 18% to $11.4 billion, meeting analysts' average estimate, driven by its transition to cloud computing and the acquisition of Cerner. Cloud revenue rose 45% to $3.6 billion, with growth of 19% in the previous quarter before the Cerner deal closed. Profit, excluding certain items, was $1.03 per share, slightly below analysts' projections of $1.06 per share due to currency fluctuations.

images.alt_text: The announcement came as the popular video snippet sharing service fended off concerns about the ability of engineers in China to access information about US users that isn’t public.

Oracle reported better-than-expected quarterly revenue and profit in a sign that demand for information technology hasn't been slowed by inflation and economic uncertainty. Shares jumped about 12 per cent in extended trading.

site_title: Twitter shares fall after it says Musk’s bid to end deal is invalid
summary: Elon Musk has made his third attempt to withdraw his $44 billion offer to buy Twitter, citing violations of the buyout agreement. Twitter's lawyers claim his move is "invalid and wrongful" and that the company has breached no representations or obligations. The company's shares fell 1% after Musk raised concerns about the number of "bot" accounts on the platform and a $7.75 million separation agreement with former security chief Peiter Zatko, who is set to testify about lax security and privacy issues.

images.alt_text: Twitter counters that Musk’s bot concerns are a pretext to get out of a deal in which the world’s richest person allegedly developed buyer’s remorse.
Musk’s legal team argued in court on Tuesday that justice demanded delaying the 5-day trial, so he could investigate allegations that Twitter had misrepresented its data security.

site_title: Goldman Sachs prepares for layoffs as deal-making slows
summary: Goldman Sachs is preparing for a round of layoffs, potentially as soon as next week, affecting employees across the company. The job cuts are expected to be at the lower end of the 1-5% range, according to a person familiar with the matter. The move comes as deal-making slows due to the Federal Reserve's efforts to tame inflation and the ongoing war in Ukraine. Goldman reported a 50% drop in second-quarter profit and a 41% decline in revenue from its investment banking division.

images.alt_text: As underwriters in New York look to offload debt tied to high-profile take privates including Citrix Systems and Nielsen Holdings, the European market remains all but shuttered.

site_title: Euro jumps on hawkish ECB signals, weakening dollar
summary: The euro surged 1.5% to a 3-week peak against the dollar, reaching US$1.0198, as European Central Bank officials signaled further aggressive monetary tightening to combat record inflation in the eurozone. This move weakened the dollar, which softened against most majors except the Japanese yen. The euro's strength also pushed sterling up 0.8% to a 37-year high, while the dollar index fell 0.67%.

images.alt_text: On Sep 9, the Japanese yen posted its best daily gain in a month, up 1 per cent at 142.675 yen per dollar, as it clawed away from recent 24-year lows.

site_title: US: Stocks close higher on Monday ahead of key inflation data
summary: US stocks rose on Monday, advancing 1.1% to 4,110.41 on the S&P 500 and 1.3% to 12,266.41 on the Nasdaq Composite Index. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.7% to finish at 32,381.34, its fourth straight gain. Investors await critical inflation data and retail sales reports before the Federal Reserve's interest rate move next week. Despite easing inflation, a third consecutive three-quarter point rate hike is expected, and Fed officials have ruled out rate cuts.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 7.78 points, or 0.02  per cent, at the open to 32,159.49.

site_title: Half of Singapore employers plan to hire in Q4: ManpowerGroup survey
summary: Half of Singapore employers, or 205 out of 510 companies surveyed, plan to increase headcount in Q4, despite economic and geopolitical headwinds. Hiring sentiments have dipped 4 percentage points from the last quarter, but improved 38 percentage points from last year. Strong demand for labor in the banking and financial services sector, particularly for IT, finance, and customer service roles, is expected to continue. However, sectors like education, health, and government face the weakest demand. Globally, 3 in 4 companies struggle to fill roles amidst a 16-year high labor shortage.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

“Help Wanted” signs are plastered in front of restaurants and other businesses in the United States, where there were more than 11 million job openings in late July, or two for every employment seeker.

For an employee, a company going from US$1 billion to US$10 billion then back to US$4 billion is not the same as a company growing from US$1 billion to US$4 billion organically. While the final valuation may be the same, the steps that follow a down round are far more brutal for employees, who may find themselves facing massive personal tax liabilities, debts or more.

“The conversation around women and leadership was really dominated by bias and discrimination,” gender researcher Leah Sheppard says. “We thought that there was a place to talk about women’s agency: Are women actually intending to pursue these positions as much as men?”

site_title: SGX RegCo to require remuneration disclosure for directors and CEOs, tenure limit for IDs
summary: SGX RegCo plans to require companies to disclose remuneration details for CEOs and directors, and limit the tenure of independent directors to prevent long-serving individuals from remaining on boards despite the 9-year rule. Currently, only 18% of companies disclose CEO remuneration, and 35% disclose director remuneration. The regulator will review market feedback before making a decision on the exact tenure limit. The move aims to improve corporate governance standards and follow jurisdictions like the UK, Australia, and Malaysia, which have similar requirements.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
office space, boardroom, conference

site_title: ‘Bulk purchases’ of private property uncommon, unlikely to impact market: MND
summary: Singapore's Minister for National Development Desmond Lee stated that instances of "bulk purchases" of private property are uncommon, accounting for about 1% of all private residential property units transacted this year. Units involved in multiple-unit purchases of more than 2 units are even lower, at about 0.2%. Lee noted that the Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) discourages the purchase of multiple units, with higher rates applying to buyers who already own at least one residential property.

images.alt_text: Private properties along Paterson Road
Price growth of private homes slows in Q1 after cooling measures, even as levels hit new high
Recovery may be in sight for Singapore retail property market

site_title: EU plans to make fossil fuel firms share excess profits, draft shows
summary: The European Commission is proposing a "solidarity contribution" for fossil fuel firms that have reported high profits from soaring energy prices, with the aim of helping citizens and industries affected by the energy crisis. The contribution would be based on "taxable surplus profits made in the fiscal year 2022" and would be used to support households and businesses with high bills, energy-intensive industries, and reduce EU energy consumption. Major European energy firms, such as TotalEnergies and Shell, have reported record-high profits this year.

images.alt_text: The surge in power prices, along with threats to supply, is affecting businesses from China to Germany to the US. It jacks up costs and threatens margins, while also sucking money out of their customers’ pockets, destroying demand.

site_title: 'Not something you can just make in a day': the queen's coffin
summary: Queen Elizabeth II's coffin, made of English oak and lined with lead, was crafted at least 32 years ago, according to the royal undertakers. The coffin, weighing significantly due to the lead, requires eight pallbearers to move it. It has been specifically designed to hold precious fitments securely on its lid, featuring unique brass handles. The coffin will lie in state in London for four days before the funeral, where it will rest closed on a raised platform in Westminster Hall.

images.alt_text: LulaandGray's wooden Queen Elizabeth tokens being sold by Laura Sheldon on Etsy.com. These handmade tokens cost 3.90 pounds (S$6.35). Sheldon has had about 220 orders since last Friday (Sep 9).

site_title: BNPL code of conduct may include credit assessment, data sharing: Tharman
summary: Singapore is developing a Buy Now Pay Later (BNPL) code of conduct, which will include measures to limit debt accumulation, such as credit assessments and suspending users from making further purchases when payments are overdue. The code may also require BNPL providers to share information on customers' outstanding amounts and delinquency status. The move aims to protect consumers from potential risks in the BNPL sector, with BNPL transactions amounting to S$440 million in Singapore last year. The code is expected to launch this year, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore monitoring developments in the sector.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Instalment payments are not new but as they become more common, budgeting techniques could keep us from eroding our savings.

Keeping credit data in the hands of individual BNPL players creates a “blind spot” for other lenders. It works against individuals hoping to build a good credit score, but whose timely payments are not captured by the system.

site_title: Better corporate governance disclosure scores, but room for quality to improve: study
summary: A review of Singapore Exchange-listed companies' Code of Corporate Governance (CG Code) disclosures found general improvement in scores, with companies scoring better for both presence and quality of CG Code disclosures in 2021 compared to a 2016 study. However, quality improvements were slower, with room for improvement in areas such as remuneration disclosures and board diversity. The review also identified areas for improvement in shareholders' rights and engagement, with only 27% of companies having a formal dividend policy. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) plans to address these issues through framework changes and thematic initiatives.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
SGX RegCo will review market feedback before making a decision, including whether the hard tenure limit will be set at 9 years or some other number.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.43 points to close at 1,497.96 on Monday, driven by gains. The market saw 2.628 billion lots traded worth RM1.546 billion, with 445 gainers out of 348 losers.

site_title: HSBC eyes resuming buybacks in second half of 2023
summary: HSBC is likely to resume share buybacks in the second half of 2023, according to its chief financial officer Ewen Stevenson. The bank had paused buybacks in 2022 due to regulatory pressures during the Covid-19 pandemic. Stevenson stated that the bank views dividends as the primary basis of returning capital to shareholders, with buybacks used to soak up surplus capital. HSBC aims to boost payouts to investors, but faces challenges due to high inflation levels and ongoing cost-cutting efforts. The bank's strategy is expected to address its underperformance starting from next year.

images.alt_text: Founded by Temasek and HSBC, Pentagreen aims to deploy “blended finance at scale over time” to accelerate the development of sustainable infrastructure in Asia.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher as focus shifts to inflation data
summary: US stock markets opened higher on Monday, driven by anticipation of crucial inflation data this week that could influence the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 7.78 points, or 0.02%, to 32,159.49, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained. Investors are positioning themselves for the inflation reading, which could determine the pace of interest rate hikes and impact the overall market trend.

site_title: GE Healthcare to be spun off in January, gets new board
summary: General Electric (GE) plans to spin off its healthcare unit, GE HealthCare, in January 2023, becoming a publicly traded company. The new board, consisting of GE CEO Larry Culp, Honeywell International, and Amazon Web Services executives, will oversee the unit. The spinoff aims to simplify GE's business and reduce debt.

images.alt_text: IHH Healthcare in January filed a motion to dismiss the suit for lack of personal jurisdiction and failure to state a claim under the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure.

site_title: Malaysia’s 2022 economic growth to surpass official projections: Finance Minister
summary: Malaysia's Finance Minister Zafrul Aziz expects the country to surpass its official GDP growth forecast of 5.3-6.3% for 2022, driven by strong private consumption. Despite a challenging year with the US dollar strengthening and a slowing global economy, Malaysia's fundamentals remain strong, with an unemployment rate of 3.7% and inflation at 2.8%. The government's accommodative monetary policy and subsidies have helped maintain inflation, while being a net exporter of commodities has benefited the economy.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan
SGX and MAS launched ESGenome, a disclosure portal for corporates to report their ESG data, on Monday (Sep 12).
Bursa Malaysia building in Kuala Lumpur . (Bloomberg)
A security stands guard  at the Bursa Malaysia Headquarters, in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.

site_title: Thailand sees 22% drop in investment pledges this year
summary: Thailand expects a 22% drop in overall investment applications to 500 billion baht (S$19.2 billion) for the year, down from a 42% slump in the first half. The government attributes the decline to a large power plant project and foreign investments, which more than halved year-on-year. Despite this, measures to promote investment, such as a long-term resident visa, aim to attract more foreign investors later in the year. Thailand has promoted high-tech sectors and electric vehicles to maintain its status as a regional auto production base.

site_title: Salaries of administrative service officers, judicial and statutory appointment holders to be adjusted
summary: Singapore's salaries for administrative service officers and judicial appointment holders will be adjusted by 5-12% starting October 1, according to the Public Service Division. The changes are necessary to close the gap with market benchmarks, which have increased significantly over the past 15 years. About 330 officers and 30 appointment holders will benefit from the revision, including key figures like the Chief Justice and Attorney-General. The adjustments aim to attract and retain talent for key leadership roles, with periodic reviews planned to keep pace with market trends.

images.alt_text: Revisions to the Civil Service generic schemes were last made in 2014, and since then, salary levels in the market have gone up, PSD said in a statement on Sunday (June 5).

site_title: India August inflation accelerates to 7% on high food prices
summary: India's retail inflation accelerated to 7% in August, exceeding expectations, driven by rising food prices (7.62%) and fuel and electricity prices (10.78%) from a year ago. This marks a fresh challenge to the Reserve Bank of India's efforts to cool prices, which are currently above the 2-6% target. The central bank has raised interest rates to combat inflation, and the latest data adds pressure on policymakers to address the issue.

site_title: India's top mortgage lender sees pickup in home loan demand despite rate hikes
summary: India's top mortgage lender, HDFC, sees a strong demand for home loans despite interest rate hikes, which have risen by 140 basis points this year. CEO Keki Mistry attributes the buoyant economy and "feel-good factor" as reasons for the robust demand. Collections on loan dues remain stable, and economists expect further rate hikes but expect home buyers to be prepared for fluctuating rates. Housing loans have grown 16% as of July, with demand expected to be particularly strong in larger Indian cities.

images.alt_text: The housing market outlook for a country of over 1.3 billion is an anomaly as home prices across most major economies polled by Reuters are expected to fall or grow at a much weaker pace next year.

site_title: King Charles III pledges to uphold UK’s parliamentary democracy
summary: King Charles III has pledged to uphold UK parliamentary democracy and follow the "selfless duty" of his mother, Queen Elizabeth II, in a key address at Westminster Hall. He emphasized the importance of Parliament's independence and praised the country's constitutional government. The new king vowed to faithfully follow the principles of constitutional government, setting an example for his own role as a constitutional monarch.

images.alt_text: epa10179557 A grab from a handout video made available by the UK Parliamentary Recording Unit shows in following Britain's King Charles III (C-L), Camilla the Queen Consort (C-L), Lord Speaker John McFall, Baron McFall of Alcluith (L) and speaker of the House of Commons lindsay Hoyle (R) singing the national anthem after the King addressed the Houses of Parliament at Westminster Hall in London, Britain, 12 September 2022. King Charles III addressed Parliament for the first time as monarch. Commentators said it was a show of unity that suggested that the death of the monarch could lead to a rapprochement.

site_title: South Korean drama Squid Game competes for Emmys history
summary: Squid Game, a South Korean Netflix series, is competing for Emmy Awards history by becoming the first foreign-language television show to win top honors for best drama. The show, which features misfits and criminals competing in deadly versions of schoolyard games, faces tough competition from previous winner Succession, which earned the most nominations overall. Experts predict Succession as the favorite, but some believe Squid Game will win best actor, making Lee Jung-jae the first winner for a non-English performance.

images.alt_text: Squid Game director predicts second season of megahit

site_title: Amazon shares recover their winning ways
summary: Amazon's shares have recovered from a slow start to the year, gaining 29% since June 16, outperforming the Nasdaq 100 Index and its peers. Despite earlier concerns over slowing revenue growth, soaring costs, and rising interest rates, Amazon has taken steps to curb expenses, contributing to its strong performance. The company's shares have seen a gain of over 16,000% in the past two decades, making it one of the best-performing stocks in the past two decades.

images.alt_text: Workers at at the Flipkart fulfilment centre in Bangalore.  Amazon and its Walmart Inc-backed local rival Flipkart Internet offer deep discounts on everything from clothes to smartphones and home appliances ahead of the Indian festive season that begins in October this year.
Chief executive officer Andy Jassy has pledged to unwind part of a pandemic-era expansion that saddled Amazon with a surfeit of warehouse space and too many employees.
“Amazon workers are rightly furious and they are ready to walk out,” GMB senior organiser Amanda Gearing said.

site_title: No need to stop decoupling and minors buying private homes
summary: Singapore is considering a policy change to discourage non-owner occupier private homes by increasing property taxes, potentially up to 36% from January 2024. The current system allows citizens and permanent residents to buy multiple homes without incurring Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD), but experts suggest levying higher property taxes on non-owner occupiers to favor owner-occupiers and reduce demand. This could help anchor locals to Singapore and prevent home prices from running ahead of economic fundamentals.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
Artist's impression of Sky Eden@Bedok. Close to 75 per cent of its residential units were sold on the first day of the project's launch.
