site_title: Sri Lankan 'white elephant' Chinese tower to open
summary: The Lotus Tower in Colombo, Sri Lanka, a $113 million Chinese-built communications tower, is set to open as a tourist attraction. Initially intended as a working communications tower, it failed to meet its purpose. The tower's operators plan to lease out space and open its observation deck to ticketed visitors to recoup the cost of upkeep, following allegations of corruption during its construction under former president Mahinda Rajapaksa.

images.alt_text: This picture taken on September 12, 2022 shows an exterior view of the Chinese-built Lotus Tower in Colombo. - A huge green and purple communications tower in Sri Lanka financed with Chinese debt that has become a symbol of the ousted Rajapaksa clan's closeness to Beijing will finally open this week, its operator said on September 12. (Photo by Ishara S. KODIKARA / AFP)

site_title: Indonesia’s rate hikes shouldn’t ‘kill’ recovery, Finance Minister Indrawati says
summary: Indonesia's Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati warned against excessive monetary policy tightening that could derail economic recovery. She cautioned that rate hikes "can kill the whole recovery of the economy" and urged the central bank to use its tools to stabilize prices without creating unintended consequences. The government is monitoring inflation, which is hovering near a 7-year high, and is coordinating with local leaders to identify the source of price pressures. A rate hike is expected at the next meeting on September 22, with analysts predicting a 25-basis point increase.

images.alt_text: The offering by Indonesia attracted investors from Europe and North America, part of deluge of bond deals around the world this week.
Funds are flocking to South-east Asia where less aggressive interest-rate hikes have helped burnish the appeal of local equity markets.

site_title: Euro jumps on hawkish ECB signals, weakening dollar
summary: The euro surged 1.5% to a three-week peak against the dollar, reaching $1.0198, amid hawkish comments from the European Central Bank and expectations of further monetary tightening to curb record inflation. The dollar weakened against most majors, with the pound gaining 0.8% to $1.1678, while the Japanese yen remained steady. Investors await the US CPI report, which may influence the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision.

images.alt_text: Goldman’s preference for US exposure comes during what is turning out to be a particularly tough year for business in Europe amid a gas crisis, soaring inflation and tightening central-bank policy.
By 1107 GMT, the euro was trading flat at US$1.0007, holding above its lowest level since late 2002 of US$0.9864 as Europe’s energy crisis keeps the single currency under pressure.

site_title: How Europe can manage without Russian gas
summary: European countries face a significant challenge in managing without Russian gas, following Russia's suspension of Nord Stream 1. The European Commission urged EU countries to reduce demand for natural gas by 15% to secure winter stocks and defeat Russian "blackmail." Gas prices surged by nearly 100% before falling by a third, only to soar again. Energy markets have become irrational, with natural gas becoming a scarce good, and prices responding accordingly. European countries have had to compensate for Russia's loss through energy savings and imports from alternative sources, with the scale of the problem being immense.

images.alt_text: Germany is at the centre of Europe’s energy crunch as Russian President Vladimir Putin slashes supplies in retaliation for sanctions related to the war in Ukraine.

site_title: Amazon India to waive half the fee new sellers pay in festival season
summary: Amazon India to waive half the fee for new sellers on its platform during the upcoming festive season, offering a 50% discount on selling fees for those registering between August 28 and October 26 and launching within 90 days. This move aims to encourage more small businesses to sell on the platform, as part of Amazon's efforts to bring India's small businesses online.

images.alt_text: Chief executive officer Andy Jassy has pledged to unwind part of a pandemic-era expansion that saddled Amazon with a surfeit of warehouse space and too many employees.
“Amazon workers are rightly furious and they are ready to walk out,” GMB senior organiser Amanda Gearing said.
The pay-as-you-go service will also help sellers significantly cut logistics costs, the e-commerce platform said, without disclosing specifics.

site_title: When the office is not always ideal for doing work
summary: Non-profit executive Marjorie Roberts finds her office time not ideal for work due to constant requests from clients and colleagues. Despite not being the IT person, she often finds herself dealing with technical issues, such as printer jams, and must seek help from others. The office environment, described as a "hoarder's paradise," can be distracting and hinder productivity. Roberts' experience highlights the challenges of balancing work and personal time in a traditional office setting.

images.alt_text: A small scale version of Potato Head Doors and 5000 Lost Soles installation will be put up at the National Design Centre.

site_title: Prince Harry pays tribute to ‘Granny’, Queen Elizabeth
summary: Prince Harry paid tribute to Queen Elizabeth II, calling her his "granny" and cherishing the time spent with her. He praised her service as head of state and monarch, and her role as a grandmother, saying she was globally admired and respected. Harry expressed his gratitude for the special moments they shared and acknowledged her reunion with his grandfather, Prince Philip. He also referenced his father, King Charles, saying they would honor him in his new role. The tribute comes after a rare public appearance with his brother, Prince William, which was seen as a show of unity.

images.alt_text: The queen's death has drawn tears, sadness and warm tributes, not just from her own close family and many in Britain, but also from around the globe – reflecting her presence on the world stage for 7 decades.

The death of Queen Elizabeth has provoked tears, sadness and warm tributes, not just from the queen’s own close family and many in Britain, but also from around the globe – reflecting her presence on the world stage for the last 70 years.
In London, the unveiling of a new sculpture for Trafalgar Square’s fourth plinth planned for Wednesday was also put on hold.

site_title: Singapore stocks close higher as Asia rallies on US, Europe momentum; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 11.77 points or 0.4% to close at 3,274.72 on Monday, driven by US and European market gains. The STI saw a gain of 214 to 146 gainers to losers ratio, with 966.9 million shares worth S$717 million changing hands. The biggest winner was Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, which climbed 3.7%, while Jardine Matheson Holdings was the biggest loser, falling 1.1%.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
In Tokyo, stocks opened higher on Monday, driven by positive market sentiment off the back of last week’s gains and a weaker yen.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality Trust privatisation bid falls shy of required 75% approval in scheme meeting
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust's (FHT) bid to go private fell short of the required 75% approval in a scheme meeting, with 70.91% of stapled securityholders voting in favor of the proposal. The trust's managers, a subsidiary of Frasers Property Limited, had offered a premium of 7% to the trust's net asset value, but minority shareholders opposed the move, citing it as an opportunistic buyout at a low point. The trust's managers will respect the decision and remain committed to creating long-term value for stapled securityholders.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
Capri by Fraser China Square SG Superior Bedroom.
Frasers Property regards hospitality as a core business and is facilitating the privatisation of Frasers Hospitality Trust
According to Frasers’ group chief corporate officer, Chia Khong Shoong, , Frasers Property Capital will continue to focus on core asset classes as well as its existing markets.
In Singapore, Frasers Property said the demand for quality residential developments remains resilient.

site_title: Epicentre gets green light to delist
summary: Epicentre Holdings, a former Apple products reseller, has received approval from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to delist from the Catalist board due to the company's liquidation and insufficient assets to meet liabilities. The company had previously announced plans to delist in January after being wound up by the High Court. Trading in its shares has been suspended since 2019. The decision follows an investigation into Epicentre's executive chairman, Kenneth Lim Tiong Hian, over rogue loans of S$27.6 million.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

site_title: Air India to expand fleet with 30 Boeing, Airbus jets
summary: Air India has leased 30 new Boeing and Airbus aircraft, expanding its fleet by over 25%. The deals include 21 Airbus A320neos, 4 Airbus A321neos, and 5 Boeing B777-200LRs. The Airbus jets will join the fleet in the first quarter of next year, primarily deployed on domestic and short-haul international routes. The B777-200LRs will be deployed between December and March, mainly on routes from Indian cities to the US. The move aims to address an immediate need for more capacity and connectivity, marking a significant step forward for the airline.

images.alt_text: Indian airlines reported 478 technical snags in the year to Jun 30, 2022, but dozens of mid-air safety incidents in recent weeks have prompted special spot checks and safety audits by the aviation regulator. On Thursday, a SpiceJet plane was forced to abort its take-off on a Mumbai runway due to a caution alert.

site_title: MOM to carefully vet, keep tabs on One Pass holders to prevent abuse: Tan See Leng
summary: Minister of Manpower Tan See Leng has announced safeguards for the Overseas Networks and Expertise Pass, a new pass for top talent, to prevent abuse. The pass does not require a specified employment period, but the government will monitor holders' professional activities. The Ministry of Manpower reserves the right to cancel the pass if there are extended periods of economic inactivity without good reasons.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh

Office workers at a crossing in the Central Business District. High-calibre talent would have been able to enter Singapore under other passes, but the One Pass enables them to contribute as fully as possible.
Singapore needs to make these foreign talent moves now to strengthen its position as a global hub for talent, said Manpower Minister Tan See Leng.

The Overseas Networks and Expertise (One) Pass will be open to top talent across all sectors, and allows them to start, operate and work for multiple companies at any one time. Pass holders will also be able to sponsor their dependants, and have their spouses work in Singapore on a Letter of Consent.

site_title: Jailed Malaysian ex-PM Najib needs ‘proper’ medical care, says daughter
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak's daughter Nooryana Najwa claims her father requires "proper" medical care after being discharged from a hospital for a second time. Najib was initially admitted for routine medical checks but was discharged back to prison after doctors prescribed a change in medication. He has been serving a 12-year sentence for corruption, and his daughter cited concerns over his high blood pressure and recurring stomach ulcers.

images.alt_text: Malaysia’s highest court Tuesday(Aug 23) upheld former prime minister Najib Razak’s 12-year jail sentence for corruption in the 1MDB financial scandal.

site_title: With Barbarian at the gate, North American moviegoers shiver
summary: The horror film "Barbarian" has taken the top spot at the North American box office, earning an estimated $10 million on a slow movie weekend. The film, starring Georgina Campbell and Bill Skarsgard, has received strong reviews, with Variety calling it a "new horror classic." In second place was Disney's fantasy adventure film "Brahmastra: Part One – Shiva," and in third was Sony's action thriller "Bullet Train" with Brad Pitt.

images.alt_text: The panel also shared trailers for Disenchanted, which will make its Disney+ debut on Nov 24 and Hocus Pocus 2, which premieres on Sep 30 on Disney+.

site_title: Vietnam sees Q3 GDP growth above 7%, but warns of external shocks
summary: Vietnam's GDP growth is expected to exceed 7% in the third quarter, according to the government, but warns of external shocks due to global inflationary pressure. The country's economy is considered small and open, making it vulnerable to external impacts. Despite maintaining macroeconomic stability, the government notes that the economy faces obstacles and remains vulnerable to changes in the global economic environment. Vietnam's consumer prices rose 3.6% in August, targeting inflation below 4% this year.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close higher ahead of US data
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index rose 1.16% to 28,542.11 ahead of US inflation data, with tech shares contributing to the gains. The broader Topix index also increased 0.75%. Investors await US data for direction, despite recent market rallies in Asia.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise further at open
summary: European stocks rose further at the open on Monday, with Frankfurt's DAX index advancing 0.7% to 13,177.16 points and the Paris CAC 40 rising 0.4% to 6,236.55. This follows strong gains ahead of the weekend, as Britain's economy rebounded slightly in July. London's FTSE 100 index also rose 0.4% to 7,377.67 points.

site_title: Do you need a financial adviser?
summary: A do-it-yourself approach to investing can work for most investors after creating a suitable plan, which may require a financial adviser. Exchange-traded funds (ETFs) have made creating and managing a liquid portfolio less complex. Key principles include investing in equity, diversifying with ETFs, and avoiding market timing. A good financial plan can be crafted within an hour, but sticking to it despite market fluctuations is crucial. Investors who struggle with emotions or have complex situations may still need a financial adviser.

images.alt_text: DBS NAV Planner harnesses fintech to get people started on their journey towards financial freedom.

site_title: Germany faces recession as energy crisis bites, says think-tank
summary: Germany is expected to enter a recession in 2023 due to a severe energy crisis caused by Russia's slashed gas supplies, according to the Ifo think-tank. The economy is forecast to shrink 0.3% in 2023, with inflation reaching 8.1% this year and 9.3% next year. Real household incomes and purchasing power are expected to drop sharply. However, the think-tank predicts a "return to normal" in 2024 with 1.8% growth and 2.5% inflation.

images.alt_text: Germany is at the centre of Europe’s energy crunch as Russian President Vladimir Putin slashes supplies in retaliation for sanctions related to the war in Ukraine.

“Help Wanted” signs are plastered in front of restaurants and other businesses in the United States, where there were more than 11 million job openings in late July, or two for every employment seeker.
With year-on-year inflation running at 7.9 per cent in August, Berlin has been under pressure to provide further aid for consumers and businesses hit by a surge in energy prices.

site_title: BOJ set to end Covid-relief scheme, but no change to loose policy
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is set to end its pandemic-relief funding scheme as scheduled this month, marking a shift away from crisis-mode policies. Despite Japan's fragile recovery, the BOJ will maintain its loose monetary policy, keeping interest rates at -0.1% and the 10-year government bond yield around 0%. The decision reflects easing funding strains among small firms and the lifting of Covid-related curbs, allowing for a broader focus on risks such as rising input costs and global growth slowdowns.

images.alt_text: BOJ governor Haruhiko Kuroda has emphasised his determination to stick with rock-bottom interest rates even as global peers hike to tackle sky-high inflation.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit over 1-week high on miners boost
summary: Australia's shares closed at a one-week high, rising 1% to 6,964.5 points, driven by gains in miners and banking stocks. The metals and mining index surged 2.2% and iron ore futures reached two-week highs. Heavyweights BHP Group, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue Metals also rose, while Westpac increased its variable home loan interest rates. Investors await the US inflation report and Australia's unemployment rate, scheduled to be released later this week.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index rose nearly 1 per cent by 0019 GMT on Monday.

site_title: SGX securities turnover slides 7% to S$24.3b in August
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) securities turnover dropped 7% to S$24.3 billion in August, with total market turnover volume rising 1%. The securities daily average value stood at S$1.1 billion, 12% lower year-on-year but 22.6% higher on the month. This was attributed to corporate earnings season and strong month-end rebalancing, with estimated S$750 million in net institutional inflows. The Straits Times Index rose 5% on the year, outperforming the FTSE All-World Index.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Comparing month on month, total market turnover value fell 30 per cent while total market turnover volume dipped 36.8 per cent, according to SGX data released on Thursday (Aug 11).

site_title: US economy is a safer bet than ‘dire’ Europe, Goldman strategists say
summary: Goldman Sachs strategists recommend US exposure over Europe due to the dire economic situation in Europe, marked by a gas crisis, soaring inflation, and tightening central-bank policy. US firms with 100% domestic sales have outperformed those with high sales to Europe. The team suggests investing in quality stocks with strong balance sheets, stable sales and earnings growth, and big dividend payers to minimize exposure to equity valuation risk. They expect the S&P 500 to end 2022 at 4,300 points, 5.7% higher than Friday's close, assuming Federal Reserve tightening leads to decelerated US economic growth.

images.alt_text: Janet Yellen, US Treasury secretary, speaks after touring the production line of the Ford Motor Co. Rouge Electric Vehicle Center (REVC) in Dearborn, Michigan, US, on Thursday, Sept 8, 2022.

site_title: Laguna’s trustee asked to give evidence in hearing on noteholder’s winding-up application
summary: The High Court of Singapore has asked the trustee of Laguna National Golf and Country Club to provide evidence on its fiduciary duty to debenture holders, who are owed tens of millions of dollars in unpaid debts. The trustee, British and Malayan Trustees, must address whether it was aware of the club's default before failing to redeem the notes and what steps it would take. The trustee had argued that a "non-action clause" in the trust deed prevents it from taking enforcement action, but debenture holders' lawyers claim the trustee failed to act in their interest, leaving the club insolvent.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng
Debenture holders serve statutory demand on Peter Kwee's Laguna
Debenture holders serve statutory demand on Peter Kwee's Laguna

site_title: UK economy weaker than expected with sluggish manufacturing gain
summary: The UK economy experienced slower-than-expected growth in July, with industrial production and construction shrinking for the second month. The 0.2% expansion was driven by information technology and consumer-facing services, but was largely offset by a decline in manufacturing. The economy is now on course for a quarter of anaemic growth, with a recession possible if the death of Queen Elizabeth II and funeral holiday tip the economy over the edge. A freeze on energy prices announced by Prime Minister Liz Truss may prevent a recession, but is likely to lead to higher interest rates and a contraction next year.

images.alt_text: Total like-for-like retail sales increased by 3.6 per cent in August compared with the same month last year and online sales fell by 0.6 per cent, their first decline since March.

site_title: China needs to tackle financial instability at local government level
summary: China's central government needs to address financial instability at the local government level, with public finance playing a crucial role in the country's modernization. The "three guarantees" policy, introduced in 2020, aims to ensure basic livelihoods and government functioning, but local governments face fiscal fragility due to declining revenue and asset sales. The reliance on land sales and state-owned asset sales is unsustainable, and tax revenue and payment transfers are insufficient to fund normal functions. To stabilize public finance, the government needs to ensure sufficient economic growth, adjust government spending, and formulate plans to deal with shocks to local government financing.

images.alt_text: Yuan-denominated bond issuance by non-financial firms exceeded that in the greenback in both July and August, a first for 2 consecutive months.

site_title: Downsizing in retirement: expenses they didn’t expect
summary: Retirees downsizing to smaller homes face unexpected expenses and challenges, including higher closing costs, monthly fees, and taxes. A study by the Center for Retirement Research found that retirees can improve their cash flow by renting rather than buying, and using the proceeds to invest in bonds or other assets. Downsizers should consider factors such as lifestyle, location, and health needs when choosing a new home. The article cites the experiences of two couples, Charles and Louise Angel and Dale and Marian Boyd, who faced unexpected costs and found that their new homes provided improved cash flow and a more desirable lifestyle.

images.alt_text: The basic supply-and-demand dynamic – with the former squeezed and the latter still strong – means that US consumers will need to pay up for a place to live.

site_title: Crypto market can learn lessons from traditional risk management
summary: Regulators are scrutinizing the crypto market due to recent market crashes, including the collapse of TerraUSD and Three Arrows Capital, and the insolvency of Celsius and Voyager. The market's high-risk, high-reward nature, with annual percentage yields over 20%, has raised concerns about the risk-return relationship. To mitigate this, experts recommend adopting traditional finance principles, such as risk management, liquidity analysis, and audited financials, as well as enhanced disclosure and clarity on collateral, custody, and segregation of assets. By learning from traditional finance, the crypto industry can protect customers, reduce risk, and grow more sustainably.

site_title: Surge in Singapore’s tax revenue in FY2021 driven by ‘sentiment-based revenue’: DPM Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong attributed Singapore's 22.4% surge in tax revenue in FY2021 to "sentiment-based revenue", including higher-than-expected stamp duty collection. This increase cannot be relied upon to meet the city-state's rising recurrent expenditure needs, prompting questions on deferring the planned Goods and Services Tax (GST) hike. Wong stated the government will proceed with the planned GST increase, but will ensure lower-income households do not feel the impact for at least 5 years and lower-income households for about 10 years. The government aims to run a balanced budget over the medium term.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
A man shopping for groceries at the Fairprice at City Square Mall on 15 February 2022.
Price increases are expected to continue in the coming months, with energy prices likely to remain "elevated" for the rest of the year, Deputy Prime M
Burden of GST hike falls on the better-off: Lawrence Wong

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's stock market opened higher on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 4.56 points or 0.30% to 1,501.09. The market saw 235 gainers for every 101 losers, with a total trading volume of 179.29 million lots worth RM91.15 million.

site_title: Opportunities in a fossil-fuel based sector indispensable to the energy transition in Indonesia
summary: Indonesia's state-owned Pertamina has launched a refinery development master plan to revitalize five major refineries, increasing capacities and product slate while improving emissions standards and reducing dependence on foreign imports. The plan aims to support the country's commitment to a 50% renewable energy target by 2032, despite petrochemicals being essential to the energy transition and manufacturing of renewable infrastructure. Demand for petrochemical products, driven by Indonesia's growing agricultural, automotive, and construction sectors, is expected to triple over the next 20 years, presenting opportunities for growth despite challenges such as limited feedstock and financing constraints.

images.alt_text: India Oil will target Scope 1 and 2 emissions under its net zero aim, chairman Shrikant Madhav Vaidya said on Thursday (Aug 25).
FILE PHOTO: PetroChina's logo is seen at a petrol station in Beijing, China, March 21, 2016.  REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon/File Photo  GLOBAL BUSINESS WEEK AHEAD
The firm posted a loss of US$63.55 million in the first half of 2022, with its refined oil products output plunging 13 per cent to 3.15 million tonnes.

site_title: Scientists discover how air pollution triggers lung cancer
summary: Scientists have identified the mechanism through which air pollution triggers lung cancer in non-smokers, revealing that exposure to tiny PM2.5 particles causes DNA mutations and triggers inflammation, which can lead to cancer. Research analyzed data from over 460,000 people and found that pollution particles increased the risk of mutations in genes linked to lung cancer. The discovery could pave the way for a new field of cancer prevention and potentially lead to the development of a daily pill to reduce cancer risk, with experts hailing it as a "revolutionary" step forward.

site_title: Euro-Asia Park up for en bloc sale at S$500m
summary: Euro-Asia Park, a 163-unit freehold condominium in Singapore's District 13, is up for collective sale via public tender with a guide price of S$500 million. The site has a land area of 129,793 sq ft and is zoned for residential use, allowing for up to 397 new units upon redevelopment. The sale is seen as an opportunity for developers to replenish their land stock, given the limited supply in central Singapore, with transport connectivity and access to amenities being major attractions.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

KSH Ultra Unity (KSHUU), KSH’s indirect 49 per cent-owned associated company, won the bid for the 84-unit development at 1037 Serangoon Road at the purchase price of S$222 million, slightly higher than the guide price of S$218 million.

site_title: ‘Don’t fight the Fed’ takes on new meaning
summary: The US and other advanced economies face a prolonged period of inflationary pressures due to underinvestment in infrastructure and weak recoveries from crises. This trend is expected to continue, with the Federal Reserve's tightening cycle likely to lead to higher interest rates. Investors must recalibrate their return expectations and consider alternative sources of income, such as private credit and floating rate debt. Traditional fixed income may be challenged by elevated inflation and rates, while real estate sectors with shorter average lease durations can respond to changing macro conditions more tactically.

images.alt_text:
AUSTIN, TEXAS - FEBRUARY 19: An aerial view from a drone shows electrical lines running through a neighborhood on February 19, 2021 in Austin, Texas. Amid days of nationwide frigid winter storms in which 58 people died, more than 4 million Texans were without power for much of the past week, with about 13 million Texans being forced to boil tap water in the aftermath of the strain on infrastructure.   Joe Raedle/Getty Images/AFP

site_title: Beyond hedging: Asean could help bridge differences between China and US
summary: The Association of South-east Asian Nations (Asean) can help bridge the differences between China and the US by adopting a "bridging" role, rather than simply hedging their bets. As the US and China engage in a Cold War II, Asean countries may be forced to take sides, but this could lead to costly trade wars and a military confrontation. Asean nations with cultural ties to both China and the US can help reduce tensions by correcting misperceptions and promoting understanding between the two powers, thereby averting a war and promoting regional stability.

images.alt_text: New investment by US companies in China is expected to slow in 2023 as a result of the virus controls and other Chinese policies.

site_title: Ardern expects New Zealand to eventually become a republic
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern stated that the country will eventually become a republic, dropping the British monarch as its head of state, but this is not expected to happen anytime soon. Ardern believes it will occur in her lifetime, but not as a short-term measure, citing numerous challenges the country faces. Her government is not planning to discuss the issue, with Ardern saying it's a "large, significant debate" that should not be rushed.

site_title: SGX, MAS launch ESG reporting portal for corporates
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) and Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) have launched ESGenome, a free online sustainability reporting portal for corporates to report their environmental, social, and governance (ESG) data. The platform aims to streamline disclosure, improve data quality, and provide investors with comparable ESG data. Initially, only listed companies will have access to the portal, with plans to expand to non-listed corporations and small- and medium-sized enterprises. The portal offers a standardized set of 27 core ESG metrics and allows companies to upload their disclosures in various formats.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
nature, earth, sustainability

Leading Singapore organisations have raised concerns about aspects of draft sustainability- and climate-related disclosure standards by the global accounting body International Sustainability Standards Board.
Getting the ISSB's expected global standards on sustainability and climate disclosures to reflect local realities will be a complex undertaking.

site_title: AirAsia parent to add 3 A321 freighters to fleet
summary: AirAsia parent company Capital A announced plans to add 3 Airbus A321 freighters to its fleet, Teleport cargo arm, starting in the first quarter of 2023. The freighters will be leased from BBAM Limited Partnership. This move aims to diversify revenue and capitalize on the e-commerce boom. Teleport, which began operating its first freighter in 2022, will expand its services with the new additions.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars struggle to extend rally ahead of US CPI data
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars struggled to extend their rally on Monday, with the Aussie down 0.2% at US$0.6832 and the kiwi dollar mostly unchanged at US$0.6108. Traders are cautious ahead of US inflation data, which is expected to show a peak for inflation at 8.1% in August, potentially weighing on the greenback and supporting risk-sensitive assets like the Australian dollar. A softer inflation reading could offer relief for risky assets.

images.alt_text: The currency has lost about 3 per cent since May as China’s slowing growth and a stronger greenback exert pressure.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally in early trading, building on US gains
summary: Asian markets rallied in early trading on Monday, driven by gains in the US and Europe, as investors anticipate further interest rate hikes to combat inflation. Stocks in Japan, Australia, and Singapore surged, while Hong Kong and South Korea were closed for a public holiday. The euro strengthened against the dollar, with the European Central Bank expected to raise interest rates, following the US Federal Reserve's lead. Investors will closely watch US inflation data on Tuesday and UK CPI on Wednesday for further market direction.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong added more than 2 per cent heading into a long weekend, while Tokyo, Sydney, Shanghai, Singapore, Wellington, Manila and Bangkok were all up.

site_title: Inventor behind Amazon’s Alexa raises funds for AI startup
summary: William Tunstall-Pedoe, inventor of Alexa technology, raised $20 million to fund UK-based startup Unlikely AI. The company aims to develop a new type of AI software, taking a contrarian approach to machine learning. Backed by investors including Amadeus Capital Partners and Patrick Pichette, Unlikely AI launched its first product during the Covid-19 pandemic, an app solving cryptic crossword clues. Tunstall-Pedoe left Amazon in 2016 after developing Alexa technology, which is now used in Echo devices.

images.alt_text: Verily, formerly Google Life Sciences, was a division of the semi-secret research and development group at the company called Google X, until it split off as an independent subsidiary of Alphabet in 2015.

site_title: Singapore wealthtech investments up 605% in 4 years amid Asian wealth boom
summary: Singapore's wealthtech investments surged 605% in 4 years, reaching US$161 million in 2021, driven by its financial hub status and growing high net worth population. The city-state's share of Asian wealthtech investments grew from 2% to 7% during this period. Global wealthtech investments doubled to US$8.8 billion in 2021, with opportunities increasing due to growing household and entrepreneurial wealth, intergenerational wealth transfer, and underfunded retirement savings. Asia is expected to replace Europe as the world's second-largest wealth hub by 2026.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Investment. Coins and plants.

A television station broadcasts Jerome Powell, Federal Reserve chairman's speech at the Jackson Hole Economic Policy Symposium on the floor of the NYSE on Aug. 26, 2022. Stocks sank as Powell said rates would stay high for some time.

site_title: Ethereum upgrade brings risks for ailing crypto lender Hodlnaut
summary: Hodlnaut, a struggling cryptocurrency lender, warned of risks to its assets if the Ethereum Merge upgrade, expected around September 15, leads to price volatility in virtual coins. The upgrade could trigger smart contract liquidations, potentially causing "material losses" if assets are unwound. Judicial managers have asked for estimated losses and precautionary steps to preserve asset value. The company's assets are under judicial management in Singapore after halting withdrawals earlier this year.

images.alt_text: Embattled crypto platform Hodlnaut has an outstanding liability of US$283 million.
Crypto platform Hodlnaut says that it is exploring options for users to make withdrawals.

site_title: UOBKH expects contraction in Malaysia telco sector, prefers Time Dotcom
summary: UOB Kay Hian (UOBKH) expects Malaysia's telco sector to contract 5% year-on-year due to higher depreciation and a one-off prosperity tax in 2022. The research team trimmed its earnings estimate for FY2022 and FY2023 and projects a "buy" on Time Dotcom, citing strong home fibre sales and data centres segment growth, with a 3-year earnings compound annual growth rate of 12%. UOBKH maintains its "market weight" call on the sector, preferring Time Dotcom as its top pick.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Telekom Malaysia (TM) remains UOBKH's top “add” pick due to its bigger upside potential.

Data centre companies in Asia have been attracting strong takeover interest, in part due to the perception they have stable returns and expectations of ongoing growth as people increasingly rely on technology.

site_title: SingPost hires UPS’ Li Yu as CEO of international business
summary: SingPost has appointed Li Yu, former vice-president of logistics and distribution for Asia-Pacific at UPS, as CEO of its international business. Yu brings over 17 years of experience in strategy, operations, and technology implementation. He will establish long-term business strategies, strengthen governance, and focus on operational excellence and sustainability. This appointment is seen as a positive move to expand SingPost's global footprint, with group CEO Vincent Phang stating that Yu's experience can bring positive changes to the company.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
SingPost Centre saw “relatively high” occupancy of 95.9 per cent as at end-June.
The potential impact of Tan’s claim “cannot not be quantified at this stage”, the postal service group added in a bourse filing on Monday (Aug 15).
CGS-CIMB sees SingPost’s recent guidance as an implication of weakness in the group’s domestic post and parcel (DPP) volumes, given the high fixed-cost nature of the business.
SingPost issues S$250m in perpetual securities at initial rate of 4.35% per annum

site_title: New Zealand scraps most Covid rules as virus battle winds down
summary: New Zealand has lifted most COVID-19 restrictions, effective from midnight on September 12, 2022. Travelers no longer need to be vaccinated or submit rapid antigen test results upon arrival. Face coverings are no longer required in most public spaces except for healthcare settings, and vaccination mandates for certain roles will end on September 26. The country will adopt a simpler two-requirements system, with mask mandates in healthcare settings and 7-day isolation for positive cases.

images.alt_text: A passenger arrives from New Zealand after the Trans-Tasman travel bubble opened overnight, following an extended border closure due to the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak, at Sydney Airport in Sydney, Australia, October 16, 2020. REUTERS/Loren Elliott/File Photo

site_title: Iraq ancient ruins open up to tourism after IS atrocities
summary: Iraq's ancient ruins, including the 2,000-year-old Hatra archaeological site, are slowly opening up to tourism after being closed due to IS atrocities. A tour of the site, organized by a private museum in Mosul, allowed 40 visitors, mostly Iraqis, to walk around the site, admiring its ancient history and architecture. The visit aims to boost tourism in the area and showcase the heritage and identity of Mosul and its surrounding Nineveh province. Despite challenges, including the risks of terrorism and kidnapping, the tourism sector is slowly recovering, with visitors from the West also exploring the country.

images.alt_text: A palm field near Iraq's central city of Karbala; Iraq’s prized trees are central to a push aimed to preserve a long-threatened ancestral culture, whose fruit historically presented prosperity across the Arab world.

site_title: Gold inches up on subdued dollar; US inflation data looms
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $1,717.17 per ounce as the dollar hovered near recent lows, influenced by US inflation data set to be released on Tuesday. A weaker dollar makes gold less expensive for buyers holding other currencies, while higher interest rates increase the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion. Physical gold demand in Asian hubs remained firm, despite restrained purchases in India due to domestic rate hikes.

images.alt_text: The hallmark details on a one kilogram gold bar are seen at London bullion dealers Gold Investments Ltd. in this arranged photograph in London, U.K., on Thursday, April 4, 2013. Gold traders are split on whether bullion will plunge into its first bear market since 2008 as economies improve or rally as central banks buy more debt. Photographer: Simon Dawson/Bloomberg
The value of its gold reserves fell to US$107.49 billion at the end of August from US$109.84 billion at the end-July.

site_title: Malaysia trade chief says economy needs to recover before polls
summary: Malaysia's Trade and Industry Minister Azmin Ali has recommended delaying the country's general election until after the economy recovers from the COVID-19 pandemic. The election is currently scheduled for September 2023, but factions within the ruling coalition are pushing for an early vote. Azmin stated that the economy needs more time to recover and provide better assistance to citizens, citing concerns about inflation and a delayed warship project. The government wants to ensure it can support the needs of the people before calling for a national vote.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's industrial production in July was expected to rise 15.2 per cent, according to 13 economists surveyed in a Reuters poll.

site_title: Biden to hit China with broader curbs on US chip and tool exports: sources
summary: The Biden administration plans to publish new regulations broadening curbs on US shipments to China of semiconductors used for artificial intelligence and chipmaking tools. The Commerce Department intends to codify restrictions on companies like KLA, Lam Research, and Applied Materials, which were previously communicated in letters. The rules would likely include additional actions against China and potentially apply to other US companies producing similar technology. The move aims to thwart China's advances in semiconductors and chipmaking, where the US still maintains dominance.

images.alt_text: File photo of Vladimir Putin and President Xi Jinping meeting at the Eastern Economic Forum in Vladivostok, Russia 2018; the 2 leaders are deepening ties  with trade soaring by nearly a third between Russia and China in the first 7 months of 2022.

site_title: Japan government to waive tourist visa requirements as part of border easing: FNN
summary: The Japanese government plans to waive tourist visa requirements for citizens of certain countries as part of a border easing measure. The move, which could be implemented as early as this week, would also allow individual travelers to visit Japan without travel agency bookings. The government aims to attract more foreign visitors, citing the weak yen as a factor, and may scrap a daily cap on arrivals by October. This easing follows recent changes, including lifting daily arrival caps and eliminating pre-departure COVID-19 tests.

site_title: EU at historic tipping point
summary: European Union President Ursula von der Leyen is set to outline her vision for the EU post-pandemic in a speech on Wednesday, including energy market reform post-Ukraine. The EU is at a historic "tipping point" between challenges such as the Ukraine conflict, growth of Euroskepticism, and the energy crisis. Von der Leyen's speech comes as the bloc faces a potential "window of opportunity" to build back better in the aftermath of the pandemic and the Ukraine crisis. The speech marks a crucial moment for the EU, which has faced significant challenges during von der Leyen's presidency.

images.alt_text: epa09936078 European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen speaks during a press conference after the closing event of the Conference on the Future of Europe at the European Parliament in Strasbourg, France, 09 May 2022.  EPA-EFE/RONALD WITTEK
Etno, Europe’s lobby for telecoms operators, said in a report in May that more than half of the global network traffic is attributable to 6 firms, including Google.

site_title: Yellen says no strong labour market in long run if inflation high
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen expressed concern that the US economy may not achieve a "soft landing" from inflation, stating that a strong labor market is unlikely without controlling inflation. Yellen emphasized that Americans understand the need for the Federal Reserve to tackle inflation, which she believes is essential for avoiding a recession.

images.alt_text: While the housing market – a key source of wealth for Americans – has rapidly deteriorated, home values continue to rise.

site_title: ECB governors see rising risk of rate hitting 2% to curb inflation: sources
summary: European Central Bank policymakers anticipate a higher risk of raising interest rates to 2% or more to combat record-high inflation in the euro zone, despite a possible recession. Inflation has reached 9.1% in August, exceeding the ECB's 2% target for two years. The bank has already increased interest rates to 0.75% and is considering further hikes, with some policymakers seeing a growing probability of taking rates into "restrictive territory." A recession is expected this winter, but the strong labor market may cushion the impact of higher rates.

images.alt_text: The euro, which had broken back above parity with the dollar, slid down as far as US$0.9934 before recovering some ground.

The ECB has lifted its deposit rate to 0.75 per cent from 0, and raised the main refinancing rate to 1.25 per cent – their highest level since 2011, as inflation is becoming increasingly broad and was at risk of getting entrenched.
Inflation hit 9.1 per cent in August, an all-time high for the eurozone and more than 4 times the 2 per cent rate targeted by the ECB.

site_title: Bear market leaves bond investors with few places to hide
summary: Global bond investors have faced a rare bear market in 2022, with double-digit losses across various debt classes. European bonds, particularly those denominated in euros, have underperformed due to the continent's energy crisis and recession odds. Central banks' efforts to combat high inflation have led to increased borrowing costs, causing volatility in debt markets. Fixed-income investors may face more pain ahead as inflation remains a priority for central banks.

images.alt_text: Soaring inflation and the steep interest-rate hikes deployed by policymakers in response have brought to an end a 4-decade bull market in bonds.

site_title: Japan PM’s support slides, hit by anger over church and funeral: poll
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's support has reached its lowest since taking office, with 41% of respondents in a poll by the Asahi Shimbun daily expressing support, down from 47% in August. The decline is attributed to anger over Kishida's ties to the Unification Church and a state funeral for former leader Shinzo Abe, which sparked controversy over its funding. 64% of respondents said they could not accept Kishida's reasoning for the funeral, and opposition to it rose to 56% from 50% in August.

images.alt_text: The removal of the 50,000 people-per-day cap alone will not return Japan’s border to its pre-Covid openness, as non-resident foreigners are also currently required to obtain visas for short-term stays, and may enter for tourism only as part of approved package tours.

site_title: AstraZeneca looks to more than double new cancer drugs by 2030
summary: AstraZeneca aims to more than double its portfolio of new cancer drugs by 2030, seeking to become the top maker of cancer treatments. The company has added 7 new cancer medicines since 2014 and plans to grow through cutting-edge technologies harnessing patients' immune systems and targeted treatments. AstraZeneca's oncology chief, Dave Fredrickson, says the company has the opportunity to be the No. 1 oncology player, surpassing leaders Bristol Myers Squibb, Roche Holding, and Merck & Co.

images.alt_text: Earlier this month, AstraZeneca and Daiichi secured US approval specifically targeting patients with so-called HER2-low breast cancer, paving the way for billions in sales.

site_title: Yen traders eye further official warnings, border opening moves
summary: Japan's yen has fallen 19% this year, and traders are watching for further official warnings and potential border opening moves. The currency dipped 0.3% on Monday after a modest rebound, amid dollar weakness and verbal intervention from the Bank of Japan. Officials, including Deputy Chief Cabinet Secretary Seiji Kihara, have warned of taking necessary steps to address the yen's slide. Analysts see the possibility of Japan easing border restrictions, which could help boost the currency, but bearish sentiment remains strong due to monetary policy and yield divergence with the US.

images.alt_text: The yen has been hammered against the US dollar as investors focus on the widening divergence between the US Federal Reserve’s aggressive interest rate hikes and the Bank of Japan’s pledge to maintain ultra-low rates.

site_title: Philippines BNPL startup BillEase raises US$20m debt facility from Helicap
summary: BillEase, a Philippines-based buy now, pay later (BNPL) startup, has secured a US$20 million debt facility from Helicap Securities, bringing its total raised debt and equity to US$55 million. The new facility will be used to grow and expand the company's loan portfolio. BillEase has been profitable since 2021 and has disbursed over 3 million loans, with a focus on underserved customers. The company's AI-driven credit engine is seen as a key factor in its growth, according to Helicap Securities.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Georg Steiger, BillEase’s chief executive and co-founder.

site_title: With republicans at the gates, Charles III meets realm envoys
summary: King Charles III hosted his first reception for representatives of the Commonwealth realms, a group of 14 former British colonies, on his third full day as monarch. The event comes as republican movements gain ground in countries such as Australia, Antigua, and Barbuda, which have declared themselves republics or plan to do so. Charles' ability to keep the Commonwealth together will be a significant challenge, as many nations are questioning his ability to inspire the same devotion as his late mother, Queen Elizabeth II.

images.alt_text: Britain's King Charles III and Britain's Camilla, Queen Consort wave as they greet the crowd upon their arrival at Buckingham Palace in London, on Sep 9, 2022, a day after Queen Elizabeth II died at the age of 96.

“As the queen herself did with such unswerving devotion, I too now solemnly pledge myself, throughout the remaining time God grants me, to uphold the constitutional principles at the heart of our nation," said Charles.

The queen's death has drawn tears, sadness and warm tributes, not just from her own close family and many in Britain, but also from around the globe – reflecting her presence on the world stage for 7 decades.

site_title: Singapore stocks upbeat on Monday’s open; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.3% to 3,274.03, driven by a rebound in US markets and a buying spree on Wall Street. Marine logistics group MarcoPolo Marine and e-commerce company Y Ventures were among top traded counters, gaining 5% and nearly 8% respectively. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also rose, with DBS increasing 1%, OCBC gaining 0.6%, and UOB rising 0.2%. The market's rally was attributed to previous overselling and uncertainty about inflation and interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
IHH Healthcare's Mount Elizabeth hospital. A US court has granted the mainboard-listed company’s motion to dismiss a suit brought against it by US fund Emqore Envesecure Private Capital.

site_title: Disney CEO says sports betting is a reason for keeping ESPN
summary: Disney CEO Bob Chapek stated that sports betting is a key reason for keeping ESPN, citing an interest from parties looking to acquire the business and emphasizing its value. He also expressed no interest in spinning off Hulu, a streaming TV service, and has been working on an ESPN sports-betting app. Chapek's vision for the company includes connecting with consumers through data and creating tailored opportunities for fans, including those from Marvel and Lucasfilm studios.

images.alt_text: The panel also shared trailers for Disenchanted, which will make its Disney+ debut on Nov 24 and Hocus Pocus 2, which premieres on Sep 30 on Disney+.
Disney said the expansion would include a “brand-new story that will bring guests into battle alongside their favourite Super Heroes”.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on resources boost; key economic data in focus
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rose nearly 1% on Monday, driven by gains in miners and energy stocks, particularly domestic miners and iron ore futures. The index has reached its highest level in over a week. Investors are awaiting key economic data, including the US consumer prices report and Australian employment data, which could influence rate hike paths by central banks. Financials and technology stocks also contributed to the gains, with some stocks, such as Block Inc, rising significantly.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index gained about 0.4 per cent to 6,876.5 points by 0100 GMT on Friday.

site_title: Stocks to watch: IHH Healthcare, Kimly, Aspen
summary: A US court has granted IHH Healthcare's motion to dismiss a US$6.5 billion lawsuit brought by US fund Emqore Envesecure Private Capital. IHH Healthcare shares closed down 1% at S$1.92. Kimly is selling its confectionery business Rive Gauche Patisserie for S$2.8 million. Aspen Holdings responded to queries from the Singapore Exchange about its fiscal year 2022 financial results. Trading was halted for Frasers Property and Memories Group pending announcements.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

site_title: Oil prices slide as China’s Covid-19 curbs, possible rate hikes weigh on demand outlook
summary: Oil prices declined as concerns over inflation and strict Covid-19 restrictions in China weighed on demand outlook. Brent crude futures dropped 78 cents, or 0.9%, to $86.01 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude fell 73 cents, or 0.8%, to $92.11 a barrel. The prospect of further interest rate hikes in the US and Europe also contributed to the price drop.

images.alt_text: Despite Friday’s bounce, both crude benchmarks were headed for a weekly drop, with Brent down about 0.2 per cent on the week after at one point hitting its lowest since January.

site_title: What tech employees need to know to survive the global slowdown
summary: The global tech sector is experiencing a slowdown due to inflation, rising interest rates, and a potential recession. As companies face reduced valuations, tech workers in Asia may face significant consequences, including reduced real compensation, tax implications, and preference stacks. Employees may see their expected total compensation drop, incur massive personal tax liabilities, or be left with a fraction of their estimated share value. To navigate this uncertain market, tech workers should seek clarity and prepare for resilience by understanding their options and seeking professional advice.

images.alt_text: Following the sale of Hmlet to co-living company Habyt, Hmlet’s employee share option programme will be terminated and any options granted will be cancelled.
(From left) Qapita co-founders Vamsee Mohan, Ravi Ravulaparthi and Lakshman Gupta.

site_title: Rising cost of living drives up minimum wages across Asean
summary: The cost of living in Southeast Asia is driving up minimum wages across the region, with countries such as Thailand, Laos, and the Philippines increasing wages to keep pace with inflation. Thailand's national daily minimum wage will rise by an average of 5% from October, while Laos and the Philippines have also made recent increases. However, some experts warn that these hikes may worsen inflation, and foreign investors may not be deterred, citing factors such as lower labor costs compared to China and ongoing efforts to attract foreign investment.

images.alt_text:
This photo taken on April 17, 2017 shows a woman working at a street noodle stall as a customer eats in the Phrakanong district of Bangkok.
Street food stalls will be banned from all of Bangkok's main roads under a clean-up crusade, a city hall official said Tuesday, prompting outcry and anguish in a food-obsessed capital famed for its spicey roadside cuisine.  / AFP PHOTO / LILLIAN SUWANRUMPHA

site_title: Aussie hurt by global slowdown gets no help from RBA rate hikes
summary: The Australian dollar has lost about 3% since May due to China's slowing growth and a stronger US dollar. Despite the Reserve Bank of Australia's interest-rate hikes, the currency remains under pressure. Analysts predict the Aussie may drop to 62 US cents by early next year, a level it last reached in April 2020. The decline is attributed to the resource-linked currency's sensitivity to global sentiment, with a potential further hit if Australian employment data shows a weaker contraction in July.

images.alt_text: The central bank is relying on the tightest labour market in half a century and still-strong household spending to keep the economy ticking over during the rapid tightening.

site_title: Australia’s trade chief says no immediate plans to meet with China’s minister
summary: Australia's trade chief, Don Farrell, says no immediate plans to meet with China's minister, citing Beijing's top negotiator's absence from an upcoming trade ministers' gathering. The wait for a meeting may extend beyond this month due to China's Covid Zero strategy, which affects Australia's tourism and education sectors, and ongoing tensions over human rights and Australian citizens' arrests in China. Farrell emphasizes the need for discussions to resolve disputes and stabilize Australia's relationship with the world's second-largest economy, while avoiding actions that weaken national security or abandon human rights concerns.

images.alt_text: Lingering effects spanning chronic fatigue and “brain fog” to hair loss and shortness of breath – are estimated to afflict some 10 to 20 per cent of Covid survivors.

site_title: Building bridges into the future of alternative investment
summary: Singapore aims to build on its success as a premier location for alternative investments, attracting fresh talent and capital. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has developed a new corporate entity structure, the Variable Capital Company (VCC), which has been hailed as a success in making the city more competitive as a fund domicile. The VCC was launched in 2020 and has garnered interest from fund managers, positioning Singapore for continued growth in the alternative investment sector.

images.alt_text: Choo Oi Yee, chief executive of ADDX, said blockchain allows assets to be liquid for both public and private markets.
Singapore is increasingly favoured as it is less connected to Beijing from a regulatory, political, and financial perspective.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.96% or 269.59 points to 28,484.34. The rally followed similar gains on Wall Street, as investors adjusted to the prospect of more central bank interest rate hikes. The broader Topix index also rose 0.75% or 14.83 points to 1,980.36.

site_title: US railroad unions warn of cargo delays as contract deadline looms
summary: US railroad unions have warned of potential cargo delays as contract deadlines looms. The unions, representing 60,000 workers, are negotiating with railroads until midnight on Friday, Sept 16, to reach tentative deals. If no agreements are reached, it may lead to union strikes, employer lockouts, and congressional intervention. Railroads have begun halting shipments of hazardous materials to ensure safety in the event of a strike, which could disrupt food and fuel supplies, cause transportation chaos, and lead to significant economic losses.

images.alt_text: The Communication Workers Union (CWU) had planned to continue a 48-hour stoppage on Friday (Sep 9) but it was called off “out of respect for” the queen.

site_title: Credit Suisse fraudster’s statements weren’t just ‘human errors’, adviser testifies
summary: A Credit Suisse adviser testified in a Singapore court that the bank's statements on a portfolio were not just "human errors" made by the convicted fraudster, Patrice Lescaudron. The adviser, George Bachiashvili, stated that some discrepancies, such as changes in value dates, were not due to human error. This testimony raises questions about Credit Suisse's responsibility for Lescaudron's behavior, as the bank has argued that he was a lone wolf. The court will evaluate whether Credit Suisse or its units bear responsibility for Lescaudron's near decade-long deception.

images.alt_text: Giving bankers a direct stake in their unit could help keep talent after Credit Suisse lost more than 60 senior dealmakers over the past 2 years.

site_title: Zelensky says key east Ukraine city of Izyum ‘liberated’
summary: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky confirmed the recapture of the strategic city of Izyum in eastern Ukraine from Russian forces as part of a counter-offensive. The city's liberation is seen as a significant blow to Moscow's military ambitions in the region. Ukrainian forces have also recently captured Balakliya and Kupiansk. The head of the Ukrainian military reported that 3,000 sq km had been retaken from Russia since the offensive began, with Zelensky thanking Ukrainian forces for "liberating hundreds of cities and villages."

site_title: More investors braving risk factor to make an impact in Asia
summary: Asia is emerging as a key destination for environmental, social, and governance (ESG) investments, with East and South-east Asia identified as among the fastest-growing regions for impact investments by the International Finance Corporation (IFC). Despite emerging markets being relatively less mature, countries such as India, Bangladesh, and Indonesia offer untapped opportunities for ESG investments. The UNDP's SDG Investor Maps, which provide country-specific investment guides, are expanding to cover regional markets in Asia, highlighting sectors such as renewable energy, green infrastructure, and agri-business as areas for growth.

images.alt_text: The United Nations' country-specific investment roadmaps highlight opportunities in line with its 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs); the latest map for Cambodia, for example, cites the development of logistics services, to promote agriculture exports, as an investment opportunity area that would support SDGs such as zero hunger and decent work.
Tesla electric vehicles are shown at a sales and service center in California. Tesla was removed from the S&P 500 ESG index this year.
Making money is OK, but what about your ESG?

site_title: Japan plans to scrap daily arrival cap by October: Nikkei
summary: Japan plans to scrap its daily arrival cap of 50,000 people by October, according to Nikkei. This move will not restore Japan's border to its pre-COVID openness, as non-resident foreigners still need visas for short-term stays and can only enter for tourism as part of approved package tours. Government officials are divided on when to remove other barriers, with some proposing to lift all restrictions simultaneously and others suggesting a gradual approach.

site_title: Slower inflation unlikely to sway Fed from another jumbo hike
summary: The US Federal Reserve is unlikely to reconsider its plans for a 75-basis-point interest rate hike despite slower-than-expected inflation in August. The consumer price index (CPI) is forecast to rise 8.1% from a year earlier, still above the Fed's target. Fed officials cite rampant and widespread price growth outside of gas prices and a need for a restrictive interest rate level to slow economic growth. A decline in CPI would be a step in the right direction, but still indicates inflation remains too high for comfort.

images.alt_text: Customers refuel at a gas station in Concord, California. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

site_title: New World Development Co sees gradual recovery ahead for HK property market
summary: Hong Kong's property market is expected to experience a gradual recovery over the next 12 to 18 months, according to New World Development Company CEO Adrian Cheng. The company plans to invest 10 billion yuan (S$2.02 billion) in land, assets, and infrastructure in China, with a focus on the Greater Bay Area. Despite the current headwinds in the property sector, Cheng remains optimistic due to Hong Kong's strong fundamentals, including salary growth and demand for apartments. New World will continue to divest non-core assets and focus on high internal rate of return projects in Hong Kong and mainland China.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani
Hong Kong developer to offer 300 homes at 50% discount to market price
HK tycoons spend billions on Chinese property bargains

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Panamax market experienced gains, particularly in the EC South America and NoPac grain markets, with impressive week-on-week gains. The Transatlantic route yielded over $5,000 in gains, while Asia saw remarkable gains, including Indonesia coal demand remaining strong. In contrast, the Capesize sector trundled along, with rates returning to $5-6k OPEX levels after a brief revival. The Ultramax/Supramax sector saw mixed activity, with limited support in the Asian arena. The Handysize market saw a rejuvenation in East Coast South America, with positive gains.

images.alt_text: The Capesize market continues to struggle as demand for iron ore remains weak.

site_title: Straits Trading shares reasonably priced, but management must continue delivering value
summary: Straits Trading, a Singaporean conglomerate, reported strong earnings for 2021 and H1 2022, driven by growth in its property investment business and surging profitability at its tin business. The company has a diversified portfolio of businesses and has paid a dividend of 8 cents per share for 2021. However, rising interest rates and dilutive placements pose risks to its future earnings. Despite being reasonably priced, shares are still trading at a 39% discount to net asset value. Straits Trading is entering a new phase of converting assets into investment products and platforms for new growth engines, but interest rate risks may impact its ability to raise funds and create value for investors.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul
Chew Gek Khim, executive chairman of Straits Trading, says that the dividend is in line with their track record of rewarding shareholders for their continued support

Despite global economic headwinds, the group remains focused on disciplined capital deployment and sustainable growth, as well as value creation for its shareholders, said executive chairman of Straits Trading, Chew Gek Khim.

site_title: Sweden’s big short signals trouble for European real estate
summary: Sweden's real estate market is experiencing significant pressure, with housing prices projected to fall as much as 20%. This has led to a sharp decline in SBB, a Swedish landlord, with its stock falling by three quarters this year. The company is considered a canary in the coal mine for Europe's real estate market, as investors have bet heavily against it, with 35% of its free float being shorted. This signals potential trouble for the European real estate market, highlighting concerns over debt levels and market bubbles.

images.alt_text: “The sentiment has started to change from the last 2 years, as home price growth is slowing down, and some areas are even experiencing price declines,” said Maheshwari.

site_title: ESG guides: New resources aim to draw would-be impact investors
summary: The United Nations is releasing country-specific investment roadmaps to guide investors towards opportunities aligned with the 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). These roadmaps highlight areas such as developing logistics services to promote agriculture exports, supporting SDGs like zero hunger and decent work. Educational resources on environmental, social, and governance (ESG) investing are also becoming more common, with institutions aiming to drum up interest and support for ESG investments.

images.alt_text: The International Finance Corporation (IFC) has identified East and South-east Asia as amongst the fastest-growing regions for impact investments. (Photo: REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha/File Photo)
Tesla electric vehicles are shown at a sales and service center in California. Tesla was removed from the S&P 500 ESG index this year.

site_title: Return of pricing power to keep India retail prices elevated
summary: India's retail prices may remain elevated due to a lack of correlation between wholesale and consumer price inflation, with the CPI hovering above the central bank's 2-6% target band. Wholesale inflation is expected to ease to less than 5% in the next year, but retail prices may not follow, potentially keeping inflation above 6% until February. This could prompt the Reserve Bank of India to tighten monetary policy further. Companies are reluctant to pass on reduced global commodity prices to consumers due to maintaining profit margins.

images.alt_text: A shopper browses clothes in a market in Lucknow, India. Photographer: Anindito Mukherjee/Bloomberg

site_title: Liquidations may pick up with tapering of Covid support moves
summary: Liquidation filings in Singapore have decreased over the past two years, with 497 business entities filing for liquidation as of June 2022, down from 950 in 2021 and 924 in 2020. However, corporate lawyers expect a potential increase in liquidations as government support for businesses dissipates and economic conditions remain gloomy. The number of compulsory winding up and creditors' voluntary winding up filings have shown a general upward trend this year, with 236 entities filing applications in the first half of 2022.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
The majority of the UK company insolvencies were creditors' voluntary liquidations, or CVLs, accounting for around 87 per cent of all cases.

The interconnected collapses of companies including hedge fund Three Arrows Capital (above) and platforms Zipmex, Hodlnaut and Vauld have highlighted the lack of extensive risk management rules for digital asset companies.

site_title: Japan must take steps against 'excessive' yen moves: govt spokesman
summary: Japan's government must take steps to counter the yen's decline, which has reached its weakest level against the US dollar in 24 years, amid the widening interest rate divergence between the US Federal Reserve and the Bank of Japan. Deputy Chief Cabinet Secretary Seiji Kihara said the government will consider relaxing border measures to attract more foreign tourists. The yen's decline is attributed to investors' focus on the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes and the Bank of Japan's ultra-low rates.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda warned on Friday rapid yen moves were undesirable.

site_title: S&P 500’s downtrend momentum set to continue
summary: The S&P 500 Index is expected to continue its downtrend momentum, down 16.5% year-to-date. A bearish outlook is maintained due to a weak momentum signal from the Relative Strength Index (RSI) and a bearish crossover on the Moving Average Convergence Divergence (MACD). The index may test key support levels of 3,900 and 3,740, with a possible break below 3,900 leading to a decline towards 3,740. The Fed's interest rate decision on September 21 is a key market driver, with inflation moderation seen as a bullish signal for markets.

site_title: Dollar slides as investors balance positions ahead of US inflation data
summary: The US dollar fell to a more than 1-week low, dropping to 108.96 as investors consolidated gains ahead of a US inflation report that could influence the Federal Reserve's rate hike. The dollar index surged to a 20-year high last week, but markets "decided not to push the dollar's strength" and lightened up positions. The euro rose to a 3-week high, while the Japanese yen and Australian dollar also gained against the US dollar. Capital Economics expects the CPI to continue to edge lower, favoring the dollar.

site_title: Asset tokenisation projected to grow to US$16.1t opportunity by 2030: report
summary: Asset tokenisation is projected to grow to a $16.1 trillion business opportunity by 2030, driven by the demand for greater access to private markets from investors. Blockchain technology enables assets to be liquid for both public and private markets, reducing barriers to investment in private markets. The report, by Boston Consulting Group and ADDX, notes that asset tokenisation could make up 10% of global GDP by the end of the decade, with significant growth expected in real estate, equities, bonds, and investment funds.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Seba Bank's headquarters in Zug, Switzerland
A consolidation among Bitcoin miners may have contributed to the rising computing power.
Despite the advantages of digitisation and decentralisation, the risks associated with cryptocurrency are increasingly obvious to even the most casual of observers.
Bitcoin traded last week within a range of about 5.4 per cent, the narrowest since October 2020.

site_title: Aspen responds to SGX queries on expenses, related party transactions in FY22 results
summary: Aspen Holdings (Group) Holdings has responded to queries from the Singapore Exchange Securities Trading (SGX) regarding its financial results for FY22. The queries included increased administrative and operating expenses, a decline in equity-accounted investee results, and a rise in trade receivables despite declining revenue. Aspen attributed the increases to the commencement of its healthcare segment, impairment losses, and capital expenditures. The company also disclosed provisions for legal actions and stated that the recoverability of receivables is probable. Aspen's shares fell 14.3% following the release of the responses.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Oxley currently holds 101.3 million Aspen shares, representing about 9.4 per cent of the total number of issued shares.
