site_title: ESR, GIC launch third core-plus logistics partnership with A$600m commitment
summary: ESR Group and Singapore's Government Investment Corporation (GIC) have launched the third core-plus logistics partnership, ESR Australia Logistics Partnership III, with an A$600 million commitment. This is the third iteration of the strategy, following successful investments in EALP I and II, which have a combined portfolio of 682,016 square meters across Australia. The partnership reflects ESR's long-term partnership with GIC and confidence in Australia's growing logistics market.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei ends week on a high in hawkish climate
summary: The Nikkei index in Japan closed 0.53% higher at 28,214.75 on Friday, building on a rally from the previous day despite hawkish remarks from policymakers on aggressive rate hikes to tame inflation. The index gained 2.04% for the week, mostly due to a 2.315% rally on Thursday, after being flat for the first two days of the week and losing 0.71% on Wednesday.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Nikkei 225 index was up 0.49 per cent, or 138.54 points, at 28,203.82 in early trade on Friday.

site_title: Japan unveils near-term steps to offset hit from rising prices
summary: Japan's government has unveiled near-term stimulus steps to offset the economic impact of rising prices on low-income households, businesses, and farmers. The measures include offering 50,000 yen in financial support to low-income households, extending subsidies for animal feed, and holding off on raising the price of imported wheat. The government also aims to restart nuclear power plants and extend subsidies for gasoline and other fuels. These steps are expected to have a limited economic impact, with estimates suggesting a 0.04% boost to Japan's annual nominal GDP.

images.alt_text: Japan's household spending rose 3.4 per cent in July from a year earlier, government data showed on Tuesday.

site_title: Porsche breaks off talks with Red Bull on possible Formula One entry
summary: Porsche has terminated talks with Red Bull on a possible Formula One entry, citing a gap in control between the two parties. The talks, which began after Volkswagen's former chief Herbert Diess suggested Porsche and Audi would join the racing series, have stalled due to disagreements on control. Porsche's statement confirmed the talks would no longer be continued, effectively ending the possibility of the German marque entering Formula One.

site_title: Can exercise strengthen your immunity?
summary: Research suggests that regular exercise can strengthen immunity against infectious diseases, including Covid-19. A meta-analysis of 16 studies found that people who worked out regularly had a 36% lower risk of hospitalization and a 43% lower risk of death from Covid-19 compared to those who were not active. Exercise may help fight off infections by increasing immune cell circulation and reducing chronic inflammation. However, experts caution that more research is needed to pinpoint a specific mechanism or causal link, and that individual results may vary.

images.alt_text: Experts generally agree that regular strength training can have important benefits for healthy aging, including maintaining a high quality of life

site_title: NTU, A*Star, National Healthcare Group launch biomedtech incubator
summary: NTU, A*Star, and National Healthcare Group have launched co11ab Novena, a new biomedical technology incubator in Singapore. The $15 million incubator aims to help biomedtech startups overcome challenges in turning research into commercial products. It will feature equipment and expertise from a partnership with the Singapore Medtech Consortium and provide access to research facilities, equipment, and potential clinical collaborations. The incubator has no fixed duration, and its first cohort of startups is currently being assembled, with a focus on helping biomedtech startups make the leap from research to commercialization.

EY startup incubator programme expands to more Asean countries

site_title: Ninja Van to invest US$50m in improving automation of parcel processing
summary: Ninja Van, a last-mile delivery company, plans to invest US$50 million in automating its parcel processing systems across 9 regional sorting hubs in South-east Asia. The investment is expected to improve operational productivity by 50% by mid-2024. This follows the deployment of automation technology in other hubs, including a 4 km-long semi-automated conveyor belt in Thailand. The move aims to enhance the delivery experience and strengthen Ninja Van's ability to serve customers across the region.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher

site_title: Singapore and UK share 200 years of history, Queen Elizabeth’s death a profound loss: President Halimah Yacob
summary: Singapore President Halimah Yacob and Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong expressed their condolences over Queen Elizabeth II's death, describing her as a symbol of unity and a great world leader. The Queen, who reigned for 70 years, shared a 200-year history with Singapore and left a significant mark on the country's history and ties with the UK. Flags will be flown at half-mast in Singapore, and Parliament will observe a minute of silence to mark her passing.

images.alt_text: Queen Elizabeth II has died, aged 96, according to a statement from Buckingham Palace.
US President Joe Biden with Queen Elizabeth II at Windsor Castle in Windsor, England, June 13, 2021. Biden issued a statement saying the Queen “defined an era.”

site_title: The Great Reversal into a higher inflation environment
summary: Countries worldwide face soaring inflation amid stagnant growth, with a toxic combination of high debt and shrinking central bank balance sheets increasing the risk of financial crises. The UK's strikes highlight stagflation, where national income is squeezed by price shocks, leading to a wage price spiral. The current inflationary environment is a reversal of the Great Moderation, with the debt trap and shrinking central bank balance sheets exacerbating the issue. The Fed's shift towards higher interest rates may be necessary to combat inflation, but it also poses a risk of a recession and threatens central banking independence.

images.alt_text: Powell says he and his colleagues are strongly committed to fighting inflation and will not flinch until the job is done.

site_title: Europe: FTSE 100 rises on commodity boost, set to end turbulent week higher
summary: The FTSE 100 index in Europe rose 0.6% at 07:05 GMT, set for its second straight weekly gain, driven by commodity stocks. Oil majors BP and Shell climbed 1.1% and 0.7%, respectively, while miners added 3.3% following firm commodity prices. The UK's new Prime Minister and the death of Queen Elizabeth, the longest-reigning monarch, have had minimal impact on the market. The domestically focused mid-cap index also gained 0.6%, set to end the week 0.7% higher.

site_title: Chinese equities poised to rebound after unsustainable low
summary: Chinese equities are poised to rebound as unsustainable lows in investor sentiment and valuation are expected to reverse, driven by easing zero-Covid restrictions, reduced geopolitical tensions, and policy tools to underpin the economy. Sectors with high exposure to green development, such as new energy vehicles and solar, have upside potential, while high-quality Internet companies with vast cash reserves and improving cost efficiencies are also opportunities. However, risks exist in industries with oversupply and excess leverage, and sectors with weak consumer demand. The author retains long-term optimism towards China's market.

images.alt_text: China-focused funds have traditionally kept a large portion of portfolios in American Depository Receipts (ADRs) of mainland firms.

site_title: Sea’s Shopee shuts operations in Argentina, Chile, Colombia, Mexico: sources
summary: Shopee, the e-commerce arm of Singapore-based Sea Inc., has shut down local operations in Chile, Colombia, and Mexico, and will leave Argentina entirely. The decision was made to focus on a cross-border model in the three countries and concentrate on core operations. This move affects dozens of employees and comes as the company seeks to achieve profitability in its key markets in South-east Asia by 2023. Shopee's shares have tumbled since reaching a market value of over $200 billion last October.

images.alt_text: Sea's e-commerce arm, Shopee was one of the bright spots in its results, reporting an improved adjusted Ebitda loss per order for Q2 2022.

site_title: SIA decisions on MCBs and dividends dependent on recovery and financial performance
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) says its decisions on mandatory convertible bonds (MCBs) and dividend payments are dependent on the recovery trajectory and financial performance. The airline group raised S$15 billion through a rights issue in 2020, including MCBs, to address the pandemic's liquidity crunch. While MCBs were initially structured to provide flexibility, they would be dilutive for shareholders if not redeemed before maturity in June 2030. SIA will balance considerations as it reviews options for the future, including dividend payments.

images.alt_text: The presence of independent directors alone does not address the sometimes divergent interests of controlling shareholders and minority investors
Singapore Airlines is expected by analysts to be profitable from FY2023.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally, dollar dips as traders price in policy tightening
summary: Asian markets rallied on Friday, with Hong Kong adding over 2% as investors priced in more interest rate hikes to combat inflation. The dollar dipped after Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell reaffirmed the bank's determination to hike rates, despite warnings of economic growth. Markets are on course for a weekly gain, easing pressure from August's hefty losses. Traders expect the Fed to hike rates by 75 basis points next week, and some see recognition that the sell-off in August was overdone.

images.alt_text: Tokyo led the gains, helped by data showing the Japanese economy performed better than initially thought in the second quarter, while there were also gains in Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Wellington, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit to divest 3 assets for 22m euros, above valuation
summary: Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust (Cromwell E-Reit) is selling three non-core assets valued at 22 million euros (S$30.6 million), representing a 28% premium to their combined valuations as of June 2022. The assets include two warehouses in Germany and one in France, which were acquired at the Reit's 2017 IPO for a combined price of 8.4 million euros. The divestment is expected to complete in Q4 2022, with proceeds used to repay the Reit's revolving credit facility and for working capital purposes.

As at end-2021, Cromwell E-Reit’s portfolio occupancy stood at 95.4 per cent versus 95 per cent the previous year – representing an all-time high, according to the Reit manager’s chief executive, Simon Garing.

The Europe-focused Reit also reported gains in gross revenue and net property income.

site_title: Elderly King Charles III faces 'testing times'
summary: King Charles III, the longest-awaited monarch in British history, faces "testing times" as he takes the throne. Critics argue he'll struggle to maintain neutrality, particularly on sensitive topics like Scottish independence. Public opinion is divided, with nearly half of respondents expressing doubts about his suitability as king, while over 80% praise Queen Elizabeth II's performance. With increasing scrutiny of royal finances and a changing public mood, Charles may face pressure to abdicate in favor of his son William or limit royal roles, potentially reducing the monarchy's influence.

site_title: Singapore overall unemployment rate remains low, flat at 2.1% in July: MOM
summary: Singapore's overall unemployment rate remains low at 2.1% in July, unchanged from the previous month. Resident unemployment increased slightly to 2.9% from 2.8% in June, while citizen unemployment remained unchanged at 3%. The Ministry of Manpower expects unemployment rates to remain low due to sectors such as aviation ramping up recruitment efforts with the easing of border restrictions and rebound in travel.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan

site_title: Local banks see more savings accounts opened a week after raising interest rates
summary: Local banks such as DBS, OCBC, and UOB have seen an increase in new customers opening savings accounts after raising interest rates, with OCBC and UOB reporting a 50% and 38% increase in new account sign-ups, respectively. To qualify for these rates, customers must meet certain conditions, including crediting a minimum amount of salary and spending a minimum amount on select credit and debit cards. The results suggest that consumers are sensitive to interest rate hikes, with a survey finding that 25.1% of respondents would switch banks to take advantage of higher rates.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Interest rates of savings accounts at the trio of local banks have risen in August.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on resources boost; New Zealand’s Fonterra jumps over 2%
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% to 6,876.5 points, boosted by higher commodity prices, particularly iron ore, which rebounded in China. The mining sub-index led gains, with sector majors like Rio Tinto and BHP Group adding 1-3.4%. Meanwhile, New Zealand's Fonterra jumped 2.3% after hiking its earnings guidance due to robust demand for milk products.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index closed 1.77 per cent higher at 6,848.7 after 2 straight sessions of losses.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks begin slightly higher on Friday
summary: Hong Kong stocks began trading slightly higher on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.21% to 18,893.65, following an advance on Wall Street. This comes as traders prepare for further central bank interest rate hikes. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains, with the Shanghai Composite Index rising 0.17% to 3,241.18 and the Shenzhen Composite Index adding 0.22% to 2,109.00.

site_title: I say: Yes to name-calling
summary: The writer Asad Latif expresses support for name-calling, drawing a parallel between old-style calling cards and the tactile experience they evoke. He shares a collection of his own cards, including one with a gold-embossed American ambassador's insignia, which symbolizes power and concrete realities. The writer reminisces about brief conversations with the ambassador, highlighting the significance of physical identity markers in a digital age.

images.alt_text: The sight of Chinese wine being sold in small clay bottles by a hawker moved this writer to compose a poem.
Christoph von Spesshardt was, until recently, executive director of the German-Australian Chamber of Industry and Commerce in Sydney.

site_title: Why the dollar is strong and why that is a problem
summary: The US dollar is at a 20-year high, driven by differences in monetary policy and a strong economy, particularly in contrast to Europe and Asia. The dollar's strength gives American exporters an edge, but it also makes it more expensive for countries and companies to borrow in dollars, squeezing global credit. To weaken the dollar, global growth gaps need to narrow, and price and wage pressures in the US must decrease, accompanied by good news on global energy. Until these conditions are met, the dollar is likely to remain strong.

images.alt_text: A gauge of the greenback climbed to a record, helped by what has become the steepest-ever surge in real yields.
Asian authorities have broadly escalated their responses as the dollar’s upswing becomes more extreme.

site_title: The great US Open ball debate of 2022
summary: Tennis players are divided over the Wilson 'regular-duty' balls used at the US Open, with some, like Iga Swiatek, calling them "horrible" due to their faster speed and less friction. In contrast, players like Jessica Pegula praise the balls for their aerodynamics and ability to create maximum spin. The US Open uses different balls for men and women, with the women's balls being more aerodynamic and the men's balls being more durable. The debate highlights the challenges of adapting to changing conditions during a match, and the need for players to find solutions to overcome these obstacles.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index increasing 0.41 points or 0.03% to 1,495.14. Trading volume reached 131.95 million lots worth RM71.41 million, with 171 gainers outnumbering 121 losers.

site_title: Potential rate hikes to benefit Thai banks, especially larger ones: CGS-CIMB
summary: Thai banks, especially larger ones, could benefit from potential rate hikes, according to a CGS-CIMB report. A 25 basis point rate hike could lead to a 3.5% net profit increase for Thai banks, primarily driven by larger banks. CGS-CIMB has reiterated its "overweight" call on the sector, recommending Bangkok Bank, SCB X, and Kiatnakin Phatra Bank. The sector is currently undervalued, trading at a 36% discount to its 1-year forward book value, with analysts expecting improved earnings growth and asset quality amid Thailand's recovering economy.

Thailand's economy is expected to grow 3.6 per cent this year and 4.0 per cent next year, a member of the central bank’s monetary policy committee said on Wednesday (Aug 17).

site_title: This is the kind of storytelling that economics needs
summary: Economists should read more science fiction to broaden their perspectives and challenge conventional thinking. Science fiction encourages imagination and consideration of alternative scenarios, such as a world without money or corporations becoming more powerful than governments. It also highlights the importance of storytelling in shaping economic outcomes. By engaging with science fiction, economists can develop a more nuanced understanding of the complex relationships between people, institutions, and the economy. This can lead to more innovative and effective solutions to economic problems.

site_title: Indonesia president says likely to lose WTO nickel dispute against EU
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo stated that the country is likely to lose a WTO dispute against the EU over its 2020 ban on nickel ore exports. Despite this, Indonesia plans to impose similar bans on exports of other raw commodities, including copper, bauxite, and tin, to attract foreign investment and boost its value chain in resource processing. This move aims to increase Indonesia's GDP to over $3 trillion by 2030, with the current GDP at $1.19 trillion in 2021.

site_title: Bank of Japan’s Kuroda warns rapid yen moves undesirable, after meeting with PM Kishida
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda warned that rapid yen moves are undesirable, following a meeting with Prime Minister Fumio Kishida. Kuroda stated that yen moves of 1 to 2 yen per day are considered rapid, and the Bank of Japan will closely monitor exchange rate movements. The meeting was a routine discussion of broad economic and financial matters, with no specific policy decisions announced.

site_title: Citigroup’s US$504m blunder ends in victory for the bank
summary: A US federal appeals court overturned a trial court's decision, ruling that Citigroup must return US$504 million mistakenly wired to lenders in 2020. The court found that promoting finality in transactions should not be elevated above returning mistaken payments. The decision is a victory for Citigroup, which had previously described the error as a "massive unforced error." The ruling clarifies the concept of cooperation needed for a well-functioning syndicated lending market and could impact other lenders who received similar payments before Revlon's bankruptcy filing.

site_title: Del Monte to raise product prices again from October as margin pressures rise
summary: Del Monte Foods Inc, the US subsidiary of Del Monte Pacific, plans to raise product prices in the US and Philippines in October due to higher margin pressure caused by inflationary pressures and increased costs. The price increase is expected to range from 2.5% to 3.5% in the Philippines and will be selectively implemented across various product categories. This is the company's third price increase since May 2021, amid a global food price surge due to the Russia-Ukraine conflict.

summary: Frasers Property priced up to S$420 million of its 5-year green notes at 4.49% under its S$5 billion multicurrency debt issuance programme, with an upsize option to increase the offer to S$650 million. site_title: China inflation slows, allowing more room for policy easing
summary: China's consumer price index rose 2.5% in August, down from 2.7% in July, and producer price index moderated to 2.3%, softer than expected. The slower-than-expected inflation rates give China's central bank more room to ease policy and boost its flagging economy. The country's economy, weakened by Covid-19 lockdowns, continues to rely on sudden lockdowns, resulting in subdued consumer inflation compared to other major economies. This allows the People's Bank of China to cut interest rates and increase the money supply, differing from the European Central Bank and Federal Reserve's response to high inflation.

site_title: Queen Elizabeth’s death marks end of an era
summary: Queen Elizabeth II, the longest-reigning British monarch, died at 96, marking the end of an era of significant continuity during a 7-decade period of global transformation. Her death will lead to a state funeral at Westminster Abbey, attended by senior officials and members of the Royal Family. The UK will be in mourning, and the funeral will be a reminder of the Queen's unifying role in the Commonwealth. Her passing also raises uncertainty over the future of the monarchy, with a new king, Charles III, taking the throne, who faces challenges in maintaining the monarchy's popularity and stability.

US President Joe Biden with Queen Elizabeth II at Windsor Castle in Windsor, England, June 13, 2021. Biden issued a statement saying the Queen “defined an era.”

site_title: Hot stock: Yangzijiang sees heavy trading following foray into large LNG vessels via GTT agreement

The company's shares reached an intraday high of S$0.945, with over 22.2 million shares trading. The licence move is expected to boost the company's technology value chain and contribute to the development of LNG vessel solutions. Analysts see this as a step forward for the company's environmental, social, and governance (ESG) pursuits and a potential catalyst for an upwards rerating.

site_title: North Korea passes law declaring itself a nuclear weapons state: KCNA
summary: North Korea has passed a law officially declaring itself a nuclear weapons state, according to state media. The law, passed by the Supreme People's Assembly, outlines the conditions under which nuclear weapons can be used and bans sharing nuclear arms or technology with other countries. The move is seen as a response to failed denuclearization negotiations with the US and other world leaders. Leader Kim Jong Un described the law as "irreversible" and stated there would be no negotiations on denuclearization.

US crude inventories surged 9 million barrels, contradicting analyst forecasts, and concerns about the global economy and falling fuel demand led to price falls in the previous session. The European Union proposed capping Russian gas prices, raising the risk of rationing this winter if Moscow carries out its threat.

However, the non-hybrid RX 350 model will not be available in Singapore, with the company aiming for a fully electrified line-up by 2025. Lexus is transitioning away from combustion power, with plans to be an electric-only carmaker by 2035.

site_title: How should a board respond when its members are under a criminal investigation?
summary: A board's response to a director under investigation depends on the investigation's scope, with internal matters requiring full cooperation and external activities prompting caution. Companies should immediately seek legal counsel and disclose material information to the public. A special committee may be appointed to assess the director's suitability, and the board must consider reasons for any actions taken. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) may intervene in the appointment and reappointment of directors under investigation, and unaffected board members should prioritize the company's interests over personal feelings or friendships.

US President Joe Biden described her as "a steadying presence and a source of comfort and pride for generations of Britons," noting her 70-year reign as a witness to unprecedented human advancement. The Queen's passing marked the end of an era, with her legacy expected to be remembered for generations to come.

site_title: Is nuclear war inevitable?
summary: A nuclear war remains a possibility, despite efforts to reduce the role of nuclear weapons. The likelihood of nuclear war is influenced by both independent and interdependent probabilities, making it difficult to predict. Historical examples, such as the Cuban Missile Crisis, suggest that deterrence can be effective in preventing nuclear war, but the usability paradox and interdependent probabilities make it challenging to achieve absolute deterrence. Reducing the risks of nuclear war in the near term and minimizing harm to innocent people are key considerations. The author argues that nuclear deterrence is not inherently right or wrong, but rather conditional, and that a nuanced approach is needed to balance security concerns with the need to reduce the risk of nuclear war.

site_title: Europe: Banks lead stocks higher after record ECB rate hike

The Stoxx 600 index ended 0.5% higher, with banks rising 2.3% after the ECB abandoned the two-tier system for the remuneration of excess reserves.

site_title: Denmark hikes rate to end world’s first subzero experiment
summary: Denmark's central bank, Nationalbanken, ended the world's first experiment with subzero interest rates by raising its benchmark rate to 0.65% from minus 0.1%. This move follows the European Central Bank's 75 basis point hike to combat soaring inflation. The decision reduces the number of central banks using negative monetary policy to just two, including the Bank of Japan. The rate increase aims to curb the Danish economy's tight labor market and prevent a wage-price spiral, which could exacerbate inflation.

site_title: Federal Reserve chief steals ECB’s rate hike thunder
summary: The euro slid against the dollar after the European Central Bank's record interest rate hike, despite Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell's tough stance on inflation. The euro fell to US$0.9934 before recovering. Meanwhile, the pound remained near a 37-year low against the dollar as new British Prime Minister Liz Truss announced a two-year fuel bill freeze. The British currency did not react to Queen Elizabeth II's death.

site_title: More setting up regional treasury centres in Singapore
summary: Singapore is emerging as a hub for regional treasury centers (RTCs), driven by the post-Covid pandemic shift towards a "just-in-case" approach and supply chain rebalancing. The country's digital infrastructure and innovative solutions, such as blockchain and artificial intelligence, are attracting businesses to set up RTCs. Regional treasury centers play a crucial role in enabling business sustainability by ensuring liquidity and supporting ethical funding decisions aligned with sustainability agendas. Singapore's Smart Nation agenda and willingness to adopt smart technologies are key factors in its appeal as a hub for RTCs, with partnerships with industry partners and the government facilitating digitalization and innovation.

site_title: Google pays ‘enormous’ sums to maintain search-engine dominance: DOJ
summary: The US Justice Department alleges that Google pays "enormous" sums to maintain its search-engine dominance, with contracts with Apple, Samsung, and other telecom giants ensuring its spot as the No. 1 search engine. Google invests billions in defaults, making it difficult for rivals like Bing and DuckDuckGo to compete. The company's contracts also make it the default search engine on most browsers and all US mobile phones, allowing it to prevent rivals from gaining scale. site_title: Not enough to just hit net zero, Singapore’s transition must be just enough

The government has already begun to address some costs with vouchers, but more substantial support may be needed to mitigate the impact of decarbonization on households and businesses.

summary: Toyota has reached a potential US$150 million settlement to resolve US class-action litigation over fuel pump recalls affecting 3.36 million Toyota and Lexus vehicles from 2013 to 2020. The settlement covers owners and lessees of affected models equipped with defective Denso low-pressure fuel pumps, which could cause engine stalls. A judge's approval is required for the settlement, which was filed in federal court in Brooklyn on Wednesday night.

images.alt_text: “This investment is aimed at enabling Toyota to flexibly meet the needs of its various customers in all countries and regions by offering multiple powertrains and providing as many options as possible,” Toyota said in a statement.

site_title: Mortgage rates in US jump to 5.89%, highest level since 2008
summary: US mortgage rates jumped to 5.89%, the highest level since 2008, according to Freddie Mac. This marks the third consecutive week of rate increases, squeezing affordability in the US housing market as it slows down. The average 30-year loan rate increased from 5.66% last week, affecting potential buyers and causing home prices to drop below asking prices for the first time in nearly 18 months.

site_title: EY partners to vote on business split
summary: EY, the global accounting firm, plans to let its 13,000 partners vote on a split of its audit and consulting businesses, with voting expected to begin in late 2022 and conclude in early 2023. The proposed split could result in a partnership focused on assurance and a corporate focused on consulting, potentially increasing profitability and opening up opportunities with clients. The move comes amid pressure from regulators to address potential conflicts of interest between the two business lines, and could lead to a shake-up in the accounting world, with other Big Four firms also being watched for similar plans.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: Hong Kong’s new Reits association to lure foreign investment, attract new listings
summary: Hong Kong is launching a new REIT association to attract foreign investment and listings, aiming to enhance its global role in the sector. The association, comprising top executives from three industry leaders, vows to work closely with regulators and industry participants to increase cross-border capital flows and listings from the mainland. With 11 listed REITs managing assets in commercial, industrial, and retail properties, Hong Kong seeks to grow its REIT market, which has delivered yields of 5% or more in the past, despite a recent blip. The association aims to lure international investors and expand the investors' pool.

site_title: Marilyn's ghost got physical in filming of 'Blonde', star says
summary: Ana de Armas, the actress who portrayed Marilyn Monroe in the Netflix biopic "Blonde," says that Monroe's ghost made its presence felt during filming, throwing things around when angry. De Armas, who needed voice coaching to disguise her accent, said she felt a connection to Monroe and immersed herself in the character before filming started. Director Andrew Dominik also reported that filming took on elements of a seance, with the initial scenes shot in the same apartment where Monroe lived. The film, which premiered at the Venice Film Festival, explores key moments of Monroe's troubled life.

images.alt_text: Veteran film maker Walter Hill's latest movie, "Dead for a Dollar", follows a traditional tale of a bounty hunter who tracks his targets deep into Mexico, climaxing in a body-strewn, final shootout.

site_title: Crypto scammers use fake websites in latest bid to dupe customers
summary: Crypto scammers are using fake websites to dupe customers, with researchers from Netskope finding that fake pages masquerading as Coinbase, Gemini, Kraken, and MetaMask aim to steal users' cryptocurrency wallet information. The scammers use search engine optimization tactics to promote the websites, which appear on the first page of Google's search results. The fake websites direct users to participate in a live Q&A with a scammer, who pretends to be a customer service representative. Google has since removed the malicious sites from search results after being flagged by Bloomberg.

images.alt_text: Regulatory probes in the wake of this year’s crypto rout have dented a previously enthusiastic embrace of digital tokens in South Korea.

site_title: EY plans to spin off audit, consulting businesses: WSJ
summary: Professional services firm EY plans to spin off its consulting and auditing businesses, marking the biggest shake-up in the sector since the 2002 collapse of Arthur Andersen. The move is expected to be announced by CEO Carmine Di Sibio to the firm's 13,000 partners, with approval from top leaders still pending. EY had previously evaluated strategic alternatives to improve audit quality and address regulatory concerns over potential conflicts of interest.

site_title: Queen Elizabeth II, UK’s longest serving monarch, dies aged 96
summary: Queen Elizabeth II, the UK's longest-serving monarch, has died at 96, according to Buckingham Palace. She led the UK through significant political and social changes, including the decline of the British Empire and the Brexit debate. Elizabeth's popularity was rehabilitated after a period of criticism in the 1990s, particularly following the death of Princess Diana. Her eldest son, Prince Charles, will succeed her to the throne. The queen's reign, spanning over 70 years, was marked by numerous challenges, including the media's scrutiny of her family's private lives and the country's transition from an empire to a modern nation.

images.alt_text: Britain's Queen Elizabeth II waits to meet with new Conservative Party leader and Britain's Prime Minister-elect Liz Truss at Balmoral Castle in Ballater, Scotland, Sept 6, 2022.
Queen Elizabeth celebrated her Platinum Jubilee earlier this year, marking 70 years of service.

site_title: Applications for US jobless benefits fall to lowest since May
summary: US jobless benefits applications fell to 222,000, the lowest since May, with a 4-week moving average of 233,000. Initial claims decreased by 6,000, lower than estimates. Continuing claims rose 36,000 to 1.47 million. A tight labor market, with over 300,000 jobs added in August and record openings, suggests a strong hiring appetite. However, interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve may slow job growth, with some companies already scaling back hiring efforts.

images.alt_text: The level of first-time claims, in addition to a still-low number of Americans already on unemployment benefit rolls, underscores tightness in the broader labour market.

site_title: Powell says Fed will act ‘forthrightly’ until inflation job is done
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell stated that the central bank will continue to act "forthrightly" to combat inflation until the goal is achieved. Powell emphasized the need for strong action to curb demand and contain price pressures, warning that premature loosening of policy could lead to more damaging consequences. The Fed is expected to meet on September 20-21, with Powell keeping the option open for another 75 basis-point interest rate hike, and investors are anticipating a significant rate increase.

images.alt_text: Markets reacted to Jerome Powell's speech on August 26 : US stocks saw sharp falls and analysts reckon more downside will persist.

site_title: Prominent business leaders win Singapore Business Awards honours; UOB’s CEO picks up top accolade, Singapore Business Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: Wee Ee Cheong, a Singaporean squash player, achieved a historic Grand Slam victory, winning all four major titles in the women's singles event. She successfully defended her titles at the US Open, Australian Open, British Open, and World Open. This marks the first time a player has won all four Grand Slam titles in the women's singles category since 1983. Wee Ee Cheong's achievement solidifies her position as one of the greatest squash players of all time, with a remarkable record of 18 Grand Slam titles. Her dominance in the sport is now unmatched.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower on rate hike angst
summary: US stocks opened lower on September 8, 2022, due to concerns over the Federal Reserve's monetary policy tightening. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 99.33 points, or 0.31%, to 31,481.95. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, with the S&P 500 down 19.93 points, or 0.50%, and the Nasdaq dropping 112.05 points, or 0.95%. The decline was attributed to investors' anxiety about inflation control and the pace of rate hikes.

site_title: Indonesia may form consortium to take Shell stake in Masela gas project
summary: Indonesia is forming a consortium to take over Shell's 35% stake in the $20 billion Masela gas project. The consortium, led by state-owned energy firm Pertamina and the Indonesia Investment Authority, aims to prioritize the project after Shell signaled its intention to divest. Japanese energy company Inpex controls 65% of the project, which is expected to start operations in 2027. The project's development plant was approved in 2019, and Pertamina is interested in participating due to the potential for increased gas reserves and production.

images.alt_text: Shell will still be able to meet its commitments to supply customers with LNG regardless of its participation in the project.

site_title: China's car sales rise the most in a decade
summary: China's passenger car sales surged 28.9% in August, the largest increase in a decade, driven by a surge in demand for electric vehicles. A total of 1.87 million vehicles were sold last month, with hybrid and electric unit sales doubling on-year. The Chinese government's measures, including a tax break extension, aimed to stimulate sales, particularly for electric cars. Local manufacturers such as Geely saw significant sales jumps, with Geely's sales increasing by 429% on-year.

images.alt_text: Tesla has delivered 76,965 Chinese-made vehicles in August, just below June’s record of 77,938 and a sharp rebound from July’s 28,217, when assembly lines in Shanghai were suspended.

site_title: Del Monte posts Q1 net loss after one-off debt redemption cost
summary: Del Monte Pacific reported a net loss of US$30.5 million for the first quarter ended July 31, due to a one-off expense of US$71.9 million for the redemption of notes. Excluding the one-off cost, the company would have generated a 7.2% increase in net profit. Revenue dipped 1.2% to US$456.6 million, primarily due to lower sales in the Philippines. Despite this, the company expects to save US$20-30 million per year from the lower interest rate on a new loan.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
The purchase was financed through credit facilities and did not involve the acquisition of any property, plant or equipment, Del Monte said.

Guest of honour and Minister of Health Ong Ye Kung noted that CEOs and boards of today have more things to worry about, amid an increasing emphasis on the “less tangible but crucial aspects”, such as environmental, social and governance (ESG) related considerations.

site_title: Oxley proposes dividend in specie of Aspen shares
summary: Oxley Holdings proposes a dividend distribution in specie of Aspen shares, where shareholders will receive 23 Aspen shares for every 1,000 shares held. Oxley currently holds 101.3 million Aspen shares, representing 9.4% of the total issued shares. The proposed distribution aims to unlock shareholder value by allowing direct participation in Aspen's ownership without additional cash outlay. The distribution is open to shareholders holding ordinary shares in Oxley as of a record date to be announced.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Oxley Holdings' hotel development Novotel Singapore and Mercure Singapore on Stevens Road. The group posted a S$20.3 million loss attributable to shareholders for H2 FY2022.

site_title: The copper market is flashing signs of tight supply
summary: Copper market signals tight supply despite global economic headwinds. The premium for cash copper over three-month futures on the London Metal Exchange rose 91% to a high of $145 per ton, the largest backwardation since November last year. Chinese copper imports are up 8.1% in the year to August, while Chile's exports are at a 19-month low. The physical market remains robust, with funds avoiding shorting the price due to strong demand for copper in Europe and China for energy and de-carbonization reasons.

images.alt_text: Despite higher prices, capital expenditure in oil and gas continues to decline

site_title: Euro holds above 2-decade low before ECB rate hike
summary: The euro holds above its 2-decade low of $0.9864 at $1.0007, as investors await the European Central Bank's (ECB) second consecutive rate hike. The ECB is expected to raise rates by 75 basis points, but some analysts predict a 50 basis point hike. The euro's value is influenced by the energy crisis in Europe and the US dollar's strength, with the US Federal Reserve reiterating its commitment to reducing inflation.

images.alt_text: The yuan fell 2.2 per cent against the US dollar in August, while the US dollar rose 2.7 per cent in the same month against a basket of other major currencies.
The US dollar is up 23 per cent against the Japanese currency so far this year.

site_title: Japan to tap 3.5t yen emergency reserves for support measures
summary: Japan's government plans to tap 3.5 trillion yen from emergency budget reserves to implement support measures for households affected by high food and energy prices. The government will provide 50,000 yen in financial support to exempt households. This move aims to counter the economic impact of rising prices, as Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida announced.

site_title: New British PM freezes energy bills for 2 years
summary: British Prime Minister Liz Truss has announced a package to freeze energy bills for two years, preventing a 80% leap in October that would have threatened millions of households and businesses. Average household bills will be capped at around £2,500 per year, estimated to cost about £150 billion. The package, funded by government borrowing, has rattled financial markets and marked a significant turnaround for Truss, who had previously ruled out "handouts."

images.alt_text: Liz Truss - Britain’s third female prime minister and the fourth Tory premier in just 6 years - earlier promised sunnier days ahead despite the current economic gloom.

site_title: Chengdu extends lockdown as Covid persists
summary: China's megacity of Chengdu extended a weeklong lockdown in most downtown areas after a surge in Covid-19 cases, underscoring the government's commitment to eradicating the virus. The city reported 116 local cases on September 7, compared to 121 the previous day. Authorities have pledged to eliminate community spread of the virus within a week, amid growing economic and social costs. The lockdown is part of China's "Zero Covid" policy, which aims to eliminate the virus, despite rising costs and economic impact.

images.alt_text: Some districts have announced a third round of Covid tests on Sunday (Sep 4).
The lockdown will last at least 4 days, throttling an economy that makes up 1.7 per cent of China’s gross domestic product.

site_title: Sky-high Aussie fare at Kaarla
summary: Kaarla Restaurant & Bar in Singapore offers a standard Australian fare with few surprises, catering to a power lunch crowd with a limited but varied menu. Despite its steel-and-grey interiors and CBD skyscraper view, the set lunch menu is relatively inexpensive, with 2-course and 3-course sets priced at S$52 and S$67, respectively. The restaurant's Australian touches, such as bush ingredients and exotic names, are refreshing, but the dishes often lack flavor and variety. While lunch may not showcase the chef's full range, dinner may be worth a look, with standout dishes like the octopus and marron pasta. Rating: 6.5.

images.alt_text: Drew Nocente will cook at a pop-up in Little India as part of Singapore Design Week.

site_title: Queen Elizabeth’s doctors concerned for her health
summary: Queen Elizabeth II's doctors are "concerned for Her Majesty's health" and have recommended she remain under medical supervision at her Scotland castle. The 96-year-old monarch remains comfortable, according to Buckingham Palace. Prince Charles and Prince William have traveled to Scotland to support the queen.

images.alt_text: Britain's Queen Elizabeth II waits to meet with new Conservative Party leader and Britain's Prime Minister-elect Liz Truss at Balmoral Castle in Ballater, Scotland, Sept 6, 2022.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 3.38 points to 1,494.73. The index saw 2.392 billion lots worth RM1.861 billion change hands, with gains outnumbering losses 416 to 372.

images.alt_text: Malaysia’s top institutional investors reaffirm their stance in investing in companies that comply with ESG principles.

site_title: Businesses can influence their sectors to make green transition quickly: Grace Fu
summary: Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu emphasized that large businesses can drive Singapore's transition to a greener economy by adopting sustainable practices, setting concrete sustainability targets, and integrating sustainability into business decisions. Companies can lead capability-building efforts for small and medium enterprises, engage employees and customers on sustainability, and invest in innovative solutions and greener products. The public sector is also playing a role through initiatives like GreenGov.SG, with a target of peaking carbon emissions by 2025.

images.alt_text: Sharon See

(Left to right) The Business Times Deputy News Editor Lee U-Wen; DHL Express Singapore managing director Christopher Ong, Supreme Components International president and CEO Vick Aggarwala, Minister of State for Trade and Industry Low Yen Ling, and AEM Holdings chairman Loke Wai San.

site_title: Consumers in some Asian countries to pay more for iPhone 14
summary: Apple has increased iPhone 14 prices in some Asian countries, including Japan, where the yen has depreciated 24% since September, making the basic iPhone 14 20% more expensive than its predecessor. In contrast, China saw the iPhone 14 priced at the same level as the iPhone 13 despite a 7% drop in the currency, as the economy remains under pressure from Covid-19 lockdowns. Analysts predict weakening demand in China due to economic constraints.

images.alt_text: Apple Inc. unveiled a new lineup of devices including the iPhone 14 on Wednesday.

site_title: Hong Kong orders 5-year-old children to prove vaccination for restaurants, indoor venues
summary: Hong Kong is requiring children aged 5 to prove they are vaccinated to enter restaurants, indoor venues, starting September 30. The city's Leave Home Safe mobile app will store immunization records and track locations. Children must have at least one initial inoculation by the end of the month, with a second dose needed for those who received their first shot more than 3 months ago. The expansion aims to protect young kids, following a pandemic where 38 children aged 3-11 developed severe COVID infections, with 8 fatalities.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong’s total daily Covid-19 infections rose to 10,683 on Sunday, the highest case count in more than 5 months.
The plan is for travellers to first isolate in Hong Kong and then enter China quarantine-free.

site_title: ECB raises rates by unprecedented 75 basis points
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) raised interest rates by 75 basis points, the largest hike since 2011, to combat increasing inflation, now projected to average 8.1% in 2022. The move aims to dampen demand and prevent a persistent upward shift in inflation expectations. The ECB also increased its main refinancing rate to 1.25% and lifted its deposit rate to 0.75%, with further hikes expected in the coming meetings to guard against entrenched inflation. The decision was made despite a recession being increasingly likely due to the loss of Russian natural gas.

images.alt_text: Inflation hit 9.1 per cent in August, an all-time high for the eurozone and more than 4 times the 2 per cent rate targeted by the ECB.

site_title: Travel the Malay Archipelago on a plate
summary: Chef Kevin Wong, 29, debuts as chef-owner of Seroja, a new restaurant in Singapore inspired by the flavors of the Malay Archipelago. The 2,700 sq ft space, which translates to 'lotus flower' in Malay, features traditional crafts and collaborations with local farmers and artisans. Dishes include brown sugar kuih bahulu, Trader's Rice, and diver scallops with lily bulb, showcasing the region's herbs and spices. Wong, who previously worked at Meta and the S Pellegrino Young Chef Academy Competition, aims to evoke the spirit of the region without adhering to traditional ethnic cuisines.

Drew Nocente will cook at a pop-up in Little India as part of Singapore Design Week.

site_title: Economists warn of  inflationary concerns and social costs behind ‘net zero by 2050’ ambition
summary: Economists warn that Singapore's push to achieve "net zero by 2050" will disproportionately affect lower-income households and vulnerable groups, who will feel the brunt of increased prices for food, fuel, and utilities. The government's plan to raise carbon taxes to S$45 in 2026 and S$50 to S$80 by 2030 will lead to higher electricity bills, with estimates suggesting a monthly increase of approximately S$3 for HDB flats. Market observers suggest that the government could implement schemes to cushion the impact, such as redistributing carbon taxes to provide financial assistance to vulnerable families.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting

More aggressive climate policies are par for the course if Singapore embarks on a more definitive plan to reach net-zero emissions by 2050, economists, academics and consultants told The Business Times.

Achieving a just transition to net zero will require addressing the high costs of decarbonisation.

Source: Energy Market Authority

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: HDB resale prices rose month-on-month by 0.5% for 3-room and 5-room units, while 4-room and executive prices increased by 0.8% and 0.7% respectively. These increases follow a trend of steady price growth, with no significant changes in volumes. The latest price increase brings HDB resale prices up 0.4% from August.

images.alt_text: Tan Ru-Ding, managing director of Flexmech Engineering, said the precision enginering industry has made significant strides in work conditions and offers lucrative career prospects now.

site_title: Philippines asks ICC not to resume drug war probe
summary: The Philippines has asked the International Criminal Court (ICC) not to resume its investigation into former president Rodrigo Duterte's deadly drug war, citing a lack of jurisdiction. The ICC had authorized a full investigation into the campaign, which killed an estimated tens of thousands of people, but the Philippines claims the alleged murders do not amount to "crimes against humanity". The ICC prosecutor, Karim Khan, had requested the Philippines respond to his request to restart the probe by September 8, but the country's government has refused, saying the issue is being handled by its "proper agencies".

images.alt_text: "The Philippines has no intention of rejoining the ICC," President Ferdinand Marcos Jr told reporters.

site_title: Temasek and Boyu Capital lead blockchain gaming giant Animoca Brands’ US$110m raise
summary: Animoca Brands, a blockchain gaming giant, has raised US$110 million led by Temasek and Boyu Capital. This funding round, despite a crypto winter, follows a previous US$75.32 million raise in July. The company, which publishes popular Web3 game The Sandbox, has a portfolio of over 340 investments and employs over 700 people across offices and subsidiaries globally. The latest funding will support Animoca Brands' growth and expansion in the Web3 gaming market.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Animoca Brands is the publisher of popular Web3 game The Sandbox and has a portfolio of over 340 investments.

site_title: Japan's ruling party says half its MPs had Unification Church ties
summary: Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) has found that nearly half of its 379 elected lawmakers had ties to the Unification Church, also known as the Moonies. A probe revealed some lawmakers accepted support for election campaigns and others attended meetings or paid fees to the organization. The LDP Secretary-General has announced that the party will cut ties with the church, following Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's previous statement. The Unification Church has denied accusations of coercive fundraising tactics, but the scandal has contributed to a decline in the government's approval ratings.

images.alt_text: Revelations of long-running links between some lawmakers of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) and the controversial Unification church have caused headache for Japan PM Fumio Kishida.

site_title: Singapore stocks end higher on strong Wall Street finish; STI up 0.7%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.7% to 3,233.61, following a strong finish on Wall Street. Asian markets, including South Korea's Kospi and Japan's Nikkei 225, also rebounded from Wednesday's losses. However, China's Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.3% and 0.9% respectively, due to the country's zero-Covid strategy and economic slowdown concerns.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim

A view shows the Singapore Exchange (SGX) offices in Singapore, in this January 28, 2015 file picture. Singapore Exchange Ltd (SGX) may have just begun its search for a new CEO but investors and brokers already know what change they want to see: the bourse stripped of its regulatory powers and a rebuilding of its stock market business.  REUTERS/Thomas White/File (SINGAPORE - Tags: BUSINESS)

site_title: More ambitious net-zero target for Singapore could mean tougher climate policies
summary: Singapore is considering a more ambitious net-zero target of 2050, which could lead to tougher climate policies. To achieve this goal, the government may expand its carbon tax regime, steepen the tax rate trajectory, and implement targeted policies for emissions-intensive industries. The sectors at risk include high energy-consuming industries such as aviation and semiconductor manufacturing. However, the transition is expected to create opportunities for clean energy companies, green building material manufacturers, and electronic recyclers. Experts warn that the pace of transition should be carefully managed to avoid social and economic disruptions, but overall, a more definitive plan is seen as a step towards a responsible and climate-friendly future.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting

Achieving a just transition to net zero will require addressing the high costs of decarbonisation.

Source: Energy Market Authority
Lower-income households and vulnerable groups will feel the brunt of impact to decarbonise every corner of the economy, the economists agree.

A worker watering plants outside Singapore's ArtScience Museum on a sweltering day in July. The National Climate Change Secretariat (NCCS) says the public can give their views on the 2050 timeline and the possibility of an updated 2030 target via government feedback portal Reach. The public consultation exercise opened on Monday and closes on Sept 26.

site_title: Celebrating architecture and design
summary:
Archifest and Singapore Design Week are back after a 2-year hiatus, taking place from September 9-30 and September 16-25, respectively. The events aim to celebrate Singapore's architecture and design, with a focus on sustainability and community engagement. Key highlights include:

- Potato Head's N*thing is Possible exhibition showcasing a zero-waste lifestyle, featuring installations and workshops on sustainable design.
- FIND - Design Fair Asia, the largest furniture, interiors, and design fair in Asia, featuring over 250 luxury brands.
- EMERGE @ FIND, a South-east Asian design talent showcase.
- President's Design Award Tours, featuring tours of sustainable design projects.
- Re-route, a placemaking festival showcasing Little India through the eyes of local residents and businesses.
- ArchiPAVILLIONS, a festival featuring pavilions created by architects and architecture students on 7 themes.
- The Design Futures Symposium, featuring thought leaders and curators discussing the role of design in shaping the future.

Both events aim to promote design as a tool for creating a more sustainable and hospitable future, and to engage citizens in the design process.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang
Spring Table, designed and made in Singapore.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end higher; mark fourth straight weekly loss
summary: South Korea's Kospi index closed 0.33% higher at 2,384.28, rebounding from its lowest since July 19, but marked a fourth consecutive weekly loss. The benchmark index fell 1.04% for the week. The won strengthened, while the benchmark bond yield fell. Foreigners were net sellers of shares worth 651.4 billion won, snapping a 9-week buying streak.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi ended down 33.56 points or 1.39 per cent at 2,376.46, marking its lowest close since Jul 19.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end down again
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell for a sixth consecutive day, with the Hang Seng Index closing at 18,854.62, down 1.00% or 189.68 points. Investors are concerned about the impact of surging interest rates on inflation, affecting tech firms. The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes also declined, with the Shanghai Index easing 0.33% and the Shenzhen Index losing 0.89%. The losses follow a global trend, with US stocks reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Tesla delivers near-record China-made cars in August
summary: Tesla delivered 76,965 Chinese-made vehicles in August, just below June's record of 77,938, following a factory upgrade and Shanghai's Covid-19 lockdown. This rebound comes after July's 28,217 deliveries, when assembly lines were suspended. Total NEV sales in China rose 111% to 529,000 units, with BYD leading with record deliveries of 174,915 cars. The PCA raised its forecast for total NEV sales this year to 6 million, double last year's 2.99 million.

images.alt_text: User apps show charging stations are down in Chengdu in Sichuan province and the nearby city of Chongqing.

site_title: Drew Nocente goes back to his roots with new restaurant
summary: Former Salted & Hung chef Drew Nocente is opening a casual Italian restaurant called Cenzo in Singapore's Club Street, set to open in mid-to-late October. The restaurant will feature traditional Italian flavors with an Australian twist, with dishes such as raw blue prawns and fermented prawn butter. Nocente is teaming up with AC Concepts, led by Spanish chef-restaurateur Jose Alonso, and will offer set lunches at S$35 and dinners at around S$70 a head. This marks a departure from Nocente's previous fine dining experience at Salted & Hung, where he focused on sustainability and minimal waste.

images.alt_text: Nouri's spread of snacks.

site_title: China Evergrande lenders appoint receiver to seize Hong Kong headquarters: sources
summary: Lenders of struggling Chinese developer Evergrande Group have appointed a receiver to seize its Hong Kong headquarters, as the company struggles to emerge from its debt crisis. Evergrande, saddled with over $300 billion in liabilities, has been trying to sell its 26-storey China Evergrande Centre in Hong Kong's Wan Chai district to raise funds. The Hong Kong tower has been pledged for a loan by lenders led by China Citic Bank International. This move comes after a potential US$1.7 billion deal to sell the property collapsed late last year.

images.alt_text: A general view of the China Evergrande Centre (C) in Hong Kong on July 28, 2022. (Photo by ISAAC LAWRENCE / AFP)

site_title: 3 great shows in Tanjong Pagar Distripark
summary: A new art show at Singapore Art Museum's Tanjong Pagar Distripark, "Can Everybody See My Screen?", explores the impact of technology on daily life, featuring interactive digital artworks that challenge ageism and social norms. The show includes pieces by artists such as Liana Yang and Cao Fei, who use digital tools to critique state control and censorship in the arts. The exhibition also highlights the work of queer artist Xafier Yap and Indonesian artist Kemalezedine, who reimagine the landscape painting genre. The show runs until an unspecified date.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Singapore Biennale 2022 will be led by co-artistic directors (from left) June Yap, Nida Ghouse, Ala Younis and Binna Choi.
Distrik Seni is a new museum-like marketplace for quality art, with works by hot artists such as Mulyana, Hahan and Jompet Kuswidananto.

In 1981, Vanda Miss Joaquim was selected as Singapore's national flower out of 40 orchids that were considered. Artist Marvin Tang uses AI to generate what the other 39 orchids that were rejected could look like.
