site_title: South Korea warns fund outflows may accelerate if global risks persist
summary: South Korea's central bank warned that fund outflows may accelerate if global risks persist, citing threats to emerging economies from the Federal Reserve's tightening, Russia's war on Ukraine, and China's economic slowdown. The Bank of Korea raised its key interest rate by 2 percentage points since August last year, aiming to curb inflation, which runs at 5-6%. A weakening won, fueled by high energy and commodity prices, makes it harder to control inflation and amplifies import costs. The BOK will stick to policy efforts to bring inflation expectations back under control.

images.alt_text: The central bank estimated a fall of US$10 in global oil prices on an annual average basis would improve the trade balance by US$9 billion.
Minister Choo Kyung-ho said external factors were mostly to blame for the increased volatility in the local markets.

site_title: Bankers plot US risky-credit comeback as Europe left in the cold
summary: US junk bond and leveraged loan markets show cautious optimism as bankers test demand for new deals. Despite sky-high inflation and rising interest rates, US credit spreads are lower than in Europe, reflecting a perception that US companies are less vulnerable to recession. European market conditions remain lackluster due to energy crisis and recession concerns, prompting bankers to seek US investors for funding commitments. A recent $4.5 billion leveraged loan sale to support Citrix's buyout is seen as a bellwether for the US market, with some market watchers predicting a widening split between US and European credit markets.

images.alt_text: The hopes of a dovish shift that drove a rebound through June and July have evaporated since Fed Chair Jerome Powell committed to higher rates for as long as it takes to tame inflation.

site_title: Taiwan confident it can sign 'high standard' US trade deal
summary: Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen expressed confidence in signing a "high-standard" trade deal with the US under the newly unveiled US-Taiwan Initiative on 21st Century Trade. Negotiations are expected to begin soon, with bipartisan US lawmakers supporting the agreement. The move comes after the Biden administration excluded Taiwan from its Asia-focused economic plan, and amid ongoing tensions with China. Tsai vowed to deepen trade and economic ties with the US, while dismissing China's opposition as "unhappy" and "scuttling" visits by US lawmakers violating the "one-China principle".

images.alt_text: The meeting this week also comes as relations with China have deteriorated further after House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s visit to Taiwan last month amid threats and opposition from Beijing.

site_title: Germany vows to aid companies hobbled by Putin’s gas squeeze
summary: Germany will expand a pandemic-era aid program to support companies hit by the energy crisis caused by Russian President Vladimir Putin's gas supply cuts. The program, which has about 5 billion euros left, will consider aid for small and medium enterprises based on the relation between energy costs and production expenses. Economy Minister Robert Habeck said the government will "open a wide rescue umbrella" to help strapped businesses, but warned that the crisis is likely to last beyond this winter and the support will be temporary.

images.alt_text: Russia’s decision to indefinitely shut its key Nord Stream pipeline to Germany last week has forced European governments to plan market interventions.
The 2 leaders could meet as soon as the UN General Assembly later in September.

site_title: Hidden items found in Vermeer's famed Milkmaid painting
summary: Experts at the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam have discovered hidden items in Johannes Vermeer's 17th-century painting "The Milkmaid," including a wooden jug holder and a woven basket. Advanced scanning techniques revealed these details beneath the plain white wall that makes the milkmaid's clothes stand out. The changes made by Vermeer were later painted over, but they provide insight into his artistic technique and influence on his later works, including "Girl with a Pearl Earring." A major exhibition of Vermeer's work will take place at the Rijksmuseum in 2023, featuring 27 of his small lifetime productions.

images.alt_text: Annelies Van Loon, paintings conservator and chemist of the Rijksmuseum (R) shows a detail on a screen projection of the painting the "Milkmaid" by Johannes Vermeer during a press conference on new discoveries made on one of Vermeer’s most famous paintings at the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam. - Experts have found a hidden jug holder and basket in Dutch master Johannes Vermeer's famed painting "The Milkmaid" which he later painted over, Amsterdam's Rijksmuseum said on September 8, 2022. (Photo by Kenzo TRIBOUILLARD / AFP) / RESTRICTED TO EDITORIAL USE - MANDATORY MENTION OF THE ARTIST UPON PUBLICATION - TO ILLUSTRATE THE EVENT AS SPECIFIED IN THE CAPTION
A Vermeer restoration reveals a god of desire

site_title: Asia's southern flank shines in fight against surging dollar
summary: Asian central banks are responding to the surging US dollar by raising interest rates and intervening in markets, with South and South-east Asia's economies proving more resilient than North Asia's. Indonesia, India, and Singapore are outperforming other Asian currencies, driven by robust growth and large currency reserves. However, analysts warn that depleting foreign reserves, budgetary constraints, and the dollar's sustained momentum pose risks for these economies. Despite the challenges, investors are taking note and moving their money to these relatively stable economies.

images.alt_text: With the greenback supercharged by expectations of higher-for-longer US interest rates, traders are struggling to pick the bottom for Asian currencies.

site_title: Malaysia hikes key rate to 2.5%, says not on pre-set tightening path
summary: Malaysia's central bank raised its key overnight policy rate (OPR) by 25 basis points to 2.5% on August 8, supporting growth momentum driven by an improved employment rate, income prospects, and robust tourism-related activities. The move aims to balance economic growth and inflation, with inflation expected to peak in the third quarter and moderate thereafter. Despite concerns from small and medium enterprises (SMEs) about cash flow and rising material costs, the bank emphasized a gradual approach to monetary policy adjustments.

images.alt_text: Wearing a face mask in most indoor spaces in Malaysia is now optional but this still subject to premise owners’ discretion.
Higher food prices continue to fuel Malaysia's inflation with the country's consumer price index climbed 4.4 per cent in July this year, the highest since May 2021.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on US gains
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 2.31% on Thursday, driven by gains on Wall Street. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index climbed to 28,065.28, while the broader Topix index rose 2.19%. Investors were watching the surging dollar, but the rally was largely fueled by US market gains.

site_title: ECB to match historic inflation with bumper rate hike
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is expected to raise interest rates by a historic 75-basis-points at its meeting, matching the high inflation rate of 9.1% in August, the highest in the eurozone. This move aims to tame soaring energy costs and inflation, which has exceeded the ECB's 2% target. The rate hike is seen as a response to the Russian invasion of Ukraine, which has driven up energy prices, and a weak euro, which has bolstered the case for bigger interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: The influential head of the German central bank, Joachim Nagel, said the ECB needs a “strong rise in interest rates in September” following August's red-hot inflation numbers.
There are growing expectations for the ECB to raise rates by 75 basis points as soon as Thursday.

site_title: What’s the deal with Riesling?
summary: Wine enthusiasts often dismiss Riesling due to negative experiences with bad wines, rather than acknowledging the complexity and nuances of the grape. Climate change has led to increased ripeness, making it challenging to produce dry Rieslings. However, some excellent dry Rieslings have been discovered, such as the Brand Pfalz Riesling Trocken 2021, Dreissigacker Rheinhessen Riesling Trocken 2021, and Georg Breuer Rheingau Estate Lorch 2020. The article emphasizes the importance of being open-minded and not judging wines based on a few tries, as good wine can vary depending on context and conditions.

images.alt_text: You can improve your drinking experience by taking a more thoughtful approach to the bottles you choose and how you judge what's in your glass.
Just how cold should red wine be when serving?

site_title: Asia: Markets bounce after sell-off, dollar closes on new highs
summary: Asian markets experienced a rare rebound on Thursday, with Tokyo leading the gains due to data showing a stronger-than-expected Japanese economy in the second quarter. The dollar continued to rise, closing on new highs, as investors seek safe-haven assets amid global uncertainty. The Federal Reserve is expected to announce another interest rate hike on September 21, which could impact global economies. Despite a brief dip in oil prices, concerns over China's zero-Covid strategy and a potential recession remain, weighing on investor sentiment.

images.alt_text: Asian currencies tumbled against the dollar due to a surge in the US bond yields.

site_title: Apple’s China iCloud operator warns of ‘dire’ Covid lockdown
summary: Apple's China data centre operator, Guizhou Cloud Big Data, has implemented a "closed loop" system due to the latest Covid lockdown in Guiyang, a city of 6 million that houses much of China's electronic information. Employees are barred from leaving the premises, with many not seeing their families for a week. The lockdown has paralysed the city, forcing the firm to take emergency measures to shut out the pandemic, but it's unclear whether Apple's servers have been affected.

images.alt_text: Apple Inc. unveiled a new lineup of devices including the iPhone 14 on Wednesday.

site_title: Brokers’ take: UOBKH calls GoTo’s valuation ‘unjustifiable’, initiates with ‘sell’
summary: UOB Kay Hian has initiated coverage on GoTo Group with a "sell" rating and a target price of 240 rupiah, citing "unjustifiable" valuations despite strong growth potential. The company is expected to turn profitable in 2029, with net income projected at 18.25 trillion by 2032. GoTo's price-to-sales ratio is a premium of over 5 times its regional peers and 3 times its domestic peers, and the company's divisions are market leaders in on-demand services, e-commerce, and financial technology.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
GoTo IPO on the Indonesia Stock Exchange.

site_title: Europe: Stocks up before major UK, ECB announcements
summary: European stocks rose ahead of major policy decisions from the UK and the European Central Bank. London's FTSE 100 index climbed 0.3% to 7,261.10 points, while Frankfurt's DAX index gained 0.6% and the Paris CAC 40 rose 0.5%. The European Central Bank is expected to hike eurozone interest rates by a record-high 75 basis points, while the UK's new Prime Minister, Liz Truss, will freeze domestic fuel bills to ease the cost-of-living crisis.

site_title: World’s top airline shares are in Asia despite China lockdowns
summary: Asian airline stocks have outperformed global peers, gaining 31% in 2022, despite China's strict Covid-protocols and lockdowns ahead of a Communist Party congress. Cathay Pacific Airways, Eva Airways, Japan Airlines, ANA Holdings, Singapore Airlines, and Qantas Airways have all advanced, with the Bloomberg World Airlines Index up 15%. Analyst Tim Bacchus attributes the gains to Asia's "revenge travel" trend and Western concerns over inflation and recession, which have driven investors to seek growth opportunities in the region.

site_title: Top scientists join forces to study leading theory behind long Covid
summary: Scientists from top academic centers are joining forces to study the leading theory behind long Covid, a complex and poorly understood condition that can last for months after initial Covid infection. The Long Covid Research Initiative aims to streamline research and quickly pivot to clinical trials of potential treatments, backed by a $15 million grant from a scientific investment fund. Researchers will use advanced imaging and gene-sequencing techniques to analyze the presence of virus fragments in tissues and their effects on the immune system, with the goal of testing antiviral treatments and designing evidence-based trials.

images.alt_text: Typhoon Hinnamnor approaches Shanghai, following the coronavirus disease outbreak, Sept 2, 2022.
The delay in meeting payments underscores the mounting cost - financially, economically and socially - of President Xi Jinping’s strict approach to stopping the spread of Omicron subvariants.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise most in 10 weeks on hopes of slower rate hikes
summary: Australian shares rose 1.77% to a 10-week high, closing at 6,848.7, after Reserve Bank of Australia Governor Philip Lowe signaled a slower pace of interest rate hikes, easing concerns about further tightening. Lowe stated that interest rates are closer to neutral levels, but uncertainty remains about how much further rates might rise. The S&P/ASX 200 index ended two sessions of losses.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index rose about 0.4 per cent to 6,756 points by 0045 GMT on Thursday.

site_title: Human development set back 5 years by Covid-19, other crises: UN report
summary: A United Nations report reveals that the Covid-19 pandemic, along with other crises, has set human progress back five years, erasing five years of gains. The Human Development Index, which measures life expectancy, education, and living standards, has declined for two years, with a global drop in life expectancy from 73 to 71.4 years. The report highlights the compounding effects of crises, including climate change, financial instability, and political polarization, leading to feelings of insecurity and a loss of trust in institutions.

images.alt_text: Corporate lawyers agreed that temporary relief measures and government financial support for businesses during the pandemic provided a reprieve from the commencement of winding up applications in 2020 and 2021.
Xinjiang, in the west of the country, saw a 76 per cent plunge in visitors in August compared to July.

site_title: Frasers Property’s Sky Eden@Bedok 75% sold at S$2,100 psf average on launch day
summary: Frasers Property's Sky Eden@Bedok has achieved 75% sales rate on its first launch day, with 118 out of 158 residential units sold at an average price of S$2,100 per square foot (psf). The 2-bedroom units were fully sold, while the remaining 3-bedroom and 4-bedroom units are priced between S$1,087 to S$1,302 sq ft. The project's accessible location in a mature estate drew buyers, with many purchasing for investment, and the pricing was considered relatively comfortable for a new mixed-use development in the area.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Huttons Asia’s senior research director Lee Sze Teck attributed July's jump in sales for the outside central region to “astounding sale results” for AMO Residence.
Intercontinental Hotel Singapore, a portfolio property within FHT

Q2 Thao Dien, Frasers Property’s first residential project in Vietnam. The group is exercising its call option to redeem all S$350 million of its 3.95 per cent of its fixed-rate subordinated perpetual securities.
According to Frasers’ group chief corporate officer, Chia Khong Shoong, , Frasers Property Capital will continue to focus on core asset classes as well as its existing markets.

site_title: Philippines’ Marcos touts US$14b investment pledges from ‘fruitful’ overseas trip
summary: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. returned home after a successful overseas trip to Indonesia and Singapore, securing investment pledges of $14 billion. During his visits, Marcos met with leaders of government and commerce, declaring the Philippines open for business and inviting private capital to upgrade infrastructure. He aims to support economic recovery efforts, create jobs, and improve agriculture to reduce reliance on food imports, with a goal of 8% economic growth and halving the poverty rate during his six-year term.

site_title: Horizon Towers takes another crack at collective sale at S$1.1b
summary: Horizon Towers, a 211-unit residential development in prime district 9, Singapore, is being put up for collective sale at a reserve price of S$1.1 billion. The site, which has a 99-year lease, offers a unit land rate of S$1,862 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr) after factoring in a 10% bonus gross floor area due to a high development baseline. The tender closes on October 20. This is the second attempt by the developer to sell the site, following a previous attempt in 2019.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani
According to real estate consultancy JLL, there were nine residential en bloc deals this year for a total transacted value of about S$1.81 billion, as at July 31.
The guide price works out to a land rate of about S$1,414 per square foot psf ppr, after including the development charge payable of around S$178.1 million, CBRE said.
Orchard Bel Air's 99-year leasehold tenure started in Aug 1980, and it has a land area of about 93,126 square feet.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 2.70 points lower, 0.18% down, at 1,488.65 on Thursday. The index saw 147.45 million lots traded worth RM82.30 million, with 193 gainers and 111 losers.

site_title: Australia takes up outlier rate stance, signalling smaller hikes
summary: Australia's central bank chief, Philip Lowe, signaled a potential end to outsized interest-rate increases, citing the tight labor market and strong household spending as factors. The RBA delivered a fourth straight half-point hike, raising the cash rate to 2.35%, and Lowe warned that a global slowdown would make delivering a soft landing in Australia harder. Markets reacted positively, with Australian 3-year yields plummeting and the Australian dollar sliding. Lowe's more cautious approach contrasts with global counterparts, including Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell, who warned of higher borrowing costs.

images.alt_text: Indeed, so resilient was the economy that the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has had to embark on an uber-aggressive tightening campaign to try and cool activity and restrain runaway inflation.

site_title: HDB resale prices inch up 0.4% in August, volumes continue trending down
summary: HDB resale prices rose 0.4% in August, marking the 26th consecutive month of increases, while overall resale flats transacted in August decreased 1.7% from July and 15.5% from last year. Despite slower price gains, resale prices still increased 10.8% year-on-year, with non-mature estates seeing a 11.4% increase. Transaction volumes, however, fell 1.7% from July and 15.5% from last year, potentially signaling lower demand in the market.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
HDB said most home buyers will be able to afford the flats on offer through its August BTO exercise.
Condominiums, apartments and hotels as viewed from Moulmein Road on May 4, 2021.
Weakening property market sentiment could be a harbinger of flagging construction demand.
Private properties along Paterson Road

site_title: Will Truss rehabilitate Keynes?
summary: UK Prime Minister Liz Truss is expected to implement unorthodox economic policies, including borrowing and spending, to combat stagflation, a rare and mysterious economic phenomenon. Despite conventional wisdom predicting disaster, Truss's approach may be viable, as stagflation's causes are complex and varied. Historically, fiscal expansion has worked in the past, as seen in the cases of Margaret Thatcher and Ronald Reagan. Truss's policies, combined with a focus on history over theory, may put Keynesian economics back on its feet, potentially averting a recession and defying inflationary disaster.

images.alt_text: BOE governor Andrew Bailey, speaking to Parliament’s Treasury Committee, welcomed Truss’ impending announcement of her plans this week.
Truss underlined her tax-cutting ambitions and warned that Britain could not “tax our way to growth.”

site_title: China tourism hotspots struggle to recover as visitors stay away
summary: China's tourism hotspots, including Xinjiang, Hainan province, and Tibet, are struggling to recover from lockdowns, with visitor numbers plummeting by 76% in Xinjiang and 17% in Hainan. The lockdowns have stranded tens of thousands of tourists, dealing a blow to the US$830 billion industry. Similar scenes are unfolding in other cities, with 33 cities partially or fully locked down, raising concerns about the long-term impact on airlines, hotels, and restaurants. The government has pledged to reinvigorate the industry, but the risk of new shutdowns may undermine people's willingness to travel.

site_title: China’s BYD signs land deal to build electric vehicle plant in Thailand
summary: BYD, a leading electric vehicle manufacturer, has signed a land deal to build a car assembly plant in Thailand's Rayong province. The 96-hectare plot of land is valued at approximately 30 billion baht (S$1.2 billion). Production is expected to begin in 2024 with an initial capacity of 150,000 right-hand-drive EVs annually, targeting Thailand's domestic market and export markets in Southeast Asia and Europe. This marks BYD's first electric vehicle plant in South-east Asia.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks flat at the open
summary: Hong Kong stocks began Thursday on a flat note, with the Hang Seng Index inching down 0.46 points to 19,043.84, amid ongoing worries about the Federal Reserve's plans to combat inflation through interest rate hikes. The rally in US and most Asian markets was offset by these concerns.

site_title: China overtakes US with 2.04t yuan corporate credit boom
summary: China has surpassed the US as the top destination for corporate bond deals in its yuan credit market, with non-financial firms issuing more yuan-denominated bonds than US dollar bonds in July and August. This shift is largely due to the diverging monetary policies of the two countries, with the US Federal Reserve tightening its stance to combat inflation and China keeping interest rates low to support its ailing economy. Despite the yuan's relatively low popularity internationally, China's massive economy and liquidity-driven market have allowed it to gain ground, with yuan corporate debt sales reaching $410 billion in August.

images.alt_text: Chinese 100 yuan banknotes are seen in a counting machine while a clerk counts them at a branch of a commercial bank in Beijing, China, March 30, 2016. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon/File Photo
The yuan fell 2.2 per cent against the US dollar in August, while the US dollar rose 2.7 per cent in the same month against a basket of other major currencies.

site_title: Sultan Plaza relaunched for the third time with potentially lower reserve price of S$325m
summary: Sultan Plaza, a 44-year-old commercial building in Singapore, is relaunched for the third time after two previous attempts failed to attract a suitable buyer. The reserve price has been lowered to S$325 million from S$360 million, with 72% of owners agreeing to the lower price. The site has a 99-year leasehold tenure and is zoned for commercial use, allowing for redevelopment options such as a hotel or mixed-use development. A developer may redevelop the site to an estimated GFA of 317,198.9 sq ft, with potential for a 20% commercial and 80% residential use.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Sultan Plaza, City Plaza join ranks of en bloc hopefuls
Sultan Plaza collective sale closing date extended to Mar 3
The site is located in the downtown District 7 and is a 5 minutes walk to Nicoll Highway and Lavender MRT stations.

site_title: Y Combinator-backed Shipmates raises US$2.2m seed funding
summary: Shipmates, a shipping platform based in the Philippines, has raised US$2.2 million in seed funding from investors. Founded in July 2021 by Josh Supan and David Marquez, the platform allows online business owners to book shipping orders and compare rates between couriers. The company aims to tap into the estimated US$26 billion e-commerce industry in the Philippines by 2025, with nine courier companies integrated into its platform. Shipmates operates on a pay-per-use model and has received US$500,000 in seed funding from Y Combinator.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
(from left) Shipmates co-founders, chief technology officer David Marquez and CEO Josh Supan.

site_title: Singapore shares extend US gains on Thursday; STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.6% on Thursday, led by US stock gains, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,231.13 points. The US Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 rose 1.4% and 1.8% respectively, while the Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 2.1%. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also saw positive gains. The rally follows recent weakness and hawkish Federal Reserve commentary, with investors remaining optimistic despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Nio reported a wider second quarter net loss of 2.7 billion yuan (S$545 million) from 659.3 million yuan the year before.

site_title: ‘Help wanted’: businesses struggle to fill jobs
summary: Businesses worldwide struggle to fill job openings, with over 11 million job vacancies in the US and 887,000 in Germany. Countries like Australia, Canada, and the UK face shortages in specific sectors, such as nurses, engineers, and postal workers. Experts attribute the phenomenon to the "Great Resignation" driven by the COVID-19 pandemic, with factors including aging populations, poor working conditions, and low salaries. To attract workers, companies are offering higher salaries, flexible work arrangements, and other benefits, leading to a structural shift in the way employees interact with work.

images.alt_text: UPS said the job openings are mainly for full-time and part-time drivers and package handlers.
A lorry driver passes a sign on the side of his vehicle advertising for jobs as he makes a delivery, in London, Britain, October 13, 2021. REUTERS/Toby Melville

site_title: China’s Covid test providers are owed billions in unpaid bills
summary: China's Covid test providers are facing significant unpaid bills, with eight major firms reporting a combined 14.1 billion yuan (S$2.8 billion) increase in accounts receivable as of June 30, a 73% gain from the previous year. The delay in meeting payments is attributed to China's strict approach to containing the spread of Omicron subvariants, with mass-testing and lockdowns affecting local governments' finances. The situation may lead to increased bad debt risks, but it is unlikely that diagnostic firms will fail to receive payment due to the government's support.

images.alt_text: Weaker exports will weigh on the currency, which is close to breaching 7 to the dollar.

The so-called “whole nation system” should improve its strategy and focus on areas critical to China’s industrial, economic and national security, CCTV reported, citing a meeting on Tuesday (Sep 6) of a high-level Communist Party committee chaired by President Xi.

site_title: Sky Eden, Lentor Modern will test market; CDL, GuocoLand among top property picks: DBS
summary: DBS forecasts strong sales momentum for Sky Eden @ Bedok and Lentor Modern, with indicative pricing of S$2,000 per square foot (psf) onwards. The projects are expected to drive a further squeeze in supply and higher average pricing in H2 2022. Sky Eden has already sold 75% of its units at an average price of S$2,100 psf, while GuocoLand's Lentor Modern is seen as attractive due to the Thomson-East Coast Line's gradual opening. DBS estimates an up to 1.2% accretion to GuocoLand's RNAV for every S$100 psf gain above S$2,000 psf.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Artist's impression of Sky Eden@Bedok, the first residential launch in Bedok Town Centre in 10 years.
Artist's impression of Sky Eden@Bedok. Close to 75 per cent of its residential units were sold on the first day of the project's launch.
GuocoLand to launch preview for Lentor condo project; prices start from S$1,880 psf

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher on Wall Street gains, eyes on Federal Reserve
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index jumping 1.21% to 27,761.44, driven by gains on Wall Street. Investors are also watching the dollar's surge amid concerns of aggressive US rate hikes. The broader Topix index added 1.18% to 1,938.35.

site_title: Cornered FX traders brace for dollar to smash more Asia records
summary: The dollar's surge due to expected higher US interest rates is causing Asian currencies to plummet, with the yen falling to 145 per dollar, the yuan teetering near 7, and the Korean won hurtling towards 1400. Traders struggle to predict a turning point, with the dollar's strength expected to continue until something stops it. Investors are selling the yuan due to China's economic slowdown and interest rate hikes in the US, while the yen's slide prompts warnings from Japanese officials and potential intervention by the US Treasury Department.

images.alt_text: Japan’s currency has slumped 20 per cent this year and edged past its previous worst annual drawdown in 1979.

site_title: Chinese developers are facing a flurry of winding-up lawsuits
summary: Chinese developers are facing a surge in winding-up lawsuits as smaller creditors turn to court to obtain payments. Sunac and Jiayuan International Group are among at least six builders to receive such petitions, with November hearings scheduled. The court filings may lead to more negotiations or a solution through the court process, as creditors become increasingly frustrated with a lack of restructuring progress. This trend is expected to continue, with more court filings anticipated.

images.alt_text: It is the first winding-up petition known to have been filed against Sunac, a top 3 property developer by sales last year.
On a positive note, Country Garden was among developers chosen to sell new onshore bonds with a state-owned entity’s guarantee, part of regulatory efforts to stem the cash squeeze.

site_title: Auditor flags KOP’s ability to continue as going concern on material uncertainty
summary: KOP Properties' independent auditor has flagged a material uncertainty that may cast significant doubt on the group's ability to continue as a going concern due to the hospitality segment's uncertain recovery. The directors plan to prepare FY2022 financial statements on a going concern basis, expecting the segment to recover in the next financial year.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Sam Goi ups Envictus stake; more companies conduct buybacks

site_title: Gold prices subdued as resilient dollar dampens appeal
summary: Gold prices fell 0.1% to $1,717.38 per ounce amid a strong US dollar, which pressured the metal's appeal. The value of the US gold reserves dropped to $107.49 billion in August, down from $109.84 billion in July. Investors remain cautious ahead of the European Central Bank's rate action later in the day, further dampening gold prices.

images.alt_text: Gold imports by India, the world’s second-biggest bullion consumer, halved in August from year-ago levels, as volatile local prices and a weak rupee prompted consumers to postpone purchases.

site_title: UK recruiters say hiring slow, pay growth weakest in over a year
summary: UK recruiters report a slow hiring pace, with permanent hiring growing only slightly and temporary hiring at its weakest pace in over a year. Pay growth for permanent staff increased at its slowest pace in over a year, with a 17-month low in July. The Recruitment and Employment Confederation attributes the slowdown to candidates playing it safe and a tightening market. The UK economy's labor market is being closely watched by the BoE as it considers interest rate hikes to combat inflation above 10%.

images.alt_text: Britain, like many Western economies, saw a surge in house prices during the Covid-19 pandemic as people sought more spacious accommodation as they spent more time at home.
London was among the strongest regions for sales, with prices in the capital jumping 8.8 per cent from a year ago, the most in 6 years.
New orders showed the weakest growth since June 2020 and concerns about the construction sector and the wider economy hit confidence.

site_title: Michael Kors, Armani watches part of haul seized for Watches.com subsidiary
summary: Watches.com's indirect subsidiary, CKLY Trading Limited, had 500 watches, valued at S$30,000, seized by Hong Kong Customs and Excise Department for suspicion of being fake. The watches were from Michael Kors and Armani, with an estimated market value of HK$600,000 (S$107,477). Watches.com claims the watches are genuine, providing invoices and supporting documents to a Hong Kong legal team to dispute the seizure and investigation. Shares of Watches.com and Incredible Holdings, the parent company, dropped 8.3% and flat, respectively, following the news.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Nio reported a wider second quarter net loss of 2.7 billion yuan (S$545 million) from 659.3 million yuan the year before.

site_title: US to start economic talks with 13 nations to counter China
summary: The US is hosting the first gathering of 13 Asian nations on the Indo-Pacific Economic Framework for Prosperity (IPEF), a counter to China's rising influence in the region. The framework, launched in May, aims to promote economic cooperation and address issues like climate change, supply chains, and infrastructure. Although the US has secured $370 billion for green energy development, specific actions on the framework's four pillars are still being worked out. The meeting comes amid deteriorating relations with China, following House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan, and may face opposition from within the US party.

images.alt_text: American families have been struggling with inflation at its fastest pace in more than four decades, exacerbated by supply chain woes, Covid lockdowns in China and surging petrol prices due to Russia’s war in Ukraine.
An August survey by Fannie Mae found that respondents see a 0.4 per cent decline in housing prices compared with the prior month’s expectations for a 1.9 per cent increase.

site_title: Energy majors exaggerating green performance: analysis
summary: Energy majors BP, Chevron, ExxonMobil, Shell, and TotalEnergies are exaggerating their green credentials through public messaging while investing mostly in oil and gas projects, according to an analysis by InfluenceMap. The companies made 60% of public communications with green claims, but only 12% of new investments went towards low-carbon activities. This "significant misalignment" could delay decarbonization and exacerbate climate change, campaigners warn.

images.alt_text: The analysis by market researcher Morningstar Inc shows that 23 per cent of funds that claim to “promote” sustainability under European regulations don’t live up to environmental, social or governance investing principles.
Bonds that combine features of green and sustainability-linked debt structures could help to address concerns about greenwashing.
The rules are intended to help India, the world’s third-largest polluter, cut emissions and meet a target of net zero emissions by 2070.
Ben Van Beurden, CEO of Shell, has steered the company through some of its most turbulent times.
Shell will still be able to meet its commitments to supply customers with LNG regardless of its participation in the project.

site_title: Singapore companies make beeline for reopened Vietnam
summary: Singapore companies are flocking to Vietnam, taking advantage of the country's growing economy and favorable business environment. Following the reopening of international borders, over 5 Singapore companies participated in the Global Innovation Alliance (GIA) accelerator program in Vietnam, with 3 startups setting up a presence in the country. The GIA program provides support for overseas setup, business matching, and market promotion. Vietnam's economy is expected to grow 7.5% in 2022, driven by a growing middle class and low operating costs. The country's pro-business government has encouraged foreign investment, making it an attractive destination for Singapore companies.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Nio, Frasers Property, Chip Eng Seng, KOP, Don Agro, Watches.com
summary: Nio reported a wider second-quarter net loss of 2.7 billion yuan (S$545 million), despite higher revenue, due to increased costs. Frasers Property sold 75% of its Sky Eden@Bedok units on the first day, while Chip Eng Seng's non-executive chairman considers a possible transaction. KOP Limited faces a material uncertainty about its ability to continue as a going concern, and Don Agro achieved a record wheat harvest. Watches.com clarified the value of seized goods from Michael Kors and Armani brands.

site_title: Digital consultancy pilots train and hire programme for non tech savvy locals
summary: Temus, a digital consultancy firm, is piloting a "hire, place and train" tech programme in Singapore called Step IT Up, benefiting approximately 400 non-tech locals. The programme, running until 2025, offers full training sponsorship, financial stipend, and a full-time job. Applicants with no prior coding training are given priority. The initiative is part of Temus' expansion from its US-based programme, which has seen 87% of graduates secure digital jobs at leading global companies. Applications close on Oct 24, with training sessions starting on Nov 28.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
The Step IT Up programme by digital consultancy firm Temus is expected to benefit about 400 Singaporeans and permanent residents from non-tech backgrounds.

site_title: DeFi projects look to replenish treasuries after crypto collapse
summary: Aave Companies, the main developer behind the biggest DeFi lending project, is seeking $16.28 million from its DAO to replenish its treasury after the crypto collapse. This is the first time the development team has asked for money from the DAO, citing rising development costs and a need for experienced builders to be fairly compensated. Other DeFi projects, such as Lido DAO and Uniswap, are also facing liquidity crunches, with their treasuries experiencing significant drops in value. The crisis highlights the challenges faced by DeFi projects in managing their assets during the bear market.

images.alt_text: Crypto lender Vauld has received a 3 month extension on its moratorium from the Singapore courts as its creditors called for the platform to allow withdrawals

site_title: Don Agro reports 23.2% growth in wheat harvest to record high
summary: Don Agro, a Russia-based agriculture company, has reported a record high of 89,107 tonnes of winter wheat harvest in 2022, a 23.2% increase from the previous year. This is the company's highest harvest to date, with 75,321 tonnes produced in the Rostov region, followed by 13,786 tonnes in the Volgograd region. The winter wheat yield in the Rostov region was 3.75 tonnes, exceeding the average rate of other companies in the area by 0.4 tonnes.

site_title: Japan’s second quarter growth beats initial estimate
summary: Japan's economy expanded 3.5% in the second quarter, beating initial estimates of 2.9%, according to revised figures from the Cabinet Office. The recovery pace picked up after the winter wave of the virus and business spending rose 2% after a stronger increase last week. Analysts expect the recovery to continue, but the pace may slow due to a record virus wave and rising costs of living. The government has kept the economy free of virus-related restrictions, but inflation remains a concern, with Prime Minister Fumio Kishida set to announce price relief measures.

images.alt_text: While sounding concern about “one-sided moves” in the currency, chief cabinet secretary Hirokazu Matsuno told reporters the currency weakness could have merits as border controls ease.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng’s Celine Tang considering possible transaction involving shares
summary: Chip Eng Seng's chairman Celine Tang is considering a possible transaction involving the company's shares. There is no certainty that the transaction will materialize. Tang, who also serves as group managing director of SingHaiyi and non-executive chairman of OKH Global, became Chip Eng Seng's chairman in 2018 after becoming its largest shareholder. The company recently reported a sharp increase in net profit for the 6 months ended June 2022, with a net profit of S$38.5 million.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: First aerial delivery drone granted design approval by FAA
summary: The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) granted design approval to Matternet's Model M2, a 4-rotor drone capable of carrying a 1.8-kilogramme package, marking a major step forward for the remote delivery industry. The approval, known as a type certificate, is the first granted for an unpiloted vehicle since drones began widespread use. The drone, designed for safe and reliable package delivery, has a top speed of 72 km/h and a maximum altitude of 400 feet. This approval paves the way for the technology to mature and eventually become widespread.

images.alt_text: Amazon customers in the Northern California town of Lockeford will be able to sign up for free delivery by “Prime Air” drones.

site_title: Vertex-backed Taranis raises US$40m in Series D funding
summary: Precision-farming startup Taranis has raised US$40 million in Series D funding, led by Inven Capital. The new round brings Taranis' total funding to US$100 million, which will be used for expansion, growth, and investment in technologies. Founded in 2015, Taranis uses aerial surveillance and machine learning to prevent crop-yield loss, leveraging a large crop data set. CEO Bar Veinstein said the funding will accelerate the company's 3-year plan, expanding operations and delivering transformative technology faster.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: Small dinosaur fit for the living room to be sold at Paris auction
summary: A small dinosaur skeleton, estimated to be over 150 million years old, will be sold at a Paris auction on October 20. The 1.3-meter-high, 3-meter-long iguanodon skeleton was discovered in Colorado in 2019 and has been restored by Italian palaeontologists. The estimated price range is between €400,000 and €500,000, significantly lower than larger dinosaur skeletons sold at previous auctions. Auctioneer Alexandre Giquello described the skeleton as "a dinosaur for a living room."

site_title: For this top DBS banker, a firm belief in learning by doing
summary: DBS Bank's group head of institutional banking, Tan Su Shan, emphasizes the need for companies to adapt to the digital age, citing the COVID-19 pandemic as a catalyst for change. The bank has digitized its services, enabling small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to access collateral-free loans and digital payment solutions. Tan foresees a future where cash is no longer the mainstay, with DBS and other banks promoting digitalization and online transactions. The bank is investing in training and hiring skilled talent to meet the growing demand for digital services, with a focus on industry-specific expertise and partnerships.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
Grab riders and taxi drivers in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam. Consumer digital services will be one of the major growth drivers for Asean in the post-Covid future.
Lee Quane, Regional Director for Asia, ECA International.

site_title: Queen calls off meeting after ‘full day’ appointing UK’s new PM Truss
summary: Queen Elizabeth II has postponed a meeting of her Privy Council advisory group after doctors advised her to rest due to "episodic mobility problems". The 96-year-old monarch, currently on her summer retreat at Balmoral in Scotland, had appointed Liz Truss as the UK's new prime minister on Tuesday. The meeting, which would have seen Truss take an oath and new cabinet ministers sworn in, has been rearranged. The queen's health concerns have been raised after she cut back on public engagements since last October and was seen looking frail while shaking hands with Truss at Balmoral.

images.alt_text: BOE governor Andrew Bailey, speaking to Parliament’s Treasury Committee, welcomed Truss’ impending announcement of her plans this week.

Liz Truss, UK prime minister, delivers her first speech as premier outside 10 Downing Street in London, UK, on Tuesday, Sept. 6, 2022.  The new Cabinet she has assembled is one of the least experienced in modern times.
Truss underlined her tax-cutting ambitions and warned that Britain could not “tax our way to growth.”

site_title: UK surveyors expect weakest home sales since at least 2012: RICS
summary: UK surveyors predict the weakest home sales since 2012, with a 12-month sales decline expected, according to the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS). This is attributed to recession fears and rising interest rates, leading to a 45-point drop in sales expectations. New buyer enquiries have also plummeted, with the biggest decline since April 2020. House prices are expected to level off, with prices still 10% higher than last year. The RICS survey balance for sales expectations has fallen to -45, its lowest reading since 2012.

images.alt_text: London was among the strongest regions for sales, with prices in the capital jumping 8.8 per cent from a year ago, the most in 6 years.

site_title: US consumers see home prices falling for first time since 2020
summary: US consumers expect home prices to fall for the first time in 2 years, according to a Fannie Mae survey. Respondents anticipate a 0.4% decline in housing prices over the next 12 months, a 1.9% decrease from the prior month's expectations. Rental price growth is also expected to slow, with year-ahead expectations dropping nearly 2 percentage points. This shift in expectations could negatively affect selling sentiment and contribute to a cooling in home sales.

site_title: GameStop posts mixed results, announces partnership with FTX
summary: GameStop reported a 4% decline in net sales to $1.14 billion in the second quarter, missing analysts' estimates of $1.28 billion. The company also reported a net loss of $108.7 million, nearly doubling from the previous quarter. Despite the disappointing sales, GameStop's shares jumped 13% in extended trading after announcing a partnership with FTX US, a cryptocurrency exchange, to collaborate on e-commerce and online marketing initiatives and carry FTX gift cards in select stores.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: A GameStop Inc. store is shown in Encinitas, California, U.S., May 24, 2017. REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Europe unveils hi-tech satellite to speed up extreme weather warnings
summary: The European Space Agency and Eumetsat have unveiled a 4 billion euro satellite, MTG-I1, to provide earlier warnings of extreme weather events across Europe and Africa. The satellite, to be launched by the end of this year, will beam back images and use a "sounding" technique to scan the atmosphere, capturing storms before they become visible on traditional radar. The technology aims to give forecasters precious hours to predict near-term storms and floods, potentially saving lives.

images.alt_text: The Artemis I unmanned lunar rocket sits on the launch pad at the Kennedy Space Center on September 2, 2022. - NASA will make a second attempt to launch its powerful new Moon rocket on September 3, after scrubbing a test flight earlier in the week. The highly anticipated uncrewed mission will bring the US a step closer to returning astronauts to the Moon five decades after humans last walked on the lunar surface. (Photo by CHANDAN KHANNA / AFP)

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 falls as commodity stocks weigh; utilities outperform
summary: The Stoxx 600 index in Europe fell 0.6% on Wednesday, driven by declines in commodity stocks amid worries about a global economic slowdown. The declines were led by miners exposed to China, which dropped 2.3%, while utility stocks rose on a possible regulatory change. The benchmark Stoxx 600 index notched marginal gains in the previous session, but ultimately ended lower.

images.alt_text: London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index slid 0.8 per cent to 7,243.79 points.

site_title: Apple unveils iPhone 14 with satellite SOS, Ultra Watch for outdoors
summary: Apple unveiled the iPhone 14 with satellite SOS capabilities and an Ultra Watch designed for outdoor activities like diving and triathlons. The new devices were introduced at Apple Park in Cupertino, California. Prices for the high-end iPhone 14s remain the same as last year's models, but the cheapest option, the iPhone mini, has been dropped, increasing its price by $100. The outdoor-focused products aim to test Apple's affluent customer base's spending habits in the face of rising inflation.

images.alt_text: Apple logo is seen in this illustration taken, August 22, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration
The launch event will take place at 10.00 am ET (2.00 pm GMT) in the Williamsburg neighbourhood of New York.

site_title: Navigating Vietnam calls for flexibility and people skills, say insiders
summary: Industry watchers say companies used to a more structured and predictable way of doing business, like in Singapore, are in for a culture shock in Vietnam due to the country's vast diversity and varying hubs. Vietnam's north and south are distinct, with a third "country" in central Vietnam. Experts, such as startup adviser Nguyen Phi Van, advise navigating the market with flexibility and people skills. Vietnam's unique business environment is shaped by its vast coastline, diverse culture, and varying regional hubs.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Now that international borders have reopened, more Singapore companies are heading to Vietnam in search of business opportunities, industry watchers told The Business Times.

site_title: Oil settles below US$90 as recession fears mount
summary: Oil prices fell below $90 a barrel for the first time since February 8 as recession fears mounted, driven by downbeat Chinese trade data and concerns over European demand. Brent crude futures settled at $88 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude fell to $81.94, its lowest since January. The stronger US dollar, which rose to a 24-year peak against the yen, also pressured oil prices. Several central banks are expected to raise interest rates to combat inflation, but economists believe the US is better positioned to weather the economic storm.

images.alt_text: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and allies led by Russia, known as Opec+, decided on Monday to cut their October output target by 100,000 barrels per day (bpd).

site_title: US inflation fight to go on ‘as long as it takes:’ Federal Reserve vice-chair
summary: US Federal Reserve Vice-Chair Lael Brainard stated the central bank will continue its fight against high inflation "as long as it takes" without plans to lower interest rates. American families struggle with inflation at its fastest pace in over four decades, exacerbated by supply chain issues, Covid lockdowns in China, and surging petrol prices due to the Russia-Ukraine war. The Fed's aggressive stance aims to bring prices down, despite the economic impact on families.

images.alt_text: The influential head of the German central bank, Joachim Nagel, said the ECB needs a “strong rise in interest rates in September” following August's red-hot inflation numbers.
Markets reacted to Jerome Powell's speech on August 26 : US stocks saw sharp falls and analysts reckon more downside will persist.

site_title: US: Stocks rebound despite more hawkish Federal Reserve talk
summary: US stocks rebounded on Wednesday, with the S&P 500 rising 1.8% and the Nasdaq Composite Index advancing 2.1%, despite hawkish Federal Reserve commentary. A drop in oil prices and bargain hunting contributed to the gains. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.4%. Despite Fed Vice Chair Lael Brainard's warning that interest rates will rise further to combat inflation, the market remained upbeat. Individual stocks, including Twitter and Apple, also made gains.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.33 points at the open to 31,145.63.

site_title: UPS to hire over 100,000 seasonal workers to deal with holiday rush
summary: UPS plans to hire over 100,000 seasonal workers for the 2022 holiday rush, similar to last year's hiring. The positions are primarily for full-time and part-time drivers and package handlers. Despite a tight labor market, supply of workers appears to be improving. The move comes as both UPS and FedEx prioritize delivery of high-margin parcels to capitalize on e-commerce growth, which has declined from pandemic highs but remains a key area for the companies.

site_title: IP management critical for growing startups, say industry players
summary: Intellectual property (IP) management is crucial for growing startups, according to industry players. Origgin, a deep tech investor, evaluates startups based on their IP assets' defensibility, market potential, and research team credibility. Lazada, an e-commerce platform, prioritizes IP protection for small and medium enterprises, while One Championship, a mixed martial arts promoter, leveraged its IP to expand into new business lines. Experts emphasize that IP is not the only factor for early-stage startups, but it is essential for deep tech companies.

Second Minister for Law Edwin Tong pointed to a McKinsey study suggesting the top-growing companies in the world invest 2.6 times more in intangibles than low-growth companies.

site_title: Leveraging digitalisation and technology for growth
summary: ASEAN small and medium enterprises (SMEs) are leveraging digitalisation and technology to navigate challenges, with 66% of respondents increasing technology spending in 2021 and 50-70% looking to digitalise. The UOB SME app, launched in August, helps SMEs manage cash flow, payroll, and digital marketing processes, and aims to onboard 200,000 users. Despite optimism about economic outlook, 74% of SMEs prefer government funding schemes, with active support for digital infrastructures and funding for digital technology adoption. The study highlights the need for tripartite collaboration between banks, governments, and SMEs for growth.

site_title: Hedge fund Capstone eyes US$1.5b Asia investments
summary: US hedge fund Capstone Investment Advisors plans to allocate around $1.5 billion to Asia by 2024, marking a significant expansion into the region. The firm, which has $8.9 billion in assets, has set up a new office in Hong Kong, where it employs staff from both expatriates and local professionals. Capstone's CEO Paul Britton sees Asia as a key growth area, citing opportunities created by central banks' differing responses to inflation and economic slowdowns. The firm's investment teams employ derivatives-based strategies, aiming to profit from volatility and pricing gaps between related securities.

images.alt_text: Airline shares in Asia have advanced despite China maintaining strict Covid protocols ahead of a key Communist Party congress next month.

site_title: TE Capital, LaSalle Investment Management JV eye forward sale of new office project on Cecil Street
summary: A joint venture between TE Capital Partners and LaSalle Investment Management is considering a forward sale of the new 20-storey office project Solitaire On Cecil, valued at around S$760 million at S$4,000 per square foot. The project, set to be completed in 2026, will feature predominantly office space and include amenities such as a sky garden, gym, and rooftop lounge. The joint venture plans to sell the entire asset rather than individual units, and the project's approved gross floor area is 218,796.50 sq ft.

site_title: To protect investors, boards should expose the divergent interests of controlling shareholders
summary: The article highlights the need for boards to expose the divergent interests of controlling shareholders and minority investors. The presence of independent directors alone does not address this issue, and boards must take steps to properly address the conflict of interests. The article cites the example of Singapore Airlines (SIA), where controlling shareholder Temasek's interests may conflict with those of minority investors. The article also notes that Reit managers and boards have a similar challenge in balancing the interests of sponsor groups and unitholders. Exposing these interests and addressing them can help ensure that minority shareholders are properly informed and protected.

site_title: Trade associations, chambers critical in Forward Singapore exercise: Low Yen Ling
summary: Singapore's Minister of State for Trade and Industry, Low Yen Ling, emphasized the importance of trade associations and chambers (TACs) in the Forward Singapore exercise, a movement to review and refresh the country's social compact. TACs play a critical role in supporting their members in achieving net-zero carbon emissions and identifying emerging opportunities and challenges. The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) launched the OneTAC SG platform to strengthen partnerships within the TAC community, enabling information sharing and enhancing internal capabilities.

site_title: Russia will stop supplying energy if price caps imposed, warns Putin
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin warned that Russia will stop supplying energy if price caps are imposed, calling EU calls for a price cap on Russian gas "stupid". Putin stated that Russia would walk away from its supply contracts if the West imposes price caps on Russia's exports. EU energy ministers are set to discuss the issue, but a plan to cap Russian gas prices appears to be in doubt. The energy crisis in Europe has grown more acute after Russia's Gazprom suspended gas supplies through the Nord Stream 1 pipeline to Germany.

images.alt_text: The Russian flag flies over the Russian Central Bank headquarters in Moscow. The internal report prepared for the Russian government calls for a raft of measures to support the economy and further ease the impact of the restrictions in order to get the economy recovering to pre-war levels in 2024 and growing steadily after that.

site_title: Kim Kardashian to launch private equity firm with former Carlyle partner
summary: Kim Kardashian is launching a private equity firm, SKKY Partners, with former Carlyle partner Jay Sammons. The firm will focus on consumer and media businesses, making both control and minority investments. Kardashian, who has gained success with her shapewear label Skims and makeup brand KKW, will serve as co-founder and co-managing partner. This marks a broader shift among Hollywood celebrities investing in private equity and venture capital, following in the footsteps of Leonardo DiCaprio, Ashton Kutcher, and Gwyneth Paltrow.

site_title: Ex-SMRT CEO Desmond Kuek to leave UBS for Temasek Trust
summary: Desmond Kuek, former CEO of SMRT and current head of sustainable finance at UBS, will join Temasek Trust as its chief executive starting January 2023. Kuek, 59, paid tribute to UBS' collaborative culture and expressed his enthusiasm for advancing philanthropy as a force for good at Temasek Trust. Prior to UBS, Kuek led SMRT from 2012 to 2018, overseeing several crises and implementing measures to improve the transport operator's reliability.

site_title: Ancient skeleton reveals amputation surgery 31,000 years ago
summary: Scientists have discovered a 31,000-year-old skeleton in Indonesia's East Kalimantan province that reveals ancient amputation surgery. The well-preserved skeleton, found in a cave, shows evidence of a deliberate ankle and foot removal, with a clean break and regrowth on the leg bone. The discovery suggests that Stone Age hunter-gatherers had sophisticated medical knowledge of anatomy and wound treatment, contradicting previous assumptions that such operations only emerged in settled agricultural societies. The findings rewrite the history of ancient medicine and highlight the complexity and potential of prehistoric surgical practices.

images.alt_text: Fossil teeth of the huge extinct shark species megalodon - Otodus megalodon - are seen in this undated image. Megalodon lived nearly worldwide roughly 15-3.6 million years ago and is estimated to have reached at least 50 feet (15 metres) in length and possibly as much as 65 feet (20 metres) long.

site_title: ‘Movie business is not over,’ super agent Ari Emanuel says
summary: Ari Emanuel, co-founder of Endeavor Group Holdings, disagrees with those who think the movie business is over, citing its ability to expand and adapt. Despite the decline in ticket sales, Emanuel believes cinemas will continue to thrive, with the theatrical business remaining as important as ever. He projects operating profit of at least $1.13 billion for Endeavor this year, and notes that cinemas have survived previous challenges from broadcast TV, cable, and DVDs. Emanuel's comments come as Comscore projects the domestic movie theatre industry will end this year with revenue of $7.5 billion, down 37% from 2018's record.

site_title: Wheat prices surge as Putin assails Ukraine grain deal
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin criticized a grain deal with Ukraine, causing wheat prices to surge 6.9% as the deal is valid for 120 days. Over 2 million tons of grain have been shipped from Ukrainian ports since early August, easing global grain costs. However, Putin stated that the exports are not benefiting poorer countries, suggesting potential restrictions on the routes. The deal was brokered by Turkey and the UN, and markets remain sensitive to signals from politicians on its future.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Sierra Leone-flagged cargo ship Razoni, carrying Ukrainian grain, is seen in the Black Sea off Kilyos, near Istanbul, Turkey August 3, 2022. REUTERS/Mehmet Emin Caliskan//File Photo

site_title: Indonesia rules out aggressive policy tightening similar to Fed
summary: Indonesia's central bank governor Perry Warjiyo stated that the benchmark interest rate will rise further, but not as aggressively as the US Federal Reserve. The bank raised borrowing costs by 25 basis points last month, partly due to a recent hike in government-subsidized fuel prices. Indonesia's inflation rate is predicted to reach 6.6-6.8% for 2022, surpassing the bank's target. Warjiyo emphasized that Bank Indonesia will assess the impact of the fuel price hike on inflation and determine an appropriate policy response.

images.alt_text: University students protesting against the price of gasoline in front of the people's representative council in Banda Aceh on Monday (Sep 5).

site_title: China forex reserves fall more than expected to US$3.055 trillion in August
summary: China's foreign exchange reserves fell $49.2 billion to $3.055 trillion in August, exceeding expectations. The yuan fell 2.2% against the US dollar, while the US dollar rose 2.7% against a basket of major currencies. China's gold reserves remained unchanged, and its central bank announced plans to reduce foreign exchange reserves held by financial institutions to slow the yuan's depreciation.

site_title: From SME to ‘SGE’: Asean holds opportunities for Singapore’s global enterprises
summary: Singapore's global enterprises, or SGEs, have an opportune time to deepen their presence in Asean amid a cloudy global economic outlook. Asean economies, however, are expected to grow at 5.3% in 2022 and 5.1% in 2023, driven by manufacturing and tourism resilience. The region's middle class is projected to double to $2.2 trillion by 2030, and digital adoption is spurring opportunities for SGEs. The Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) is also expected to accelerate economic integration across Asia-Pacific, providing reduced trade barriers and improved market accessibility for SGEs.

images.alt_text: The Asean SME Transformation Study 2022 found that SMEs in Indonesia are the most optimistic, with 75 per cent expressing confidence in the economy.
Tourists outside a restaurant on Khaosan Road in Bangkok..

site_title: US: Wall St opens nearly flat as bond yields climb
summary: The US stock market opened nearly flat on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 0.33 points to 31,145.63, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite gaining 0.03% and 0.13%, respectively. Investors are pricing in aggressive moves by the Federal Reserve to suppress inflation, driving bond yields higher.

site_title: Swiber unit inks conditional agreement to sell vessel for US$8.5 million
summary: Swiber unit Quetzal Offshore has signed a conditional agreement to sell the vessel Swiber Quetzal for US$8.5 million. The 2009-built pipe-lay and accommodation work barge, registered under the Mexico flag, has a book value of US$61.7 million but an open-market value of between US$21 million and US$25 million. The sale price is based on market conditions, vessel age, and orderly liquidation value, with the proceeds to partly repay loan facilities. The sale is subject to the expiration of a financial lease agreement and shareholder approval.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Swiber enters MOU to sell its Jurong headquarters for S$30.8m

site_title: For the stock market, confidence is everything
summary: Singapore's stock market has long struggled with confidence due to various incidents, including the Noble Group's collapse and other cases of fraud and negligence. The Society of Remisiers has called for an Ombudsman Office to protect retail investors. The erosion of confidence has led to a decline in market activity and investor trust, with some blaming the lack of effective regulatory action. Stronger, swifter action is needed to restore confidence and protect investors' interests, which could involve setting up an Ombudsman and other measures to prevent similar incidents.

images.alt_text: October may have been the worst month for markets several decades ago, but it has been replaced by September.

site_title: India is going after fake, paid reviews on social media
summary: India plans to introduce regulations to curb fake and paid reviews on social media and e-commerce websites, targeting reviewers who receive compensation for endorsing products. The framework aims to hold such reviewers liable in case of product issues. With 600 million smartphones and cheap mobile data, India is grappling with a growing consumer concern about authenticity on the internet, particularly for key players like Google and YouTube. The move is seen as a response to a phenomenon that has plagued other mature internet markets in the past.

site_title: Truss rules out funding energy support with windfall tax
summary: UK Prime Minister Liz Truss ruled out funding energy support with a windfall tax on companies, instead promising to cap average annual household energy bills at or below £1,971. She announced plans to use more UK energy supplies, including oil and gas from the North Sea, and to build more nuclear power capacity. Truss also warned against taxing companies to fund support, saying Britain cannot "tax its way to growth."

images.alt_text: BOE governor Andrew Bailey, speaking to Parliament’s Treasury Committee, welcomed Truss’ impending announcement of her plans this week.

site_title: Musk can use whistleblower claims, but judge won’t delay Twitter trial
summary: A Delaware judge allowed Elon Musk to include whistleblower claims in his Twitter countersuit, but denied his request to delay the 5-day trial over his bid to back out of the $44 billion deal. Musk's team argued for a delay to investigate data security allegations against Twitter, but the judge deemed this would cause further harm to the company. The trial is now set to begin on October 17.

site_title: Departing Hong Kong residents took US$269m from pensions in Q2
summary: Departing Hong Kong residents withdrew a total of US$269.31 million from their pension accounts in the second quarter of 2022, a 0.9% increase from the previous year. The COVID-19 curbs and restrictions, which led to a net outflow of 113,200 people from Hong Kong between mid-2021 and mid-2022, are partly blamed for the trend. The Mandatory Provident Fund saw a 8,600 claims for withdrawals in the April-June quarter, up from 7,500 claims in the previous quarter.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong's brain drain worsens as expats, locals flee city

site_title: German inflation relief package to amount to 13 billion euros in 2022
summary: Germany's inflation relief package will amount to 13 billion euros in 2022, with the federal government contributing 12 billion. The package includes 6 billion euros for pensioners, 3 billion euros for energy-intensive firms, and 10.1 billion euros for inflation compensation. The 2023 package will be 42.5 billion euros, with 24.6 billion euros coming from federal coffers. The measures aim to help consumers and businesses cope with soaring energy prices, which have driven year-on-year inflation to 7.9%.

site_title: Developer Sunac China faces winding-up petition in Hong Kong
summary: A winding-up petition has been filed against Sunac China, a top 3 property developer in Hong Kong, at the Hong Kong High Court. The petition, filed by Chen Huaijun, is related to the firm's restructuring of offshore debt after missing some bond payments earlier this year. This is the first winding-up petition against Sunac. The hearing is scheduled for November 16, amid a wave of defaults in China's debt-laden property sector.

images.alt_text: UOB alleged that Shimao and the group entities breached terms of certain loan and security agreements, according to a writ in the High Court of Hong Kong dated Jul 12.

site_title: Creating value for beneficiaries and their own businesses
summary: Companies such as Certis and GEX Ventures demonstrate that strategically incorporating social responsibility into business operations can benefit both the company and its beneficiaries. Certis partners with local charities to develop inclusive programmes for the well-being of its beneficiaries, while GEX Ventures uses its business expertise to help non-profit groups. These initiatives have improved relationships with customers, boosted recruitment among younger generations, and enhanced brand image. By making "doing good" a core part of their business, these companies can create value for both their beneficiaries and their own businesses.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang
Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wrong interacting with various Champions of Good 2022.

site_title: Qatar reopens Doha airport to ease World Cup traffic
summary: Qatar is reopening Doha International Airport ahead of the 2022 World Cup, which is expected to draw over a million visitors. The airport has been in semi-retirement since 2014, when Hamad International Airport was built. Airlines such as Jazeera Airways, flydubai, SalamAir, and Pegasus Airlines will begin selling tickets to Doha airport from September 15. The move is intended to ease traffic at Hamad International Airport, which is expected to handle 150,000 people per day during the World Cup.

site_title: Labour shortages set up Malaysia for third year of palm oil losses
summary: Malaysia's palm oil industry is facing its third consecutive year of losses due to a severe labour shortage. The industry, which relies heavily on foreign workers, is struggling to maintain trees and harvest fruit bunches, resulting in thousands of tonnes of fruits going to waste. The shortage, caused by travel restrictions during the Covid-19 pandemic, has left the industry short of 120,000 workers. As a result, palm oil output is forecast to decline or remain unchanged, with plantations facing their worst labour crisis since the industry's inception in 1917.

images.alt_text: The latest data from the Indonesia Palm Oil Association showed inventory stood at 6.68 million tonnes at the end of June.

site_title: Leading without fear, Singapore Business Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: EnterpriseSG and CapitaLand Investment have launched a challenge to encourage innovative retail concepts in Singapore. The challenge aims to foster creativity and identify unique retail ideas that can enhance the shopping experience. A total of 10 winners will receive funding and support to develop their concepts. The challenge is open to individuals, small businesses, and startups. The selected concepts will be showcased at the CapitaLand Mall in Singapore, providing a platform for them to gain exposure and potentially launch their businesses. The challenge is expected to stimulate innovation in the retail sector in Singapore.

site_title: King dollar stomps on yen, sterling under heavy pressure
summary: The US dollar surged to a 24-year peak, reaching 144.99 yen, up 1.5% on Wednesday, driven by rising economic hard landing risks in Europe and a strong US economy. Sterling fell 0.7% to $1.4175, while the euro hit a 2-year low of 99 cents. The European Central Bank is expected to deliver a massive 75 bps rate hike, but this has little impact on the battered European economy. In contrast, the US services industry unexpectedly picked up, supporting the view that the economy is not in recession and giving the Fed leeway for another 75-basis-point rate rise.

images.alt_text: The central bank had also cut the reserve ratio for foreign exchange deposits for financial institutions for the second time this year on Monday to support the currency.

site_title: EU to propose price cap on Russian gas, von der Leyen says
summary: The European Commission, led by President Ursula von der Leyen, plans to propose a price cap on Russian gas to lower soaring energy costs in Europe. The proposal, aimed at reducing Russia's revenue from the war in Ukraine, will also include measures to cap the revenue of non-gas power generators and require solidarity contributions from oil and gas firms. EU countries will discuss the proposals at an emergency meeting on Friday, amid concerns from some countries about the potential impact on dwindling gas supplies.

site_title: Putin calls for review of Ukraine grain deal, accuses West of deception
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin called for a review of the UN-brokered grain deal with Ukraine, accusing the West of deception and claiming most grain exports are going to the EU, not poorer countries. Ukraine denies any breach of the agreement, while Putin threatens to restrict grain exports to the EU if the deal is not renegotiated. The agreement, which aims to ease global food prices, has been the only diplomatic breakthrough between Moscow and Kyiv since the war began in February.

images.alt_text: The cost of grains, cereals and oils has returned to levels last seen before the war began.

site_title: Chinese city to start building stalled housing projects amid mortgage boycott
summary: Chinese city Zhengzhou vows to start building stalled housing projects within 30 days by utilizing special loans, recovering misappropriated funds, and encouraging developers to file for bankruptcy. The move aims to achieve sustained construction on all suspended projects by October 6. The mortgage boycott, affecting at least 80 cities, has added to concerns about China's prolonged property market slump. Local governments have set up bailout funds to prop up the market, with Zhengzhou's fund worth 10 billion yuan. The goal is to save housing projects, not developers, according to a government notice.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 3.08 points to 1,491.35. A total of 2.365 billion lots worth RM1.617 billion were traded. Losers outnumbered gainers 477 to 348.

site_title: Waging and winning the economic war against Moscow?
summary: The G7's plan to cap the price of Russian oil on global markets has been met with skepticism, as it may not effectively reduce Russia's energy revenues or prevent funding for President Vladimir Putin's war. The plan, aimed at amplifying existing sanctions, could neutralize its impact by allowing China and India to continue purchasing Russian energy supplies at lower prices. Russia may retaliate by cutting energy supplies to Western Europe, potentially escalating an energy crisis and inflationary pressures. The effectiveness of the plan relies on the assumption that major players will act rationally, but President Putin's actions suggest he may not be an "economic man" and may instead prioritize national interests.

images.alt_text: Von der Leyen outlined the EU’s upcoming emergency proposals to lower soaring gas and power prices, which have hiked bills for households and hammered Europe’s energy-intensive industries.

site_title: TDCX sees growth in moving beyond customer service to sales , Singapore Business Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: A new book "Leading Without Fear" by former US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright emphasizes the importance of courageous leadership. Albright shares her experiences and insights from her 34-year diplomatic career, highlighting the need for leaders to be fearless and take calculated risks. She argues that fear can hold leaders back from making tough decisions, and that true leaders must be willing to challenge the status quo and face criticism. Albright's message encourages readers to adopt a more courageous approach to leadership, one that prioritizes integrity, empathy, and a willingness to take bold action.

site_title: Chinese EV maker Nio widens Q2 loss to 2.7b yuan on higher costs
summary: Chinese electric vehicle maker Nio widened its Q2 loss to 2.7 billion yuan due to higher costs, including research and development expenses. Revenue rose 21.8% to 10.3 billion yuan, with vehicle sales up 21% to 9.6 billion yuan. Despite challenges, Nio's vehicle deliveries rose 14.4% to 25,059 units, with the ES6 model accounting for 9,914 units. The company plans to start mass production and delivery of the ET5 in late September, aiming to attract a broader user base.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

The Nio ET5. The electric carmaker's annual Nio Day has become a platform for the company to unveil new models. The event generates so much buzz that Nio has come to rely on its customers to do its public relations for it.

site_title: GDS explores Singapore listing after Hong Kong, US: sources
summary: GDS Holding, a Shanghai-based data centre operator, is exploring a direct listing on the Singapore exchange, following its initial talks with potential advisers. The move comes after considering listings in the US and Hong Kong. The company has not decided whether to raise capital through the listing, with considerations still in the early stages. GDS could decide not to proceed with a listing in Singapore, according to sources familiar with the matter.

images.alt_text: institutions were net sellers of Singapore stocks for the five sessions ending Sep 1, with S$38 million of net outflows.

site_title: Xi, Putin set for first meeting since Russian invasion of Ukraine
