This follows a 1.0% drop in July. The ANZ Job Ads index reached 242,301, a 20.2% increase from the same period last year. Analysts expect the Reserve Bank of Australia to hike rates by 50 basis points to 2.35% this week, driven by the tight labor market and inflation concerns.

images.alt_text: A combination of pandemic-era stimulus and unemployment of just 3.4 per cent has unleashed a boom in household spending.

site_title: World’s first Covid vaccine you inhale is approved in China
summary: China has approved the world's first Covid-19 vaccine that is inhaled, developed by CanSino Biologics. The inhaled version, called Ad5-nCoV, stimulates cellular immunity and mucosal immunity, providing protection without intramuscular injection. CanSino's original one-shot Covid vaccine was first tested in humans in March 2020 and has been used in several countries, including China, Mexico, and Hungary. The approval of the inhaled version has boosted CanSino's shares by up to 14.5% in Hong Kong.

site_title: Era of through-the-roof house prices in Australia set to end
summary: Australia's housing market is expected to decline sharply this year and next due to rising mortgage rates and cost of living pressures. According to a Reuters poll, average home prices are forecast to fall 6.5% this year and 9.0% next year. The Reserve Bank of Australia has already lifted interest rates by 175 basis points and is expected to hike again, leading to a steep increase in mortgage rates. Experts say a substantial correction is needed to return housing affordability and prices to fair levels, with some predicting prices may need to fall by 10-35% to make housing affordable.

images.alt_text: A combination of pandemic-era stimulus and unemployment of just 3.4 per cent has unleashed a boom in household spending.
The average home in Australia’s major cities took 31 days to sell in August, while sellers may also factor in a contract settlement time of about 6 weeks.

site_title: ‘Squid Game’ grabs early Emmy awards, setting up drama battle
summary: Squid Game won its first Emmy awards, taking home an acting honor and three other trophies, ahead of the main ceremony next week. Lee Yoo Mi won the Outstanding Guest Actress in a Drama Series award for her role in the Netflix series. This marks the first non-English language series to be nominated for the top drama prize, competing against Stranger Things and Succession.

images.alt_text:
LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIA - SEPTEMBER 04: Lee Yoo-mi, winner of the Outstanding Guest Actress in a Drama Series award for Squid Game, attends the 2022 Creative Arts Emmys at Microsoft Theater on September 04, 2022 in Los Angeles, California.   Amy Sussman/Getty Images/AFP
== FOR NEWSPAPERS, INTERNET, TELCOS & TELEVISION USE ONLY ==

site_title: Heavy China platinum imports spur shortages elsewhere, WPIC says
summary: China's large platinum imports in the first half of the year, totaling 1.44 million ounces, have led to shortages elsewhere, despite a reported surplus of 349,000 ounces in the second quarter. Lease rates for platinum peaked at around 10% in May, higher than the pandemic peak, due to untracked imports and declining supply. The market's tightness was exacerbated by low platinum prices, which have shed 13% this year, and increased demand for the metal in catalytic converters and jewellery. Total supply is forecast to decline 8% this year.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was unchanged at US$1,611.48 per ounce, as of 1.48 am GMT.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as US jobs offset by recession fears
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Monday as a US jobs report showed moderating employment growth, easing pressure on the Federal Reserve to sharply lift interest rates. However, growing fears about an energy crisis in Europe, Chinese Covid lockdowns, and geopolitical tensions offset the positive news. European markets surged, while Hong Kong fell, with tech firms hit by reports of US limits on investments in Chinese firms. The news has raised concerns about a prolonged recession in Europe, which may slow down the European Central Bank's rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Tokyo, Hong Kong, Sydney, Wellington and Taipei fell, while Shanghai, Seoul, Manila and Jakarta edged up on Friday.

site_title: Elite apartments in Korea's posh Gangnam district are falling after rate hikes
summary: South Korea's luxury real estate market, particularly in Gangnam, is experiencing a decline in apartment prices for the fourth consecutive week, signaling the impact of the central bank's policy tightening cycle. The district, known for its wealth and status, saw a 20.9% rise in property values last year, but prices have now fallen about 5% compared to the same period last year, with some apartments declining by as much as 20%. The cooling momentum coincides with global economic concerns and rising interest rates, leading to concerns about a prolonged downturn in the luxury market.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians walk across a road in the Gangnam district of Seoul on August 12, 2022.

site_title: Procurement startup Eezee raises US$7.5m in Series A round led by Ayala
summary: Eezee, a Singapore-based digital procurement platform, has raised US$7.5 million in Series A funding led by Ayala Corporate Technology Innovation Venture Fund. The funding will be used to grow the team, expand market share, and develop new product features. Eezee's platform has seen a 90% acceleration in procurement processes for its customers, and the company plans to double its headcount and expand into new markets, including Indonesia, Malaysia, and the Philippines.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Philippine conglomerate Ayala to take 20.2% stake in Yoma Strategic
B2B marketplace network Proxtera expands its reach

site_title: Bukalapak, Standard Chartered launch digital banking service in Indonesia
summary: Bukalapak, an Indonesian e-commerce company, has partnered with Standard Chartered to launch BukaTabungan, a digital banking service targeting the underbanked segment. The service, set to be available within Bukalapak's platform, allows users to open accounts in 5 minutes with no administrative fees, up to 20 free transfers and cash withdrawals, and higher interest rates on savings. The move aims to serve Bukalapak's 110 million users and 20 million business owners, leveraging Standard Chartered's nexus technology and banking-as-a-service solution.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Bukalapak said that revenue for the 3 months ended Jun 30, 2022 rose 105 per cent on year to 903 billion rupiah (S$83.6 million).
INDONESIAN e-commerce company Bukalapak posted an 86 per cent rise in revenue on year to 788 billion rupiah (S$75.4 million) for its first quarter ended Mar 31, 2022.

site_title: Chip downturn to fuel more Taiwan dollar losses as exports slow
summary: The Taiwan dollar is expected to face further losses due to slowing export growth, a resurgent US dollar, and declining tech shipments. The currency has fallen almost 10% against the greenback this year, underperforming most Asian peers. A weakening trade outlook, with a possible 10.5% slowdown in August's exports, and a decline in purchasing managers index to its lowest since May 2020, are also contributing to the downward trend.

images.alt_text: Taiwan, a global hub for chip production and a key supplier to Apple, is one of Asia’s leading exporters of technology goods.

site_title: Schooling, Noble and financial market regulation
summary: Singapore's approach to regulating markets and tackling drug abuse holds lessons for financial regulators. The case of Olympic swimmer Joseph Schooling, who confessed to consuming cannabis, and fellow national swimmer Amanda Lim, who was found with a cannabis grinder, highlights the importance of swift action. In contrast, the investigation into Noble Group, which resulted in a $12.6 million fine, shows that regulators should target the wrongdoers and impose penalties that compensate investors. A tougher approach is needed to maintain investor confidence and ensure accurate market disclosures.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul
Lim was issued a stern warning by CNB under the Misuse of Drugs Act while Schooling has been referred to the Ministry of Defence (Mindef) to assess and take the appropriate measures.
Noble and its subsidiary were discovered to have applied an incorrect accounting treatment to long-term marketing agreements by classifying them as financial instruments instead of service contracts.

site_title: South Korea pledges pre-emptive action to stabilise markets
summary: South Korea's Finance Minister Choo Kyung-ho has pledged pre-emptive action to stabilize local financial markets, citing external factors as the main cause of increased volatility. The US Federal Reserve's policy tightening and slowing economies have led to a decline in the won, bond, and stock prices. Despite this, South Korea's economic fundamentals remain strong, with a current account balance in surplus. The meeting of top economic officials will discuss possible actions to mitigate market volatility.

site_title: Grab rival Be Group gets US$60m loan for Vietnam expansion
summary: Vietnamese ride-hailing startup Be Group has secured a loan facility of at least $60 million from Deutsche Bank to expand its services, including ride-hailing, food deliveries, and digital banking. The loan, which can increase to $100 million, aims to challenge Grab Holdings in Vietnam's growing ride-hailing market, forecast to grow at a 28% compounded annual rate over the next 5 years. Be Group's CEO, Vu Hoang Yen, plans to use the funds to enhance primary services and compete with companies like Indonesia's Go-Jek and FastGo Vietnam.

site_title: Indonesia finally raised fuel prices. What comes next?
summary: Indonesia has raised fuel prices by over 30% to curb soaring subsidies, with President Joko Widodo citing the move as the "last option" available for his administration. The fuel price hike is expected to worsen food and energy inflation, potentially forcing the central bank to impose more rate hikes and slow economic growth. The move is expected to squeeze the finances of lower and middle-income households, who are already dealing with rising inflation. Protests are anticipated, with tens of thousands of workers set to demonstrate in Jakarta on Tuesday, amid concerns that the fuel price increase will diminish purchasing power at a time when wages are stagnant and inflation is soaring.

images.alt_text: The price of Pertalite, the most commonly used petrol, will increase more than 30 per cent to 10,000 rupiah (S$0.94) a litre.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 0.2% or 7.43 points to 3213.12. Local banks traded mixed, with DBS and UOB gaining 0.4% each, while OCBC fell 0.3%. The global markets followed mixed signals, with US stocks ending the week with losses and European stocks rising 2% after easing concerns over a more aggressive Federal Reserve stance.

images.alt_text: The thinking among Wall Street traders is that a hawkish-at-all-costs Federal Reserve is increasingly determined to engineer tighter financial conditions – via lower stock prices and higher bond yields still – in order to combat raging inflation.

site_title: Credit Suisse court spat with billionaire kicks off in Singapore
summary: Credit Suisse is set to face a trial in Singapore, where billionaire Bidzina Ivanishvili is seeking damages of up to $800 million, alleging negligence by the bank's local subsidiary that cost him hundreds of millions. Ivanishvili, a former Georgian prime minister, had previously won a $600 million damages award in a related case in Bermuda, which is now being appealed. The trial comes as Credit Suisse faces reputational hits and restructuring challenges, and its CEO and chairman seek to resolve ongoing legal disputes.

images.alt_text: The Swiss bank is struggling to retain talent as it battles weak staff morale with its share price at record lows and a looming revamp of mainly its investment bank.
Credit Suisse Group is shifting resources to win business from a broader range of rich clients, as the lender focuses more heavily on wealth management amid cuts to its troubled investment bank.
Other reports have said that up to 4,000 jobs could be cut, including a significant part at Credit Suisse's headquarters in Zurich.

site_title: China’s BYD jumps to No 2 in global electric-car battery market
summary: China's BYD surpassed LG Energy Solution to become the second-largest electric-car battery supplier in the world, supplying 6.4 gigawatt-hours in July. Contemporary Amperex Technology (CATL) remains the market leader with 34.7% market share. Global battery sales rose 80% in July, reaching 39.7 gigawatt-hours, as demand for clean cars surges in China. BYD's market share jumped to 12.6%, while LG Energy Solution fell to third with 14.2%. The surge in battery sales is attributed to China's growing demand for electric vehicles.

images.alt_text: Berkshire has begun shedding BYD stock, dragging down the company’s shares as traders feared an exit by its most notable backer.
BYD shares plunged as much as 13% in Hong Kong early Wednesday.

site_title: Worsening energy shock to weigh on euro, test ECB on rates
summary: The European Central Bank is expected to raise interest rates by 75 basis points as soon as Thursday to combat the intensifying energy crunch in Europe, caused by Russia's halt of gas supplies through a key pipeline. The euro dropped 0.5% to 99.04 US cents, its weakest since 2002, as energy prices rise and businesses and households prepare for a cold and difficult winter. The ECB's decision will test its ability to manage the economy amid the energy shock.

images.alt_text: The ECB unveiled a tool in July to address potential trouble on bond markets as more highly indebted euro-area members get used to rising borrowing costs.

site_title: Surge in digital adoption not slowing: Telenor
summary: A survey of over 8,000 mobile internet users in 8 South and Southeast Asian countries found that nearly all respondents believe digital access is crucial for a greener lifestyle, with 93% citing improved quality of life. Women in Thailand and Indonesia reported the highest percentage of improved quality of life. Financial inclusion was a key area where mobile usage leveled the playing field, with 92% of respondents saying it increased access to financial services. Despite this, disparities persisted between urban and rural areas, and South Asian markets showed less conviction in the benefits of digital adoption.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan
Removing barriers to the unbanked and accelerating financial inclusion in Asean
The opportunity is huge, for SMEs in Asia Pacific to employ immersive data, and the metaverse, to create new relationships with prospective customers.
Asia tech opportunities abound

site_title: Leading Singapore entities raise concerns about draft global accounting rules on sustainability, climate
summary: Singaporean entities have expressed concerns over the draft global accounting rules on sustainability and climate, citing issues with harmonisation, comparability, usability, and understanding. Despite overall support for the ISSB's proposals, respondents highlighted inconsistencies with existing international standards, differing reporting boundaries, and the need for guidance on applicability and implementation. Many recommended a phased-in approach, flexibility, and consideration of different jurisdictions' readiness levels to facilitate compliance. The ISSB is expected to release the new disclosure standards under the IFRS framework by the end of the year, with implementation and compliance likely to be a complex undertaking.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah
Getting the ISSB's expected global standards on sustainability and climate disclosures to reflect local realities will be a complex undertaking.

Tan Boon Gin, chief executive of the Singapore Exchange Regulation  said that greenwashing is the “biggest threat” when it comes to the market having accurate climate information to drive decision making
Corporate ESG disclosures have come a long way, but do they serve their intended purpose of informing the market of how well companies are managing such issues? / AFP PHOTO / ROSLAN RAHMAN
Emissions from an oil refinery in Melbourne. Corporates have boosted their environmental disclosures, including carbon emission and reduction targets.

site_title: Japan’s services sector shrinks for first time in five months in August: PMI
summary: Japan's services sector contracted for the first time in five months in August, with the au Jibun Bank Japan Services PMI dropping to 49.5, a seasonally adjusted reading. The contraction was driven by a resurgence of Covid-19 infections, which hurt demand. The figure is worse than a slight expansion in July, and a 50.3 reading in July separates contraction from expansion. The recovery of Japan's economy remains fragile, with average cost burdens for services firms expanding at a marked pace due to hikes in energy and raw material costs.

images.alt_text: Revised real GDP data is expected to show the world’s third-largest economy grew at an annualised 2.9 per cent rate in the second quarter, according to the poll of 19 economists.

Kishida has made a top priority of addressing the impact of rising energy, food and raw materials prices on businesses and consumers, instructing his government last month to draw up new policy measures.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Metis Energy
summary: Metis Energy, a renewable energy infrastructure company, has entered into a sale and purchase agreement with Kaiyi Investment to sell shares in Manhattan Property Development for US$45.7 million. As part of the deal, Kaiyi must pay a deposit of US$5 million in cash to Metis Energy within 2 months. This development may impact trading of Metis Energy's securities.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This file photo taken on October 4, 2021 shows the solar farm of Marcoussis, south of Paris, inaugurated by French energy group Engie and the Sigeif (Syndicat Intercommunal pour le gaz et l'electricite en Ile-de-France). - With two photovoltaic farms and a third planned in their town, residents of Bessens (Tarn-et-Garonne), south-western France, are mobilizing to avoid becoming "the capital of the solar panel", believing that they have already contributed enough to the ecological transition. (Photo by Eric PIERMONT / AFP)

site_title: A new structure is just the first step in tackling today’s media challenges
summary: The Business Times (BT) has introduced a new organisational structure, prioritizing audience strategy and product development alongside quality journalism. The new structure, which took effect in April, features three pillars: Content, Audience, and Product, with dedicated leaders for each. The changes aim to enhance the digital product, improve audience engagement, and retain talent. The new CMS allows for a unified workflow, enabling journalists to create and publish content across platforms seamlessly. The reorganisation reflects similar structures at other digital-focused media businesses, and the journey towards a digital-driven newsroom is ongoing.

images.alt_text: Wong Wei Kong
Making change work is harder than change itself
Being a trusted news source is not enough. So what makes journalism worth paying for?
Retaining talent in the newsroom goes beyond attractive pay and hours, to creating an environment that nurtures passion for journalism.

site_title: Shenzhen to adopt tiered Covid-19 measures; Chengdu extends lockdown
summary: China's southern tech hub Shenzhen will adopt tiered Covid-19 measures starting Monday, including mass testing and restrictions. Meanwhile, Chengdu will extend its lockdown curbs for most of the city until further notice. The measures come as the country grapples with fresh outbreaks, with Shenzhen going into a weekend lockdown on Saturday.

images.alt_text: The lockdown will last at least 4 days, throttling an economy that makes up 1.7 per cent of China’s gross domestic product.
Tourism players are enhancing and reviewing their offerings to diversify their tourist source markets, experts said.

site_title: Markets scream warning over new UK prime minister’s mammoth task
summary: The UK's new prime minister faces a daunting task as the country's economy struggles. The pound has plummeted nearly 15% this year, its worst performance since the 2016 Brexit vote, while borrowing costs have surged and domestic stocks underperformed. Inflation is expected to spiral further out of control, with rising energy costs and a decline in household spending. Strategists warn that the new prime minister, likely to be Liz Truss, may exacerbate the economic woes with heavy borrowing to fund tax cuts.

images.alt_text: The governing Conservative Party is widely expected to name Liz Truss its new leader, and Britain’s new prime minister, on Monday.
The new British prime minister will face a bleak economic picture.

site_title: Building family-friendly workplaces with empathy and flexibility
summary: Singaporean companies are adopting family-friendly initiatives to improve staff welfare and productivity. Employers such as Klook, Kim Choo Kueh Chang, and Greenpac Singapore have introduced flexible work arrangements, including staggered start times, work-from-home options, and part-time working arrangements for disabled staff. These initiatives have led to increased employee motivation and productivity, as well as improved work-life balance. SMEs are encouraged to explore government grants and consider their individual needs and priorities when implementing family-friendly initiatives, striking a balance between business needs and employee welfare.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh

Companies need to have better ways to onboard new workers and get them involved in corporate culture. They also need to ensure improved promotion prospects for purely remote workers and the ability to go completely remotely from one firm to another.
Building the hybrid human-digital workforce of the future
Organisations need to approach hybrid work with clear policies and the right technology.

site_title: India August trade gap narrows on easing commodity prices
summary: India's trade deficit narrowed to $28.6 billion in August from a record high of $30 billion in July, driven by easing global commodity prices. Imports rose 37% to $61.68 billion, while exports decreased 1.15% to $33 billion. The decline in commodity prices lowered import costs, aiding the government's efforts to curb gold purchases and reduce inflows. This narrowing gap is attributed to the impact of hawkish central banks' actions on global market fears over rising interest rates.

site_title: EU to discuss radical energy interventions as crisis worsens
summary: European Union ministers will discuss radical energy measures to combat soaring energy costs, including gas-price caps and suspending power derivatives trading, amid the deepening crisis caused by Russia's squeeze on gas. The Czech Republic, holding the EU presidency, has proposed a list of emergency intervention options, including temporary capping of gas prices, to address the crisis threatening to become an economic, social, and financial crisis. The measures aim to avoid increasing gas consumption and jeopardize efforts to cut gas demand while being consistent with the bloc's climate goals.

images.alt_text: Russia’s Gazprom has made a last-minute decision not to turn the crucial Nord Stream pipeline back on after maintenance.

site_title: Taiwan’s ProLogium seeks European site for US$8b battery plant
summary: Taiwanese battery maker ProLogium Technology has shortlisted four European countries - France, Germany, Poland, and the UK - for an $8 billion solid-state lithium battery plant with a capacity of 120 gigawatt hours. The plant, expected to employ thousands, will be built over the next decade. ProLogium has appointed a consulting firm to find a location for the plant, which aims to supply electric vehicles. The move aims to capitalize on the growing demand for electric vehicles and solid-state lithium batteries.

images.alt_text: The Biden administration said in mid-August that about 20 models still qualify for tax credits of up to US$7,500, which includes Nissan’s battery electric vehicle Leaf.
People walk past a booth of BYD's subsidiary FinDreams Battery, at the 2022 World Robot Conference in Beijing, China August 18, 2022. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang

site_title: More German troops begin arriving in Lithuania
summary: Germany has begun deploying more troops to Lithuania, bolstering NATO's eastern flank following Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Around 100 German soldiers arrived in the port city of Klaipeda on September 4, 2022, as part of a new brigade command unit. The troops will remain permanently in Lithuania, while combat units will join them for exercises. This move comes after Germany pledged to deploy more troops in June, with Chancellor Olaf Scholz stating his country was ready to deploy troops to Lithuania towards a robust combat brigade.

images.alt_text: Flags of EU and Ukraine at European Square in Kyiv, June 2022. Are cracks beginning to show in the European wall of support for Ukraine in the war?

site_title: Indian anti-money laundering agency searches Paytm, Razorpay
summary: India's Enforcement Directorate searched the premises of online payment companies Razorpay, Cashfree Payments, and Paytm Payment Services as part of a probe into a Chinese loan app. The agency alleged extortion and harassment of customers involving the Chinese app, which was found to be controlled by Chinese persons. The investigation revealed that the companies had forged documents of Indians to make them "dummy directors" of the companies generating proceeds of crime. The agency seized 170 million rupees (S$3 million) and the companies cooperated with the investigation, stating they were independent and not affiliated with Paytm.

images.alt_text: The Justice Department’s money laundering section asked Binance to voluntarily hand over messages from Zhao (above) and 12 other executives and partners on matters including the exchange’s detection of illegal transactions and recruitment of US customers.

site_title: Australia set for fourth half-point hike in race to cool prices
summary: Australia's central bank is set to raise its overnight cash rate target by a half-percentage point to 2.35% at its upcoming meeting, its fourth consecutive move of that size. The decision aims to curb inflation, which has doubled the Reserve Bank's 2-3% target and is expected to peak at 8% late this year. Despite a housing market downturn, policymakers believe consumer demand will help the economy absorb the interest-rate increases, with household spending expected to continue fueling the expansion.

images.alt_text: The increase aims to alleviate Australian firms’ difficulties in securing employees in a red-hot economy where the jobs market is the tightest in almost half a century.
The average home in Australia’s major cities took 31 days to sell in August, while sellers may also factor in a contract settlement time of about 6 weeks.

site_title: Meetings in the metaverse: The future of work
summary: Companies like Accenture, Walmart, and Bank of America are increasingly using virtual reality (VR) for onboarding and training, with 60,000 Oculus VR headsets purchased by Accenture to facilitate immersive experiences. The metaverse, a virtual world, is being explored as a hybrid work model, with Regus surveying company leaders and office workers, finding 65% believe their company will adopt metaverse work. Key benefits include improved communication, teamwork, and creativity. However, concerns remain about accessibility, bandwidth, and comfort with VR technology, with many workers preferring to spend time in a virtual world rather than reality.

images.alt_text: Engineering and product teams from Meta and Qualcomm will work together to produce the chips, which will be powered by Qualcomm’s Snapdragon platforms, they said in a statement.
A spokesman for Facebook-owner Meta confirmed the departure of vice president Vivek Sharma and said his team would report directly to Vishal Shah, vice president of Metaverse.
Ng Wee Wei, Accenture country managing director in Singapore, will not pursue technology just because it is the latest shiny toy. Technology must solve a client’s problem and make an impact.
Interactions among avatars in the metaverse could result in breaches of the law, as in the real world.
Now, as employers recalibrate their hiring needs and labour budgets amid growing concerns of a recession, that hype has come face to face with a sobering, and fully non-virtual, reality.

site_title: Revving exports to US keeps India in race to become next China
summary: India's exports to the US have surged, reaching $157 billion in the first 4 months of the fiscal year, with a significant increase in low-cost, labor-intensive sectors such as apparel and handicrafts. The country has broken into the top 5 suppliers of Christmas decorative items and t-shirts to the US, surpassing the Philippines. Analysts see this as a promising start for India's growth, with the country projected to have the world's most abundant labor force by 2030, contributing over $500 billion to the global economy.

images.alt_text: Global commodity prices have fallen from their peak seen earlier this year as hawkish central banks stir up market fears over rising rates.

site_title: SGX Cares launches financial literacy workshops for Lion City Sailors footballers
summary: SGX Cares, the Singapore Exchange's outreach initiative, partnered with Lion City Sailors football club to launch financial literacy workshops for the team's players. The workshops, led by SGX Academy trainer Chua I-Min, covered financial planning and investing basics. Players, including Singapore national team captain Hariss Harun, attended the first session, citing the importance of financial literacy for their future careers and personal lives. The workshops aim to equip players with the knowledge to manage their finances and invest wisely, preparing them for life beyond football.

images.alt_text: The initiative is part of Deliveroo’s global community-focused campaign, Full Life, which aims to utilise its network of riders, restaurants and grocers to support communities in cities where Deliveroo operates.

site_title: A-Sonic Aerospace looks to grow logistics business post watch-list exit
summary: A-Sonic Aerospace, the first company to exit the Singapore Exchange Watch-List in 2022, has reported a 25.3% increase in profit to US$4.1 million for the first half of 2022, driven by its logistics segment. The company is now focusing on growing its logistics business, despite a weaker outlook due to rising fuel prices. CEO Janet Tan aims to maintain costs and acquire more customers to offset the decline. A-Sonic's shares have gained 42.7% this year, making the company undervalued on several measures, with a market capitalization of S$60.5 million.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Singtel group enterprise chief executive Bill Chang believes the company will need to digitalise and scale its operations to make up for pressure on margins.
Yangzijiang Financial Holding  executive chairman Ren Yuanlin.

site_title: Trying to sell your old Peloton bike? So is Peloton
summary: Peloton, a fitness company, is facing a slump in sales and is attempting to sell its used bikes to "value-minded" customers. The company, which experienced rapid growth during the pandemic, now sees many customers returning to gyms and busy schedules, resulting in unused bikes. Peloton has launched a certified pre-owned bike program, allowing customers to buy second-hand bikes through the company, in an effort to cut costs and reach new customers. However, the company faces stiff competition from a crowded third-party market, where used bikes are being sold for significantly lower prices.

images.alt_text: Peloton has also been struggling to boost membership, adding just about 200,000 customers who paid a monthly fee to access classes in the reported quarter.
Peloton has also been struggling to boost membership, adding just about 200,000 customers who paid a monthly fee to access classes in the reported quarter.
The young kings of Silicon Valley are dismounting their unicorns and signalling the end of an era.
Peloton said to draw takeover interest after share plunge

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.31% or 85.23 points at 27,565.61. The decline followed worsening sentiment on Wall Street after Russia announced it would keep a key gas pipeline to Germany offline. The broader Topix index also slipped 0.29% or 5.65 points. The early trade follows a global market trend of falls on Wall Street, with the US stock market also experiencing declines.

images.alt_text: epa10144766 A pedestrian walks past a display showing closing information of the Nikkei Stock Average (L) and New York Dow in Tokyo, Japan, 29 August 2022. The Tokyo stock benchmark plunged 762.42 points, or 2.66 percent, to close at 27,878.96 after the Wall Street fell more than 1,000 points on last weekend.  EPA-EFE/KIMIMASA MAYAMA

site_title: Tough financial conditions belie a ripe venture debt market
summary: Venture debt firms in South-east Asia are seeing an uptick in demand for their services despite a tighter funding environment and macroeconomic headwinds. Key players such as Genesis Alternative Ventures and Innoven Capital are tracking quarter-on-quarter growth in venture debt requests, with Innoven Capital seeing companies incorporate venture debt into their capital raising rounds. Venture debt providers focus on startups with strong business fundamentals, growth potential, and favorable valuations, offering a less dilutive alternative to venture capital. As investors preach financial prudence, venture debt providers see opportunities to provide capital to growth-stage startups.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Temasek-backed Innoven to manage external capital with launch of South-east Asia, India funds
The founders of Genesis Alternative Ventures from L-R:  Martin Tang, Ben J Benjamin, Jeremy Loh and Eddy Ng.

site_title: Metis Energy enters sale and purchase agreement to sell remaining shares in Manhattan Property Development
summary: Renewable energy company Metis Energy has entered into a sale and purchase agreement to sell its remaining shares in Manhattan Property Development (MPDPL) to Kaiyi Investment for US$45.7 million. The proceeds will be used to fund Metis Energy's renewable energy business. The company had previously held a 30.2% stake in MPDPL, which will be sold to Kaiyi, an investment holding firm. The sale is part of Metis Energy's strategy to diversify into renewable energy and exit its investment in MPDPL, which has been delayed due to onshore project financing issues in China.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Solar power panels

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Investing in cars - worth it or lemons from the start (Ep 126)
summary: A recent podcast episode discusses the viability of investing in cars, particularly rare and collectible ones. Despite indices reaching all-time highs, the value of cars can be volatile and may not be a reliable hedge against inflation. To maintain value, investors should focus on mint condition cars and avoid driving them, which can depreciate their value. The conversation also highlights trends in the space, such as modern classics gaining popularity. The episode aims to provide general information, but listeners are advised to consult professionals for independent advice.

images.alt_text: Is art investing the best way to hedge against inflation given its stable returns and immunity to current market conditions? Correspondent Howie Lim finds out.
How the mass affluent can get bespoke financial advice which won't cost an arm and a leg.

site_title: America’s midterm magic to support stocks in US and Singapore
summary: US President Joe Biden's low approval rating (44%) suggests Republicans will gain control of the House, creating gridlock that is bullish for stocks. This is a reliable pattern in midterm elections, with US stocks averaging 6.3% gains in the final quarter and 6.6% and 5.5% gains in the following quarters. Developed markets, including Singapore's, benefit from America's midterm magic due to their strong correlation (0.60). Historically, Singapore's stocks have surged alongside America's in midterm years, with positive returns in 77% of quarters.

images.alt_text: Putin is threatening to halt gas shipments to Poland (pictured), but Poland's contract expires at year-end anyway.
A stronger USD makes American exports relatively more expensive, but also lowers some costs for companies sourcing supplies overseas.
The current bear market is being driven by falling valuations among growth stocks. These will rebound first when the bull market returns.

site_title: Are insurance endowments losing their shine?
summary: Insurance endowments may have lost their competitive edge in Singapore's savings landscape due to higher interest rates making lower-risk options more attractive. Non-par endowments with short tenors, typically 3 years or less, offer comparable returns to fixed deposits and Singapore Savings Bonds, but inflation remains a risk. Guarantees on non-par endowments mask the portfolio's true volatility, and insurers may reduce bonuses in poor years. Par endowments, which offer partially guaranteed returns, are less attractive with quotes for 10-year endowments relatively unattractive, especially at lower illustrative return rates.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua
Singapore Savings Bonds
Gleneagles Hospital operating theatre. Private hospital healthcare inflation is much higher than overall healthcare inflation.

site_title: Japan PM says govt panel on inflation and wages to meet Friday
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida announced that a government panel tasked with addressing inflation and wage issues will meet on Friday to consider additional policy measures. Kishida emphasized the need to review and raise subsidies for regional revitalization to effectively respond to rising prices. He also acknowledged the importance of offering support tailored to local communities' needs. The move comes as Kishida has made addressing the impact of rising energy, food, and raw materials prices a top priority.

site_title: New global sustainability disclosure standards won’t bring quick local relief
summary: The International Sustainability Standards Board (ISSB) has released draft global sustainability and climate-related disclosure standards, aiming to provide a comprehensive global baseline for investors to make informed decisions. However, implementation will be complex, requiring local authorities to assess and adapt the standards to their respective markets. Singapore companies, in particular, will need to navigate the journey from draft standards to on-the-ground implementation, with the Accounting Standards Council and Singapore Exchange suggesting a phased approach due to varying maturity levels in reporting systems. The ISSB's standards will not override existing international reporting frameworks, but will instead sit alongside them, creating a need for further coordination and harmonization.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

Leading Singapore organisations have raised concerns about aspects of draft sustainability- and climate-related disclosure standards by the global accounting body International Sustainability Standards Board.

Over US$3 trillion has flowed into investments specifically touting their environmental, social and governance (ESG) credentials reported under scores of voluntary disclosures, stoking regulatory concerns about greenwashing.
Corporate ESG disclosures have come a long way, but do they serve their intended purpose of informing the market of how well companies are managing such issues? / AFP PHOTO / ROSLAN RAHMAN
Emissions from an oil refinery in Melbourne. Corporates have boosted their environmental disclosures, including carbon emission and reduction targets.

site_title: S&P 500 faces increased volatility due to Fed signals, US midterm polls
summary: The S&P 500 is facing increased volatility due to the Federal Reserve's signals and US midterm polls. Following a 18% relief rally, Fed Chairman Jerome Powell's "Don't fight the Fed" address at the Jackson Hole Symposium hinted at maintaining a restrictive policy stance and hiking interest rates to tame inflation. This has led to a bearish crossover signal on the MACD technical indicator, and the S&P 500 Volatility Index is pointing to an upside in volatility. Historically, September is the weakest month for the S&P 500, with a 1% loss since 1928, and midterm election years have higher market volatility.

site_title: Hong Kong health chief dismisses assertions of debate over when to end hotel quarantine
summary: Hong Kong's Health Secretary Lo Chung-mau has dismissed assertions of a debate over ending hotel quarantine, citing common goals among the government in fighting Covid-19. Lo stated that the government's policy is based on 5 principles, including controlling infection numbers and balancing health risks with economic needs. This comes after a Bloomberg report suggested Hong Kong aimed to lift hotel quarantine in November, citing differing opinions among health officials, including Lo. Lo reiterated that there is no disagreement within the administration regarding the approach.

images.alt_text: The plan is for travellers to first isolate in Hong Kong and then enter China quarantine-free.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Capesize market struggles due to weak demand for iron ore, with prices diving as vessels compete for cargo. The Transatlantic C8 bottomed out at $944, while the Pacific C5 and C10 indices showed improvement, but the market remains far from resuscitated. Scrubber-fitted vessels continue to trade as normal, benefiting from high and low sulphur bunker spreads. The market's volatility is attributed to speculation on the route's potential low, with trading levels still above operating expense levels.

images.alt_text: An undated photo of a VLCC (Very Large Crude Carrier) manufactured by the Universal Shipbuilding Corporation sailing off the coast of Japan. Source: Universal Shipbuilding Corporation via Bloomberg News.

site_title: Money transfer firms replace banks in crisis-hit Lebanon
summary: Lebanon's banking sector is widely despised and avoided, prompting a shift towards money transfer agencies offering various services, including currency exchange, credit cards, and tax payments. This trend is driven by banks' actions, such as barring depositors from accessing their savings, stopping loan offerings, and closing branches. Citizens, like Elias Skaff, now prefer money transfer companies due to the perceived lack of trust in traditional lenders, citing the risk of "dying 100 times before cashing" their money.

images.alt_text: Russia-Ukraine fallout starts felling fragile 'frontier' economies

site_title: UK PM favourite Truss promises immediate action on energy
summary: UK PM favourite Liz Truss promises immediate action on energy bills and increasing energy supplies if appointed prime minister. She will tackle rising energy costs and industrial unrest in her first week in power. Truss, expected to replace Boris Johnson, aims to spur economic growth and fix the country's long list of issues, amid a forecasted long recession and double-digit inflation.

images.alt_text: Conservative leadership candidate Liz Truss arrives at Broadcasting House ahead of her appearance on BBC's Sunday with Laura Kuenssberg show in London, Britain September 4, 2022. REUTERS/Phil Noble

site_title: Hi-tech toilet maker sees US growth after Covid ‘paper panic’
summary: Japan's largest toilet maker, Toto, reports significant growth in US sales after the COVID-19 pandemic-induced "paper panic." Sales of the company's Washlet device more than doubled in the first quarter of 2020 and jumped 18% in the first quarter of 2022. Despite the pandemic's impact, Toto sees a bright outlook for further growth in the US, with potential in Taiwan, Vietnam, and other Southeast Asian nations. The company's brand image and marketing efforts will be crucial in maintaining sales.

images.alt_text: Most of Shenzhen’s nearly 18 million population is now under Covid controls amid the city’s most serious outbreak since spring.

site_title: Pofma correction direction to be issued to The Alternative View for implying HDB profits from Ang Mo Kio BTO flats
summary: The Alternative View's Facebook post was issued a correction direction by the Protection from Online Falsehoods and Manipulation Act (Pofma) for implying that the Housing and Development Board (HDB) would profit from the sale of Build-To-Order (BTO) flats at Central Weave @ Ang Mo Kio. The post contained a misleading statement that HDB would reap a profit from the sale of the flats, contrary to the HDB's statement that it would not profit from the sale.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
HDB said most home buyers will be able to afford the flats on offer through its August BTO exercise.

site_title: Enough of quiet quitting: It’s time to talk about quiet firing
summary: Quiet firing, a phenomenon where employers intentionally or unintentionally discourage employees from staying by neglecting their growth and well-being, has gained attention. Experts define quiet firing as a strategy to get people to quit without firing them, often due to managers' lack of investment in employees or unclear expectations. Examples include denying raises, blocking opportunities, and neglecting feedback. Human resources managers emphasize the importance of clear communication, support, and investment in employees to prevent quiet firing, which can lead to low morale, engagement, and performance.

images.alt_text: On-the-job stress rose from 38 per cent of those polled in 2019 to 43 per cent the following year as Covid-19 upended the world of work, Gallup found. Women in the United States and Canada faced the most pressure.
Rachel Bentley, a 31-year-old from Austin recently boomeranged back to her former employment with Duo.
R

site_title: UK’s slumping local stocks reflect headache facing new leader
summary: The UK's local stocks have slumped, with the mid-cap index down 20% this year, as investor pessimism grows over the economy. The pound has also plummeted, near its lowest since 1985, making local companies face rising costs. A recession may stretch into 2024, and the new prime minister, Liz Truss, faces a policy headache due to proposed tax cuts being seen as inflationary. Investors are particularly cautious on homebuilders, utilities, and retailers, with some expecting a plunge in housing demand and lower prices.

images.alt_text: UK GDP grew just 1 per cent in cash terms in the second quarter and, after adjusting for inflation, shrank 0.1 per cent.
British Foreign Secretary Liz Truss is expected to be named the new Conservative party leader, and UK prime minister, on Monday Sep5.

site_title: Germany agrees 65b euro inflation relief package
summary: Germany's government agreed on a 65 billion euro inflation relief package to ease pressure on households as Russian gas supplies dwindle and energy bills soar. The package includes a one-off payment of 300 euros to pensioners and 200 euros to students, as well as heating cost payments for those receiving housing benefits. This is the third relief package, following two previous packages totaling 30 billion euros, and aims to mitigate the impact of high energy prices on citizens and businesses.

images.alt_text: Russia’s Gazprom has made a last-minute decision not to turn the crucial Nord Stream pipeline back on after maintenance.

site_title: Gen Z’s dreams of TikTok fame may be closer than you think
summary: Alicia Chia, a 26-year-old former TikTok employee, achieved virality with her silly content on the platform, amassing over 200 million views and 326,000 followers in just four months. Chia's success is attributed to her consistency, understanding of what viewers want to see, and diversifying her efforts across multiple social media platforms. She advises aspiring creators to focus on their community, create content that resonates with them, and start creating content to attract brands and marketers. Chia's journey serves as an example that with persistence and the right strategy, anyone can achieve success in content creation, even if they don't have a large following.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
A TikTok account run by Starbucks Workers United, the group of employees aiming to unionise the world’s largest coffee chain, has taken off this month with several viral posts.
While TikTok has banned paid political ads since 2019, campaign strategists have skirted the ban by paying influencers to promote political issues.

site_title: Traders find haven from global stock gloom in South-east Asia
summary: Global investors are flocking to South-east Asia's stock markets as the region's growth outlook and low tech weighting make it an attractive haven in a rising global interest-rate environment. The Indonesia Stock Exchange has outperformed the broader MSCI Asia-Pacific Index, with the benchmark MSCI Asean Index poised to outperform global stocks for a third straight quarter. The region's booming domestic demand, commodity exports, and reopening are driving the bullish sentiment, with Man Group, BNP Paribas, and Credit Suisse among those touting the region's resilience.

images.alt_text: Tourism players are enhancing and reviewing their offerings to diversify their tourist source markets, experts said.

site_title: Opec+ faces output dilemma as darkening economy unsettles market
summary: Opec+ is expected to maintain production steady when it meets on Monday, despite concerns about a global economic slowdown and potential supply disruptions. The group faces uncertainty, including a widening range of scenarios, conflicting data points on demand and recession, and supply uncertainties from Libya to Iraq. Recent price fluctuations have prompted Saudi Arabia's Prince Abdulaziz to consider output cuts, but Opec+ delegates say all options remain on the table, and cutting production could be a politically sensitive move. The meeting comes as China's economic slowdown and US recession concerns weigh on the market, while a potential deal with Iran could add 1 million barrels a day to world markets.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A 3D printed oil pump jack is seen in front of displayed OPEC logo in this illustration picture, April 14, 2020. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic//File Photo/File Photo

site_title: A volcano erupted without warning. Now, scientists know why
summary: Scientists have identified why a volcano erupted without warning in 2021, killing at least 31 people and injuring 750 others. The Nyiragongo volcano, in the Congo, had magma intrude below its flank, but instead of erupting, it waited, allowing the flank to weaken and eventually break apart, releasing the magma. The study found that traditional monitoring methods failed to detect any precursory signals, highlighting the limitations of current volcanic monitoring techniques and the need for improved technological wizardry to forecast future eruptions.

images.alt_text: Television footage showed lava and dark plumes of ash exploding from Sakurajima in Kagoshima.
Motorists maneuvering next to a damaged building following an earthquake in Bangued, Abra province, Philippines, July 27, 2022.
The blast from Bulusan volcano lasted about 17 minutes, sending a grey plume shooting up at least 1 km

site_title: Sweden, Finland to offer liquidity guarantees to energy firms
summary: Sweden and Finland plan to offer billions of dollars in liquidity guarantees to energy companies to mitigate the impact of Russia's Gazprom shutting the Nord Stream 1 gas pipeline. Sweden aims for 32 billion Swedish kronor (S$32 billion), while Finland targets 10 billion euros (S$14 billion). The guarantees will last until March next year and cover Nordic and Baltic nations for two weeks. Without these guarantees, electricity producers could have faced "technical bankruptcy." This move aims to address the rapid rise in electricity prices, which have pushed up European prices by nearly 400% over the past year.

site_title: Rolex hikes watch prices by 5% in UK as sterling slides
summary: Rolex has increased prices of its watches in the UK by an average of 5% due to the weakened British pound, now at its lowest level in over 3 decades against the US dollar. The price hikes follow a similar increase in major markets, including the US, and reflect the relative affordability of Rolex watches in the UK compared to other markets. The price of a Rolex Submariner increased to £7,500, and a GMT Master II to £9,000.

images.alt_text: Rolex Oyster Perpetual GMT-Master II watch.

site_title: Indonesia raises fuel cost to ease subsidy burden on budget
summary: Indonesia has raised fuel prices by more than 30% to ease the subsidy burden on its budget. The price of Pertalite, the most commonly used petrol, will increase to 10,000 rupiah (S$0.94) a litre, while Pertamax will rise about 20% to 14,500 rupiah. The move is aimed at balancing inflationary pressures and reallocating fuel subsidies, with over 70% of subsidies going to wealthier individuals. The government aims to return its budget deficit to within 3% of GDP by 2023, despite the fuel price hike.

images.alt_text: Motorists queue at a petrol station in Jakarta on September 3, 2022, as the government announced an increase in the price of subsidized fuel from 7,650 rupiah (0.51 USD) to 10,000 rupiah (0.67 USD). (Photo by BAY ISMOYO / AFP)

site_title: Dutch homes built on wooden piles are rotting after severe drought
summary: The Netherlands is facing a crisis as homes built on wooden piles are rotting due to severe drought, threatening to collapse within a decade. About 1 million Dutch houses, including the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam, are at risk due to retreating groundwater levels. Experts warn that a lack of qualified engineers and funding will slow remediation efforts, with estimated costs of up to 100 billion euros. The problem may not be limited to the Netherlands, with similar issues reported in parts of Sweden, Germany, and Italy.

images.alt_text: “The severe drought affecting many regions of Europe since the beginning of the year has been further expanding and worsening as of early August,” the EDO report said

From Kenya to California and nearly half of Europe, a shortage of fresh water has grabbed the attention of policymakers and given millions of citizens a fresh window into the stressed state of the planet.

site_title: CVS in advanced talks to buy Signify Health for about US$8b: source
summary: CVS Health is in advanced talks to acquire home-healthcare company Signify Health for approximately $8 billion. The deal would help improve care and reduce costs by ensuring patients receive necessary support after medical procedures, potentially preventing new hospitalizations. CVS beat out competitors including Amazon and UnitedHealth Group to secure the deal, which could be announced as early as next week. Signify, which went public in 2021, has struggled financially since its IPO and has been exploring strategic alternatives since earlier this summer.

images.alt_text: The FDA authorised Moderna’s vaccine for those aged 18 and above and Pfizer’s for those aged 12 and above to be given at least 2 months after the primary vaccination series or the most recent booster shot.

site_title: K-pop, K-drama... K-art. Frieze fair lands in Seoul
summary: The inaugural Frieze Seoul 2022 art fair marked the arrival of the prestigious event in Asia, positioning South Korea as a cultural powerhouse and art hub. The fair coincided with the country's growing art market, which has seen explosive growth since the COVID-19 pandemic. Industry experts attribute Seoul's success to its rich art scene, world-class museums, and a demographic of collectors born after 1980, who are driving the market's shift. The fair's arrival is seen as a confirmation of Seoul's sustainability as an art market hub, rather than a replacement for Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: Beyond the “Made in” tag on our clothes that tell us where they were made, most consumers know little about how their clothes were made or by whom. Many of the human and environmental aspects of apparel production remain unseen and unheard.

site_title: China extends lockdown in Chengdu, expands mass testing
summary: China extends its lockdown in Chengdu's central Jinjiang district, ordering mass testing and intensifying control measures for at least 3 days. This move aims to contain a Covid outbreak, despite the huge economic loss it has triggered. China reported 1,673 local Covid cases on Saturday, with Tibet and Sichuan provinces among the hardest hit. The lockdown in Chengdu, China's sixth-largest city, demonstrates the country's commitment to its Covid Zero approach, which has led to significant economic losses.

images.alt_text: The lockdown will last at least 4 days, throttling an economy that makes up 1.7 per cent of China’s gross domestic product.

site_title: Asean tourism pivots and recovers, but Chinese tourist gap remains
summary: Southeast Asia's tourism industry is recovering from the COVID-19 pandemic, with eased travel restrictions and diversification of tourist offerings attracting international travelers. However, the absence of Chinese tourists, a major pre-pandemic source of visitors, is limiting the pace and strength of the recovery. Countries that removed pandemic-related curbs early have seen increased bookings, with intra-Asia travel strengthening. The US remains the top source of inbound traveler demand, while Thailand and Singapore are seeing a surge in travel from the US and UK. Despite diversification efforts, the region's reliance on Chinese tourists remains a concern, with some analysts predicting it will take time for the market to fully recover.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan

site_title: Surge in real rates hits every asset on Wall Street and beyond
summary: The US Federal Reserve is tightening financial conditions by raising interest rates, fueling the worst cross-asset sell-off in decades. Inflation-adjusted Treasury yields have surged, with 5- and 10-year measures near multi-year highs, and short-dated real rates jumped to their highest since March 2020. This is expected to lead to lower stock prices and higher bond yields, which could further restrict economic activity. Experts warn of potential market chaos and a risk of further drawdowns, with Goldman Sachs projecting 10-year real yields could reach levels that would materially restrict economic growth.

images.alt_text: Even if the Federal Reserve stopped hiking rates after its September meeting, the effects of recent rate increases will continue to ripple through the economy.

site_title: Serena Williams forever changed how brands see female athletes
summary: Serena Williams' 27-year tennis career has made a lasting impact on the sports industry, inspiring brands to invest more in female athletes. Her partnerships with major brands like Nike, Gatorade, and Puma have set a new standard for sponsorship, with many companies committing to equal representation of females and males on their endorsement rosters. Williams' success has also led to changes in pay policies for pregnant athletes and the US Soccer Federation's decision to compensate male and female athletes equally. As she prepares to retire, brands are committed to continuing their support for female athletes, with some pledging to increase investment in women's sports over the next five years.

images.alt_text: The prime-time doubles match reminded tennis once again of the immense popularity of the Williams sisters and the absolute hold they have on the sport.

site_title: Europe faces energy rationing after Russian gas cut
summary: Europe is facing energy rationing due to Russia's Gazprom decision to keep the Nord Stream pipeline shut after maintenance. German storage is at 85% capacity, and even with full storage, Russia's cut would only last 2.5 months. The EU has set a voluntary 15% demand reduction target, which may become obligatory if needed. Germany has an emergency plan that includes rationing, and policymakers are bracing for the economic damage of Moscow's energy war. A mild October start to winter may help, but a cold winter could lead to gas shortages, with demand curtailments likely.

images.alt_text: Ministers and head of delegates attend the G20 Energy Transitions Ministerial Meeting as Indonesian Energy and Mineral Resources Minister Arifin Tasrif delivers a speech in Nusa Dua, Bali, Indonesia, 02 September 2022.
The ministers said they plan to implement a price cap in line with the timing of European Union sanctions on Russian oil set to kick in on Dec 5.

site_title: Want to buy a Banksy? This building comes with it
summary: A Los Angeles art deco building featuring Banksy's "Girl on a Swing" mural is set to be sold at auction, with a hoped-for price of $30 million. The building, which dates back to 1914, was purchased by Tarina Tarantino and Alfonso Campos for $4 million in 2007. As part of the building's Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing, the mural is being sold alongside the property, with appraisers estimating its value to be at least $10 million. Art experts argue that the mural's value cannot be separated from the building, and that removing it would be a loss to the public.

images.alt_text: The star of the Phillips auction on Thursday was "Moi aussi je déborde”, from 2017, by Flora Yukhnovich. It sold to an online bidder in Canada for US$2.1 million, some seven times the low estimate.
Shredded Banksy painting sells for record£18.6m

site_title: Bayer to pay US$40m to end whistle-blower claims
summary: Bayer agreed to pay US$40 million to settle US lawsuits alleging the company bribed hospitals and physicians to use its drugs, including Trasylol, Avelox, and Baycol. Former employee Laurie Simpson, who filed two whistle-blower suits, will receive about US$11 million. Bayer didn't admit liability under the settlement, which resolves allegations of unlawful actions, including paying kickbacks and downplaying safety risks.

site_title: Holiday season airfares soar on pricey fuel and revenge travel
summary: Airfares are expected to soar during the holiday season due to "revenge travel" and high jet fuel prices. The price of jet fuel has more than doubled in a year, driven by Russia's energy curbs and the war in Ukraine, leading to a shortage of fuel and increased costs for airlines. Global seat capacity is 14% below 2019 levels, and prices are likely to remain high until early 2023. Experts predict ticket prices could be 20% higher than 2019 levels, with fuel prices continuing to rise in the fourth quarter.

images.alt_text: Lufthansa said it had cancelled about 800 flights at its main bases in Frankfurt and Munich on Friday, affecting 130,000 passengers.
SAS said on Friday (Aug 19) 1,700 flights, roughly 4 per cent of the total number of flights, had been cancelled in September and October.
In total, about 130,000 passengers will be affected as Lufthansa scraps 800 flights at its 2 biggest German hubs.

site_title: US FTC wants Zuckerberg to seek approval for any future mergers
summary: The US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has asked Meta Platforms CEO Mark Zuckerberg to seek approval from the agency before engaging in any future deals, following a lawsuit over the proposed acquisition of virtual reality fitness app Supernatural. The agency is seeking a court order to force Meta and Zuckerberg to obtain FTC approval for any future mergers. A trial has been set for January 19, with the FTC continuing to pursue a case personally against Zuckerberg.

images.alt_text: Engineering and product teams from Meta and Qualcomm will work together to produce the chips, which will be powered by Qualcomm’s Snapdragon platforms, they said in a statement.
In their letter to Zuckerberg, the Republicans demand all documents since Oct 1, 2020, between any Facebook employees and the FBI referring or tied to the Post’s reporting on the Biden family.

site_title: Amazon closes, abandons plans for dozens of US warehouses
summary: Amazon has abandoned plans for dozens of US warehouses, totaling nearly 25 million square feet of usable space, as part of its efforts to reduce its sprawling delivery operation amid slowing sales growth. The move is a significant contrast to previous years when Amazon would typically open new facilities and hire thousands of workers before the holiday shopping season. Chief executive officer Andy Jassy has pledged to unwind part of the pandemic-era expansion that saddled Amazon with excess warehouse space and employees.

images.alt_text: “Amazon workers are rightly furious and they are ready to walk out,” GMB senior organiser Amanda Gearing said.

site_title: 25 companies conduct buybacks, with S$64 million combined consideration
summary: Institutions were net sellers of Singapore stocks for five sessions ending Sep 1, with S$38 million of net outflows. The Straits Times Index declined 0.8%, while the FTSE China A50 Index, Hang Seng Index, and FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI also fell. Notable institutional buyers included OCBC, Keppel Corporation, DBS, UOB, and City Developments, while Jardine Matheson Holdings, Singapore Exchange, and others led net institutional outflows.

images.alt_text: UOB logo on the facade of the UOB Plaza on 31 August 2021.

site_title: Biden weighing actions to curb US investment in China tech: sources
summary: The Biden administration is considering executive orders to restrict US investment in Chinese technology companies amid growing tensions between the US and China. The moves aim to address national security concerns, particularly regarding access to American customer data and potential threats from Chinese companies like TikTok. The Commerce Department may also place restrictions on chips used for artificial intelligence computing, and the White House is discussing legislation requiring companies to disclose potential investments in Chinese industries.

images.alt_text: While TikTok has banned paid political ads since 2019, campaign strategists have skirted the ban by paying influencers to promote political issues.

An advocacy group calling itself Gen-Z for Change said it coordinated the pledge from more than 70 popular TikTok talents to stand in solidarity with Amazon workers through a “People Over Prime Pledge.”

site_title: Indian startup Skyroot Aerospace raises US$51 million, led by GIC
summary: Indian space-tech startup Skyroot Aerospace has raised $51 million in a Series B funding round led by sovereign wealth fund GIC. The investment will fund all initial developmental launches and infrastructure to meet high launch cadence requirements for satellite customers. Skyroot aims to provide best-in-class rocket launch services and affordable small satellite launches, with plans for a demonstrator launch to space this year. The funding also includes Mayank Rawat, managing director of GIC India Direct Investment Group, joining Skyroot's board.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

WSP Global is raising about C$800 million in new equity - half of it coming from Singapore sovereign wealth fund GIC, the Caisse de Depot et Placement du Quebec and Canada Pension Plan Investment Board.

site_title: S-Reits with Malaysia assets record stronger operating results
summary: Malaysia's retail sales surged 62.5% year-over-year to record levels in Q2 2022, driven by stronger domestic demand and the reopening of international borders. This growth is part of a broader economic expansion, with the country's GDP growing 8.9% year-over-year in Q2 2022. Singapore-listed S-Reits with exposure to Malaysia assets, such as Ascott Residence Trust and Starhill Global Reit, reported strong operating results, with net property income rising 70.1% year-over-year for Starhill Global Reit's Malaysia properties.

images.alt_text: A-Reit on Aug 4 said it is acquiring the Philips Apac Center in Singapore for S$104.8 million.

site_title: China’s Covid spread persists after mega-city lockdown
summary: China continues to experience elevated Covid-19 cases after a mega-city lockdown, despite a rigid "Covid-zero" policy. The country reported 1,819 new local infections on Friday in 25 provinces and municipalities, with Chengdu and Shenzhen also seeing increased cases. The lockdown in Chengdu, China's sixth-largest city, will last at least 4 days, affecting an economy that contributes 1.7% to China's GDP. The nation's north-eastern province of Heilongjiang reported 235 new cases, with Tibet seeing the most, mostly asymptomatic.

site_title: Biden administration to maintain China tariffs while review continues
summary: The US will maintain tariffs on $360 billion of Chinese imports while continuing a review of the duties imposed by former President Trump. The review, under the 1974 trade law, may take months. The decision was made despite consideration of removing some tariffs to ease inflationary pressures, which was put on hold following China's military actions near Taiwan. Companies and stakeholders expressed support for maintaining the tariffs, and the Biden administration will now proceed with the formal review process.

site_title: Qatar to allow beer sales at World Cup games 3 hours before kick-off: source
summary: Qatar will allow beer sales at World Cup games 3 hours before kick-off and for 1 hour after the final whistle, but not during the match. Budweiser, a major World Cup sponsor, will serve beer within the ticketed perimeter surrounding each stadium, not in the stands or concourse. This is the first World Cup held in a Muslim country with strict alcohol controls, presenting a unique challenge for the tournament's organizers.

images.alt_text: Hamad International Airport in Doha will see over 90 new flights landing each day. Photographer: Christopher Pike/Bloomberg

site_title: How and when to watch Nasa’s giant rocket launch to the Moon
summary: NASA's giant rocket, the Space Launch System, is set to launch on September 3, 2022, as part of the Artemis I mission to the Moon. The launch was initially halted due to a technical hiccup, but officials are hopeful that engineers have resolved the issue. The rocket will be launched at 2:17 pm Eastern time, with coverage available on NASA Television and online. The mission aims to test the rocket and Orion spacecraft, which will carry astronauts on future missions to the Moon and beyond.

images.alt_text: A major deity in ancient Greece, Artemis was a daughter of Zeus, the chief god of the Olympians, and the twin sister of Apollo, god of the sun and oracles.

site_title: Tennis: Tiger, Michelle Obama lead tributes to 'the greatest' Serena
summary: Tennis legend Serena Williams is being hailed as "the greatest" by fellow athletes and icons, including Tiger Woods, Michelle Obama, and LeBron James, as she prepares to retire from her 27-year career. Williams, a 23-time Grand Slam winner, played her final match at the US Open, where she lost to Ajla Tomljanovic. Tributes poured in from the tennis world, with many praising her impact on women's sports and inspiring future generations, including teenage star Coco Gauff, who credits Williams for her own passion for tennis.

images.alt_text: The prime-time doubles match reminded tennis once again of the immense popularity of the Williams sisters and the absolute hold they have on the sport.
Serena Williams, 40, says she’ll focus on her family and her venture capital firm after tennis.

site_title: Thai Red Bull heir still at large a decade on from fatal Ferrari crash
summary: Thai Red Bull heir Vorayuth "Boss" Yoovidhya, accused of killing a policeman and fleeing Thailand in 2013, remains at large 10 years after the fatal Ferrari crash. Despite the backlash, TCP Group, Red Bull Thailand's parent company, has distanced itself from the case, citing it as a private matter. The case has sparked criticism of the impunity enjoyed by the super-rich in Thailand, with Yoovidhya becoming a symbol of this issue. Prosecutors have yet to bring him to justice, with his whereabouts still unknown.

images.alt_text: Thailand's economy is expected to grow 3.6 per cent this year and 4.0 per cent next year, a member of the central bank’s monetary policy committee said on Wednesday (Aug 17).
A view of Bangkok's port along Chao Phraya River is photographed during sunset in Bangkok. Thailand's new Long Term Resident visa aims to attract a million wealthy foreigners over the next 5 years

site_title: Citigroup makes small cuts in mortgage workforce as housing market cools
summary: Citigroup has made small cuts in its mortgage workforce, affecting fewer than 100 positions, due to an internal streamlining of functions. The move comes as the mortgage sector downsizes amid a cooling housing market. This is the latest in a series of layoffs in the industry, with JPMorgan Chase & Co also laying off over 1,000 employees in its mortgage business. The layoffs are a response to a shift in the market, with low interest rates driving a surge in mortgage originations and refinancings between 2018 and 2020.

site_title: Reject a promotion? Why not!
summary: A woman turned down a promotion opportunity, citing she wants to earn enough to live comfortably and maintain a fulfilling life, rather than seeking higher status. This decision may not be a setback, but rather a strategic move to prioritize personal priorities and well-being. Experts agree that rejecting a promotion should be considered on a case-by-case basis, taking into account factors such as stress levels, family time, and career readiness.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang

“We might be living in a digital world now where listening to music is so accessible and convenient, but we are surely missing the thrill and excitment of exploring music through a physical medium like vinyl.," says vinyl collector Teo Chee Keong (left), with his son.

site_title: US approves US$1.1b in arms for Taiwan, angering China
summary: The US has approved a $1.1 billion arms package for Taiwan, the largest under President Joe Biden's administration. The package includes $665 million for a radar warning system, $355 million for Harpoon Block II missiles, and $85.6 million for Sidewinder missiles. The announcement comes amid heightened tensions with China, which warned the US of "counter-measures" and urged the US to "immediately revoke" the arms sales. The package needs US Congress approval, which is virtually assured.

images.alt_text: File photo of Taiwanese F-16 fighter jet flying next to a Chinese H-6 bomber (top) off the coast of Taiwan. Taiwan has repeatedly said it has responded calmly to China’s activities, and no shots have been fired between the two sides.
Based on the 1974 trade law under which the duties were imposed, USTR will move on to a formal review of whether to keep the tariffs in place, a process that could take months.

site_title: To make money in the stock market, do nothing
summary: The S&P 500 index rose 17% from mid-June to mid-August, defying predictions and ignoring market shifts. For long-term investors, doing nothing is the best approach, as the market's uncertainty and economic changes won't be resolved soon. Historically, a bear market continues until the previous bull market's peak is recaptured. The Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes aim to combat inflation, but a soft landing remains uncertain. Investors can cope by setting up a solid investing plan, using low-cost index funds, and rebalancing holdings periodically, without needing to time the market or make short-term moves.

images.alt_text: Even if the Federal Reserve stopped hiking rates after its September meeting, the effects of recent rate increases will continue to ripple through the economy.

site_title: Europe: Shares end 5-day losing streak, still down for the week
summary: Europe's stock markets rose 2% on Friday, ending a 5-day losing streak, but still down for the week due to concerns over energy prices. Investors sharply increased bets on a 75 basis point rate hike from the European Central Bank next Thursday, following hawkish comments from policymakers and a record high inflation print in August. The Stoxx 600 rose 2%, but fell 2% for the week. Key stocks rose, including Credit Suisse and Ryanair, while Philips slumped to its lowest level since 2012.

images.alt_text: London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index of major companies rose 0.4 per cent to 7,180.87 points, compared with the closing level on Thursday.

site_title: Endurance and exhilaration
summary: Chan Fook Leong, a 49-year-old executive director, reflects on his journey in endurance sports, including triathlons, mountaineering, and climbing. He began with triathlons, building endurance through long training sessions, which also benefited his studies and career. After a decade of inactivity, he revisited swimming, cycling, and running, and later explored mountaineering and climbing. Fook Leong attributes his success to consistent effort and finding new interests, stating that these activities keep him healthy and in shape for work.

images.alt_text: Before moving to Singapore, EHL Singapore Dean Luciano Lopez was a part-time referee for semi-professional football leagues in Switzerland, overseeing international friendlies that included teams from the Premier League, LaLiga, Primeira Liga, Süper Lig and the Swiss Super League.

site_title: BYD stock sale is an old-school value-investing move by Buffett
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway has started selling shares of Chinese electric vehicle maker BYD, dragging down the company's stock price. The move is seen as an old-school value-investing strategy by Buffett, who has made billions from holding the stock since 2008. Analysts believe the selling is not a reflection of concerns about BYD's business but rather Buffett's focus on intrinsic value. Berkshire has sold 3.05 million shares, reducing its stake to 18.87% from 20.04% as of August 24.

images.alt_text: People walk past a booth of BYD's subsidiary FinDreams Battery, at the 2022 World Robot Conference in Beijing, China August 18, 2022. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang
BYD shares plunged as much as 13% in Hong Kong early Wednesday.

site_title: Bitcoin attempts to break range while testing highs of the week
summary: Bitcoin rose 1.5% to $20,376, breaking its tight trading range of $19,500-$20,700, as investors debated the implications of rising borrowing rates on riskier assets. Other cryptocurrencies also advanced, with an index of 100 largest digital tokens adding over 3%. The coin remains down over 50% this year, with investors focusing on protection and hedging, and awaiting the potential implications of the US$19,000 area breaking.

images.alt_text: A consolidation among Bitcoin miners may have contributed to the rising computing power.

site_title: US: Stocks fall again as hiring slows
summary: US stocks fell for the third straight week, ending with losses on Friday. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 1.1% to 31,318.44, while the S&P 500 fell 1.1% to 3,924.26.
