The decline followed a cautious sentiment after Fed Chair Jerome Powell's speech, which indicated the central bank will act "forcefully" to cool the economy. The jobs report showed 315,000 new hires in August, lower than July's 526,000, but in line with economists' expectations.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 192.08 points, or 0.61 per cent, at the open to 31,848.50.

site_title: Oil climbs ahead of Opec+ meeting on Sep 5
summary: Oil prices rose on Friday ahead of the Opec+ meeting on September 5, with Brent crude futures up 66 cents to $93.02 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures up 26 cents to $86.87 a barrel. Opec+ is expected to keep oil output quotas unchanged for October, but may consider production cuts to bolster prices. The producer group now sees demand lagging supply by 400,000 barrels per day, down from a previous forecast of 900,000.

images.alt_text: “We produce exactly as much as we have the ability to produce and sell. We have a small increase, the situation is improving as you can see. ” Russia Deputy Prime Minister Alexander Novak told reporters.
The reduced flows via Nord Stream have complicated efforts across Europe to save enough gas for winter, when governments fear that Russia could halt flows entirely.

site_title: CFMoto 800MT review: Passing the touring test
summary: The CFMoto 800MT Touring, a mid-sized adventure bike, offers a great balance of power and comfort at an affordable price. Priced at S$39,800 with COE, it undercuts rivals from BMW, Triumph, and KTM. The bike features a 799 cc twin-cylinder engine, keyless start, digital display, adjustable suspension, and rider aids like cornering ABS and a quickshifter system. The CFMoto is suitable for both on-road and off-road riding, with a comfortable saddle height and broad handlebar. It's a great option for those seeking a fun, powerful, and well-equipped bike without breaking the bank.

images.alt_text: Thanks to its station-wagon shape, the Octavia Combi RS is part family car, part pack mule.

site_title: Axington proposes acquisition of Malaysia-based firm, could lead to RTO
summary: Axington Inc has entered into a conditional sale and purchase agreement to acquire Achieva Technology, a Malaysian IT distribution company, in a potential reverse takeover. The deal is valued at S$27 million or the lower valuation ascribed to the sale shares. The acquisition aims to enable shareholders to participate in growth areas and increase market capitalization. The deal is subject to Singapore Exchange and shareholder approvals, following Axington's delisting risk due to lack of revenue-generating business.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani
Axington has inked a non-binding memorandum of understanding to acquire a 100 per cent stake in Mushan Food Industries and 3 other sister companies.
Axington may have potential claims against its former directors Marjory Loh and Michael Wong, and the Loh cousins of scandal-hit Bellagraph Nova Group (pictured).

site_title: Hard-hitting heavyweight contender Shavers dies at 78
summary: Earnie Shavers, a renowned heavyweight boxer known for his powerful punch, has died at 78. Born on August 31, 1944, in Garland, Alabama, Shavers won 74 of his 89 fights, 68 by knockout. He fought for the world title twice, losing to Muhammad Ali and Larry Holmes. Shavers' punching power was praised by Holmes, who said he could knock the hell out of it. The boxing legend passed away on Thursday, the day after his 78th birthday.

images.alt_text: The prime-time doubles match reminded tennis once again of the immense popularity of the Williams sisters and the absolute hold they have on the sport.

site_title: Europe’s top football leagues serve up a weekend feast
summary: Europe's top football leagues are set for a weekend of high-stakes matches. The English Premier League's Arsenal faces off against big-spending Manchester United, while Italian Serie A's Milan clubs face off. In Germany, Bayern Munich takes on Union Berlin, who share the same 10-point record from four games. These matchups are crucial in establishing early dominance in their respective title challenges.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
Barcelona's Robert Lewandowski (left) in action against Real Madrid when the two Spanish teams last met in July 2022 in Las Vegas.
Manchester United were thrashed 4-0 by Brentford last week, and will have to improve considerably to avoid a heavy defeat at the hands of their arch-rivals Liverpool on Monday night.
Serena Williams waved to the crowd after losing, 6-4, 6-0, to Emma Raducanu of Britain on Tuesday.

site_title: Amazon staff at UK warehouse ‘ready to strike’ over pay, says union
summary: Amazon staff at a UK warehouse are prepared to strike over pay, with over 300 workers voting 97% in favor of a walkout. The GMB union claims Amazon's starting pay of £10.50-11.45 per hour is inadequate, especially during the cost of living crisis. The company has offered a benefits package worth thousands of pounds annually. This dispute is part of a wave of industrial unrest in Britain, where rising costs of living are outpacing pay rises.

site_title: US factory orders drop in July on defence aircraft
summary: US factory orders dropped 1.0% in July, after increasing 1.8% in June, according to the Commerce Department. This decline was largely due to a decrease in defence aircraft bookings. Despite this, the manufacturing industry remains resilient, with year-over-year orders increasing 13.4%. Economists had forecast a 0.2% increase. The unexpected drop in orders may indicate a slowdown in the US economy.

site_title: US job growth solid in August; unemployment rate rises to 3.7%
summary: US employers added 315,000 jobs in August, exceeding expectations, but the unemployment rate rose to 3.7% from a pre-pandemic low of 3.5%. This solid job growth suggests the economy continues to expand despite slow GDP growth in the first half of the year. The Federal Reserve is likely to raise interest rates by 75 basis points this month, as it tightens monetary policy to quell inflation. Strong wage gains are keeping the income side of the economic growth ledger expanding, but the labour market remains resilient despite rising recession risks.

images.alt_text: The level of first-time claims, in addition to a still-low number of Americans already on unemployment benefit rolls, underscores tightness in the broader labour market.

site_title: First Zika case reported in Singapore since 2020 amid current surge in dengue cases
summary: Singapore has reported its first Zika case since March 2020, amid a surge in dengue infections this year. The case was confirmed during the week of Aug 21 to 27, with 666 dengue cases reported for that week. Zika is a virus infection transmitted by the bite of an infected Aedes mosquito, and symptoms include fever, rash, and body aches. The case is not part of an active Zika cluster, according to the National Environment Agency. This is the first Zika case since 2020, highlighting the ongoing health concerns in the country.

images.alt_text: Another case of monkeypox has been confirmed in the Republic, bringing the total number of cases detected since June to four, said the Ministry of Health on Friday (July 8).

site_title: Jackson Hole’s missed lesson
summary: Central bankers at the Jackson Hole symposium acknowledged the difficulty of fighting inflation, blaming external factors such as the pandemic and Russia's invasion of Ukraine for the surge. However, the article argues that central bankers also underestimated the impact of monetary policy and failed to normalize conditions, contributing to the current problems. The authors suggest that policymakers should recognize the demand-supply imbalance and that monetary and fiscal stimulus alone cannot buy prosperity, emphasizing the need for a more comprehensive assessment of the past decade's policies.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 64.85 points, or 0.20 per cent, at the open to 32,163.84.

site_title: G20 talks end with pledge to accelerate energy transition
summary: G20 energy talks in Bali concluded with a non-binding "Bali Compact" pledging to accelerate the transition to cleaner energy, but no binding agreement was reached due to discord over Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The compact outlines principles for achieving net zero emissions, strengthening national energy planning, and boosting investment and financing. Despite the lack of a joint communique, G20 nations sent a strong signal to the market that policymakers are taking action to strengthen the investment-enabling environment, according to Indonesian Energy Minister Arifin Tasrif.

images.alt_text: Scientists said most such extreme weather events are attributable to human-caused climate change, and will only increase in severity and frequency.

site_title: Worst China property earnings since 2008 signal more stock angst
summary: China's property developers reported their worst first-half earnings in over a decade, with total net income slumping 87% to 17.6 billion yuan (S$3.6 billion) due to a clampdown on leverage, strict Covid Zero policy, and a weakening economy. This marks the worst half year since 2008. Country Garden Holdings, the largest builder by sales, warned that the crisis has yet to bottom, with Logan Group swinging to a net loss of 540.6 million yuan. The outcome is expected to pressure stocks further, despite government efforts to stabilize the sector.

images.alt_text: Profit was 171.5 billion yuan (S$34.6 billion) in the 6 months through June, compared with 163.47 billion yuan in the same period a year earlier, ICBC said in a filing on Tuesday (Aug 30).

site_title: US: Wall Street up after August jobs report
summary: US stock indexes rose on Friday after the August jobs report showed stronger-than-expected jobs growth, but with cooling wage increases and a rise in unemployment rate easing inflation concerns. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 192.08 points, or 0.61%, to 31,848.50. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, with the S&P 500 up 27.81 points, or 0.70%, and the Nasdaq up 114.01 points, or 0.97%.

images.alt_text: A trader works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., August 29, 2022.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: UK slips behind India to become world’s sixth biggest economy
summary: The UK economy has slipped behind India to become the world's sixth-largest economy, according to the International Monetary Fund. The UK's GDP grew 1% in cash terms in the second quarter, but shrank 0.1% after adjusting for inflation. This marks the UK's decline in the international rankings, which was accelerated by India's growth. The economic data comes as the UK prepares to choose a new prime minister, with Liz Truss expected to win the Conservative Party leadership. The news is a blow to the government, which is grappling with a cost-of-living shock.

site_title: Double celebration: Two-headed tortoise Janus turns 25
summary: Janus, a 25-year-old two-headed Greek tortoise, is being celebrated at the Natural History Museum in Geneva. Born in 1997, Janus has two heads, two hearts, two lungs, and two distinct personalities. Despite being unable to survive in the wild, he thrives under the care of his team, who provide him with organic food, massages, and daily walks. Janus has undergone medical procedures, including a bladder stone operation, and requires periodic treatment to prevent head soreness. His unique characteristics often lead to conflicts between his two personalities.

images.alt_text: Animal acupuncture is centuries old in China, says veterinarian Li Wen, who founded his practice in 2016.

site_title: MOH, insurers to provide additional support with introduction of Cancer Drug List
summary: The Ministry of Health (MOH) and insurers will provide additional support to cancer patients affected by changes in financing of cancer drug treatments. Starting Sep 1, 2022, only treatments on the Cancer Drug List (CDL) will be covered by MediShield Life and MediSave. MOH will provide transitional support for patients who started treatment before Sep 1, 2022, and extend drug subsidies through the Medication Assistance Fund (MAF) to more Singapore residents. Insurers will also offer optional IP riders with non-CDL coverage starting Apr 1, 2023.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani
ISTOCKPHOTO
Gleneagles Hospital operating theatre. Private hospital healthcare inflation is much higher than overall healthcare inflation.

site_title: Philippines raises US$7.4b via first Marcos retail bond
summary: The Philippines successfully raised $7.4 billion through its first retail bond sale under President Ferdinand Marcos Jr., exceeding its target. The 420.4 billion pesos (5.75% coupon) retail bonds were sold to retail investors across Asia, accounting for 17% of the government's planned borrowings for 2022. This marks a significant milestone in the country's efforts to tap into the retail market and diversify its funding sources. The sale was notable for its high subscription rate and flexibility, allowing investors to exchange securities for the new bond.

site_title: Nikon to buy Germany’s SLM Solutions Group in 622 million euros deal
summary: Nikon is set to acquire German 3D metal printing machine maker SLM Solutions Group for 622 million euros, becoming a global leader in metal additive manufacturing. The deal values SLM Solutions at 20 euros per share, a 75% premium to its closing price. The acquisition aims to leverage SLM's technology and Nikon's manufacturing expertise to revolutionize mass production and reduce waste. The deal is expected to close in the first half of 2023 and will be supported by SLM's key shareholders and founder.

site_title: University incubators key to propelling Singapore startups in the region
summary: Singapore-based university incubators play a crucial role in propelling startups to commercial success in South-east Asia. The Singapore Management University's Business Innovations Generator incubator has helped students like Kinobi founder Benjamin Wong develop their business ideas. With over 400,000 students helped and 60 universities partnered, the incubator aims to increase the percentage of students becoming entrepreneurs from 5% to 15%. As the digital economy in South-east Asia is expected to double to $363 billion by 2025, university incubators can fine-tune strategies and test business models, enabling the next wave of tech startups in areas like edutech, fintech, and renewable energy.

site_title: Myanmar sentences Suu Kyi to more jail time for election fraud
summary: Myanmar's military court sentenced Aung San Suu Kyi to 3 more years in prison for alleged election fraud in the 2020 general elections, increasing her total jail term to 20 years. This is the fifth verdict against her since the military coup in February 2021. Deposed President Win Myint and former government office minister Min Thu were also sentenced to 3 years each. Suu Kyi's legal team plans to appeal the verdict.

images.alt_text: Myanmar’s military chief said Friday(Aug 19) the junta was open to negotiations with ousted leader Aung San Suu Kyi to end the crisis sparked by its coup after her trials in a junta-run court have concluded.

site_title: Eurozone producer price growth accelerates further
summary: Eurozone producer price growth accelerated to 37.9% in July, surpassing expectations, driven by a 97% surge in energy sector costs. This increase is likely to keep consumer prices higher for months, foreshadowing more pain for households. Consumer inflation in the euro area accelerated to 9.1% in August, with a peak forecast around 10% by year-end. Industry prices rose 15.1%, with durable goods and non-durable consumer goods increasing by 9.8% and 13.8%, respectively.

site_title: Singapore electronics PMI contracts for the first time in 2 years amid region-wide slump
summary: Singapore's electronics manufacturing sector contracted for the first time in 2 years, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) falling to 49.6 in August. The sector's PMI dropped 0.9 points, entering contraction territory for the first time since July 2020. The overall PMI also slid 0.1 point to 50, the lowest reading since June 2020. Analysts attribute the decline to slower expansion in key indices and a faster expansion in supplier deliveries. The contraction is linked to global demand softening, particularly in North Asian economies, and US efforts to curb chip exports to China.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
The final au Jibun Bank Japan Manufacturing Purchasing Managers’ Index (PMI) fell to a seasonally adjusted 51.5 in August from a final 52.1 in the prior month.
S&P Global’s final PMI for manufacturing, which accounts for about 1/5 of Germany’s economy, fell to 49.1, its lowest reading in more than 2 years, from July’s reading of 49.3.
Singapore's latest PMI readings signaled the start of the second half of the year on a slightly dour outlook for manufacturers.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore hotels reported a year-to-date overall room revenue of S$1.39 billion, surpassing the 2021 total. This marks a significant increase, with the average room rate (ARR) reaching a near-decade high in July at S$236.28. For the sixth consecutive month, Singapore hotels have seen growth in their average room rates, driven by the country's strong tourism industry.

site_title: Hong Kong: Equities close week with loss
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed the week with a 0.74% loss, shedding 145.22 points to 19,452.09 on the Hang Seng Index. Investors await US jobs data release, adding to market volatility. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index edged up 0.05% and the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.44%.

site_title: Digital banks stake out customer segments, but early returns likely limited
summary: Singapore's two digital banks, Trust Bank and GXS Bank, have launched in a competitive market, targeting different demographics. Trust Bank aims to appeal to a wide range of customers, including NTUC members, while GXS Bank focuses on the Gen Z demographic. Maribank, Sea's digital bank, may struggle to compete, but could leverage its gaming arm or Shopee customer base to gain an advantage. The market's limited size and incumbent banks' potential response to digital banks' no-fee accounts may limit their success, with profitability being a key challenge.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
GXS Bank CEO Charles Wong believes that there are segments in Singapore not well-served by banks.

Trust Bank Launch. (L-R) Kee Teck Hoon, Chairman of FairPrice Group, Deputy Chairman of NTUC Enterprise Co-operative Limited, Board of Directors at Trust Bank; Lawrence Wong, Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister;Judy Hsu, Standard Chartered's CEO of Consumer, Private and Business Banking; Dwaipayan Sadhu, CEO of Trust

site_title: G7 backs price-cap plan for Russian oil to limit revenue
summary: The Group of Seven (G7) has agreed to implement a price cap on global purchases of Russian oil, set to kick in on December 5, in line with European Union sanctions. The plan aims to limit Moscow's overall revenues and ease energy market pressures. The price cap will be set by a broad coalition of countries and will be publicly communicated. However, the effectiveness of the measure is uncertain, as some major buyers, including India, have expressed reluctance to join. Russia has vowed not to sell oil to nations that impose a price cap, and the G7 faces challenges in convincing European Union member nations to amend its sanctions package.

images.alt_text: Shell will still be able to meet its commitments to supply customers with LNG regardless of its participation in the project.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed marginally lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.77 points to 1,491.18. 2.179 billion lots worth RM1.573 billion changed hands, with losers outnumbering gainers 475 to 316. The decline follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Oil rallies ahead of Opec+ meeting
summary: Oil prices rose ahead of the Opec+ meeting on September 5, with Brent crude futures up 1.5% to $93.78 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures advancing 1.7% to $88.04. The rally comes despite concerns over China's Covid-19 curbs and a weak global economy. Opec+ expects a market deficit of 300,000 barrels per day in 2023, and the group may discuss production cuts at the meeting. A potential price cap on Russian oil exports is also on the agenda.

images.alt_text: Oil prices have declined by more than 20 per cent in the 3 months till August, prompting Opec+ to signal that it could cut supply.

site_title: Banks ready to leave pandemic behind as staff return to desks
summary: Major banks are winding down remote work efforts, stepping up efforts to bring employees back to office full-time despite the pandemic's lingering impact. The finance industry, led by major banks, has sought to end remote work plans derailed by the Omicron variant earlier this year. With the pandemic largely in the rear view, banks are easing or lifting COVID-19 protocols, signaling a shift towards a post-pandemic work environment.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A combination file photo shows Wells Fargo, Citigbank, Morgan Stanley, JPMorgan Chase, Bank of America, JPMorgan, and Goldman Sachs from Reuters archive. REUTERS/File Photo

site_title: 325 suspects being probed for allegedly scamming victims of over S$9m
summary: Singapore police have rounded up 325 suspects, aged 16-86, in a 2-week operation for allegedly scamming victims of over S$9 million. The suspects are believed to be involved in more than 695 cases, including business email compromise, e-commerce, and phishing scams. Those found guilty of cheating, money laundering, or providing payment services without a license can face up to 10 years in jail and fines ranging from S$125,000 to S$500,000. The operation aims to deter the public from being accomplices to crimes and reduce losses to scams, with S$346.5 million lost to all scams in the first half of the year.

site_title: Credit Suisse hit by key private bank resignations in Hong Kong
summary: Credit Suisse has faced two senior private banker resignations in Hong Kong amid weak staff morale and a looming overhaul. Managing director Echo Hui and team leader Jeff Tsang have left the bank, with Tsang's departure unclear. Despite rumors of a pullback from China, Credit Suisse plans to maintain its long-term presence in the country. The bank is targeting a global overhaul, including 3,200 job cuts, to slash its cost base by $1 billion.

images.alt_text: Other reports have said that up to 4,000 jobs could be cut, including a significant part at Credit Suisse's headquarters in Zurich.

site_title: EU uneasy about Truss as UK leader
summary: EU diplomats express unease about Liz Truss becoming UK leader, citing her hardline stance on Brexit and her comments about France. Truss, a former Brexit supporter, has promised to unilaterally tear up part of the UK's divorce deal with the EU, sparking concerns about a potential trade war. EU diplomats are focused on the war in Ukraine and inflation, and see no need for another Brexit battle. Truss's comments have been met with irritation and skepticism, with some EU officials questioning her ability to bring a conciliatory approach to post-Brexit issues.

images.alt_text: Liz Truss enjoys overwhelming support over Rishi Sunak in polling of the members. But the winner faces a vanishingly short political honeymoon with UK in the throes of its worst cost-of-living crisis in generations.

site_title: US dollar near 2-decade high ahead of US jobs data
summary: The US dollar index reached a fresh 20-year high of 109.99, driven by robust US data showing a fall in unemployment claims and bolstered by Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's comments on interest rate hikes. The dollar is headed for its third weekly gain and nears 2-decade highs against other major currencies, awaiting US jobs data on Friday that could fuel aggressive interest rate hikes to combat inflation.

site_title: Philippine central bank chief: Fed move ‘big factor’ in Sep policy decision
summary: Philippine central bank Governor Felipe Medalla said the US interest rate hike will be a "big factor" in the country's decision to adjust its monetary policy. The BSP expects inflation to average 5.4% this year, easing to 4.0% next year and 3.3% in 2024. The peso hit a record low, and Medalla stated that the BSP has done enough to address the currency's decline, attributing it to the US dollar's rise.

site_title: Staff at AXA Singapore cut in retrenchment exercise; more than 20 affected
summary: AXA Singapore has reportedly retrenched over 20 staff following its acquisition by HSBC earlier this year. The retrenchment exercise began on Thursday and continued into Friday, with affected employees coming from various departments, including telemarketing and legal. Those impacted were offered severance pay, with a limit of 12 months for assistant manager roles and above. The move follows a larger trend of staff departures since the acquisition, with more than 10 employees leaving the company since February.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani
HSBC's new insurance chief eyes 'crucial' new China expansion
HSBC names new chief for Singapore insurance operations

site_title: World food prices fall for 5th month in a row: UN
summary: World food prices have fallen for a fifth consecutive month, according to the Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) food price index, which declined 1.9% in August. The decline is partly due to the resumption of exports from Ukraine's Black Sea ports after Russia's invasion in March. This marks the first time food prices have fallen since the invasion, with the index having been steadily falling since its all-time high in March.

images.alt_text: Both Germany and Norway are some of the developed economies experiencing disruptions to everyday life because of labour actions.

site_title: Warren Buffett’s Berkshire offloads more shares in Chinese EV giant BYD
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway has sold another 1.72 million shares of Chinese electric vehicle maker BYD, reducing its stake to 18.87% as of September 1. The latest sale, which was the second in two weeks, comes after Buffett's stake sale sparked a 13% decline in BYD's stock price. Despite the sell-off, BYD remains a leading player in the electric vehicle market, with a 30% market share and record sales of cleaner cars. Berkshire's total shares sold in BYD now stand at 3.05 million, valued at around $80 million.

images.alt_text: BYD shares plunged as much as 13% in Hong Kong early Wednesday.

site_title: Indian property developers offer deals to lure buyers as market cools
summary: Indian property developers are offering discounted mortgages and loan payment pauses to attract buyers amid rising interest rates. Despite slowing sales, average residential prices in top eight cities have increased 5% in the second quarter from a year earlier. Developers such as Tata Housing and Lodha Group are offering lower interest rates, with some locking in rates at 6.99% until 2024, while others are offering 1-year mortgage payment pauses. These incentives coincide with the Hindu festival season, typically considered auspicious for property purchases.

images.alt_text: India’s real GDP growth increased 13.5 per cent year-on-year in the reported quarter, below the 15.2 per cent forecast by economists polled by Reuters.
Fuelled by consumption, India's GDP rose 13.5 per cent in the April-June period from a year ago.

site_title: Ex-Macau junket boss appears in court on illegal gambling, crime syndicate charges
summary: Former Macau junket boss Alvin Chau appeared in court on over 200 charges, including illegal gambling and money laundering, related to a $105 billion illegal syndicate. Chau stepped down as chairman of Suncity junket in 2021 after his arrest, and his syndicate's collapse led to the shutdown of VIP rooms and the collapse of several other junket operations. The junket industry's influence is expected to be further diluted, with Macau's government implementing new laws to limit their power. Chau and co-defendant Levo Chan have been in custody since their arrests.

images.alt_text: Under the terms of a revised gaming law released by Macau’s legislature earlier this year, a casino needs a minimum capital requirement of 5 billion patacas.

site_title: Meta, Qualcomm strike agreement on custom virtual reality chips
summary: Meta Platforms has signed an agreement with chip-maker Qualcomm to produce custom chipsets for its Quest virtual reality devices. The collaboration will be powered by Qualcomm's Snapdragon platforms, and the chips will be optimized specifically for the Quest's system specifications. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed. The agreement signals Meta's ongoing commitment to Qualcomm's technology as it develops its own custom silicon solutions for virtual, augmented, and mixed reality devices.

site_title: Operator data suggests Nord Stream 1 flows to resume Sep 3
summary: Nord Stream 1 pipeline operator data indicates gas flows should resume from September 3, after Gazprom completed maintenance work. The pipeline's capacity was reduced to 20% in July due to maintenance and sanctions, complicating Europe's efforts to save gas for winter. The resumption of flows is seen as a positive development, alleviating concerns of a potential halt in gas supplies.

site_title: Lufthansa cancels hundreds of flights as pilots strike over pay
summary: Lufthansa cancelled approximately 800 flights at its Frankfurt and Munich bases, affecting 130,000 passengers, due to a 24-hour pilots' strike over pay demands. The Vereinigung Cockpit union is seeking a 5.5% pay rise and automatic inflation compensation. Lufthansa has offered a smaller increase, citing a 40% staff cost rise and 900 million euros in annual expenses. The strike coincides with peak travel season, causing frustration among holidaymakers.

site_title: Boom turns to gloom as higher interest rates hit New Zealand housing
summary: New Zealand's house prices are forecast to decline 10% this year and 5% next year due to aggressive interest rate hikes. Despite this, prices are still far from returning to pre-pandemic levels, and experts predict a 20-30% decline is needed to make housing affordable. House prices have risen 40% since the start of the pandemic, fueling homelessness, inequality, and keeping first-time homebuyers as renters. Experts say the decline will continue and it may take until 2027 for prices to reach a more fair valued position.

images.alt_text: The Real Estate Institute’s price index slid 2.9 per cent from a year earlier, the first fall since 2011, the group said last week. The gauge has dropped for 5 consecutive months.
New Zealand's economy is running near full capacity and the central bank has been driving up borrowing costs to try to keep inflation expectations anchored.

site_title: Yuan appeal fades in Hong Kong as local rates hit 14-year high
summary: Hong Kong's monetary policy has pushed the three-month Hong Kong interbank offered rate to a 14-year high, widening the gap between the local currency and the offshore yuan. This has led to a decline in yuan-denominated deposits, with a 26% slump from January, and a drop in the offshore yuan-Hong Kong dollar currency pair to 1.13, its lowest in two years. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority's efforts to push up local rates closer to those in the US may undermine Beijing's efforts to maintain Hong Kong as a key offshore yuan centre.

images.alt_text: Yuan lost about 2.2 per cent against the US dollar in August, booking its worst monthly performance since April.

site_title: NTUC says SMSes with clickable links about OCBC card cancellation were ‘service announcement’
summary: NTUC sent SMSes to OCBC Plus! cardholders informing them that their card would be cancelled by Jan 31 due to a change in the Link Rewards loyalty program partner, Trust Bank Singapore. The NTUC SMS included a clickable link, while an OCBC SMS provided a detailed explanation but did not include a link. This discrepancy highlights a disparity in how bank partners and banks are treated regarding SMSes, with banks agreeing to remove clickable links following a warning from the Monetary Authority of Singapore.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
MAS said on Jul 18 that the development of the framework for equitable sharing of losses from scams is taking longer than expected “in view of the complexity of the issues”
MAS has slapped an additional capital requirement in response to a wave of spoofed SMS phishing incidents in Dec 2021
IMDA concludes anti-SMS spoofing registry pilot, starts onboarding process

site_title: India’s new ESG rules to address corporate greenwashing
summary: India's new ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) rules aim to curb greenwashing by requiring companies to submit detailed emissions data starting next fiscal year. The rules, mandated by the stock markets regulator, will collect data on over 120 metrics from the top 1,000 companies, starting April 1, 2023. The goal is to improve transparency and help India, the world's third-largest polluter, meet its target of net zero emissions by 2070, as part of its efforts to cut emissions.

site_title: Seoul: Shares, won fall ahead of US jobs data
summary: South Korean shares fell 2.89% for the week, marking their third consecutive loss, amid investor caution ahead of US employment data. The Kospi index ended at 2,409.41, its lowest close since July 25, while the benchmark bond yield fell. The won touched a 13-year low, and foreigners were net sellers of shares worth 173.3 billion won. The main inflation rate in South Korea slowed in August, but inflation is expected to stay elevated.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi ended down 56.44 points or 2.28 per cent at 2,415.61, its lowest closing level since Jul 27 and biggest daily fall since Jun 22.

VIP’s focus on Korean entertainment shares reflects the growing worldwide popularity of the nation’s dramas and musicians, as blockbuster hits help deliver stock price gains to companies involved in their production and distribution.

site_title: Australia: Shares close lower ahead of US payrolls report
summary: Australian shares closed lower on Friday, recording their worst week since mid-June, ahead of the US jobs report. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.3% to 6,828.7, with mining stocks plummeting 2.2% due to weaker iron ore and base metal prices. The benchmark index dropped 3.9% this week, its largest decline in 2 1/2 months, amid concerns of aggressive US rate hikes and weaker commodity prices.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.03 per cent to 6,843.8 by 0111 GMT on Friday and was on track for its biggest weekly drop since June 17.

site_title: Europe: Equities stage rebound at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rebounded on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 index rising 0.4% to 7,180.87 points, and the eurozone's DAX and CAC 40 indices adding 1.2% and 0.7% respectively. The rebound came after markets tumbled on Thursday due to concerns over inflation and interest rates. The rebound was seen as a prelude to key US jobs data later in the day, with investors looking for signs of a slowdown in the labor market.

site_title: Shooting down drone off Chinese coast was 'appropriate', says Taiwan premier
summary: Taiwan's military shot down an unidentified civilian drone that entered its airspace near an islet off China's coast, with Premier Su Tseng-chang labeling the action "the most appropriate" after repeated warnings. The incident follows China's military drills around Taiwan and complaints of harassment by drones from China flying close to Kinmen islands. China responded by calling Taiwan's move "hype up tensions," while Taiwan vowed to protect its land and people. The drone was shot down and crashed into the sea after entering restricted air space near the Lion islet.

images.alt_text: Chinese military helicopters fly past Pingtan island, one of mainland China's closest point from Taiwan, in Fujian province on August 4, 2022, ahead of massive military drills off Taiwan.

site_title: BT Market Focus: Markets poking at the Bear (Ep 10)
summary: Markets are retesting June lows, struggling to find support, as investors face uncertainty. The SGX's wrap for the week highlighted bear market rallies, safe haven assets, and investor concerns. Digital banks launched and companies to watch were also discussed. The podcast emphasizes the need for investors to seek professional advice and cautions against relying solely on the information provided.

images.alt_text: Howie Lim
How did the lack of inspiration affect markets this week?
What uncertainties are causing markets to stay cautious?

site_title: Ex-President Rajapaksa set to return to Sri Lanka ‘early on Saturday’
summary: Former Sri Lankan President Gotabaya Rajapaksa, 73, is expected to return home early on Saturday after a self-imposed exile in Thailand. He fled the country in July amid protests over the nation's economic crisis, which has led to widespread shortages and inflation. Rajapaksa's return is seen as a signal from President Ranil Wickremesinghe that he can maintain order, but rights activists plan to press for his arrest over alleged crimes, including the 2009 assassination of a prominent journalist. Rajapaksa faces multiple charges, including those in a California court and in Sri Lanka.

images.alt_text: Sri Lanka’s former president Gotabaya Rajapaksa will return to the island nation next week after fleeing in July amid mass protests, local broadcaster Newsfirst reported on Wednesday(Aug 17), citing a former ambassador.

site_title: Shell CEO prepares to step down next year
summary: Shell CEO Ben van Beurden is set to step down in 2023 after nearly a decade at the helm. The company has shortlisted candidates, including Wael Sawan, Huibert Vigeveno, Sinead Gorman, and Zoe Yujnovich, to succeed him. Van Beurden has overseen Shell's shift from fossil fuels to cleaner energy, including a plan to achieve net-zero carbon emissions by 2050. His tenure has seen significant changes, including the 2016 takeover of BG Group and the first dividend cut since World War II during the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: China has room for monetary policy adjustments: central bank
summary: China's central bank says the country has room for monetary policy adjustments due to restrained stimulus measures and controlled consumer inflation. The People's Bank of China will continue to deploy its monetary tools to support the economy and keep liquidity ample. Consumer inflation remains under control, and the central bank will closely monitor global inflation and avoid excessive stimulus. China aims to keep consumer prices stable and revive its sluggish economy, which is threatened by fresh coronavirus flare-ups and a distressed property sector.

site_title: China's Shenzhou-14 astronauts carry out spacewalk
summary: China's Shenzhou-14 astronauts successfully completed a six-hour spacewalk on Friday, marking the first spacewalk of the six-month mission. Astronauts Chen Dong and Liu Yang returned to their cabin module, declaring the spacewalk a "complete success." This follows China's recent achievements in space exploration, including landing a rover on Mars and sending probes to the Moon.

images.alt_text: A major deity in ancient Greece, Artemis was a daughter of Zeus, the chief god of the Olympians, and the twin sister of Apollo, god of the sun and oracles.

site_title: Truss will only make the UK more miserable. That could be good
summary: British Foreign Secretary Liz Truss is expected to be named the new Conservative party leader and UK prime minister on September 5. This marks the latest in a long tradition of peaceful power transfers in the UK, allowing each new leader to feel like a fresh regime. However, Truss's appointment coincides with Britain's economic and public realm in crisis, with rising energy bills, stagnant wages, and a predicted recession. The country's regions face an uncertain long-term economic strategy, with many relying on tourism and national heritage. Truss's leadership may be seen as a continuation of this downward spiral.

images.alt_text: British Foreign Secretary and Conservative leadership candidate Liz Truss leaves her house in London, Britain, July 20, 2022.

site_title: Taiwan August exports seen up for 26th straight month
summary: Taiwan's exports are expected to rise for the 26th consecutive month in August, with a 9.5% year-over-year increase, according to a Reuters poll. This growth rate is slower than the 14.2% jump in July, amid concerns of a global recession, the Ukraine conflict, and Covid-19 flare-ups in China. The trade data is seen as a gauge of world demand for tech gadgets, with Taiwan being a key supplier to Apple and a global hub for chip production.

images.alt_text: Downtown Taipei, with the Taipei 101 building in the backdrop. Export orders, a bellwether for global techology demand, fell 1.9 per cent from a year earlier to US$54.26 billion, Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs said on Monday (Aug 22). Analysts had expected 3.6 per cent growth.

site_title: Singapore hotels rake in highest average room rate in 10 years in July
summary: Singapore hotels experienced their highest average room rate in 10 years in July, with an average rate of S$259, up 69.2% from the previous year. Visitor arrivals surged to 726,601, while overall room revenue reached S$318.5 million, more than 4.5 times the level recorded in the corresponding period a year ago. Industry analysts attribute the growth to pent-up demand and rising costs, with luxury segment room rates registering the highest 13.4% month-on-month growth.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Some 726,601 tourists arrived in Singapore in July, up from the 543,733 recorded in June, though the new figure remains far below the 1.8 million recorded in July 2019 before the pandemic.

site_title: PetroChina builds major storage for new south China refinery: report
summary: PetroChina has completed a major storage tank farm for its new refinery and petrochemical complex in southern China's Guangdong province. The 3.8 million cubic meter tank farm has 2 million cubic meters for crude storage and is part of a 400,000-barrel-per-day refinery and 1.2-million-tonnes-per-year ethylene complex. The facility is expected to support the production of petrochemicals and fuels in the region.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end almost flat ahead of US jobs data
summary: Tokyo stocks ended nearly flat on Friday ahead of US jobs data, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.04% at 27,650.84. Investors remained cautious due to uncertainty surrounding the jobs report. The broader Topix index lost 0.27% at 1,930.17.

site_title: Australia: Shares flat; set for worst week in over two months on China worries
summary: Australia's shares fell 0.03% to 6,843.8, on track for their worst week in over two months, due to weakness in underlying commodity prices caused by China's fresh Covid-19 restrictions. Domestic miners and energy stocks were dragged down, with the S&P/ASX 200 index ending 2% lower on Thursday and down 3.8% for the week.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 2.1 per cent to 6,8430 points by 0030 GMT on Thursday.

site_title: Brokers’ take: DBS raises Civmec target as trading price a ‘steep discount’ relative to peers
summary: DBS Group Research raised its target price for Civmec to S$0.92, citing a "steep discount" relative to peers due to its higher earnings growth and margins. The company's FY2022 net profit exceeded consensus estimates, driven by record revenues and an improving orderbook. Analysts expect Civmec's margins to increase, despite a more modest outlook on revenue growth, driven by diversified revenue streams and expansion plans. However, a sharper-than-expected contraction in private capital expenditure poses a key risk.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Civmec’s assembly and sustainment facility at Henderson in Western Australia.

site_title: Russian banks lost 1.5 trillion roubles in first half, central bank tells RBC
summary: Russian banks incurred a combined 1.5 trillion roubles (S$34.8 billion) in losses in the first half of 2022, primarily due to foreign currency operations, according to Dmitry Tulin, Russia's central bank first deputy chairman. The largest banks accounted for the majority of losses, with a combined 1.9 trillion rouble (US$31.60 billion) loss. However, Tulin stated that there is a "more than 50 per cent chance" that full-year losses will not exceed the first-half figure. The central bank does not anticipate a repeat of the 2014-17 banking crisis.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Friday; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.3% to 3,214.13 points on Friday, reversing gains seen in previous days. The STI was down 9.95 points, with 39.2 million securities worth S$52.5 million changing hands. Gainers outweighed losers 62 to 59. The decline was attributed to local bank stocks, including DBS, UOB, and OCBC, which traded lower.

images.alt_text: Even if the Federal Reserve stopped hiking rates after its September meeting, the effects of recent rate increases will continue to ripple through the economy.

site_title: Japan’s Q2 GDP likely revised up on robust capex, outlook murky: poll
summary: Japan's Q2 GDP is likely revised up to 2.9% annualized growth, driven by solid business spending, according to a poll of 19 economists. The expected upward revision is mainly due to a 1.8% increase in capital expenditure, higher than the previously estimated 1.4%. However, the outlook for the current quarter and beyond may be murky due to another virus outbreak, raw material inflation, and a global economic slowdown. Despite these challenges, economists expect Japan's economy to continue expanding into fiscal 2023.

images.alt_text: The final au Jibun Bank Japan Manufacturing Purchasing Managers’ Index (PMI) fell to a seasonally adjusted 51.5 in August from a final 52.1 in the prior month.
A key attraction for new private equity entrants is the standout returns Tokyo’s office market has delivered so far this year.

site_title: Tennis: Williams sisters crash out of US Open doubles but Serena not done yet
summary: Serena Williams, along with her sister Venus, lost their US Open doubles match to the Czech duo of Lucie Hradecka and Linda Noskova, 7-6 (5) 6-4. This match marked the first time the Williams sisters played together in over 4 years, and it is unclear if this was their final match. Despite the loss, Serena is still competing in the singles tournament, where she will face Australia's Ajla Tomljanovic in the third round.

images.alt_text: Serena Williams, 40, says she’ll focus on her family and her venture capital firm after tennis.

site_title: China securities regulator says will implement Sino-US audit deal
summary: China will implement its audit agreement with the US, allowing US regulators to vet accounting firms in mainland China and Hong Kong, potentially ending a dispute that threatened to boot over 200 Chinese companies from US exchanges. The agreement, announced last Friday, will strengthen communication with foreign institutional investors and roll out more measures to open Chinese markets. China will also expand its Hong Kong Stock Connect scheme and put Chinese firms' offshore listings in a uniform regulatory framework. The move aims to avoid mass delisting of US-listed Chinese firms by 2024.

images.alt_text: The regulations appear to focus on chips called GPUs with the most powerful computing capabilities, a critical but niche market with only 2 meaningful players, Nvidia and AMD.

US Commerce Department had suspended the export privileges of Belgium-based Hasa-Invest and its owner Hans De Geetere for attempting to send sensitive technology to China in violation of US regulations.

site_title: Australia fines Mercedes Benz unit A$12.5m for lack of urgency on airbag recall
summary: The Federal Court of Australia has ordered Mercedes Benz's local unit to pay an A$12.5 million fine for failing to communicate the urgency of a recall for potentially deadly airbags manufactured by Takata. The Australian Competition & Consumer Commission found that Mercedes-Benz staff downplayed the risks, describing the recall as a "precaution" and implying that the airbags had not caused any accidents. The regulator called the airbags a "potentially deadly issue" and emphasized the importance of clear communication to consumers.

images.alt_text: The start of production in Tuscaloosa is part of Mercedes’ plans to produce 8 all-electric vehicles at 7 sites on 3 continents this year, it said in a news release.
Mercedes, which already sells its imported EQC sport-utility vehicle (SUV) in India, will be the first to assemble a luxury EV in the country.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Friday, rising 4.38 points or 0.29% to 1,496.33. The index saw a high volume of 213.93 million lots worth RM85.21 million, with 195 gainers outnumbering losers 195 to 109.

site_title: Financial advisers can add value during turbulent times
summary: A 2020 CFA Institute survey found Singapore retail investors' confidence in making investment decisions is lower than the global average. This lack of confidence presents an opportunity for financial advisers to provide sound advice and increase the probability of investors achieving their financial goals. If financial advisers cannot add value, retail investors may opt for low-cost index funds or DIY passive investing, which can outperform active investing over the long term. Financial advisers can help keep investors on track to achieve their goals by offering independent advice on asset allocation and strategy.

images.alt_text: Dexter Tiah

site_title: ECB still seen playing catch-up as rate-hike path steepens
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is expected to continue raising interest rates to combat record euro-zone inflation, despite a looming recession in the euro area. More than two-thirds of economists surveyed predict a higher end-point for rate hikes, with some expecting a 75 basis-point step on September 8. The ECB's actions are seen as a priority over the threat of recession, with most analysts predicting a contraction in gross domestic product for at least two quarters.

images.alt_text: “It’s also noticeable we’ve seen a bit of magnetism around this parity level for euro/US dollar, so many times these big round levels can become major sticking points.” said John Hardy head of FX strategy at Saxo Bank.

site_title: Truss on brink of power as UK Tories finish voting
summary: Liz Truss is poised to become the UK's next prime minister after Conservative party members voted overwhelmingly in her favor. Truss, the foreign secretary, has vowed tax cuts but faces a short political honeymoon amid the country's worst cost-of-living crisis in generations. With energy prices set to rise by 80% from October, Truss has promised "immediate support" to help households cope with unaffordable fuel bills. The result of the vote will be announced on Monday, and Prime Minister Boris Johnson will formally tender his resignation to Queen Elizabeth II the next day.

images.alt_text: Conservative leadership candidate Liz Truss answers questions at a hustings event, part of the Conservative party leadership campaign, in Norwich, Britain, Aug 25, 2022.
With inflation set to exceed the 13 per cent peak forecast by the Bank of England, workers will be no better off by mid-2023 than they were 20 years earlier.

UK Business Secretary Kwasi Kwarteng is working to extend so-called contracts for difference to generators to replace more lucrative subsidies in an attempt to cap profits and avoid imposing a windfall tax.

site_title: IEA says Indonesia policy reform needed for clean energy transition
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) has urged Indonesia to implement policy reforms to support a clean energy transition, aiming for net-zero emissions by 2060. Indonesia, a major carbon emitter, needs to reduce its reliance on coal and increase the share of renewable energy in its energy mix. The country currently relies on coal for 60% of its electricity, but solar projects are economically uncompetitive due to high costs. The IEA recommends transparent tariffs and predictable project pipelines to reduce costs and attract investment into renewables, with potential for 25 Gigawatts of solar and wind capacity by 2030.

images.alt_text: Indonesia’s Environment Minister Siti Nurbaya Bakar said countries must jointly arrest global warming or see the planet pushed to a point “where no future will be sustainable”.
Indonesia has tripled its subsidy budget to 502 trillion rupiah (S$47.1 billion) to keep prices of some subsidised fuels, power tariffs and liquefied petroleum gas unchanged.

site_title: Gogoro awarded LTA battery-swapping sandbox pilot, partners Jardine C&C
summary: Gogoro, a Taiwanese startup specializing in battery-swapping technology, has been awarded a sandbox pilot by Singapore's Land Transport Authority to deploy and validate battery swapping as a means for next-generation smart mobility. The company is partnering Jardine Cycle & Carriage, the exclusive distributor of Gogoro's electric scooters in Singapore, to operate and install its battery-swapping infrastructure. The pilot is expected to launch "soon" and aligns with Singapore's Green Plan 2030, aiming to transition the city-state to sustainable energy and transportation.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Temasek-backed Taiwanese startup Gogoro in merger talks with Poema SPAC: sources
Temasek-backed Taiwanese startup Gogoro in merger talks with Poema SPAC: sources

site_title: The ‘superpower’ of doing good
summary: Corporations that prioritize social responsibility are better positioned for success, thanks to a "superpower" that sets them apart in the competitive business world. The "S" element of ESG (environmental, social, and governance) encompasses a company's interactions with employees and communities, including diversity, inclusion, and community relations. Investors and analysts assess social factors based on financial risks, and companies with high social scores tend to have lower worker strikes and workplace accidents. Successful for-profits, such as Who Gives A Crap, demonstrate that doing good can lead to financial profitability.

images.alt_text: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wrong interacting with various Champions of Good 2022.
Kindness is a strength, a management tool.
Businesses need to be responsive to their stakeholders in the ESG space to remain relevant, competitive and sustainable.

site_title: Asia: Most markets down as traders focus on US jobs data
summary: Asian markets declined on Friday, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, Sydney, and Wellington falling, while Shanghai, Seoul, Manila, and Jakarta edged up. The dollar gained against other currencies due to rate hike expectations, with traders focusing on the US jobs report later in the day. Oil prices rose on fading Iran nuclear deal hopes, but were under pressure from the strengthening dollar and Covid lockdowns in China. Analysts said the US jobs data would give the Federal Reserve more room to tighten monetary policy, potentially leading to a recession.

images.alt_text: Man Group continues to hold confidence in South and South-east Asia over their northern neighbours as benchmark indexes for Indonesia, India and Singapore remain the only ones in the green in Asia this year.

site_title: Australia to welcome thousands more migrants to ease crisis
summary: Australia has raised its permanent migration ceiling to 35,000 more workers per year, aiming to alleviate labor shortages in the country's red-hot economy. The increase is expected to bring more nurses, engineers, and agricultural workers to Australia, addressing the nation's tightest jobs market in nearly half a century. The move follows a review of the country's migration system, which will investigate overhauling the system to attract skilled labor. This comes as the country seeks to recover from the labor shortages caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, with unemployment at 3.4%.

images.alt_text: The average home in Australia’s major cities took 31 days to sell in August, while sellers may also factor in a contract settlement time of about 6 weeks.
The cash rate has already risen 175 basis points to 1.85 per cent and markets are wagering on a further half-point move to 2.35 per cent at the Sept 6 policy meeting.

site_title: South Korea sees ‘betrayal’ in Biden’s electric vehicle push
summary: South Korea views the US's new Inflation Reduction Act as a "betrayal" due to its favoritism towards American-made electric vehicles and batteries, potentially disadvantageing major South Korean brands like Hyundai and Kia. The act provides up to $7,500 in tax credits for EV purchases made in North America, which could harm Hyundai's US operations. The dispute may complicate economic and security cooperation between the US and South Korea, and could also affect South Korea's participation in initiatives like the Indo-Pacific Economic Framework and the Chip 4 Alliance.

images.alt_text: Hyundai Motor had said in May that it would break ground on its new facility in Georgia in early 2023 to achieve commercial production in the first half of 2025.

“This investment is aimed at enabling Toyota to flexibly meet the needs of its various customers in all countries and regions by offering multiple powertrains and providing as many options as possible,” Toyota said in a statement.
Mercedes, which already sells its imported EQC sport-utility vehicle (SUV) in India, will be the first to assemble a luxury EV in the country.

site_title: Philippine peso slides to record, boosting case for rate hikes
summary: The Philippine peso has dropped to a record low of 56.90 per dollar, weakening 0.9% and extending its decline to 10% this year. The currency is the third worst performer in Asia in 2022, after the yen and South Korean won. The peso's slide is attributed to a widening trade deficit and increasing divergence between the Federal Reserve's hawkish stance and the Philippine central bank's slower interest-rate hikes. The central bank may slow the pace of tightening, with a possible 25 basis point increase for the rest of the year.

images.alt_text: Ferdinand Marcos Jr’ proposed budget, which is equal to 22.2 per cent of Philippines’ total economic output, is nearly 5 per cent higher than his predecessor’s spending plan for 2022.

site_title: South Korea’s inflation eases but underlying pressures persist
summary: South Korea's inflation rate slowed to 5.7% in August, the first decline in seven months, due to a drop in global crude prices. However, underlying pressures persist, with core inflation rising to 4.0% and service prices increasing 4.1%. The Bank of Korea has signaled it will continue to raise interest rates to combat inflation, despite a softer-than-expected rate hike.

images.alt_text: While the outlook for exports remains clouded, consumption has been a key support for the Korean economy as Covid regulations are loosened.
Samsung Electronics has a massive presence in South Korea, with its revenue equivalent to around 13.5 per cent of country’s gross domestic product in 2021, according to Bloomberg calculations.
The benchmark Kospi ended down 56.44 points or 2.28 per cent at 2,415.61, its lowest closing level since Jul 27 and biggest daily fall since Jun 22.

site_title: Federal Reserve ends decade-long enforcement action against HSBC
summary: The US Federal Reserve has ended a decade-long enforcement action against HSBC Holdings PLC for violating anti-money laundering rules and sanction laws. The enforcement order was terminated on August 26. The 2012 accusations against HSBC, including being a "preferred financial institution" for Mexican and Colombian drug cartels and money launderers, were the basis for the enforcement action. The Fed's decision brings an end to a long-standing issue for the bank.

images.alt_text: Founded by Temasek and HSBC, Pentagreen aims to deploy “blended finance at scale over time” to accelerate the development of sustainable infrastructure in Asia.
Investment banking revenue for UBS in China has plunged by about half and new issuance in debt and equity markets has slowed this year following sweeping policy changes in China.

site_title: Artemis - Nasa’s latest mission to the Moon is named after an ancient lunar goddess turned feminist icon
summary: NASA's Artemis mission, set to launch a rocket without a crew on a month-long journey around the Moon, aims to increase women's participation in space exploration. The mission will carry two mannequins to study the effects of radiation on women's bodies, and Nasa expects to bring the first woman and person of color to the Moon on Artemis III, possibly after 2024. The mission's name, Artemis, is inspired by the ancient Greek goddess of the Moon, known for her independence, strength, and connection to the wilderness, and has become a modern-day feminist icon.

images.alt_text: The Space Launch System has been in development for roughly a decade, slowed by a myriad of delays and cost overruns.

site_title: US job market walking a tight rope
summary: The US job market is experiencing a slowdown, with private sector jobs created in August falling to 132,000, a far cry from the expected 315,000. The unemployment rate is expected to remain at 3.5% in August, matching its July level. Despite a strong labor market, the Federal Reserve's efforts to curb inflation through interest rate hikes may lead to an employment slowdown and a rise in the unemployment rate.

images.alt_text: The level of first-time claims, in addition to a still-low number of Americans already on unemployment benefit rolls, underscores tightness in the broader labour market.
ISM said that its manufacturing PMI was at 52.8 in August, unchanged from July. A reading above 50 indicates expansion in manufacturing, which accounts for 11.9 per cent of the US economy.

site_title: Gold inches higher; set for third weekly fall as rate-hike bets mount
summary: Gold prices edged up 0.1% to $1,697.80 per ounce, but are on track for a third straight weekly decline due to rising interest rate expectations. The resilient US economy and strong dollar near recent peaks have bolstered the likelihood of the Federal Reserve keeping interest rates higher for longer, increasing the opportunity cost of holding gold as a hedge against inflation and economic uncertainties.

images.alt_text: Even though gold is seen as a hedge against inflation, higher interest rates increase the opportunity cost of holding bullion and boosts the dollar.

site_title: Hedge fund co-founder Neil Phillips charged with market manipulation
summary: Neil Phillips, co-founder of hedge fund Glen Point Capital, has been charged with conspiring to manipulate the US dollar-South African rand exchange rate in late 2017. Phillips, 52, is facing up to 20 years in prison and was arrested in Spain on a US request. The indictment describes at least two co-conspirators, raising the possibility of additional charges. Phillips previously raised nearly $2 billion from investors, including George Soros, and his arrest threatens to ripple across the hedge fund industry.

images.alt_text: The number of Alibaba shares held by the Asia-focused funds increased 311 per cent during the period, while that of Sea jumped by 110 per cent.
Equity hedge funds posted gains of 2.89 per cent, underperforming the S&P 500, which went up 9.11 per cent last month. For the year, equity hedge funds were down 9.2 per cent.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.25% at 27,731.25, driven by cautious trade ahead of US jobs data. The broader Topix index also edged up 0.10%. The move follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a surge in the S&P 500 and Nasdaq in the US, despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Global bonds tumble into their first bear market in a generation
summary: Global bonds have tumbled into their first bear market in a generation, with the Bloomberg Global Aggregate Total Return Index falling over 20% below its 2021 peak. The decline is attributed to soaring inflation and steep interest-rate hikes by policymakers, ending a 4-decade bull market in bonds. Experts warn that yields won't return to historic lows, and the 60/40 portfolio is on track for its worst annual loss since 2008.

images.alt_text: Singapore Savings Bonds
China's property market has been rocked by a government crackdown that began in 2020 on developers' excessive borrowing and real estate speculation.

site_title: Nissan still analysing new US law on EV credits, executive says
summary: Nissan is analyzing the new US law restricting tax credits for electric vehicles to those assembled in North America. The law, set to take effect on January 1, will limit credits to about 20 models, including Nissan's Leaf, with up to $7,500 in tax credits. Nissan's chief sustainability officer, Joji Tagawa, stated that the company needs to understand the law's details before taking further measures to accelerate electrification and localization.

images.alt_text: 2023 Nissan Pathfinder is unveiled at the 2022 New York International Auto Show, in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., April 13, 2022. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: With new China AI chip restrictions, US takes aim at a critical niche
summary: The US has instructed Nvidia and AMD to stop sending their flagship artificial intelligence (AI) chips, specifically GPUs, to China. The move targets a critical but niche market with only two major players, Nvidia and AMD, and is seen as a long-overdue step by national security experts to slow China's AI growth. The affected chips, costing tens of thousands of dollars each, are used for high-performance AI work such as image recognition and military equipment analysis. Intel, the only major rival, has not released competitive products and is trying to break into the market.

images.alt_text: Nvidia says that US officials told it that the new rule “will address the risk that products may be used in, or diverted to, a ‘military end use’ or ‘military end user’ in China”.

site_title: Broadcom looks to defy chip slowdown on data centre, wireless strength
summary: Broadcom forecasts above-estimate fourth-quarter revenue of US$8.9 billion, driven by resilient demand from businesses investing in digital infrastructure. The company expects 20% sequential jump in wireless revenue and adjusted profit of US$9.73 per share. Despite a likely chip industry slowdown, Broadcom's focus on infrastructure and hybrid work models gives it an edge over competitors. However, analysts warn that enterprise spending may moderate in 2023, potentially leading to supply-demand imbalance.

images.alt_text: Raghuram believes VMware’s revenues will improve in predictability as the company transitions its business model.
VMware, which had 40 days to solicit rival offers, may disclose the outcome of that effort, although its plans haven't been finalised.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks slightly lower at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks declined 0.13% at the start of the day on September 2, 2022, as investors focused on rising interest rates. The Hang Seng Index dropped 24.84 points to 19,572.47. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.15% and the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 0.26%. The market is awaiting the release of US jobs data later in the day.

site_title: Rising energy prices could fuel social unrest across Europe this winter
summary: Rising energy prices in Europe could fuel social unrest this winter, with over 50% of almost 200 countries experiencing an increase in mass mobilizations risk, according to a risk consultancy firm. Germany and Norway are among the developed economies experiencing disruptions due to labour actions, while countries like Bosnia and Herzegovina, Switzerland, and the Netherlands are at high risk of civil unrest. The war in Ukraine and existing supply chain disruptions have contributed to the rise in prices, which have hit an all-time record.

images.alt_text: The S&P Global/CIPS UK Manufacturing Purchasing Managers’ Index (PMI) has dropped to 47.3 from 52.1 in July.

UK Business Secretary Kwasi Kwarteng is working to extend so-called contracts for difference to generators to replace more lucrative subsidies in an attempt to cap profits and avoid imposing a windfall tax.
Shell will still be able to meet its commitments to supply customers with LNG regardless of its participation in the project.

site_title: Data meets fashion -- and falls short
summary: The fashion industry's sustainability efforts have been called into question due to inaccuracy and greenwashing, with manufacturers often being the main culprits. The Higg Index, a widely used sustainability evaluation tool, has been criticized for using outdated data, leading to warnings from the Norwegian Consumer Authority to brands such as H&M and Norrøna. This highlights the need for greater transparency and accountability in the industry, with consumers being largely unaware of the human and environmental aspects of apparel production.

images.alt_text: Textile production generates more greenhouse gas emissions than shipping and aviation combined, and the sector is the second largest user of the world’s water.

site_title: Sea cuts some Garena unit jobs, shuts projects, sources say
summary: Sea Ltd, a gaming and e-commerce company, has made significant changes to its operations, impacting multiple roles, as part of its efforts to improve efficiency. The company has shut projects at its development unit, Garena, and reduced staff at its gaming livestream platform, Booyah!, with 30-40 employees set to be let go. This move comes after Sea reported a nearly US$1 billion quarterly loss and a 72% drop in its share price this year. The company aims to focus on the "long-term strength of its ecosystem" despite setbacks.

images.alt_text: Sea's e-commerce arm, Shopee was one of the bright spots in its results, reporting an improved adjusted Ebitda loss per order for Q2 2022.
Sea’s overall Q2 results missed CGS-CIMB's expectations.

site_title: Cost of growing food in US is set to rise by most ever in 2022
summary: The cost of growing food in the US is set to rise by 18% in 2022, the largest increase ever, according to a US Department of Agriculture report. Production costs are estimated to rise by $66.2 billion due to soaring prices of fertiliser and animal feed. The rise in costs is attributed to disruptions in grain shipments from the Black Sea, a major breadbasket, and global inflation. This increase may exacerbate levels of hunger, with global food prices already at records. Corn and wheat prices remain elevated, further contributing to the rising costs.

images.alt_text: Corn grows in a field outside Wyanet, Illinois, U.S., July 6, 2018. REUTERS/Daniel Acker/File Photo

site_title: Stocks to watch: ComfortDelGro, Emperador, GYP Properties
summary: GYP Properties shares rose 3.3% to S$0.188 after a voluntary cash offer by Rumah & Co was raised to S$0.188 per share. ComfortDelGro was dropped from the Straits Times Index and replaced by Emperador on September 19. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks rallied 0.4% on Thursday despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views, with the STI set to close at a 5-day high ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Boeing expects more orders from India as airlines boost capacity
summary: Boeing expects Indian airlines to order 2,345 aircraft over the next 20 years, with a 25% increase in capacity expected over the next year. The company's president, Salil Gupte, predicts more widebody and narrowbody orders from India, driven by rising demand and long-term growth of 7% annually. Boeing dominates the country's widebody market, with new entrants like Akasa Air and Tata Sons-owned Air India giving the company hope to regain share, and SpiceJet, its largest customer, close to placing new orders.

images.alt_text: Boeing had been widely expected to win the deal as talks by the government-backed carrier to renew its fleet coincided with attention to security partnerships amid what Taipei has called its worst tensions with China for 40 years.
The 8-day mission would mark the final test mission before Nasa can certify Starliner for routine astronaut missions.

“Boeing anticipates US$3.6 billion in economic impact to the Indian aerospace and defence industry over the next 10 years, with the F/A-18 Super Hornet as India’s next carrier-based fighter,” the company said in a statement.

site_title: The Credit Suisse businesses at stake as executives mull future
summary: Credit Suisse is facing significant financial challenges, with revenue from its equity and debt financing business nearly wiped out in the second quarter. The bank's board is considering radical changes, including selling up to two-thirds of its investment bank, with potential losses and reputational hits estimated in the billions. Key areas under discussion include fixed-income trading, equities trading, and deal-making, with some businesses potentially being downsized or sold off to reduce costs and risk. The bank is also exploring ways to attract outside capital to support its operations.

images.alt_text: Other reports have said that up to 4,000 jobs could be cut, including a significant part at Credit Suisse's headquarters in Zurich.
Credit Suisse Group is shifting resources to win business from a broader range of rich clients, as the lender focuses more heavily on wealth management amid cuts to its troubled investment bank.

site_title: Oil slides 3% as China lockdowns stoke demand fears
summary: Oil prices dropped 3% on Thursday, with Brent crude settling at $92.36 a barrel, down $3.28. The decline was attributed to new Covid-19 lockdown measures in China, fueling concerns about high inflation and interest rate hikes reducing fuel demand. US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell 3.3% to $86.61 per barrel. The drop in oil prices was also influenced by bearish market sentiment following US President Trump's tariff announcements.

images.alt_text: “We produce exactly as much as we have the ability to produce and sell. We have a small increase, the situation is improving as you can see. ” Russia Deputy Prime Minister Alexander Novak told reporters.
Oil prices have declined by more than 20 per cent in the 3 months till August, prompting Opec+ to signal that it could cut supply.

site_title: Europe: Shares get September off to bad start as rate hike concerns grow
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 fell 1.8% on its fifth straight day in the red, hitting seven-week lows due to growing concerns about economic growth, aggressive interest rate hikes, and record-high inflation. The European Central Bank is expected to raise interest rates by 75 basis points next week, with a 80% chance of this move, according to money markets. This follows a second consecutive month of shrinking euro zone manufacturing activity and a record-high inflation rate. Defensive sectors such as utilities and telecoms were the only ones to record a small decline.

images.alt_text: The pan-European STOXX 600 has slid for a fifth straight day on Thursday (Sep 1), dropping 0.8 per cent by 0715 GMT.

site_title: Starbucks names outgoing Reckitt leader as next CEO
summary: Starbucks has named Laxman Narasimhan, former Reckitt CEO, as its next CEO, replacing Howard Schultz on April 1, 2023. Narasimhan will relocate from London to Seattle and join the company on October 1. The transition comes as Starbucks navigates a US unionization push and responds to worker concerns with increased investments in pay and stores. Analysts see Narasimhan's partner-centered approach as a positive move, while unionization supporters call for an end to union-busting efforts.

images.alt_text: A TikTok account run by Starbucks Workers United, the group of employees aiming to unionise the world’s largest coffee chain, has taken off this month with several viral posts.

site_title: Met Office says summer 2022 England’s joint hottest on record
summary: England experienced its joint hottest summer on record this year, tied with 2018, according to the Met Office. The country's mean temperature of 17.1 deg C was the joint warmest ever recorded, with the east of England seeing its hottest summer on record. This marks the fourth warmest summer in England since 2003, with the effects of human-induced climate change being felt on summer temperatures. The summer was also the driest in England and Wales since 1976, with minimal rainfall throughout the period.

images.alt_text: Harvesting season this year was about two weeks early in most large wine regions of France - something likely to be a lasting trend, winemakers said.
Scientists said most such extreme weather events are attributable to human-caused climate change, and will only increase in severity and frequency.

site_title: Microsoft combat goggles win first US army approval for delivery
summary: The US Army has cleared the delivery of Microsoft's Integrated Visual Augmentation System (IVAS) combat goggles, with Assistant Secretary for Acquisition Douglas Bush approving the acceptance of a first batch of 5,000 sets. The goggles, valued at $373 million, provide a "heads-up display" similar to those for fighter pilots, and are expected to project information onto a visor in front of a soldier's face. The Army plans to spend up to $21.9 billion over a decade on the program, pending the results of a final test report expected next month.

images.alt_text: Soldiers wear Integrated Visual Augmentation System Capability Set 3 hardware while mounted in a Stryker.
Microsoft Qatar general manager Lana Khalaf said it will help the tiny Gulf state become a “digital hub for the region and the world”.
Microsoft’s move came after smaller European Union competitors took their grievances about its cloud service practices to EU antitrust regulators.

site_title: Shell walks away from major Russian LNG project with nothing
summary: Shell has walked away from Russia's Sakhalin-2 liquefied natural gas project with no financial gain after President Vladimir Putin transferred the facility to a new operator. Shell had already written off $1.6 billion from its 27.5% stake earlier this year and will still meet its LNG supply commitments. The decision reflects the push by European governments to lessen economic ties with Russia over the Ukraine invasion. The remaining partner, Gazprom, may now absorb Shell's stake, potentially increasing energy revenue for Russia.

images.alt_text: Shell shut the 3.6-million-tonne-a-year Prelude facility in July.
The strong results reflected higher energy prices and refining margins, as well as strong gas and power trading, Shell said, but were partly offset by lower liquefied natural gas trading results.

site_title: Durapower to power 60% of Tuas Port’s automated guided vehicle fleet
