summary: Durapower will supply high-performance battery systems to power over 60% of PSA Singapore's automated guided vehicle (AGV) fleet at Tuas Port, with approximately 200 electric AGVs planned for deployment by 2023. The move aims to reduce carbon emissions by nearly half and contribute to PSA's goal of achieving net-zero emissions by 2050. This partnership marks a significant expansion for Durapower, which currently serves the electric mobility and specialty vehicles segments, and is expected to boost the global AGV market growth to US$2.3 billion by 2024.

images.alt_text: Venga (எஸ். வெங்கடேஷ்வரன்)
Singapore is forging ahead with a US$14 billion project to build the world's biggest automated port by 2040.
An artist's impression of Changi Airport's Terminal 5.

site_title: Bankrupt Celsius seeks to return US$50m of locked crypto
summary: Celsius Network, a bankrupt cryptocurrency lender, is seeking a US bankruptcy judge's permission to release approximately US$50 million worth of cryptocurrency from custody accounts. This is a fraction of the over US$200 million trapped in these accounts. The move aims to return coins to users who are locked out of their accounts, with a full hearing scheduled for October 6. The company's bankruptcy has sparked a split among thousands of users, with some having deposited crypto to earn interest and others retaining title to their assets.

site_title: Twitter will roll out long-awaited edit button to paid subscribers
summary: Twitter will roll out its long-awaited edit button to paid subscribers, allowing them to edit tweets "a few times" within 30 minutes of publication for $4.99 per month. This feature has been highly requested by users for years, with some joking that it would be introduced before other products. The update is expected to be released in the coming weeks.

site_title: The best sustainability reports: Winning features
summary: Sustainability reports have become mainstream, with most large companies releasing them annually. However, the reports have become increasingly complex, making it difficult for the average person to understand what companies are doing in their sustainability efforts. To create a worthwhile report, companies must include quantitative data on key performance indicators, providing insight into their eco-green and resilient practices, progress, and areas for improvement. This approach helps readers understand a company's environmental commitment and social responsibility.

images.alt_text: Guest of honour and Minister of Health Ong Ye Kung noted that CEOs and boards of today have more things to worry about, amid an increasing emphasis on the “less tangible but crucial aspects”, such as environmental, social and governance (ESG) related considerations.

site_title: There can be value in employees having side hustles
summary: Asia's generational shift is transforming the workforce, with 600 million Gen Zs and millennials entering the labor market. Employers must adapt to meet their needs, prioritizing flexibility, financial security, and mental health. Young workers value work-life balance and are more likely to have side hustles to supplement their income. To thrive, employers must adopt a people-first approach, embracing flexible work arrangements, recognizing the value of side hustles, and prioritizing health and wellbeing. Those who fail to adapt risk becoming uncompetitive in a labor market that is increasingly remote and geographically flexible.

images.alt_text: On-the-job stress rose from 38 per cent of those polled in 2019 to 43 per cent the following year as Covid-19 upended the world of work, Gallup found. Women in the United States and Canada faced the most pressure.

site_title: Hot stock: Emperador up as much as 5.1% after news of STI addition
summary: Emperador shares rose 5.1% on the Singapore Stock Exchange after it was added to the Straits Times Index (STI) on September 19. The company, a subsidiary of Alliance Global Group, traded at S$0.52 after 584,000 securities changed hands. Analysts DBS and CGS-CIMB advised investors to buy the stock due to its share price weakness. Emperador's market capitalization of S$8.3 billion put it in the 20th spot among eligible counters for STI inclusion.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani
Traders were eager to put the bumpy month of June behind them, but July promises to no less uncertain

site_title: Samsung Electronics debt rating raised to same as government
summary: Samsung Electronics' credit rating has been upgraded to Aa2 by Moody's Investors Service, the same level as the South Korean government, due to expectations of solid earnings and a strong business profile. The company's revenue is equivalent to 13.5% of Korea's GDP, and it has a healthy balance sheet with a net cash position of 108 trillion won. Despite a cyclical downturn in the memory chip industry, Moody's expects Samsung to remain profitable. This upgrade reflects confidence in the company's financial stability.

site_title: UK plans to cap renewables’ profits amid rising energy costs
summary: The UK government plans to offer fixed-price contracts to existing renewable-energy producers to cap profits amid rising energy costs. Business Secretary Kwasi Kwarteng aims to replace more lucrative subsidies with these contracts, avoiding a windfall tax. This move is part of efforts to help households cope with increasing energy tariffs. Existing contracts for difference, mostly used for offshore wind farms, will be extended to limit producer profits. The goal is to ensure cost of living support can be delivered to households as the new prime minister takes office.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as slowdown worries mount
summary: US stocks opened lower on September 1, 2022, as weak factory activity surveys from Europe and Asia fueled fears of a global economic slowdown. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 55.85 points, or 0.18%, to 31,454.58, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. This marks a dour start to the month, with investors cautious about the economic outlook.

site_title: Thailand’s new 10-year visa scheme to lure up to 1 million wealthy foreigners
summary: Thailand launched its Long Term Resident (LTR) visa scheme on September 1, aiming to attract 1 million wealthy or highly-skilled foreigners over the next 5 years and generate 800 billion baht in new investments. The 10-year visa is part of a strategy to promote foreign investment in value-added industries and escape the middle-income trap. The initiative, led by former JP Morgan Securities advisor Chayotid Kridakon, is expected to bring in significant revenue and drive economic growth.

images.alt_text: A view of Bangkok's port along Chao Phraya River is photographed during sunset in Bangkok, Thailand, June 2, 2021. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha/File Photo
Thailand hopes to tap into “pent-up demand” from the multi-billion dollar Indian wedding industry.
Thailand is benefiting from a rebound in global travel demand with authorities scrapping all pandemic-era restrictions that kept visitors out for almost 2 years.
Even with some salaries going up, many Thais will find their pay increases eaten up by the cost of goods they buy.

site_title: Zuckerberg targeted by House GOP eager to probe Hunter Biden
summary: US House Republicans have demanded that Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg hand over FBI warnings and communications related to the suppression of a 2020 New York Post article about Hunter Biden. The letter, signed by over 30 Republicans, seeks all documents since October 1, 2020, between Facebook employees and the FBI regarding the article. The move comes as Republicans are expected to gain control of the House in November's midterm elections, potentially leading to public hearings and demands for internal documents from tech companies.

site_title: As recession fears loom large, can the Fed finesse a ‘soft landing’?
summary: The US Federal Reserve is increasingly skeptical of achieving a "soft landing" as it battles inflation, with many experts warning that a recession is likely. Despite mixed economic data, including weaker job growth and falling home prices, the Fed is cautious about cutting rates too soon. Fed Chair Jerome Powell has signaled a "hard landing" as a necessary evil to tame inflation, echoing Paul Volcker's approach in the 1970s and 1980s. Economists predict a recession, but expect it to be relatively mild, with a 3% inflation rate and 4% unemployment rate.

images.alt_text: The broad-based S&P 500 dropped 0.8 per cent to close at 3,955.00, while the tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index slumped 0.6 per cent to 11,816.20 on Wednesday.
Valuation has been a central plank in arguments that the worst has passed for bulls in 2022.

site_title: Starbucks workers winning union fight on TikTok
summary: Starbucks workers are winning their union fight, largely thanks to a viral TikTok account run by Starbucks Workers United, which has gained over 250,000 followers and 9 videos surpassing a million views. The account, launched in December, has helped spread the union's message, with comments like "no contract, no coffee" trending on the platform. This campaign is seen as a new template to challenge the world's largest coffee chain, with a 71% approval rating of unions in the US and a growing following among Gen Z, who make up TikTok's core audience.

site_title: US jobless claims decline for third week to 2-month low
summary: US jobless claims declined for a third week to a 2-month low, with 232,000 initial claims filed in the week ending August 27. Continuing claims rose to 1.44 million. The data suggests labor market tightness, with job openings surging in July to near a record high. Economists say labor market conditions are not weakening dramatically, despite Fed tightening.

images.alt_text: People walk past a "now hiring" sign posted outside of a restaurant in Arlington, Virginia on June 3, 2022. - US employers added 390,000 jobs last month, the government reported on June 3, 2022, a sign of a slowdown in hiring but still a better-than-expected result. The jobless rate held steady at 3.6 percent for the third consecutive month, just a tenth of a point above the pre-pandemic level of February 2020, the Labor Department said. (Photo by OLIVIER DOULIERY / AFP)
3M, which makes everything from dental adhesives to Post-it notes, employed about 95,000 people at the end of 2021.
Businesses’ payrolls rose 132,000 this month after a nearly 270,000 gain in July.

The number of available positions edged up to 11.2 million in the month - topping all estimates -  from a revised 11 million in June, the Labor Department’s Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey, or JOLTS, showed on Tuesday (Aug 30).

site_title: EU will propose crisis tool for supply chain emergencies
summary: The European Commission is set to propose a crisis tool for supply chain emergencies, giving it the power to force companies to fill orders within the EU first during times of crisis, risking fines. The Single Market Emergency Instrument plan aims to prevent shortages and guarantee the EU's single market in emergencies, including geopolitical instability, climate change, and natural disasters. The proposal also includes measures to monitor supply chains, fine companies for non-compliance, and require countries to stockpile certain items in a "vigilance mode" if necessary.

images.alt_text: A European Union flag flies in Brussels, Belgium Photographer: Geert Vanden Wijngaert/Bloomberg
Big players such as Deutsche Telekom, Orange and Telefonica have long complained about tech rivals free-riding on their networks.
Eurostat said greenhouse gas emissions from businesses, households and government activities amounted to 1,029 million tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalents.

site_title: UK is already in the middle of a recession, BCC says
summary: The UK is in the midst of a recession, according to the British Chambers of Commerce (BCC), with inflation expected to hit 14% this winter and 5% by the end of 2023. The economy is forecast to contract for two more periods before a 0.2% rebound in 2023, attributed to rising energy costs, declining household spending, and weakened export prospects. The BCC warns that the economic situation is dire, putting pressure on the new prime minister to act quickly to avoid an economic calamity.

site_title: Russia supports Opec+ deal extension, country’s oil output may grow in 2022: Novak
summary: Russia's oil production may increase in 2022, defying predictions of a decline, with Deputy Prime Minister Alexander Novak stating the country produces "exactly as much as we have the ability to produce and sell." Russia supports the extension of the Opec+ deal, which expires this year, and production is expected to reach 520-525 million tonnes in 2022. Despite Western sanctions and plans to cap Russian oil prices, Novak believes production will increase if the situation stabilizes and companies find new markets with confidence.

site_title: Asia still key in cocoa industry despite lower production levels, lack of investments: panel
summary: Asia remains a crucial player in the global cocoa industry despite lower production levels and lack of investments, according to a panel discussion at the International Cocoa Conference. Indonesia, Malaysia, and Singapore are key cocoa processing locations in the region, but production has declined significantly over the past decade due to factors such as low yield and limited investment. The region accounts for 25% of global cocoa powder imports, and cocoa prices remain relatively flat due to a surplus supply. Experts predict a decline in global cocoa production this year, with yields still increasing in some countries and freight rates impacting margins for Asia's cocoa processors.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
The startup has come up with an AI-driven food profiler, which it says can predict the quality and profile of a food sample within seconds.
Olam said it expects to deliver a better year-on-year performance for the full year as revised sales pricing and margin recovery gathers pace in H2.
When completed, the new Abidjan’s factory is also expected to “incrementally expand” JB Cocoa’s annual bean processing capabilities.
The United Nations' food price index pulled back from a record high in March after the war choked exports from Ukraine and triggered a raft of sanctions on Russia.

site_title: Credit Suisse plans 3,200 job cuts in Zurich: Blick newspaper
summary: Credit Suisse plans to cut 3,200 jobs in Zurich as part of a cost-cutting drive, according to Swiss newspaper Blick. The move is part of a broader effort to scale back investment banking and cut $1 billion in costs, following a series of scandals and losses. The bank has not confirmed the job cuts, citing speculation from unnamed sources, and will announce its third-quarter earnings to provide an update on its comprehensive strategy review.

site_title: Beckham slammed for PR video praising ‘perfect’ Qatar
summary: David Beckham has faced criticism for promoting Qatar as "perfection" in a series of promotional videos, despite concerns over its human rights record. Beckham, a cultural ambassador for Qatar, has appeared in videos praising the country's art, food, and culture, but made no mention of its human rights issues. Amnesty International has called on Beckham to use his platform to highlight the abuses faced by migrant workers, who have died or been injured while working on World Cup construction sites.

site_title: Tessa Therapeutics’ new CEO bullish on moonshot in off-the-shelf cancer therapy
summary: Tessa Therapeutics, a Singapore-based biotech firm backed by Temasek, has appointed a new CEO Thomas Willemsen, who is optimistic about the company's potential for an off-the-shelf cancer therapy. The company, which has raised $126 million in funding, is working towards commercializing new cell therapies for lymphoma, including an allogeneic option that could be cheaper and more scalable than current treatments. Willemsen predicts the approval of allogeneic treatments could be a "watershed moment" for CAR-T players, and the company is targeting US approval for its lead asset TT11 in 2025.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Tessa is a player in the niche field of CAR-T therapy.
Tessa is a player in the niche field of CAR-T therapy.

site_title: Volvo Cars to close China plant due coronavirus restrictions
summary: Volvo Cars is temporarily suspending production at its manufacturing plant in Chengdu, China, due to a lockdown caused by the coronavirus. The company is assessing the impact on its business and will continue to monitor the situation. This decision follows a lockdown in the nearby city of Daqing. The closure affects Volvo's production operations in the region.

site_title: UK watchdog to further probe Microsoft’s US$68.7b Activision deal
summary: The UK's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) will conduct an in-depth investigation into Microsoft's $68.7 billion acquisition of Activision Blizzard, citing concerns that the merger may reduce competition in gaming consoles, multi-game subscription services, and cloud gaming services. The CMA gave Microsoft and Activision Blizzard until September 8 to offer acceptable undertakings to address these concerns.

site_title: S-Reits in good position to stave off challenges from competing Asian Reit markets
summary: Singapore's real estate investment trust (Reit) market is facing increasing competition from Asian counterparts, but experts say S-Reits are well-positioned to stave off challenges. The market, which has a total market value of over $111 billion, is expected to continue growing due to its established regulatory framework, favorable tax regime, and investor familiarity. The Reit Association of Singapore notes that the market has expanded into new sectors and asset classes, and large Reits are now considering acquiring assets from other markets, positioning Singapore as a global Reit hub.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
Keeping Singapore's status as Asia-Pacific's global Reit hub

site_title: Oil sinks further to test Opec’s resolve amid demand concerns
summary: Oil prices have declined by over 20% in the past three months, prompting Opec+ to signal potential supply cuts amid growing demand concerns and rising US dollar. West Texas Intermediate futures dropped below $88 a barrel, marking the longest decline since April 2020. Investors are focused on tighter monetary policy and the lockdown of China's Chengdu, which has added to negative sentiment. Opec+ is set to discuss output policy on September 5, and potential supply cuts could limit the downside of the market.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures for October due to expire on Wednesday, settled at US$96.49, down US$2.82 a barrel, or 2.8 per cent.
Opec+ Joint Technical Committee sees the oil market in a surplus of 3.1 million bpd in September, falling to 0.6 million bpd in October before rising to 1.4 million bpd in November.

site_title: US manufacturing sector steady in August; price pressures ease further: ISM
summary: The US manufacturing sector showed steady growth in August, with the ISM manufacturing PMI unchanged at 52.8, indicating expansion. Employment and new orders rebounded, while price pressures eased further, with inflation at the factory gate subsiding to 52.5, the lowest reading since June 2020. The continued growth in manufacturing suggests the economy was not in recession, despite a contracting GDP in the first half of the year. Supply chains are improving, and demand for labor remains strong despite tighter monetary policy.

images.alt_text: The level of first-time claims, in addition to a still-low number of Americans already on unemployment benefit rolls, underscores tightness in the broader labour market.

site_title: Ford recalls 198,000 US SUVs due to risk of fire
summary: Ford Motor is recalling 198,000 2015-2017 Ford Expedition and Lincoln Navigator SUVs in the US due to a risk of fire. The recall is related to a faulty blower motor assembly, which has been linked to 25 reported fires. Three fires caused property damage and one resulted in minor injury. Ford will notify owners starting September 12 to replace the affected assembly. The recall is unrelated to recent safety recalls on newer model vehicles.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 20.10 points to 1,491.95. 2.444 billion lots worth RM2.023 billion were traded, with losers outnumbering gainers 661 to 269.

site_title: PUB issues S$800 million of its first green bonds, priced at 3.4%
summary: Public Utilities Board (PUB) issued S$800 million in its first green bonds, priced at 3.4%, to finance potential projects such as a floating solar photovoltaic project and the Tuas Water Reclamation Plant. The 30-year bonds mature on Aug 30, 2052, and will have coupon payments every 6 months. The issue was fully subscribed, with investors showing strong interest in the green notes, which are part of PUB's new S$10 billion multi-currency medium-term note programme.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
The green bonds will help fund potential projects eligible for financing, including Tuas Water Reclamation Plant.
A general view of Shell's Pulau Bukom petrochemical complex in Singapore.
Singapore’s inaugural green bond issue sees public offer fully subscribed at 1.06 times

site_title: US mortgage rates rise, hitting highest level since end of June
summary: US mortgage rates rose to 5.66% for a 30-year loan, the highest since the end of June, according to Freddie Mac. This surge in rates has led to a sales slowdown, with new listings dropping 15% from the same period last year. Sellers are holding back due to decreased buyer interest, resulting in continued price-growth deceleration. The increase in mortgage rates comes as the Federal Reserve aims to tame inflation, with rates expected to remain high to achieve this goal.

site_title: Thailand mulls first taxi fare hike since 2014 as costs surge
summary: Thailand is considering its first taxi fare hike since 2014 to help drivers cope with rising fuel and living costs. About 25% of taxi drivers in Bangkok have been squeezed out of business due to the freeze in rates, which has led to earnings lagging behind a 7% gain in cost of living. The Ministry of Transport is gathering feedback from consumer groups to ensure a fare increase does not negatively impact users, who are also facing rising expenses. A time frame for the hike has not been announced.

site_title: US sought records on Binance CEO in 2020 for crypto money laundering probe
summary: The US Justice Department's money laundering section asked Binance, the world's largest cryptocurrency exchange, to provide extensive internal records and communications involving its CEO, Zhao Changpeng, in a 2020 probe. The investigation, which remains ongoing, is focused on whether Binance violated US financial crime laws, including the Bank Secrecy Act, which requires crypto exchanges to register and comply with anti-money laundering requirements. The probe seeks documents related to Binance's detection of illegal transactions, recruitment of US customers, and compliance with US sanctions. Binance has not publicly responded to the request.

images.alt_text: Argentina saw citizens pour savings into bitcoin this year despite a crash in cryptocurrency prices.
Binance said its co-founder Yi He will serve as the new head of venture capital arm Binance Labs.

site_title: Thailand tightens rules on crypto advertising
summary: Thailand's Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has introduced new rules for cryptocurrency advertising, requiring companies to clearly show investment risks and provide a balanced view of potential returns. The new rules also require companies to disclose advertising terms, including influencer and blogger fees, to regulators within 30 days. The move comes as the industry faces increased scrutiny from authorities, with several companies fined for regulatory non-compliance, including Bitkub and Zipmex.

site_title: Some G20 nations ‘backsliding’ on climate targets: UK envoy
summary: The UK's climate delegate Alok Sharma stated that some G20 nations are "backsliding" on their emissions commitments, citing concerns over the lack of a joint communique at the climate talks in Bali. Sharma described the response as "incredibly worrying" and warned that the prospect of meeting the 1.5°C temperature limit is slipping away. The G20 nations, which account for 80% of global emissions, failed to adopt a joint communique due to objections over language on climate targets and the war in Ukraine.

images.alt_text: US Special Presidential Envoy for Climate John Kerry (R) meeting Environmental Protection Agency Administrator Michael Regan (L) during the G20 Joint Environment and Climate Ministers' Meeting in Nusa Dua, Bali, Indonesia, 31 August.

site_title: China says automakers must have licences for mapping data in smart cars
summary: China's Ministry of Natural Resources requires automakers to obtain licenses to collect geographic data for smart cars, citing security concerns over foreign companies' access to detailed mapping capabilities. Foreign companies like Tesla must partner with Chinese firms to collect and process such data. China has issued over 20 mapping licenses to companies, including Baidu and Navinfo, to support the country's growing intelligent and connected vehicle industry, projected to reach $470 billion by 2030.

site_title: ComfortDelGro dropped from STI, replaced by liquor giant Emperador
summary: ComfortDelGro has been dropped from the Straits Times Index (STI) and replaced by Emperador, a Philippine-based liquor company, in the latest quarterly review. Emperador's market capitalization of S$8.3 billion put it in the 20th spot among eligible counters, allowing it to gain entry into the STI. ComfortDelGro, with a market capitalization of S$3.1 billion, was ranked the smallest among existing STI constituents and will be removed from the index. The change takes effect on September 19.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Emperador could be included on the STI if secondary listing goes through
Immediately prior to the investment unit spin-off, YZJ Shipbuilding had a market capitalisation of around S$6.1 billion – ranking it as the 22nd-largest STI counter, according to Bloomberg data.
Emperador shares opened at S$0.435 in the morning and climbed during the day to end at S$0.45, after 6.2 million shares worth S$2.7 million were traded.

site_title: French ideas, Chinese heart at Chez Kai
summary: Chez Kai, a new restaurant in Singapore, combines French ideas with Chinese flavors. The young team, led by a chef with painting skills, created the eatery with their own bare hands. The menu features dishes like homemade XO noodles, rice mousse, and pyrenees lamb with smoked snapper and lamb jus. The restaurant is open for lunch and dinner, Tuesdays to Saturdays, and is known for its passion and good humor. Despite being a first-time restaurateur, the team's do-it-yourself approach has resulted in a unique dining experience.

images.alt_text: Nouri's spread of snacks.

site_title: STI rises marginally by 0.07%, bucks trend of losses across region
summary: The Straits Times Index rose 2.41 points or 0.07% to 3,224.08 on Thursday, bucking regional losses amid cautious trading due to rising interest rates. The US stock market closed in the red, while European indices also fell. Despite a bear market rally in Wall Street, analysts see the current situation as a tactical opportunity to pick up select growth names at inexpensive valuation levels.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
The pan-European STOXX 600 has slid for a fifth straight day on Thursday (Sep 1), dropping 0.8 per cent by 0715 GMT.
The Hang Seng Index fell 1.79 per cent, or 357.08 points, to 19,597.31.
SGX CEO Loh Boon Chye (centre), flanked by members of Reitas' exco and management, at an event celebrating 20 years of S-Reits.

site_title: Hong Kong’s Lee gets nod for reverse quarantine into China
summary: Hong Kong Chief Executive John Lee has secured China's support for a "reverse quarantine" program, allowing travelers to first isolate in Hong Kong before entering China without quarantine. The plan aims to alleviate hotel capacity issues in mainland China and facilitate regular travel between Hong Kong and Shenzhen. Lee plans to establish a task force to ensure the program's safety and has proposed a community isolation facility in Lok Ma Chau. This move comes as Hong Kong's economy contracts due to pandemic policies and China continues its strict Covid Zero policy.

images.alt_text: Chengdu is the largest city to be locked down since Shanghai was shut for 2 months earlier this year.

site_title: Lufthansa to scrap flights at German hubs amid strike
summary: Lufthansa is suspending nearly all flights at its two largest German hubs, Frankfurt and Munich, due to a strike by pilots demanding higher pay. The airline will cancel 800 flights, affecting around 130,000 passengers, as the pilots seek a 40% increase in pay. The strike, the second in less than a month, comes as the airline struggles with staffing shortages and soaring inflation. Lufthansa has offered a 13.6-18.6% pay increase to ground crew, but the pilots are seeking better conditions, leading to a breakdown in talks.

images.alt_text: Strikes and staff shortages have already forced airlines including Lufthansa to cancel thousands of flights this summer and caused hours-long queues at major airports, frustrating holidaymakers keen to travel after Covid-19 lockdowns.
British Airways has been among the hardest hit after dismissing 10,000 workers at the peak of the Covid pandemic.
SAS said on Friday (Aug 19) 1,700 flights, roughly 4 per cent of the total number of flights, had been cancelled in September and October.

site_title: DeClout Ventures leads US$4.5m investment in e-mobility scale up Charged Indonesia
summary: Singapore-headquartered DeClout Ventures led a US$4.5 million investment in e-mobility scale-up Charged Indonesia, aiming to reduce air pollution in Indonesia by transitioning combustion motorcycle users to sustainable mobility. Charged Indonesia plans to establish a 16,000 sqm zero-energy facility and launch affordable electric motorcycles for commercial fleets and individuals in Q4.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani
Heavy traffic on highways at Tegal Parang in South Jakarta.Photographer: Muhammad Fadli/Bloomberg

site_title: Sterling, euro slide as US dollar marches higher
summary: The US dollar surged against the euro and sterling, with the euro sliding 0.37% to just above parity at $1.10016, and the pound hitting a 2½ year low at $1.15545, as investors anticipated higher US interest rates and concerns over European economies. The US dollar index rose 0.34% to 109.09, near its 2-decade high. The safe-haven dollar was driven by moves away from riskier assets, with investors seeking protection from potential economic instability.

site_title: Tuas Port officially opens with 3 berths, 500 workers as freight volumes reach record high levels
summary: Singapore's Tuas Port officially opened with three operational berths, handling 500 workers and freight volumes at record high levels. The port's eventual capacity of 65 million TEUs will make it the world's largest, surpassing competitors in Shanghai, Hong Kong, and Amsterdam. With its fully automated operations, Tuas Port is expected to create thousands of jobs and boost Singapore's status as a trade hub. The port is set to drive the country's economy and make port services cheaper for industries in Western Singapore, including Jurong Industrial District and Jurong Lake District.

images.alt_text: An artist's impression of Changi Airport's Terminal 5.

site_title: Australia’s property downturn puts home buyers in double mortgage bind
summary: Australia's housing market downturn has led to a double mortgage bind for home sellers, who are taking out mortgages for new homes while holding onto their old properties. With prices falling at their fastest pace in 4 decades, the durations of bridging loans are doubling or quadrupling, causing financial stress for borrowers. Lenders are benefiting from the increased demand, but experts warn that the trend may continue as interest rates rise further. The average home in major cities took 31 days to sell in August, and sellers are now holding onto properties for 6 weeks or more, resulting in a longer-term bridging loan.

site_title: Volkswagen to speed up electric vehicle transition, new CEO says
summary: Volkswagen's new CEO, Oliver Blume, has announced plans to accelerate the company's transition to electric vehicles, aiming to overtake Tesla as the world's largest electric vehicle maker by 2025 and have half its global vehicle sales be battery-electric by 2030. Blume has developed a 10-point plan focusing on financial robustness, sustainability, and development in key markets, while also emphasizing the importance of teamwork and collaboration. Despite initial concerns about his dual role as Porsche CEO, Blume aims to maintain a focus on battery-electric vehicles.

images.alt_text: German Chancellor Olaf Scholz (left) and Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau (right) watch as Volkswagen AG's CEO Herbert Diess (second left) shakes hands with Canadian Minister of Innovation, Science and Industry, Francois-Philippe Champagne at the Canadian-German Chamber of Industry and Commerce in Toronto, Canada, on Aug 23, 2022.

site_title: Asia stocks will be first to emerge from downturn: Man Group
summary: Man Group expects Asian stocks to outperform other regions in 2023 due to softer inflation and the end of an earnings downgrade cycle. The hedge fund giant is betting on defensive stocks in India and South-east Asia, while cautioning that equities in northern Asia, particularly China, remain vulnerable. Asia's equity benchmark has slumped 19% in 2022, but forward earnings-per-share estimates have improved, with the MSCI's Asia benchmark down 9% from a March high. Man Group has increased exposure to China in its portfolios and sees opportunities in stocks that have been hurt but can deliver good results in the coming years.

images.alt_text: Also up from a year ago (49 per cent), 73 per cent of respondents believe that the European Union (EU) should pursue a region-to-region free trade agreement with Asean now.
Tokyo, Hong Kong, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Wellington, Taipei and Jakarta were all deep in the red, though Shanghai eked out small gains with Manila.

site_title: Yuan’s declines slowed by firmer-than-expected fixings, fuelling talks of PBOC support
summary: China's yuan declined 2.2% against the US dollar in August, its worst monthly performance since April, but recent firmer-than-expected official guidance rates have slowed the decline. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) lifted the official fixing rate for the seventh consecutive trading day, sparking speculation that it may have revived the counter-cyclical factor to stabilize the currency. Analysts believe the move is a signal from the Chinese authorities to dampen depreciation pressure ahead of the 20th National Congress of the Chinese Communist Party.

site_title: Gallery hopping in Jakarta
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Jakarta's art scene has returned to pre-Covid capacity, with the city hosting various galleries and museums showcasing quality art. Art Agenda, a Singapore-based gallery, has opened an outpost in Jakarta, featuring works by modern artists. Rubanah, founded by Indonesia's leading curator Enin Supriyanto, is a hip new gallery showcasing art across mediums. Distrik Seni, a museum-like marketplace, features works by hot artists including Mulyana and Jompet Kuswidananto. Other notable galleries include ROH Projects, Gajah Gallery, and Museum MACAN, which features blue-chip works by international artists.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
After a 2-year partial hiatus, Art Jakarta expects strong sales owing to pent-up demand and revival of economic activities.
ART SG Co-Founder Magnus Renfrew and Director Shuyin Yang.
Singapore Biennale 2022 will be led by co-artistic directors (from left) June Yap, Nida Ghouse, Ala Younis and Binna Choi.

site_title: 112 organisations named Champions of Good 2022
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong recognized 112 organizations as Champions of Good 2022 for their efforts to help vulnerable members of society and rally staff and stakeholders during the pandemic. The award, launched in 2017, aims to celebrate organizations that have made a positive impact through corporate giving and collaboration. This year's recipients include 66 repeat winners and 46 first-time Champions, such as Food Playground, which empowers stay-at-home mums to re-enter the workforce. The recognition highlights the growth of corporate giving, with two-thirds of businesses engaging in corporate giving last year, up from 50% five years ago.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang
Every business is deeply intertwined with environmental, social, and governance (ESG) concerns and can contribute to business performance in the ways of investment and asset optimisation

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with big losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.79% on Thursday, September 1, 2022, due to concerns over central bank interest rate hikes and a new Covid lockdown in China's Chengdu city. The Hang Seng Index fell to 19,597.31, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.54%. The decline was attributed to global market fears and the added selling pressure from the Chinese lockdown news.

site_title: Grand Hyatt Singapore to open new restaurant with Michelin-starred chef
summary: Grand Hyatt Singapore is set to open a new restaurant in the second half of the year, in partnership with Dutch Michelin-starred chef Sergio Herman. This is the hotel's latest collaboration with a well-known chef, following recent openings with Mauro Colagreco and Nancy Silverton. Herman's Asian debut will be his first international restaurant, and he has hinted that the concept will reflect his Dutch heritage and seafood background. The new restaurant will be located in the former Mezza9 space and is part of the hotel's major refurbishment ahead of its reopening in 2023.

images.alt_text: Nouri's spread of snacks.

site_title: Amazon introduces seller storage service to tackle supply chain woes
summary: Amazon has introduced Amazon Warehousing & Distribution (AWD), a pay-as-you-go service that allows sellers to store bulk inventory and cut logistics costs. The service, set to launch in 2023, will enable sellers to send inventory to any location, including wholesale customers or brick-and-mortar stores. This move aims to address supply chain issues and help sellers grow their businesses while reducing costs. The service is part of Amazon's efforts to rein in costs after slowing warehouse openings.

site_title: GYP Properties raises voluntary cash offer up to S$0.188 per share
summary: GYP Properties, a Singapore-listed real estate developer, has received a voluntary cash offer from Rumah & Co to take the company private at S$0.188 per share, up from S$0.168 per share. The offer is part of Rumah & Co's plans to delist the company, allowing both parties to manage the business more flexibly and optimize resources. The closing date for the offer has been extended to Sept 23.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Tuan Sing CEO William Liem pictured on 30 August, 2021.

The total number of shares owned, controlled or agreed to be acquired by Sanjuro and its concert parties, including valid acceptances, is now approximately 51.29 per cent of the total number of shares — which means the offer has turned unconditional in all respects.

site_title: German manufacturing stuck in contraction in August: PMI
summary: Germany's manufacturing sector contracted for a second month in a row in August, with S&P Global's final PMI falling to 49.1, its lowest reading in over 2 years. The sector's new orders index ticked up to 40.9, but remained below the 50 mark, indicating contraction. Economic uncertainty and strong inflation led to a decline in sales volumes, with businesses accumulating stocks of finished goods and scaling back purchasing activity. The sector's performance is seen as a downside risk in the coming months.

site_title: Eurozone factory activity contracted in Aug as cosumers stay cautious
summary: Eurozone factory activity contracted in August, marking the third consecutive month of decline, according to a survey by S&P Global. Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) fell to 49.6 from 49.8 in July, below the 50 mark separating growth from contraction. Weak demand and soaring energy and food bills led to consumers reining in spending, contributing to the contraction. This suggests a higher likelihood of GDP falling in the third quarter.

site_title: Singapore Savings Bond coupon rates for 1st-year at 2.6%; 10-year average at 2.75%
summary: Singapore Savings Bond (SSB) interest rates have dipped, with the 10-year average return at 2.75% and the 1-year interest rate at 2.6%. This decrease follows a rise in rates earlier this year, with the January SSB having an interest rate of 2.44% and an average return of 1.78% per annum. The SSB interest rates are linked to the yield of a Singapore government bond, but adjustments are expected to have no impact on the return if held for 10 years.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Singapore Savings Bond, unlike most bonds, are non-traded.

Trust Bank Launch. GXS Bank CEO Charles Wong believes that there are segments in Singapore not well-served by banks.

site_title: Chengdu locks down 21.2 million people as Chinese cities battle Covid
summary: Chengdu, China's largest city, has locked down 21.2 million residents for 4 days as part of a citywide Covid-19 testing scheme. Residents are allowed to send one person per day to shop for necessities, while non-essential sector employees are required to work from home. The lockdown, which began on September 1, is the largest since Shanghai's 2-month shutdown earlier this year. Other major cities, including Shenzhen and Dalian, have also implemented Covid restrictions, curbing economic activities and putting pressure on China's "dynamic-zero" Covid policy.

images.alt_text: More than 100,000 tourists were trapped in hotels when the tropical island of Hainan locked down this month, while tens of thousands of holidaymakers were stranded in Tibet and thousands more confined in the Beihai beach town.

site_title: Asean to become more important in terms of worldwide revenues: EU businesses
summary: European Union businesses expect Asean markets to become more important in terms of worldwide revenues over the next 2 years, with 69% of respondents expressing this expectation. 73% believe the EU should pursue a region-to-region free trade agreement with Asean now, and 63% see Asean as the region with the best economic opportunity. However, respondents also expressed concerns about non-tariff barriers to trade, with 81% believing they are not decreasing. The EU-Asean Business Council urged faster climate change action and quicker trade deal negotiations with the EU.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan

The VF-8 electric vehicle from VinFast, a Vietnamese automaker producing electric cars and SUVs, on display at their showroom in California. VinFast also wants its cars to hit the roads in Holland, Germany and France by end-2022.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares fall on risk-off trade
summary: Tokyo stocks plummeted 1.53% on Thursday, following US losses, amid growing fears of no respite from Federal Reserve rate hikes. The Nikkei 225 index fell 430.06 points to 27,661.47, while the Topix index dropped 1.41% to 1,935.49. Investors are concerned about inflation and the impact of rate hikes on the economy.

site_title: MUFG makes senior APAC hires in corporate banking, leveraged and acquisition finance
summary: MUFG has appointed Randy Loo as its Singapore head of global corporate banking and Frik Dreyer as head of leveraged and acquisition finance in Asia-Pacific, both effective September 1. Loo will lead the coverage of MUFG's Singapore-based global corporate client portfolio, including local corporates and global multinationals. Dreyer will oversee leveraged and acquisition finance in the region. The appointments are based in Singapore and report to Richard Yorke, Asia-Pacific head of global corporate and investment banking.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group reported a 70 per cent plunge in first-quarter net profit, blaming one-off losses related to the sale of MUFG Union Bank and a drop in the value of its stake in ride-hailing firm Grab Holdings.

site_title: Malaysia’s former first lady Rosmah sentenced to 10 years’ jail for graft
summary: Rosmah Mansor, the former first lady of Malaysia, was sentenced to 10 years in prison for seeking and receiving bribes in exchange for government contracts. She will also pay a fine of RM970 million (S$301 million) over 3 bribery charges. The sentence was granted after prosecutors proved their case beyond a reasonable doubt, and Rosmah will not serve the sentence immediately due to a stay of sentence. This verdict comes after her husband, former prime minister Najib Razak, was jailed for corruption in a separate case linked to the 1MDB scandal.

images.alt_text: Rosmah, 70, has pleaded not guilty to three charges of soliciting and receiving bribes between 2016 and 2017.
Malaysia’s highest court Tuesday(Aug 23) upheld former prime minister Najib Razak’s 12-year jail sentence for corruption in the 1MDB financial scandal.

site_title: Living large
summary: A Singapore-based design consultancy, SKEW Collaborative, transformed a 30-year-old home into a multigenerational family-friendly space. The existing house was combined with a new addition, creating a unique living arrangement. The design prioritized easy access and privacy for grandparents, while also accommodating the needs of younger family members. The result is a functional and harmonious home that balances the needs of multiple generations.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang
Raclette House, so named because of its round windows that make it look like cheese.

site_title: Seoul: Shares, won slump on record trade deficit
summary: South Korea's benchmark Kospi plummeted 2.28% to 2,415.61, its lowest closing level since July 27, amid a record trade deficit in August. The trade deficit nearly doubled to a record monthly amount due to weak export growth and high energy prices. The won slumped 1.28% to 1,354.9 per dollar, while the 3-year treasury bond yield rose 7.8 basis points to 3.767%. Foreigners were net sellers of shares worth 355.6 billion won, contributing to the market's decline.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi rose 3.77 points or 0.15 per cent to end at 2,481.03, extending gains to a third session.

site_title: Sri Lanka gains IMF’s provisional agreement for US$2.9b loan
summary: Sri Lanka has reached a preliminary agreement with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) for a $2.9 billion loan to help the country recover from its worst economic crisis in decades. The agreement, subject to IMF approval, includes measures such as boosting government revenue, introducing new pricing for fuel and electricity, and hiking social spending. The IMF program, spanning four years, aims to reach a primary surplus of 2.3% of GDP by 2024 and will also require Sri Lanka to restructure nearly $30 billion of debt and work with creditors to secure financing assurances.

site_title: Crypto.com mistakenly transfers A$10.5m to woman owed A$100 refund
summary: Crypto.com mistakenly transferred A$10.5 million to a woman in Melbourne after discovering a 7-month-old error in processing a A$100 refund. The error occurred when an account number was accidentally entered into the payment amount field. The court has ordered the sale of a 5-bedroom property in suburban Melbourne, purchased by the woman's sister, to return the money to the company. The case is set to return to court in October.

site_title: US officials order Nvidia to halt sales of top AI chips to China
summary: US officials have ordered Nvidia to halt sales of its top AI chips to China, citing concerns that the products may be used in or diverted to military end uses. The ban affects Nvidia's A100 and H100 chips, which are used for machine learning tasks. The move is part of the US crackdown on China's technological capabilities amid tensions over Taiwan. Nvidia's shares fell 6.6% after the announcement, which may interfere with the development of its flagship H100 chip.

images.alt_text: Nvidia is already facing a sales slump, triggered by lower demand for personal computers.
Nvidia graphics chips called GPUs have been used for cryptocurrency mining and sales have taken a hit as the crypto market has crumbled.

site_title: Europe: Shares hit 7-week lows as rate hike fears grow
summary: European shares hit 7-week lows, sliding 0.8% on the STOXX 600, for a fifth straight day. Worries of aggressive rate hikes and record-high inflation drove the decline. Rate-sensitive tech stocks fell, while miners lost 1.8% after metals prices tumbled. The European Central Bank is expected to hike rates by 75 basis points, with a 80% chance of this happening next week. Stocks like Lufthansa, LVMH, and Burberry also declined.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 fell 1.1 per cent to new six-week lows, carrying its losing streak to the fourth straight day.

site_title: Italy unemployment rate falls in July but 22,000 jobs lost in month
summary: Italy's unemployment rate fell to 7.9% in July, the lowest since April 2020, but employment levels shrank by 22,000. The decline was due to people withdrawing from the labor market, not job growth. Despite this, employment was up by 140,000 over the past three months and 463,000 over the past year. The economy is expected to slow down due to energy costs, with a sharp slowdown forecast for the rest of the year.

site_title: UK house prices rise more than forecast but slowdown anticipated
summary: UK house prices rose 0.8% in August to £273,751, exceeding forecasts of a 0.1% increase. A shortage of properties for sale is driving prices, but Nationwide warned that a slowdown is likely due to increasing household budget pressure and inflation. The annual pace of gains slowed to 10% from 11%. Mortgage rates are at their highest since 2016, further weighing on affordability. The Bank of England's interest rate hikes are expected to continue, which could further cool the market.

site_title: Nasa orders 5 more astronaut missions from Musk’s SpaceX in US$1.4b deal
summary: NASA has awarded SpaceX a $1.4 billion contract to launch 5 more astronaut missions to the International Space Station by the end of the decade. This deal brings SpaceX's total contracted missions to 14 and maintains a steady run of astronaut flights until 2030. The order is part of NASA's effort to ensure a reliable crew transportation system, as Boeing's Starliner space capsule has faced technical issues. The contract ensures two commercial crew industry partners will support NASA's human access to the space station.

images.alt_text: The 98-metre-tall rocket is scheduled to embark on its first mission to space - without any humans - on Aug 29.
The Perseverance rover, which landed on Mars in February 2021, has so far collected 11 samples as part of its hunt for signatures of ancient life.

site_title: UK factories suffer worst month since May 2020 as economy stumbles
summary: The UK manufacturing sector experienced its worst month since May 2020, with the S&P Global/CIPS UK Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) dropping to 47.3 in August from 52.1 in July. This decline was attributed to deepening uncertainty over surging inflation and recession risks at home and abroad. Manufacturing output and new orders fell by the most in over 2 years, with the headline figure and measure of new business at their lowest since May 2020.

images.alt_text: Nationwide said a shortage of properties for sale was underpinning prices but warned that the slowdown was likely to continue as the pressure on household budgets intensifies, with inflation set to remain in double digits into next year.
With inflation set to exceed the 13 per cent peak forecast by the Bank of England, workers will be no better off by mid-2023 than they were 20 years earlier.
Food price increases hit 9.3 per cent with milk, margarine and crisps seeing the biggest rises.

site_title: Private rents to rise further but recession could dampen ‘super bull cycle’: Savills
summary: Savills Research forecasts private residential rents in Singapore to rise 15-20% for 2022, up from a previous 10-15% estimate, driven by 11.7% year-to-date growth and a 6.7% quarterly surge in the Urban Redevelopment Authority rental index. Rental increases are expected to continue into 2023 with a 5% on-year rise, despite a recession potentially dampening the "super bull cycle" in the property market. Only two of the top five non-landed projects with the most leasing transactions in Q2 were in the Core Central Region.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Rental volumes also rose month on month for condos and HDB flats, but were lower year on year and when compared to the average 5-year volumes for July.
HDB flats, condominiums, and CBD skyline as viewed from Block 79D Toa Payoh Central on Mar 17, 2022.

ST20211117_202146255160 Kua Chee Siong/ pixgeneric/ Generic pix of private housing in Holland Road with the backdrop of D'Leedon condominium towering over properties in the central part of Singapore on 17 Nov 2021.

site_title: Former Noble directors who were issued ‘stern warnings’ named by Acra
summary: Former directors Neil Timothy Dhar and Timothy Martin Eyre of Noble Resources International received "stern warnings" from the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) for failing to prepare and table annual financial statements in compliance with Singapore's prescribed accounting standards. This comes after previously unmentioned individuals received similar warnings. The Acra spokesperson confirmed the identities of Dhar and Eyre on August 31.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has imposed a civil penalty of S$12.6 million on Noble Group for publishing misleading information in its financial statements for the fiscal years ended December 2012 to 2016.
Investors hurt by Noble Group's misleading disclosures have no relief in Singapore at the moment.
Commodity trader Noble reaches agreement with creditors on US$1 billion of debt

site_title: Logistics, industrial Reits best-placed to weather economic slowdown: Fitch Ratings
summary: Fitch Ratings predicts logistics and industrial Real Estate Investment Trusts (Reits) will be the most resilient against an economic slowdown in 2023, citing rising e-commerce adoption and reshoring of supply chains. These Reits, such as Mapletree Logistics Trust and Mapletree Industrial Trust, will benefit from lower electricity costs and long leases to large corporate tenants. In contrast, hospitality Reits are at risk due to low rating headroom and recovering credit profiles, while retail-focused Reits with prime mall exposure will take longer to recover.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
A-Reit on Aug 4 said it is acquiring the Philips Apac Center in Singapore for S$104.8 million.
Two of Manulife US Reit's biggest tenants are giving up space at Figueroa, a Grade A office building in Los Angeles..
CICT (formerly known as CMT) -- the first Reit to be listed in Singapore -- has generated total return of over 600% since its IPO in 2002.
While the iEdge S-Reit Index has recovered significantly from the depths of the crash at the start of the Covid-19 pandemic, it is still trading at some 10.6 per cent lower than at the start of 2020.

site_title: Indonesia’s headline inflation eases in August, core prices rise
summary: Indonesia's headline inflation rate decreased to 4.69% in August from 4.94% in July, exceeding the central bank's target range of 2-4%. Meanwhile, core consumer prices rose to 3.04%, in line with forecasts. The data suggests that inflation remains above the target, indicating the need for further monetary policy adjustments.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with a 0.97% decline, or 192.67 points, to 19,761.72, amid expected US interest rate hikes to combat inflation. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also fell, with losses of 0.24% and 0.15%, respectively. The decline follows a global trend of market volatility, with US stocks reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Tech platform Starboard raises US$3.5 million in pre-Series A round led by Monk’s Hill Ventures
summary: Tech platform Starboard has raised US$3.5 million in pre-Series A funding led by Monk's Hill Ventures to expand its engineering, operations, and customer success teams. The funds will support users in Singapore, South-east Asia, and the US. Starboard's platform provides digital entity management services, including accounting, compliance, and payroll, for global businesses. The company aims to automate workflows for corporate entity management and governance, increasing productivity and reducing errors for traditional corporate service providers.

site_title: Yen falls to fresh 24-year low as US-Japan policy gap weighs
summary: The Japanese yen fell to its lowest level since 1998, reaching 139.59 per dollar, due to the widening gap in inflation-adjusted yields between the US and Japan. The yen's decline is attributed to the hawkish Federal Reserve and Bank of Japan's differing policy stances, with the Fed's interest rate hikes and the BOJ's continued easing. The real-yield gap has been a significant driver of yen weakness, and officials are expected to intervene to support the currency if it falls to the 140 level, a psychological barrier.

images.alt_text: Against the US dollar, the Japanese currency was on track for a fifth consecutive session of gains on Tuesday (Aug 2), taking its cumulative increase to nearly 4.5 per cent in 5 trading sessions.

site_title: Show stealers at Geneva Watch Days
summary: Geneva Watch Days 2022 showcased 20 brands featuring new timepieces, including the Ulysse Nardin Blast Tourbillon Rainbow and Lady Diver Rainbow, Urwerk's UR-100V Ultraviolet, and De Bethune's DB25 Perpetual Calendar. The Ulysse Nardin models feature silicium escapement components and iridescent rainbow colors, while the UR-100V Ultraviolet celebrates the boundary of human perception with a violet color scheme. The De Bethune DB25 Perpetual Calendar boasts a new movement and 5-day power reserve, limited to 15 pieces per year. Prices range from $13,600 to $145,000.

images.alt_text: The Carerra Red Dial 3.

site_title: Tackling an inconvenient truth in Singapore
summary: Singaporean playwright Alfian Sa'at's new play "Pulau Ujong" explores climate change through a diverse cast of characters, including humans and non-human subjects. The play, which runs from September 15 to October 2, features interviews with stakeholders and incorporates fictional conversations with a banyan tree, a hornbill, and a tiger. Alfian aims to shift the audience's perspective, encouraging empathy and care for the non-human world, rather than simply guilt-tripping them into action. The play is part of Alfian's documentary theatre style, which he has used to tackle hot-button issues in previous works.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Distrik Seni is a new museum-like marketplace for quality art, with works by hot artists such as Mulyana, Hahan and Jompet Kuswidananto.

In 1981, Vanda Miss Joaquim was selected as Singapore's national flower out of 40 orchids that were considered. Artist Marvin Tang uses AI to generate what the other 39 orchids that were rejected could look like.
