site_title: Cathay Pacific sees weaker air cargo peak season this year
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways expects a weaker air cargo peak season this year due to supply chain disruptions, inflation, and China's Covid-19 policies. The airline has relied heavily on cargo revenue since the pandemic, and a decline in consumer demand and product launches may impact its revenue. This contrasts with last year's peak season, which saw record revenue for many air freight carriers. The fourth quarter, typically the busiest period, may not meet expectations, with Cathay freight executives warning of a potentially weaker peak season.

site_title: Asia: Investors step up selling as rate hikes loom
summary: Asia stocks plummeted on Thursday as investors braced for more interest rate hikes to combat inflation, with some analysts warning of a potential recession. The eurozone's record-high inflation rate in August reinforced central banks' determination to tighten monetary policy. US Treasury yields rose further, and a top Fed official signaled the bank would continue to raise borrowing costs, potentially pushing interest rates above 4% by early next year. The dollar surged against other currencies, with some speculating the Bank of Japan might intervene to support the yen.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong and Shanghai-led Asian markets opened lower after a report on Chinese factory activity showed another contraction.

site_title: Australia house prices suffer sharpest fall in 40 years: CoreLogic
summary: Australia's housing prices plummeted 1.6% in July from June, marking the sharpest fall in 40 years, according to CoreLogic. This drop dragged annual price growth down to 4.7%, from a peak above 21% late last year. Rising interest rates and cost-of-living pressures have significantly reduced demand, threatening household wealth and confidence.

images.alt_text: With inflation set to exceed the 13 per cent peak forecast by the Bank of England, workers will be no better off by mid-2023 than they were 20 years earlier.

site_title: South Korea posts record trade deficit on inflation, weaker won
summary: South Korea posted a record trade deficit of $9.5 billion in August, driven by a 28.2% jump in imports due to elevated energy and commodity prices, and a 6.6% increase in exports. The deficit nearly doubled from $4.8 billion in July, amid supply chain disruptions and inflationary pressure. Despite a resilient export growth, the country is headed for its first annual trade deficit since 2008, and its economy is viewed as a key barometer of international demand.

images.alt_text: Women wearing masks walk in a shopping district amid the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic in Seoul, South Korea, November 29, 2021. REUTERS/Heo Ran
Excluding extra budgets, South Korea’s 2023 spending will grow by 5.2 per cent, the slowest since 2017.

site_title: Australia Q2 business investment slips, outlook still upbeat
summary: Australia's private business investment decreased 0.3% in the June quarter, missing forecasts of a 1.5% increase, due to torrential rain and surging costs affecting building work. Despite this, firms upgraded spending plans for the year to A$146.4 billion, up 12% from the previous estimate. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to hike interest rates for a fifth straight month to combat high inflation, with forecasts suggesting rates could peak at 3.85%.

images.alt_text: Figures from property consultant CoreLogic out on Thursday showed prices nationally sank 1.6 per cent in July from June, when they fell 1.3 per cent.

site_title: Chinese junk bonds just chalked up their best month in a decade
summary: Chinese high-yield dollar bonds saw their best returns in 10 years in August, rising 6.8% to end a record 11-month losing streak. Government support for the crisis-hit property sector, including a policy rate cut and state guarantees, fueled the rally. This lifted average prices off all-time lows, although they remain in distressed territory. The rally is seen as a sign that the worst of the market rout may be over, with some developers' offshore notes soaring over 20 cents from record lows.

images.alt_text: Dividend stocks
Bonds or financial management concepts. investment plan.money market forecasting

site_title: Hong Kong’s key borrowing rate surges to highest since 2008
summary: Hong Kong's 3-month interbank offered rate (Hibor) surged to 2.68%, its highest level in 14 years, amid expectations of aggressive rate hikes by major central banks. The rate increase is driven by hawkish monetary policies from the Federal Reserve and European Central Bank, as well as Hong Kong's de-facto monetary authority draining liquidity to cap the currency's decline. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is expected to intervene further to support the market.

site_title: Asia’s manufacturing hubs slumped in August as demand fades
summary: Asia's manufacturing hubs saw a decline in demand in August, with Taiwan's PMI falling to 42.7, its lowest since May 2020, and South Korea's reading at 47.6, its lowest since July 2020. Japan's PMI weakened to 51.5. In contrast, Malaysia's PMI slipped to 50.3, while the Philippines, Indonesia, and Thailand saw increases. The data reflects a slowdown in China, which has been weighing on the region, and adds to the uncertainty of the global economy amid rising interest rates and inflation concerns.

site_title: Golden Agri subsidiary to suspend proposed IPO in India
summary: Golden Agri-Resources announced the suspension of its proposed initial public offering (IPO) for its India subsidiary, Gemini Edibles & Fats India (GEF), due to "adverse and uncertain market conditions". The IPO, initially planned for 2021, aimed to raise approximately US$100 million. The company will continue to explore opportunities to enhance shareholders' value.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: Lufthansa aims to minimise effect of pilots' strike on Friday
summary: Lufthansa aims to minimize the effects of a pilots' strike set to begin on Friday, which will affect both passenger and cargo services. The Vereinigung Cockpit union, representing over 5,000 pilots, is demanding a 5.5% pay rise this year and automatic inflation compensation. The strike comes amid travel disruptions caused by staff shortages and strikes, forcing thousands of flights to be canceled and hours-long queues at major airports. Lufthansa has defended its offer during wage talks, but the strike is expected to cause further frustration for holidaymakers.

images.alt_text: Lufthansa has already been rocked by strike action by its ground staff last Wednesday, which forced the carrier to cancel more than 1,000 flights.

Strikes and staff shortages have already forced airlines including Lufthansa to cancel thousands of flights and caused hours-long queues at major airports, frustrating holidaymakers keen to travel after Covid-19 lockdowns.
Lufthansa said on Thursday it would offer only around 80 per cent of pre-crisis passenger capacity in the third quarter, less than previously planned.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 1.04% and the Topix index down 0.80%. Investors fear no relief from Federal Reserve rate hikes aimed at tamping down inflation. The US market also saw gains, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Japan property lures private equity with solid yields, prospective deals
summary: Private equity firms, including KKR & Co, are entering Japan's property market, drawn by attractive yield spreads and prospective deals. Tokyo's office market has delivered standout returns this year, with a yield spread of 2.063% in the first quarter. Japan's low-interest rates and stabilising vacancy rates are also attracting investors, who are looking to improve returns on under-utilized corporate assets. With $384 billion in global property funds on hand, investors are poised to capitalize on opportunities in Japan, despite relatively slow deal flow.

images.alt_text: The final au Jibun Bank Japan Manufacturing Purchasing Managers’ Index (PMI) fell to a seasonally adjusted 51.5 in August from a final 52.1 in the prior month.

Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida’s “New Capitalism” vision seeks to boost the world’s third-largest economy and aims to double the wealth of households while offering support to help the country’s so-called Web3 businesses grow.

site_title: 3M plans job cuts as part of a broader cost-cutting initiative
summary: 3M plans to cut jobs as part of a broader cost-cutting initiative in response to the slowing economy. The company, which employs 95,000 people, will realign its safety and industrial division, reducing its structure and eliminating positions. The move comes amid underperformance in recent years due to supply-chain issues, currency fluctuations, and rising costs. 3M has also cut its sales and profit outlook and plans to spin off its healthcare operation. The company will adjust roles and responsibilities to prioritize investments and resources for future growth.

images.alt_text: 3M plans to funnel US$1 billion to a trust that would pay people suing over the earplugs and has set aside US$240 million to fund the bankruptcy itself.

site_title: Goldman cuts India’s growth forecast; Morgan Stanley sees downside risks
summary: Goldman Sachs has revised its growth projections for India, cutting its forecast to 7% for 2022-23 from 7.6% due to lower-than-expected quarterly GDP growth. The April-June quarter's growth rate of 13.5% was below the 15.2% forecast by economists polled by Reuters. Morgan Stanley also notes a downside risk of 40 basis points to the current fiscal year growth estimates, citing a decline in GDP momentum and a large drawdown in inventories.

images.alt_text: Fuelled by consumption, India's GDP rose 13.5 per cent in the April-June period from a year ago.

site_title: Stocks to watch: ST Engineering, Sembcorp Marine, Wing Tai
summary: Sembcorp Marine has addressed a cybersecurity incident and relative risks, according to investigations and impact assessments. ST Engineering clinched a S$1.4 billion contract for a new Kaohsiung MRT Yellow Line. Wing Tai Holdings acquired Winnoma Investment's remaining 50% stake for US$18.3 million. The Singapore Stock Exchange Index (STI) rose 0.4% on Thursday, despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Economists downgrade 2022 Singapore GDP forecast to 3.5%, raise core inflation outlook to 3.8%: survey
summary: Singapore's private-sector economists have downgraded their 2022 GDP forecast to 3.5% from 3.8% in June, citing a slowdown in global growth. They also raised their core inflation outlook to 3.8% from 3.4%. The economists expect inflation to ease further in 2023, but warn of potential risks including a global growth slowdown and supply chain stress. The biggest risks to Singapore's economy, according to the survey, are a global growth slowdown and geopolitical tensions, particularly involving Taiwan.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Private-sector economists now expect headline inflation to hit 5 per cent, and core inflation to reach 3.4 per cent for the full year.

site_title: Gold hits 6-week trough on stronger dollar, rate hike worries
summary: Gold prices fell 0.2% to $1,706.99 per ounce, reaching a 6-week low, as the dollar strengthened and interest rate hike concerns weighed on the metal's appeal. The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates above 4% by early next year to combat inflation, increasing the opportunity cost of holding gold. Euro zone inflation jumped to a record high, and US private payrolls increased moderately, further supporting the dollar's rise.

images.alt_text: Even though gold is seen as a hedge against inflation, rate hikes raise the opportunity cost of holding bullion.

site_title: UOB Kay Hian fined S$375,000 for business conduct compliance failures
summary: UOB Kay Hian, a brokerage firm in Singapore, was fined S$375,000 for failing to comply with business conduct and anti-money laundering requirements. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) discovered these failures during an inspection, including accepting third-party receipts without due diligence and failing to verify customers' source of wealth. The firm was also found to have lacked effective compliance controls, including inadequate involvement of its compliance function. UOB Kay Hian has since paid the penalty and taken remedial measures to enhance its internal policies and controls.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
The significant drop in group revenue in the first half reflected the contraction of trading volumes in the major markets it operates in.
GoTo's offering is pricier than peers Bukalapak, Bank Neo Commerce: UOBKH

site_title: Japan’s Aug factory activity growth drops to near one-year low: PMI
summary: Japan's manufacturing activity contracted at its weakest rate in nearly a year in August, with the PMI falling to 51.5 from 52.1 in the prior month. This decline was driven by worsening global conditions, declining demand from China and South Korea, and a second straight month of declines in output and new orders. The reading remains above the 50-mark but is the weakest growth rate since September 2021, indicating a warning sign for global growth.

images.alt_text: The panel has already set targets for domestic production capacity of EV and energy storage batteries at 150 gigawatt hours (GWh) by 2030, and global capacity of Japanese makers at 600 GWh.

Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida’s “New Capitalism” vision seeks to boost the world’s third-largest economy and aims to double the wealth of households while offering support to help the country’s so-called Web3 businesses grow.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 0.93% lower on Thursday, down 14.05 points to 1,498.00, with 283 losers outnumbering 95 gainers. The lower opening was attributed to a mix of global market trends and local economic factors.

site_title: Singapore’s first digital bank Trust Bank launches
summary: Singapore's first digital bank, Trust Bank, has launched with savings accounts and credit card offerings for retail customers. Unlike other digital banks, Trust Bank has acquired a full bank licence, allowing it to offer a full suite of banking products. Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong stated that the launch highlights the potential for the banking sector to relook its approach and serve customers better with greater digital adoption.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
ANEXT is the latest digital bank to be unveiled in Singapore.
From left: Kavita Bedi, UOB’s country head of business banking Singapore; Lawrence Loh, head of group business banking; and Rosalind Lee, head of enterprise banking, at the launch of the UOB SME app.
GXS Bank CEO Charles Wong believes that there are segments in Singapore not well-served by banks.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Thursday; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.3% to 3210.6 points on Thursday, with losers outweighing gainers 63 to 39. The decline came as global markets took a beating. Oceanus was the most traded counter, dropping 6.3% after 26.4 million shares changed hands. Among index counters, Singtel traded 0.8% lower after 3.2 million shares changed hands.

images.alt_text: The key Straits Times Index fell on Wednesday after US stocks logged their third straight day of losses on more hawkish posturings by Fed officials
The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 36.28 points, or 0.11 per cent, at the open to 31,827.15.

site_title: Thailand lures rich foreigners with 10-year visa, tax breaks
summary: Thailand has launched a 10-year visa program for top professionals, high-net-worth individuals, and retirees, aiming to attract one million wealthy or talented foreigners over the next five years. The program, launched on September 1, 2022, seeks to boost the country's economy, which is expected to grow 3.3% this year, and generate $38 billion in annual economic activities. The move aims to tap into remote talent and add value to Thailand's economy, particularly in industries such as electric vehicles and digital technology.

images.alt_text: Thailand hopes to tap into “pent-up demand” from the multi-billion dollar Indian wedding industry.
Thailand is benefiting from a rebound in global travel demand with authorities scrapping all pandemic-era restrictions that kept visitors out for almost 2 years.
Even with some salaries going up, many Thais will find their pay increases eaten up by the cost of goods they buy.

site_title: ST Engineering unit bags S$1.4 billion turnkey rail project for new Kaohsiung MRT Yellow Line
summary: ST Engineering's subsidiary Urban Solutions has won a S$1.4 billion contract to provide turnkey rail services for the new Kaohsiung MRT Yellow Line in Taiwan. The 10-year project includes rail electronics solutions, above-ground train depot design, and construction. ST Engineering's unit will also manage the project and serve as the systems integration lead. The contract is expected to have minimal impact on the company's net tangible assets per share and earnings per share.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Taiwan invests in next generation of talent with slew of chip schools
Taiwan to set up US$200m fund to invest in Lithuania amid dispute with China

site_title: UK households facing biggest living standards shock in a century
summary: The UK is facing the biggest living standards shock in a century, with inflation set to exceed 13% peak forecast, leaving households £3,000 worse off and 3 million more people in poverty by mid-2023. The Resolution Foundation warns that workers will be no better off than they were 20 years earlier unless the next prime minister delivers tens of billions of pounds of additional support, including an energy support package worth tens of billions of pounds.

images.alt_text: Food price increases hit 9.3 per cent with milk, margarine and crisps seeing the biggest rises.
British credit and debit card spending in “delayable” and “social” areas, are down by 8 and 4 points respectively.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit 5-week low as miners weigh; BHP drops nearly 8%
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index fell 2.1% to 6,8430 points, its lowest level in five weeks, as mining stocks declined and major banks tracked a US sell-off. Export-reliant miners, including BHP, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue Metals, shed between 1.2% and 7.9%. Financials fell 1.8%, with all "Big Four" banks sliding over 1%. Energy stocks also declined, with oil prices slipping on worries of a hit to the global economy from renewed Covid-19 restrictions in China.

site_title: Alibaba’s Lazada plans Europe push to challenge Amazon, Zalando
summary: Alibaba's Lazada plans to expand into Europe, targeting Amazon and Zalando in the largest online shopping market. Lazada Group CEO James Dong stated the company will go where brands want it to, without specifying the timeline or European countries to enter. This move aims to revive Alibaba's global ambitions, following a slowdown in recent years. Lazada has had success in South-east Asia and is investing in Indonesian digital wallet provider Dana and Malaysia's e-wallet company Touch 'n Go. The company aims to serve over 300 million users by 2030.

images.alt_text: Touch ‘n Go Group CEO Effendy Shahul Hamid said:”The collaboration will bring next-level value propositions to users and merchant bases across the Lazada and Touch ‘n Go ecosystem.”

site_title: UK mortgage turmoil threatens a 70% surge in average costs
summary: The UK mortgage market is experiencing turmoil due to a dramatic rise in swap rates, which could lead to a 70% surge in average mortgage costs by March. Lenders have responded by pulling over 40% of their mortgage products, and the average 2-year fixed-rate mortgage is expected to increase to £1,325. This rise in borrowing costs threatens to undermine affordability and potentially cause home deals to fall apart, with the price of new-build homes expected to fall 15% in 2024.

images.alt_text: A person walks with a dog in front of a row of residential housing in south London, Britain, August 6, 2021. REUTERS/Henry Nicholls

site_title: Australia: Shares mark best day in 3 months on resources boost
summary: Australia's shares rose 1.4% on Thursday, marking their best day in 3 months, driven by gains in commodity companies and a rebound in global equity markets. The Bank of England launched an emergency bond-buying program to calm its bond markets, which had been impacted by a global sell-off in equities. Commodity indexes, particularly miners and gold stocks, led the gains, while the financial index rose 1% with the "Big Four" banks firming in the range of 1.1% to 1.7%.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 1.7 per cent by 0024 GMT on Thursday.

site_title: First Reit secures 1.7 billion yen social loan to partially fund nursing home acquisitions
summary: First Reit secures 1.7 billion yen social loan from Shinsei Bank to partially fund 2 nursing home acquisitions in Japan. The loan, valued at S$16.9 million, aims to secure houses for the elderly and promote women's active participation in society. The loan is expected to have minimal impact on the trust's leverage ratio and aligns with the United Nations' Sustainable Development Goals of good health and well-being, gender equality, and decent work and economic growth.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng

site_title: UK long bonds poised for record rally as BOE moves to stem crash
summary: The UK's 30-year bonds are poised for a record rally after the Bank of England (BOE) stepped in to calm a disorderly market, driven by forced selling from pension funds. The yield on 30-year gilts plummeted as much as 100 basis points to below 4% after the BOE announced temporary purchases of long-dated debt and delayed planned bond sales. This move injected confidence into the UK's bond market, which had shown signs of collapse following the new government's spending plans.

images.alt_text: The BOE says the purchases are designed to restore orderly market conditions.

site_title: Telcos and streaming – Here’s how it can actually work
summary: Telcos are exploring bundling their broadband capacity with streaming offerings to redefine their consumer value proposition and monetize their content delivery infrastructure. By partnering with streaming services and leveraging their extensive customer data, telcos aim to increase revenue and customer loyalty. Successful telcos, such as StarHub in Singapore, have seen significant growth by offering exclusive content and seamless experiences. As the industry continues to evolve, local platforms are expected to replicate Netflix's approach to producing content based on audience preferences, while leveraging AI and data analytics to inform their decision-making.

images.alt_text: Apac telcos seek pricing power, economies of scale through M&A
Singtel group enterprise chief executive Bill Chang believes the company will need to digitalise and scale its operations to make up for pressure on margins.

site_title: Singapore moves up a spot in Global Innovation Index 2022
summary: Singapore has moved up to seventh place in the Global Innovation Index 2022, maintaining its leadership position in the region. The US moved up to second, while Switzerland retained the top spot. However, challenges in translating innovation investments into impact are emerging, with stalled productivity growth and slowing technology adoption. The World Intellectual Property Organisation warns that it will take time for innovation waves to materialise, with obstacles in adoption and diffusion.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Netflix, as with other household tech names, redefined the industry years ago when it launched its online streaming service in 2007. Can it maintain its dominance in the space it helped create?
Danny Chua, president of the Association of Process Industry, at ASPRI's 25th anniversary dinner on Jul 20.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on mining, energy boost
summary: Australia's shares rose 0.5% on Tuesday, driven by gains in mining and energy stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index hit a three-month low on Monday but recovered as investors took a breather after a sharp sell-off. Mining companies like BHP and Rio Tinto rose 1% each, while energy stocks like Woodside Energy gained 1.2%. The gains were limited by declines in the financials and tech sectors.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped as much as 1.9 per cent by 0022 GMT on Monday, its lowest since June 21.

site_title: Clean, customised and creative: Ingredients for success for Singapore F&B founders
summary: Singaporean food and beverage (F&B) founders are capitalizing on the growing demand for home-grown foods, with a focus on localised flavors and clean labels. Companies like Melvados, Batu Lesung Spice Company, and Jill's Sausages are adapting their products to cater to health-conscious consumers. The pandemic has been a game-changer for these businesses, with sales surging for companies that sold food products to the public and experienced a trend of food gifting. As a result, these companies are exploring opportunities for expansion, including exporting their products to other countries and collaborating with international brands.

images.alt_text: Batu Lesung Spice Company, founded by Jeremy Nguee, saw its sales spike during the circuit breaker as diners began cooking at home instead.
Nicholas Lee set up Jill’s Sausages to produce and sell gourmet cooked and smoked sausages, hams and deli meats targeting the Asian market.
Melvados will be opening its 9th and 10th stores here in November. It is targeting to have 15 stores in Singapore in the next 2 years.

site_title: Heartfelt Japanese-Italian cooking at La D’Oro
summary: Chef Yohhei Sasaki's new eatery, La D'Oro, offers a unique Japanese-Italian fusion experience with Italian-style omakase in a semi-private dining room. The menu features dishes such as takibi (grilled mackerel in creamy burrata sauce), snow-aged A4 Wagyu carpaccio, and uni pasta with bottarga. The restaurant's autumn-inspired menu is served in a cozy, all-black interior with warm lighting. A 5-course dinner costs S$188, while an 8-course dinner without supplements is S$258. Sasaki's passion for his craft is evident, with a focus on high-quality ingredients and creative flavor combinations. Overall, La D'Oro is a standout restaurant that showcases Sasaki's culinary talents.

images.alt_text: Hazuki's Gucci-inspired interiors.

site_title: Global bonds tumble as UK tax cuts deliver fresh headwinds
summary: Global government bond markets are on track for their worst year since 1949, with UK tax cuts fueling concerns about increased government spending and central bank hawkishness. US and German debt slid, while equities and the pound plummeted. Investors fear the pressure on governments to deliver cost of living relief, which may lead central banks to raise interest rates further. The yield on US 10-year Treasuries climbed to 3.72%, while the pound dropped 4.7% to a record low, prompting a sell-off across major currencies and stock indexes.

site_title: Pound plunge extends as UK’s Kwarteng signals more tax cut
summary: The UK's pound has plummeted to a 37-year low against the dollar, with the currency trading at $1.08, amid the government's "Growth Plan" which includes significant tax cuts. Chancellor Kwarteng has vowed to press on with more tax cuts, despite financial markets' dismal reaction, and warned that there's "more to come." The government's borrowing needs are estimated to be £400 billion over the next five years, which could lead to a dramatic increase in interest rates and a potential crisis.

images.alt_text: Sterling fell as low as US$1.1151 – its weakest since early 1985 – after the Bank of England on Thursday hiked borrowing costs by 50 basis points.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.54% at 26,574.95, and the Topix index edging up 0.40%. Investors sought bargains following sharp falls in the previous session due to fears of an economic slowdown.

site_title: France says inflation control is the main priority for 2023 budget
summary: France's Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire said controlling inflation is the top priority for the 2023 budget, amid unprecedented uncertainty due to the ongoing war in Ukraine. The government has budgeted 45 billion euros to cap gas and power price increases at 15%, with a net cost of 12 billion euros. Despite a forecasted 1% economic growth, the public sector budget deficit is expected to remain steady at 5% of economic output, meeting EU-imposed ceilings by 2027.

site_title: IMF tells UK to ‘re-evaluate’ tax cut as global criticism mounts
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has criticized the UK's new tax cuts as excessive and in need of revision, citing elevated inflation pressures and potential to increase inequality. The IMF urges Chancellor Kwasi Kwarteng to re-evaluate the tax measures, particularly those benefiting high-income earners, and consider more targeted support. The IMF's comments come as the UK's economic plan has sent the pound to a record low and drawn concern from international policymakers and economists.

images.alt_text: Markets have given the UK Chancellor's budget proposals a big “thumbs down” with the most negative reaction to any UK fiscal event in living memory.

site_title: The climate crisis in our backyard
summary: Wild Rice's new production "Pulau Ujong" tackles the environmental damage Singapore inflicts on itself, featuring real-life Singapore-based environmental professionals, activists, and scientists. The play uses non-human characters, such as an orangutan, banyan tree, and hornbill, to highlight the consequences of human actions, while also showcasing the importance of sustainability. With a strong production design and performances, "Pulau Ujong" urges the audience to confront the environmental crisis and fight for a more sustainable future.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Pulau Ujong, a play about climate change in Singapore, stars (clockwise from extreme left) Ryan Ang, Krish Natarajan, Al-Matin Yatim, Koh Wan Ching and Siti Khalijah Zainal.

Photographer Aik Beng Chia takes over one of the units in Peace Centre and transforms it into a Club Hawaii-like experience to showcase his photographs. (Club Hawaii is one of the oldest nightclubs in Singapore.)
Distrik Seni is a new museum-like marketplace for quality art, with works by hot artists such as Mulyana, Hahan and Jompet Kuswidananto.

site_title: Financial markets enter a dangerous new phase
summary: Financial markets worldwide are experiencing distress due to a strong US dollar and surging interest rates, causing global currencies to weaken against the dollar. The US Federal Reserve's commitment to crushing inflation has led to a relentless rise in interest rates, affecting markets globally. A global slowdown may not bring about a weaker dollar, as investors seek the relative safety of the greenback during downturns. As a result, commodity prices are falling, and companies are downgrading their profit forecasts, leading to stress in financial markets.

images.alt_text: hd wallpaper, us dollars, american
Markets have found themselves scrambling to price in a “HFL” moment —rates that are going Higher, getting there Faster, and staying there Longer.

site_title: Singapore food vendors launch first hawker centre in New York
summary: Singapore's first hawker centre, Urban Hawker, has opened in Midtown Manhattan, New York, featuring 17 vendors serving traditional Singaporean dishes such as chilli crab, oyster omelettes, and Hainanese chicken rice. The market was curated by KF Seetoh, who met US celebrity chef Anthony Bourdain in 2013 and was inspired by the idea of bringing Singaporean street food to the US. The market aims to replicate the authentic Singaporean dining experience, with vendors preparing meals in a traditional six-hour process.

images.alt_text: More than 80 per cent of the US population has not been eating enough vegetables, fruit and dairy, while consuming unhealthy amounts of added sugars, saturated fat and sodium in their diet, the FDA said.

Even though the current strata retail market is nowhere near the sales performances recorded in 2012 and 2013, there are promising signs that interest in strata-titled retail space could rekindle in the next 12 to 18 months. While the lingering threat of Covid-19 remains, Singapore has resolutely reopened at a time when revenge travel and shopping is gaining momentum.

site_title: Japan PM Kishida says ready to act again to support yen
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida announced the country's readiness to intervene in the foreign exchange market to support the yen, which has been battered due to the Bank of Japan's ultra-low interest rates. This is the first time Japan has intervened since 1998. Kishida stated that excessive yen movement due to speculation cannot be overlooked and that the government will take action if necessary to shore up the currency. The move aims to mitigate the impact of rising prices on households and retailers.

images.alt_text: The yen has depreciated nearly 20 per cent this year, sinking to 24-year lows.
The US dollar was last down 1.17 per cent at 142.42 yen. It hit a low of 140.31 after the intervention, having earlier reached a fresh 24-year peak of 145.9 yen.
Indonesia was also more aggressive than expected and Vietnam made a rare move, while Switzerland ended Europe’s experiment with subzero rates.

site_title: Russia plans to use digital rouble in settlements with China, says lawmaker
summary: Russia plans to use its digital rouble in mutual settlements with China, aiming to reduce Washington's global financial hegemony. The move follows Russia's development of digital money to modernize its financial system and speed up payments. The digital rouble was launched early next year, with the central bank conducting tests with banks amid sanctions that have limited Russia's access to global financial markets. Russia hopes to launch the digital rouble for mutual settlements with China, which has already tested its digital yuan, to bypass Western-controlled systems and gain more financial independence.

images.alt_text: Peter Szijjarto, Foreign Minister of Hungary, says: “Without Russian energy, the Hungarian economy would not be able to operate.”

site_title: Japan unlikely to intervene to stem weak yen, half of economists say in poll
summary: Japan is unlikely to intervene to stop the yen's decline, with over half of economists polled saying the government will not buy yen to halt further weakening. The yen has lost nearly 20% against the US dollar this year, hitting a 24-year low of 144.99. Economists expect a widening gap between Japan's loose monetary policy and global peers to prompt policymakers to act, but a slim majority believe direct intervention is a long shot.

images.alt_text: Banknotes of Japanese yen are seen in this illustration picture taken June 15, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration

This photo taken on September 17, 2022 shows people shopping at a clothing store in the Motomachi shopping street in Yokohama, Kanagawa prefecture, south of Tokyo. - Inflation in Japan hit 2.8 percent in August, the highest level since 2014, government data showed on September 20, 2022 as soaring energy prices bite. (Photo by Richard A. Brooks / AFP)

site_title: Spotify offers 300,000 audiobook titles for purchase
summary: Spotify has introduced a new audiobook offering, allowing users to purchase and download 300,000 titles on a pay-per-download basis, a departure from its monthly subscription model for music and podcasts. Users will purchase audiobooks through a separate webpage, which will then be available in their Spotify libraries. This move marks a shift for the Swedish company, which typically relies on its subscription-based model for music and podcasts.

images.alt_text: Spotify Technology will slow hiring growth by 25 per cent, the latest sign of how fears of a recession are weighing on the economy.
As the streaming field gets more crowded, the biggest media companies have turned to giants in other industries to find new subscribers.

site_title: The cost of death
summary: The cost of death can be overwhelming, with funeral expenses ranging from simple ceremonies to elaborate events. In Singapore, funeral companies offer various options, including eco-friendly choices such as biodegradable urns and wicker caskets. Luxury funerals can cost upwards of $50,000, while more affordable options start at around $1,500. Funeral directors emphasize the importance of needs-driven services and encourage families to plan ahead to avoid financial burdens. Despite the costs, many funeral companies offer pro-bono services for underprivileged individuals.

images.alt_text: Founded in 1990, Nirvana provides funeral, burial and cremation services for humans and pets. It also has a presence in Singapore, Thailand and Indonesia, according to its website.
The queen’s coffin was made at least 32 years ago of English oak, which is lined with lead, a royal tradition to help preserve the corpse for longer after its burial in a crypt.

site_title: Developer China Fortune Land’s debt plan meets with resistance
summary: China Fortune Land Development's offshore debt restructuring plan, aiming to push out repayment by 8 years, faces opposition from creditors, including an ad-hoc group representing over 25% of dollar-note principal outstanding. The plan, which could recover about 30% of original investment by 2023, has been met with skepticism due to the developer's lack of progress in onshore restructuring efforts. Creditors are increasingly turning to courts for resolution, highlighting the potentially lengthy and difficult process for bondholders to recover values from the sector.

images.alt_text: Homebuyers are boycotting 342 projects in 119 cities, up from about 320 in 100 cities in early August.

site_title: Grab sees no big layoffs despite weak market
summary: Grab, South-east Asia's largest ride-hailing and food delivery firm, does not anticipate mass layoffs despite the weak market. Chief operating officer Alex Hungate attributed the company's cautious hiring approach to its desire to conserve capital. Grab has selectively hired for specialized roles, such as data science and mapping technology, while reining in its financial service ambitions. The company's focus on higher-margin business lines, including selling lending products and insurance, is expected to improve its profitability. Grab's cash liquidity of $7.7 billion is among the highest in the industry.

images.alt_text: Sea’s e-commerce arm Shopee is axing more employees as its parent company Sea faces pressure to turn profitable.

site_title: Startup layoffs mount amid market chill
summary: Tech startups in South-East Asia are bracing for more layoffs amid an uncertain market and funding slowdown. E-commerce player Shopee is cutting staff, including in human resources and product engineering, as its parent company Sea faces pressure to turn profitable. Other companies, such as foodpanda and gaming unit Garena, are also reducing staff. Despite cost-cutting, the industry still faces a talent crunch, with recruitment platform Glints noting a rise in remote hiring and a shift towards more cost-effective hiring solutions.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Claudia Chong
Sharanya Pillai
Shopee’s parent company, Sea, has taken massive cost-cutting steps in recent months as it battles increasingly uncertain macroeconomic conditions.
Even as startups face a tighter funding environment and macroeconomic headwinds, venture debt firms are still seeing opportunities in this climate.

site_title: New Zealand: Shares inch higher on Thursday, Australian markets closed
summary: New Zealand shares rose 0.1% to 11,509 on Thursday, driven by gains in healthcare, consumer, and technology firms. The benchmark index was also boosted by improving consumer sentiment, which saw a 9-point increase in the consumer confidence index to 87.6. In contrast, global markets declined, with the MSCI's gauge of stocks worldwide down 0.2% and Japan's Nikkei down 0.9%. Key stocks that led gains in New Zealand included Sky Network Television, Air New Zealand, and Stride Property.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index closed 1.6 per cent lower at 6,700.2, marking its third session of fall in 4.

site_title: JD Sports to pay former CEO Cowgill £5.5m after exit
summary: JD Sports Fashion has agreed to pay former CEO Peter Cowgill at least £5.5 million as part of an exit deal following his ouster in May. Cowgill will not work or advise competitors, cannot solicit employees, and will serve as a consultant to support the company's leadership. He will receive £3.5 million over two years and £2 million over three years, plus his salary, benefits, and bonus. The deal comes amid regulatory issues and a series of fines for the company, including a £5 million fine for breaching competition law.

site_title: Private market assets not immune from interest rate and inflation challenges
summary: Private market assets, including private equity, are facing challenges from interest rate and inflation concerns. The macro environment is uncertain, with ongoing conflicts and market volatility. As a result, investors are seeking alternative assets that can generate uncorrelated returns. Private equity assets under management have grown significantly in recent years, but now face challenges such as persistent inflation, slower growth, and higher financing costs. Investors will need to be more discerning and expect lower returns, with median net internal rate of returns potentially falling below 15%.

site_title: Man sets himself on fire near Japan PM’s office
summary: A man set himself on fire near Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's office in Tokyo on September 21, 2022, while protesting against a state funeral for assassinated former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe. The man, who expressed opposition to the funeral, was taken to hospital unconscious. A police officer was injured while trying to extinguish the fire, and a note was found expressing the man's opposition. The funeral, which is rare in Japan, has been controversial, with polls showing about half the public opposed to the idea.

images.alt_text: Liberal Democratic Party Secretary-General Toshimitsu Motegi said a probe found some lawmakers had accepted support for election campaigns from the church and its spin-off groups.

This photo taken on September 17, 2022 shows people shopping at a clothing store in the Motomachi shopping street in Yokohama, Kanagawa prefecture, south of Tokyo. - Inflation in Japan hit 2.8 percent in August, the highest level since 2014, government data showed on September 20, 2022 as soaring energy prices bite. (Photo by Richard A. Brooks / AFP)

Prime Minister Fumio Kishida, who has seen public support for his Cabinet slump in recent weeks, faces pressure from his ruling coalition for fresh measures to prop up his ratings and a fragile economy.

site_title: US plans funds for new Atlantic grouping on ocean health, security
summary: The US has led an initiative of 18 Atlantic nations to boost cooperation on ocean health and security, with a $100 million funding commitment. The nations aim to combat piracy, unregulated fishing, and pollution, while exploring economic opportunities. They also plan to develop a "sustainable ocean economy" and improve search and rescue operations. The move is part of the Biden administration's growing focus on environmental cooperation, following similar efforts in the Pacific and Arctic regions.

images.alt_text: Liner shipping has in general either yielded very thin profits or has been loss making from the early years of containerisation.

site_title: China willing to make effort for peaceful ‘reunification’ with Taiwan: government spokesperson
summary: China's government spokesperson, Ma Xiaoguang, stated that the country is willing to make efforts for a peaceful "reunification" with Taiwan, following weeks of military manoeuvres near the island. China claims Taiwan as its own territory, while Taiwan's government rejects sovereignty claims and says only its people can decide its future. China has proposed a "one country, two systems" model, but it has been rejected by all Taiwanese parties and has little public support. China has not renounced the use of force to bring Taiwan under its control, citing a 2005 law allowing military action against Taiwan.

images.alt_text: The island’s export orders, a bellwether of global technology demand, unexpectedly fell in July.
An Air Force aircraft of China's People's Liberation Army (PLA) takes part in military exercises in the waters around Taiwan on Aug 4.
China’s application of Covid Zero is acting as a deterrent to European firms because of its inflexible and inconsistent implementation.

site_title: Terra founder Kwon under more pressure from crypto collapse
summary: South Korea's Foreign Ministry has requested to revoke Do Kwon's passport, which could force the Terraform Labs founder to return to Seoul within 14 days if approved. Kwon, who is in Singapore, faces allegations of capital-markets law violations and is wanted by a court in South Korea. The collapse of TerraUSD and Luna in May led to a $60 billion wipeout and shook faith in the digital-asset sector, with estimated 280,000 South Korean investors affected. Kwon has expressed a willingness to cooperate with authorities.

images.alt_text: Do Kwon found himself at the centre of one of crypto’s biggest blowups when TerraUSD crumbled from its dollar peg and brought down the ecosystem he had built.

site_title: Apple to hike App Store prices in several countries from Oct
summary: Apple announced it will hike App Store prices in several countries, including Japan, Malaysia, and euro territories, starting October 5. The price increase reflects new regulations requiring Apple to collect and remit applicable taxes, including a 5% value-added tax (VAT) and corporate income tax (CIT) in Vietnam. The changes aim to comply with local tax laws and ensure fair compensation for developers.

site_title: Italy’s election may undermine EU stance on Ukraine war
summary: Italy's upcoming election may impact the EU's stance on the Ukraine war. Giorgia Meloni, leader of the far-right Brothers of Italy party, is likely to become prime minister and may shift Italy's position, as public opinion in Italy favors a peace deal (52%) compared to other EU countries (16-22%). Meloni claims to be pro-Nato and pro-Ukraine, but her right-wing coalition has expressed lukewarm support for Ukraine and has ties to Russia. A new government may eventually shift stance on the conflict, potentially undermining EU unity against Moscow.

images.alt_text: Italian Prime Minister Mario Draghi's resignation has precipitated an unexpected general election in September.
Italy's Prime Minister Mario Draghi looks on during the debate on government crisis following his resignation the week before, at the Senate in Rome on July 20, 2022.

site_title: Four feared dead after typhoon hits Japan
summary: Typhoon Nanmadol made landfall in Japan's southwestern city of Kagoshima on Sunday, causing widespread damage and killing at least four people, with another two found "without vital signs." The storm dumped a month's worth of rain in 24 hours, toppling trees and smashing windows, leaving 140,000 homes without power. At least 114 people were injured, with 14 seriously. The storm is part of Japan's typhoon season, which sees around 20 storms per year, with climate change increasing storm severity and frequency.

site_title: Why Italy’s election could be blockbuster
summary: Italy is set to hold a pivotal election on November 25, which could trigger a potential political earthquake in Europe. Polls indicate that far-right leader Giorgia Meloni is likely to win, potentially forming a coalition with other right-wing parties that could secure a two-thirds majority in the legislature, allowing for far-reaching constitutional changes, including a shift from a prime ministerial to a presidential system. This could have significant international repercussions, particularly given Italy's membership in the G7 and its large economy, and could impact the wider West.

images.alt_text: Italian Prime Minister Mario Draghi's resignation has precipitated an unexpected general election in September.

site_title: Elton John to perform at the White House
summary: Elton John, 75, is set to perform at the White House on September 23, as part of a celebration of his record-breaking career. The event, titled "A Night When Hope and History Rhyme," will feature remarks from President Joe Biden and First Lady Jill Biden, and is part of a return to public events at the White House. The performance follows a recent show by James Taylor and marks the latest stop on John's farewell tour, which will feature over 300 gigs worldwide before wrapping up in Sweden next year.

images.alt_text: Elton John vows to keep making music as he turns 75

site_title: Japan's inflation hits near 8-year high, stays above BOJ's target
summary: Japan's inflation rate hit a near 8-year high of 2.8% in August, exceeding the Bank of Japan's 2% target for the fifth straight month. Core consumer inflation, excluding volatile food and fuel costs, rose 2.7%, driven by higher utility bills, food and grocery prices, and fading mobile phone charge cuts. Analysts expect core inflation to exceed 3% in October, potentially prompting the BOJ to reconsider its ultra-easy policy stance. The BOJ will meet on September 22 to assess economic recovery and interest rates.

images.alt_text: This photo taken on September 17, 2022 shows people shopping at a clothing store in the Motomachi shopping street in Yokohama, Kanagawa prefecture, south of Tokyo. - Inflation in Japan hit 2.8 percent in August, the highest level since 2014, government data showed on September 20, 2022 as soaring energy prices bite. (Photo by Richard A. Brooks / AFP)
Banknotes of Japanese yen are seen in this illustration picture taken June 15, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration

site_title: More Americans are stuck with long-term credit-card debt
summary: US consumers are struggling to pay down credit-card debt, with 60% carrying balances for at least a year and 40% for over 2 years. High inflation and rising interest rates are exacerbating the issue, with day-to-day expenses and emergency expenses cited as primary reasons for carrying balances. Total consumer debt rose $23.8 billion in July to a record $4.64 trillion, and experts predict higher delinquencies as interest rates are set to rise for the fifth time this year.

images.alt_text: Unemployment among people in China aged 16 to 24 stands at almost 19 per cent, after hitting a record 20 per cent in July, according to government data.
Alternative view: The US economy is poised for significant sustained growth, with the removal of impediments to inclusive growth.

site_title: Making service great again
summary: Singapore's F&B sector is facing severe staff shortages, with many eateries at risk of closure due to understaffing and rising labor costs. Automation and technological solutions, such as robots, are being explored as a long-term fix to the manpower crisis. Despite initial barriers, some entrepreneurs are successfully implementing automation, citing improved productivity and scalability. However, the industry needs to invest in career development and provide attractive working conditions to retain staff. If not addressed, the shortage may lead to a "downgrading" of Singapore's F&B scene and rising prices, prompting a "reset" of staff salaries to reflect the true value of service to consumers.

images.alt_text: A Google robot carrying a bag of chips during a media demo at a micro-kitchen in Google’s robotics research space in Mountain View, California, US; August 2022.  Particularly in the hospitality and healthcare sectors in Singapore, critical business needs will demand an acceleration of robotics adoption.
“We don’t have enough workers in the United States of America to fill all the job openings that are out there,” Labor Secretary Marty Walsh said.

site_title: Upset by high prices, GM’s Cruise develops its own chips for self-driving cars
summary: General Motors' autonomous driving unit Cruise has developed its own custom chips for self-driving cars, aiming to reduce costs and scale up production. The move follows Tesla's playbook, shifting away from Nvidia's products. Cruise's custom chips will power its Origin vehicle with no pedals or steering wheel, set to be deployed by 2025. The in-house chip development will help increase driving range and reduce power consumption, making personal ownership of autonomous vehicles viable.

images.alt_text: The first dividend, at the rate of 9 cents per share on the company’s common stock, will be paid on Sep 15, 2022, GM said in a statement.

site_title: Pasir Panjang redevelopment site for sale with guide price of over S$18m
summary: A freehold residential redevelopment site at 303/305 Pasir Panjang Road in Singapore has been put up for sale by tender with an indicative guide price of over S$18 million, based on its land area of 16,379 square feet. The site, located near the National University of Singapore and National University Hospital, has direct access to the West Coast Park and is 2 km from the Haw Par Villa MRT Station. The sale is expected to attract keen interest due to its strategic location and fast turnaround time.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
The site is located in the downtown District 7 and is a 5 minutes walk to Nicoll Highway and Lavender MRT stations.
The low-rise development was built in 1996 and has a total of 163 units.

When completed in 2026, Solitaire on Cecil will rise to 127 metres and comprise predominantly office space, which will be on 15 levels ranging from 11,000 sq ft to 13,000 sq ft.




Source: Solitaire Cecil Pte Ltd

site_title: Retrenchments fall to a record low in Q2 while job vacancies ease: MOM
summary: Singapore's retrenchments fell to a record low in Q2 with 990 layoffs, down from 1,320 in the previous quarter. Job vacancies decreased slightly to 126,100, but remained at "historical high levels." Unemployment rates held steady at 2.1% overall and 2.9% for residents. Non-resident employment rose, but remains 10% below pre-pandemic levels. The labor market is expected to remain tight for the next 3-6 months due to uneven recovery and supply constraints.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh

“Hiring activity in Singapore is expected to remain brisk as employers continue to scale up their hiring to fill their backlog of vacancies,” said Linda Teo, country manager of ManpowerGroup Singapore.
Dark clouds above Singapore's central business district. With growth slowing and inflation rising, tougher times may lie ahead.

site_title: F1 unlikely to return to Malaysia anytime soon: circuit chief
summary: Malaysia is unlikely to host Formula One (F1) again anytime soon due to the country's focus on rebuilding its economy after the COVID-19 pandemic. The Sepang International Circuit's CEO, Azhan Shafriman, stated that the government may reconsider its options in two to three years when the economy stabilizes. The circuit previously hosted F1 from 1999 to 2017, but dropped out of the calendar in 2018 due to rising costs. For F1 to return, the government must assess the benefits and consider factors such as sports tourism, technology transfer, and environmental sustainability.

images.alt_text: Vettel has won 4 successive titles from 2010 to 2013.
The Alpine team's Fernando Alonso (left) placed second at the Formula One F1 race in Montreal, Canada.  He has signed a multi-year contract with Aston Martin.

site_title: Typhoon Muifa lashes eastern China, forcing 1.6 million from their homes
summary: Typhoon Muifa made landfall in eastern China, forcing around 1.6 million people to evacuate their homes. The storm, with winds of up to 82 km/h, caused heavy rainfall, traffic tailbacks, and floods in the Yangtze river delta region. No immediate reports of deaths or casualties were reported. Flights to Shanghai's main airports were grounded, but operations at some major container shipping ports were scheduled to resume. This is the strongest tropical cyclone to hit Shanghai since 1949.

images.alt_text: Shanghai will suspend some operations of its port including Yangshan terminal and others from Tuesday evening and halt all operations on Wednesday morning, according to the Shanghai International Shipping Institute.
Initial reports suggested limited damage and minor flooding around Shanghai, though local media reported that more than 400,000 people were evacuated.

site_title: Japan’s contradictory stance leaves yen at risk of further slide
summary: Japan's contradictory stance on inflation and growth is adding to the yen's weakness, with officials warning of possible intervention but also taking steps to support the currency. The Bank of Japan's bond purchases and Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's comments on the yen's attractiveness for companies are at odds with Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki's warnings of intervention. The yen is expected to continue its decline, with some strategists predicting it may fall to 145-155 per dollar, as the yield gap between US and Japanese policy rates widens.

images.alt_text: An employee handles sheets of Japanese 10,000 yen banknotes at the National Printing Bureau Tokyo plant in Tokyo, Japan, on Monday, May 20, 2019. Japan’s unexpected growth spurt on the gross domestic product (GDP) in the first quarter masked weakness in the economy just as policy makers prepare to hike the sales tax in October. Photographer: Akio Kon/Bloomberg

site_title: Architecture’s Gang of Four
summary: Formwerkz Architects, a 23-year-old Singaporean firm, has established itself as a trendsetter in the architecture world through its unconventional designs. The firm's success stems from its approach of engaging deeply with clients, understanding their needs, and creating bespoke projects. The quartet of partners - Alan Tay, Gwen Tan, Berlin Lee, and Seetoh Kum Loon - prioritize meaningful conversations over showcasing past works. Their innovative designs have resulted in awards, including the Singapore Institute of Architects' Architectural Design Awards. The firm has expanded into interior design and experiential design, further solidifying its position in the industry.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang
In good company

site_title: Chinese buyers snap up luxury homes as ‘hard currency’ in soft property market
summary: Chinese luxury home buyers are snapping up properties as a "safe haven" in a weak market. In Shenzhen, 604 luxury units have been presold at up to 162,000 yuan (S$32,541.6) per square meter, valued at up to $9.8 million. Despite a 48% decline in property sales by floor area in August, luxury properties valued at 10 million yuan and above saw a 11% year-over-year increase in the first half of 2022. Wealthy buyers view luxury homes as a stable investment in the struggling market.

site_title: Glenn Goh: Riding the wave of new masculinity
summary: Fashion influencer Glenn Goh is redefining traditional notions of masculinity through his bold fashion choices, often wearing dresses and mixing high-end designer pieces with more affordable alternatives. With over 28,000 followers on Instagram, Goh credits social media for making fashion experimentation more accessible and inspiring a new wave of men to break style norms. He emphasizes the importance of self-expression and authenticity, advising men to find what works for their body type and refine their look over time. Goh's approach to fashion is centered around embracing individuality and having fun with style.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Willabelle Ong in olive green knitted pullover by Hermes.
Genne
Mae Tan

site_title: Building an icon of modern Chinese cuisine
summary: Executive Chinese Chef Edward Chong of Peach Blossoms, a flagship restaurant in Singapore, is redefining modern Chinese cuisine with his unique style. Born as a self-professed delinquent youth from Malaysia, Chong persevered to become a renowned chef, learning from industry stalwarts Sam Leong and Yong Bing Ngen. Under his leadership, Peach Blossoms has gained recognition, including the Rising Chef of the Year Award at the Asian Masters 2019. Chong emphasizes showcasing the finesse and versatility of fine Chinese cuisine, particularly to a younger audience.

images.alt_text: The interiors of Chez Kai are decorated with paintings by its chef.

site_title: Zoom renames chat product, adds features in push to compete with Teams, Slack
summary: Zoom has renamed its chat product to Zoom Team Chat and added features to compete with Microsoft Teams and Slack. The updated app will allow users to share in-meeting chat, schedule meetings from chat or channels, and integrate with third-party services. This move aims to enhance the chat experience and boost its growth in a post-pandemic market where companies are shifting to hybrid work. The update is set to be released by the end of the month.

site_title: Fall fashion favourites
summary: This season's top Fall fashion trends include a return to conservative workwear, bold Lego brights, and minimalist styling. Designers such as Burberry, Valentino, and Marc Jacobs showcased eye-catching colours, while brands like Bottega Veneta, Dior, and Chanel featured plain, unadorned looks. Aviator jackets are also back, with various takes on the classic style. Additionally, full black leather items, traditional tailoring, and classic workwear are key trends worth investing in. Overall, the season's trends reflect a shift towards androgyny and a more minimalist aesthetic.

images.alt_text: Volutes Mystérieuses transformable necklace and earrings with detachable pendants in white and rose gold with diamonds and rubies

site_title: Ant Group rebuilds for regulators, but at what cost?
summary: Ant Group, an affiliate of Alibaba Group Holding, has been gradually rebuilding itself after a year of restructuring under Chinese regulators. The fintech company's consumer lending business has been decoupled from its ubiquitous payments service Alipay and moved into a consumer finance subsidiary, Chongqing Ant Consumer Finance (CACF). As a result, Ant's valuation has tumbled from its 2020 peak. The company's earnings and revenue have also been impacted, with its net profit dropping 17.3% year-on-year and 48.9% quarter-over-quarter. Ant plans to separate its finance business into four main areas, including finance, internet, technology, and overseas, to satisfy regulators while maintaining growth. The company has also made internal changes to improve its corporate governance and continues to explore new growth points outside of China.

images.alt_text: James Dong took the reins of Alibaba’s most important international business unit in June after heading Lazada’s Thailand and Vietnam operations.

site_title: Wine Pinnacle Awards – Celebrating the world’s greatest wines
summary: The Wine Pinnacle Awards returns for its second edition at Resorts World Sentosa, celebrating the world's greatest wines with a new and refreshed program. The 5-day event, from Oct 28 to Nov 1, features 52 nominees across 18 categories, judged by a panel of 61 international experts, including Jeannie Cho Lee, the first Asian Master of Wine. The awards include new categories such as 'Comfort Wines' and 'Pandemic Hero', and will feature wine-pairing dinners, masterclasses, and a wine industry symposium.

images.alt_text: A variety of Beaujolais in New York, Sept. 12, 2022. A number of terrific wines from the region are available now and range from the simple thirst-quenchers of old to the surprisingly complex. (Tony Cenicola/The New York Times)

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Sembcorp may be impacted by the UK's energy price cap, the company has stated it is monitoring the situation. In Singapore, the number of condominium resale deals fell for the fourth consecutive month in August. DBS has set sector-specific decarbonisation targets, including a 28% emissions cut for the oil and gas sector. The Singapore government spent S$72.3 billion on Covid-19 in FY2020 and FY2021, less than the budgeted S$100 billion. The Straits Times Index rose 0.5% on Tuesday, following a US bear market rally.

site_title: Indonesia considering buying Russian oil as fuel prices soar: FT
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo is considering buying Russian oil to offset rising energy costs, amid fuel price hikes and inflation. A 30% increase in subsidized fuel prices earlier this month sparked protests, and the country's state-owned oil company, Pertamina, is reviewing the risks of purchasing Russian crude. Any move to buy Russian oil above the G7 cap could subject Indonesia to US sanctions. This decision comes as Indonesia's annual inflation rate of 4.69% exceeds the central bank's target range for a third straight month.

images.alt_text: Indonesia state-owned Pertamina launched a refinery development master plan that seeks to revitalize five of its major refineries by increasing their capacities and product slate while improving product emissions standards and reducing the country’s dependence on foreign imports.
“Please don’t think we will be aggressive like the Fed,” central bank governor Perry Warjiyo said.
South-east Asia's favourable climate and fertile soil make it a major crop grower. The region is home to key producers of  palm oil, rice and dried beans.

site_title: Crypto traders hedge against Ether disappointment ahead of Merge
summary: Crypto traders are increasing short positions on Ether ahead of the Merge, a highly anticipated upgrade to the Ethereum blockchain. The short interest is seen as a hedge against potential disappointment, as the funding rates for Ether perpetual futures contracts have become sharply negative. This means short traders are paying expensive fees to keep their positions open. Some traders expect the Merge to be a "sell-the-news" event, where the price falls after the upgrade is announced, due to the Ethereum price having already surged in the past year.

images.alt_text: The hotly-anticipated Merge, expected around Sep 15, will transition Ethereum to a more energy efficient network.
Developers have spent years working on a more energy-efficient version of the ethereum blockchain.

site_title: Japan liquor businesses turn to non-alcoholic drinks to attract Gen Z
summary: Japan's liquor businesses are turning to non-alcoholic drinks to attract Gen Z, as the country faces a steady decline in revenue from alcohol sales. The global market value of low- and non-alcoholic drinks rose to $10 billion in 2021, driven by the pandemic's increased health consciousness. Japanese drinks makers are introducing new products, such as mocktails and non-alcohol wine, to cater to younger generations. This shift is also driven by Japan's shrinking older population, which tends to drink more.

images.alt_text: A non-alcohol "beer garden" is pictured in Tokyo, Japan August 26, 2022. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon
Brewers in Japan have struggled to arrest a decline in alcohol sales due to more health-conscious consumers, an ageing society and changing tastes among the young.

site_title: Q2 results underscore resilience of Singapore listcos
summary: Singapore-listed companies, or listcos, demonstrated resilience in the second quarter despite global economic concerns. Nearly 70% of the 61 profitable listcos reported improvements from the previous year, with 25 companies posting higher profits and 16 reversing into the black. Combined group profits rose 24% year-over-year to SGD 6.7 billion. Technology companies, such as UMS Holdings and Venture Corporation, outperformed expectations, while real estate investment trusts (Reits) like CapitaLand China Trust and EC World Reit faced challenges due to China's zero-Covid policy.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan

UMS said all of its core business segments - semiconductors, aerospace and others comprising water-treatment solutions and trading of non-ferrous metal alloys and cutting tools - continued to report sterling results.
DBS believes SIA is poised for growth on the back of tourism recovery.

site_title: Independent directors: Under pressure to protect minorities
summary: Independent directors are under pressure to protect minority investors' interests as companies navigate economic storms. They face challenges in championing minority interests due to the influence of institutional shareholders and management. A former independent director warned that directors should carefully assess the company's management and controlling shareholders before joining the board. Independent directors must stand up to executives and ensure proposed changes support the company's long-term survivability and sustainability. They also need to be aware of complex regulatory changes and keep up with market developments to protect a broader swathe of stakeholders.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
ESG data currently is far less available than financial data, which can be accessed through databases providers such as Bloomberg.
Both Incredible Holdings and Watches.com acquired stakes in HB 2021, a Danish watch retailer with a store in Copenhagen.
The offer price is lower than Zico Capital’s estimated value range of between S$0.37 and S$0.46.
Acra will be proposing amendments to the compulsory acquisition framework.

Extra care should be taken when  implementing ESG-based executive compensation or it can result in distorted incentives, prioritizing the  pursuit and performance of certain quantifiable metrics while ignoring the others which may have hard to-quantify dimensions.

site_title: Japan's travel curbs choke off chance for tourism recovery on weak yen
summary: Japan has relaxed its COVID-19 border controls, allowing 50,000 daily visitors to enter the country, but requiring visas for entry. The move comes as the yen has depreciated rapidly, breaching 144 to the US dollar. Despite this, travel bookings have increased, but a true tourism recovery is delayed due to visa requirements. Industry experts say Japan needs to ease visa restrictions to capitalize on the weak yen and recover its tourism industry.

images.alt_text: Japan’s currency has slumped 20 per cent this year and edged past its previous worst annual drawdown in 1979.

site_title: Xi to leave China for first time since Covid pandemic to meet Putin
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping will meet Russian President Vladimir Putin in Uzbekistan on September 14, marking his first trip abroad since the COVID-19 pandemic. The trip comes as Xi is poised to cement his position as China's most powerful leader since Mao Zedong and ahead of a Communist Party congress where he is expected to secure a third leadership term. The meeting will deepen the "no limits" partnership between China and Russia, with trade between the two nations soaring by nearly a third in the first 7 months of 2022.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Russian President Vladimir Putin and Chinese President Xi Jinping toast during a visit to the Far East Street exhibition on the sidelines of the Eastern Economic Forum in Vladivostok, Russia September 11, 2018. Sergei Bobylev/TASS Host Photo Agency/Pool via REUTERS/File Photo

Chinese President Xi Jinping is widely expected to break with precedent at the congress that starts on Oct 16 and secure a third 5-year leadership term, cementing his status as China’s most powerful leader since Mao Zedong, founder of the People’s Republic.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 10.12 points lower to 1,487.84 on Tuesday, with 2.640 billion lots traded at RM1.738 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 450 to 351, marking a lower session.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on tech, financials boost; Link soars over 8%
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.4% to 6,756 points on Thursday, driven by gains in tech and financial stocks. Link Administration surged 8.1% after receiving regulatory approval for a buyout, while domestic tech stocks rose 2.3% and financials 0.5%. Energy stocks fell 4.5% as oil prices slumped. The benchmark ended 1.4% lower on Wednesday.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index ended 1.4 per cent weaker at 6,729.3, its lowest closing level since Jul 19.

site_title: Crypto trading firm Amber cut as much as 10% of its staff
summary: Cryptocurrency trading firm Amber Group has cut up to 10% of its staff due to an overall market downturn. The Singapore-based company, co-founded by Tiantian Kullander, is seeking to fill 18 positions across its US, Singapore, Hong Kong, and UK locations. Kullander stated that the company reduces lower-priority roles and increases higher-priority positions amid market conditions. This move follows Amber's efforts to raise funding, which were initiated as recently as May.

images.alt_text: Crypto firm Amber gets Temasek funding at US$3b valuation

site_title: Why markets are swinging so much on economic news
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's speech at the Jackson Hole Economic Policy Symposium has sent markets swinging, with the S&P 500 falling over 5% and Nasdaq falling 7% in the three trading days following the speech. The Fed is committed to controlling inflation, which may require sustained below-trend growth, softer labor market conditions, and some pain to households and businesses. The bond market has already priced in a certain future expectation, with Treasury yields above 3.5%, and investors are focusing on quality and dividend stocks to weather economic weakness.

images.alt_text: S&P 500 faces increased volatility due to Fed signals, US midterm polls

site_title: Asia: Stocks, currencies fall as strong data fans hawkish Fed bets
summary: Asian stocks fell as investors reacted to strong US economic data, which fueled expectations of a hawkish Federal Reserve and a surge in US bond yields. The US 10-year treasury yield rose to 3.365%, the highest since June 16. Asian currencies, including the Japanese yen and Chinese yuan, tumbled against the dollar. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index dropped 1.5% and Japan's Nikkei average fell 1.12%. Investors shifted to high-grade bonds to gain cash flow from coupons, and shares in Hong Kong and Australia fell.

images.alt_text: Markets fluctuated between gains and losses, with Hong Kong, Seoul and Wellington down, while Shanghai, Sydney, Singapore, Taipei and Jakarta edged up on Tuesday.

site_title: No Signboard files application to subject OCBC to moratorium terms
summary: No Signboard Holdings has filed an application with the Singapore High Court to subject OCBC to moratorium terms, preventing the bank from initiating legal proceedings against the company. The move comes as No Signboard and OCBC have failed to agree on the terms of repayment of a S$3 million outstanding loan. The company believes it won't have sufficient funds to make monthly repayments until it completes an agreement with potential investor Gazelle Ventures, currently underway. Trading in No Signboard shares remains suspended.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

site_title: The Best of Fashion and Gems
summary: Van Cleef & Arpels showcases its expertise in couture and diamonds with its latest high jewellery collection, "Legend of Diamonds – 25 Mystery Set Jewels." The 25 creations, launched in July, feature 67 diamonds cut from a massive 910-carat rough diamond, with intricate designs that blend fashion and luxury. The collection includes transformable necklaces, earrings, and rings, such as the "Volutes Mystérieuses" necklace and the "Duo Mystérieux" ring, which demonstrate the maison's innovative use of precious stones and materials. The collection's pièce de résistance is the "Vagues Étincelantes" necklace, inspired by Renaissance-era collars.

images.alt_text: Duo Mystérieux Between the Finger Ring. White gold, two emerald-cut DFL Type 2A diamonds of 2.10 and 2.10 carats, buff-topped Traditional Mystery Set rubies, pink sapphires, diamonds.
